description:
I've been wanting to try this restau for awhile now.  Since school was starting, I thought we'd take the family out for one at hurrah to finish off the summer.

We made a reso for the 1st seating on Saturday at 5:30.  We checked the traffic coming from the East Bay and planned accordingly.

We arrived about 15 minutes early.  We weren't sure where the valet was.  It wasn't set up yet. Apparently it's on Stuart at the corner of Stuart and Market.  There's a sign.

We were immediately greeted by the host.  Since we were early we were asked to hang out at the bar / lounge until dinner service was ready.

While we waiting Lilianna, also our server, helped us take a family picure by the front entrance.  

We were seated with the best seat in the house.  It had a spacious view of the whole restaurant, looking towards the outside with views of the Pier and the city life.  

We frequent Blvd down the street.  Their menu is similar.  However the ambiance at One Market is more open and don't feel so dark and squished inside. 

We came at a great time as they are a farm to table restaurant and rotate their menu items based on what a in season.  

Lilliana gave excellent recommendations and we obliged.  

We ordered:

Apps to start...

Heirloom tomato salad with burrata-  Super ripe, creamy cheese

Grilled octopus with a curry lentil salad-  Tender octopus slow cooked for 4 hrs, very flavorful lentils worked well with this combo

Fois gras with a strawberry glaze, panzanella-  all the ingredients worked well together and balanced out the richness of the fois gras

Main...

Lobster Mushroom Risotto-  tomato based, rich, creamy and so flavorful.  

Seared sea scallops-  Mine and the DD 's favorite dish

Braised Beef cheeks-  super tender, spinach spaetzel was yummy

Dessert....

Butterscotch pudding - We scraped up every last bit of this 

Chocolate Ganache banana tart- Loved the torches bananas.  DD called is Creme Brulee bananas.

Carrot Cake-  Nothing like I had have before.  Lighter and not heavily sweet like a traditional cake would have with the sour cream frosting 

We had a wonderful experience from beginning to end.  The staff were attentive just enough.  We even enjoyed the piano player who greeted us.

Chef Michael came out to say hello.  He and Hubs are IG followers.
author: Winnie L.

description:
My boyfriend and I visited One Market last night for his birthday celebration, and, unfortunately, we were very underwhelmed. The staff was friendly, but service was pretty slow and the atmosphere was forgettable. Unfortunately, the food didn't make the experience any better. 

We ordered the following: 
- Grilled octopus: The octopus itself was good. Well flavored and cooked well, but I didn't care for the flavor combination of the cucumber salad, which added a pretty unwelcome bitterness. 
- Hawaiian Kampachi Crudo: This was my personal favorite dish, though it seemed to be something that you could get at any sushi restaurant. Tasted good, but nothing to write home about. 
- Acorn quash soup: A little heavy handed on the cumin for me, but my boyfriend enjoyed it.
- Oysters: Seemed fresh, and the vinaigrette they had on the side was a welcome combo.  
- Lobster mushroom risotto: Honestly, this tasted like a cheese pizza on top of rice. The tomato flavor was so overpowering that you could barely tell it was a mushroom risotto. I was especially disappointed with this one.
- Pan-seared scallops: These tasted fresh and were flavored decently, but it only came with two. For the price, I would have expected more than two scallops and should hardly be considered an entree. 
- Sautéed spinach with garlic chips: This could have been easily replicated at home, and was definitely not worth $9. 
- Fried green tomatoes: Again, these were just fine. Nothing special. 
- Creme brûlée duo and butterscotch pudding: Dessert was the best part of the meal. Both the vanilla and espresso flavored creme brûlées were quite tasty, though nothing exceptional. The butterscotch pudding was delicious- no complaints on this one. 

Overall, this was a very forgettable evening, which is very disappointing when you come for a special celebration. Our bill came to just over $230, and the overall experience did not make it worth the money. This feels like a great restaurant to bring the out of town work colleague that you want to impress, but not a place to go if you want to have an overall great experience that makes the bill worth it. Very disappointed :(
author: Beth H.

description:
Prices:  San Francisco prices.

Service:  A little slow.  You have to flag them down and ask a lot of questions to get what you want.

Menu:  A decent selection but sort of trying too hard.  Everything had weird ingredients that you'd have to Google or was trying to be healthier or more inventive than it was.

Actual food:  Decent.  Just the right portion size.  I liked my trout with slivered almonds and greens.  The sauce, I'm forgetting what it was, was a little sweet for me, but maybe it balanced out the otherwise pretty salty fish.  My mocktail, which I forgot to document, was pretty good.

Reservations:  Recommended.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Brought my gf here for the Chefs table pre-fixed menu for her birthday. You have to call in and they seat you in the back where all the action is!
I highly recommend the pairing option with the wine. Each chef comes to your table and explains each dish and how it was prepared and plated. 
Feel free to feel like a judge on Iron Chef!
Lastly they give you a tour of the Kitchen and take you to their wine cellar where all the reserves and imported wines are kept!
Lastly they get you up and making your own desserts!
I recommend this for an amazing date night or team building. 
Staff and chefs are amazing and very up to date with their culinary skills!
author: Miguel E.

description:
Another great experience at One Market!  This time we sat in the main dining room and had a fabulous time.  Our server was terrific; personable, helpful and proficient.  

They were honoring Women in Wine and offering bottles for 1/2 off.  We enjoyed a lovely Pinot Noir from Theopolis, owned by Theodora R. Lee. Our starters were their Soft Shell Crab crushed carrots, harissa,
nasturtium salsa verde and Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout "Mi Cuit" potato rösti, pancetta vinaigrette, pastured chicken egg. The Trout is one of their specialties that has been on the menu forever and I can see why.  It was amazing!  That could have been my meal:)

For our mains we had their English Cut Double Lamb Chop, fresh corn polenta, green tomato, niçoise olives, marcona almonds and Hot Smoked Wild Salmon chermoula, micro-cilantro.  My fav was the lamb chop with it's accoutrements, which made it absolutely heavenly. For sides, we had sauteed spinach and chickpea fries, which were also exceptional and are now on my list of things to make. So healthy and delish!

Happy to see that after a couple years from our first visit, this restaurant still has what it takes to create an exceptional experience.  Loved it!
author: Kathleen S.

description: 5 stars, from food to atmosphere to fine service. I love this elegant place with the creative menu executions. I went here for a business dinner recently and we had a divine time. You can't go wrong with the cocktails. I was the envy of all at my table with my Envy cocktail. My fish entree melted in my mouth. We all went bonkers with the desserts. And you must not pass up the appetizers - they were my favorite part of the meal!
author: Chanda M.

description:
We came here for SF restaurant week lunch. ($25 for a choice of 1 of 2 apps: 
1) white bean soup with shrimp  - or 
2) an arugula salad with almonds and roasted pears)

Then a choice of 2 mains:
1) trout
2) beef sugo on top of house-made fettuccini

I had the soup and the pasta.

Make sure you get the bread, yummy, served warm with a large portion of sweet butter.

I got the soup (shrimp in the side for my friends to enjoy), it was thick and so hearty I barely had room for my pasta (took most of it home for dinner)  - there was a lemon olive oil drizzled on top which added some depth to the soup.

Wish we had room for dessert (about 4 choices for SF restaurant week at $5, but we were just too full)
author: Amy W.

description:
Came here for restaurant week and I have to say I was pleased. Service here is great. The ambiance was fancy high class. Definitely not for a commoner like me but hey, who cares! 

Lunch $25 for white bean soup and grilled steelhead trout. 
-They first served the shrimp with avocado and cilantro. Then one of the servers come around and pour the white bean soup all over. I thought that was a pretty neat service. The soup itself was pretty good. It didn't taste too beany but it definitely had the consistency. It also went well with the complimentary bread and butter.
-The trout was definitely good. The trout was definitely cooked perfectly. I requested it to be fully cooked so I feel like I got a smaller and flatter piece compared to others. I really liked the sauce that came with it. Creme fraiche? Maybe? IDK it was good. 

Definitely a good place for a business lunch or fancy dinner. If they have restaurant week again, I'll definitely come back.
author: Benita M.

description:
It was delicious!

Came here with a couple of colleagues for lunch. It wasn't my first time at One Market but it had been a while since the last time.

This time around I started with the Butternut Squash & Dungeness Crab Soup. The flavors were very balanced and pleasant and the texture was just right.  

We also shared and order of Chickpea Fries. It was my first time trying this. I must say they were different from any Fries I had tried before, and good!

For my main course I was torn between the Grilled Tombo Tuna Salad and the Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout "Mi Cuit". I opted for the latter and I am glad I did.

The dinning area at One Market is very nice and comfortable and the service is top class.
author: Afshin A.

description: I enjoyed my visit to One Market today. This is clearly a very popular place because I got there a few minutes before it opened but there was no space in the dining room. No worries, I was gonna sit in the bar anyway since I was alone. This is a beautiful restaurant and a great location. I'm already planning a dinner trip here via the Larkspur Ferry. The bartender was very friendly and got me taken care of right away. He brought over some fresh rolls that were AMAZING!  I ordered the chickpea fries and the crab cakes. I'd never had Chickpea fries before but I saw them on "Check Please!" on PBS so I thought I'd try them. They were quite interesting and tasty. I couldn't quite pinpoint the flavor at first but then all of a sudden it hit me. They kind of tasted like hummus which makes perfect sense I guess. The crab cakes were excellent quality. I'm not sure if there was any binding agent at all. It kind of just seemed like little scoops of crab meat. Everything I had was great. The only thing that wasn't perfect (which was my fault not theirs) was that what I wanted to try was not on the lunch menu. Guess I'll have to go back soon.
author: Marcus K.

description: Amazing place. Had Bradley's Caesar salad and steelhead trout for dinner. Wonderful pace to spend time with family.
author: Devan K.

description: Service and food was excellent. I enjoyed the Natural Angus Flat Iron Steak and the BlackBerry Pie. I'd definitely return to try more items!
author: Crystal K.

description:
One Market is one of the early restaurants in San Francisco that were in a class that served sophisticated, higher end dining. The restaurant sits at foot of Market St. and offers a great view of the Ferry Building and the Embarcadero.  There's a bar area in front, the main dining room and a Chef's Table that allow you a view of the kitchen in action as the staff prepares the meals for the diners. One Market debuted in 1993 and recently had a celebration for its 25th anniversary. We were fortunate to secure a dinner reservation for this special celebration.

The restaurant was full for the celebration and after a short wait after checking in, we were seated at a table in the middle of the dining room. Our waiter explained the offerings and took our drink order as we checked out the menu.  

Amuse-bouche - Flounder ceiche on silver spoons
ACME rolls as complementary house bread

Our orders:
Grilled Spanish Octopus in a chorizo puree, avocado chimichurri and parsley. It was delicious, but wished the portion was a little more generous.

Hand-picked Dungeness Crab Salad with miso, citrus, and seaweed. Beautifully plated.  Not a typical salad, in there were no greens. It was a light and refreshing with leg and body crab meat.

Pan-seared Day Boat Scallops on a bed of celery root risotto, spinach and black truffle jus. Three large scallops were perfectly prepared. 

12oz. Creekstone Angus New York Steak in a red wine butter, bearnaise relish. Ordered the steak medium rare, but it came out medium. The steak was tender though. Tasty red wine butter. 
 
Sides: Roasted Mushrooms in thyme and roasted garlic; Roasted Brussels Sprouts with Applewood smoked bacon

Chocolate Cremeux Cake with Earl Grey whipped ganache, blood orange, chocolate sherbert. Beautifully presented. Chocolate lovers will enjoy.

Pear Tarte Tatin with ginger-thyme ice cream, pear caramel, candied pecans. Nicely presented. Not overly sweet 

Our meal was finished with complementary Mignardises of house made candy.

It's been years since I dined at One Market. The food, service and atmosphere is as good as it was when I was last here. It was great to been able to help One Market celebrate its 25th.  Happy Anniversary!
author: Al L.

description:
Come here for happy hour!

1) People watching
2) Drinks
3) Appetizers

Too early for dinner and too hungry to wait that long. Decided to get a drink and some appetizers here to nibble on. It was decent to hold my tummy over, but it wasn't anything great to rave about. Service was so-so.
author: Owie N.

description: Very good service and nice ambience. Foods was very good better than what I expected. Good overall experience. Pork tenderloin and chicken breast is very tender
author: Allen L.

description: Nice setting. I got the ricotta  ravioli which came fast. Service was weird, they seemed out of it
author: Sunil R.

description:
Service and food are great.  Wine list is highly overpriced and narrow.  Really, place needs 600 percent wine bottle price markups to survive?

But the big negative is the manager.  We had a big group dinner.  Dropped almost 2500 dollars on meal.  We sit down and they have less chairs than our reservation number.  We ask for a small table to be added to end so we can comfortably fit our group.  He says impossible because every single table in restaurant is booked tonight.  Blames us for changing our count from 16 to 13.  Says not his fault, and is a total no can do personality.  We then have to do our dinner cramped.  Meanwhile, we watch while three two tops and a five top next to us remain empty the entire night.  And a private room set up for 20 also remains empty all night long.

At end of evening, I find him and ask what happened.  He says literally "I can't control cancellations.  What did you want me to do?  Interrupt your dinner to add table space?"  When I say yes of course, he gruffs and says nothing more he could have done and again is our fault, the customers.  I ask him how many cancellations he had, and he says one two top and one five top.  Ok, so why again wasn't he able to take one of the other two open tables at outset to make group comfortable?  Or give us the set up private room?   His answer is to stick his chin up and walk off.  This guy has no business managing or having direct interface with customers.  Cropped haircut and glasses, in case owner reads this and cares.

But for him, it would have been great.

Notice how "Larry" of restaurant replies to the good reviews, but ignores the true ones.  Should show you all you need to know about this place.  He never once contacted me or anyone in our group for follow up.  Guess he is good with this type of poor experience for a $2,500 bill spend at his place.  Sad.  His picture is a match of the guy I described.  Clearly, he knows truth of what he did and what kind of management he offers you.  Must be why he is silent.
author: Brian A.

description: A great standard spot for business lunch and dinner. Excellent service and food. I love the chickpea fries.
author: Robin B.

description:
Visited One Market for a business related luncheon. Got the private room outside of the restaurant. Venue was very nice. Always great to have a private space for a large party.

Had a three course lunch. Started with a salad which was generous and fresh. A great start. I had the tombo tuna over a warm frisee salad. Good, but the amount of tuna could have been more generous. Others at my table had the steak option and that looked much more generous in serving. Finally the apple cobbler dessert was terrific with a small scoop of ice cream.

Service was solid. Professional and efficient. A strong four star rating which could have been better with a little better serving size on the entree.
author: John C.

description: Lovely old school restaurant. Elegant and wonderful ambiance. If you value great service and linen, great food and easy access take your clients there. Highly recommended
author: Flower P.

description:
Chefs Table was a wonderful experience.
Food courses - large portions too
Strawberry Gazpacho - was ok tasted like liquid strawberries
Soft Shell Crab - very nice balance of acid and sweet
Grilled Spanish Octopus - very good
Olive Oil Poached Alaskan Halibut - melt in your mouth
Pan-seared Day Boat Scallops - large scallop perfectly done
Liberty Farms Duck Breast - rare and good
4 different desserts.  

Selected wine bottles were 1/2 off too.  

Tour of Cellar and restaurant was interesting got to speak to sommelier 
Price is right too.  
Kitchen was a little warmer than rest of restaurant but ok
author: Brandon Y.

description:
Nice restaurant. Fine dining. Man on the piano and good location. 

I had the Caesar salad which was large stocks of lettuce. I then had the Red Snapper which was fresh. The outside had a very nice crisp to it while cooked to perfection inside. I topped it off with a creme brûlée. 

I certainly think it's worth it. I would go again.
author: Marcos O.

description:
Love the service and atmosphere. Bread is all star, food is mediocre. Had grilled octopus, chestnut soup, half chicken, braised lamb shank, and potato tots. Octopus was soft and lost its texture, chestnut soup was good but mushrooms were way too sour, braised lamb shank was overcooked on edges and taste like jerky while inside was soft and not very seasoned, chicken was tasty but raw on the inside. Server was good and bread was great. Fresh, warm, soft and light on inside, crispy on the outside. 

Come here for the bread. Yum
author: Willis Y.

description:
Came here for dinner recently. It was good overall!

As others have noted, it's an upscale-feeling, white tablecloth sort of ambience. They seek to cultivate an upscale feel with the service as well. This aspect of the experience fell a bit short, though, as the servers my group interacted with were pushy with upselling additional items we didn't want and not all that flexible with accommodating our needs. (For example, someone in our group wanted to order dessert after the bill had been brought, which caused more discomfort and confusion than seemed necessary.)

The food was good -- my main course was tasty and was presented nicely -- but it wasn't SO good as to warrant its price tag ($33 for a piece of fish and veggies). The cocktail I ordered was nicely made, but not exceptional.

All in all if you're looking to enjoy an upscale meal downtown/near the Ferry Building, this is a good choice in a great location. If you're looking for an exceptional foodie-type meal, though, there are better options at this price point in SF.
author: Christine G.

description:
One Market is probably our most loved Bay Area restaurant.  Think of them as upscale California cuisine.  The chef works hard to make presentations with fresh ingredients that work well together.  

Unlike many of the places we frequent, we like everything we have.  Our servers help navigate the menu and can explain the entreés.  

Tonight we went a la carte along with one of the new Going Social menu items.  Think happy hour with their new Going Social menu items.  The items are nicely priced prix fixe three course menu where you can choose halibut crudo or a pea soup followed by an olive oil poached salmon or lamb followed by dessert. They also have a good selection of wines that are half off.

We had the halibut crudo and the salmon.  Both the flavor and presentation were superb.  The chef nicely split this for us.  

Our other choice was a collection of appetizers:  the market fresh pea soup from the Social menu; octopus avocado chimichurri and foie gras torchan with rhubarb-strawberry compote.

For dessert we had the dolce cream cheese ice cream bar.  This came on carrot cake with orange gastrigue.

Add to this we took Bart so we could have a really nice discounted bottle of Pinot Noir.

Jackie, our server, was fun, made the evening  special and helped us sequence the meal.  

One Market has a really nice piano player that adds to the ambiance.  

If you want something elegant without being pretentious give them a try.  Alternatively, if you are looking for a coffee shop through the meal out of a can experience  then this won't be your place.
author: Allen S.

description: This place had a really good Thanksgiving menu - really enjoyed the duck liver mousse, agnolotti, pork loin and white chocolate pumpkin cheesecake. The turkey is quite good as well. Service was well paced and all glasses had liquids at all times. It's actually a great value for Thanksgiving and really good location.
author: Andrew S.

description: Had an annual​ LP dinner meeting at the restaurant​ and it was a lovely experience. Great pinot noir it might beat my favorite in Press Club.
author: Christina Y.

description:
Had a chance to have dinner with some work colleagues Thai evening. The One Market staff were very attentive and provided great service. They fulfilled our request to be at a window to look out at the Ferry Terminal and the Bay Bridge and Treasure Island.

The food was outstanding! We had the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin and the lamb. Everything was very tasty.
author: Bill G.

description:
This is a go to stop for dinner with co-workers or clients.  The night we went the service was spot on and the Brussels sprouts were raved about along with the pork tenderloin & grilled octopus .

The miss!! Halibut. 

How you may ask?!?! It was smothered in EVERYTHING

It literally says everything but when I got my dinner it was overwhelming.  Firstly I couldn't even see the filet and then when I took my first bite...
Wow; too much going on! The fish is a delicate and lite fish but this was like eating meatloaf.  I only ate half and was totally ready to go home and make a steamed halibut filet with a nice Beurre Blanc sauce to whip the slate clean!

Again - this place is a go to but this new fish was a huge miss
author: Aaron H.

description:
Terrible server, rude, classless & unprofessional.
Food so so, definitely not worth the overpriced menu.  They ran out of Titos, scallops, & fish. There was no apology from the server or recommendations for a substitute.
Tuna meal was gross covered in anchovies - it was NOT edible. Specially aged beef was mostly fat again not edible.  Is the chef even checking or tasting the food they put out?   

Not once did the server ask if everything was ok.

What a Royal jerk- if you're unhappy in your job don't project your negative attitude towards the paying customer.
Will NOT be back.
author: Simone C.

description: Lunch visit. Coffee: perfect. Cobb salad: perfect (the bacon was still sizzling). The service: impeccable. I was sitting at the bar, and Thomas noticed I drank my coffee left handed and set my silverware up accordingly. Wow. What a great experience.
author: micah v.

description:
Great service and decent food, but nothing particularly spectacular about it / I don't feel the need to ever go back again.

Venue / Service: came here for a business dinner with my boss and clients.  Slightly dim inside (from the dark walls, contrasted by white tablecloths, and little light inside) but thankfully could read our menus since we sat near a window while it was bright outside.  Service was good, perhaps slightly better than normal since my boss knew the chef and so he frequently came over and checked in to see if we liked our dishes.

Food:
- Hors d'oeuvres - each person got 4 bites before our dishes came out (ours included a baked potato with creme fraiche, a corn fritter, shrimp with cream foam, and tuna with cucumber).  These bites were actually quite tasty, though I wish they would have told us if there was any particular order to eat them in
- Corn soup (ramp pesto, bay shrimp, pickled fresno chile)($14) - great corn flavor, with some herbal lightness from the ramps and a bit of heat from the chile.  The shrimp somewhat seemed out of place, even if it added a bit of texture to the rich soup.  Also, this portion is HUGE and so, especially since this was rather creamy and rich, was a bit of an overkill portion-wise.
- Pan seared day boat scallops (~$28) - again, this was a rather big portion, partially because the scallops were massive; I only finished half the plate.  At least, however, they were not overcooked (one of mine looked like it was on the border of being under, but I'll take that vs. over).  Wasn't crazy about the foam fru-fru- it added no texture and it had weak flavor.  

Wasn't particularly blown away by my meal size-wise and flavor-wise.  I know this is a staple for business dinners in FiDi, but I'd rather take my client somewhere else for better food for the price I pay.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Food is amazing. Well priced and very tasty. Happy hour prices are beyond generous and well worth it.
Great view & wonderful ambience.
author: Andria F.

description:
Dinner Saturday night 8:30 reservation 
All good. Have not been in several years, very good dinner all around, food, service, ambiance, hospitality. Appreciated the live music with pianist.
Half of list of good selection of wines and $45 menu option all helped with the bottom line.They are celebrating 25 years
Family dinner and we had a first class meal.
author: Paul S.

description: Lousy service. We were the first reservation at 5:30 pm when it opened. Waitress forgot my beer order. Halibut arrived lukewarm - obviously been sitting on kitchen counter getting cool. We struggled to get out of there in 2 and 1/2 hours. The food was not worth it
author: Kathee S.

description:
The food is average. Everything for our party was under cooked.
Nothing special about the décor and the service is slow and often impossible to obtain when needed. I equate this to Uber drivers or Amazon delivery service.
We won't be back nor will our team.
author: J M.

description: Great service from the start.  Very attentive team of waiters and waitresses.  Had oysters, Spanish Octopus (amazing flavor), the scallops (also a great combination of complimentary flavors and textures) and wrapped it up with a Toffee Almond cake.  Excellent meal.
author: Chris M.

description: They must have a new chef.  I've eaten there several times and it was always good.  This time I ordered smoked trout for an appetizer -they brought a plate containing a large round pink raw fish - topped by an egg and on top of a potato pancake.  I ate the egg and pancake,  The main course was to be grilled trout - it came with slices of raw fish, the outside of which had been cooked and coated heavily in black pepper corns.  I gave both raw fish to my dining buddy and filled up on lemon cheesecake.   Doubt if I'll be back.
author: Peter C.

description:
Very strange dining experience. Was here with a large private party of 5 tables in a private room. Our table watched the whole night our wait staff service just one of our groups tables and completely ignored the others. It was like we were watching a show of this one particular table enjoying their dining experience while we were all forgotten and ignored. The wait staff were aggressive and rude when we even dared to ask them for anything. Especially the short, bald server. When we asked for bread, his response was "you need to wait".   Like I said, it was a very strange experience. 
The food on the other hand was this places saving grace. I had a delish octopus app with chorizo sauce and day boat scallops for entree, both done very well. Will we come back? No. Too many other beautiful SF restaurants with better, friendly service.
author: Loren M.

description: This place is massive and I've always walked by it, decided to go one night and I thought it was just average. The food wasn't great quality but the service was good. It's typically very busy so a reservation is recommended. Nothing fancy about the ambiance, and overall just an average experience.
author: Carol Ann V.

description: I had a wonderful time at One Market. To start out with the wait staff was very attentive. He also presented all of the specials and described in detail all of the dishes we asked about, not having been there before. I had the duck and it was well cooked and very tasted! A nice place to go on a date or a work event like mine was.
author: Robert E.

description: Had a great meal with a bunch of friends. Can't remember one negative comment or slip up.  Service, food, and relaxed atmosphere all top notch.
author: jack q.

description:
Very good place near the port. I came back from Oakland and I have a good appetite : I ate west oysters, a beautiful beef piece and I drank a good wine after tasting more than two glasses of Chardonnay. The sommelier is a woman and I think we have a good conversations about the wine taste and for not being pretentious, I had given her some good knowledges about wine.
It was on St-Patrick's day and I spent a time with a friendly family face to my table, there were very happy and touched me. It was a good dinner and very warmly.
author: Marie-Claire L.

description: Amazing dinner last night.   We booked the "chef's table" - what an outstanding way to spend an evening!   See photo of menu and dishes.   A full evenings entertainment, wonderful dishes and a behind the scenes tour of the restaurant, while sitting in the "kitchen table" for our several course dinner.   A highly recommended experience.   The Chef, our waiter, and our Somm all took wonderful care of us!
author: Mr. R.

description:
This review is in response to a private event we had at One Market.

We arranged to have a make-shift wedding reception at One Market. It was a five-hour event that included a cocktail hour and full dinner meal. We had no idea what to expect going in as we had never even been to the restaurant, and we were *pleasantly* surprised.

The cocktail hour was a perfect setup right outside One Market's Wine and Wall room. The dinner was delicious, the dessert was delicious, and the table setups were perfect. One Market was extremely accommodating, and their staff was nothing but pleasant. Everyone certainly made us feel welcome, and everyone had a smile on their face whenever we spoke during the event. All of our guests were complimenting us on the food, and it was all just so perfect.

Serena, the Event Manager, was on site for the Saturday event, and made sure everything was to our liking. We couldn't have asked for a better reception, and our family couldn't stop talking about how nice everything was.

10/10 would book them again. Not a single complaint.
author: Joseph G.

description: I came in on a Wednesday night and the bar side was packed so I ended up sitting in the dining room. The kitchen served me two small bites of a tuna tartare with roe on top. They were very creamy and delicious. My pallet was certainly warmed up. I ordered the Swordfish since it is my favorite fish and the tater tots. The tots are more like deep fried potato wedges. They are served with a curry ketchup. Crunchy on the outside and light and fluffy in the center. The Swordfish was finished on the grill and you could taste the grill char flavor throughout it. It was perfectly cooked, not dry or overdone. Beautiful tasting fish to enjoy for dinner. The restaurant sits close to the water and has a great view. I enjoyed this spot and would like to come for a happy hour as they have a great cocktail list.
author: Megan H.

description: Michelin chef... Enough said.  Great service great view, great atmosphere. My wife had the prime rib, I had the halibut and was cooked to perfection. Sides were the cream spinach and creamy mashed potatoes. Melts in your mouth.   On top of that, the prices are extremely reasonable considering everything.
author: Jay S.

description:
I was really surprised that we were able to get a last minute reservation on a Saturday evening for this place! This place is in a prime location across from Embarcadero. The staff are great here. Everyone had a smile on their face and no pretentious 'tude that you get from some of these fancy places. 

The food was pretty tasty here. Can't go wrong with any of their seafood dishes. We also really enjoyed their chickpea fries. Mmm yummy!!
author: Cindy K.

description: Painfully slow service in a half full restaurant. They had more hostesses then servers. Duck was awful, chewy and no flavor. Portions were tiny and prices sky high. Drinks were good.
author: Smiley S.

description:
The worst experience at a restaurant.  Second time they gave me gluten food with explicit directions for gluten free and explanation of allergies.  2/2 times of negligence in eating here in six months.

They have nothing labeled, no care and awful service where the servers don't even understand gluten free vs vegan. This place is a health hazard and I was sick for one month after.
author: CA R.

description:
Overall a very nice place, and very good value (even more so when judging its value on "the major city cost curve", of course). I am sooooo close to calling our meal 5 stars. I guess the couple of nitpicks I have are (1.) Very nice servers, though it would have nice if they were maybe just a tiny bit more attentive. And, (2.) I hate to say it but the meal was just the tiniest bit bland (I had the gnocchi). Not jarringly so, just...a bit uninspired, flavor wise. Especially for a place I'd heard such great things about.

Next time I'm in town, I'll plan to go back one more time & see if that 5th star should be there. Stay tuned!
author: Rich G.

description:
Came in pretty skeptical about the vegetarian choices in a stake place. To my surprise they had options for sure.
They had the Beet Scampi, Melon Salad for starters.

The entree was the place they got me! Dejected in asked the waiter for my options and he suggested the gnocchi. I asked for it to be spicy and it was cooked to perfection, so much that it was one of the best gnocchi I've eaten in a long time.

Now to desert, instead the crunchy chocolate cake and was really nice in combination with the Ice cream.

All in all One Market was a surprise home run in my view. Definitely worth a repeat !!
author: Neeraj S.

description:
A vendor picked One Market Restaurant for a lunch meeting so I landed up here a couple of days ago. It was good that they had made reservations as there is only a small section open during lunch which was packed with a 30 minute wait for walk-ins.

One Market Restaurant is your typical run of the mill white table cloth restaurant serving American cuisine. What struck me was it was not as noisy as the more modern places offering fancy small plates, so I would categorize this as more old school elegant. We were quickly seated and offered menus. Our server was back after a couple of minutes and started to push us to get drinks. Suggestions are fine but she was really pushy. Most of us did not want to do drinks as we had to get back to work so we settled on moktails instead. Even here she would not let up and started pushing people who got the Arnold Palmer to get the mint version instead. One of the weak among us succumbed, but I got a mocktail ($5) whose name I do not recollect.

After the drinks, our server made it her mission in life to get us to order appetizers. She tried to push some off menu crab cakes. By now most people in the group had sensed that this was not a normal server but one on a mission. A mission to ensure an order - drinks, appetizers, salad, mains, desert which frankly we did not want. We told her clearly that we did not want appetizers and sent her on her way. However she had not received the memo about this being a business meeting so she kept interrupting us and it made having a conversation really tough. When she was back to take the order for our mains she tried to palm the daily special on us. Again none of us wanted that. I decided to get the Natural Angus Flat Iron Steak ($24) and made the mistake of asking her if this could be pared with a salad. The only thing I heard from her response was that I could get either a Caesars salad or a grain based salad. As I am not a fan of just eating overpriced lettuce, I asked her what type of grain is present in the grain salad. I figured this is downtown so they may have a fancy couscous or chickpea salad. On hearing this she actually poked fun at me and finally someone interpreted that she was saying green salad. I decided to get that, I don't know if it was charged as a side or a main, but considering the fancy nature of this place I feel it would most probably be full priced.

The food did take some time to come out, but it was nice as it did give us some time to catch up on the main agenda for the meeting. When the food arrived, the gentlemen sitting directly opposite me was shocked that he got a burger when he had actually ordered the flat iron steak like me. The only difference was that he wanted it medium and I wanted it medium rare. This meant that we had to deal with the pushy server again. He joked that as I had got my correct order he should start speaking in an Indian accent as his straight forward mid-western accent was not good enough in San Francisco. I feel you brother. I go through this every day. Each time that I order, I don't know if I will get what I've asked for or a random dish that the server feels that I asked for. So welcome to the problem faced by the other 50%. Anyway the server got him his replacement, but not without taking her shot - "Wouldn't everyone be happy if they got their food so quick?" Seriously? This was one of the worst servers that I have dealt with. She made this entire dining experience really bad. She personified the stereotype. One that has no concept of service, is only interested in pushing a lot of crap on you so that it increases the bill and hence her tip.

Anyway let's come to the food. The mock-tail was really bad. Its description mentioned that it would have ginger so I was expecting a little ginger but what a got was a drink with a huge amount of chopped ginger. Each sip resulted in a couple of pieces that had to be spat out. Just gross. The flat iron steak was average at best. It wasn't the best piece of meat (which was expected) but it just did not come together well with the mashed potatoes and jus. The green salad was pretty good. Its dressing was like an oil vinaigrette which was nicely tossed into the salad. Everything considered this was like a below average meal. A colleagues who got the Mushroom Stroganoff ($25) reported that the pasta was soft and mushy and over sauced. Goes without saying that he did not like what he ate. The colleague who got the mint version of the Arnold Palmer reported that he should have stuck to the plain version.

Price wise it was in line with what you would pay in any other formal dining setup (Entrees around $25). The food was mediocre at best. The service was just plain horrible. Overall, forget about being impressed this was a depressing dining experience. We barely managed to get our business discussed with all the drama with our server, while eating overpriced average food. I would rather go to a Chipotle rather can come back here again.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
This place deserves a 3.5 in my book.    I wish Yelp would change their rating system to be 1 through 10.   
Came here with friends for dinner.    We started off with the foie gras.    What a delicious treat.    Then we had their signature dish of pork wrapped in bacon and a steak.     The pork wrapped in bacon had too much of a bacon flavor for my taste.   The steak well cooked as medium rare and delicious.    The chick peas fries a disappointment as they were very greasy.    Wine choice very good but expensive as you would expect in SFO.  Probably won't return because there are so many options in SFO for good restaurants.   Came on the advice of the hotel concierge.
author: John M.

description:
Solid restaurant - maybe closer to a 4 star.  I'll let you judge for yourself.  Prices are a bit high and our server was a little snooty.  That's why I shaded to a 3-star.

Most memorable item I had? - the house made tater tots - AWESOME!  Why don't more restaurants do this? it can't be that difficult.  Way oversize tater tots made with fresh potatoes that were crispy on the outside and tender on the inside.  Talk about finger licking good.  It's worth coming back just to order those again.  A nice change from the usual choices of either roasted/mashed/baked potatoes.

I wanted to try the brisket which they brag about on their menu - but it was not available that evening.  Instead I had the roasted chicken, which was nicely prepared and juicy.  Other folks at my table had steak, roasted fish etc. and all seemed fine.

I had been avoiding this place for years because of the spotty reviews.  But now I am more of a convert.  I will be back to try more items.  And hope for a more friendly server.
author: Lewis C.

description: The food is always good here.  It should be - it's not cheap.  The service is always good.  This time, I ordered chicken.  It was very good.  I took the leg and thigh home for lunch because I couldn't finish it...It was raw... I don't expect this when the dish is $20 without sides. My friend got the pork; he asked that it not be pink.  The waitress said that's how they like to cook it, he said he doesn't like pink pork.  It came pink...he didn't send it back and said it was good.   Also had to order additional sides.    So....there are too many great restaurants in SF....I won't be going back.  The funny thing is, when you look at the reviews, no one from the restaurant responds.  Clearly don't care what you think!
author: sue r.

description:
Came here for dinner and loved the hospitality. The salmon and asparagus were beautifully done- great texture too. Definitely would come back. 

Perfect for business meetings as well. 

Well deserved five stars!
author: Rani M.

description:
Came here for my boyfriend's company dinner. 

The food was pretty good and it was an entertaining evening, to say the least. 

There was a steak with jalapeño grits that I just couldn't get enough of and I wished there was more. 

Also, they served a duck breast with sauerkraut... The duck was super delicious with a soft inside and a crispy skin on the outside! It was so good that I deducted one star because they took my dish away when I wasn't finished yet, as I would've eliminated that dish. No question to it.
author: Karen B.

description:
This restaurant definitely had the old school, upscale feel of the Financial District. They have live piano music a noticeably older crowd. The restaurant itself is beautiful - a big space, lots of seating, and a wide open atmosphere.

I came here for Restaurant Week. At first, I was worried that the food would be in smaller portions and of lesser quality with the special tasting menu, but I could not have been more wrong! Service was impeccable and I left the restaurant feeling completely full and content! For $40 prix fixe, you get more than your moneys worth. I would not recommend getting the wine pairings, which will cost you another $20+ for two average wines that were just alright - one red and one white. 

Some thoughts on the meal:

The artichoke soup came with a garlic flan, which added more texture and flavor. It was tasty, but I didn't get enough artichoke flavor as I would have expected. If I took my first sip blind folded, I wouldn't have been able to tell what kind of soup I was tasting! 

I had never had lamb's tongue before, but I was pleasantly surprised. It was thinly sliced and tasted like a less salty, lighter version of prosciutto. 

The entrees were both delicious and came out fresh and hot out of the pan. The Petrale sole came with a sweet foam broth that was great with the fish. Similarly, the pork chop was just the right amount of sweet and savory. Both entrees came in a healthy portion and were very tasty despite not being on the normal restaurant menu.

If you are choosing between the two dessert options, the apple crumb tart is definitely a safer choice. It's basically a mini apple pie with vanilla bean ice cream. The presentation is beautiful and the dessert is warm, crunchy, and gooey - perfect for a rainy day! The tropical sorbet Bombe is for the fruity dessert lovers. It does not like like your typical Bombe as it comes out as a cube...but the presentation is still beautiful. I was already so full after the first two courses so I was struggling to finish this one. Still absolutely delicious and tart, and I particularly enjoyed the almond tuile with the sorbet and fresh fruit. 

Was impressed with this meal and would come back to try the normal menu items!
author: Sarah N.

description: Stopped by for a happy hour drink at the bar with some coworkers. It's a nice place, with happy hour. I didn't have food. Would come back for drinks, it's a convenient location.
author: Marie D.

description: The service here is always fantastic. I come here for monthly lunches and they are very consistent, which is why I'm giving this review 5/5. I've tried their Farmers Market Salad, Pan-seared Gulf Flounder, Natural Angus Flat Iron Steak and various desserts like the Valrhona "Black Forest" and the Market Fruit Sorbet. I am always satisfied with what they serve. You definitely can't go wrong with anything on the menu!
author: Dianna O.

description: I have been coming to this restaurant for a few years now. Food is great and so is the ambiance. This place is always bustling and it's important to make reservations on advance especially during lunch. This time I ordered the Dungeness crab cakes and they were excellent.  Apparently they are fresh caught daily. The pan seared flounder with the carrot curry emulsion hit the spot, it was just right and perfect. We will be back.
author: Wasif I.

description:
We came in before the theater on a Tuesday. Service was good. Knowledgeable waitstaff were keen to explain the menu and share perspective. 

I ordered the Duck leg and confit with cherries and hazelnuts and Oh Em Gee! So delicious. Chef plates food as though it were art. And whatever magic they use to create the olive rolls--delectable sorcery at its finest.  

If you are less adventurous, as is my hubby, the steak is also a tasty choice. 

Not cheap, but not outrageous. I will definitely return :)
author: Gemma C.

description: Larry Bouchard, manager at One Market, read my Yelp review and promptly called me to rectify the situation.  The server who calculated the tip on our bill did it incorrectly.  He should have based it on food and drinks only and Larry refunded the difference.  He also mailed me a $100 gift certificate by way of apology for the poor service.  I appreciate the fact that One Market takes customer reviews seriously and reaches out.  I'll give it another go and look forward to sharing my experience.
author: Dana B.

description: Came for dinner with coworkers one night after work. Place was packed! Vibe feels very corporate (lots of suits) but food was pretty good. Nothing was stellar but everything was tasty!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Dang! Bada Bing! BOOM! Great food,stellar wine selection. Worth the cost. Fresh octopus, scallops, new york strip - out of this world. Coming back? No doubt!

Well worth it at the end of the meal, even though your wallet may feel it! Special occassion - dont doubt it, do it!
author: Kevin K.

description:
While I admit the food was delicious, our New Year's Eve experience did not meet my family's expectations. We felt rushed even though we were staying for 3 hours until midnight. They also ran out of party favors which is ridiculous since they should have known how many people made reservations. They also advertised the ability to watch fireworks to be higher than usual - everyone had to crowd around a few doors/windows, so really the majority couldn't even see them that well.

Food wise though, like I said, it was quite good. The Amuse bouche was a cheese/caviar dish that was in an egg shell - cute and delicious. The first courses that stood out to us were the ahi tuna tartare and the wild trout 'mi cuit'. For the second course, the scallops were good and I had the bison on jalapeño grits which was delicious. The beef shoulder was good but not our favorite. We ended with a pear crumble and chocolate cake which was nice but like I said, we were rushed so our meal was timed abnormally. Good restaurant but not worth the amount of money we spent for the NYE meal.
author: Margaret K.

description: Went for lunch on a weekday and had their daily special beef brisket. It was the best slow-cooked brisket I've had in a long time: moist and succulent, very satisfying. Came with a bowl of slaw, pickles, and bbq sauce/gravy. The tomato bisque was also quite appetizing with just a hint of spiciness. But one of my dining companions felt his market lunch pork belly was overcooked and dry on both sides. That aside, I felt my experience here was quite positive, and The Manhattan I had probably helped with that too. Lol
author: Ger T.

description: Wish my $45 medium well NY steak wasn't burned well done, but my sides were delicious.  I probably should have sent it back but took forever to come out in the first place.
author: Patrick C.

description: Pretty average, unexciting fare at pretty expensive prices.  While the service was solid overall, the first bite, an ahi amuse bouche had very little flavor.  The kampachi crudo was tasty, but something you could make in your own kitchen in about 5 minutes.  The grilled octopus had decent flavors, but the octopus was a bit chewy.  The entrees we had (Ahi Tuna, and the 1/2 chicken) were solid, but uninspired.  And finally, the two side dishes we ordered (Potato Tots, Roasted Cauliflower) were just plane bad.  The Tots were basically flavorless, and the parsley salsa verde on the cauliflower was horrible.  The dish was completely inedible.  On the positive side, we did like their 50% off wine list, and my wife enjoyed the creme brulee.  Overall not a *bad* meal, but very average at best.
author: Franklin G.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco for about 10 months now. During that time I've had the opportunity to try a variety a restaurants throughout the city. There are so many restaurants to choose from, and my list of restaurants to-go-to is always evolving. I'm a firm believer of the idea that there is no such thing as a perfect restaurant. Different restaurants serve different purposes depending on the occasion and what the group is in the mood for. With that said, if I had to pick a "favorite restaurant" in San Francisco (based on my experience thus far), it would have to be One Market.

I've been to One Market on four different occasions, and each time I leave a bit more impressed than the last time. It should come as no surprise that One Market delivers an exceptional dining experience, as the restaurant was awarded a Michelin Star back in 2010. The restaurant really prides itself on serving farm-to-table food, ensuring its food is fresh and innovative.

During my most recent visit to One Market, I decided to order the "Weekly Beast" 3-course dinner. In the spirit of farm-to-table cooking, this dinner option highlights a different ingredient each week from a nearby farm. During my visit, the featured ingredient was rabbit (sourced from Devil's Gulch Ranch in Marin County). The 3-course dinner included the following: 

Course One: Braised Rabbit Agnolotti with tomatoes, corn, and chanterelles

Course Two: Ballotine with grilled peaches, padron peppers, beans and basil 

Course Three: Peach Shortcake with candied pecans, and cinnamon ice cream

I think the above pictures really capture the kind of culinary dream One Market is. The restaurant serves gourmet food at a reasonable price, given its location in San Francisco. Sure, you could go to French Laundry and spend $300 on a meal. Or if you're feeling particularly adventurous, you could hop on over to Saison, and spends around $1200 per person. However, for those of us who are on a budget, I think One Market finds the perfect balance of offering an upscale, fine-dining experience, at a fair price. When you walk in you are kindly greeted by the host, as a pianist plays relaxing classical music in the background. The waiting staff is generally very friendly, and eager to answer any questions you have about the food. 

As I mentioned earlier, every restaurant is fit for a different occasion. In my mind, One Market is the perfect spot to go for a relaxing (and savory) dinner. Many guests frequent the restaurant for business lunches as well, given its close proximity to the financial district. Regardless the occasion, I think you will be satisfied with your experience at One Market. It's my go-to spot in San Francisco :)
author: Andrew L.

description: My partner and I were married at One Market over a week ago (Already?!). We held a family and friends dinner in the Atrium Room private dining space after a short ceremony in the Atrium of the office building, a great white modern cathedral. All of it was perfect and wonderful! The venue was warm, inviting and well decorated for our event. Serena and Nicole, private events staff, were exceptional helping us plan, accommodating our requests and supporting our wedding to the beautiful affair that it was. Dinner was delicious, staff was friendly, helpful and discrete. The wedding cake (made there) was perfect! All our guest had a wonderful time, raved about the venue and food and felt completely comfortable in the setting. Thank you, One Market, for making our wedding the perfect special occasion! Rick Appleby and Logan Ramras
author: Richard A.

description: I ate here December 10, 2017. I had an unexpected trip to San Francisco, my Wife and I were looking for a nice place to eat. One Market was recommended by the Marriott Marquis and they were able to get us a reservation. Our experience was very good from the pre dinner drink at the Bar to the food at Dinner. Atmosphere had a nice holiday touch and the staff was attentive. I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Keith F.

description: Nice ambiance and good food. Mushroom gnocchi was delish. Beware the modest portion size on the crab cakes :-(
author: KB L.

description:
I first came here 6 months ago. I can see why this is not a highly rated restaurant. They have a prime location but the food is pretty tame. I ordered a dish with fish and the portion size was not very satisfying and the cost is high. It was only for lunch.

If you need something convenient, sure, check it out. If you want to lay down some bucks for a 3-star meal, check it out. I probably won't be back. There's much better stuff nearby that isn't a high price and is so much better!
author: Jess A.

description:
It's was a solid white table cloth restaurant. Not a ton of character, felt like a nice place for a business dinner, but the food was great. Perfect portions, perfectly cooked. We all enjoyed various seafood dishes that were fresh and cooked to perfection. I really appreciated that menu was more creative than your typical steak and seafood place. 

My favorite part was the dessert! It was the best dessert menu I have seen in a while. I would go back just to eat dessert so save room!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
What can I say, I love free food and when vendors fly in for one day from New York and take us out to dinner.  Enter One Market.  We had reservations booked on a Tuesday night at 6:30 and was seated immediately.  Service in the beginning was a bit slow though, as we waited 15 minutes before anyone came up to us and offered water and if we had decided what we wanted.

First we started with some tater tots, brussel sprouts, and cauliflower.  Perfect complements to my main dish, which was the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin.  Mmmmmmm.....the portion was generous and man was it filling.  I don't think I remember having pork that was this chewy (not in a bad way!).

We also had a bottle of....oh shoot, I don't remember the name of the bottle of white wine...Oopsie....

Anyways, the dark lit ambiance definitely makes this place a romantic worthy spot for future dinners.  And if you're seated by the window, you can get a glimpse of the Ferry Building at night and the Bay Bridge.  

Next time, I'll be back to try the foie gras.  Yay, legal again in SF again. =)
author: Kevin C.

description:
My execs like to have luncheons here and when I'm fortunate to be invited, I never decline. I order a different entree every time and what ever it is, it never disappoints.

My first time there I had a Dungeness crab pasta dish that was to die for. Creamy, crabby and just oh so good. Unfortunately, I haven't seen it on the menu again but if it returns, it's a definite must try.  The recent time I was there, I had the natural Angus flat iron steak with braised greens and mashed potatoes. Now that was damn good. Meat cooked perfectly (pink in the middle), juicy and very flavorful. The greens and the mashed were so deelish and everything just worked well together. 

One Market is definitely a high-end restaurant for lunch, which is probably why I only go there when being treated by the company but I would love to check it out for dinner, maybe the next date-night with the Husband.
author: Resa N.

description:
I've been meaning to try One Market for the longest time as it was right under my office. I finally had the opportunity to try during Restaurant Week but I was quite disappointed by the service and the hygiene. 

When we arrived, we realized that the menu had changed and it was no longer a seafood bisque as the appetizer, but a black bean soup. It was good, but not the same quality of food that we had expected. The sauce of braised boneless short ribs was delicious, but the meat could have been softer. However, while the food was good, my friend found hair in her food.....an instant turn off.

The environment was quite pleasant though and it would be ideal for a business lunch; however, given the hygiene level, I doubt that I would return.
author: Michelle Y.

description: I enjoyed everything about One Market, menu, food, service, ambiance. The cocktail menu looked interesting but I opted for wine. Starters were excellent including chickpea fries and Brussels sprouts. The house made tater tots were the only somewhat bland option we tried. They needed a lot of salt and could have benefited from garlic or other flavoring element. We tried several seafood options, fish, octopus, and scallops which were exceptional and served with risotto. While there, we enjoyed that there was a pianist. Service was excellent from start to finish. We were too full to try dessert. I will have to return.
author: Sue D.

description:
One Market is a reliable place for a business dinner or lunch.  The food and service are good, and the FiDi location is very convenient.  That said, I'm never blown away.

I was recently at One Market for a work dinner and found my meal good but not great.  I shared oysters as a starter, and they were decent.  I then had the seafood bisque, which was the best part of my meal - it was flavorful yet not creamy at all, and full of tasty seafood.  My main was the red snapper, which I found bland and lacking in flavor.   The fish was served with spinach and potatoes, and the entire preparation was uninspiring.  The complimentary olive bread was tasty, and the single bite I had of the (tiny) pecan tart our table shared was delicious.

The service was friendly, prompt, and patient, and location and upscale setting do make it a good place for business meals.

Overall, a good place, though I do wish they'd step it up in the flavor department!
author: Barnali D.

description: Great food and service... Very much enjoyed.  Excellent help with the wine list.  Sommelier helped with a reasonably priced wine.  We ended up with two to go with our fantastic meal.  The place was extremely busy but service was still excellent!
author: Mike B.

description:
Nice place for a business lunch. Both the food and service were a solid 4 stars.

I came in a party of 3 for lunch on a Tuesday at about 12:30. We had reservations, but it wasn't super crowded. We were seated immediately in a spacious booth.

There seemed to be a slight disconnect among the waiters, because two different people came by to take our drink orders and explain the specials; weirdly, they didn't both list the same specials (each of them told us 3, 2 of which they both listed, and 1 different one each). Anyway, they were both very nice and responsive.

We shared two appetizers: the chickpea fries, which were delicious, and the crab cakes, which were good, but not particularly memorable.

For my entree I had the "grilled Tombo tuna salad," which is seared tuna (rare) served on a bed of chopped Granny Smith apples, cucumber, kohlrabi, and some spring greens (including edible flowers; it was really a beautiful dish). I thought the fish itself was pretty bland and boring, but the salad that it was on top of was great - very bright and summery.

They had a bunch of interesting sounding dishes on the menu that I had a hard time choosing between; if I go back (and if they have the same menu), I'd like to try the artichoke soup (which has "garlic flan" (??) and hazelnuts - would have ordered this today, but I thought the garlic might be a bit much for a business lunch ) and/or the "thinly sliced lamb tongue" (just because it sounds interesting). I've also heard good things about the ahi burger.
author: Liz F.

description: Love this place; their lunch has been consistently delicious (I used to get the $25 lunch special).  Happy Hour is what I frequent; til 7pm and their chardonnay and pinot on happy hour are excellent. The bartenders, Kiyan and others are great too.  Love the sliders on happy hour!! mmmmmmm!  pork tacos not bad either!!  Piano til 9pm nightly; so lovely to unwind there in evening.  thanks!!!
author: Neveen B.

description:
Came here with former coworkers for happy hour and dinner. Right off the bat, kudos to the waitstaff that let us linger for hours. Thank you!

We ordered the charcuterie to share -- it was interesting! The ham was really tasty. I ordered the pork for my main meal and it was to die for. Really tasty. I am always a little put off when asked how I want my pork cooked and I am glad I asked for medium rather than the suggested medium rare. It was juicy but still a little borderline pink for me. 

Overall a great meal. A little spendy for the four of us, but we had been drinking three hours worth of wine... All good! Would come back!
author: Chloe M.

description:
Finding glass or plastic pieces in the spinach probably says it all.
Had gone here for a work lunch and while the restaurant reduced our bill 50% the worry of trying to see if causes any internal damage makes me not want to go back here.
author: Anirudh G.

description: Visiting from Seattle we took my mom here to celebrate her 70th birthday. We decided to do the Chef's Table set in the middle of the kitchen. It was a 7 course meal prepared especially for us and they made sure to take care of any special diet requests (gf, no onions, garlic, scallops). The wait staff was fun and attentive and the food was absolutely UNBELIEVABLE! I highly recommend this place for a small intimate celebration of 5-6 people. We had THE BEST time ever!
author: Kim M.

description: Exceptional service! Came here for a work event and had wonderful scallops. The risotto was okay and Creme brûlée was okay and I did not love their butternut squash coconut milk soup but their service was great and the plating and presentation of food was classy!
author: Felicia C.

description:
Excellent service from start to finish. The food is delicious! We had the Social dinner:
Beet salad - delicious, artfully presented
Pork Belly salad - scrumptious pieces of pork belly with tomatoes and lettuce. Colorful presentation.
Petrale Sole - sole, covered w shaved cucumber in butter sauce. Light and flavorful.
Dessert -  Strawberry Financier - chewy
Although the wine we had was delicious we had to wait a long time for it to chill. This was unacceptable and our waiter graciously removed it from our bill.
author: Arch D.

description:
Wow. Food was good, but the service was sloooow! We had a decent size group, but our meal took three hours from sitting to paying the bill! I came her with my team from work and I just kept thinking about all the work I had to do when I got back.

I got the seafood bisque as a soup and it was really good. The soup broth was kind of sour and tangy which I wasn't expecting and I like the added crunch of the puffed rice. I got the octopus confit (mixed with pasta) and it was really good! I loved all the flavors and the octopus was fresh and perfectly cooked! I would totally recommend either of these dishes! I tried a couple of the apps and desserts and they were good as well.

Overall, good food, nice atmosphere - open space, high ceilings, and lots of windows, but the service was so slow!
author: Sophia Y.

description: Upscale New American cuisine, warm atmosphere, knowledgeable staff and an extensive wine list. What more could one ask for? Oh yeah - amazing food, great dining room at the perfect downtown/Embarcadero location & a kick-ass chef! Chef/Owner Mark Dommen is "all that."
author: Nick S.

description: Ok place in a city with lots of better places. Went there after work and place was dead. Dining area was dead. Bar was dead. Staff was good and attentive. Bar bites was ok. Not my place after last visit. So many other places where you can get more for your hard earned money.
author: Brian A.

description:
Came here with my bosses while at a work conference in San Fran...we had an 8pm reservation on a Friday evening & were immediately sat upon arrival. The place itself wasn't really that crowded, which surprised me a bit. It took a bit for the waiter to finally come over with some water & to take our drink order, which perturbed me a bit. 

We started with some cocktails. I had the Coquito, it was very tasty, thick, creamy & sweet. I wish they had given me more! I finished it in 2 sips! 

For starters, I had the grilled octopus. Three pieces of octopus were served over spaghetti squash with a variety of spices. Interesting dish, I've never had grilled octopus served this way. 

For dinner I had the pan seared scallops. 4 scallops were served in a heavy pomegranate like sauce with boiled peanuts & blacker trumpet mushrooms. Again, a very unique dish. The sauce was tasty, but a little heavier than what I expected for a scallop dish. 

The 2012 Cab we had was delicious & the wine menu they had was great. 

The desert menu did look really tasty, I like that they offered mini deserts too. I just had a hot tea. 

Service was decent. Place was pretty, cozy, warm ambiance. Food was good...nothing I would rave about.
author: Shannon W.

description:
Though relatively modern, One Market is a relatively old restaurant in SF's current dining landscape.  Opened in the early '90's by the famed Larks Creek Inn owners, this was their second location aside from their now gone original Novato spot; Bradley Ogden who made his name at Campton Place headed the kitchen here.
It's been a long while (fifteen years) since my last meal here.  A business friend arranged for e lunch here on a recent Friday.  The main dining room has stood the time test though the tables seem more densely packed here.  The lunch menu is not particularly large but there is an ample selection to choose.  After a quick study, the lunch special was the most tempting.
Here's what I had:
Appetizer
1) Shrimp salad (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=17XYtLuN8wcbqI15B3PSZg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Normally, when I think of bay shrimp, briny, fishy little frozen ones come to mind.  These were deliciously crunchy and had no aftertaste.  Very refreshing and generous portions.

Entree
2) Pappardelle with lamb ragout (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=JKhBBRgrE08px3OVt6CtuQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - In total contrast to the salad, this was hearty, heavy, and rustic.  The noodles had a nice chew yet weren't too doughy and the sauce complemented it perfectly.  

Dessert (shared)
3) Almond crunch cake (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=udj0DyolO-JskWvBNEAmSg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - This was the star of the show, especially considering I didn't have much expectations for a lunch dessert.  The almonds were crispy and fresh (in season) and the different texture and flavors really made for interesting bites.

The dining room was about 70% full and mostly with younger work groups.  Some enjoyed raw oysters and drinks while others were grabbing simple meals.  At $25.00 business deal lunch for two courses and a $5.00 supplement for dessert, this is certainly a reasonable deal especially given the location, atmosphere, and service.  The bread was a nice hunger curb considering it is a decent walk from the Financial District and Chinatown.  
Yes, will likely come back and definitely recommend if you are in the area.
author: Mike C.

description:
Tried it on restaurant week.I ordered a lunch combination of black beans soup, short rib and creme brûlée for dessert. The server accidentally gave  us two pairing wines which we didn't actually order. But they are generous and didn't ask us to pay for the wines.

Dessert and wines are highly recommended, but you definitely don't want to try short ribs...the meat is not carefully selected.
author: Dingding Sherry W.

description: Came here for business lunch with my clients.  Their business lunch is only $25, which includes a Creamy Spinach Soup, and a Wild Salmon entree, generous portion for both items.  I also ordered a "Quench Splash" non-alcoholic drink and it was so refreshing!  Added another $5 for a Lychee-Rose Panna Cotta, very reasonably priced and the food was so yummy!!!  Definitely blew my mind away and the service was also decent, highly recommended and would love to come back again.  :D
author: Vicky H.

description:
There's a reason why this place isn't on the Michelin Star list for 2014.

First, it's like they can't taste their own overly salted food.

And I mean EVERY dish I had was overly salted.

The first, overly salted dish was the complimentary chopped salmon, with a heaping of salt on top.

Free isn't always good.

Next came the Avocado and Crab Gazpacho.

Here's the thing that irked me. When our waiter served it to me, I noticed that there were sliced of fish, and no crab, and when I asked him why, he said, "We ran out of crab."

Hmmm....don't you think you should have told me that BEFORE you served it to me?

What if I was like Miss Bad Idea Bear, who doesn't eat fish of any kind, but will eat shellfish?

I was tempted to ask him to return it, but he convinced me it would be great with the fish. Wrong. It was salty avocado with plain slices of raw fish.

When I finally tasted it, and asked him to take it away, and remove it from the bill because I didn't like the dish, he said I had already eaten several bites.

So much for a 20% tip, it just dropped down to 10%.

Then the Duck Breast came, with sausage. Whoever invented this dish must have been high because it had a chocolate mole sauce, sausage, granola, and once again, an overly salted duck breast.

The sausage looked like a log and was seared on both sides. It was hard and tasted like emergency ration food.

The granola and duck were awful in my opinion with an overly greasy skin.

I was fearful about my Blueberry and Coconut dessert, which tasted like a coconut macaroon with cheap blueberry compote on top.

One Market really should receive one star in my opinion, but I'll give it an extra star for nice decor.
author: Jack R.

description:
I came here for Mother's Day and had a wonderful time. 
The staff is very friendly and welcoming
The food is delicious 
Definitely  will come again
author: Annabelle S.

description:
I have been back to One Market for a few times and their service and quality of food have been dramatically improved.  

They offer a $25 business lunch which consists of a choice of salad or soup, entree, and a chocolate chip cookie as dessert.  The cauliflower soup and veal was good but the piece of chocolate chip cookie was on the weak side.  It's about the size of a sand dollar.  You could pay an additional $5 and select one of their "singular sensations" which was what we did.  So really if you want a complete three course lunch, it will be $30 and not $25.
author: Shirley H.

description: Great place for a business luncheon or dinner. The menu had a good variety of delicious dishes to wet anybody's appetite. From barbecue asparagus to a tasteful Halibut, you will probably not be disappointed with any dish on the menu.The dinner portions where plentiful, hot, and delicious to fulfill ones craving of a meaningful meal. The service was exceptional, along with the ambiance by a live piano player. This restaurant is a place of business that serves a certain clientele based on the total cost for our meals. The value of the experience in dining at this restaurant comes at a hefty price, its a place that an average person can not make a habit of.
author: Kurt C.

description: Service is top notch.  Our waiter is a true professional. He gave great recommendations and never let the drinks run out. He had a lovely personality and you could tell he enjoyed his job.  The food, WOW.  Just wow.  Definitely try the foie gras. They make it perfect.  Melts in your mouth.  Is not over or undercooked.  And to top it off you have live music from a pianist. Honestly this place is top notch.  Great food and drinks.  Both cocktails and wine list.
author: Christina C.

description: Great business lunch place.  I just had lunch here 3 business days in a row.  Good service and great food.  Looking forward to visiting again soon.
author: Norman C.

description: Came here for Restaurant Week, but we ended up ordering from regular menu. Got their trout appetizer which is so delicious and for entrees we got scallops and pork tenderloin. The pork tenderloin is so tender and soft!! The scallops are amazing too! Service is a bit slow, might be because they are very crowded with the super bowl 50. We skipped desserts because we were trying to catch the fireworks show but overall it was a great meal!
author: Prisilia P.

description:
Went on a busy weekday for Dine About Town.  Bargain lunch where you get an Appetizer, Entree, and Dessert for $25.  The place was full and will be wild when Super Bowl City is up and running!  What a prime location for people watching inside and outside the restaurant.

Food was excellent and service unpretentious.  We have been to a few Dine About Town lunches and dinners where you get attitude from the wait staff.....none of that here....just excellent service!  Great bread too..which is a good barometer as to how the rest of the meal will turn out.

Nice location, excellent food, excellent service (brought black napkins at our request, checked on us multiple times), upscale setting.  What more can you ask for?!
author: Scott L.

description:
All the fancy people in my office always came here to eat and I was always super envious. When Dine About Town came around I decided to take advantage of the discount and made a reservation for me and 5 of my frugal coworkers. The food was delicious and the price was reasonable....if you were one of the smart ones that didn't buy a drink. The iced team that my coworkers bought were $6! Did they know they could get a tea bag at work for free and put ice in it. 
Another factor that ended up being a drag had more to do with my friends and less about One Market. Hint: if you go in a large group- all order roughly the same thing or don't be so cheap when the bill comes. I feel like we ended up wasting a good $10minutes trying to figure out the bill. That always sucks!
author: Julianna I.

description: Bar can get crowded early, but some good drink deals and the chickpea fries are delicious! 1/2 off wine bottles on some days (fridays?)
author: Steve F.

description: Staff remembers you and the sommelier was remarkable. Recommended a wonderful Sonoma Chardonnay that went perfectly with the raw oysters appetizer and lobster main course, which was cooked perfectly. The "tater tot" side is highly addictive. S'mores ice cream bar for dessert was divine. A perennial favorite.
author: David H.

description:
One Market is where you go to feel like a FiDi baller (whether you're power-lunching, having post-work martinis, or people-watching). 

It's been ages since I've dined here, but I decided to swing by here the other while waiting for my Ferry to arrive. The inviting bar was packed with biz suits and power-players. This isn't really a place for jeans and sweatshirts. 
I saddled up at the bar and nursed a bourbon on the rocks. I enjoyed eavesdropping on all the "only in San Francisco" chatter all around me (everything from tech deals to juice cleanses - you gotta love the Bay Area!). From my seat, I could see all the Ferry Building and all the foot traffic on Market Street. So in essence, you're far away from everything, and yet close enough to all the action if you want it (something I like very much). 

Although I saw signage for happy hour, nothing on the menu really stood out (at least from a price/value stand-point). I only stayed for a quickie beverage, and that ran me about $12 (I wouldn't exactly call that happy hour pricing). That being said, you're really paying for the whole swank environment and location. So I didn't really mind coughing up a few extra bucks for my bourbon.

All in all, I enjoyed my short but sweet experience here. I'd certainly be back, especially if I wanted to impress a client or date. One Market is a class-act.
author: Kevin B.

description:
My first review of the year and I'm sorry to say, this was not the place to be.  Our table for 3 was given away to another party because the host claims he didn't understand the thick accent of the folks that took our table.  It was quite racist how he explained it actually.  But we waited an additional 40 minutes to get another table set.
