The food itself was off - way off.  You can see by the pictures.  I'm not sure the plating was appropriate for the "Lamb's tongue shavings."  It tasted fine, but I didn't understand the concept of a giant plate for 1 bite.  This was a complete rip-off so I wouldn't ever recommend anyone to pay full price for it.  The "Lentil soup" was average... and then when I got to the main pork dish, I wasn't blown away mostly because the vegetables were burnt - to the point where it made the dish bitter.  We ended with a dessert that was overly sweet - it looked pretty, but not memorable.

I'm sorry, but I simply can't come back.
author: Julie C.

description: I've been going to One Market on/off for a long time. This is the perfect place for biz, as long as you're not paying! Its a total serene, white cloth setting with excellent service, top-shelf food, live piano, valet parking (a must) and super-professional staff and bar. I had butternut squash soup, a righteous bone-in meat thing which had a bone the size of a SF Giants bat! Salad was excellent too. Awesome martinis and excellent coffee! Right on!
author: Kevin F.

description:
Made reservations for dinner with my partner (who is from LA) per the suggestion of a family member. I ordered the day boat scallops with buckwheat and pork belly, and my partner ordered the king salmon (prepared medium rare). We also ordered the chickpea fries with harissa aioli and the spinach with roasted garlic. They gave us tuna tartare to start off, on the house. There was also someone walking around serving sourdough and olive bread (with cold butter, one of my dining pet peeves).

The highlight of my order was, honestly, the buckwheat. Whatever they used to season it was amazing. But my dish was delicious all around. The spinach was good but probably wouldn't order again if I come back, not worth it. Partner's dish was pleasant--I've never had medium rare salmon before but it was very good. The chickpea fries were good, but the aioli wasn't anything special.

Service was fairly attentive without being overbearing. They gave us vanilla caramel chews at the end, and they were delicious--they definitely tasted like they were made in house.
author: Beatrice C.

description: Wow. Kind of a surprise given it's Embarcadero location, great quality drink and food. The dessert comes stunningly beautiful. Reasonably priced.
author: April W.

description:
If this restaurant were not so seriously overpriced, and if the service had lived up to it's high ratings, maybe I would be tempted to give it four stars, since the food was good, not great, and nicely prepared.  In fact, the waitress, who was certainly charming, and really knew her menu, lost track of us after another server delivered our main courses, and forgot to bring the side orders we had requested.  My husband had to flag her down in order to get the rest of our meal delivered.  She was very apologetic and comped us the sides, but in a restaurant for which one pays a premium price, one expects better.

We were there with friends celebrating dual birthdays and even though we mentioned it, no one offered us even so much as a cookie to celebrate.  I know it isn's Denny's, but a candle on something?  I don't know, I really expected better than just okay.
author: Elayne I.

description: I bought a Chef's Table special tasting menu and wine pairing dinner for 4 at One Market at a fundraising event. This dinner FAR exceeded any of our expectations. The tasting took place in the kitchen with a 7-course meal that was beautifully presented and introduced by the Chef-partner Mark. The wine pairings were incredible, well thought out and introduced by Tanya the Sommelier. Before the last course, we were given a behind-the-scenes tour of One Market and received another wine tasting in their cellar. Two of us were then dressed in chef's coats and invited to the pastry area to finish off the dessert offerings. Truly a remarkable evening full of thoughtful unique experiences!
author: Lori F.

description:
We had been to this restaurant for over ten years and watched it going downhill year after year.  But after this week's dinner, we have decided never to go back anymore.  The food is mediocre, especially the sauce.  Actually we tried three main dishes (seafood and meats), and all seemed to have similar sauce  using fruits and were overly sweet.  These dishes completely lacked creativity or balance of flavors.  
The service was attentive but rushed.  In fact, the waitress never smiled for the entire evening.  She looked as if she was very unhappy to be there. 
The worst is the mandatorily added service charge (used to be called tips).  Despite that we were only a group of 3, a mandatory service charge of 20% was added (by handwritten note directly on the printed bill) on top of all the taxes and SF surcharges. That was equivalent to 25% of the bill.  I felt this was a very sneaky practice on the part of the restaurant or waitress to force a tip out of us, knowing that their service was sub-par.  This is disgraceful.  A restaurant of the likes of One market does not need to be this desperate.
author: Kim L.

description: After many times walking by this place, I was able to satisfy the wonder! The food was good (socks not blown away though) and it was a cool cat vibe. I loved the piano music and deco. I'll be back, but not on my priority list.
author: Jeanette Jane G.

description:
I am an event coordinator for a company who holds a few dinner meetings per week. I worked with One Market from across the country to plan a corporate dinner and it was a breeze. They were extremely attentive to my needs and requests. We were able to customize a menu for our guests exactly to our liking and organize the drink menu. The end result was wonderful! Thank you to Serena Collins for making it happen!

I highly recommend One Market for an amazing private dining experience!!
author: Ilana T.

description:
Just had delivery from here, and we eat here downtown occasionally. 

Pros: Great New York steak. Always get the tater-tots.. Mushroom were good. Octopus rocked! 

Cons: However I ordered the 'strawberry cheesecake' (BIG FLOP!) 
Super small little square piece of something that did not even deserve the name 'cheesecake' it was like a jiggly flan! Plus no mention that the 'strawberry cheesecake' was lemon flavored! And there was literally one small strawberry cut in half with less than a teaspoon of whipped cream on top! For $7.50.00 this was a sorry excuse for cheesecake! (It wasn't cheesecake guys!) no crust on the bottom really as well. So scrumptious and overthought... I can get just a standard piece of real cheesecake at almost any dive, in any town. Had this been cheesecake I'd given three stars... Yawn
author: Kirk M.

description: One of the best restaurants in the city. $$$ but well worth it. Saturday night had a pianist and made the atmosphere more inviting. Went there to celebrate my nephew's HS graduation and couldn't have been happier. Will return someday!
author: JM T.

description:
My dear friend Gary took me here for a late birthday dinner. I opted for the pig 4 course tasting menu and he had the 3 course prefix. I didn't have high expectations because of the average reviews but I wanted to give it a try to see if they are worth their Michelin star. I was pleasantly surprised and thought the meat is wonderfully done and the food simple but tasty. 

My first course was a pork pâté and it was full flavored. I loved the warm bread that the restaurant serves. The pate was a country pate, with chunks and that was right up my alley. 

The second course was a pork tenderloin. This is the star of the show. I've never had pork this tender and juicy. The texture is almost like a great cut of steak. I've had juicy pork before, but never a buttery texture as the tenderloin at one market. Drool!

The third course was a pork schnitzel. The dish was more like pork katsu, with a panko crust instead of the more traditional flour and egg batter. I liked it, but thought it needed some sauce to give it more flavor. 

The dessert was the weakest course. The peach ice cream didn't go with the chocolate and caramel toppings. My favorite part was the pig shaped cookie crisp. The dish would have been much better if they used a vanilla or bourbon ice cream. 

All in all, I enjoyed my experience at one market. The service is very white glove and the decor is nice. If you order the set menus, the price is also very reasonable. I would come back again
author: Alice W.

description:
Nice restaurant.

I have been there for New Years' Eve and I am not disapointed at all. 

We came a bit early, so we stayed at the bar waiting for our reservation. We had good advice about drinks and the coktails were good too. 
They have a tons of alcohol, whisky, bourbon, cognac, ... You can find everything, even some french rare alcohol. Nice surprise!

The atmosphere was pretty loud during diner, the room is big and the kitchen is opened. 

We had the 3 courses menu for New Years' Eve, $125 each after 8:30pm, and it worths it.The food is cooked correctly, served beautifully and most of all : it tastes amazing!

People who stayed there until midnight could have watched the fireworks. 

Go there, try, and enjoy !
author: Anthony D.

description:
Over priced and mediocre at best. Didn't realize they had a Michelin star. Surprising. 

The duck had great reviews on open table. I was disappointed to get a duck breast that was tough, well done and dry. Accompanying confit was boring. Too much salt. No balance in flavors. The sauce didn't complement the duck.

Bummmmmmer.
author: Winston B.

description: The food and service are very good, but what earned the 5th star was the incredible s'mores dessert.  I will never be able to enjoy a campfire s'more again. Wow!
author: Andy H.

description: I had a fabulous lunch today at One Market Restaurant!  The duck pate starter was just right and gnocchi sardi was sublime!  I had a Vieux Carre --- bourbon, cognac, sweet vermouth, Benedictine, and Peychaud and Angostura Bitters --- it is now my favorite cocktail and all I have to figure out a way to sit there and drink it all day.  Our waiter David could not have been more helpful or more friendly.  One Market is crowded and busy at lunchtime, but he made us all feel like we were the only people there, the only people who mattered.  All this for what one would normally expect to pay at a place with meh food and the barest minimum in service.  We were so pleased with everything that we forgot to order the giant tater tots!  Gotta go back there soon.  Thank you, David!  You made our lunch extra specially great!
author: Tracy L.

description: Came w large group. Many of the steaks were improperly cooked. Server was rude. Pasta dish was cold. Manager was not accommodating. Would not recommend this restaurant.
author: Ann J.

description: The food is pretty good but the lunch service was pretty bad. We had a noon reservation and they didn't take our order until 12:37. My drink was empty half the time and had to inhale my meal to be 10 minutes late to my 1pm. Was pretty frustrated. Also, the waiter spoke so fast that I couldn't keep up with her rants. Asked her what her favorite dish was and she named 1/3 of the menu. Was actually pretty funny when she walked away because I looked at my guest and said "wow I'm back at square one with all that." The food saved this place. The flounder was amazing. Ambience is good and view is pretty good.
author: Andrew V.

description:
Finally came to check it out during Dine About Town.  Good service, nice ambiance, food was about fairly good.  I chose the little gems salad for my first course and we all went with the hangar steak for our second.  My family chose the chickpea soup for their first instead.  We noticed a note on the menu that if you dine exclusively from the Dine About Town menu that an 18% gratuity charge would be applied to your bill.  That's a little odd, especially for smaller groups like ours.  

After placing our order, we were presented with my favorite bread....the Pain Epi from Acme!  OMG soo good!  Anywhoo, the little gems salad was adorned with blood oranges, fennel and radish and was small and a little tart for my liking, but not a bad salad.  They thought their chickpea soup was alright.  I thought the hangar steak cooked medium rare as requested was satisfying though.  Super tender, a good portion and had enough of that fatty flavor.  The swiss chard and the shallots were a good accompaniment as well.  Since we were celebrating my aunt's birthday we decided to pay $4 more to get her the meyer lemon cheesecake on the Dine About Town menu.  It came with a huckleberry compote, but was tiny.  I can't believe they charge twice the price for something so small on the regular menu.  The cheesecake needed the berry sauce since the lemon flavor was faint.    

One Market has a nice ambiance, good service though lunch can be at a leisurely pace, and the food from what I've experienced was good...not awful not great; though one of my co-workers loves this place and says that it's always consistent.  3.5 stars.
author: Cat C.

description: One Market has got absolutely fantastic food. The short rib was real tender, with the meat falling right off the bone. Veggies were prepared just right too, and service was prompt.
author: Casey S.

description: There's a reason why One Market remains one of the very very very best restaurants in San Francisco.  From the second that you walk in the door, the experience is wonderful in more ways than I have fingers and toes to count.  The service is flawless.  The food is terrific in ways that most restaurants try but can't deliver on -- the food is both traditional AND cutting edge at the same time.  Great flavors, great textures, perfect presentation, flawless service.  We shared the goat cheese appetizer today for lunch (an exquisite mound of goat cheese coated in chopped pistachios and honey -- sublime), followed by the gnocchi (crazy delicious in a tangy October fall kind off way), and mint ice cream sandwiches (we each had one all on our own).  Our wonderful server was incredibly informative and kind.  Oh and I haven't even mentioned the warm bread and butter . . . .  After all these years, One Market continues to amaze and delight.  I wish I could give far more than 5 stars.  Maybe 1,000,000 stars??  BRAVO.
author: Thomas M.

description:
High ceilings, beautiful décor, lots of natural light.. the ambience was perfect for our celebration lunch!  We started with the dungenous crab cakes with saffron aioli and the Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout.  The dungenous crab cakes were tasty, but smaller than expected.  The smoked trout came paired with a delicious potato hash!

For the main dish, I ordered the duck confit cavatelli (type of dense pasta). The duck pieces were delicious and came with a delicious spinach pesto sauce.  I couldn't help use my bread roll to make sure I got every bit of it!  

Dessert was quite the finale... we ordered the following:

1. Crème Brulee - came with 2 different types (standard and expresso).  I loved the expresso brulee, brilliant idea!

2.Chocolate Toffee Almond Crunch Cake - There's nothing muted about this dessert.  The chocolate was rich and the toffee almond crunch pieces were huge!

3. Cheesecake - tasty and solid.

4. And in honor of pi day (3/14).... we ordered delicious apple pie!  

All the desserts were a work of art!  To top it all off, I had the most delicious Chardonnay from Williams HIll.  Best 4 hour lunch break I've had in awhile!  :)
author: Helen T.

description:
After a clumsy exchange with the restaurant regarding some feedback about their service and how they handled a large corporate party,  the general partner personally reached out and sincerely apologized and genuinely wanted to fix the issues at hand (that's probably a run-on sentence but whatever). 

While I wouldn't necessarily seek this restaurant out, it is solid enough for a corporate event and is managed by someone who definitely wants to do right by customers.
author: Farooq K.

description: I have dined here about 6 times and love this place. Great for a date night or a business meeting. The food rocks at this place with well executed and prepared dishes.
author: Dan R.

description:
Came here for a company lunch on a weekday, and it was busy. The staff was super friendly and the food was great!

I ordered the Grilled Trout ($21.50 - warm herb vinaigrette, broccoli rabe, toasted almonds)
 and my coworker ordered the Chanterelle Mushroom Risotto ($28 - yuzu, pine nuts, mitsuba) and we shared the dishes. We both really enjoyed the Trout. It was succulent and crunchy because of the almonds. I really enjoyed that combonation of soft and crunchy. The Risotto was okay, but still delicious. 

They were also a part of restaurant week for $25, and everything that my coworkers ordered looked good. That was a  good deal for them. 

The location is perfect for a adventure in SF, because you can go any where from there. Catch a Giants game, go to the Ferry Building, walk along the Embarcadero and go to Fisherman's Wharf, or walk down Market back and hit Union Square. Or even catch the bus/muni/bart and pretty much go anywhere.
author: Mayra E.

description:
Dinner food is just okay. Service is awful. Very nice view of the Embarcadero though, and nice restaurant ambiance.

Happy hour options are decent, and the bar staff was attentive and friendly. The sliders were pretty good. Seating was easy enough to get at 6pm.
author: Jaching H.

description:
Dinner at One Market with my *old man* was a thoroughly enjoyable experience.

However, that's because I love my Dad.

The restaurant really did nothing for me, aside from locate itself in an extremely convenient place for me to get to after work. After an especially brutal hump day, that counted for a lot. 

Foodwise my Dad had the Wild King Salmon, which he seemed to enjoy. Myself I went all out and had the New York Steak. **Excuse me** I had the -- 12 oz Creekstone All Natural Angus New York Steak -- fancy description and everything.

It was decent.

But you don't even have to know the price of that thing to know that you are most certainly paying for more than just "decent' when you order that thing. Not impressed. Plus the guy either lied or just didn't know left from right when he explained it by saying it was the "leanest piece of meat on the menu". That thing had several, large, visible strips of fat coming off it. Lean indeed. 

The garlic mashed potatoes were good. That's gotta be a whole star by itself right there...

...which bring it up to three (3) total. And that's all she wrote folks. 

Seriously for that price, I'm just not sure. Maybe they have good wine, and since I wasn't drinking that night perhaps I missed out on something? Because the food is "ehh"...at best.

I'm digging for more stars at this point: 

Service? Decent, but certainly a cut below what you'd expect at a top tier restaurant such as this. And it might be a cut-and-a-half below too.

Ambience? So in theory, there's a very nice view of the Embarcadero, however at night the curtains somewhat obscure the outside world, so really what you have is a nice view of the inside of the restaurant.

Seriously, don't you just leave here expecting more? I did.
author: Brian S.

description:
I've been here for lunch and dinner and both my experience was pretty good. Both times, it was for business purposes so the service was great ( but from reading the other reviews, I have a feeling that we were served well because of the company's name and the dinner was private dinner). 

(++) Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout "Mi Cuit". I actually still remember this appetizer and craves it as it has been one of the best appetizers I have ever tried. The flavors are so right and I was a bit mindblown at the egg on top and how well it complements the trout. Definitely recommend this dish for seafood lovers! 

(+) Grilled Tombo Tuna Salad. The ahi tuna was perfectly grilled (and I love tuna!) Great flavors and the portion was perfect for lunch. 

(+) DInner: Mahi Mahi ! This came with a three course business dinner. IT WAS SO GOOD. It came with 2 pieces of mahi mahi. The fish was seasoned perfectly. I don't know what the sauce is that went along with the mahi mahi because it's not on the menu online. 

Overall, I loved my experiences here and the food was amazing. No regrets.One star alone just for the tasmian trout.
author: Tram N.

description: I've been coming to One Market since it opened (more years ago that I care to admit).  The reason it has outlasted many other restaurants and remains popular is consistently good food.  It's good every single time.  I like the location, at the foot of Market near the Ferry Building; very pretty (esp. at night).  One of the best deals in the FiDi is the 3-course business lunch.  It's $25 bucks and you get a soup or salad starter, an entrée, and cookie for dessert.  Pretty good deal.  Another excellent time to try One Market is during Restaurant Week.
author: Donna G.

description: Completely appreciate the service, quality of food, and price point of the wine.  this was the second time that I came here and I love how easy it was to valet park, how friendly and accommodating the staff was, as well as their openness to our ever-evolving needs (number of people kept changing; we showed up at different times / left at different times, etc).  they worked with us as a party, as well as some very picky eaters that were present.  I don't hear about One Market when people mention great restaurants in San Francisco, but those of us who eat out a lot and are familiar with the restaurant scene really appreciate this place for business dinners and a great date night.
author: Deanna S.

description: Always delicious!  Great service, amazing food.  You won't be let down here - it just won't be a cheap meal.
author: Alexis B.

description:
Came here for dinner to celebrate a friend's birthday. Reservations were smooth, and they had no trouble accommodating changes in our party size last minute. They also sent out a complimentary birthday dessert as well, which was nice.

Food:
I decided to order from the Anniversary Menu. I picked the smoked trout for my appetizer, the roasted bass, and the popcorn ice cream sundae; there was also a dungeness crab amuse bouche, all for $40 per person.
All the food was great - I particularly liked the bass. It was tender and deboned expertly, and the sausage stuffing was really flavorful. Presentations of each dish were excellent as well. 

Service:
Wait staff were attentive and readily cleared finished plates and refilled water. Our server was nice as well, although it was a bit hard to hear her at times over the noise. They were also very accommodating for the vegetarians in our group. 

Ambience:
The decor gives the place a classy and elegant feel, while avoiding being too stuffy. Tables aren't spaced too close together and there's live piano music as well.

Overall, we left happy and full. If you're looking for a place to have a nice classy dinner, then look no further than One Market.
author: Oliver L.

description:
I typically have numerous birthday dinners each year. One dinner is always with my parents. Every year, they let me pick the restaurant I wanna go to. Since we are a family that shares every dish, they are not a huge fan of set menus with no choices. So I can never take advantage if this by suggesting some of the fancier restaurants with prix fixe menus. Back in 2012, I suggested we go to One Market.

*Amuse: Potato and caviar http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#73GfvlEgyQITcNg1lyjRsw
*House-made charcuterie http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2?select=Vj60sp4IYMtqPSAZb4AE4A#Vj60sp4IYMtqPSAZb4AE4A
*Hand-picked dungeness crab http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#YuiIKd_wCDE_iXoSCat1lw
*Lightly smoked Tasmanian ocean trout http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#y45MXRYf2O8JzSio0ADSgw
*Market menu: Shaved beef tongue salad http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#qqUljJUA2HQQWGC6Ti7NzQ
*Market menu: Bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#HCwpuA_oj6eLUULBSeOGHQ
*12oz painted hills all natural Angus new york steak http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#x3VlzY5HcSsv8hCmuMOu1w
*Pan-seared day boat scallops http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#UIK8qaDp0ccEvFn0hslMAQ
*Roasted liberty farms duck breast http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#60bCeSsqMq-4fv_-EEJlRA
*Potato tots http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2?select=Vj60sp4IYMtqPSAZb4AE4A#nscQm_AawZqwTvYbbYplog
*Sauteed spinach http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2?select=Vj60sp4IYMtqPSAZb4AE4A#aTp-JVxVLJj_b5QUgyDgtA
*Coffee toffee almond crunch cake http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#A__6qaTI5U67AsWTG8OvEg
*Blueberry cheesecake http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#1lbxPJkmGwceJH8vx0kvkw
*Lark creek butterscotch pudding http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#WmePH-SeUqKhhfU4CQRRxg
*Duo of creme brulee http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/one-market-restaurant-san-francisco-2#oSHbhjaNKLKfLCHHWTgB5Q

Their menu is definitely diverse and we had a good amount of choices for a party of four. My favorite dish of the night was charcuterie. It was beautifully presented and we got a good assortment of meats. The rest of the dishes were good, but what I remember most is that some of the dishes were super bland. The crab needed seasoning. The side dishes needed something to give them a little more flavor. Even just a pinch of salt would have helped tremendously!

Service was great! When we got our desserts, they had written happy birthday on one for my dad and another for the roommate. (Did I mention the roommate's bday is the day before mine and my Dad's is the day after?!) Even though it was my birthday too, I felt it might have been a little too much to tell them we were celebrating three bdays!

I'd been going back and forth between giving them 3 or 4 stars while writing this review. Based on what stayed with me most about the food, I settled on 3. Most dishes didn't seem to quite deliver in taste for me. So in all, with the price point, I'd say this was just a solid 3 star experience.
author: Elena N.

description:
I have eaten here on many occasions - both business and with friends and family. 

Great variety in the menu with creative nightly specials. Wine list is above average. Service has always been great.  

More health/ lite fare options on the menu would be welcome.

Valet parking has been slow in retrieving our cars on many osscaions.
author: Jim C.

description:
Been here multiple times by now and every single time the quality was good. But nothing exciting. At this price level, I expect the menu to change on a regular basis and surprise me whatever I order.
The taste of the food was just mehh. Service was good nothing to complain.

Apps:
 - Foie Gras: Loved it. Very good. Didn't like the seaweed bed.
Entree:
 - Duck Breast: Alright. Nothing special. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
 - Brusselsprots: Undercooked. Had so much better. Quite disappointed with it.
Desert:
 - Banana chocolate tart: Very delicious. w/ candied hazelnuts. Best part of my night.
Wine pairing:
 - Hartford Court, Pinot Noir: Great recommendation by the waiter. Worked very well w/ the duck. 

If I had a better overall experience with the food, I would have easily bumped this up to 4 stars, but due to the above reasons, I had to stick w/ a 3 star rating.
author: Toby B.

description:
Serena Collins, one of the event planners, is organized, professional and detailed.
I highly recommend letting her handle any of your corporate events, award ceremonies or lunches/dinners.  It was an amazing and delicious experience.
author: Susie S.

description:
I had grilled octopus and Bacon-wrapped Pork Tenderloin. It was amazing! 
I will definitely come back.
author: Iris C.

description:
Beautiful experience at this fancy restaurant!  Delicious food, lovely classy atmosphere, wonderful service, comfortable tables, and have I mentioned delicious food?  So tasty!  If you're looking to splurge on a fancy dinner, this is a wonderful spot.

Aside from the food, the restaurant 's beautiful atmosphere and low lights combined with wonderful service contribute to a great experience.  We had such a lovely time!  

Our table ordered:

-  Bread: perfectly crusty on the outside and soft on the inside with plenty of flavor
-  Beet carpaccio: wow, so tasty with the goat cheese and super-thinly-sliced beets (they're not kidding about the carpaccio)
-  Ahi Tuna: absolutely mouthwatering seared ahi that melts in your mouth, with delicious mushrooms.  I got it without the lardo.
-  Red Snapper: this was so incredible that it was even better than the Ahi - there's mustard in the sauce and the fish is so tender!  The potatoes are also so tasty.
-  Monkfish:  our friends said this was delicious - it's not possible to leave out the chorizo due to the preparation, but if you eat meat, it really makes the dish.
- Dessert minis: not too tiny, and we got 3 for $15 and every single one was amazing!  So, I recopmmend: Chocolate toffee almond crunch cake, pineapple upside-down cake(w/Ice cream) and pecan pie with caramel (w/Ice cream) 

We each had a drink, as well, and for this level of fare, even the prices were appropriate.  We'll definitely be back if we're in SF for a special occasion!
author: Irina H.

description: One of my faves on SF.  They have an excellent wine menu--make sure to ask for Tanya, their sommelier, to guide you; you will not be disappointed.  The poached egg on wild trout over Rodri is not to be missed.
author: Jon R.

description:
I have wanted to try One Market for some time and when I found that they were taking part in Dine About Town, I made the reservation as soon as the participating restaurant list was released. 

One thing I must say, they have two DAT menu. One priced at the DAT dinner price and another for about $10 more. But unlike many other DAT restaurants I've been to, One Market's DAT and DAT+ menu do consist mainly of their regular menu items. 

My girlfriend and I ordered one of each DAT menu so that we could sample their food. We started with the lamb tongue and Caesar salad. The tongue was surprising good and this was the comment from my girlfriend who 1) has never had lamb tongue before and 2) is a food critic in her own rights. The Caesar salad was served very crisp, just correctly dressed and not overrun with crotons nor Parmesan. 

For the main course, my girlfriend ordered the Liberty Farm duck breast and andouille sausage. I ordered the grilled pork chops over collard greens and corn polenta. The duck breast was one of the most tender piece of duck I've ever had! The pork chop was grilled to perfection. 

For dessert, we ended with the Valhorna white chocolate crème fraîche panna cotta and flourless chocolate soufflé cake. Both were delicious and were quickly dispatched into our roomless tummies.

Service was excellent throughout the meal. I can't wait to go back and try some more food!
author: Tony L.

description:
Thanksgiving dinner!

Service was spot on, and about everything else was just about perfect. 

The food was not. 

I was very disappointed with what they think 'Thanksgiving Dinner' means. 

Afterwards, and still hungry, we went to another restaurant which was a million times tastier and delicious than the slop at One Market.
author: Raleigh S.

description:
My visits to One Market have always been great and satisfying. It is not a surprise to me that they are a Michelin Star Rated Restaurant. The food is always delicious and beautifully presented, and the service is always impeccable. 

In Financial District and at the foot of Market Street, with the historic Ferry Building in view and the streetcars passing by, it is not surprising that most of the diners are in their power suits. I have witnessed a few job interviews held and business deals closed during my visits -- yes, they do make for great business people-watching. Do keep this in mind when you plan to dine: this is not a shirt-and-flip-flop kind of restaurant. I never felt that they are snobby, though. 

Today, we visited during Dine About Town (really a great deal: $18.95 for a starter and an entrée, and additional $4 for dessert). We wanted to taste everything. As a result, we ordered the little gem salad and the sweet potato soup for our starters; the cod, the pot roast, and the gnocchi for our main courses; and the chocolate cream parfait and the upside down cake for our dessert.

The Little Gem Salad was a delightful start to the meal, with the cherries and blue cheese combination giving the salad a wonderful flavor. The Sweet Potato Soup proved to be disappointing, however. The ginger and shiso were too overpowering that the taste of sweet potato was almost nonexistent. The oranges did give the soup a refreshing note.

The Pan-seared True Cod was perfectly cooked - with the crust perfectly crisped and the meat perfectly flaky. The piquillo peppers was delicious in combination with the squash and perfectly complemented the light flavor of the fish. The Pot Roast seemed to satisfy my dining companions as the words "phenomenal" and "very tasty" were thrown around quite a bit. Finally, the House-Made Potato Gnocchi was really delightful, with its perfectly balanced mushroom and parmesan flavors.

For dessert, the clear winner was the Blueberry-Coconut "Upside Down" Cake. I am not normally a big fan of coconut cake because I find it to be too sweet, but the tartness of the blueberries and the richness of the vanilla bean ice cream perfectly counterbalanced the sweetness of the cake. The Valrhona Chocolate Cream Parfait was also rich, delicious, and not too sweet. It was very good, but the upside down cake outshone it easily.

I have always and will always be a fan of One Market. I highly recommend you try them when you are in San Francisco.
author: Clarice O.

description: On Thursday afternoon I stopped by for a beer and also to watch a few minutes of the Warriors game. I was there for a total of 10 minutes. At halftime, I swipe my card and quickly left to jump in the waiting Uber. The bartender, a young African-American male, ran after me all the way to the car, to give me the credit card I had forgotten to retrieve. Amazing!!!! He didn't have to do that. He could have just left it, called me, or done nothing about it. But he made the effort and save me a lot of trouble. He is the kind of person that should be commended and reviewed positively. Unfortunately I didn't get his name. Not all heroes wear capes.
author: A Z.

description: I made reservations here after checking out many places online.  Once we arrived, I was pleased with the look & decor of the restaurant.  It has a classy yet casual feel to it.  The wine list was nice- I found Rafanelli Zinfandel on it which always makes me happy.  I ordered the wild salmon for my entree and my friend ordered the halibut.  I was very disappointed in both.  Neither entree was up to par for the prices listed.  Service throughout was efficient.  Bottom line... It might be a good place for a drink, but you might want to get dinner elsewhere.
author: Rachael S.

description: Was meeting a long-time family friend for dinner near work so it was very convenient.  The   staff was excellent and very personable.  Good food in a lovely location.  It's a bit overpriced for some of the items.  $25 for pasta with mushrooms in it seems a little high.  I guess they have to charge a lot because of the location.  Overall, it was a nice experience.
author: Carol L.

description:
Made reservations for four definitely not young women for Valentine's Day. Everything we ordered was beautifully presented and really good   Desserts were great. The most attentive service we have had in a very long time. A little pricey but worth it. 

Easy to get to from the BART station - a real plus if you aren't driving.
author: Marian G.

description:
I honesty do not understand how this restaurant *ever* had a Michelin Star.!?
After at least a hundred visits in the last 2 years (I work in the same building) - I've NEVER had a similar experience as Boulevard, Frances, Slanted Door or Heirloom Cafe!
Again, tonight - lackluster service, horrendous version of a Caesar salad (dry, warm, no lemon flavor, no fishy, savory nor cheeses flavor.!?
Sad - poorly conceived sorbet dessert in the tasting menu and the only saving grace was a bacon-wrapped Pork tenderloin w/dandelion & salsify, but the wine pairing..? Confusing & mis-matched atrociously with wine-pairing; plus, why should anyone wait 15 minutes to get the Sommelier's suggested wine *after* not with the course.!? For a Thursday evening, 1/2 filled restaurant the arrival of every course was delayed & un-announced for a table of 10.
Plates were dropped & unexplained; no mention of what was ordered, delivered it its preparation... and this was dinner, from a previously Michelin-star'd Restaurant.!?
The Sommelier was "in-adequate" at their suggestions; they "at best" delivered a near opposite of the preferences requested, according to the chosen tasting menu;
and this was a mixed/sophisticated chef/wine connoisseur crowd.
Everyone had grilled steak or pork as a main, yet the wine offered was acidic, light, flat & bland; menu stated: wet, briny, slightly spicy yet herbaceous - seriously?
Overall - flavor and luscious savoriness the menu implied was severely lacking - and desserts were muted while too simple in flavors & presentation.
Very disappointing for the price...
author: Johnny V.

description: One Market is a go to place when in SF. The consistency is impeccable and the atmosphere and location are outstanding. The place to go for the roasted duck or foie gras. The menu changes regularly with options of game meats, venison or wild boar as examples. They always have an ultra fresh seafood selection and a vegetarian gluten free option.
author: Darryl P.

description: Consistently high quality. Come here for lunch and dinner and  I always enjoyed all the freshness of the ingredients, the service and the elegant atmosphere.
author: Antoine N.

description:
(This review is from 2014 -- the review sat finished but un-posted for quite a while.)

My wife was in the city on business, so I BARTed in to meet her for dinner. We had reservations for 6:45 pm, but arrived about half an hour early, and they were able to seat us without a problem. 

I liked the open floor plan, and the view into the area where they grill the meat. It was interesting to watch the process. One Market clearly is a bit more formal/upscale than most S.F. restaurants -- suits and ties for the vast majority of men -- but they didn't bat an eye at my attire of jeans and a V-neck sweater.

The food was extremely good. We had the chick pea fries with harissa aioli as an app, which were delicious. Sort of super-thick cut fries with the texture of polenta inside. A very filling app for two people; highly recommended! Both entrees were also very nice -- I had the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin with dandelion "persillade," salsify and natural jus, and my wife had the pan-seared day boat scallops with artichokes, olive oil mashed potatoes and lobster emulsion. Note that the pork comes medium rare -- which is the chef's preference -- which was fine, even though I normally would order it medium.  The desert was also very good, something chocolate, but I don't recall now exactly what it was.

The only minor blemish on the meal were the drinks. The Smokey Cuban
(Appleton Rum, Sombra Mezcal, lime juice, simple syrup, Angostura bitters and prosecco) was just mediocre -- the Mezcal was too dominating -- and overpriced at $13. In hindsight, I should have had the Moscow Mule. My wife had the Outofbeer Sauvignon Blanc, which was fine at first, but on ordering a second glass she had a bad reaction to it.
author: Andy S.

description: Delightful all around!  Service was friendly and prompt. Our waiter made great recommendations on all the courses and the wine. The scallop was one of the best I've had -- tender, with not hint of undercookedness. The creme brulee and bread pudding desserts were wonderful -- a little taste of fall. Being next to the ferry building, wonderful ambience and memorable San Francisco experience!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
3.5 STARS

HOW is One Market a Michelin Star Rated Restaurant?

One Market is also part of the Lark Creek Restaurant Group (Lark Creek Steak, Yankee Pier, Bradley Ogden, etc.) so I expected more. Granted it's beautifully located near the Ferry Building and is a scene for power lunches (do come dressed to the nines), however, the food is uninspiring. The best parts of my meal were the oysters and dessert. 

Today, I came to One Market for lunch at 1 PM after it had been on my list for a while. Luckily, I was able to snag reservations (recommended) 2 hours prior. We were seated in a booth facing the Ferry Building with waterfront views. 

D R I N K S 
DOLLAR LUNCH MARTINI: $1 Hendrick's or Stolichnaya Vodka from 11:30 AM - 2 PM (limit 2 per an entrée ordered)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=5k_OMwO0zMJWSmCj-XzwCA
As a Hendrick's Gin lover, I was dancing in my seat...LITERALLY! They don't skimp on the alcohol either. 

F O O D
*HALF DOZEN OYSTERS w/ Mignonette & Cocktail Sauce ($18) - 4.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=-sBuSK5oIoiWj-EXlhiagQ
The sweetwaters were silky smooth with a deliciously clean sweet taste. The mignonette gave it a pop of tang while the cocktail sauce gave it a spicy bite. 

*NATURAL ANGUS FLAT IRON STEAK w/ Bay Leaf, Green Peppercorn Sauce ($21.50) - 2.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=pp5rKXLcCntC4UYMfHQDSw
First things first, presentation was lacking. I eat with my eyes first and the way the dish was presented didn't make me want to dive into my plate even though I was starving. Though requested medium rare, only two of the four slices were cooked to order; the other slices were more a medium well. The steak was chewy and not seasoned properly; it was bland to be exact. Very disappointing especially when I've dined at Lark Creek Steak at least 8 times and have always enjoyed my steaks there. 

*CHICKPEA FRIES w/ Harissa Aioli - 3.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=YLrZGp_vIpT7g7zi0G59kg
Dusted with cornmeal and then lightly fried, the chickpea fries were lightly crisp on the outside and soft on the inside. The harissa aioli added a creamy spice to the fries. If you like hummus, you will enjoy the chickpea fries. 

*BRADLEY'S BUTTERSCOTCH PUDDING w/ Chantilly Cream and Pecan Wedding Cookie ($5.75) - 5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=esDn_-tXz7bkT_-lb9EU8Q
After seeing that One Market had a similar butterscotch pudding to Lark Creek Steak on the menu, I WAS SOLD!. The butterscotch pudding totally redeemed the lackluster steak. It ain't the Jello snack puddings I grew up on as a kid. Seamlessly smooth and velvety rich, the butterscotch pudding had a luxurious sweetness. The Chantilly cream added a nice fluffiness with an extra oomph of creaminess. One of the most decadent, yet light refined desserts. MUST ORDER. 

S E R V I C E
Professional, attentive, and slightly pretentious (to be expected). Before I saw the dollar lunch martini, I told our waiter I like Hendrick's and he came back with the Aviator (Gin, Maraschino Liqueur, Crème de Violette & Lemon Juice) and it had the perfect balance of alcohol to tang to slight sweetness. Brownie points for a guy who knows how a lady likes her liquor. 

Food took awhile to come out so unless you have at least 1.5 hours for lunch, go elsewhere. 

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Simple elegance; crisp white lined tables, wooden panel furnishings, and waterfront views. This is where the attorneys and investment bankers come for their power lunches. Dinner would be nice for intimate dates and/or to celebrate a special occasion. 

P A R K I N G
Relatively easy street parking before 6 PM. Valet is $10. 

Unless I'm rolling around in a bed of Benjamins which will probably never happen, I doubt I would come back. Though I didn't pay, I rather spend my hard earn money at another Michelin Star Rated Restaurant with solid reviews and a more tantlizing menu.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
The lil lady and I had our 15th anniv dinner here before catching some comedy at the punch line a month ago.  After working in the building for 10 years then working nearby for another ten, I figured I should visit and partake in some grub that gets fairly good reviews - I wasn't disappointed.

I started with the uze, VO manhattan up, then came a caesar and for dinner, a smoked prime rib.  Each and every morsel was well prepared, tasty and reasonably priced.  The location itself is well appointed, very nice decor with an open kitchen.  And of course, the iconic ferry building can be seen through the Steuart side of the building.

Always wanted to try, finally did, and, the wait was worth it.  I'll be back!

Ya feel me?
author: Johnny L.

description:
Came in here for dinner. The appetizer that I had was the pickled sardines. which were quite delicious. For my main I ordered the 12 oz NY steak. it was cooked perfectly, but a little too heavy on the salt. I had to down my water because it was a bit dry on my throat the more bites I took. We also ordered some sides, and same thing with the buttered spinach - too much salt.

Flavor-wise, everything else was good. Just less salt, please.

The service and the ambiance were excellent.
author: Kenson K.

description:
I've been to Thanksgiving dinner here two years in a row now and it's very good! They have great wine here and we have enjoyed a bottle both times now. I love the turkey dinner.. it's huge so come prepared! Delicious sides and starters too. The vegetables and stuffing that came with my turkey were tasty. I really enjoyed the pumpkin risotto with chicken as an appetizer. I wish they didn't give so much dark meat with my turkey since there was more than enough white meat to fill me up. The turkey is good but not the best I've ever had.. I guess nothing beats homemade! I felt bad to waste the extra food but unfortunately I couldn't take it home with me! There are additional menu choices on Thanksgiving too.. my father in law really enjoyed the pork loin dinner (it had a more reasonable portion than the turkey). 

Definitely make a reservation if you are heading in for the TG holiday.. otherwise you probably won't get a table. We got lucky and someone canceled last minute so we were able to make reservations a few days in advance. Also, the booth tables by the windows are much nicer than sitting in the middle. We had a more relaxed time this year because of better seating. Our server was very nice and easy going.. we weren't rushed in any way and had a wonderful time.
author: Dan N.

description:
I love One Market - simply because they are very consistent in delivering great food and quality service.  My friend was in town for business and so I was tasked with the last minute herculean effort of finding a quality dining establishment the day of!  Did I mention all the hotels were booked so you can imagine I was beside myself with worry.  I must have called 7 restaurants and was told they would either be free at 9ish (this is not NY people, who eats dinner this late?) or we can try our luck at the bar... NOT!  

Then en route to my friend's hotel, I remember this lovely establishment.  My old company would frequent this place for posh lunches and yummy happy hours.  As luck would have it, the hostess was able to squeeze us in at a decent dining hour.  Not only did she deliver but we got PRIMO seating (yes, I used to be a foodie in a previous life).  I was beside myself with glee.  The service was absolutely flawless, the food divine and my foodie friend was so impressed that he wanted to somehow make the chickpea fries for his son back at home. Total win win.

Now don't come here if you're looking for a bargain or heaven forbid, no reservation.  Two drinks, appetizers and main course will run about $130ish.  But it's soooo worth it.  Everyone needs a good arsenal of "old faithfuls" when guests are in town.  And I'm happy to report that One Market just joined my repertoire.  Love this place!
author: Ann S.

description: Happy hour prices and drinks are good, but come here if you are not in a hurry! Service in the bar area/lounge was terrible. We literally had to ask for a drink. One of the bartenders looked like he hated his job. Definitely had better service in San Francisco.
author: Phuong N.

description:
Im surprised the ratings are so low here. they have one of the most affordable tasting menus and wine pairings around. It's been a while so this is a catchup review from a few years back...

During the snow season we had decided to come here and have a meal, then basically were too full to head up to Tahoe. We never made it to Tahoe, So I blame the tasting menu from keeping me from snowboarding :)

The ex at the time worked in the area and had always wanted to go here, so we made resys and were sat along the bank of two tops. We sat next to a couple that were also doing the tasting menu and they were having a fabulous time. We got talking with them about food and service and we could tell we were going to be happy. So the meal consisted of:

-Duck liver mousse, quinoa tabbouleh, pickled cauliflowers and carrots
-Golden lentil soup, vadouvan, yogurt
-Red wine risotto, duck confit, gizzard, chicory
-Roasted Liberty Farms Duck Breast duck leg crepinette, cilantro, sweet potato, chocolate
-Spit-roasted Berkshire pork loin, fennel, apple, potato puree, cider
-Valrhona chocolate soufflé cake, chocolate-banana ice cream, chocolate malt cream

Tasty all around. As I mentioned earlier, it's one of the better tasting menu deals around and it always changes. The surprise from the market I think is the way to go. Sure, Bradley Ogden has signature dishes that are worth trying but why not leave the whims of Chef Dommen and his crew to surprise you? Service was solid and they took good care of us. I know the Ogden empire is supposed to grow into Las Vegas and the Peninsula pretty soon. but I think this will remain a flagship for a while
author: Kim N.

description: Fantastic food!  Great service from the entire staff. Jarrod was the most gracious host as well as their fantastic sommelier. Started off with the smoked trout starter and was not disappointed. The rabbit was fantastic entree. The mint chocolate ice cream sandwich and crime brûlée were great. Can't wait to come back
author: Daniel B.

description:
Saturday night the changing "Weekly Beast" was beef forequarter.  Beef tartare for the first course was delightful and the sourdough bread offered was a nice touch.  NOTE: Too many restaurants are not providing bread with the meal... this is San Francisco folks....the home of the best sour dough bread in the US.  It seems that  SF restaurants are cutting back on food (bread & butter) and putting a 4% health care tax on patrons as a way of increasing their bottom line.  Remember...this is a prime world-wide tourist destination.
 Second course was braised beef (I say short ribs) that my late Jewish mother would say was superb served with matzo dumpling slices (pretty good).  Dessert was a deconstructed Dulce con Leche cake with chocolate (sooooo good) ice cream and caramel sauce and other accoutrements.  This 3-course dinner was $45 .... a bargain for a top notch beautiful restaurant with great service..... I WILL RETURN.
author: Toby T.

description: Always my family's go-to for a nice SF dinner. I love the ambiance, the food, and everyone that works there is so friendly!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Great place for business lunches. Formal enough but not stuffy.  Wait staff is professional but not intrusive.  Food options cater to a variety of taste.  I particularly loved my green salad, which is simple, but so many places butcher it.  The chickpea fries are delicious, and octopus was really tender and flavorful.
author: Candice B.

description:
Wow, filet mignon...so perfect in every way! The sauce was a bit too salty for me but the meat was memorable in every way. Sides are a la carte - mash is creamy and melts in your mouth. Can't go wrong with the New York steak either. Others got the duck breast - and while it was good, they were thoroughly disappointed with the servings. Two small slices?! We ordered 36 more oysters to fill our tummies. (The oysters are served as raw but I asked them to grill it due to avoid raw shellfish hives and they accommodated. It was VERY good. We wanted more and they were out.)

Dessert: must have the chocolate toffee cake. Comes with a very small portion of vanilla ice cream, so you can request for more. 

Service was ok- our waitress didn't seem too happy with us granted we were a huge, loud party - but she put up with us. The hostess was annoyed we added an 8th person to our reservation when we got there, but ended up making it work. 

Loved the food, great ambiance. Everyone working there could look a bit happier though.
author: Karyn L.

description:
My friend wanted to eat somewhere nice for her bday, and we needed to find a place with a last minute reservation for 5 people. One Market Restaurant fit this criteria! I wasn't expecting much since this place has 3.5 stars on Yelp, and because most people said this is mostly a place for Business lunches. However, this place very much exceeded everyone's expectations!

To be honest, we were all very late for our reservation. It was originally for 6:45pm on a Friday night, and we didn't get there until 7:15pm. Traffic was awful downtown, just in case you'll be in that situation.  However, they were very accommodating and still sat us regardless. They weren't even irritated by it! Perhaps it happens often.

We ordered 4 appetizers. Everyone loved everything. The quality was very impressive. My favorites were the veal tartare and the Duck Frisee Salad. Yum....they were devoured in minutes! Small side note - even the comp bread was good. It came warm, and had the perfect chewiness.

I got the Red Snapper. The waiter said he liked this one a lot, so I wanted to try it. The fish was so amazing! The flavors were perfect. The snapper can be plain, but with the celery root risotto, and blood orange, it was full of flavor. It was saucy, but only as much to complement the dish. I would DEFINITELY recommend this fish. I couldn't believe how great it was.

I remember we got 2 desserts, but can't remember what they were. Guess I was too drunk by then. But, I do remember that they wrote "Happy Birthday Frances" on the plate in chocolate, which was super sweet. Usually places just say "congratulations" or "happy birthday" with no name. But adding the name made it more special! Thank you One Market!

For 4 appetizers, 5 entrees, 2 desserts, the price came out to 62/person. Not bad! I will definitely be back. I don't know why everyone gives this place an average score. It deserves way better than that!

The service was great. They were very patient with our medium sized group, and just left us alone to do our thing. They didn't rush us in ordering, didn't rush us with the bill. Perfect! Would return with a group again.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
We wanted to eat one really special meal during our 3 day weekend so we picked One Market after trying two other spots that had over 2 1/2 hour wait.  They were able to get us a window table looking out at the bay on a Saturday night with only an hour's notice - which probably should have been my first clue as to what was going to happen for the rest of our One Market experience.

We were properly greeted and seated right away.  The waiter got us our drinks (both wines and cocktails for the 4 of us) in appropriate fashion.  The busboy got us our water without ice, per our request.  The waiter came back and got our order....things seemed fine.  And then we did not see our waiter for over 40 minutes - as in we saw him in the dining room at other tables, but not ours.  We completely ran out of water - no bus boy came by to refill them - the entire meal!  We ran out of cocktails and wine - no one even came by let along asked us if we wanted anything else.  The restaurant was not full - so it wasn't that they were swamped. 

When our meals finally arrived at about 45 minutes wait, another busboy delivered our food - not the waiter. The two fish meals were very hot, the lobster was warm but not hot, and the smoked brisket was on a hot plate - but the meat was barely warm.  There also was only a butter knife with the fork and napkin at the table.  Admittedly one could cut this meat with a butter knife -  the concept of a steak knife with beef is a reasonable presentation.  I couldn't eat this super fatty meat cold - and the waiter at that time buzzed over to ask how everything was, and I told him I needed the meat to be heated - it was whisked away by a busboy and returned about 12 minutes later by a busboy -- after our friends had finished most of their main courses.  I then ate my main dish - which over 1/3 of the two small pieces of meat were fat, so it really was not much meat.  NOTE- neither the waiter of the bus boys filled our water glasses at this point, nor were we asked if we would like another glass of wine or cocktail.  Nor was there an apology that the meat was cold or that it took them so long to get me a hot meal. Shameful!

The two fish dinners were both tasty and hot.  The Maine lobster however was cut in such a way that the meat was all stringy, including cutting the tail in half the long way, which I think should always be left as a whole.  Sadly it had virtually no taste at all and was one of the most expensive entree items on the menu at around $50.  The menu is al la carte - and we had brussel sprouts, Caesar salad, and mash potatoes as sides - which were all good but not great.

Waiter brought desert menu, and hopefully he heard me as he stood behind our table - when I said, I am not giving these people another dime of my money, let's go somewhere else for desert and night cap.  We paid for our meal (no adjustments made for cold food and delay) and out we went - the first couple passed by the front desk and no one even acknowledge them - as the 3 people at the reception desk were all chatting with each other.  When we went by, we got an over the shoulder, "good night".  

We all left pretty mad at the entire scene - mediocre food, high prices, piss poor service, and not even a genuine or concerned good bye.  I do not recommend this place - there are so many outstanding restaurants in SF - go elsewhere.
author: Randi I.

description:
Lunch.  We did not have a reservation.  Arrived at noon and there was plenty of seating.  The place filled up quickly...Make a res.  

Flounder in that Spanish style sauce... ground almonds, red peppers, garlic.  The guy had a very good pasta dish ..crab meat.

I have never had a bad meal here.  Be prepared to spend the $..
author: Bleep S.

description:
This place is so so good.

We had lunch here today and pretty satisfied.

The selection on the menu is very limited which is kinda good because it made us choose faster. 

The setting and customer service at this restaurant is definitely fancy and elegant.

I'm a huge fan of ahi poke that's why I decided to get Ahi Tuna Burger. The tuna was cooked almost all the way (not the way I want it). I guess because it's a ground tuna rather than a huge piece of tuna seared on both side really really fast. 

Crab Cake was good but it would have been better if there were no shell grains in it and it was a little salty.

The butterscotch pudding was really good.

Overall, we were all satisfied and would go back here again.
author: irwin v.

description:
Had the burger with blue cheese & patato-tots. Very savory, it was a 1/3 lb. burger. 

Duo of Creme brûlée, butterscotch pudding, banana cheesecake, mint ice team sandwich, Verona chocolate pudding. The desserts definitely shine here. 

Next time I come I definitely want to try the bacon wrapped pork or seafood. 

Word of advice, be sure to reserve in advance as the local legal eagles and Salesforce execs can book tables quickly.
author: Sandino N.

description:
I booked a reservation at One Market for a holiday family dinner- and wished I had taken reservations at House of Prime Rib, or Farallon, or State Bird Provisions instead. The farm-to-table food/drinks are well-prepared, the service is low-key, and the location/decor is beyond reproach, but One Market feels more appropriate for power lunching than for a family get-together. There's nothing intimate or romantic about the dining experience, and the dining room is loud, loud loud (!) to boot. 

One Market also feels dated. The menu, which hasn't changed in a decade, reads like a throwback to a nostalgic time period when Ahi tuna, lemongrass skewers, and popped collars were cool. Pan-seared scallops, NY strip steak, risotto with walnuts (walnuts? walnuts??), brussel sprouts with bacon, and baked potato amuse bouches may delight your palate, but not your imagination. Reading the menu was yawn-inducing, and my table didn't bother ordering the tasting menu because nothing piqued our interest.

However, our potato rosti "mi cuit" appetizer, along with our charcuterie plate, were textbook perfect, with all flavors mingling, yet carrying their own weight on the plates.I ordered the roasted lamb with (delightful!) mushrooms persillade, (uninspiring) snails and honeyed farro. My lamb was perfectly cooked to order, but I made the mistake of ordering it rare. The texture of rare lamb, combined with al dente farro, made for a dish that could only be described as ... chewy. The combination of farro and lamb would have been excellent if I ordered the lamb medium rare. My sister's roasted monkfish was also perfectly cooked, but served alongside a plateful of mealy corona beans. One Market does protein unimpeachably well- accompaniments however, will vary in quality and marriage with the rest of the plate. 

I'd also skip dessert- the flourless Valrhona chocolate souffle cake (yawn) was rich and dense without being too sweet, but the gingerbread with cider-glazed quince, candied walnuts and maple cream is a dessert probably better made and enjoyed in the comforts of your own home. If you feel like lingering, the French press coffee and digestifs are much better choices. Housemade vanilla bean caramels are a nice (but yawny) surprise that appear with your bill. 

Given the obvious talent of the chef, it'd be so interesting to see One Market modernize its menu; as it exists, I probably wouldn't return unless I was on the expense account of one of the aforementioned power lunchers (but then, gladly! Because a free lunch is always a lunch I am into :) )
author: Tianyi S.

description:
Came here for Dine About Town over the weekend, and debated between 3 or 4 stars. But presentation and service had me rate this place higher, but for a michelin star, I would've expected more.

Called the restaurant 5 minutes to our Open Table reservation as we were stuck in traffic, and they were very nice and understanding. We arrived 15 minutes later, and the restaurant is way bigger than I had thought! It was also nice as they have curtains at the entrance, to keep the SF wind out of the restaurant. The bar area was nice, and a piano player playing the entire time.

I could see the open kitchen, and people dining around them as well. Very cool. We were seated at the end of the front restaurant, at a slightly odd table (instead of sitting across from each other, my friend was to my left).

They had the 2 Dine About Town menus, and a special one for the weekend, that looked really good, and at a reasonable price. They also had the Chef's Tasting Menu that looked like a good deal too. However, we went with the Dine About Town 3 course prix-fixe menu, and added the wine pairing for $14. Our server was nice and let us switch out the red wine for a white that would complement our entree. We had a glass of sauvignon blanc in the beginning, which was very crisp and nice. The chardonnay we were given with our entree, was a bit buttery, and we definitley enjoyed the sauvignon blanc better.

We were brought an amuse bouche, a tiny baked potato with caviar on top. It was delicious and so cute, I almost didn't want to eat it! We then asked for bread, which was freshly brought. They didn't seem to give us a choice though, one pain epi for my friend, an olive sourdough bread for me. And no butter. I asked for butter, and it was brought promptly. I enjoyed the pain epi more, which my friend shared with me, and then our appetizer of chickpea fries was brought (we ordered this on top of the 3 course menu). Chickpea fries were nice and hot, and it reminded me of hummus and falafels. Enjoyed the aioli sauce it came with too. A lot more than I had imagined them to give us, and by the time I filled up on my carbs, I was full! Ack, and I had 3 courses to go!

The steak tartare was delicious, enjoyed the kick it had, and the capers and raw quail egg on top. They also give you toasted bread to put it on too. Ack, more carbs! I didn't care for the parsley salad it came with though. Next, came our entrees, the braised pork short ribs. It came with farro, cabbage, and mustard seeds. A good sized portion, and really, I was way too full at this point, that I could only eat a few bites. It was very tender, although some of the outer parts were dry. A good amount of fat came off the bones too. It was my first time trying farro, and I didn't care too much for it, as healthy as it is. My friend and I agreed that this dish would be complete if there were more vegetables accompanied with the dish. We also both ordered the ricotta cake with blood oranges. It came with honey frozen yogurt on top, and was yummy! We had asked for one in a to go box, as there was no way we would be able to finish both, and since I had noted it was my friend's birthday, they brought it out with a candle and Happy Birthday written in chocolate. The cake was super moist, and a good compliment with the frozen yogurt and blood oranges.

Overall, a great meal and time here. Glad Dine About Town brought me here.
author: Denise L.

description:
Solid service, great food.  A little slow in taking our lunch orders today, but it gets busy with the business crowd - mine was a biz lunch too.  Worth the money - better on expense account ;-)

Bar happy hour is always great with great martinis and various cocktails.
author: Massimo M.

description: I had salmon with rhubarb, and sides were parsley cauliflower and tater tots (gourmet!). Delicious and interesting flavors and perfect presentation and service. We wanted a quality farm-to-table regional meal. This was upscale, fine dining.
author: FoodGirl G.

description: I loved this restaurant ...it was a last minute choice while staying in union spare .  Lucky for us they had had off wines all month long in July.. Not a few select all wines entire wine list! We opted for a cab called Napa Howling Moon Cab blend wine ....a must if you ever come across it! . We decided to do the 6 course tasting menu and every last dish was excellent!  The views were great the staff is top notch on service!  I will be back!
author: Izzy V.

description:
Our staff holiday party was held here a couple of weeks ago. I thought that the service was pretty top-notch and that none of us were ever really left wanting for anything -- be it food, drink or anything else One Market could provide us with.

Our table had a horrible wobble to it, though, and it took our waiters several minutes to fix it, but they were very prompt and apologetic that it wasn't as perfect as it could be. As if I would complain at that point! At least they were ready and willing to fix it immediately.

I decidedly did NOT like the famer's market salad that they brought out, but I'm also generally not a fan of salads period. The vinaigrette was a bit too strong for me (and that's saying something because I usually have no problems with vinegar), and I didn't like the taste of the greens. Give me the main course already!

I had the vegetarian option for lunch, which was the mushroom risotto (changed from the mushroom ravioli that it was going to be). I honestly thought that the risotto was amazing. Creamy and filling without being too runny or weirdly thick. The pieces of mushroom added a nice texture and color to the dish as well. Boyfriend's steak was a little tough to chew, but I felt that it was overall pretty good, too. I liked the flavor, though cutting the meat proved to be a little difficult too (probably had to do with the chewiness of the meat as well if I had to guess).

The dessert was VERY rich. Too rich to the point that I couldn't finish it. But that's not necessarily a knock. I just wish we could've had something with the dish to cut the thickness of how sweet the cake was.

Overall, I would say it was a pretty fun experience (aided, no doubt, by the fact that we had a pretty ridiculous open bar). I've never been here otherwise, so I can't say what service is like on any regular old day, though I've heard lunch here can be pretty pricey for what it is. I guess I'll just have to come and try it again to be sure!
author: Anna W.

description: My daughter and I had a lunch date for her spring break- we were lucky to have Steven help us - he was awesome and the food was great. He surprised us with a cake that said "spring break forever" such a beautiful and thoughtful gesture. Go see Steven!! Tell him I sent you!
author: hamid h.

description:
A group of us decided to go to One Market for their Weekly Beast menu. Out of the 10 of us in the group, half of us decided to do the Weekly Beast, while some ordered a la carte. I would definitely have to say that part of the experience is always about the company that you're with. Everyone that was at dinner did add to the experience. One of the guys who joined us, only went because of the company. If it were up to him, he had been to One Market a few times before and wasn't that impressed.

As we waited for the whole party to arrived, we wetted our appetites with a couple of appetizers: Pan Seared Foie Gras and Grilled Octopus. (If you've read any of my recent posts, you will have noticed that octopus has been a recent theme and it's all about trying to match the experience of that one amazing octopus dish, but that has yet to happen). Although some people may say that foie is just foie and that you can only have so much of it, this preparation was delicious, particularly because of the Duck Dashi that it was served with. It was soo good that we took our bread to sop up every last bit of the dashi.

Honestly, I was kinda full after the two appetizers and some wine, but decided to order the Weekly Beast anyway. This particular week was a pork menu. The first course was a grilled pork with a Vietnamese flavor. It was a thin piece of pork, with good grill marks and great flavor. I don't know how I managed to finish that course and continue, because it was a substantial portion. Unfortunately, that was probably the best of the three courses that I had. We moved on to the second course which consisted of a pork loin. It was prepared well, but just not that exciting, especially compared to the Duck Breast that was on the plate of the person sitting next to me. The duck was very juicy and tender, and I think the vote at the table was that that was one of the best entrees. Then was dessert. I don't remember what it was that I had, but it wasn't that memorable. The part that I enjoyed the most was the garnish, a thin piece of chocolate in the shape of a pig (which I think are the cutest!)

So for a $49 tasting menu, meh...I'd rather eat off the regular menu.
author: Audrey C.

description:
I really enjoyed my time at One Market. The ambience, the food, and the waitstaff all live up to ones expectation of a four or five star establishment... the restaurant is in a wonderful location with high glass to look out to ferry building area and general downtown/embarcadero.

- The pork belly and fried green tomato starter is delicious
- The Caesar salad is a staple, having been on the original menu for past twenty years
- The seared Ahi is very tasty
- Their halibut dish is also very nice 
- The chocolate soufflé is decadent.  Looks like a 'lava cake' but so much better...

My company also hosted a party here and was pleasantly surprised.  Great bartending and attention to detail.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Three of us went here for dinner yesterday and were very pleased with our meal.
I just had the duck frisee salad which was excellent.  I also had a lemonade which was too tart.
My friends had the pork tenderloin and another pork dish which they liked very much.
For dessert, they had a some kind of an apple tart and bread pudding.  I tasted each one and found they were excellent.
The service was very attentive and efficient.
Items on the menu were very expensive so I would not return unless I was splurging.
author: Philip C.

description: Love this place!! I have gone 4 times for business lunches and every time the food and service have been great!!
author: Brandy O.

description:
I work in the same building, One Market.  I used to go to this restaurant until December 30, 2013.  I made a reservation for a Year-end Lunch on the day.  We arrived there 5 minutes before noon.  

The receptionist, a middle age women, was a kind of mean.  We had to wait in front of the reception more than 10 minutes.  The floor was not busy.  I thought they were preparing a nice table for us, but it was not.  

This place offers fantastic cuisine and skilled service.  However, I don't want to feel that embarrassing again. Now I really miss their pork tenderloin.
author: Happy D.

description:
I would love to give this place ZERO star if I can!! This place is THE WORST OF THE WORST!! Long story short, 1. The sever was rudely leaning on our booth while he taking our order.  2. We never got dessert that was included in our 3 course meal(and got charged for them when  we ordered), 3. The server was very rude by giving us the attitude when we were using the GIFT CARD!

I went to One Market few days before New years eve, and it was THE WORST experience Ive ever had. Well.. here is what happened when I went. 

1. A second we sat down, the server came. And guess what he said... 
"What do you want for drink? Wa-tah"? while he was leaning on our booth!! 
No info on drinks, just Wa-Tah?
- Both my parents and I were really shocked about his service. We found it so rude..
First of all, we havent even opened our drink menu yet, and he almost sounded like he was mimicking Asian accent for "Water" 
And Second, he was leaning on our seat while he was asking us for a drink (well, "wa-tah")....... What a service already!

2. Then my mom and I ordered 3 - course meal, and yes we never got the dessert. 
-After we finished the main course, we told our server that we were ready for the dessert (that was included 3 course meal!). But instead of giving us the dessert (as we ordered in 3 course), he brought the dessert menu. We were so confused, but ordered anyways because he did not say anything, so we assume this was how 3 course meal dessert was given.... No info was given. AGAIN!
- Obviously, on our check, there was 2 dessert we ordered. I do not understand why we never got the dessert that was already included in our 3 course meal. (or do they count soup + main course as THREE COURSE MEAL?) I wonder...  (I tried to call the server, but he just disappeared after... I guess he really wanted to go home, since it was officially closed?10pm? I do not know)

3. Then when we asked for a check, we told the server we would like to use the gift card. Oh gosh... He was giving us such an attitude for using them. WHY? 

Again... I am sorry One market, but this is just NONO
I am never coming back, and I really hope you could either train this server better, or fire him. 

+at least food runners were so nice. They were much more helpful, giving us info about food we ordered. I think they should rather be the servers :)
author: Yumi K.

description: Come on One Market really $74 a person for Thanksgiving dinner!!!! Love the atmosphere, the location is great. Service was OK but the pricing for what we had to choose from was bad at best. Two of us had Pork Tenderloin that was mostly inedible fat. My daughter had risotto that may have cost the restaurant $3. The food was tasty but let's think about the profit margins here. I know the employees had to work on a holiday, the place had to be open and we didn't have to spend hours and hours cooking and cleaning but there could be more of a compromise here. I get that businesses need to make money but not at the cost of losing potential future diners because of greed. We will not be back. Sorry!
author: Richard W.

description:
Christmas Eve dinner with the fam!

Apps:
Oysters
Lambs Tongue- unique! should definitely try.
Crab Salad
Beet Carpaccio- loved this dish! I love beets!

Entrees:
Scallops
Beef Cheeks
Wild Sturgeon
Prime Rib - my favorite out of the bunch!
Chicken Breast

Dessert:
Tropical Sorbet Trio
Dessert Sampler- came with Butterscotch pudding, chocolate cake, and creme brulee. YUMMM!! The pudding was awesome!

Overall, it was a good dinner but not amazing.
author: Angela D.

description:
Pancetta-wrapped fliet.  

Yes, I'll take a Lipitor with that on the side.  

But I wouldn't have cared as much if this dish, which came as part of the group dinner we were at, wasn't so salty. But it needed about 3 glasses of water too.

Yes, the service was decent, but overall, this felt like a bland restaurant. Nothing bad, but nothing stood out too -- (though the tuna ahi app was pretty good).  

But for $110 a person, it needs and should be better than this. Otherwise, we could've gone to Boulevard for that type of price. And Boulevard is just much much better.

Again, A-Ok.
author: Dan S.

description:
Great service. This really stood out.

Our group of 40 made a stop after a tour to have a private function/dinner here. They had set us up in a private room, completely separate from the main restaurant, woth a large bar, high tops and roundtables. It looked more like a hotel banquet than a restaurant, but it was ok.

Pros:
Pinot noir was amazing.
Caesar salad was delicious. 
The bacon wrapped pork loin, served medium rare, was an insta-hit. 
The filet mignon was soft, and enormous - the broccolini couldve been less acidic but overall it worked well.
Creme brulees were spectacular. I was left wanting more and I am not a creme brulee kind of girl. 

Cons:
Because it was separate, food had to be run from the restaurant, out to the windy streets of San Fran, and back in the side door. Thankfully food was never cold so it worked despite the interrupted logistics.

Overall a good dinner experience for the financial district.
author: Victoria D.

description:
