The gnocchi is quite delectable. I love how fine dining gives you smaller portions. I definitely do not want to leave somewhere feeling bloated.

We came on a Friday night with reservations at 8. The restaurant was a little backed up, so we had to wait, but we were seated pretty quickly. Our server was a little slow getting to us, but that's understandable. They were also out of the wine we wanted to order at dinner, but the cocktail I had was just fine. My date's scallops were cooked perfectly, and it was a pretty good night altogether. The ambience here also can't be beat. I mean, there's an actual guy playing piano by the bar. And, it actually isn't that pricey for some really high quality food.
author: Danny C.

description:
While I don't typically give 5-star reviews, I must say that my lunch at One Market this past week was exceptional and well deserving of the coveted 5-star Yelp rating.

I was having what one might refer to as a "bad day".  Traffic getting into downtown SF was like a bad horror movie that I couldn't escape from.  I was running 15 minutes late for my lunch so I decided to splurge and do valet parking for $15-certainly not inexpensive-but then again, after the morning I was having, I would have paid twice as much just to get out of the car, get some food in my stomach and spend some quality time with a dear friend. 

Within the span of 90 minutes, I was transformed from grumpy, hungry,frazzled business woman, to calm, relaxed, and satisfied woman.

Quality food, service and ambiance are three must-have's when I dine out.  One Market excels at all three.  First the food.  I've been going to One Market ever since it opened and always enjoy dining there.  Some how it's managed to withstand the test of time.  

We started our lunch off with a free sample of a beet carpaccio type dish with a dollop of chevre cheese that was out of this world. That was followed by a delicious Kabocha Squash Soup with pickled apples, toasted hazelnut and spiced crème fraîche.  It was the perfect texture, and the waiter was kind enough to split the bowl for my guest and I.  For beverages we both enjoyed a fresh glass of lemonade with a hint of ginger and pineapple.  It was so refreshing and a nice alternative to a glass of wine.  For main entree I ordered the Ahi Tuna burger that was cooked to perfection with mizuna & shaved fennel salad, saffron aioli.  I prefer my Ahi rare to medium-rare and that was exactly how it was served.  My guest ordered the Wild Gulf Shrimp "Louis".  It was a work of art. It was a unique presentation in that the salad was skillfully wrapped in four separate romaine of hearts circles bound together and topped with avocado and quail eggs.  Wow! Be sure to ask for some of the delicious fresh bread they serve.  One Market does not automatically bring bread anymore so be sure to ask for it.  I wish we had time for dessert but unfortunately we didn't.  The food continues to be consistently good at One Market.  I'm getting hungry just writing this review!

Service.  I'm a bit of a stickler when it comes to service.  SF restaurants are pricey.  My expectations of good service have increased in tandem with today's restaurant prices. I can't say enough about the service.  Our waiter, I believe his name was Ilsandro (hope I got this right?), was outstanding. He had a very pleasant demeanor, he was extremely knowledgeable about the menu and he was so friendly and easy to communicate with.  In fact, the next time I return, I would ask to be sat in his section he was that good.  One thing in particular that I appreciated was that he told us while reviewing the menu and specials, that they were out of the house-made Pappardelle with rock shrimp and lobster sauce.  A pet peeve of mine is when a food server does NOT inform you of the dishes they are out of until you're about to order.  Tell the customer what you're out of in ADVANCE-at the time you present the menu-not at the time you're ready to order and have your heart set on a particular menu item. Thank you Ilsandro!

Lastly, Ambiance. One of the many reasons I enjoy One Market so much (aside from the food) is the ambiance-big, sky-high ceilings so the acoustics are good.  You can actually have a conversation and hear the other person talking.  There is some privacy between tables.

All in all, the quality food, excellent service and soothing ambiance are what lead me to give it a 5-star rating.  I walked out of the restaurant feeling 100% better than before I walked in.  It's incredible that a good meal with one of my best girlfriends can transform my day (and me) from one of frustration to one of gratitude and appreciation for the simple pleasures in life.
author: Suzanne H.

description:
Very impressive!
We thoroughly enjoyed the Beast Feast - Lamb. Four courses paired with different wines.  Each course was a rare find and the wine pairing was great. Highly recommend this experience, great fun and delicious!
The wait staff is excellent!
author: Celeste A.

description:
I came here to kill time right before going to an event and it just so happen to be happy hour. Not wanting to drink, my colleague and I ordered some finger foods. 

The chickpea fries were great! 
Fried calamari was bomb.
Shrimp skewers were ehhhhhhhhhhhh...... (_ _") Maybe my tongue was off (probably not) but the foam was the nastiest thing I've ever tasted in my life. 

Other than that Place was great.
author: Mai W.

description: One of the best meals we ever had and phenomenal ambiance.  Mortimer was a great and knowledgeable server who led us to all the right choices.  The wine was fantastic and in July was half off. It started with amazing bread (you can always judge a restaurant by its bread!).  Sourdough olive.  Octopus and fois gras amazing.  We loved our main courses of scallops and the halibut.  The scallops were surrounded by a fantastic foam.  Really classy.  topped off with amazing desserts.  Views!  Right across from the Embarcadero.
author: Joel R.

description:
Yooooooooo!!! Dis iz dat fancy shiit. Me and my homies walked in like damn we ain't fancy. Errbody dressed nice and shit. Whatevs, Cali don care.

Damn dey food iz fine. It look good lik dat chick from da block errbody tryna hit up, but taste good lik a clean girrl.

Tryna be classy and shit I orda de ahi tuna. Damn fish is my shit! I like dem southern fried fish, but dis tuna hellllaaa good!

De waita was my motherfuckin man. My dude tod us about some good shit to get at the giants game! That dude supa cool!

Dis dat kinda place u gotz to bring yo lady wen u iz tryna get it in. U wine & dine her den u go home and she get freaky wit u

This place was delicious! The food was amazing and the server staff was great. It's a little pricey, but treat yourself for once, you deserve it. You will not be disappointed.
author: BlackItalianDoe R.

description:
WONDERFUL experience!

It was me and four others at the Chef's Table (back in the kitchen!) where I believe they can have parties of 4-7 people. This is a tasting menu and I chose the option of adding wine to each course via the wine pairing. ALL of the food was amazing, not to mention the fantastic wines! The variety of the food & wine was impressive too. Matthew, our waiter, was extremely friendly, knowledgable and his service was spot-on!

The mount and quality of the food was great for the price, not to mention a much more reasonable wine-pairing than other places. Good ambiance is a must for a big dinner like this and One Market didn't disappoint! I watched many of the kitchen staff working hard on some impressive-looking food! We even got a tour of the restaurant, hung out in the wine room for a bit and was told all about the restaurant and the food. Two from our table even got to go help make the desserts!

One Market was no only an amazing meal but an amazing experience! Even better, the price was just! I'll definitely be back!
author: Jordan M.

description:
I went here for a company dinner with a fixed menu so my review is just on the food I never saw a menu or the prices. 

We started with a variety of bite sized appys - Ahi Tuna, risotto bites,  beef dip bites. I liked them all and the service was fantastic waiters coming by every 60 seconds with something new. 

Then into a salad. I don't remember much other than it had blue cheese and was really good. 

Then the best part: the steak! That was impressive. Usually group dinner steaks are terrible. Everything gets cooked medium and they often sit under headlamps getting dry as 100 other steaks are made. 

Not the case here. Great flavorful steak. 

I should also point out most restaurants and steakhouses fail to impress me - I bought a $3000 piece of lab equipment called an immersion circulator - also know as Souis Vide.  So I can make a damn good steak at home. 

Last came an excellent dessert. A pear tart. 

Also the wine they served was excellent and my glass never got empty. Waiters came every few minutes.
author: Chris S.

description: This is a more expensive American restaurant with a menu that is somewhat interesting. I came with a Meetup group. They were trying the Dine About Town option, which seemed decent. I didn't feel like having pork chop, fish, or gnudi, so I ended up getting a hamburger. I have eaten all kinds of hamburgers in my life, but I hadn't had one in a while. I got it medium rare for some reason, and it was too rare in some parts. I liked it. It came with cole slaw and potato tots. I would come here again and try something more adventurous. I also got a lemonade, which was overpriced at 4.75. They made it slushy. Nice interior and location near the Embarcadero.
author: Denise C.

description:
I'll break this apart in 2 bits... the food and the wine.

The food - there's some nice diversity without being overwhelming on the choices when going through the menu.  I was with a large group so I got to try a few different appetizers, and saw most of the entree's.  The steak looked like the best option if you're hungry.  I went with an off-the-menu special which was a veal water buffalo.  I'd give that 4.5-5 stars all by itself.  It was great!  However, let me back up to the appetizers.  Now that foie gras is legal again in SF they had it on the menu, so I had to try it.  It was good, but not great.  It was over seared and the arrangement didn't pop.  For a $25 starter I expected more flavor.  Maybe I'm just comparing their foie to the incredible foie I had at another restaurant in SOMA the night before.  Given 4.5 stars for the entree and 2.5 stars for the appetizer I'll average that to be 3 stars.

Now for the wine list.  It was good diversification for a place that's not specifically known for wine.  They had several of the staples that you'd expect from known California wineries as well as a few of the more "specialized" wineries that aren't as common to see on a wine list.  The prices, well...they were restaurant prices and given the location of this restaurant they weren't 2x of retail they were 3x of retail.  Not unexpected given the location.  I did have one bottle that was corked and the waitress promptly replaced it with another one that was fine (same vintage and producer) as you'd expect.

The service was ok.  They were pretty slammed when my party of 8 got there.  However, given the amount we spent I would have expected a soda faster than 10 minutes.  

Finally, just FYI...due the size of my group I fully expected gratuity to be on the ticket however it wasn't.  I'm glad we checked instead of just assuming gratuity would be added on for the size of our group.  I'm not sure if our group was too small for auto-gratuity or if it was just overlooked.  We wanted to take care of the waitress appropriately for the service.
author: Ben F.

description:
I went here for dinner and decided to partake in the three course menu for $40. Sadly, two of the three courses were a bit of a disappointment. I had the carrot soup, the pork tenderloin, and the mint ice cream sandwich. The soup was overpowering, and I felt like I was drowning in excessive amounts of Chinese five spice. The bacon wrapped pork tenderloin was excellent. It was on a bed of spinach and very tender, cooked perfectly. The ice cream sandwich was sandwiched between two excellent cookies, but the ice cream itself was way to "minty."  

The warm bread was delicious, and the beer on tap was very cold and went down great. The inside of the restaurant had a nice vibe, and I couldn't help but chuckle when the waiter told us that the catch of the day was from sustainable resources in accordance with the Monterey Bay Aquarium (there was even literature about it!! Portlandia anyone?LOL)
author: Erica K.

description:
OMGDTFKPORG!

I have been here on and off over the years, but my latest special occasion dinner here was beyond dining, it was a peak experience, one of the ten most memorable meals I've had in this town.

That was, goat tartare (who knew raw goat meat is so delicious), goat shoulder with homemade square pasta (like sugo, only better), goatchiuto -- a huge hunk of prosciutto made out of goat wrapped in goat bacon, and then goat milk ice cream. Plus, thanks to their July wine promotion, a $55 bottle of massive Cabernet Franc that would cost more than $55 if you bought it at the store. 

How good was this? It was so good we decided to walk a mile and a half back home instead of taking the cab, and the world sparkled with wonderment, I felt elevated.

This isn't the first time it happened, of my 5-10 dinners here, at least three of them were elevated experiences like this.

First, you have to understand the Weekly Beast. It's a moderately-priced fixed-course meal offered on certain saturdays and sundays ($49 for 4 courses, half the price or less compared to similar offerings) based on their acquiring one big animal or several smaller ones from a local farm. The chef then designs an entire menu around that, using all kinds and parts of the animal. But he goes beyond that, he kind of imagines some cuisine, whether Moroccan, Mexican, Japanese, you can never tell what he's going to do, but all in a high end French style.

The regular menu is a lot more expensive, price and concept are midway between casual fancy places like Zuni or Slanted Door, and higher end places like Gary Danko, Saison, or Coi. $100 / person seems about right here.

This is food that goes a step beyond, it has the magic dust of inspiration, like a music concert or a tour of a museum it makes you think. Unlike some other restaurants that make art out of food, everything here was professional and accommodating, food was tasty, portions were ample!

The location and decor are epic, basically big windows overlooking the Bay and the Bay Bridge. Fancy, white tablecloth. Most people are a little older here, some in their 30s, many in their 50s and 60s. 

Service is a little funky. The waiters are all experienced veterans, but a number of them (including ours tonight) let a little too much personality hang out, just a little TMI with your meal. But a special shout-out to the host stand and one of the best hosts in SF, and a great wine director here too.
author: Gil S.

description: Food was great waiter was a pretentious freak trying to up sell everything. I don't need an idiot reading the specials to me off the menu. If there off menu items fine tell me those. Left a bad impression with my client, will not return. Once again food was great.
author: Manny G.

description: We were here for a business dinner and I would absolutely not come here on my own account. One of my co-workers ordered smoked salmon and could not eat it as it has a bad smell to it. A few other co-workers are vegetarian and all they have is a pasta dish that didn't live up to expectations and for $23! I had a better homemade pasta dish this weekend at Bistro Tupaz in San Jose for less than $10. Service is not worth any mention as well.
author: Carl E.

description: Hubby and I came here for dinner over the weekend. Very much the financial crowd that was seated around us. But the food was fantastic. I had the John Dory and he had the steak, which was cooked to perfection. 4 star review because we were seated almost 30 min past our reservation with no update in between.
author: Marissa W.

description:
Decent for a work lunch meeting, but way too pricey for something only decent.

The crab cakes were good, but the portion was super small. It was over too quickly! The roasted half chicken was what you'd expect, other than the fact that it was not sufficiently better than a supermarket rotisserie chicken to justify the price. :(  I'd give it another shot if I was in the neighborhood and try something different.
author: Denise L.

description:
One Market is the perfect spot for a business lunch - good food, warm atmosphere that is serious without being overly formal, great location.  The food is pricey, but very well executed.  If you're really hungry and looking to shave a few bucks off the bill, they do have a "Business Lunch" (prix fixe) option.  I came with 7 colleagues and not a single complaint or criticism was heard.  I would certainly come back again.

POTATO TOTS: These things are enormous.  Far better tha the frozen things you get at the grocery store.  The tots are crisp on the outside and fluffy on the inside.

HEIRLOOM YELLOW TOMATO & MUSSEL SOUP: Tomatoes and mussels aren't a combination that usually comes to mind, but this was a real success.  The broth was light yet very flavorful while the mussels added a nice amount of briny flavor.

RISOTTO: Kudos to the chef for the risotto, some of the best I've had.  Perfectly cooked with fresh, crisp peas, a good amount of ham hock, and sorrel on top.  The sorrel added some sourness/acidity to the creamy risotto.  Texture, flavor, balance - it was all there.
author: Chris C.

description:
One thing I hate is when a restaurant makes me feel like they're doing me a favor by serving me dinner. Or, worse, making me feel like I'm inconveniencing them. I made a reservation for 8 while in town for a trade show. I had to call them back because some people canceled on me. I called once right away to change to 7. About 45 minutes before the reservation, I called again when another team member canceled on me and I changed it to 6 people. When we arrived, the hostess was full of attitude, "It will be a wait. We have to reconfigure the tables and that takes time." Once seated, we waited over 10 minutes until we had to interrupt a server walking by to get our waiter so we could order drinks. It just felt like they were annoyed with us. And the restaurant was not full. 

The menu was quite limited and expensive for the quality and quantity of the food. Vegetarian options were minimal for our one vegetarian guest. I had the rabbit pot pie and it was fine but nothing exceptional. After dinner the waiter dropped off the check and I reserved an Uber. The waiter disappeared for some time and we were all waiting to pay the check so we could go. The Uber arrived and I had still not seen our waiter come back to take our check. We finally had to flag someone else down. 

If the food had been exceptional, I may have been OK with the price, noise level, and attitude. but it just wasn't that great. Not worth it and won't go again.
author: George H.

description:
I came to One Market for a business lunch recently, and was excited after seeing their Michelin star sitting proudly on the counter at the reception area.  I had been meaning to try here, but it was always hard to justify paying that much money for lunch and there are too many better places in the area for dinner.  Anyway, there were four of at the table (two of them were our interview candidates, so it was sort of a tenuous situation), but we ordered two appetizers to share and everyone got their own meal.  We ordered the following:

Appetizers:
-Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout "Mi Cuit" potato røsti, pancetta vinaigrette, pastured chicken egg: I'm actually not a big fan of trout, so I sort of freaked out and ended up just eating the pancetta on the plate.  It wasn't much, but everyone at the table thought it was incredible.  I should note that the reason we got this was because they had run out of their crab cakes that day.  It's 12:30pm in prime lunch hour and you've run out a signature item?  There's something not right with that.  Our waiter kept coming back to this item, so we caved and ended up with this.  

-Oysters on the Half Shell: YUM YUM YUM.  Usually I'm not a big fan of fishy slimy things, but I adore oysters, especially when there's a great sauce or garnish to go with it.  I really enjoyed their couple of sauce options that came out on the beautifully presented plate.  We each had one, but I was secretly wishing that someone would pass on their oyster.

Mains:
-Roasted All Natural Half Chicken braised cipollini, chicken jus with a side of Roasted Brussels Sprouts Applewood Smoked Bacon: To be totally honest, I enjoyed the brussel sprouts more than the chicken.  I mean these brussel sprouts were cooked to where they were slightly crispy and cooked in the bacon.  I mean, I could go on and on about how awesome these things were.  Ultimately, I finished the brussel sprouts when I couldn't really finish all the chicken.  The chicken itself was moist with great skin, but, and maybe this was my fault, it was just chicken.

-Two people ordered the Grilled Salmon:  The piece of fish was presented PERFECTLY on the plate.  I didn't get to try it, but it looked beautiful.  Both people finished their plates.

-House-Made Potato Gnocchi Liberty Farms duck leg, yellow foot chanterelles, natural jus: This was my second choice from a food perspective, and when it came out, I was slightly envious.  My co-worker said that the duck was absolutely delicious and the gnocchi was cooked perfectly.  Next time, I'd be interested in trying this dish.

The service here was OK, I wasn't sure about our waiter who seemed a little pushy on getting us to order more things.  Ultimately, we were able to have our time to talk to each other uninterrupted and it turned out to being a pretty good meal.  I'm not sure if I'd go back, but I certainly think that for a business lunch, it was perfect.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Would be five stars if the portions were not so skimpy!!

Most of the food tasted excellent - especially the duck - though again, the portion given my husband was not enough food for a grown man!  My red snapper was a larger portion, and the potato and cauliflower sides were terrific.

The artichoke soup appetizer was beautifully presented, but tasted a bit bland.

The complimentary tuna appetizers presented courtesy of the chef were nothing special, and again, extremely tiny.

When rolls were offered, two of us chose the french roll and two of us chose the sourdough.  The sourdough was the standout-- it was an olive sourdough-- just delicious!

The teeny tiny dessert tasted great.  When it came time to order dessert, I asked the waiter if I could share with my three tablemates.  The waiter said that would be fine, and he set out normal-sized forks and spoons for all four of us to share.  So I did not expect the teeniest, tiniest dessert ever created to arrive at the table!
author: A K.

description: A friend took me for my birthday. We both ordered the grilled trout and we were both dissatisfied. Fish was fine but it sat on some kind of soupy mess.  Worse than that was the supposed signature desert --hazelnut chocolate torte....$11.00!!!! Very overpriced and fairly mundane stuff. I've had better meals before at One Market...they need to be more consistent.
author: Christina S.

description: Service was excellent.  Very friendly and comfortable, nice location, ambiance, etc.  Food was thoughtfully and expertly prepared. Traditional flavors, the menu choices are pretty average fine dining American style.  The wine list was great and the cocktails were much more contemporary than the dinner menu, excellent.
author: Melissa G.

description:
Men is sharp suits and stiff vodka martinis equals a panty dropping event for women of all ages (21 and over).

The white collar crowd will have a field day here networking after a long work week in the shadow of San Francisco's business district. The steaks are tender, waiters flowing through the crowded hustle tendering to your every want and desire. Really I just want an cold martini.

Desserts are highly caloric so don't even think of coming here in the middle of a starvation diet. Just get the fucking ice cream sandwich and enjoy.
author: Jeri T.

description:
The first half of our meal, the six item tasting menu, was fabulous. Delicate flavors artistically juxtaposed. Wine pairings that were surprising and delightful. Then something happened.  There was a delay in our next course coming out. Long enough that our server came over to apologize for the wait. The remaining two courses both suffered from over salting of the vegetable component of the dishes. All of the courses were constructed to create a harmony of flavors. With one part nearly inedible, the dish lacked the balance and harmony of the earlier courses. For both of those courses we left the salty part Uneaten. Overall the service was OK. But the server did not inquire "how was the dish?" after the first couple of courses, and there is a team of servers, not just one. As a consequence it was not til dessert that I got a chance to inquire what had happened and let our server know about the sudden saltiness. She conferred with her manager and a small adjustment to the bill was made. 
Overall it was a very uneven meal. Very good and some parts nearly inedible. Desserts were only OK.  The kitchen has some issues.
author: Kendra H.

description:
4* One Market
SF
Nice holiday luncheon
Tasty house bread
Good wines by the glass
Friendly food service by Ryan
Loved the pecan bleu cheese salad
Lamb sugo was fantastic
Chicken was tasty
Killer chocolate almond toffee dessert
Holiday luncheon specials
author: Rosquete B.

description: Terrible mothers day experience.  They had two choices and ran out of the fish option.  Really mediocre food, not even hot, flavorless.  And expensive.  We won't return.
author: Matthew M.

description: Scallops were delicious.  Service was a bit slow and the bread wasn't warm for dinner.  The ambiance is lovely, there was a pianist there at dinnertime.  When I came for lunch the service was much better.  The vibe is very business-like and caters to high end professionals.  Great location by the Ferry Building and Embarcadero BART.
author: Natassia K.

description:
It was a GNO and our sole purpose of dining here was for the foie gras. Since the ban is temporarily lifted, we had to take advantage of it. They didn't have a foie gras entree, but we asked if they can make the starter into one and the answer was yes. Our server was excited by the fact that we came here for that. The cocktails were good, the bread was good, the food came out in a timely manner and we really enjoyed our dinner. For the 5 of us, it came out to about $100 each. Not too shabby.

I was really wowed by the Cripsy Pig Ear salad. It's was almost like bacon. I think I have to go back for that next time. The foie gras entree was doubled the starter size. It was filling. It came seared and in a broth. Really good and honestly, if the portion was any bigger we wouldn't be able to finish it. It's located at the end/start of Market so parking shouldn't be a big problem at night. I would definitely return to try other dishes.
author: Julie V.

description:
I went here for lunch during restaurant week. My food was good,  but the service was disappointing.  

I expect at a high-end place the servers understand the delicate art of being, friendly, attentive and giving their patrons space. 

The server I had was aggressively attentive and it became unpleasant. Definitely not fitting for the space. Some examples:

1.  After delivering our main courses the server stopped by 3 times to ask us how our food was over about a 5 minute period
2.  The patron next to us tried to speed up the pace of his meal by offering his card to the server and asking the server to put in his dessert request. The server was almost defensive the patron didn't say "he was in a rush."  
3.  The server came to our table and asked us several times if we were in a hurry so she could speed up our food. We replied we were not in a rush so it wasn't a concern, but we kept getting asked the question. 

It ended up feeling awkward each time our server came by and dampened the experience. 

I was expecting a lot more polish from this restaurant.
author: Jame E.

description:
Decided to meet a friend for happy hour...
Worst decision in my life...

Arrived at 5:45.  Sat in the bar, far table in back by window.
Server did not come to ask for my drink order until....6:05...NO JOKE!!!

Ordered a Martini...
She returned 10 minutes later and told me that she forget to put my order into the bar!!!!
I am not kidding!!!!

My friend arrived.  We ordered calamari, (tasted tough and frozen). sliders, (extremely cold), and tater tots, (again frozen and cold).

A terrible way to start a beautiful weekend in SF.

Service-0
Food-0

With so many great spots for happy hour, this is NOT RECOMMENDED!!!
We will not return, and will spread the word.

Shame on you One Market.
author: Dr. Octagon O.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while since they hold one Michelin star. I originally wanted to take my parents here but instead my brother took us all out. My brother told me I've been here years ago, maybe 10+ but I was too young to even remember. 

I opted for the Weekly Beast four course tasting menu which featured beef the weekend I went. The tasting menu came with carpaccio, braised beef cheeks, grilled N.Y. steak and rhubarb brown butter tart. The carpaccio was great. The braised beef cheeks were a little filling but that was good because the steak wasn't filling enough. The steak was good but I really didn't enjoy my dessert. Well I'm a little bias because I'm not much of a dessert person. 

Overall the food was decent but the service was terrible. The waiter needed a serious attitude check but by the end of the meal he was a little better maybe because he wanted us to tip more. Also I don't really know how restaurants get rated for Michelin stars. I've been to many restaurants more deserving than this one.
author: Sean W.

description:
I came here during the June Dine About Town. First time trying a Michelin starred restaurant, so DAT gave me a reason to go. 

Unfortunately, I was not impressed with the food. They had two DAT menus, I went with the deluxe one with crab soup, duck breast with foie gras sausage, and panna cotta. I added wine pairing to my dinner as well. If I'm going to try a Michelin starred place, and if the prices are reasonable for my to splurge, why not add in the wine pairing to enhance the food?

The crab soup was very rich and creamy, but presentation wasn't that incredible. My date and I ordered the same soup, yet my server poured the soup over my butter, which spreads all around the soup. It didn't look pretty under the camera lens. The tastes saved its face.

My entree, the seared duck breast with foie gras sausage, was very disappointing. I've had better ones at  Isa. The duck breast here was a bit tough to chew, and wasn't as rare as it should have been. The sauce was a bit too sweet for the dish, it was a bit overwhelming and took away the spotlight of the main ingredient itself. Perhaps it may be the pricing of the DAT menus, but that foie gras sausage was a waste. It tasted just like a regular sausage except in cubic form. It wasn't anything eye opening in terms of tastes and presentation.

My panna cotta dessert looked very cute, with wafers here and there. That was the best part of it all. Portions were huge. I could only finish half of the dessert. It was rich and tarty at the same time, odd but that's how it is. Richness came from the creamy portion of the panna cotta, and the tart came from the fruits and syrup on the side. 

Wine pairing wasn't too great. Maybe I was too inexperienced with wines, but my meal wasn't enhanced by the wine in any way. Also, they paired all the foods with the same wines. Again, not experienced enough to know if that worked well. But I doubt I would want to do the wine pairing next time.

DAT was a nightmare. I do feel like it wasn't doing One Market any justice, since it was locked down to sell at a certain price. I would come back in another season to try their regular menu items or their regular tasting menus. Hopefully my experience will be better then.
author: Connie C.

description:
The service was horrible!! 

We were left unattended for nearly 15 min before we got water and had a chance to order our cocktails, then again didn't see our waiter for 20 min, he came back with our cocktails & helped us choose a bottle of wine and then again, was MIA.. 

They didn't have any nice vegetarian dishes, salads or appetizers... except the sides (which were all delicious) 

We ended up ordering a variety of cheeses from the dessert menu to start and the lamb tongue which we asked for twice but never came.. 

We got pretty much all the sides - the chic pea fries were the best! But all tasted great !

They have a cool trio of desserts you can select from and those were fantastic as well! 

Also, awesome cocktail menu!! 

As great as everything was, the service killed it... Actually, even the host was cold when she greeted us..
author: Shanna N.

description:
How does a Michelin star restaurant get a 3-star rating? Good food + shitty service, that's what I discovered after my experience here.

Came with a small group of friends for the Dine About Town menu on a Saturday night. To break it down, here's how my evening here went from great to down the drain in a matter of 2.5 hours.

Food:
I opted for the Sunchoke Veloute, Grilled Berkshire Pork Chops, and the Carrot Cake Cheesecake.
- They were all really good, but my favorite by far were the pork chops. They were cooked to perfection and were covered in a really good sauce. The pork pretty much melted in my mouth, which is rare because being able to make a slab of pork that thick tender and well-marinated can be a pretty difficult task.

Now, on to the service.

Initially, the service seemed great. Our waitress was very friendly and attentive. But as our meal progressed, it seemed as if she had just stopped paying attention to our table. For example, we were out of bread and water, and after 10 minutes of waiting for her to ask us if we wanted more, we ended up just asking ourselves. We ended up asking 3 different waiters/waitresses and waiting about TWENTY MINUTES until we actually got more bread and water. Are you kidding me??? We also sat there for another 15 minutes AFTER we finished our dessert to ask for the bill. I don't know how they were trained, but from common sense if you see your table has completely finished their meals, wouldn't you ask them if they would like the check?

The thing that blew my last straw was that on our way out, 3 members of the staff were standing there at the podium, and as they were watching us walk out the door, they didn't even bother to say thank you, or any words at all.

Yeah, your food is awesome, props to your chefs, but I'm pretty appalled by the lack of good customer service skills from a restaurant that was awarded a Michelin star.
author: Angela K.

description:
Carrot puree done badly. Fibers everywhere. 

steamed halibut. Not even an attempt to season or sear. 

Shame on you Bradley Ogden for making a nice evening sour (horrible wine pairing with the halibut too).
author: Ray J.

description: Went here yesterday for a business lunch. Fantastic service. I love the grilled flounder. No skin and the filet was perfectly crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. It was perfectly seasoned as well to my taste buds, light but fresh. I also had the Cesar salad which I loved. I love the whole romaine leaves served and just the hearts. The mint lemonade was great but next time I would order it without sugar as it was a little sweet for me. Overall great expierence.
author: Jen C.

description: Eaten here a few times over a few year period and the menu, food and service is consistently  good, damn good!.
author: Louise P.

description:
Rounding up from 3.5 stars. I have been here 3 times, twice for dinner and and once for a work lunch. Both dinners were top notch, definitely a 4-star, Michelin experience. Lunch, on the other hand, was just ok. Still good, but definitely not as good as dinner and it didn't come off to my coworkers (who are foodies) like a Michelin-rated place or anything impressive. Maybe it's just the lunch menu.

Here's what's deelish (from dinner):
-Bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin - I've had this twice, both times it was pretty bomb
-Hand picked dungenous crab - i remember this being particularly good/fresh. we ended up ordering a second one!
-Pumpkin cheesecake with brittled pepitas - I've had this twice, BOMB.COM award winner. I will be be back for it this fall!

I've also had the tuna tombo salad at lunch time (solid, didn't blow my mind), shrimp bisque (it was decent; had sort of a southern flavor), and sides like the chickpea frieds (pretty good), tater tots (ok), and spinach (ok).

I def recommend it for dinner! Lunch, maybe.
author: Erica L.

description:
Sometimes Foodies spend too much time asking "What's New?" and not enough time asking "What's Good?"

One Market isn't new to the San Francisco Financial District/Embarcadero, but it still manages to raise the bar with high quality, creative and innovative food. They also provide a level of service (professional, yet friendly) that's every bit as good with the food.

During our visit today, we just couldn't decide which part of our lunch was the best. It was all so amazing that it was impossible to pick and dish that you wouldn't go back for over and over.

We started with crab cakes that contained no filler. They were simply crab, butter and some herbs. They were by far the best crab cakes I've ever had and is from someone who used to live in Seattle, where there's no shortage of excellent seafood. We also had smoked trout served on roshti with an egg yolk. When mixed together, it was a fantastic combination of texture and taste. By the way, the greens served with the crab cakes were excellent and would have made a great flavorful salad dish even without the crab cakes.

While enjoying a bottle of Argyle Chard from the Willamette Valley, we moved on to the entrees. Tombo Tuna Salad was cooked perfectly with the tune just lightly seared and sashimi on the inside. Combined with a light sauce and some pancetta, it was excellent, both light and satisfying at the same time. We also got the housemade gnocchi, which was prepared in a simple brown butter with a generous amount of wild mushrooms. The two made a great combination.

I really can't emphasize enough just how good the service was. From the person who looked up our reservation and directed is to a nice table in the back of the restaurant to our server who had some great recommendations to the bus boy who was friendly and seemed genuinely pleased we were enjoying out food, we felt welcomed and appreciated during the entire experience. 

It''s easy to see why this San Francisco institution manages to fill every seat during lunchtime on a Friday, it's all about what's good.
author: Eric W.

description:
Cheapest one-star Michelin ever (which is a good thing).

Amuse Bouche: melon, smoked salmon, chives, sesame seeds

1st course: Seasonal salad: grilled yellow peaches, prosciutto, arugula, fennel, radish, olive oil

Main: bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin; day boat scallops (only 4) with diced tomatoes, cepe mushrooms, red quinoa

Side: giant tater tots are awesome

Dessert: Chocolate toffee almond crunch cake

The amuse and salad were standard, though the grilled peaches were pretty delicious.  The scallops were sparse and lacked the bite of a nice sear.  Yes, yes, there is a schism in the Church of Scallop on the importance of the sear.  If you're not a hardcore sear fiend, then the scallops are pretty close to perfect here.  If you are such a proponent, you might be less than enthused.  My date for the evening was the latter and suggested scallops at Redd.

Unfortunately, they ran out of the filet mignon.  The pork tenderloin and was not bad and well-prepared though nothing special.  I loved the texture of the tater tots, a real winner against those you might be used to.  Also, +1 for GIANT tater tots.  They made me smile =)

I love their attention to fresh, seasonal farmers market ingredients but hate the disconnect between good ingredients and good execution.  The ambiance is corporate but laid-back, the service was understated (ahem, read sometimes hard to find) but friendly and didn't mind that we took our time.  This we took to our advantage to sneak in a passing friend for a few minutes to try some our dishes.
author: Timothy Y.

description:
My family and I ate here the other weekend while visiting SF. We all enjoyed our food, and had good a good Pinor noir with wine. There were 7 of us at dinner, so a lot of different dishes were ordered. I enjoyed the brussel sprouts and the crab cakes a lot. I ordered the salmon for my entree. It was a good cut, but it was far too rare for me. It was charred nicely, but the inside was basically raw. I hardly ever send food back, but it wasn't edible, IMO. Three of us ended up sending back our salmon for it to be cooked a bit more. It was still pretty rare when it came back after being in the kitchen for 10 minutes.

Dinner was good, overall.
author: Tom M.

description:
The food was 4 star.

The location is 5 star.

The ambience is great, so 4 stars.

Our waiters were good, so 4 stars.

Manager stopped by to make sure we were satisfied!
author: Best P.

description:
Come for: duck breast, sides
Skip: toffee crunch cake

The duck breast is amazing! Too bad the andouille thay comes with it isn't as impressive. Must order the cauliflower and brussel sprouts. Get the creme brulee duo but skip the toffee crunch cake.
author: Lise N.

description:
Came with family and had a good overall experience.  We were seated at a large table close to the kitchen which was both good and bad.  Good to see the care with which the food is prepared, bad because the head waiter was barking orders in a unpleasant tone most of the night.

Starters ordered included Tasmanian Trout, Pork Belly, Caesar Salad, and Lamb Tongue.  

Main Courses:  Scallops, Bacon wrapped pork, Duck Breast, and Steak.

Everything was solidly executed with the Tasmanian Trout, Seared Scallops and Bacon wrapped pork being the stand outs.

Good service, nicely prepared food, and pleasant ambiance without being too formal make One Market worthy of the occasional return visit.
author: Norman G.

description:
I've been to this place many times since it opened. I would classify it as nice to very good. The one thing that has remained constant over the years is that the portions are not large. Do not come with a huge appetite unless you plan on getting an appetizer + entree at the very least. 

I went with two coworkers and we ordered the lamb tongue plus the crab cakes. The tongue was very rich which is why it was sliced so thin. It was good, but probably something I wouldn't order again. We also split crab cakes, but each crab cake was about the size of half a golf ball; merely one bite and it was gone. 

Entree-wise, since it was crab season, we all ordered the crab pasta, which was quite good. However ... no leftovers to take away for dinner that night. I also have to note that it took about 30 minutes for our entrees to arrive -- not very relaxing when you know you have to get back to the office in a timely manner.

A solid meal overall and a crowd pleaser, with consistent service.
author: Lori M.

description:
I am a little late on writing this review. We booked the chefs table back in October 2013 for my companys 25th Anniversary party. We are a small company, so even with our spouses there was a whopping 6 of us!

Service was great from the moment I called to make the reservation. The chefs table is a bit cramped, but what do you expect when there is a table placed in the kitchen???

We were the new chefs first tasting menu (I am sorry I forgot his name). He did great and served us with many more courses than we expected. He was very charming and really made you understand his inspiration behind every course. 

Most of us were non-drinkers, but a couple of our guests requested pairings from the somelier. She was great but very busy (granted we didn't request her services until we got there). I loved listening to her talk and she was so knowledgeable, but I guess that is her job!

We received a tour of the restaurant, including the wine cellar. Very cool indeed! I believe it was the manager who gave us the tour, he was very energetic and amazing!

I was able to don a chefs jacket and assist in the pastry kitchen making our desserts. Actually it was just finishing them off and adding the final touches. 

Great evening and great food! I would come back in a heartbeat!
author: Melissa B.

description:
One Market holds a special place in my heart for so many reasons not just because it's an easy and convenient stop for me after my workout and few steps from the BART station (if in case, you'll get too tipsy and you'll struggle your way out), this is a favorite place of mine simply because the food and drinks are great. 

I always sit at the bar area even if I would come here to have dinner. I hate calling for reservations or appointments, doing so avoids me from doing this. Plus, I don't have to be dressy if I set in the bar area. My first meal was the Alaskan Halibut "Sous Vide", $28.50.  The right amount of sourness of the bouquerones (anchovy marinated in salt, vinegar, garlic & parsley) gave the dish a distinct taste and the sweetness of the sweet 100 tomatoes and summer squash complimented and balanced the flavor, an eruption of flavors in my mouth.

I've always loved their bar bites. The calamari is my favorite $9.25 an order. I've had their One Market sliders and their Rock Shrimp Tacos (this I had to order twice, couldn't get enough), they were all good.

The gentlemen behind the bar are always willing and able to  make you cocktails that suit your desire if there is something else specific that you want besides those that they already have in their menu. Hooray to Dylan and Shante! Average cocktail  drink is $9-10 and beer is $4.50. 

Great foods, great drinks, great times. Been here 28 times!
author: Lora M.

description:
This is a great place for a power lunch. Service was excellent and I expected the food to not be as exciting/well-prepared as it was. Had the Shrimp Louie and tried the Tombo Tuna. 

Next time will try the $22.50 business lunch when I am hungrier...
author: Karen S.

description:
I should give them an additional star for the chutzpah to serve ravioli in foamy water as a specialty. It tasted as it looked. I was invited and had a great conversation with a new acquaintance. No complaints there. Also the water and bread were OK. I left hungry and had to pick up a cheese sandwich to calm my rumbling stomach. 

Food was nicely served but ultimately disgusting. So in a sense it was good that there was do little. 

Ravioli need a heavy white sauce an attempts to make the dish lighter can be overdone - lighter and lighter and even lighter - and suddenly you end up with white water...

Forget this place. There is great food across the street at the Ferry Building. I'll try to post a photo of the food.
author: Flo B.

description: Every dish tasted like thought and care went into it.  The hand made polenta was awesome!   The octopus amazing!  My poached halibut melted in my mouth. Smoked salmon was very unique!   The smoked salt margarita was delicious!
author: Amanda S.

description: Food was adequate but terrible service for a restaurant spring to be upscale. Wait staff seemed disinterested, every request was met with an air of "I'm doing you a favor". Ttook almost ten minutes to just get water, another ten to take drink orders, and another five to order food.  When the check came the waiter spent most of his time chatting with the other staff instead of taking our card. Avoid.
author: R T.

description:
If I were lucky enough to find Donald Trump's cash-stuffed wallet in the FiDi, where would I go?  HELLO ONE MARKET!  

In a private dining room, I sampled fine wines and had the opportunity to choose a 4-course meal from a pre-determined selection.  Pure deliciosity ensued:

*  Some sort of lemon-grass and crab soup which arrived as just a dollop of something in a bowl but was soon joined by the pouring over of some sort of creamy manna from heaven

*  Paper-thin slices of "Beet Carpaccio" elegantly presented 

*  Perfect piece of medium rare Angus New York Steak 

*  Ample serving of "Fruit Sorbet" accompanied by a decorative and tasty piece of waffle cone.    

I missed the opportunity to sit inside the beautiful restaurant and witness all the other patrons blowing money out their ears but beggars can't be choosy.  I was happy just to be here.

One Market has a beautiful bar area, weekday happy hour cocktail specials until 7 p.m., and 732 people who have reviewed the place before me.  It's a beautiful, high quality place that screams "expense account" however, In true California/Bay Area style, patrons here can feel equally comfortable dressed to impress or casually clad.  it's not uppity; just pricey.   

It won't help a whole lot, but right now Costco is selling $100 gift cards to One Market (and associated restaurants: Lark Creek, Yankee  Pier, etc.) for $79.99.
author: Tracey A.

description: Spent New Years here. Dinner was fixed menu and no where near price. Every dish was some weird pairing and there were no standards. The oysters were poor and the venison was all bone. Nowhere worth price
author: Michael L.

description: Great spot for a nice dinner. Took my team there for a team dinner. Food was delicious, cocktails perfect and service excellent.
author: Arnaud D.

description:
Went here Saturday night for a friend's 30th birthday (she's a baby), We were with a party of 10 and our table was in an odd spot. Almost halfway between the kitchen and the main dining room but really in neither.

I really didn't care for our waiter at first (I'll spare his name) as he seemed almost combative when it came to wine. We all brought bottle. We brought a chardonnay and a 2009 Pinot Noir. We asked if he could chill the white and he acted disgusted. "You actually want to chill it? You know it's going to be VERY cold if you chill it." 

Yes we know it will be very cold. I don't care if you think that's the improper way to drink white, we don't and we want it chilled!

Then I asked if he could aerate or decant our Pinot since it's a young vintage and very tight. I just wanted it to open up a bit. I've had this particular vintage both aerated and not and prefer it aerated. He acted like I asked him to do the most ridiculous thing ever and then very snotty said, "fine I'll decant it". 

It just rubbed me the wrong way. Of course once I asked him his name, he got more polite.

The food was very good. I just had the grilled mahi mahi and a side of steamed spinach. The spinach was steamed perfectly and it's very easy to over steam spinach. 

Hubby had the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin and was very happy.

Others had the NY Strip Steak and couldn't even cut it with a knife. They were sawing away and most just gave up. I thought that was very off for a NY Strip.

I was also really disappointed with the bathrooms. They were very run down. There were chips in the tile and it was very dated. I expected more from such a nice restaurant.

So, a nice restaurant yes, but not the best.
author: Alexis M.

description:
Who goes out to have a drink at 2pm in the afternoon?  

Me, apparently.  Well, to be exact, I was there for the sole purpose of quenching my diet soda craving however, Lora convinced me to have a drink w/ her.  I tried a sip of hers and thought it tasted rather delicious (not too alcoholic-y) so I ordered one as well.  

It was then that we started to act like a lesbian couple.  I kid you not.  The bartender (whom was very nice and funny) gave us a look after Lora was playing w/ my hair.  OK, I know that statement appear so gay but she was helping me try to figure out which hairstyle would work best on my damn face.  We were also playing w/ our phones, talking about everything every guy would not want to know.  Kidding.  We had normal gossips.   

Halfway through our drinks, Lora decided to order some calories.  Please note that during the afternoon (after lunch yet before dinner), they only serve bar foods.  Lora ordered the sliders which I must admit were SUPERB- it was savory and juicy and I wish I could order the mega slider (bigger than a burger, mind you) but I was on a strict diet (as usual) so I held back my cravings and appetite of Adam Richman (from Man vs Food).  

The drinks... bourbon based which I have no clue what that really means but it did not have that nasty alcohol taste.  I did finish my glass and honestly I felt tipsy after that.  The sliders.. well.. all you need to know is that it was SUPERB and that it's a definite repeat order next time.  The presentation of the sliders were contemporary, yet simple.. I enjoyed looking at it for under a minute before it got completely devoured.  

What i love- bartenders seem cool as they were friendly, attentive, funny, and one remembers Lora!  The nice atmosphere... very cozy w/o the uncomfortable cozy feeling, and I liked sitting at the bar where I can talk to my girl freely and enjoy the view of the hundreds of bottles of alcohol they have to offer.  

This was the end of our girl-girl date and I ENJOYED it.  Love Lora!
author: Tram N.

description:
Unfortunately, this was the location of our annual company holiday party. Their prefix menu was extremely piss poor: filet mignon with sweet potato or flounder.

The filet was cooked extremely raw for everyone ordering medium rare, and the combination with tiny sweet potatoes with a couple pieces of spinach was weird. My co-worker bit into a piece of string that was presumably used to tie the steak. 

The flounder looked like something straight out of a cafeteria - I felt bad for my co-worker that ordered it.

Terrible service because they knew they would be tipped automatically. The middle aged female manager was rude, unpleasant, and should probably get canned.

I live a few blocks away and I will never return.
author: Derek B.

description:
I have passed my One Market twice a day for over 3 years, frequently thinking that I need to try that place! After dinner the other night I wish that I had just kept on walking. 

Where do I begin? 

How about here...I ordered two glasses of happy hour wine in the bar while waiting for my friend to arrive. My friend arrives but the wine was still MIA so I asked the 'eager-to-seat-us' hostess to please deliver it to our table. She agreed. We sit down and tell our waiter that we have glasses of wine coming from the bar. He tells us that he cancelled that order and that we can't order 'happy hour wine' in the dining room. I tell him I didn't order in the dining room and would appreciate the original order I made in the bar! He tells me he thought he was "doing me a favor" because it was half priced bottle month. Ugh! He was so incredibly condescending.  

From there the rest of the night plummeted. We did eventually order a bottle which he only bothered to fill our glasses once with. When he showed me the bottle of champagne I questioned if it was correct since I ordered Iron Horse Cuvee but the label was not Iron Horse.  My waiter rolled his eyes and went on to tell me that Iron Horse makes this wine for One Market.  Had to literally wave down another employee to get ANY service...even after our food arrived. Which was very salty and terribly overpriced for the portion and quality.  Our waiters attitude was so bad I complained right that evening to the wine director and a guy I figured to be a dining room manager. I NEVER complain, usually just decide to vote with my wallet and just never come back. After I explained my issues with the service they seemed genuinely concerned took down my information and said a manager would call me. 

After 3 weeks...I'm STILL waiting for that call.

If One Market didn't have such a great location that place would be out business.  Instead of voting with just my wallet this time, I'm voting with YELP.
author: Kerri M.

description:
This restaurant has a lot of potential, but there are definitely some holes to be filled. Namely, the restaurant seems understaffed.

The biggest problem from this, of course, is the service. We waited an unreasonable amount of time for most things, namely initial service. We were seated and waited close to 20 minutes before we even got water and bread. At one point, we considered leaving, but the server did stop by to let us know she would be with us soon. Unfortunately, soon is a relative term. If staffing is an issue, the restaurant should work on that. The service was pleasant when it finally happened, but it was an unfavorable start to the experience.

The food was good, but we did have a rather alarming issue with a spot of bright red in the guinea hen that I ordered. I found it at the end of the meal, and the service redeemed itself in the response, which bumps them up a star in my review. I was concerned with showing the blood so that the server could notify the kitchen of problems with undercooked food, but she immediately took it away and removed it from my bill. I didn't get sick from the meal, thankfully, but it did make me a bit worried. Otherwise, the food was tasty and we had no real problems. 

All in all, it was an average experience for an above-average price. I could tell that they were trying, but perhaps understaffing was a cause of most of our problems. I may try it again if I was dining with someone else, but I doubt I would come in on my own. If I could, I would give 2 1/2 stars, but in response to the attention when I pointed out the blood in the hen, we'll bump up to 3.
author: Chanele R.

description: The food was great and the wine pairings were excellent. There were very molecular items like deconstructed powdered eggs. I had dishes that I wouldn't have believed were as good as they were by reading descriptions, like seared foie gras in dashi (at least atypical). The wine pairings were great examples of wines that showed synergy with the food (but were less likely as quaffers on their own)... which I consider to be a holy grail of sorts. Cin cin, folks!
author: Tom S.

description: Thanksgiving dinner here was amazing the service was amazing the food and ambiance is nothing but perfection
author: Ethel F.

description:
***One Market puts out a satisfying (though not amazing) upscale lunch; still, everything--bread, starter, entree, and dessert--had good flavors and was prepared to the right temperatures; both the atmosphere and service were also pleasing***

One Market has a prime location right across the street from the Ferry Building.  Even if you are not familiar with SF, you can tell this is an area where a lot of people go once you are inside the restaurant (floor-to-ceiling windows allow you to see the pedestrian heavy street).

One Market makes the most of its location with an imposing outside.  The building is nice and the restaurant's name is clearly prominent from the street.  Once inside, the restaurant feels big too.  There are high ceilings and big booths.  The dining room is a nice room with a simple, clean and contemporary look.

Lunch started with their complimentary epi baguette (a mix of baguettes shaped like a wheat stalk; you pull away the baguettes with your bare hands).  The bread had a great crispy crust and was warm with a good chew.  The bread was served with easy-to-spread butter.

I started with the Dungeness crab (though it is not really the best season for it).  The crab was good though.  Nice and light with a good flavor (and very soft).  The crab was served with verjus (grape gelee) and powered yogurt.  It was quite tart and strong.

There were also some good and lightly tart grapes on the plate.  Some sorrel and radishes were also added.  Overall, it was a good dish--not really unique or creative but satisfying and pleasant.

I thought my entree was a better combination of flavors.  I had the housemade cavatelli with Liberty Farms duck leg, duck prosciutto, hen-of-the-woods mushrooms, broccoli di ciccio, and parsley.  It was a pretty rich dish--the very fragrant parsley really helped cut the strong richness of the sauce.

The cavatelli was good and not too doughy.  The duck leg had a good flavor and was very tender.  The duck prosciutto was also good.  The mushrooms were very good.  I liked the broccoli as well.

While I wouldn't say it was too salty, there was definitely a prominent salt flavor and I could see them easily over-seasoning the dish here.

Quite a few of their desserts sounded good, but I opted for the Bing cherry pie with Tahitian vanilla ice cream, pistachio cream, and port-cherry reduction.  I was worried this was going to be a simple and boring cherry pie, but luckily it wasn't.

I find these desserts often feature a hard and dry pie crust.  This one had a good, flaky and crispy puff pastry-like texture instead.  The Bing cherries mixture was very generous and the flavor was good but also quite tart.

The pistachio cream was light and good.  The vanilla ice cream was creamy and refreshing.  The vanilla ice cream really helped dilute the very strong cherry flavor. There was also a port-cherry reduction and it tasted exactly as it sounded.

Service was good.  The waitress was polite, personable and helpful with the ordering process.  The food came out at a good pace and plates were picked up promptly.  There was a little bit of a wait on the dessert, but the waitress did a good job of providing information on the when the dessert would be ready.

One Market features an upscale lunch so prices are on the high side.  And while SF's Spruce features smaller portions, I think that restaurant is a much better option for an upscale lunch in the same price range. 

One Market does feature sandwiches and a $22 two-course special to provide a lower priced option.  Also, they were featuring a special where wines were half off for lunch.

If you are looking to have an upscale lunch near the Ferry Building, One Market and Boulevard are both decent choices.  Their decors are different.  Boulevard is more old-school while One Market is more contemporary.  They both put out satisfying food though I would say neither one of them would be as good as some of SF's best restaurants.

Still, if you find yourself near the Ferry Building and are looking to splurge a little at lunch, I think either would likely make for a satisfying dining experience.  If you are familiar with LA, One Market would be similar to The Lobster in terms of quality of cuisine and value.

Parking is very difficult to find here at lunchtime.  One Market does offer valet parking and it is expensive at lunch ($12).
author: Anthony N.

description:
DISHES, DISHES, DISHES
We, as a group birthday dinner, ordered basically most of the dishes off the menu! I like how they change up their menu from time to time!


WHAT STOOD OUT:
- Chick Pea Fries with Aioli Dip Side - Smooth, unique  texture of the warm fries and the dip complimented it.
- Dozen Oyster Shots - Squeeze some lemon juice, add a bit of cocktail sauce and it is YUM!
- Lettuce Cups with Glazed Pork Belly Appetizer - The succulent pork belly was amazing!  Every bite of this was savory!
- Dungeness Crab topped with Kelp Appetizer - They change up the toppings with this appetizer, but the crab is the main ingredient and that doesn't change.  Interesting combo and compliments from the sea!
- Pan-seared Day Boat Scallops -  Not overcooked or under cooked scallops; cooked to perfection!
- Bacon-Wrapped Pork Tenderloin - I love the presentation of this entree, in particular, but the pork meat was a bit on the dry side.
- Duo of Creme Brulee Dessert - A hint of espresso flavor in the Creme Brulee hit the spot!
- Coconut Cream Pie - Everything from the cream, coconut shards, pie crust and caramel topping was great for this dessert!

I suggest getting their mini platter when ordering dessert so you can sample up to 3 desserts!

WHAT DISHES NEED IMPROVEMENT:
- Shrimp Tacos Starter - Regular taco with shrimp filling.  Sauce and taste is lacking.  
- Lamb in Roasted Coffee Sauce - It was their special of the day dinner entree.  I love lamb and this main course was downright disappointing.  The taste of the strong sauce overpowered the flavor of the lamb.  On top of that, there were no decorations to this entree!  Presentation was horrible.  No veggies, no potatoes, nothing!!! REPLACE or make improvements please!

SERVICE - They made sure that cups of water were refilled when  nearly empty and continuously came around our table to see if we needed anything else during the dining experience.

AMBIANCE - Modern, spacious and keeping it classy with the piano.

PRICE - On the pricey side, but keep in mind that you are paying for the presentation and quality of the food, service and ambiance. 

FINAL SAY - You can be rest assured that it will be a good dining experience.  The address is perfectly suitable for the restaurant's name! Cheers!
author: Tiffany D.

description: I've been to one market a few times for happy hour when I'm off work. Everyone is friendly and professional but Dora is especially an outstanding server. Always continuously checking on our table to make sure we're taken care of and very attentive to anything we need. I would recommend to try and be seated with Dora if you can as I know she'll take care of you.
author: Daniel P.

description: I went to One Market last night with my aunt and uncle who have frequented this place for years. I must say that it was a very pleasant experiece. Soft lighting, very attentive staff just make for a great atmosphere. I had the shrimp bisque, the duck, and pear streudel for dessert. All were delicious and were good sized serving. The restaurant is a bit pricy at about  $19-39 for main dish but worth it. I will be going back when I visit San Fran again!
author: Rachelle M.

description:
My review is for Beth, the special events manager.  When I made an inquiry about hosting my birthday dinner here, her responses were incredibly short and unhelpful - as if she could care less about me giving them my business. She seemed immediately turned off by the fact that I wouldn't use one credit card to pay for a dinner of 20 people.

I will gladly take my business somewhere else.
author: Lina M.

description:
I used to really like this place and would recommend it to friends, especially visitors from out of town.  The chef (Mark Dommen) has been there about 9 years now?  I remember when he first arrived, his creations were unbelievable (I still remember a rabbit ravioli with wild nettles -- OMG).  The best thing was -- the menu varied with the seasons, and was always exquisitely prepared.  

I've been away from SF for awhile and was looking forward to going back to One Market after we returned.  My dear foodie-friend came into town from overseas, it was half-price wine month (July)* ... seemed like the perfect time to go back!

Well.  

My first clue should have been the menu.  It's high summer -- what's that salad with Dungeness crab & grapefruit doing here?  that's way more about November than July ...  

Overall -- the food was fine, but seemed much less 'inspired' than i remembered.  I formed a theory that certain customers must eat here all the time, and demand that certain 'signature' dishes must always be available (like that crab & grapefruit salad perhaps?) -- regardless of season.  

I still love the space, and depending on the situation I might go again (i will order more carefully) -- but at this price point, there are so many better choices in the city.
author: Jaina S.

description:
One Market is the perfect lunch venue: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=kAbz7EzbDB8BybA6egyEKQ

a)  If you have a huge expense account.
b)  If you know somebody who has a huge expense account.
c)  To impress your business lunch date
d)  For a nice mid-week gal-bonding lunch
e)  To make a friend feel special on her birthday 
f)   To try the Dine About Town
g)   As a nice treat unless you are loaded and  have $$$ to spend on lunch.
h)   If you found a bag of counterfeit cash, and need to spend it somewhere other than banks (Courtesy: Nick J.) 

DECOR/AMBIANCE: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=7j8VsDQ94ms8W_N84KKozA
One Market is classy in its simplicity.  Huge windows looking into Market Street made One Market feel spacious.  The earth tones and white linen covered tables gave this restaurant  a formal business feel without feeling stuffy.  The open kitchen added a cozy ambiance to the place. Serious business suit seemed to be the preferred attire at One Market. 

My friend Heather and I do not have an expense account  but we went to One Market for reasons D, E and F. We are not loaded either. At least I'm not!

It was my beautiful friend's birthday and I wanted her to feel special. We also wanted to check out Dine About Town's lunch menu. And we also wanted to sneak in our monthly gal-bonding lunch before we go on our trips separately.

Heather chose to try the DAT lunch menu. For $17.99, she got a 
FARMER'S SALAD: A simple salad of seasonal greens. Very fresh and generously portioned that we had enough to share between the two of us.

STEAMED MUSSELS (chili flakes, pesto and grilled bread): Heather loved her dish! The portion was also generous. I tried the mussels with the sauce and it tasted like curry instead of pesto but I thought it was good! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=hjw-pyBQJ8WZrPLyxtjoeA

I was about to try the DAT menu as well until I saw two dishes on the main menu that I could not resist:

STEAMED GULF FLOUNDER (soy sauce, shitake and bokchoy) $22 The fish was sooooo tender, sooooo flavorful, sooo delicious! Yes, you can tell I loved it! I wish they gave me a little bit more fish but it was really good in its simplicity. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=UT7SwxZq4-_ZyE4zOqQ8fg

CHICKPEA FRIES ($5): Heather and I were intrigued that we had to have these. We thought they were deep-fried chickpeas but they were chickpeas that were mashed, formed into sticks then deep fried. They came with aioli type sauce but they were good even without. Light, not greasy and seasoned-well. Best to eat while hot off the fryer. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=6dIhJBSL2Z3HH4WQTx3Mjw

SERVICE:
Service was efficient and friendly. We opted for tap water but our server somehow insisted with a bit of pressure for us to try the flavored lemonades. We declined twice and the 3rd time, we just went, "What the heck. We'll have one each." They were refreshing but we just really wanted tap water.

LOWDOWN:
One Market's DAT is one of the best DAT we have tried so far. Heather and I have tried quite a few DATs over the last couple of years and somehow we oftentimes thought they were just okay.

At One Market the DAT dishes were executed well, priced right and generously portioned. 

If I  had an expense account  or loaded with cash I will be ordering the flounder ($22) at One Market 3x  a  week! That's about $66 a week, $264 a month for flounder lunch. I think I would have to stick with my $3.25 Tofu banh mi lunch at Saigon, instead. :(

And I also found out after our meal that One Market is a 1 Michelin Star awardee. As good as our meal was, no stars fell from the skies for me. It was very, very good but I had better Michelin star meals in the past.

Tab: $70 including tax and 20% tip.
author: Leah E.

description: This restaurant is tried and true in SF.  It has always been an excellent choice for business lunches and dinners, as well as just going in for some great food and wine.  The menu changes seasonally and one can always find something which fits their palate.  I really enjoyed the wine pairings done by the very professional and fun sommelier, Tonya!  In this regard the wine list is extensive and representative of a wide range of American wines.  The bar is also a great place to have that appetizer and glass of wine before you head home after working a long day downtown. Location is superb.
author: Brian M.

description: I've been here plenty of times and the place is always a safe bet to take anyone for a business meal. Not for the foodie at heart but good food, nicely presented.  Nice service!
author: John S.

description:
Came here today for a work / team lunch.  The service was a little off which made my experience not so great.  I ordered the dungeness crab cakes as my main and I asked the server, "does it come with a salad?"  He said no, but asked if I wanted to add a "market salad."  I said sure, thinking that it would be served on the side of the crab cakes.  Well no.  It came as a first course, and they took it away when the crab cakes came (despite the fact that I had only a few bites because I was saving the salad to eat at the same time as the crab cakes).  And the crab cakes are tasty but oh-so-tiny!  AND THEY CAME WITH A SIDE SALAD (albeit tiny).  In the end, I tried to end my meal on a positive note by stuffing down a few chickpea fries.

Pros: Chickpea fries, lemonade drinks (incl. arnold palmer).  Also the burger and tater tots looked delish.  Wish I had ordered that instead...
author: Christine Y.

description: We had a great dinner here Friday night.  Having been faced with making a last minute reservation for dinner on a Friday night in the city, I wasn't expecting a whole lot, but I was actually blown away by how nice it was.  Everything from the food and view to the service was top notch.  What made our experience really great, however, was our server, Jo'phine.  Her menu suggestions, attention, timing, and witty sense of humor really added to our great time there.  If you are considering this place, ask to be seated in her section.  She will take great care of you!
author: Melissa C.

description:
Service: A
Atmosphere: B+
Food: B-

appetizers: dungenness crab cakes, chick pea fries
main: mushroom gnocchi, flounder
dessert: dessert mini trio with ginger carrot cake with vanilla bean ice cream, mint ice cream sandwich, crunchy almond cake with vanilla bean ice cream

The Dungenness crab cakes, like all other dishes here, it was presented very nicely, but EVERY SINGLE DISH is TOO SALTY! What is going on?! I had to scrape off the salt on the fries to eat them. Although the flavor was very good on the chick pea fries, I could not taste it well because it was way over seasoned. 

Mushroom Gnocchi, very nicely presented again. Creamy and thick. Not the traditional gnocchi I was expecting. I wouldn't say it was a pleasant surprise, but it was okay. This was one of the better ones because it was only slightly over seasoned instead of extremely. 
The flounder..... My mom and I couldn't even finish one fillet. I don't understand this. The chefs here must have a strange palate for seasoning things. It was like eating soft fish oozing with warm salt juice. Even the little side salads were way over seasoned. 

Desserts, I really don't have much to complain. House made min ice cream sandwich was absolutely delicious. Crunchy almond cake, slightly on the sweeter side, but I liked the texture combinations-- crunchy and light, fluffy creamy. Carrot cake also on the sweeter side, but I liked the zing with ginger. Honestly, I would have given 2 stars if it weren't for the desserts. French press coffee was also very nice. 

All in all, I'm in a bit of a disconnect as to how they got two michelin stars. Dishes were nicely presented though.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Haven't been here in years and was very satisfied with the experience.  My friend and I had a cocktail and an absolutely over-the-top decadent 'pork belly' starter with Asian inspired flavors (which I was assured would be on the menu when I next returned).  We decided on martinis with a bit of citrus and a Ginger liquer.  HIGHLY recommend the happy hour starters/appetizers which are available as of 5pm.  

Ambiance is upscale modern and as always I appreciated the beautiful table settings and linens.  DINING ROOM TIP: ask your server for a BLACK NAPKIN if you don't want the white fuzzies that often land on your clothes and are nearly impossible to remove (unless you're packing a huge lint roller.)

Dinner Entree was a special of Dungeness Crab Ravioli topped with a very light and yet somehow frothy/rich Lobster Sauce.  My friend ordered duck.  Both were delicious.  Will definitely be back and although it's pricey, it's do-able on a regular basis to just stop in for drinks and starters until you can swing a full dining experience.
author: Catherine R.

description:
Delicious gourmet food. Beautiful cozy atmosphere. Spent about 2 1/2 hrs here. You need a reservation. It was packed all night. Our group included a baby which didn't throw anyone for a loop. 
I especially loved the toffee crunch chocolate cake at the end of my meal.
author: Leah M.

description:
With respect to Michelin starred restaurants in the U.S., you'd be hard-pressed to find a better deal for a full three course dinner than the Market Menu ($39) from One Market Restaurant.  Wine pairing for both the appetizer and entree portion of the meal is only an additional $13 charge.  Normally one glass of wine costs that much on its own.

I've dined here twice for dinner thus far and they can expect me back plenty more times.
- Bread: Acme bread, specifically olive bread (amazing) and French bread.  Acme is the best!
- Amuse bouche: Both times were a small bite of garnished crudo presented in a small flat spoon.  Very good.
- Appetizers: Golden beet and saffron soup with seared ahi tuna wrapped around geoduck clam and julienned green apple.  Shaved beef tongue salad with an almost kimchee-like cabbage, croutons and frozen crumbles of horseradish that can easily be mistaken for cheese crumbles.  Of these two I prefer the soup, but both are still very good. 
- Entrees: Bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin medallions over persillade and sliced dehydrated apples.  Pan seared Alaskan halibut with fish stick (love their version of the fish stick).  Both are great but the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin stands out here.  Pork wrapped around more pork!?!  Should be featured on Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations' Food Porn episode!  Initially the tenderloin did not look especially tender or juicy but to my delighted surprise it very much was.  Coupled with the savory and crunchy bacon exterior this dish is just plain excellent with a nice and mild smokey open-fire-grill flavor.    
- Extra sides: Buttery mashed potatoes.  This wasn't particularly notable.  Really wanted the roasted brussel sprouts with bacon instead but the sprouts weren't in season.
