- Desserts: I've tried a number of the desserts: (1) brown sugar cheesecake with peanut butter cookie crumb crust and candied peanuts, (2) chocolate toffee almond crunch cake with vanilla ice cream, (3) strawberry cheesecake, (4) duo of crème brûlée (vanilla bean and espresso), and (5) pineapple upside down cake with vanilla bean ice cream.  I numbered them in terms of how I'd rank them.  The brown sugar cheesecake (very light and airy) with the sweet and salty peanut butter cookie crumb crust was simply sweet sensational goodness!

Service the first time I dined here was good, second time was excellent.  They actually ran out of wine selected for the entree I ordered the second time I was here so our waiter gave us a similar zinfandel but also gave us an extra glass of pinot, free of charge, that he thought paired better with the pork tenderloin than what the sommelier actually selected and he was spot on.

Very good restaurant overall.  Great views of the Embarcadero and Ferry Building, elegant and sharp setting, very good service and of course delicious food.
author: Erich D.

description: I was here for a business dinner.  The menu is a bit pricey, but that's to be expected for the area (financial district in San Francisco).  The food and service was excellent.  I had the ahi tuna as my entree.  The others at the table loved what they had, too.  Once had the scallops and one had pork tenderloin.  The dessert selections were great.  We got a trio and shared at the table.  Steven, our waiter, was great.  Would definitely recommend if you are looking for a restaurant near the BART, for a business dinner.  This is an upscale place.
author: Randi G.

description:
This review is for the bar only--
Met my fiance here for drinks because
1) It is located in the same building I work in
2) I heard about their great HH

Was very disappointed wtih the service. The bar was not super crowded..but getting service was painful. We had wanted to order food but by the time the server finally came back we decided to go elsewhere...

Better luck next time..
author: Mimi T.

description: Awesome street views for people watching, and of the Bay Bridge.  But sad to say, the service is way too slow to not let others know.
author: Winny S.

description:
Food was good.  I ordered the flank steak and was done just right.  My waiter was good as well BUT the bus boy crew were abrupt and careless.  For instance, placing wrong dishes in front of guests; set dishes at the edge of the table instead of in front of the guest; plates were taken away abruptly which could splash sauce on plate onto guests.  Lastly, our table was wobbly which was quite annoying.

Decor was high-end and food was great but the bus boy crew need to be retrained.
author: Carmen W.

description: So i previously had a much longer review that eas on the negative side. But after careful consideration and conversation with the managing partner I have thus removed my post amd replaced it with this. I unfortunately didn't have the opportunity to have dinner here but had plenty of drinks. The decor is really nice and this a a great place for evening get together. I'll be returning for a another shot and look forward to posting an edit to my review.
author: Kenneth S.

description:
One Market is not cool. It's possible it was at some point, but it's definitely not now. Does that matter? Not really--because the food is solid.

Our waitress was really nice but pretty clueless. She said she didn't drink, which obviously is fine, but she seemed to know nothing about the wine list. Luckily the bartender makes pretty killer Manhattans.

The menu is pretty vast and relatively seasonal. Their signature scallops dish really is "that good."

If you're there on a Saturday you'll get a nice little jazz serenade in the bar.

Oddly, and maybe unfairly, what stuck with me is the ambiance. It just feels like it needs an update. And the booths are a joke. Multiple times servers had to reach over me to get things to the person inside the booth. Water meant to be poured into glasses splashed on to plates and utensils. The view of the Bay Bridge was nice but geez these booths are super poorly designed.

It's easy to get a reservation here which is always a plus :)
author: Paul C.

description:
This place is near work so me and some co workers stop in here for lunch. We decide to do the pre fix menu and get drinks and basically are spending lots of $$$. Geez the server here was the worst. He rushed through our orders, if I asked what your favorite appetizer or what type of fish is this more like, he was so unimpressed with us as customers that he couldn't be polite and just answer our questions.

Its places like this that I HATE. I eat out often and spend a lot of money on GOOD QUALITY restaurants an when a server Fu&%# it up for me it's going to go down hill for their reputation. 

Mangers and owners of this place listen up--- do a crash 101 course with your servers on how to be polite to customers and go above and beyond. Let's face it your a restaurant in San Francisco, if you do poorly on Yelp.com you will not survive.  

I will never come back nor recommend anyone here.
author: Jess O.

description:
Came in for dinner to squeeze in one last DAT meal.  Restaurant has a nice feel to it.  We were greeted and taken right to our table.  Throughout the meal the service was timely and pleasant. 

For the hype and price, the food fell a little short.  Other reviews have mentioned the sweet potato soup was overly gingery and I have to agree. Shards of ginger are not appetizing, ever.  The caesar salad was really nice though, not overly dressed, and of all things, the croutons were delish. 

The salmon felt boring. There wasn't a major issue, it just tasted (and looked) uninspired.  The pork chop was decent, a tad overcooked but the flavors worked well.  

Desserts were probably the highlight, props to the pastry chef for the perfectly-sized and nicely presented dishes! 

I think the best best is to stop in for a weekday lunch.
author: Brianna M.

description: I had passed by this restaurant every day while I commuted to work from Embarcadero Bart and have always wanted to try it. I love the restaurant's style which has an old world charm. We came on Friday night around 6:30pm. We were early for our reservation but they graciously showed us to our table. I was a little worried about how we would be treated since my husband and I were both dressed very casually but the staff was very friendly and made us feel welcome. The service was amazing the whole night from the host to our server and bus boys. I was also really impressed with the food! I did the 3 course Market dinner, which for $45 is great value. I started with the summer squash soup which was the BEST soup I've ever had. I would go back for this alone! For my main course I had the Halibut and my husband had the pork loin. The halibut was nicely cooked and the foam had a nice citrus flavor to it. I wasn't in love with the veggies served with it but all in all it was tasty. The pork loin was delicious and well portioned. It came with creamed spinach which was very good as well. We also ordered a side of spinach (not knowing that the pork loin came with spinach) and it was cooked perfectly. For dessert we had the toffee cake. My only complaint is that I wish it came with more ice cream! It was on the sweet side and needed more Ice cream to offset it but it would be amazing with a cup of tea or coffee (I was too full by then). It has great texture! Overall the meal did not disappoint and we would DEFINITELY come back for a special occasion!
author: Stephanie N.

description:
Came here for lunch just the other day with some colleagues and it was a very nice experience. Everything on their menu sounds absolutely delicious and I'm sure it is because we all had a difficult time deciding what to get but it all turned out quite tasty!

I would highly recommend the flounder for lunch and the polenta, spinach, and carrots as sides were flavorful.  It is a bit on the pricey side so be prepared to spend about $20 at least, per person for lunch. I hear their dinner menu is about $50 per person for entrees but is really great. The restaurant is quite large, seats a lot of people, and is great for business lunches, special occasions, or nice dates. I would come here again, but it would be much more enjoyable if the staff smiled a bit more and didn't try to keep up-selling you food and drink items. I was there on a business lunch and we were not going to be drinking or doing dessert, but the server seemed upset that all we wanted was water with our meals. It was an enjoyable lunch, but I had higher expectations since it was a highly rated restaurant.
author: Akvile D.

description:
I came here for Dine About Town dinner with my coworkers. We all ended up spending nearly double of the original DAT $35 price given One Market's special menus. It was well worth it for my deluxe DAT courses, though I can't say the same for my coworkers' wine pairing selections.

The first dish, the Shaved Beef Tongue Salad, was like no other meat I had tasted before. It was sliced very thinly and simply melted in my mouth. I absolutely loved both its texture and its flavor.

The Wild Sturgeon was even more surprising. It had the bouncy texture and taste of scallop ... that is, if you could acquire such an impossibly-humongous slice of scallop. That, by itself, would have made the visit worth it.

As for desert, I really can't remember it. I mean, I'm sure it delicious, but after the first 2 dishes, I couldn't have cared for anything short of heaven. The service was meh, but I was so entranced by the dishes that I'm still giving the rare 5-star rating.
author: Nathan Y.

description:
*********************** 474 *******************

           One Market is definitely a staple destination for fine dining in San Francisco. Although the food is good, the wine list is amazing, the place is just too big for me. 

           I came here often before with my folks and love their freshest ingredients, farms to table style. Their menu changed almost daily which makes this resto more interesting.

          Although I say the bar is a cool place for happy hour. Love their "Caramelized onions sliders" and the "Lettuce Cups, glazed pork belly, cilantro, jalapeño." Plus they have live piano on certain evenings, make it more fun. Their cocktails are also great & Dora at the lounge is super nice!  

Overall: 4 stars
For value: 4 stars
For Food: 5 stars
For Service: 4 stars
Ambiance: 4 stars
For Location: $10 valet parking & the valet guy there "Yogi" is really nice too!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
This place was pretty underwhelming especially given the price. The service was fine but the food, while not bad, was nothing special. The most memorable part of the meal was the delicious Acme bread served at the beginning of the meal. 
Convenient location, but I'd prefer to just grab a baguette, cheeses, and a meat platter from the ferry building across the street than spend money on this place again.
author: Sydney M.

description:
I visited on a Friday night when it was wet and windy. It looks like One Market was trying to keep the wild weather OUTSIDE where it belonged. The first thing you see when you step inside is a big, heavy velvet curtain that keeps out the wind. Very smart.

Inside, the bar was packed with people enjoying happy hour. Even after we were seated in our elevated booth, I could hear some of them enjoying themselves a bit too much. I ordered the Dine About Town deluxe menu with choices of sunchoke veloute, duck breast, and carrot cake cheesecake (swapped out with the regular DAT choice). 

I liked that there was a choice of bread with our meals. I believe there was a regular roll or a olive loaf.

We started out our meal with an amuse bouche of ahi poke with sesame seeds. Nothing too fancy, though my fellow diners noted that it was a bit fishier than they expected. I thought it was fine, though not mind-blowing.

The soup was tasty, but I should know better than to get sunchoke anything as it gave me a really bad stomach ache a couple of hours later. The hazelnuts were an interesting touch, and you can't really go wrong with crunchy bacon, but my favorite part were the mushrooms which were an odd slightly greenish in color but tasted really good. 

My duck was okay, though I prefer for the fat to be rendered down a bit more. There was a very heavy sauce that had a slight sour plum flavor to it which I thought was a bit too rich tasting. The duck was also accompanied by a chunk of homemade foie gras and duck sausage, which mostly tasted like the best breakfast sausage you've ever had, but really didn't taste much of foie gras. My favorite part of the plate was actually the green colored farro that was under the duck breast slices. It was slightly nutty and chewy and quite good. 

The highlight of my meal was probably the cheesecake, which was a delicious creamy cheesecake on top of an equally moist and delicious slice of carrot cake. It had a light glaze on the plate which wasn't too sweet, as well as a scoop of intense vanilla ice cream. The braised pineapple were a nice touch as they weren't too sweet and had just enough bite to them to cut through the richness of the rest of the desert. 

I tried a bite of my sister's pork chop, and it was cooked perfectly. The portion size of her dish was absolutely massive, as the chop was probably an inch thick and 10oz. It came on a bed of super smooth mashed potatoes with a side of escarole sauteed with more bacon.

The wine pairings went well with both the soup and main entree. 

Service was impeccable. I will definitely be back.
author: Leslie H.

description:
My Dine About Town adventure brought me to One Market.

First off, they should remove those long, heavy curtains at the entrance. Knowing San Francisco is windy 90% of the time... these curtains are just knocking people who are standing there waiting to be seated every time the door opens.

My 3-course dinner started off with the Steak Tartare. A bit on the tangy side, but decent. This tasted better with my dinner bread instead of the baguettes that came with it. For the main course, I ordered the trout. Nothing out of the ordinary and it did not WOW me neither. Ended the night with the tropical fruit sorbet. Came with a scoop of pineapple and a scoop of kiwi flavor topped with a thin piece of flower-shaped cookie that tasted like a fortune cookie. Refreshing after a salty main course.

They have happy hour on Saturdays from 5:30-9pm. $4 draft beers, $5 house wine, $6 cocktails. The happy hour cocktails are not listed on the menu so you have to ask the host to specify.

However, our server was friendly and attentive. I thank him for that. Will I be coming back here? Most likely not.
author: Nancy N.

description:
A couple of years ago, the service seemed like they were being put out by waiting our table.

I went for a team lunch this week. It took 60 minutes from the time we sat down to get our entrees. There was zero apology about the wait for getting non-alcoholic drinks, for our two shared appetizers or for our entrees. It took more than 90 minutes to have a work lunch. 

This lack of apology about the wait makes me think this happens on a regular basis or they just don't care.

The food was OK but I won't be back here.
author: Janet B.

description:
3.5 stars!

I came here for my second Dine About Town dinner this week and I absolutely loved the ambiance and decor of the place. It was sophisticated, open and huge! We were seated in a large booth area that could probably seat 6 comfortably and there were only the 3 of us. The reception area was not warm and friendly but whatever. Our waitress was very professional but not personable at all. By the way, there is an automatic 18% gratuity for DAT!

Now onto the food! The funny thing is we all ordered the chicken because it was either that, the flounder or tortellini. We chose different appetizers and desserts which was a perk because I like to pick off my friend's plates lol. Get the complimentary green olive bread, its pretty yummy. Nice, warm and fluffy to make up for the reception area.

Our selections:

First Course
Bradley's Caesar Salad- Refreshing and crisp but over dressed and on the saltier side.

Butternut Squash Soup 
ras al hanout, spiced pumpkin seeds, yogurt cloud-  creamy, semi sweet and delicious!

Second Course
Spit-roasted Rocky Jr. Half Chicken 
boulangere, potatoes, applewood-smoked bacon, thyme jus- juicy, tender and had great flavor. I ate every bite.

Third Course
Duo of Mango & Pineapple Sorbet 
fresh fruit, almond tuile - Bleh! Nothing special. I'm not sure if they make their own desserts themselves because it seems very simple and thrown together aside from its fancy dressings.

Pear Brown Butter Tart 
spiced caramel sauce, vanilla bean ice cream -  Flaky, sweet and pretty good but nothing special. The better dessert of the 2 options given. 

I expected more from a Michelin Star rated restaurant.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
I recently went to a birthday celebration for a friend at One Market.  The entire experience was superb.  We had a tasting menu with wine pairings included: six dishes plus wine with each.  The food was top notch, and our server (Steve) took care of our every need.  The result was one of the best evenings out that any of us had ever had.

Highly recommended, and if you can swing it, get the chef's tasting menu with wine.
author: Joe O.

description:
Itsa great place. 

Location: ONE MARKET STREET - numba one on a street that defines/divides/ and runs the length of  SF

Food: menu changing frequently and just always fresh and good with a tremendous variety and creativity. Beautifully presented and prepared. Too many great dishes I have had over the years to report, but there is something for everyone. 

Service: always professional and knowledgeable, without the attitude that can sometimes come with a joint of this class

Price: it ain't cheap (but good things rarely are cheap - ever hear of someone looking for cheap Ferrari ? ) think $25+ per person for lunch (and that would be if you drink tap water), $ 50++ per person for dinner.

For me, one of the icons of dining in SF. Many other joints have come and gone during One Market's tenure. They have survived and thrived due to their quality and consistency ... and location.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
I have been to two of the Lark Creek owned restaurants since moving to San Francisco two years ago, Cupola and One Market. Cupola is a hidden gem of an Italian place located in the Westfield Shopping Center. The food is amazing, the staff attentive and friendly and the atmosphere calming and relaxing. I often find myself recommending this little known treasure.

And then there is One Market. 

While everything from appetizer to dessert was delicious, savory and perfect, the hostesses attitude was not. She rudely doubted the status of our reservation and almost delighted in treating us like pure crap. I understand protocol in any business, but at least be polite about it. Luckily our amazing waiter and food more than made up for her awful behavior and the night was salvaged. 

Our super waiter was very knowledgeable and friendly and the food was really amazing, I just wish they'd get a less pissy hostess.
author: Dylan P.

description:
Maybe I just don't get it, but I don't see why this is Michelin rated. Maybe this restaurant's past it's peak, but I just can't begin to compare this with something like a Sons & Daughters.

Servers were very attentive, accommodating, kind. Location is central, which is nice for all type of commuters.

Though, the food was good, not great esp given the hype.  We got the gnocchi and the scallops entrees, with a few sides.  I just can't even remember anything that memorable from the meal.

Seems like a good place to go for happy hour, the folks at the bar were having a wild time apparently.  Don't think i'm coming back for dinner, not even a "special occasion"
author: Sandy K.

description:
3.5

"Twinkle twinkle Michelin star
How I wonder, what you are (all about)?"
 
One Market was the site of our twofer birthday lunch celebration.  The guests of honor arrived in their usual garb, Natasha S. in her "Mrs. Thomas Keller" T-shirt and Peg S. in her Elle Woods power pink.  Add a few other lovelies and voila - a yelptastic FiDi lunch.
 
Warning:  Do not order the Vegetarian Sampler unless you are prepared to share. 

Fortunately for Cathy K., she choose this dish.  Unfortunately for Cathy K., she then had to deal with the rest of us trying to eat it.  The Chickpea Fries with harissa aioli and the Sunchokes were my faves.  (Random Food Trivia:  While sunchoke may sound like a yoga wrestling hold, it is actually a deliciously starchy root vegetable.)  The Brussel Sprouts and Sauteed Spinach were good but nothing out of the ordinary. 

My Ahi Burger with Fennel Salad was fine but walking across the street to Taylor's Refresher and getting their ahi burger is a better bet for your tastebuds.  The Persimmon Salad was a creative and unusual mix of flavors as well as a crowd pleaser.   
 
The Golden (Dessert) Rule:  More = Better. 

So, we opted for the Mini Platter of Desserts (Choice of 3):  Pumpkin Cheesecake, Butterscotch Pudding, and the Chocolate Toffee Almond Crunch Cake.  All were solid.  Our server was flummoxed at how to divide the 3 Desserts among 2 birthday girls' specially decorated plates but came up with an EXCELLENT solution:  Put 3 Desserts on EACH plate.  Works for me!

I didn't find One Market to be "Michelin star worthy" when compared with the many other SF restaurants that I've enjoyed more due to their interesting food, flawless service and a modern and comfortable ambience.  (But then again, I'm all about the yelp stars.  Aren't you?)
author: Amy C.

description:
One market was pretty disappointing. 

Came here for Dine about Town. They serve a regular DAT and a deluxe DAT menu. So three of us decided to do regular and my bf do deluxe so we could try a little bit of everything. 

Steak tartare was alright. Presentation was nice, and toasted baguette on the side. I had much better steak tartare so I was not impressed. And, most importantly, the toasted baguette was stale. It was supposed to be crispy but not hard. I was so disappointed. On the other hand, the shaved lamb tongue was pretty good. The lamb tongue was finely sliced so it wasn't chewy but tender. 

Grilled steel-head trout was alright too. The sauce was a bit too salty. Braised pork short rib was a little bit better. It was very tender. Duck breast was probably the best. It was juicy and tender. I loved the mashed sweet potato. I wish they give us small. 

Dessert was disappointing too. The ricotta cake was dry and hard. The sorbet and the bloody orange was sour. The parfait was pretty sweet. I only had a little bit because I felt like i was eating sugar. 

The only thing that stood out was the bread. It was hot and nicely toasted. Outside was so crispy and inside was so soft. It was so good with the butter. But other than this, I don't see what's so good about one market. I don't think I'm going to return again.
author: Louisa L.

description:
Honestly the worst restaurant I've ever been to in my life.

When you put into account the cost vs. the quality this place doesn't even deserve 1 star. The service was horrible. We actually had to grab a waiter after waiting 20-30 minutes after we had finished our appetizers to order our entrees. Our appetizers were the Octopus (which we didn't finish between 6 of us because it tasted horrible), Oysters (which weren't bad) and the chickpea fries (which weren't to bad either). 

All of our entrees were horrible. It became comical as we tried to find out who's was the worst of all. The $40 steak took the cake as the worst. All you could taste was piled on seasoning. 

Our side dishes, which came out after we had finished our entrees, were the icing on the cake. The squash was unbearable. At this point we already knew the quality so we all tried a piece to get a good laugh at how bad it actually was.

I would never come back here. There are much better restaurants in San Francisco that cost much less. Consider this place an Apple Bee's who attempts to cook classy food but fails miserably.
author: Jason M.

description:
I've been to this restaurant two times now, and both were fairly underwhelming.  The first was a large work event we were hosting so dinner was a fixed meal.  Tasty, but not mind-blowing.  

Yesterday I went for a business lunch, and had the Ahi Tuna burger--very underwhelming.  Normally I expect a Ahi Tuna burger to be a solid slab of seared but rare tuna, which is generally crusted with spices on the edges.  This burger was minced tuna, which was formed into a patty, and had a dull grey color to it...very unappetizing.  The inside of the patty was indeed rare, but just the whole presentation and fact that it wasn't a solid piece of tuna was disappointing.  Service + bread in the beginning were both great, otherwise I'd give it 2 stars...
author: Mike A.

description:
Great place for seafood near Embarcadero Center! Although, my two coworkers got steak instead :)  

I had the Day Boat Scallops, which were amazing! I couldn't remember everything else I read in the menu that came with them but together, it was a [classy] party in my mouth! 

The service was great; everyone is very accommodating and friendly.
author: Jenny C.

description:
This place was great overall. It is a one star Michelin rated restaurant and I think that is extremely valid. Went here with some coworkers for a work dinner and the service, food, and wine were all incredible.

They have a good happy hour that we started with at the bar. Once seated, we got a variety of wines, appetizers and entrees. The servers even provided our table with some appetizers on the house; one of them being a beet salad with candied walnuts in it. I personally hate beets normally, but they were personal bite size, prepared on individual spoons for a mouthful of amazing-ness. I really enjoyed it to my surprise. I got the caesar salad as a starter and it was a great wedge salad. I loved the dressing. For an entree, I got the scallops. They were great. Next time I would try the steak I think because some of the others ordered it and I was pretty jealous. They bring around fresh, warm, yummy bread as well with choices of olive or french bread.

As at most classy restaurants, the serving sizes were small.
author: Megan F.

description:
Place I work for rented the place out for a dinner for our whole division. It was awesome.

Free drinks and mingling with my co-workers outside of work.

For dinner I had some braised ribs and the standard dessert with ice cream.

To be honest the food I had was great but because it was a standard menu I couldn't order a variety of things but just from the prix fixe. Maybe next time I'll go independently and find something on the menu unique to this place. Otherwise not too bad for something free!
author: Julia P.

description: I rate this place based on its price (which is not cheap). You are paying for the atmosphere at a place like this and it is indeed top notch. The service is great. I am not a meat eater, so I was challenged in finding something interesting to eat. In the end, my dish was just okay.  If you're a hard core meat eater, you may think this place is heaven on a platter. But based on the food (particularly veggie options), I have to knock off a couple of stars since that's what I was there for.
author: GoodBadUgly T.

description: Reasonable happy hour prices, considering the location. I was also there with a friend at 630, and it wasn't crazy packed at all--pretty easy to grab a seat in the bar.
author: Mel G.

description:
Dine About Town was the perfect excuse to try out this restaurant. I have high expectations of any place with a Michelin star... It didn't exactly blow my mind, but I could tell that their technique and ingredients were both good, so who knows how good their regular menu items are.

I had the butternut squash soup, the rice flake-crusted gulf flounder, and the pear brown butter tart. The soup was good, but didn't exactly wow me. The flounder was nice and flaky, and the crunch of the rice crust gave it a nice contrast of texture. The tart was okay.. nothing special. 

We also ordered a seared foie gras on the side. It was interesting because it was combined with a soy sauce-based sauce, complete with shiitake mushrooms. It was good, but it definitely wasn't one of the better foies I've had.

The highlight of the meal? THE BREAD. Yes, the super soft, freshly-baked bread. Yum!

Dine About Town was probably not the best sampling of what this place offers, but it wasn't bad. I want to come back and try their regular menu.
author: Kazu O.

description:
One of the biggest benefits to moving away from San Diego and into the Bay Area is the endless amount of food options up here. Granted we don't have a great taqueria where I can get my carne asada fix, or that I'm still finding something to rival Din Tai Fung's dumplings, but the food up here is pretty amazing. The biggest find up here is the amount of stars up here. Now I'm not talking about Catherine Zeta Jones or Brad Pitt... but something even more coveted. Michelin Stars. Yup! The Bay Area boasts of plenty of Michelin Stars... including the only 3 star restaurant in the US. French Laundry! I'm still awaiting the day where I can eat there again... with my D300 so I can capture my meal in its wonderful photographic glory!

For my 21st birthday (yes, I'm still celebrating my 21st birthday... I think we're up to a few anniversaries of my 21st birthday... but seriously, whose counting right?) Sam arranged for a lovely get together at the wonderful One Market in San Francisco. It touts a star so now overall my star count is up to 8... They were wonderful in keeping a large round table for our dinner party and the food there was delicate and well thought out.

I started out with the pea soup, accentuated with crisp pancetta and topped with a soft boiled organic egg. Now keep in mind, I've always hated egg yolks ever since I was a kid. It still baffles me to this day; this egg-yolk hating habit. Evolution has made it so that we crave high fat and rich foods (which explains my endless love affair with butter...) but to this day, I still have a hard time eating yolks. This soup... was perfect. This was the first time I understood why people call egg yolks creamy. We gently broke the egg and mixed it into the soup to create this amazing creamy rich finish. The pancetta broke up the smoothness and added a nice textural balance along with the briny saltiness. Emulsified peas never really appealed to me but the soup was this beautiful beautiful bright green color. Nothing was overlooked here; even the croutons were crisp and well seasoned!

I recall awhile ago when I was living in San Diego, there was quite a bit of controversy about foie gras. I'm not sure if it is still served down there, but it was offered on the menu up here. (Along with at the menus at the Google cafeteria... their Kobe burger with foie gras with a side of Maine lobster tail is amazing!!) In any case, we ordered a side of the foie gras to whet our palate. Oh Mr. Goose... you did not die in vain. The foie gras was seared perfectly; I normally hate liver in any shape, way, form or preparation but I didn't turn my nose down on this one. The foie gras had a perfect creamy consistency, paired with the carmelized hazelnuts and apricot compote, it was one fab dish! 

In my family, we grew up eating a lot of fish. Having Taiwanese roots, fresh whole fish is super important to my family. When we have family dinners, there's alway a whole steamed fish which then the chopstick battles ensue to claim the fish cheeks. Yes... fish cheeks. Since fish spend their whole lives bug eyed and gulping, these two highly priced muscles are extremely tender yet firm at the same time. When I saw that they had Halibut Cheeks on the menu... I squealed. I ordered the Halibut Cheeks with Root Vegetables and Fennel Foam. I didn't really quite understand the foam component but the cheeks were amazing! Tender... chewy... and very "Q!"

Sam ordered the Seared Steak on Polenta with Bok Choy and Brussel Sprouts. Again... seared perfectly, but I couldn't really tear myself away from my fish cheeks to eye his dish. When I finally sampled it, it was utter steak heaven. The meat was amazingly tender, flavorful and seared perfectly. The centers were warm and moist and the edges were still slightly crusty from the hard sear. The sauce was a wonderful reduction and the bok choy was cooked perfectly.

All in all, it really showed on how well the restaurant was run. The dishes were very well presented and thought out. The pairings were great and our server suggested great wine pairings. I was pleasantly surprised at how great the service was since they were charging a standard service charge for how large our party was.
author: Vicky L.

description:
My boyfriend brought me here to celebrate my birthday over dinner. The restaurant is located near the piers, and is on a very busy street. I don't know if other guests park their cars in a garage and just walk to the restaurant, but my boyfriend opted for valet (they park your car at the nearest curb to the entrance of the restaurant).

Our dinner reservation was for 7:15, but we were a tad early and arrived around 6:45. Lucklily, the hostess said that she was able to seat us. There is a pianist near the bar/waiting area, and large floor-length curtains that you have to go through to get to the hostess stand.

At first glance of the dinner menu, we decided to skip one of their "starters". My boyfriend ordered their "bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin" with an addition of their 
"buttery mashed potatoes", and I decided on their "pan-seared day boat scallops". Of course with a round of martinis with a twist and a cosmopolitan on the side.

One of the servers gave us water and offered us a choice of two breads while we wait for our food: some sort of sourdough, or a "olive" bread (I'm sorry, I forgot the exact name of the bread). The "olive" bread was sort of a mixed bag for me. Some bites the bread was yummy with just right amount of bread to olive ratio, other bites were straight up chunks of olives (yes, actual olive chunks are in the bread).

Our entrees took quite some time to get out. My boyfriend and I were thinking that the kitchen were making up for our early arrival with the delay in food preparation. Another server approched our table with a "compliments of the kitchen" dish that was two spoonfuls of some potatoe blob (again, my apologies for not remembering the exact name). It was good, but it only made me more hungry and more eager for my food.

Overall, our entrees were delicious. My boyfriend commented that their tenderloin was cooked to perfection, and the bacon was nice touch. Their scallops were satisfactory, and the artichoke accompanied it well. Their mashed potatoes were fluffy and buttery indeed. I honestly would prefer mashed potatoes that had cheese in it (or are cheesy), but that's just me.

As for dessert, I chose to have their pumpkin cheesecake and my boyfriend ordered their "mint chocolate chip ice cream sandwich". Side note: They offer this $15 "mini platter" of their "singular sensations", any three of your choice. I didn't see this till now, nor did our waiter offer this to us. Their "mint chocolate chip ice cream sandwich" was just as it is described. My only thing is, I am a huge mint and/with chocolate fan, so I am very particular about my mint taste. This dessert was more of a mint liqueur taste, not quite your usual grocery store mint chocolate chip ice cream taste. Their pumpkin cheesecake was just like any other pumpkin cheesecake, which was also adorned with glazed pecans on top.

I would definitely come back to his restaurant, maybe to try out lunch, or just for some drinks. The location of the restaurant is pretty, and it appears to be spacious inside. I also noticed a few of their guests were ordering their "chef's tasting menu" with the "wine pairing". I might come back just to try that as well.
author: Nilda Lynne A.

description:
Not recommended.
Had a glass of Chardonnay which was too sweet to finish. Small wine portions.
Fish had a hint of a moldy flavor. 
There are much better places to eat in San Francisco, for the money.
Service was not up to par either. 
We told the waiter we only had an hour and a half because we had to make a ferry. The service was so slow we missed the ferry, even though the restaurant was nearly empty. They make a big deal about the partners on the menus. These guys should be embarrassed.
author: Steve K.

description:
Had dinner here last night and was really happy with the service and the food. Our waitress was very attentive and made sure our drinks were always filled. 

The salad was just okay, but the main course (I had steak and the others had fish) were all delicious!
author: Eman S.

description: Ate here in the summer and enjoyed the atmosphere. For sure filled with professionals and tourists. Oysters were out of this world and the dessert memorable. Have to break a diet? Calorie worthy place.
author: Davy M.

description:
I went here twice with my family for their Weekly Beast menu.  The first was "pork" and the second was "chicken".  When we went for the Weekly Beast menu with pork we had reservations on a Friday night.  Not surprisingly, they were super busy.  We arrived promptly and were seated right away but to a cramp corner table that actually had a great view of the Ferry Building Clock.  The "pork" menu was incredible.  I like each dish immensely.  I just wish I didn't stuff myself with bread so I could have finished my dessert.  I don't remember the dishes names but I took pictures...hope you find them.  Regarding our service though, it was just OK.  Our server wasn't what you'd expect from a Michelin star restaurant.  She wasn't very prompt, attentive, and accommodating.  The food runners/bussers, however, were exceptional - they saved my rating of One Market restaurant that's for sure.

Fortunately, I was lucky enough to go to One Market Restaurant with my family again the following week for their Weekly Beast "chicken" menu.  Maybe I caught the service on an off day.  Busy Friday night...it's understandable right.  OK, so this time we had reservations for an early Saturday night dinner.  We were so early the place was practically empty.  We got a different server this time.  A guy this time that wasn't stuffy but had a funny air about him.  His shining highlights were that he made notice to me that the wine we brought could have possibly been spoiled.  Being a former bartender and server for some good restaurants I tasted it to give my approval or disapproval.  The cork was slightly damaged like he stated which I noted.  I sampled the wine...it was borderline but still held its uniqueness.  It was a 2003 wine that later after research was suppose to be consumed no later than a few months from our dinner at One Market.  The wine was still good but I'm glad he made us aware of its possible flaw.  As for the Weekly Beast "chicken" menu...well, it was a waste of a nice night out at SF.  None of the dishes were exceptional and the dessert, aside from maybe having egg in it, didn't portray a chicken concept.  Where's the chicken, man? :-)  As for our waiter...he was a bit abrasive, missing at times, and pushy.  Again, not what you'd expect from a Michelin star restaurant.  It was pretty rude of him also to pick up our checkbook before we vacated the table.  Maybe he thought we were tourist from Europe or Asia and thought we would stiff him...who knows.  It's pretty rude for a high end restaurant though.  Not acceptable...  

The food runners/bussers were great though.  Better, if not as great, than the previous weeks food runners/bussers.  Definitely, the food runners/bussers here are what I'd expect a Michelin restaurant to have.  The servers though are a bit unprofessional.  I don't know why One Market has a Michelin star...maybe for past glories.  The food is adequate.  The food runners/bussers are exceptional.  The servers are questionable.  Time to reevaluate the Michelin star...
author: Jules S.

description:
One Market's events personnel made hosting my wedding dinner for a very small group of friends and family a cinch. Beth, the events coordinator, was incredibly helpful and easygoing - due to the small number of people, she was very flexible with the number of choices on our custom menu. Tonya, the wine director, was certainly spot-on with her picks for our wines, and everybody enjoyed the food offerings. 

The dinner was a joy to plan, the food was delicious, and the night was completely stress-free thanks to these guys.

Menu favorites: The NY steak, duck breast with mole sauce, white bean soup, the potato risotto, and the seasonal pear blueberry tart.
author: Miriam W.

description: Went there with my colleague for happy hour earlier today.  Got a cocktail (spicy Manhattan) and got a few appetizers from the HH menu....pancetta flat bread, roasted peppers, and market veggies.  The drink was well made and the food was  appetizing!  Get the market veggies and the roasted peppers (yum!) if you go or choose something else besides pancetta flatbread.
author: Happy L.

description:
I've been here twice before I begrudingly agreed to come here again for lunch. The first two times, I was not impressed at all. The food was good, but when you get REALLY slow service your overall experience just causes you to leave with a bad experience. 

Anyway, I came here for Dine About Town and the experience was a lot better than my previous ones (which I found rather weird since restaurants normally snub Dine About Towners). 

Started with the watercress soup, which had clams, turnip and ginger. This soup was very flavorful. The waitress said it takes a day to make and the flavors reflect that. On a cold day, I could eat a pot of this stuff. Too bad the waiters who present the plate and pour the soup tableside wouldn't come along with. Oh well... 

Next I got the Pan-Seared True Cod, with fennel, potatoes, pesto-mussel broth (which came with the teeniest mussels). It was pretty delicious. The preparation of the potatoes was something I didn't care for. It looked like they ran them through a mandolin so it had the same shape as the fennel... Eh? The Cod itself was awesome. Crispy skin oustide, perfectly flaky inside. 

Dessert was what is called the "Valrhona Chocoalte Cremeaux Parfait", salted caramel, almond streusel and white chocolate. SUPER chocolatey goodness. The salted caramel was light, so that was a little disappointing but still overall very tasty. 

4 dollars extra for the dessert on a Dine About Town menu? That must come from the prissy nature of being a Michelin Star rated restaurant. But at the price of $18.95 for the starter and main course, FINE, it's worth it. 

They also added 18% for all Dine About Town Menus along with the annoying SF "healthcare" charge.

BTW, the best part of lunch. $2 martinis! I know they used to be a dollar, but $2 for a super strong martini is still a steal!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
uhhhhh, not so much . . . 

Not terrible, but over-hyped.  Not disasterous, but not impressive.  

Not putting it on my Never Again List; but not putting it on the Must Go List either.  Next time, I hope it earns the solidly impressive reviews given by a number of other reviewers, because those booths of theirs are soooooo comfy, cozy.
author: Adrienne A.

description: Based on how good the experience and food was last time, I wanted to try it again. Unfortunately this round I didn't have time to sit down so I wanted to order for take-out. I guess this place is too good for take-out because I was told they don't do that. Your food is good, not that good. Minus 2 stars
author: David G.

description: I had a great time here, went here for happy hour, was a lol crowded, but we happened to get a table. Our waitress was Dora, she was super busy but very attentive, and friendly. I told her it was my friends bday and the manger sent over a really cute desert for my friend, totally made her day. It was the sweetest thing, she didn't have to but she went the extra mile...she was a complete delight. :)
author: Abel M.

description:
Ended up going here on the insistence of my brother-in-law for mothers day.
Certainly didn't disappoint.

From the second I walked in I felt like I was being taken care of, the service was fantastic.  While I waited to be seated until the entire party arrived, they offered coffee while I waited. 

We were able to sit 5 people and my nephew at a booth with room to spare.  They even brought my nephew crayons and paper to draw on.  While he can be a handful, the staff was understanding though the rest of the restaurant my not have been.

Ordered several appetizers including the doughnuts with bacon butter.  Fantastic. The calamari was also very solid. While I did not partake in the smelt dish (too fishy) I was told it was good.

Ended up ordering a eggs benedict item.  It was fantastic.  Was served with no to little salt bringing out the natural flavors of the egg and complimented by the naturally salty ham.  The sister ordered the dish vegetarian and while I ordered my 'with her ham' as a joke, they delivered.  The dish was very solid though I was somewhat confused as to the inclusion of a 'greens' salad with the dish.

Between 6 people, coffee/drinks, 3 appetizers, 6 entrees,  and 2 deserts the total bill came in under $75 a person.  Very affordable.

Will definitely try and revisit One Market next time I am in San Francisco!
author: Patrick T.

description: Never disappointed. It always have the best food and services. I am not quite understand why they have better steaks then others that claim they are steakhouses.
author: Racky W.

description: The service was impeccable.The host (Amanda) was very sweet and easily recommended her favorite !!!! Great place to wow people.
author: Jeff S.

description:
This place was awesome to say the least.  Our waiter Damien was excellent!!  As were the staff who supported him.  Food was fresh, creative and innovative.  Dessert was homemade and we had a trio.  It was a birthday dinner.  Well worth the price and surprised how cheap the bill was.  Pictures say a thousand words and the impeccable service says thousands more.  The only comment I can make is when everything is served on a tray, it is very friendly and clean.  But when dishes are pulled from the table, the also need to be pulled with a tray.  This keeps their sleeves clean and everyone sanitary.  An added bonus would be to cover with a napkin providing fresh napkins for dessert.  You also are missing out as the patrons of your establish would appreciate a nice port/wine pairing with dessert on the menu.  Other than that, FLAWLESS!  Chef sends you a wonderful one bite appetizer as a welcome too!  I cannot say enough good words.  Since it is so centralized to tourism it may be easy to dismiss however, do not be fooled, this place is A MUST!!  

Please One Market take my suggestions!  You will one up everyone else in town!  Okay, 2 up.....I not only speak from my foodie experience but my fine dining training
 as well.  You have the tools and the people perfect for the job, you just need to utilize them to their best.  If you do not put the pairings on your menu for dessert, at the very least, train train train your staff to suggest appropriate dessert wines.  I mean you already offer a choice of tap or bottled to seek potential upsells so why not pairings?

I will be back!  And look forward to trying more on your menu.
author: K J.

description: Good service. Steak was totally overcooked. Asked for medium rare and it was made medium well. Good wine selection but waiter was not very informed about wines.
author: Audrey S.

description:
I had a Caesar salad to start. Unfortunately the yellow lighting in the room made the lettuce look terrible. It was actually okay but the visual was disturbing. 

For dinner I had the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin and mashed potatoes. The pork was excellent with a thick bacon wrapping and a bed of spinach and pear. Tender and very flavorful. 

The mashed potatoes tasted like they had been made from a box..,  grainy and "thin". I took one bite and no more. The waitress apologized and took them off the bill but it was disappointing nonetheless.

General atmosphere was nice. A little noisy but not too bad. I may go back but only if I want the pork!
author: David W.

description:
GREAT DEAL: Half off ALL bottles of wine for the entire month of July!! (This only happens once a year.) 

My two girlfriends & I came for some good quality girl-time bonding. What a better way to do that over wine. I was craving the usual light, crisp, & sweet flavors so we ordered the following:

*Cakebread Sauvignon Blanc (2008)
*Ludwig Monterey Riesling (2008)

Both were good, but my favorite for the evening was the Sauvignon Blanc. 

Our friendly server, Dora (not the Explorer), stuffed us plenty w/ warm straight-out-of-the-oven baby croissants. Mmmmmm! 

We weren't interested in ordering food. However, they did have some eats available @the bar- crab tacos, (gourmet) foot long hot dogs, cheese & shrimp platters, etc. 

Bottom line: Great place to bond w/ your girlfriends over wine. Take advantage of their special this month. Two bottles of (really good) wine only cost us $20 per person.

Tips:
*If the bar is crowded, snag a table that doesn't have a table cover.
*Embarcadero Bart is right outside.
author: Joy A.

description:
*expense account place, food was really good but my pork sandwich special while tasty was cold by the time it arrived
*just uber expensive for what you get, I guess they can charge those prices
*table was all wobbly, as in, you could spill your drink, just a 101 thing in a high end place, gotta dot your I's and cross your T's
author: Dan S.

description: The service at the bar is usually fantastic when Dora is around. I went on a Thursday and the waiter ignored me. I went over to the bar and got my drinks directly and she didn't seem interested. Avoid going there on Thursdays.
author: Mahesh A.

description:
Dine About Town was a perfect opportunity and excuse to try One Market!  I tried to make reservations on Opentable for Saturday night, but nothing was available.  I then called, and they said they were also booked up except for walk ins to be seated at the bar.

Well, we decided to just walk in! We were greated at the front counter and asked if we made reservations.  I said no, and they quickly walked us over to a table for two!  Not fully booked after all! 

Service was extremely prompt and informative.  She was very helpful and catered to our needs after knowing we were in a rush to go somewhere else after.

I tried the deluxe DAT menu: beef tongue salad, duck breast with duck leg confit, and chocolate souffle for $45.  Fyi - you're only saving a few bucks with this menu, so if you're not soo enthusiastic about what they are offering, you might as well order your dishes a la carte!

To begin with, they offered us bread and butter, as well as a small complimentary taste of their ahi tuna.  This had a refreshingly good taste.   The beef tongue salad was nicely presented.  Thin slices of beef tongue over pickled cabbage served with nice crispy croutons.  The duck breast was cooked perfectly: nice, pink, and tender.  I would have liked the skin to be more crispy though! This was served with a duck confit that was way too salty! The polenta was good and went well with the duck.  The cocoa reduction glaze on the dish complimented the duck very well.  As for dessert, the souffle was rich and fluffy.  However, it wasn't freshly made and lacked the nice, warm taste of a fresh chocolate souffle out of the oven.  The carmelized banana, mascarpone, and ice cream went well with the souffle.  

My bf had the foie gras appetizer, which was delicious and seared to perfection.  Upon serving this, they pour a sweet vinegar soy sauce like sauce over the foie gras.  Yummy!  He also tried the Bacon-Wrapped Pork Tenderloin, which was a much larger portion than expected.  The pork was amazingly so tender, and cut easily even with a butter knife!  It was served on top of pear slices, which went very well together.  The dandelion persillade was tasty also!

In the end, we got the bill with two apricot jellies!  A nice ending to a good meal! :)

Overall, everything was great... but I have to agree with others that  I would definitely expect more out of  a Michelin rated dining establishment.
author: Tramy V.

description:
Service was horrendous. 

When you walk into a 4* restaurant you expect a certain level of service... This restaurant would barely get 2 stars on my radar after forgetting to serve us dinner! So here's the story... 

Reservations were at 8pm, we got there at 7:30pm. We checked in with the hostess (who told us they are running on time and might even get us seated earlier). While waiting we ordered wine at the bar (the Zinfandel was superb). At 8pm we settle up and go get seated. We ordered wine (Malbec) and the "House-made Charcuterie" (not a fan of the pate)... And that's when it started....... We waited NINETY minutes for our dinner (2 mains: the duck and steak). When we got fed up of waiting, we finally grabbed our waiter and asked what the hell was going on.. His response was "there was a mix up in the kitchen, the manager will bring over your food in thirty seconds." (It would have been nice to have been told about this "mix up" instead of having to ask after waiting for so long!) Anyway, the manager comes over with dinner (warns us that the plates were hot then says that dessert will be on the house). Seriously? Next time, take responsibility and ownership of mistakes. I don't expect to pay $200 at a restaurant that forgets to bring me my meal. 

The food: 7/10. The duck was good but the andouille wasn't that great. The steak was cooked medium-rare as requested, flavorful but nothing special. The two sides we ordered were the mashed potatoes and the brussel sprouts (highly recommend the sides lol). Thank goodness for the many glasses of wine we had. 

Dessert: We ordered the toffee crunch bar as well as the bread pudding. The crunch bar was nothing special (literally a chocolate cake covered in almonds and hazelnuts? I think) The bread pudding was good.... Although this was served barely luke warm. Maybe if it was warmer it would have tasted better. 

The scene: higher end, social scene, mostly business dinners on week days.
author: Raveena P.

description:
If I could give Chef Dommen a 4.75 star, that's where it stands. Boulevard and Prospect are still better, but Dommen gives Nancy Oakes a real run for her money these days. His "Mark of the Beast" dinners are amazing, and one evening we had a lamb shank entree that was hands-down simply the finest piece of lamb we had ever tasted in our lives - and all three of us dining that evening are lamb lovers. 

Salads are wonderful starters here, as One Market is one of the few kitchens that really knows how to dress a salad properly (RN74, by contrast, is a dismal failure in this and other areas). Desserts have long been a weak point, but a recent Manjari Souffle Cake was ethereally light and tender.

Service was as always, unfriendly at reception desk but wonderful when you actually sit down and are waited upon. Waitstaff is top notch and takes the edge off the (literally/figuratively) cold reception when you first walk in.
author: Jean K.

description:
Thanks to Dine about Town, hubby and I got to try this place.
I wanted to try this place and check out why they got a Michelin Star.

We got to the restaurant at 6:30 for our 7pm reservations and they had us seated right away.
I was hoping that the place is a bit less casual than what I observed it was so I was a bit disappointed with the ambiance.
Our server was good but service wasn't memorable.

I tried the deluxe DAT menu while hubby tried the regular DAT menu.
He had ceasar salad, pork chops, and grand marnier strawberry bowl.
I had the  Golden Beet soup,  Duck Breast and choc souffle cake.

Hubby thinks ceasar salad is too fishy, porkchops were good but the doneness were not even and he wishes there's more potato puree, strawberry bowl was good.

I think the beet soup is odd.. the combination with geoduck and apples pus the beets just didn't work for me.  Duck breast with duck sausage was good, chocolate souffle cake was mediocre.

We also had some cocktails and they were okay. the Bon Vivant that I had was good but all of the cocktails definitely needed more booze in it.

Okay so we didn't spend as much money as a regular One Market diner would but I was definitely disappointed with this place....
author: Learnee L.

description: I loved their happy hour strawberry moscow mule, but their calamari and sliders were only okay.  The restaurant seems a little overrated, probably because of its location and great view of the Embarcadero.  However, I would come back again for happy hour, but would definitely try different appetizers.
author: Cici A.

description: Travel to San Francisco, I found this restaurant, perfect! I like it here, service is the first-class, my mother and I together, have a great lunch!
author: Qiong C.

description: We decided to pick a restaurant where we can stay up for the fireworks and celebrate. We picked this restaurant because it has a rating of 4 and you are right across from the Ferry building for the fireworks.  They charge $50 more for the 2nd seating "2nd seating - 8:30-10pm $145 per person- Four Course prix menu includes party favors, midnight sparkling wine toast, live piano and weather permitting, fireworks views from outside the restaurant on Steuart St."  It is the worse new year celebration ever at a restaurant!! We had a reservation, we were on time, it took almost 10 min with 4 different people at the check in to finally greet and seat is!  They ran out of party favors?!  Are you serious?? They didn't even pass anything out at the tables. Not even half of the restaurant had any!! $50 for a glass of sparkling?!  The whole bottle doesn't even cost that much!!  There were no other seating after us yet the waiter was rushing us like crazy, we were done with 3 of the 4 course in one hour and we still have to wait 2 hours before midnight!!!  The food was what you expected at a restaurant like this with 4 $ sign but definitely not a place that I would want to come back for their over priced menu.
author: Angie K.

description: Traveling through San Francisco on Christmas Eve, my friend and I decided to check out One Market.  It's right on Embarcadero, nearby several notable restaurants.  We called to make a reservation, which required a credit card confirmation, which is fine, since it's Christmas Eve.  Food was good.  Coming from New York, there's pretty amazing food so I'm not going to say it's life changing but it's certainly well prepared and well presented.  My complaint is really the portions to price ratio.  Our grilled Octopus appetizer was one leg of octopus.  Literally one tentacle.  It was $18.  My scallop entree was $35.  It had 3 scallops.  My friend and I paid $200 for 2, we each ordered an appetizer and an entree plus 2 glasses of white wine each.  The part that left the really bad taste in our mouths was that our waitress added her own 20% gratuity to the check.  And no, it's wasn't like a pre-set thing, where oh, it's a large party, or oh it's Christmas Eve.  No where, on the menu or the website, or when I called to make the reservation did they say gratuity would be included tonight.  We would've left her 20% regardless but the fact that she hand wrote it in herself, on the FULL bill, kind of just pushed it over the edge.  I think there are lots of lovely, upscale restaurants in SF.  I obviously made the wrong choice tonight.  Better luck next time.
author: Christina L.

description: Dined here tonight and the food was fabulous. When the bill came we were charged $80 for a bottle of Chardonnay that said $40 on the wine list. When questioned the waiter came back with "$40 was for 1/2 bottle, $80 for the full bottle." The menu he brought back to prove it was a different menu then the one I ordered from. No offer to attempt to make it right.  Bottom line: excellent food-don't order wine! There is another YELP post stating they were scammed with the wine charges as well from 2 weeks ago. We don't recommend!!
author: GarynGina H.

description: Great tasting and great looking food! The service was excellent and ambiance was was definitely happening! I will be back
author: Aubria T.

description:
---------dinner only-------
Celebrated my anniversary here. Great decor and very good food! It's quiet here and has a nice view of the ferry building (when a bus isn't blocking your view). Service is attentive but doesn't bother you too much
author: Diana Y.

description:
I'm really surprised at the 3 and half star rating - it really should be a 4 and a half or five. One Market was really a great dining experience for us.

We stopped in on a whim on a Saturday evening after closing down the Hog Island Oyster company across the way at the Ferry Building. We needed something more substantial to eat after oysters and bubbly before we headed home and we decided to try One Market. I've been hearing good things about it lately and hey, it has a Michelin star!

We chose to sit at the bar and ordered from the dinner menu. Our server, Dora, was extremely helpful and the service was perfect. We ordered the house charcuterie, the sardines, chickpea fries, yellow wax beans (Dora's suggestion) and the hamachi with avocado. Our favorite was definitely the hamachi - yum! It was perfection. 

I also really enjoyed the charcuterie - housemade mortadella, salami, duck liver mousse, etc. It had a few tiny dots of apricot mustard on the plate and wow, was it full of flavor, it complimented the meats beautifully. 

On Saturday nights Billy Philadelphia plays the piano at the bar and he is delightful. He played some requests for us and came over to talk, he is a treasure and a talented pianist.

I asked about private dining rooms since I'm in the wedding and event business and Tim (the manager?) took me on a tour. It would be a great place for a wedding reception, rehearsal dinner, business dinner, etc. They can really accomodate any number with the adjoining atrium and cool wine bar - Wine & Wall. 

When the check came there were house made salted caramels that were so good, I asked for more. Dora happily accommodated me. We will definitely be returning to sit in the dining room.
author: Susan K.

description: I attended a networking gathering last week at One Market and used the valet service for my car. At the end of the evening I came out to my car to find that someone had rifled through my center console, taken my cheap sunglasses, and stole my expensive jacket.  There was no sign of forced entry, so I think the valet simply left the door unlocked.  I sent an email to One Market over a week ago with still no reply.  The food was delicious, but their lack of professionalism has left a sour taste in my mouth.  I'll take my money (and car) elsewhere.
author: Krissy A.

description: Sorry to say that our evening at One Market was marred by the food - I had a beet salad that I enjoyed and the bread was delicious but the main course (scallops) was so undercooked that I could not finish it. Lucky for us we had excellent company and the event was a reunion and the service was very good (waiter was with a trainee and both were patient and attentive and fun). I would however not recommend and will not return. So many great options in San Francisco sad to waste an evening out with expensive mediocre food.
author: Cynthia F.

description:
I came here with my family, we had reserved the chef's table for dinner in celebration of my mom's birthday. It was a such a pleasant experience. We had brought 5 bottles of our own wine from very exclusive wineries, and the the sommelier was very knowledgeable and suggested the right pairings with all seven courses. Staff was beyond attentive. I was very impressed with the service - it was just excellent. Food was well prepared. We made our own dessert :) 

The restaurant chef, Mark Dommen is was a pleasure to talk to, stayed there late just talking to us at midnight, even though he had a long drive ahead of him home to Sonoma. 

Beautiful experience, loved it here.
author: Beeta O.

description: Food was really good but service was incredibly slow. I waited over 10 minutes for a menu then 15 minutes for somebody to come and take my order. Granted, I was seated in the lounge not the restaurant. Not what I expect when I am paying that much and ordering off the dinner menu.
author: Lisa P.

description:
My friend and I came here for Dine About Town and it was so goood!!

We were running a little bit late for our reservation, so I called in and told them I would be about 15 minutes late. They were super accommodating and said that it would be fine. 

When we entered there was a live pianist playing and the hostess was extremely friendly. She offered to place my coat in the coat check, which I've never experienced before--kinda cool. We were sat right away and there was no wait.

We did the 3 course prix-fixe meal: I had the DAT regular, he had the DAT Deluxe, and we both had wine pairings. 

Started off the meal with tuna tartare compliments of the chef! I liked this extra touch, it was a great way to start off the night. 

DAT: 
Steak tartare - absolutely delicious with a raw quail egg on top, also came with a grilled baguette. It was also a lot bigger than what a regular starter should be. 
Braised pork short ribs - mouthwatering, I loved this dish with the farro and cabbage. The pork was soft, juicy, and tender. It was also a large portion, I couldn't finish. 
Tropical fruit sorbet - mango and kiwi sorbet with fresh mangoes and kiwis, loved it!

DAT Deluxe:
Shaved lamb's tongue salad - the tongue was shaved so it was thin and not too chewy, I had a bite and it was quite good. 
Roasted liberty farm's duck breast - looked pretty good, I don't think my friend liked it that much though. 
Valrhona chocolate cremeaux - salted caramel with almond ganache and with chocolate?! Absolutely delicious, I am a huge fan of salted caramel. 

Overall, I think we both thought the regular DAT was a better choice than the deluxe version. And I would recommend spending that extra $15 to get the wine pairing, it was a great choice and definitely made the food's flavor stand out even more. For the price, you can't beat it. The food came out with great timing and they made sure you were finished, I didn't feel rushed at all (our dinner was almost 2.5 hours long!).
author: Shannon W.

description: Great view, service is on point, but the food for the price is a total rip off.
author: Allison G.

description:
I was expecting a lot more from a "Michelin rated" restaurant. The pear salad and blue cheese appetizer was good but I've had similar salads at less expensive places.  The blue-cheese in this case was a bit too much so it was pretty strong as an appetizer. I ordered the sliced roasted lamb shank for my meal.  It was tender and was immersed in juice and foam, but fell flat on the flavor upon the first bite (maybe it was all the blue cheese that dulled my tastebuds?).

I did like the service; our waitress was friendly. She even took a picture of us at the table without cracking a smile at my awful new hair-cut.
author: Gail S.

description:
I stopped by for their Dine About Town menu & my friends & I were not disappointed -- the food is delicious!! We got seated in a big comfortable booth, maybe a little too comfortable because one of the booths was sunken in, haha. 

We were started off with a tuna/cucumber amuse bouche & then some bread (which included my favorite Acme roll, the olive roll!). The steak tartare was fantastic, with really bright & fresh flavors & it was also a good-sized portion. Of the entrees, the trout was definitely the standout dish, cooked to the perfect texture & crispy skin. The sauce was rich & decadent & went perfectly w/ the fish. The other entrees were also pretty good -- braised short ribs as comfort food & kabocha gnocchi w/ whey form as the ~experimental~ dish. The citrus-ricotta cake was a perfect end to the meal. 

With Dine About Town menus, I'm usually disappointed by either the starter or the dessert (or both), but One Market Restaurant definitely blew me away with each dish. The entire experience was luxurious & all the food I ate was interesting & new. I can't recommend the restaurant enough!
author: Ruby H.

description: On a business lunch? Great place to see the movers and shakers. Nice menu of interesting and fresh choices. Service was perfect. Not a cheap place, but worth a special visit.
author: Matt T.

description:
What I Ate
- Fava Bean Risotto (smoked duck tenderloins, spring blossoms, sorrel)
- Sauteed spinach
- Potato tots
- dessert sampler (pineapple upside down cake, almond toffee cake, mint ice cream sandwich)

Would I Go Again?
I've been to One Market before for dinner, but I had the privilege to go back this week for lunch.  I was excitedly anticipating the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin, until I was told that it was a dinner entree only.  It was an extremely lucky break for which I was so grateful.  The waiter recommended the duck and although I don't typically like duck, I decided to go for it.  I would rank it as one of the five best entrees I've ever had.  The meat, risotto, beans, and cheese all blended together to create perfection in a bite.  I wouldn't change one thing about that dish, and I would recommend it to anyone.  

The potato tots were delicious, same as before; however, the sauteed spinach was very disappointing.  With sodium, less is more, and that axiom was unfortunately not implemented with this side.  The dessert sampler was pretty good, but nothing was nearly as good as the pecan tart I tried last time.  As it should be, the entree was the star of the meal, but the 1-star side and 3-star dessert are holding me back from giving One Market the five-star rating it probably deserves.
author: Ben M.

description:
I have a cousin who lives in Hong Kong.  Every time she visits me in SF, she wants to do the following:

1) Go to a supermarket
2) Go to Target
3) Eat "American food" with local ingredients

So last night I took her to One Market, because she loves "American food" so much.  I made a reservation on Open Table and arrived 10 minutes early.  Thankfully I was seated right away so I could wait for my cousin out of the cold.

While I waited, I looked through the wine list and ... no one came by to take my order.  It wasn't until about 15 minutes later that the waiter finally came by and asked if I wanted anything to drink while I was waiting.  Why thank you for noticing that I'm here!

The rest of our evening went by a bit more smoothly in regards to service.  We ordered the shaved beef tongue salad, the charcuterie plate, cornish game hen for her, and the ahi tuna for me.  We also split the chickpea fries and brussels sprouts.

YUM for the beef tongue salad and chickpea fries!  Both were so unique and had a distinct texture and taste.  I'd totally order these two again.

MEH for my ahi tuna, and my cousin's cornish game hen.  Both lacked flavor, though they were both juicy and moist.  The mushrooms that came with my tuna didn't pair well with it at all.

BLEH for the brussels sprouts and the charcuterie plate.  The brussels sprouts were extremely limp and oily (best ones so far are at Anchor & Hope), and the charcuterie plate was pretty sparse and pathetic for being over $14.  Also, the baguette slices they give with it are extremely buttery and greasy, totally not a good fit for the paper-thin, half-ply sheets of cured meats.

We ended our meal with the butterscotch pudding, which my cousin didn't like but I LOVED.  It's very smooth and heavy in butterscotch flavor and had a dollop of fresh whipped cream on top.  Best part of the meal for me, although I wish it could've been a big bucket of the stuff.  Next time.

Overall, this place has decent food for too hefty a price tag.  If I'd been blown away by each of the dishes, they would've easily gotten 4 or even 5 stars.
author: Tori S.

description:
I came here for lunch for dine about town. We had reservations at 11:30pm. We were one of the firsts to get seated. We were seated at this one sided booth. Instead of facing one another we were at an angle. I found that strange. The place was really nice. I liked the decor.

The dine about town menu was part of the entire menu. 

First Course
-Farmers Market Salad
seasonal vegetables and greens
( I got this and it was extremely flavorful, I thought it could have used some toppings)
or
-Cauliflower Soup
nantucket bay scallops, asian pears, pickled ramps
(My friend got this. First you get a plate/bowl with three scallops? and then the waiter pours this soup in. The presentation was really nice. My friend really liked it)

Second Course
-Mussels
lemon grass, thai basil, coconut
(We both ordered this. They gave us mini forks that I just LOVE to eat the mussels. I liked how theres some potatoes included. It would have been boring without it)
or
Liberty Farms Duck Confit red wine risotto, herb salad
or
Five Spice Winter Squash Skewer
rabe. dry fruit vinaigrette, pumpkin seed oil

They offered complementary bread with a lot of butter. It was alright. Nothing fancy. 

The service was extremely good here. We received more bread when we ran out, our water was refilled in a timely manner, and we were out of there within 40 minutes without getting the feeling of being rushed.

The only downside to this place is how the tables with the booth-ed seating are really close to one another. I was able to listen in to the entire conversation the table next to us was having. 

I was satisfied but was hungry after 2 hours.
author: Sarah C.

description: Always and forever one of my favorites. The Chickpea Fries with Harissa Aioli, Chef Mark's Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout "Mi Cuit" and his Bacon-wrapped Tenderloin, any of Chef Patti's Panna Cottas, Chef Brad's Butterscotch Pudding. It's  making me hungry just thinking about it.  And I'll never forget my love for Chef Adrian's Braised Pork Shoulder from way back when. The service is always impeccable - professional but warm and friendly. Over 20 years and OMR still manages to remain fresh and relevant.
author: Lyza L.

description: Came here for a business lunch. The service was great. Our waiter was attentive and knowledgeable.  The food was good but can be better.  I had the Octopus with pasta - a bit sour and not much octopus but very good homemade pasta. The pomegranate lemonade was delicious!
author: Carmencita S.

description:
I've wanted to try One Market since an intern of mine told me about working the salad station back in the 90s. I'm old.  Wow.

This was an absolutely wonderful meal.  The service was solid. Not perfect, but solid.  The food, was wonderful.  We did the goat meal of the Weekly Beast.  For what you get, the price makes sense.  The dishes were all well prepared, thoughtful, and tasty.  I admit it was a bit rich overall, but it was 4 courses of meat, followed by goat cheese, which put me over the top.  

Why not 5 stars you ask?  Well, the service isn't quite what I'd call 5-star service.  I can't exactly put my finger on it, but he got flustered and misstepped a couple of times.  And I am just not a fan of the bar. I came here to meet a friend for happy hour before dinner, and I guess so did every other person on the planet.  I felt like the .com boom had just been frozen in time, and was still there, the same people, 10 years later.  I suppose that would include me along with it, but it just was crowded at the bar, and service was not all that here either.
author: Erin O.

description:
I was here for a business dinner. I started off with an asparagus salad, good but nothing to write home about. I had the duck breast entrée whcih also cane with duck confit, and this dish was amazing. The breast was cooked to perfect temperature, crispy skin and great flavor. The confit was very tender and had contrasting flavor and texture compared to the breast.

They also have a great selection of wine.
author: Reggie L.

description:
What I'd heard prior to going was that this place was fairly hit-or-miss.  My experience, while not fantastic, was good.

The meal started with a Caesar Salad, that was pretty good - it was straight-forward and nothing necessarily special.  My entrée was a NY Steak with Mashed Potatoes and Steamed Vegetables - all items were good, although the steak could have been seasoned just a bit more to bring-out the flavor.  I had a Strawberry New York Cheesecake, which was actually great - a nice cheesecake with a strawberry swirl, but with a unique touch: a yellow cake "crust" - such an interesting take on a typical dessert.

The place is a bit pricey so it's perfect when you don't have to pay for it.  The setting is nice since the building and décor make you feel like an important San Francisco business person, especially when you are surrounded by high-powered people.  The service is good and fairly attentive.  As far as a power lunch place with that power lunch atmosphere, this spot is perfect, while the food is maybe not as powerful.
author: Ken G.

description:
they had me with an amuse bouche of foie gras mousse and roasted pecans served in an egg shell. light, soft, silky and full of foie gras goodness. but then it was a plateau and a shallow grade downhill from there.
 
then came Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Sea Trout "Mi Cuit" rösti, organic chicken egg, pancetta vinaigrette. it didn't taste as fishy as it sounds, which made it much better than our expectations.
 
the Malpeque Oysters on the Half-shell rice wine mignonette and wasabi tobiko caviar was fresh, but not chilled to the perfect temperature. nonetheless, they were still tasty.
 
the Braised Beef Short Ribs anson mills white corn grits, horseradish, and natural jus was not as tender as i would have hoped. sure, it fell off the bone but there was a bit of dryness running through the meat.
 
Mushroom Pot Pie with roasted root vegetables and pistachios. this was one of their recommended dishes. i was sorely let down to find a mush of mushroom stew that neither had the depth of mushroom flavor or the cohesiveness of a pot pie. this should not be a recommended item and perhaps should be taken off the menu as it was highway robbery at $18!

Bosc Pear Galette brown butter filling, pear caramel sauce, frozen late harvest bavarios, pear sorbet. the pear sorbet was excellent, but i can't say much else for the soggy galette.
 
Valrhona Chocolate Dessert Tasting warm manjari souffle cake, carmelized ivoire chocolate napoleon, jivara cream soda. which do i eat first? the best thing was the cream soda and everything else was too dense and rich for my tastes.

not bad but not great. definitely not up to par in the one star michelin ratings as its competitors.
author: Charmaine L.

description:
I used to look forward to coming here for lunch, but not so much these day.
