Though the menu hasn't changed much, the food now seems to be lacking.  My salad and entree didn't have very good flavor, and tasted really salty.  The other entrees looked like they had been waiting a while before they made it to the table.  

I felt like the service wasn't bad, but there seemed to be a lot of times we were waiting and no one checked on us.  I am honestly surprised that this place is Michelin recommended still.
author: Andrea W.

description: Beautiful old building,  but modern restaurant.  High standard of service.  Very good quality of food, but very high prices for the size of the portions. I ordered the mushroom risotto,  it was nice, but not the best I have tasted and it was the tiniest portion I have ever seen. My colleague ordered the salmon and that was a reasonable portion, but you have to order potatoes and vegetables separately.
author: Vicki O.

description:
Let's just say, 1 Michelin star should most def equate to 5 Yelp stars (and maybe then-some). 

I came here for a work holiday party, and their private room met all of our needs. It came equipped with our own personal waiter. The waiter has excellent customer service! My wine glass was never empty! 

I love their NY strip steak, especially medium-rare! It was better than an orgasm in my mouth. Each bite was moist, juicy and tender. 

Also, their desserts are too pretty to eat. But trust me, my strict diet was not a concern when I savored every crumb from my pear tart. 

Furthermore, one of my coworkers contested that the duo of creme brulee was the best she has ever had. And this came from a creme brulee obsessed woman who owns her own torch!
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Very popular and busy place.  We were seated in the middle of the dining area and there was little room for the server to move between two back-to-back chairs.  Consequently we were jolted whenever the guy in the back moved his chair or when the waiter tried to get across the two chairs.

My main course of ahi tuna was quite salty.  They used peppercorn and rock salt on one side to sear the tuna and then salted it again on top.  I finished three slices with a lot of water before giving up.

4% surcharge added to total bill to comply with SF employer mandates.
author: Tabisky C.

description:
Came here last year during the Dine About Town week and was sorely disappointed.  I ordered off the special menu and my friend ordered a steak off the regular lunch menu.  Both were mediocre at best.  My starter salad seemed cheaply made.

There really was nothing memorable about the meal.  Average-at-best food, average service, average ambiance.  My friends and I always marvel at how this place consistently manages to get a Michelin star.  Save your money and try one of the bay area's many other "fine dining" establishments.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I had the 3 course market menu for $39.  

Appetizer: Carrot soup with black cod, star anise, and chrysanthemum - The soup had a nice, smooth texture but was not terribly exciting.  I enjoyed the black cod.  

Main: Sous-vide Alaskan halibut with black radish, miso, maitake mushrooms, and sea bean - The fish was cooked well, and the dish was generously portioned.  I thought the mushrooms were delicious, but there was a gel-like sauce around the fish whose flavor I felt was a bit off.  

Dessert: Chocolate toffee almond crunch cake with vanilla bean ice cream - The Market Menu gives you a choice of a dessert off the "singular sensations" menu.  The portion for the chocolate cake was very large compared to other "mini" desserts.  The cake was rich and covered in almond and toffee.  The vanilla ice cream was delicious and a nice complement to the cake.

Service was friendly and helpful without being overbearing.  The dining room was comfortable and has a nice view of the ferry building.
author: T T.

description:
So about 2.5 months after my scholarship dinner (refer to my first review), I came back here with my boyfriend for my graduation dinner.  I said that I couldn't write a proper review until I came here for a regular meal (instead of the private party last time) and so now I can deliver.

I really appreciate how they took our reservation even though it was technically 15mins before their closing time (yeah, I had a really late graduation).  Service was extremely friendly.  The atmosphere was gorgeous and dimly lit.  It is definitely quieter here than my signature fancy dinner place (Scala's) which can be a good or bad thing.  Since I was only with my boyfriend, it was nice since it meant we could have a good conversation and hear each other.  However, I think if I were in a large group, I'd feel bad about possibly being too loud.

Food was amazing.  Yes, I'm going to preface this by saying that this place is pricey.  It was about $100 for the two of us (and that's us sharing a starter and dessert and not drinking anything alcoholic).  However, the food was delicious and definitely worth a splurge once in a while.  We had the foie gras and O.M.G. it was amazing.  I definitely recommend this place for foie gras.  My boyfriend had roasted duck with a bunch of other stuff and he thoroughly enjoyed it.  I had the gnocchi and it was perfect.  For dessert we chose three minis and they were all super decadent.  

This may become my new favorite splurge place.  Food is amazing.  Service is friendly.  Atmosphere is beautiful.  Location is amazing (esp if you love pictures like me).  It is definitely a place I'd go to if it's a special event (birthday, anniversary, etc).  Some may complain about the price, but really, do you want to remember your birthday as the night you spent $10 on dinner?
author: Vy L.

description:
I am a big fan of the fixed price Market Menu.  For $39, I had fennel soup with crab legs, Liberty Farms duck breast with duck leg confit and polenta, and finished with pineapple upside down cake.  I have to admit I was a little nervous when I first found out that the soup did not have any cream in it.  But it was so full of flavor I never missed the cream.   And the crab made the soup make sense because it complemented the strong earthy fennel flavor with its richness and texture.  The entree came with a square block of duck leg confit which was so perfectly fatty and crispy it was like eating duck carnitas.  My dessert was good but not very memorable, whereas, my boyfriend's mint chip ice cream sandwich was much more fun; very minty ice cream served between two delicate chocolate cookies.  

Although I was skeptical that we would be able to get to the symphony by 8:00 from here,  we let our waiter know our plans and we were able to eat at a comfortable pace and take BART to the concert hall with plenty of time to spare.

Oh, before I forget, I started this meal with one of the best gin martinis of my life.  If you are a martini drinker, this is the place to go.
author: Jeannette W.

description:
We have been here several  times. We were in the SF area this past weekend. 

First, One Market is a comfortable high end restaurant with no pretensions by the staff.  Great decor,  and we had a window table. Service is dignified. 

I had the  beet carpaccio, tomato mussel soup,  then the chick pea fries, potato tots ( great dipping sauce), and pole bean salad. All very good. Also ordered was the kampachi (Hawaiian yellow tail) and avocado salad, and the scallops which came with a risotto. All great. 

For dessert, we had the peach galette and a blueberry sorbet.  MMMMM. 

We then took a walk on the Embarcadero, which is nearby.
author: Jerry P.

description:
The FiDi foodie lunch crowd is often too busy paying $13 for thimble sized bowls of ramen or waiting 1-hour for some Indian burrito, that they totally neglect Michelin 1-star quality food offered at Dine About Town prices all year long.  You could easily pay double for "The Business Lunch" quality food during dinner time, so why not splurge every week or so?

Duck Egg Salad: It's not like the hard boiled and minced egg salad you put on bread, but more like a salad with a big old runny duck egg on top.  The greens were frisee, creating a cute nest effect for the gooey egg center.  Really enjoyed the gizzard bits to add some heartier texture and saltiness to this untraditional salad dish.  I was a little apprehensive about eating the muscular stomach of a duck, known as the gizzard, but can now understand why most of the world's poor people love it.

Rabbit Cannelloni: Definitely not your Italian-American peasantry fare, doesn't even possess any of those overused cheap tomato sauce or ricotta cheese ingredients.  Slow cooked bits of rabbit and seasonal vegetables rolled in a supple and slightly pan fried pasta wrap.  Loved both the irony and the perfect pairing of the carrot foam surrounding... wonder if they caught the rabbit and the carrot at the same time?

Strawberry Shortcake: The fresh strawberries and hand whipped cream was enough to sway my overall sentiment as positive, but I wasn't a fan of the "shortcake".  It was way to hard and crumbly for my liking.

Bradley's Butterscotch: Apparently it's not for nursing homes anymore!  I definitely appreciated the taste that is somewhat smokier/heavier than simple caramel or dulce de leche.  Also appreciated that it was a thick pot de crème consistency as opposed to the runny My T Fine butterscotch pudding.
author: Adam B.

description:
Kind of underwhelmed. Food was a bit overpriced considering it didn't taste spectacular. The decor also felt a bit boring and dry. I had the steak (forgot the cut) and potatoes, with drip coffee. would recommend another place around the area if u have to go for a business lunch.

also go here often for happy hour. once again, kind of not the best place for that either. although the calamari was great, it wasnt super conducive to walking around and mingling amongst coworkers.
author: Thach N.

description:
I'm rather sad that I only got to experience this place once. The other sad part is that, my office was a block away from One Market and I never thought to come in. 

The bacon wrapped pork was out that day so I opted for the duck breast. The duck came with sausage, foie gras, cilantro and figs. Read that without drooling on your keyboard.. Hands down the best breast I've tasted, oh wait? Yes, it was indeed the best breasts! 

Some other sides we had were: 

mashed potatoes
tater tots (huge hit)
brussel sprouts with bacon
roasted baby carrots

Excellent  and knowledgeable waitstaff + cozy and sexy ambiance= Win.

Two bottles of the Lark Creek Cuvee brut later, I can say we had an amazing time at One Market.
author: Thao L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place more since it is one of my buddy's favorite restaurants.  I've been here 3 times and tried 3 different menu options.  The very first time earlier this year for the Valentine's Day prefix which I wasn't happy with since they were charging so much but didn't give much option with the menu selection.

The second time was for dine about town which I felt the portions were really small.  

So it was unlike me to give a place a 3rd chance when the first two wasn't that great.  This time we ordered off the menu and still found this place underwhelming.  The food wasn't creative nor imaginative and the staff wasn't particular nice in any way either.  The food wasn't bad but nothing left an impression.  

Which leaves me little reason to ever come back here..
author: Mac S.

description:
I hadn't been here in 7-8 years but came recently for a business lunch.  It's a great location and while it might not get as much hype as other restaurants nearby, it's a nice choice for a slightly formal lunch.

The crab cake appetizer consists of a side of greens with three cakes that are quite small.  But they don't have all that excess starch and consist of just crab, which is great.  

The tomba tuna entree was good (although I thought the tuna was a tad overcooked).

Didn't partake in libations but their Arnold Palmer is visually stunning (with iced lemonade on top of the tea) although it lacked flavor somewhat.

Service is upscale and the decor if sophisticated but not stuffy. Not too loud a place so perfect for business meetings and somewhere you can take your parents or out-of-town guests who are more sensitive to loud, raucous, restaurants.
author: F. P.

description:
For hosting private events, One Market is divine.  Their catering staff is friendly, reachable, and easy to work with.   Paired with the fact that their food and wait staff are great, this is one great restaurant.

5 stars.
author: R H.

description: I joined a party of favorites for lunch at One Market. Everything was spot on. The food was excellent. The wine and service were beyond reproach. We were well on our way to a 5 star experience until the bill was presented. When the waiter dropped the check we told him how much we enjoyed our meal and the service; to which he replied, in a very condescending tone, "The best way to show your appreciation is financially" and walked away. This unprofessional gesture spoiled our outing and will keep us from returning for some time to come.
author: Richard L. D.

description: This is one of a handful of go-to places for me when I travel to San Francisco. With all the new fancy restaurants opening every week in SF, I can't keep up, so when I make the trek from Sonoma, I like to host my business lunches here. The food is always seasonal and delicious. The service is consistent, professional and friendly. I like to come here at least twice a year,  July which is 1/2 off on all wine by the bottle in September for their heirloom tomato menu. Had a fantastic birthday lunch here last week. Kris and Jose made were outstanding and the kitchen turned out amazing food. This restaurant should have 2 Michelin stars, not just one. I can't recommend One Market enough.
author: Samantha W.

description:
Let me just start by saying that the only thing that gets on my nerves about this place is the entrance! LOL I don't know if it's just me but that velvet drape kills me! 

I came for dinner on Thursday and was immediately seated.  We had a long supper type table considering it was a group.  The staff was not the friendliest ehh, but despite that they still attended the table just enough to keep our waters, wine, & juices coming.

I ordered the Natural Angus NY Steak well done with a Caesar Salad, which I was very satisfied with & had no complaints.  The beef was perfectly cooked, considering a past visit when Well Done came a lil bloody.  The serving was just right & came with mashed potatoes & spinach, yumm! The Caesar Salad here is one of my favorites, big crispy leaves with huge, crunchy, fresh croutons! Mmm, my only problem is the croutons LOL I feel like the whole world can hear me crunching on them :)

I ended the night with the seasonal dessert trio, which included a pecan pie with vanilla ice cream, pumpkin creme, almond tuile, & gingerbread loaf.  Now this has to be one of my fave desserts ever, highly recommended while it lasts!
author: Christina O.

description:
The food was too expensive and the portions were small.  The salad and the breakfast was mediocre and if it wasn't for cruising around the Farmers Market on Saturday mornings, we could have made these entrees at home.  

Skip the One Market restaurant and try the local vendors at the Farmers Market.  Wish I had.
author: Nell C.

description:
Someone is going to have to explain to me why people like to go to this place.  Even more, how they managed to swing a Michelin star.  Is the food pretty good, I would say yes.  Is it worth the price and deserving of the Michelin star, no way.  Everything is a bit above average.  Food, decor, service.   First, the food is very typical.  I had the duck.  The flavor was OK, but it was basically three small strips of duck breast is a sweet reduction of some sort.  It was so typical, I can't even remember what it was.  I also had about a 1-2oz block of duck confit.  All for the bargain price of $30.  For portions so small at these prices, I am going to need some sort of point of view from the chef.  Again nothing special here.  I would rather walk 15 mins to chinatown and get 2 whole ducks for the same price.  

Decor, nothing special except for the view of the ferry building.  Maybe they thought they can get away by cutting corners since they have a good view to lean on.  The place looked like the spawn of an Idea and a pottery barn.  Nothing special.  

Service.  My biggest complaint here is that they have these really deep booths and hire short servers.  We ended up having either someone reach over us (almost knocking over drinks) to hand us food, or more often than that, we had to pass plates to each other.  The server kept on saying "be careful the plate is hot" yet is unable to place the dish in front of the customer.  What are we supposed to do but get our hands burnt.  

The Michelin reviewers should be ashamed,  May they be cursed with a lifetime of bad meals for making such a bad call.
author: Scott C.

description:
One Market Restaurant has horrible robotic service and poorly trained waitstaff. Do not come here unless you want to be treated like a peasant, and made to wait. Given their reputation and cost, I would expect so much more from One Market and highly recommend that you look elsewhere for fine dining experiences in San Francisco.

Long story short, my company had a 40 person event at this restaurant last night. I am suffering from a chronic cough so my girlfriend and I both personally asked at least four off the waitstaff numerous times to bring me some tea. It took these incompetents over 12 minutes to bring me some hot water as I sat coughing up a lung. 12 minutes for water and tea leaves??

I would never come here again, either as a patron or as a guest.
author: Mike C.

description:
I've been to One Market twice now for work lunches.  The first time was several years ago, and I recall the duck ravioli was really salty.

This time around, I ordered the grilled mahi mahi and chose the chickpea fries as my side.  I have to say, the mahi mahi was flawless - had nice grill marks but was still very moist and the fish's flavor game through.  It came with this delicious "salsa" that must have included apples; I could have eaten just this stuff all day long.

The order of chickpea fries is quite generous, and the cornmeal crusted pieces of mashed chickpeas are also hearty.  I can't say the dipping sauce had too much flavor to it, but this was a definitely a side dish worth trying.  Everybody at my table asked me what it was.

For the price, One Market isn't a place I would come to without an expense account, but the food is well prepared and the service is friendly.  They also understand the need for fairly swift service for business lunches, which I appreciate.  Thanks One Market!
author: Naoko M.

description:
Rating = More like a 3.5.

I went here on a Saturday night for my bf's company holiday party.  It was held in the foyer in the back which easily fit 200 people.  There's a high ceiling and the mood was set very nicely!  I enjoyed the water art display in the center.  

The food was pretty good.  Usually when mass produced, even the best restaurants can ruin it!  For appetizer, we had bread & cheeses (brie, blue cheese, white cheddar & some other smelly but tasty one).  For the main course, there was prime rib, brussel sprouts, spinach, mashed potatoes, dinner rolls & at the end of the table you can customize 3 different types of pasta (ravioli, tortellini, rigatoni) with 3 types of sauce (tomato, pesto, alfredo).  It's funny because they make it look all fancy but the server just dumped some pasta/sauce into the pan and apathetically moved it around before sliding it onto my plate.  HAHA!  For dessert, they offered a chocolate fondue accompanied by pineapples, brownie bits, mini pecan pies, cookies, etc.  

I like how the foyer is so huge.  You can definitely have a wedding here because it's practically soundproof so it doesn't disturb the rest of the restaurant.  Service was also great... all the servers were incredibly polite.  As for this restaurant, I don't know if I'd come here on my own accord.  It seems like any other upscale American restaurant primarily for the white collar business folks.
author: Shannon L.

description:
I'm happy to see that time has not changed all the elements that I have enjoyed so much about One Market.   I've been here for personal and professional events over the years, with my latest visit being this past week.  The good service, attention to detail and upscale American farm-to-table food are still present.

On this most recent visit, I met up with a couple of friends for happy hour.  Our original spot was a bust (you could have swatted flies in there...it's a Chinese saying as there were NO actual flies in there!) so we took a walk to find a locale that was a bit more lively and One Market was fit the bill perfectly!  They had a decent crowd, good HH menu and reduced prices on a few wines and spirits.  We started off with glasses of prosecco and orders of the sliders, chickpea fries and lettuce cups.  I thought the mini-burgers were a bit dry and the fries were okay but could have been more crisp.  The lettuce cups contained small chunks of pork belly and were pretty tasty.   Even though the bar area was packed, several people waited on us during our time there.

After a couple of hours we decided to stay and have dinner and moved to the dining room.  I had left my unfinished glass of sparkling wine in the bar and our waitress was kind enough to bring it to our table.  A gesture that was much appreciated on my part.  

There were so many dishes that I wanted to order after perusing their menu, but my stomach would not allow for that, given that I had already eaten earlier.  I ended up with the petrale sole, prepared sous-vide, with shrimp, clams and mussels.  The seafood was very fresh, with the fish light and rather delicate, and the portion size just right to satisfy my hunger.  For dessert we decided to share the chocolate toffee almond crunch cake with vanilla ice cream.  Toffee bar + chocolate cake + ice cream = "What did you say?  Shhhh!  Don't bother me while I'm eating this."  It was quite delicious.  This was listed as one of their "Singular Sensations" and was portioned at half the size of their regular desserts.   Personally, I thought this size was perfect and wished more restaurants would return to "normal" portion sizes for their desserts.   Throughout the meal our wait staff was attentive and quite friendly, especially our primary waiter.

Whether here to entertain clients, celebrate a life event or just enjoy a nice meal, One Market still shines with good, fresh, well executed food, efficient and attentive service and a good bar scene.
author: Melissa L.

description: Solid business lunch restaurant. The menu is seasonal.  Great selection if fresh fish/oysters. The vegetables are always beautifully and tastefully prepared.  The service is always great. This place has been a trusted lunch spot for years. In the financial district and a stones throw from the embarcadero/ferry building.
author: Rose F.

description:
The bread is great but the butter is better!  I love butter and the flavor of this butter takes me back to distant beautiful travels.  mmm

We had the Scallop salad for starters and though beautifully arranged it didn't excite me.  The scallops were small, raw and very strong in taste, almost like a sea urchin for me.  Thank goodness it came served with citrus and sharp tasting greens to contrast.  Next time I would pass.

The best entree we had was the mussels in curried broth.  Beautifully steamed and the flavors and colored were just right.  It was exciting to eat!

The Tombo Tuna Salad was just ok.  It's a seared raw tuna on a bed of stringed cucumber, ringed with mango and red-onion pieces.  Meh.  There have been so many incarnations of seared tuna, It's a safe choice akin to a chicken teriyaki.  But at least it was made of quality ingredients.

Now the part that makes me smile all the way to the gym!  Worth every calorie was the Chocolate Toffee Crunch Cake!  Can I get a Hallelujah?  Oh my gosh!  I will dream of this cake anytime I want a chocolate cake!  It's the best Chocolate cake I've had in a long, long time.  Heavy in Chocolate flavor but light in density of the cake itself.  Not too much frosting, but just enough to glue the toffee and nuts to itself.  It's perfection on a plate.

Oh we also had the Creme Brulee in Vanilla and Coffee but for me the coffee creme brulee was weak and both paled in comparison to the Toffee Crumb Cake.  

And get their Coffee.  They French press them.  I'd go back just for the dessert!
author: Gina K.

description: Came here for a corporate event. The steak was good. Will try their normal menu next week.
author: Tracy D.

description:
My wife and I have eaten at One Market a number of times over the past few years.  The first time was during DAT and we had a really great collection of dishes that really had a great collection of tastes.  I started with the cauliflower soup and then had skirt steak.  My wife had the squid appetizer followed by duck.  Dessert was apple dumpling (amazing) and chocolate soup.

Our followup visits since then have all been great as well.  We've always had excellent service, great food and a very pleasant meal.
author: Richard M.

description:
I took wife here for her Birthday and both the food and service are excellent. Both my cow tongue salad and pork tenderloin medallions where perfect and my wife's scallops where spot on.

Service was attentive although touching on the slow side the food more than made up for this. Reasonably priced for the quality.
author: Mark Anthony H.

description: Sat at the Chef's counter with my husband. The fois gras and octopus starters were delicious. Note:  the staff is super efficient so if you wish to enjoy a slow-paced dinner don't order your entre' until you are ready to eat. My husband ordered the ahi. It was as to be expected, cooked seared and delicious. I ordered the duck. It had an extremely perfect complimentary sauce with duck sausage on the side. The duck sausage would be perfect in a sandwich. It was very old European. We watched Tomas and Pedro, both Mexicans, cook. They were the stars of the show. Neither ever had to say a word.  They were in perfect sync and worked hard, and with pride.  I would hire either of them in half a second.
author: Rosalie K.

description:
I went here today with a friend and we ordered 1 ham and cheese sandwich , 1 ckn salad and 1 basket of fries ...  Food came out real quick except the easiest thing that i ordered ... the fries...  ... 

The basket of fries finally arrived as i took my last bite of my salad... I honestly asked 3 people for the fries and when it finally came out.. the sever never said "ohh i sorry" or " do you still want the fries".. he just brought it out like it was the main course... and 2 mins later the bill came out.... and i thought to myself.. well he wont charge me for the fries.. and he did... 

overall food was good.
author: V b.

description:
I don't get all the hype about this place. I wasn't disappointed but I wasn't impressed either.  Our waiter was nice and all the bussers had our tables cleared and water filled very quickly.

Food was ok.  the Foie Gras was good, but I've had better for much cheaper. The Bacon wrapped pork tenderloin was ok - everything was over powered by the bacon, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, it just wasn't what I was expecting.  The Bay Scallops were good. Teeny tiny portion. I mean, a normal amount of scallops for a single portion, but everything else was tiny. I had two spoons of rice and then 5 spoons of that sea foam stuff on top. I am not a fan of the foam and I only remembered that when they put the dish down in front of me.  The Sturgeon was really good. The dessert (Valrohna souffle) was ok. I've personally made better souffles and I'm not great at cooking or baking, so maybe my expectations were too high - maybe I'm better than I thought (haha)

I've been waiting to come back to this place for a year since I came for lunch in 2009 and I find myself unsatisfied. I won't be back unfortunately. That said, it wasn't a bad meal, it was just, normal. I'll never pay $200 for dinner for 3 again here.
author: Kym P.

description:
Thanksgiving feast 2011 at One Market. 
Wow, thank you for making my tummy so happy this year.

We had a remarkable view from our table. The ferry building framed beautifully by the elegant, big windows. The eye candy waiter (impeccable service) also contributed to the stunning visual experience. Lol. 

Amuse-bouche: 
quinoa, liver mousse and cauliflower. The liver mousse stood out from the bunch. It was earthy yet light with a hint of sweetness. 

Duck agnolotti: 
Delicious. My taste buds thank you, chef. 

Beet carpaccio:
I'm not a huge fan of beets, but my friend who ordered it loved it. 

Turkey 2nd course
Not a huge fan of turkey, but the corn bread stuffing was great! My friend loved it!

Pork loin 2nd course
oh. mi. goodness. I tried really hard not to lick the plate. It was so good. I have never had pork cooked so perfectly. Not even at NOPA. It was literally mouth watering good. Michelin star well deserved. 

Didn't really try the dessert, but they looked damn good!
author: Emily T.

description: January and June are two of my favorite months in San Francisco, specifically because of Dine-About-Town, when restaurants all over the city offer 3-course prixe fixe menus for cheap. Last night, my friends and I went to One Market to take advantage of their Dine-About-Town Specials: 3 course meals for $36.95 (standard) or $44.95 (deluxe). Add another $15 for wine pairing. Yes, the maitre d' could use a lesson in warmth and hospitality. However, our server Steve made up for it with his ebullient personality. Two of us opted for the Deluxe selection with wine pairing. I had the Tombo Tuna Carpaccio, Liberty Farms Duck Breast with Sunchokes and Duck Andouille Sausage (super salty). I wish I had read the menu more clearly, because my entree did not come with any starch at all --- no potatoes, pasta or risotto to temper the flavors of the duck (which was divine). For dessert, I had the White Chocolate Creme Fraiche Panna Cotta, which just melted in your mouth.The busboy seemed like he was in a bit of a hurry, as the pacing between courses felt rushed. For example, he attempted to clear my appetizer plate when I hadn't put down my fork, and had one bite left. On another occasion, our server asked which one of us was the birthday celebrant (none) and another maitre d' stopped by to say "How's the Birthday Celebration going?" Ummm.... it's not.The dinner company more than made up for these few WTF moments, and overall still had a wonderful evening.
author: Marcus J.

description:
Pros: Restaurant was able to sit a party of six (without a reservation) at the chef's table in the kitchen for a Friday lunch meeting. Fun to see the behind the scenes of a busy kitchen. The food was also very nice. 

Cons: One very long, very strong black hair in a colleague's brussel sprouts. So intertwined that removing the hair lifted the entire sprout. When we were finally able to track our server down (poor service in the back?) he whisked it right away, but there was never any apology from him/the manager, etc. When you're spending $300+ for lunch I'd expect at least an offer to remove that meal from the check. 

We probably caught One Market by surprise by not having a reservation, but they simply shouldn't have sat us if they weren't prepared to wait the table with any kind of consistency. And hair doesn't usually sick me out, but this was pretty horrific.
author: Natalie W.

description:
The restaurant was great overall, however they did make one mistake that simply ruined my appetite.

We were seated next to the bussing station where the staff inputs their orders and also at this station was a dish of delicious caramels that they give you with your check.

I would say we had been sitting for three or four minutes before my hand slithered over to the dish and before appetizers came I think I had four or five candies in my belly.

Joking aside, the service and food were both great.  The place was busy, but not overly loud.  We had a great table near the restaurants huge windows overlooking the ferry building area and it was nice to be able to do a bit of people watching while we sat there.

Bonus points awarded for the colossal potato tots and house-made ketchup!
author: Gary M.

description:
For a restaurant with a Michelin Star, I expected to be wow-ed but was disappointed.  The good: great location, grand space, pleasant service, and yummy desserts. Requires improvement: appetizers and main course dishes. 

We came here with the family for Dine About Town 2010. 3 of us ordered dishes from the Dine About Town menu ($34.95), 2 from the Market prie fixe menu ($44.95), and 1 ala carte. 

- The Cauliflower soup was decent, with tasty ingredients 
- Octopus appetizer from the Market menu was a little on the salty side and not much flavor aside from that
- Chick pea fries tasted like fried polenta
- Skirt steak, when done right, was decent. My brother-in-law's dish came out overdone and charred.
- Black code was oily, which is a good thing, but certainly takes skills to get it right.  It was a little fishy.
- Scallops and sweetbread was a sad little dish. Only four small scallops and two heavily breaded sweetbread (that doesn't taste anything like sweetbread we had elsewhere). The dish was supposed to have Matsutake mushrooms but we didn't find any in the dish.
- The best part of the meal was certainly dessert.  All the dessert dishes were pretty good. My favorite were the chocolate soufflé (from the Market menu) and bread pudding (from the DAT 2010 menu).

If you come here for Dine About Town 2010, get the cauliflower soup, skirt steak, and bread pudding.  Otherwise, consider a dessert dinner!
author: Christine C.

description:
I knew that this place had one Michelin Star so I was really excited to try it.  I expected not just good but GREAT service and awesome food.

The food was indeed pretty good.  A group of about 8 of us came here while they had Dine About Town.  I tried the baked scallop cauliflower soup which was delicious, the rice flake crusted baked sole and bread pudding.  Their dishes are a nice "twist" on the classic American menu.

The service, however, was terrible. I know that since we were going for Dine About Town, we're obviously not "regular patrons" who frequent the restaurant but since there was such a big group of us, an 18%+ tip was pretty much guaranteed.  Our server never came to refill our drinks, made a mistake on the bill and didn't even apologize for the mistake and I even caught her rolling her eyes at us and whispering to her co-worker about us.  Yes!  I am sure! 

Just because it's an upscale-one Michelin star-highly rated restaurant doesn't mean that they are entitled to provide snobby service.
author: Gloria C.

description:
I've come here a couple of times for recruiting lunches/dinners and it is nice. The atmosphere is very professional and they do have good food.

I will admit, it's pricey, but since I didn't have to pay for it myself, no big deal. The best part of my meal was the delicious duo of creme brulees. Vanilla and chocolate? Ah, it's love.
author: Nina Y.

description: Attended a private event here, so not your typical resto experience.  The space is beautiful - light and warm.  One Market staff were attentive and the event was well organized.  The food was good and set up as themed stations - oysters/raw, sliders, cheese/crackers, dessert.  All very cute and creative.
author: DC L.

description:
I read the reviews before I went, and was surprised a Michelin rated restaurant had such low Yelp reviews.  I quickly found out why.

I unfortunately followed in a man with mental illness who hid behind the curtain by the front door, talking to himself.  I let a waiter know, who let management know, who quietly asked the man to leave.  I was then ignored.  I tried to stand out of the way and waited for my party to arrive.  

After we were seated, I was impressed the waiter noticed we were wearing black and substitued black napkins for white.  That's where being impressed ended.  There were very long waits between getting the menu, getting our wine order taken, getting the wine, our food selections being taken, and then getting plates.  This weighs heavily in my bad experience.  

I ordered the charcuterie plate.  It was delicious, with at least 5 kinds of meats, although one of the meats was purely fat, no red meat, just white fat, blech.  The radishes and pickled grapes, and jam, were delightful.  I split it with my friend and saved room for dinner.

I've always wanted to try sturgeon and was thrilled it was on the menu.  What I got was so salty it was inedible.  I would have liked to tell the waiter, but after dropping it off he didn't come back, so as my dining companions finished their meal, mine sat untouched.  When he finally returned, after my companions had finished, I was able to tell him it was awful.  He said, "Oh, sorry!" and took it away.  About five minutes later he thrusts a menu in front of me, telling me I can order an appetizer or small plate.  No thanks.  I've been here about an hour and a half, I'm tired, I've just eaten half a salt lick, and I have a 45 minute BART ride home, and I would be the only one eating since the others were finished.  I'm done.  I let him know I didn't want anything else and he seemed offended.  The waiter opined the sauce may have been too salty, and I'm sure it was overreduced,  I just suggested the chef taste it.  

By then our dinner was a downer, even though my companions liked their meals, so we skipped dessert and coffee and headed out.  

It was loud, the service was poor, and the food was inedible.   Is that Michelin star worthy?  Not to me.
author: Rebecca H.

description: Up until today, One Market had been my "go to" restaurant of choice for business lunches - service was good and food was consistent.  After today, I will be taking my business elsewhere.  First, we waited 20 minutes and no one came by to offer us water, give us menus or acknowledge our existence.  This is unacceptable, particularly for a business lunch.  After requesting a waiter, I thought the worst was over.  Unfortunately, it was not.  Everyone at the table had the 2-course business lunch.  All agreed that both the starter salad and the main course were extremely salty, almost to the point where they were inedible.  Needless to say, I will not be back.
author: Chris O.

description:
Surprisingly there were a few tables open in the bar for happy hour, so my friend and I spontaneously jumped in.  It was only 5:40pm and it wasn't packed as usual.  

Happy hour has $5 wines and $4 beer on tap.  The bar food is all regular price.  We started off with the cheesy donuts??  Weird, but oh so bad and GOOD.  The little doughy donuts are freshly fried then topped with some cheese.  There's a little heat to them too.  A nice surprise to wake up the heavy taste.

After munching on our sinfully delicious donuts and alcohol, we figured we'd try to hop over to the other side of the restaurant to dine for dinner.  So I used my handy dandy phone that I cannot live without, and went to Open Table to see if there were any seats.  6:30pm for 2 booked!  Easy....

The server had overheard us booking and kindly brought us over our tab and helped us move over.  Nice asian lady...she waited on us before and it seems like she's the only lady who handles the HH crowd.  Kudos to her for working so hard.

So far so good, slightly buzzed, in the mood to eat and have a nice meal.

I didn't want to become wasted ( i get easily buzzed) so I opted for a non alcoholic drank~ Mint Lemonade - to be spoiled is lovely....fresh mint, simple syrup, fresh lemons squeezed to make this heavenly slushy drink that's slightly sweet, refreshing, and oh so classy feeling.  It was pretty much the highlight of our meal.  

To make this quick, we ordered the following:
1. mahi mahi ceviche - free appertif
2. foi gras - 19.95 for a nice healthy serving of it, broth was delicious, but after reminding myself again of the torture that the animal goes through to produce that fatty liver, I've decided to NEVER, EVER eat foi gras again...*gulp*
3. Med-Rare slices of white fish on top of potatos/beans with a red FOAM - i HATE foam...it looks like spit and that's such an old food trend that was phased out A LONG TIME AGO!!!  STOP IT!  no wonder you're NOT Michelin rated anymore.  I ate just one slice of white fish and stopped right there.
4. Friend had wednesday special - thin slices of veal.  A plate of thinly sliced veal on top of a red sauce - meat was pretty rare itself, and on top of a dark red sauce just seemed like it was drowning in it's own sauce...you'd definitely get the boot if you were on Top Chef.
5. Apple Turnover accompanied with a small ginger milkshake - perfect, divine, no complaints.  This dessert would be ea 4.5 star.
6. Coffee - served in a french press, strong and good like it should be.  

I opt for the 2 star because the entree is the main dish and as the main dish, they failed.  Our waitress was also VERY slow, avoided eye contact, and felt like she was running back and forth unnecessarily.  She really irked me.

I did come during lunch and thought service was ABOVE par, lunch menu was also much more enticing (there was no foam - I had the gnocchi with duck and it was amazing, bit salty, but VERY good).  I'd recommend this place for lunch.  Maybe there's a different chef that runs the joint during dinner.
author: Janet L.

description:
I took the lady here last night for V-Day and it was quite the treat.

Unfortunately, the freaking pajama party was going on across the street so valet parking was a nightmare and there were feathers everywhere.  No fault to the restaurant, but it was just a nuisance worth mentioning in case you want to book this place for this holiday in the future.

To be honest, we showed up an hour late due to all the holiday madness (yes, I forgot...dammit).  However by the time the valet took my car, our table was ready.  And we got a view of the Embarcadero :)

The decor is the type of retro glamor I like, but subtle.  The service was great; our server was very attentive and was polished enough to talk to everything on the menu and adequately on the wine list.  This is the difference between normal restaurants and fine dining.  The servers come by and survey the table without bothering you.  Once in a while, they will ask if you need anything, but they won't ask every single time they pass your table.  That is really nice.

The menu tonight was prix fixe, which was kind of a bummer because I really wanted to try the foie gras, but it also means I'm probably dropping less Lì Xì (or Hóng Bo) for the two of us, jk.

One of the servers actually brought us an amuse bouche compliments of the chef (probably because of the holiday or that it took a while to get some fresh bread) and it was delightful.  For our real starters, we had the

Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout "Mi Cuit"
potato rösti, organic chicken egg, pancetta vinaigrette

and the

Hand-picked Dungeness Crab
green apple water, jalapeno, cilantro

The smoked trout was DELICIOUS.  I was so jealous that my gf got that because the crab was fresh and delicate, but we both thought that the green apple belonged in a granita.  It made for interesting textures with the jalapeno sorbet, but it wasn't my particular cup of tea.  I could have totally made a meal out of the trout though...I mean 62 degree cooked eggs...MMM.

For the main course, we had

Pan-Seared Day Boat Scallops
sweet breads, matsutake mushrooms, sunchokes 

and

12oz All Natural Angus New York Steak
red wine butter, béarnaise relish

I could tell by the smirk on the corners of her mouth that my gf REALLY like the delicateness and flavor of the scallops.  And had I had them before my steak, I would've agreed.  The steak was delicious.  It was a little tougher than the NY cuts I cook at home, but it was THICK and juicy.  I mean it's NY, not filet.  The creamed spinach it came with was also really nice and the relish was just the right amount of punch.

For dessert, there was a chocolate sampler and crème brulée.  The chocolate was awesome.  It's hard to describe, but they had a small glass that had layers of cream and chocolate mousse with a chocolate crunch on the bottom with some sort of chocolate covered something (like berries) on the top.  It was accompanied by a pétite brownie with raspberry syrup.  My brulée was up there with the better ones I've had.  It wasn't too rich (common mistake) and it was perfectly creamy.  There were fresh raspberries on top and it was served with an almond/pistachio biscotti and chocolate ice cream.

I will say for the money, the prix fixe menu was a good deal and the food was awesome.  There are plenty of places in the Fin District that tout great food but are overpriced because they've become complacent.  This is NOT the case here, especially for the location (like how the Cliff House used to only rely on the location and not the reputation of the chef).  This is a great choice for special occasions or anything else.
author: Dylan T.

description:
I've been to One Market a couple of times, and the food and service has been consistently good. The house made gnocchi with duck leg is my favorite... it's sooo good. Probably one of my favorite dishes ever. I would go back to One Market just to get that dish (actually... I'm already doing that in a couple of weeks). Also, I'm not a big dessert person, but their duo of creme brulee is perfect. 

I've had some dishes there that I thought were "good" not "great", but even when I get something that 's not my favorite, it's still creative and unique. The bad thing about this is that not everything on their menu is wonderful (in my opinion)... I feel like when trying a new dish there, there is a chance that I might be wishing I got something else instead. 

I like how the atmosphere here is upscale and professional, but not stuffy. Great place to have a business lunch. And seriously.... try the gnocchi!

Bottom line is, everytime I go here I have a wonderful exprerience, and I always leave planning my next visit...
author: Alison B.

description:
I would have given them a 3 star if the waiter wasn't a total dick. We were at their bar for a bit but wanted to sit at a table and have a bite to eat. It wasn't busy or crowded so we quickly had a table. My companion tried to order a salad and asked if they could add chicken to it. He plainly said no. OK, how about Tuna or another fish? No. OK, throw me a bone here, what CAN you add to it? Or should we just keep guessing at what you don't have? Same story with my order. Basically, he was very unhelpful and seemed upset even being there. He sighed and rolled his eyes. Hmm, OK. I just didn't get it. I would have just walked out if I didn't already have an open tab.

It salad was OK. Nothing special. The service was the worst I have had in ages. Generally a nice place, but not nice enough to deal with a boner like that...
author: Justus P.

description: My boss took me and the rest of my coworkers here for our Christmas dinner. Our server's name was chase and he was great! He knew everything about the menu, which is a plus to me. Now the reason for the two stars. First of all, every course took forever to come out. Secondly, the food wasn't that great. Also, parking sucks around here. I suggest taking bart or muni if you're deciding to eat here. I would like to give this place another try, but it's hard especially since the food wasn't too impressive..
author: Mertani G.

description:
This is a story of a slow, not so good start but eventually got better as the night go on......
Made a reservation for bf's bday and requested for a booth seat...
My reservation was for 7pm but the stuffy host seated the 7:15 reservation before us claiming they are getting a "booth" ready for us...... 
But we were led to a regular table .. I had to point out all the other available booths to get seating as I noted in my reservation.....
Despite the slight frustration the evening got better as we received tentative service and enjoy the meal.
The sides dishes and the appetizers were better than their entrees so we tweak the menu to our liking started out with side dishes as appetizers...
The chick pea fries was delightful and the trout was yummy.....
I would love to come back and check out their happy hour~~!!
author: YC L.

description:
2.5 Stars for the Food.  Not terribly bad,  but not good either.  

NEGATIVE FIVE, YES, - 5 for the Service.

Steven was the server and what a FREAKN jerk.  I can say that we've been to all the hot and 5 star restaurants in the city. Also, the neighborhood gems.  NEVER in my life have I stiffed a tip but tonight made it a point to give him $2.  He was a rude, jerk who used ignorant judgement bantering with his co-workers and taking no interest in serving us.  

Overall, very disappointing considering Lark Creek is the Parent.
author: Ed M.

description:
I've eaten here 3 times and had a fantastic experience every time.

Depending on how much you can spend on a lunch or a night out, this is either a special occasion restaurant or a great lunch spot.

They feature a rotating menu of fresh ingredients, the decor is fantastic and the food has always been excellent.  That said, you are going to spend some serious money here, more if you order alcohol.

One part of their menu which is relatively cheap is the deserts - they have several $5.50 options which are just the right size for a sweet taste after a satisfying meal.  The last time I was here I got their "creme brule pair" - one vanilla, one cappuccino.  Delicious.
author: Ryan F.

description:
Went for dinner and was not impressed at all. The waiter was excellent. The atmosphere is good, but they need a new chef. Dinner was not impressive. The fish (sturgeon) was terribly prepared - bad presentation and lack of flavor. 
Did not order meat, so could be that their steaks are good, not sure.
author: Martin K.

description: A good place for happy hour. Cozy and urban at the same time. Except, only get drinks, not food. Food's expensive!
author: Andrew K.

description:
I was part of a group that went to One Market this week for what could best be described as a "business dinner."  Some of us drove over from Berkeley, and that worked very well:

If you make a 7:15 reservation and have three people in your car, you can slip over the Bay Bridge as a carpool if you hit the toll plaza before 7PM and then park essentially for free in a "no stopping until 7PM zone" on the Embarcadero, which of course you'll arrive in just after 7PM.  Neat, isn't it!  BART is a great thing, but it's missing a lot of its timed transfers in Oakland these days.  It really is no fun sitting around on a platform for 20 minutes late in the evening after a nice dinner in the City.  It was probably helpful that there was no Giants game scheduled for the evening of our visit.

When we arrived at One Market at 7:15, the bar area was dense with fat cats who were numbing their taste buds with specialty cocktails before stepping out onto the street for a cigar or two.  Quite a few of those cats then took seats in the restaurant for their filet mignons and triple-digit Napa cabernets.  We avoided the cats and the cabs, but we did get occasional whiffs of the cigars as the main doors opened and closed.  If you're sensitive to smoke, request a table away from the podium.  (We didn't -- our bad.)  Full disclosure: I had a filet mignon, and it was a winner!

As other yelpers have reported, the atmosphere in the restaurant is serious and adult.  The service is very professional and a bit formal, but it's not stuffy.  The team who took care of us did a good job, except for one detail: after our server came to take our drink order and we replied that we wanted to look at the wine list, no one came to ask us for our wine choice for what seemed to be 20 minutes.  When the question was finally popped ("what wine will you be ordering"), I replied with a question or two of my own.  This triggered a visit from the sommelier, who was knowledgable, charming and helpful.

We ended up with a delicious sauvignon blanc from Somebody's Family Vineyard; I'm thinking that it was the Hall Napa Valley Sauvignon Blanc, but I'm suddenly not sure!  As a second wine, we had a Donkey & Goat mourvedre that was a real treat.  There are wines for as low as $40 (or maybe even a tad lower), but there are also plenty of bottles in the $100+ range.  Their chardonnays and cabernets were not bargain wines.  The bottles on the list were chosen with great care; clearly, the sommelier who came to speak with us loves every single one of her children.  All of the wines are from California.

Oh yeah, on to the food.  These guys take themselves seriously, and they include plenty of touches that signify high-end dining: an amuse gueule at the start of the meal, warm breads before your first course comes out, a fruit gummy on a stick when the check arrives.  (Maybe they should also include a jar of tranquilizers.)  The kitchen is definitely not running on auto-pilot, and I liked what I ate.  My starter was the "Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout `Mi Cuit' potato røsti, pancetta vinaigrette, pastured chicken egg" @15.00, and I loved it.  For my main dish, I chose something simple, the filet mignon that I mentioned above.  It's Thursday's "daily roast": Filet Mignon, pancetta wrap, caramelized onions $31.50.  What comes on your plate is basically a big hunk of meat.  You definitely need one of the farmers' market sides, as they're called ($6.75 each); I selected the Sautéed Spinach with garlic chips and was happy enough.  (The garlic chips were great.)

To summarize, this sounds like a 4-star experience.  However, I must confess that I haven't become a fan.  The restaurant feels too established, too corporate.  It's all a matter of taste -- I'd rather go elsewhere, but this may be your spot.
author: Kenneth R.

description:
It's OK for DAT. 

Came here on for the lunch special with coworkers.  After sitting down, you can already tell....business lunches galore.  Half these people sitting and ordering mid day alcoholic drinks must be expensing this or doing a deal requiring it.  It's just that though.  A nice charming area right by the ferry building along the Embarcadero serving up decent, not great food, but defining what I'd see as a business meal whether it be lunch or dinner.  

But unfortunately, for us public workers, we don't get to indulge in that sort of fantasy, and so my coworkers and I went with a DAT option.  Overall, i was satisfied with my meal but not very impressed.  I've been wanting (not eager) to try a meal here, but after all, I can leave saying I've had it and probably wouldn't have a full desire to come back unless there was good reason to.

My lunch?

-Sunchoke Veloute with black trumpet mushrooms, hazelnuts, and applewood bacon - Don't be fooled by the laundry list of ingredients, because it gets chopped up into little pieces and served in those fooling large soup plates.  I did enjoy it however as it came served with the items positioned in an empty bowl followed by a pour of the frothy soup to complete the dish.  This was perhaps my favorite dish, but of course, I'm a sucker for all types of soups.

-House Veal Bratwurst over a bed of veggies - quite a disappointment in flavor and texture, but perhaps the most filling amongst the other options.  It was either this or a ravioli, or a fish.  Certainly this monstrosity would fill me up and it sure did.  Along with the shanghai bok choy that went with it, I'll give it that its a hearty meal, but to call it a veal bratwurst.....doesn't that usually mean bockwurst?  It wasn't that.  I don't know what it was, but I tasted no veal in flavor or in texture.
author: Vincent K.

description:
More fancy than good, One Market is an archetypal business restaurant.  There are more ties on display in the dining room than there are in Nordstrom's down the street.

The service is sharp, the the decor professional.The menu reads wonderfully.

Unfortunately, the food is just okay.  Most recently the vinaigrette dressing on the salad was serviceable, but institutional.  The crab gnocchi had the real goods, but was heavy and flat and not up to showcasing the seafood. It was good stuff, but just not that tasty or special.

Still, the lunch was pleasant, and we could conduct business.  And, the service was impeccable.   

One Market is a place you go to when you're making an impression and validating that you are a real professional.  It's not a place to go to when you sincerely want to roll around like a dog because the food is so special.
author: Galen W.

description:
We decided to try The Weekly Beast menu that One Market has Friday and Saturday evenings.  

The Weekly Beast menu is a fairly well kept secret as the diners next to us were locals and this was the first they heard about it.  There's a weekly rotation between Pork, Duck, Veal and Beef.

The menu is 4 course for $45 and it was $18 for the wine pairing.

We decided to go during the pork menu and were blown away.  I was expecting mini portions but these were plentiful and nicely prepared.  The wine pairings were excellent and a good value at $18.  I work in the wine industry and was tempted to bring a bottle and pay corkage but decided to go with the pairing.  Wise choice.

Since it was after 6pm street parking is free.  I had to search for about 10 minutes before I got a space in front of 101 California.  Primo parking and por gratis.

The service was stellar as we have 4 waiters attending to our every need.  Our lead waiter was quick with the wine pairings with each course and explained each dish in detail.

It was one of those warm October nights in San Francisco so, it's good to get a table with a view of Market Street to do some people watching along with the meal.

We loved the maple bacon cheesecake.  Cheesecake had a slight liquid texture that was perfect.  Not your typical run of the mill cheesecakes. 

I don't know about the rest of the menu but The Weekly Beast is an awesome value.

Here is the menu we had along with the wine pairing.

MILK-BRAISED SUCKLING PIG SHOULDER
sweet corn, peppers, cilantro
Wine Pairing: Robert Sinskey Abraxis, Carneros  

Second Course
SUCKLING PIG LEG CONFIT
butter beans, tomato, orange
Wine Pairing: Capture Dark Rosé, Sonoma County  

Main Course
SPIT-ROASTED PORCHETTA
brown butter, pumpkin purée, chanterelles, cipollinis
Wine Pairing: Testarossa "Lark Creek Cuvée" Pinot Noir,  
  
Dessert Course
MAPLE BACON CHEESECAKE
caramelized quince
author: Scott B.

description:
For places that are have "higher" class, I usually expect more from what I usually get...if that makes sense.

To start off, the atmosphere is classy.  Pretty typical for how much you are paying.  Most people are in at least business casual.

Food: Was great.  To start my table ordered crab cakes for appetizers.  They were delicious and came in bite sized pieces which I thought was pretty cool.  For my Entree, I just had a simple half-chicken with mashed potatoes.  The chicken was perfectly cooked and the mashed potatoes were nice and creamy and buttery...mmmmmmm

But what really ticked me off was the service.  The hostesses seemed unwilling to seat us and looked like they were dying inside.  Our waiter was very pushy and aggressive and seemed to bother me more than being helpful.

Overall, the food is great, expected for that price, but the service is extremely lacking....
author: Ryan G.

description: I have not eaten here yet, but I am hosting a dinner for 12 on a very tight budget on Thursday night (1/22/15). I called the restaurant for ideas on how to stretch the budget and Beth in Special Events was so helpful! They recommended being in the bar and even set us up an area. I cannot wait to host my group at One Market. Thank you Beth!
author: Hilary M.

description:
Visited sf recently from Miami for a business conference.  Our host neglected to make dinner arrangements for the 20 people we were hosting, so I suggested One Market and ask for the chef's table in front of the kitchen.  

Perfect food, prix fix menu prepared for us, worked out spectacularly well (for about $3K).  If it gets too crowded for the chef's table, you can request the private dining rooms (2) immediately adjacent.  

Great place for a larger group, great bar to start.  Would highly recommend.  If the beef cheeks are available, go for it, none better.
author: Robert R.

description:
I've had better. My husband received a gift card to One Market during the holidays. Otherwise, we probably wouldn't have gone.
To be brief: 
The server was very confused about which oysters were being served. When you are spending $3+ dollars per oyster, it would be nice to know what they are and where they are from. If your staff can't remember the specials, have them write it down.
The ambiance is fine, but a bit depressing. Most of the couples there looked like they hoped poison was in the other's food. 
The food was good but not worth the $$ in my opinion. There are so many bomb-ass restaurants in San Francisco so why settle for less?
All in all, One Market is a very safe choice. If you are looking to spend a lot of money on a pretty good dinner, I would recommend it.
author: Sarah C.

description:
When my friend from Boston called saying she was in SF for a trade show this week, I went into one of my obsessive considerations of what would be the ideal dinner pick.  I consult all my favorite restaurant websites, I consider and reconsider the best location taking into account that I'm going to have to drive into The City at rush hour and she's going to have to find her way there from the Marriott in SOMA.  I carefully weigh the pros and cons of going someplace I've been to and like or trying someplace I've always wanted to go to and haven't visited yet.... accessible food vs. innovative.  Why can't I be normal and just select something good enough and move on!!

Anyway, I decided One Market was the best fit for all my overwrought criteria.  I hadn't been there for awhile.  I like that their valet parking is probably more economical than any nearby lot ($10), and since I'll be getting out by myself, I don't have to question the safety of walking through a lot at night.  

K was late, and since there's nowhere to sit except the bar, I had them take me to our table to wait.  I started with a martini with extra olives and sipped while perusing the menu (on to my next obsession the perfect food order).  The place ended up quite full, but our service was pretty good, even if we did  have to have  our busboy flag down our waiter to get our wine order.  I had the nightly rotisserie special, veal on Wednesdays.  When it came it was a plate almost completely covered with lovely, smokey, perfectly pink slices of what I think was from the leg with jus, and nothing else.  The waiter had warned that it came all by itself, so I ordered the sauteed spinach with garlic and fried green tomatoes on the side.  The spinach with the light golden garlic chips on top was perfect.  The green tomatoes had too much breading to tomato for me.  Though cooked correctly, the blue cheese mousse for dipping was too rich to go with the not very acidic tomatoes.

K had the scallops with a sort of deconstructed caponata under and around it.  We didn't share, so I don't know first hand, but she liked it.  Then we shared a small dessert, some sort of macadamia nut torte,   which was just good, not great, but as someone who's not big on sweets, I appreciate that they have a selection of desserts that are smaller and less expensive.
  
Total including the martini, one glass of Malbec, one of Sauvignon Blanc (both good, but short pours by my standards), SF. employee fee and tax was $118

Food: 37/40
Service:  16/20
Atm/facility:  17/20
Value/intangibles 16/20

=86/100 = B=4stars
author: Diane B.

description: Omg! Where do I start...first off I want to thank my waiter for being so imformative and making such excellent suggestions. He guided me perfectly, and even gave me small wine tasting to figure out what I wanted with my meal. Also...he sat me next to the most handsome brittish guy so I was definately a happy camper!  I got the olive bread that was really special...warm and soft on the outside with just the right amount of crispyness on the outside. The star of the evening was definately the pork belly blt(see photo). Im not usually a pork belly kind of girl but this was very lean and smokey. Artfully arranged with fried green tomatoes and seared romain it was pure colinary bliss! For my main dish I had the seared scallops that had a delightful molecular gastronomic flare with foamed mashed potatoes and deep fried artichokes. The whole place seemed to fill with a spectacular buzz you can only get in a San Francisco favorite like One Market. I thoughly enjoyed the experience here and hope I can come back again before I leave town!
author: Danielle M.

description:
I was really excited to try this place after all the reviews and how much everyone talks it up.  It was just okay.. actually I was a little disappointed.

I ordered their 12oz steak, medium, and while it was cooked perfectly, they gave us these horrible knives.  Now the knives looked cool, like hunting knives with a little bee logo soldered on (my bf's looked like it had fallen off) but it was a flat edge instead of serrated.  The knives looked like they were more meant for stabbing than cutting.  I was literally sawing at my steak and kind of wanted to give up half way through.  Also, the steak itself costs $33 and doesn't come with sides.  

My boyfriend and I ordered two sides which'll set you back about $6-7 each.  We got the buttery mashed potatoes, which were delicious, and the sauteed spinach, which had yummy roasted garlic chips on top.  Went well with the steak I couldn't cut.

Dessert was also good.  Creme Brulee was delicious and I adored the Key Lime Tart.

However, the fact that we had to saw our meat to death (bf used a butter knife because at least that had a serrated edge) and the fact that the steak was nothing to write home about, was a total deal breaker.  If I'm not impressed by one of their main courses then their supporting stuff doesn't matter as much.

Their olive bread was so good though.  Maybe I just need to try a different dish but for the price, I don't know when I'll be coming back.
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
Was there for New year's eve. It was a fantastic experience! We had a quiet table.  The staff was attentive and made appropriate recommendations and suggestions. 

I had braised beef cheeks for main course and was excellent.

What will bring me back is their smoked Tasmanian ocean trout 'mi cuit'.
author: Sadia A.

description: Friends took us to One Market for a pre-wedding dinner. Out of this world cocktails and the pork tenderloin is absolutely the best I've ever had! Service is impeccable.
author: Alan B.

description:
I've always wanted to go to a restaurant with Michelin Star honors. Unfortunately, One Market did not live up to my lofty expectations. 

The evening could not have gone off on a more sour note. We arrived at the front desk and a hostess had her back turned to us while she was on the phone. The other hostesses were running around until about 5 min later, one of them came out to take care of us. Mind you, there were about 3 or 4 parties behind us waiting to be greeted as well. 

The other reviewers' knocks on the service could not be more true. Our waitress did not even give her name. I bet this is due to the fact that she did not want us to complain to management by name about her unbelievably poor service to come. She was condescending and borderline RACIST. 

I'll just say that we were asian and younger than our waitress, and there was an older white couple to our right who sat about 5 min after us. Our waitress took our drink orders and then returned with the order. She then went to the white couple, took their drink order and then began to recite the Specials of the day, which sounded awesome and we would have totally ordered one (ceviche-style scallops starter). When she came back to our table, she never mentioned the Specials. WTF?! Does she think we would not order any appetizers because we're asian or not sophisticated enough to know what ceviche is? 

We also ordered bottled water. It was served out of a large glass bottle like wine, and the bottle was left on the table. It is a waiter's job to fill the glasses with liquid when it begins to run low, but this was not done. I actually made a point to refill our glasses with water when this bitch was at the older white's table (opening a bottle of wine) to show her she wasn't doing her job. 

Our food came out luke warm. WTF, again?! Our waitress didn't even serve us the food; it was served by another waiter. I even heard the bitch mumble a 'thank you' to him presumably because the food was just waiting in the window to be picked up and served. 

The crab dish we ordered even had shells in it. What kind of fine dining experience is that? Maybe I was expecting to be blown away, but the food was average for the price. There's nothing outstanding about it or memorable to warrant such accolades. It was no fine dining experience at all. I've been treated to much better experiences at In N Out. The experience was so bad during the dinner that I started talking about what other restaurants had way better food (like Ozumo, Morimoto, and Eve) and other places we need to try (like King Noodle, Mission Chinese and Andalu).

I ended the night with probably the lowest tip I've ever given for a $100 bill. 

I'll never go back to this place. Way overrated...
author: Vincent Y.

description:
For my graduation week I had my family come up from Europe to celebrate with me. My dad being a foodie & wino, my mom being on a tight budget, and my younger siblings not being able to stay at a restaurant for longer amount of time nor drink (11 & 12 years old), I had a hard crew to pick restaurants for.

That being said, One Market tried their best to accommodate all of us and we definitely appreciated that. Our server however had no clue about wine, which might be ok, since they have a sommelier , but having a bit of knowledge about wine would be great for a server working in a michelin star restaurant (our server didn't know a cabernet was red wine... just saying).

The sommelier was great and hit the wine on the spot. The food was alright, I definitely had better or similar for less money. 

Overall the service was good (not great, except for the sommelier) and the food was ok. The atmosphere is a little cold and I would just expect more from a 1 michelin star restaurant. I might come back for a bite or two, but definitely not for a special occasion anymore, nor would I be too excited to go again. Maybe, except for the wine!
author: Helen D.

description: Amazing food, great service and wonderful ambiance.  this is a great place for celebrations, quiet romantic conversation or just a place to reward yourself after a hard day at the office.
author: Curt T.

description:
*swanky place with some unique food*
#notforlunch
#greatseating

So we came for a work lunch and instantly knew this place was going to be swanky. Trying to keep it light we were just looking for a sandwich. Since they were booked for another 2 hours, we had the option of sitting at the bar or the "Chef's Bar" which we opted for the latter. This gave a pretty amazing look directly into their kitchen and was impressive to see the cooks at work making Risotto, and fried greens, and my sandwich. 

This menu was filled with exotic sounding dishes, none of wish I wanted for lunch. Their "business lunch" consisted of a 3 course meal, which was far too heavy for what I was looking for. I ordered the Cat Fish Po-Boy which seemed unlikely for a typically messy, sloppy sandwich. 

This place is definitely pricier, and for the ones who enjoy splurging on lunches on weekdays. The food took a while to come out, and in the meantime we were offered appetizers, a bottle of wine, and perhaps another look at the menu. 

My po-boy came out on a small bed of onion rings and the fried catfish sandwich. The breading was incredibly crispy and light, and didn't feel like I was eating pure fried oil. That contrast with the soft and fresh catfish was spectacular. The onion rings had a similar batter, and I actually tasted the onion as opposed to pure batter. The aioli in the sandwich was light and complimenting as well. 

My boss got a plain burger, but there "tater tots" were these massive cylindrical drums of potatoes that were well seasoned and well cooked. Crispy on the outside, and soft and flavorful potatoes on the inside. 

I'd be curious to check out their other unique dishes. Damn good tasting water too.
author: Kevin T.

description: Food OK. Nothing amazing. Their wine pairing is terrible. They need to renew their entire wine menu. It's pretty shitty...
author: Davy K.

description:
My wife and I met for a special valentines lunch
We waited ten minutes before anyone acknowledged we were there. 
We received no water or even offered a drink. 
We finally got up and left....the waitress finally approached us while we were complaining to the host telling us how she was "going to get to us"
Whatever!!!!
Too many other restaurant with good service.
author: John S.

description:
The bar area and bar menu are not great - I definitely wouldn't drop in here for a drink. The decor in general is sort of all over the place. I can't tell if they're trying to be 60's mod or what.

However, the food itself and dinner service is quite good so no complaints there. To be honest, for a 1-Michelin Star restaurant, I would expect the ambiance (including the bar, decor, etc) to provide a better overall experience.
author: Jigar C.

description: Experienced "in the kitchen" chef's table.  Wonderful food, wait staff was great.  Six course tasting menu and the executive chef explained each course.  Some of the courses were a full meal.  Wine pairing was great.  And then you finish the meal by making your dessert.  Very fun and worthwhile.
author: Kathleen G.

description:
OK, good food... but the portions are getting smaller and smaller!  The term "Elf Food" comes to mind.  I've been here a couple of times before, but this is the first time that I had to stare at the plate for a minute to absorb the fact that "that's it."

My friend and I shared the crab cakes.  Hmmm, crab poppers were more like it.  Three of them.  And a small salad.  While tasty, I couldn't get over that they were so tiny!!!  About half dollar sized.   I feel sorry for the woman next to us who actually order that as her entree.

After a fairly noticeable wait for our main course, I was a bit surprised when those dishes finally came to our table too.  I had the mahi mahi.  Small portion of fish, but nicely grilled, and served with some small potatoes and what I believe were little cubes of squash?  My friend had the gnocchi.  Wow... good thing we had bread on the table.  Big plate, and basically enough gnocchi to fill a half cup measuring cup. 

Honestly, from my previous visits, I don't remember portions being ridiculously petite like that.  Food wise, I want to give 4 stars, but I can't get over the portions.  I'm only giving 3 stars because the food is good.  I just wish there had been more of it.  Sadly, here I am two hours later, and I'm hungry.  Looking at other tables, we would have had  more substantial meal if we ordered the burger or sandwiches instead.  

My friend ended up getting a frozen yogurt nearby after lunch...  

The place isn't cheap.  We shouldn't be hungry leaving, and I definitely shouldn't have a growling tummy a mere two hours later.
author: Denise M.

description:
Went for a business dinner with colleagues.  The atmosphere was nice.  We were asked to wait for 20 minutes without a reservation past 8pm. 
The dishes were all well-done. Service was not professional...maybe they thought they could leave before our large party showed up.
author: Nina V.

description:
I had the worst experience at One Market last night. Especially all due to our rude waiter. When we first arrived around 7:30 pm, the host had to tap the shoulder of said waiter a few times before he stopped chitchatting with his friends. Without really acknowledging us, he started walking, my date and I looked at each other and agreed to follow him. He then left us and didn't come back after 10 minutes. When he did, I asked him what cocktail would he recommend from the menu, to which he replied "I am more of a shot and beer guy". I would have appreciated the joke if he had followed it with an actual recommendation. But he mention he had no idea what was listed on the menu (WTF?). So I granted him a menu and asked him this time what was popular, he still didn't want to give me a straight answer, I then sensed his apathy and asked him for a glass of Riesling.

 When it was time to order, we chose from the Market Menu, as you get 3 courses for a reasonable price. We also ordered the crab cakes appetizer, which I've had before and are to die for. After the first course came and went, we waited over 20 minutes without service, and we realized that the crab cakes wouldn't be coming when we saw the second course arriving. He had the swordfish an I had the duck; They were both great, though I didn't care for the sauce accompanying my dish, (it just tasted like barbecue sauce.) As we were starting eating our main dishes, the waiter finally reappeared and said, "I just noticed you didn't get your crab cakes. Do you still want them?" We declined -as we were already enjoying our second course- and  he walked away, without offering any apologies. Then, the unimaginable happened. I tried to cut one of my mini potatoes in half, but... IT WAS RAW!  I told the waiter "my potatoes are raw", to which he responded "I'd say" Again, no apologies, though he said "Can I get you anything else?" (aka "I don't really want to deal with you but I have to pretend I care")  I think that when these atrocities happen in a restaurant like One Market, you have trained your staff to be more attentive and offer solutions, not just leave it to your patrons to figure it out. We then ordered dessert, plus a single espresso, but again, I had to remind them of the espresso once we were almost finished with our meal. My date had one look at the tab and called the waiter to promptly remove my dish off the total. (At that moment then became my personal hero :) )

 Our waiter never apologized for anything. Those words do go a long way, even if nothing can be done to remedy things such as a forgotten dish or a RAW POTATO!

Ambiance is great, though.
author: Pony R.

description:
Could restaurant week please be every week?  I'm not rolling in dough these days (far from it, like most of America), but lord, did we ever have a delicious meal here.
