My boyfriend's birthday happened to fall during SF Chef's Week 2011 Restaurant Week, and how lucky for him - a $35 prix fixe dinner menu was all ours, and served by a young man who looked remarkably like one of my law school classmates.  (Sorry if I stared, sir, but the resemblance was eerie.)

He had the heirloom tomato soup and the alaskan halibut; I had the beet carpaccio and the bacon-wrapped pork-tenderloin.  Both were finished off by a peach dumpling with peach compote and vanilla ice cream.

The atmosphere is clean, spacious, and has a gorgeous view - perfect date spot (if you like your date and want to spend money on them, that is).  The service was impeccable.  Two months later, I think back to that meal and start drooling.  I'd say it was money well spent.
author: Jennie K.

description:
Service was good, food was average and the view was beautiful.  We got the wine pairing and tasting. Some of the pairings were better than others. I have never been more drunk at a Michelin star restaurant from a wine pairing. It was our anniversary and we forgot to do an obligatory anniversary shot. 

One Market on the romance scale is pretty up there. The ferry building glowing in the background is definitely a nice touch.
author: Margaret S.

description:
Went here for a client lunch. This place really gets 3 stars but our waitress Mickey (sp?) bumped them up another star. She was awesome! The food was satisfactory. I think for the price, there are plenty and I mean PLENTY of other restaurants to go to in the city. I've been here once before and I thought the food was better the first time but still not very memorable. The lobster bisque was warmish, would've been much better piping hot. Love the pouring theatrics though. I didn't care for the fennel in it though.

The catfish was eh. It was cooked perfectly but lacked a little bit in flavor. The chorizo was a tad bit too chewy but still provided enough flavor in the sauce to compensate for the bland fish. Now on to dessert...

The blueberry cheesecake was A-W-E-S-O-M-E! Perfectly sweet, graham cracker crust was lightly coated all over the cheescake and the sauce was amazing! My only issue with it was its tiny size. I could eat that all day...well, not really, but you get what I'm saying. My advice, go for the service, desserts and a drink or two. For food needs, find somewhere else to go.
author: Shariyah M.

description:
I went to One Market for Dine Around Town. It reminded me of Restaurant Week in Washington DC, which allows you to go to really expensive restaurants for a fixed price. Sadly, this proved not to be the same. In ordering the Dine Around Town menu, you pay equal, if not more, than the usual menu. I felt that it just wasn't worth it for that occasion. 

That said, the food was delicious. I found the waiters to a bit a bit pretentious. There is a fine line between respectful, high end service, and being a bit full of yourself. But once again, the food was good. 

I started with the broccoli soup which was nice. If you don't like the taste of broccoli, don't order it though. Because that's what it tastes like -- broccoli in smooth, creamy form. 

As my main I had the skirt steak. I'll give it a 4 out of 5. Very juicy but a bit too much. Not quantity wise, but it was a bit too heavy. Even though my stomach felt like it could take a bit more, my mouth just couldn't. The flavour was a bit too much. Good, but too much. 

All in all, I'm glad that I experienced this place, but I don't think that I will be going back. For the price, there are better places in the city.
author: Mariko F.

description:
One Market has always been on the list of Top San Francisco restaurants. It provides an elegant and sophisticated ambiance, coupled with an "upper crust" food selection.

Was it as spectacular as you'd believe from all the reviews?

I'm not a standard yelper, I've been to culinary school, I've working in French restaurants of high caliber. The food is good. Standard high end business lunch fare. I can't say I was blown away, or super amazed.
author: C. H.

description: Excellent in every way!  Had dinner here last week and everything was delicious, fresh and very tasty.  I had the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin and my friend has the 3 course meal of the beet appetizer, duck ( a few ways) and a creme brulee duo.  The duck was amazing.  So flavorful.  The bread that was included ( the one I ate was warm and filled with green olives) almost made it hard to save room for the meal.  We both got cocktails and my friends Manhattan was very well made (brandy soaked cherry inside was epic) and mine was too sour, so I asked for it to be adjusted with a little more simple syrup and then it was great.  The service was excellent.  I dropped my knife and it slide into my sauce heavy plate and instantly they gave me a new one so I didn't have to use a saucy knife.  It's a very nice restaurant with excellent well prepared food.
author: Ginger w.

description:
I just thought I would come and give a review since I have enjoyed this resturant and saw this posted on the internet which I don't think should advise people who haven't been to the resturant to post negative reviews!  Shame on you.  This is not right people.

ACTION ALERT! One Market Restaurant San Francisco
Date: NOW
Location: 1 Market Plz (at Steuart St) San Francisco, CA 94105 Neighborhood: SOMA (415) 777-5577 www.onemarket.com 
URL: Click here for more information.

It's incredible just how low a restaurant can sink in its offensive offerings....
 
One Market Restaurant's "Weekly Beast Feast" May 7 and May 8 is all rabbit meat--"Relish The Rabbit" from that aptly named rabbit mill and meat farm in Nicasio, CA. 

Here are some ways you can help without being there:
 1. Post a review of One Market on Yelp.
 Be advised your review will be deleted if comment just on the rabbit meat issue. You may want to consider making comments about the service, the prices, the flavoring, etc. Avoid coming across as an "animal activist" who is just posting a vindictive review. Your opinion does matter!
 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/one-market-san-francisco#query:one%20market%20restaurant
 
POLITELY contact reviewers on Yelp to see if they would amend their high star reviews of One Market if they were aware of the cruelty involved with serving rabbit meat. DO NOT identify yourself as part of any rabbit rescue efforts or groups as that takes away your impact as a regular consumer.
author: Shannon B.

description:
One Market continues to deliver a rock solid performance. 
Food: I had the business lunch menu. Corn soup and roast chicken. (of course, it was much more elaborately named, as well as delivered) Both were exquisite. 
Service: top notch. Our waiter was attentive, yet not over bearing. Delivery of the main course was coordinated. They didn't miss a single request. 
Ambiance, elegantly decorated and right on the street level of market and embarcadero. Great location and perfect atmosphere for the business lunch/dinner.
author: Mr. G.

description:
So, One Market has a Michelin star and I have friends who are big fans so we decided to try it.  Not packed on a friday night so I was a bit worried.  The bar was a bit slow with our drinks, but that was our only complaint about the service.

The food:  Very good, not 5 star good, but still good enough for a birthday dinner.

Apps:  Blue crab for me, 1 tomato soup, shaved beef tongue salad.  The blue crab was interesting, and quite tasty.  The beef tongue was eh.

Entrees:  Guinea hen, sturgeon, halibut and scallops.  The guinea hen was the best thing that we had.  It really was delicious.  All three seafood dishes were good, perfectly cooked.  If I had to order one of them I'd take the sturgeon, it had a great tomato sauce.

Desserts:  Butterscotch mousse, chocolate mousse, hazelnut tart, blueberry cheesecake.  The chocolate mousse had sea salt, soooo good.  The others were nothing special.

One Market is good, but not great.  I'd probably choose Boulevard, Nopa or Prospect if looking in this price range and cooking style.
author: Shen J.

description: wow!  I love it.  I went twice in one week. The first night I had the New York steak, expertly prepared.  It was one of the best steaks ever.  The second time I wasn't even hungry but went to try an odd item on the menu - rabbit pot pie.  It was great.
author: Steve V.

description: Had dinner here on Saturday night, our last night in SF. I had the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin and basically I assume this is the type of food served in heaven, or at least I hope. It was so juicy and just mouth watering. My boyfriend had the NY steak and was quiet the entire time! Said it was the best steak he ever had. We also shared Brussel spouts, mash, and mushrooms for sides which were all good. Super fancy surrounding which was beautiful. The only downside and why I didn't give this place five stars was that they sat us next to the area where all the waiters picked up their utensils -prob should put that station away from all guest. Just didn't seem right for such a fancy smansy place. Also word to the wise -if you are a waiter and want to sing "the roof, the roof, the roof is on fire, we don't need no water -let the mother fucker burn, burn motherfucker burn" -my suggestion would be to not do that while picking up utensils when guest are sitting right there. (Common sense much?!) Good thing the food was amazing.
author: Diamond G.

description:
A group of colleagues and I are visiting San Francisco on business from New York City, and we made reservations to dine at One Market because we have a mix of omnivores and plant-based eaters in our party, and the restaurant's online menu specifically states that 'other menu items can be prepared vegetarian, vegan or gluten free.'  

I made sure to call the restaurant on the morning of our reservation, in the hopes that the chef could prepare a plant-based menu option worthy of the quality and reputation of the restaurant.  In response, the hostess told me that 'all food allergies can be accommodated.'  I requested that she speak with the chef specifically, so that he/she would have some notice to prepare a special entree, but the hostess declined, continuing to restate that all food allergies could be accommodated, and that I should just wait and speak with the server when we arrived at the restaurant.

When we arrived and I mentioned the request to our server, we were told that there were three 'entree' options which are actually listed as side dishes on the menu:  asparagus, baby carrots, and spinach.  We were told that the the three sides could be combined to make an 'entree,' and that there were no other options.   To add insult to injury, this 'entree' of three vegetables cost nearly $25!

As you can imagine, it was a very disappointing meal.  I think many people would agree that a plate of grilled or sauteed vegetables, and a white bread roll, does not make a creative or inspiring meal.  I am frankly quite surprised that a high-caliber, renowned chef would not be able to create an original, thoughtful meal from local, farm-to-table, sustainably grown plant-based foods.  It really is hard to believe, especially in an age when most restaurant chefs have the expertise and flexibility to create high-quality entrees that satisfy a diversity of customers.

There are many chefs in San Francisco, and nationwide, who could have prepared a fantastic, worthwhile meal using plant-based foods, even in restaurants that prioritize meats and other animal foods.  I urge One Market to improve its ability to accommodate its customers.
author: Michelle M.

description: I was there last night for a small business networking event.  We were given a limited menu to select appetizer, entree and dessert from.  I had the beef heart with sliced apples, scallops and creme brûlée.  The beef heart was sliced deli thin and piled atop equally thin slices of green apples.  When paired with whatever Sauvignon Blanc (SB) was being served to the group, I felt like I experienced a little piece of heaven while the conversation was circulating around me.  The scallops also paired well with the SB  and I couldn't believe how perfectly seared they were.  Fresh, fresh, fresh and so light. When the duo of creme brûlée came out (one of my favorite desserts), I wasn't surprised that I again was delighted.  I do like my creme brûlée a little warmer, but when serving a group with dessert all at the same time, it's hard to get that just right. While the price of my dinner was covered by the event host, I can honestly say that if I had paid for this myself, I would have walked away just as happy.  Wow.  Love this place.
author: Beth K.

description:
We have been in SF for three days and have found its restaurants overpriced with consistently inconsistent service.

One Market should have been the highlight of our visit - this is a highly regarded Bradley Ogden owned restaurant and the food was indeed very gourmet.  How disappointing, therefore, that it took them well over two hours to serve us two courses of food, one of which was a simple charcuterie plate that could not have taken more than 5 - 10 minutes to assemble.  

Before our entrees arrived, we had finished a $70 bottle of Pinot Noir, and eaten enough bread that we could not finish our entrees, which were by no means oversized.

For a $150 meal, this was extremely disappointing - One Market is a should be 5 star restaurant that did not perform to half of its potential.   I doubt we will return here.
author: Jess R.

description:
I took my sister since she has not been to One Market. We brought our new born babies, and I noted in my reservations. The restaurant accommodated us well, and that is what I expected too. Food is always great there and my sister loves it. The Dine about Town lunch menu was not too attractive this time, so we went with regular menu. Service was great as always, and our dishes were split in plates since we wanted to shared all the starter, main & dessert. Awesome lunch and dinning experiences as always!!!
It is a Michelin one star restaurant!!!
author: Christine Allen C.

description: We had our daughters law school grad lunch here and it was amazing. The event planner was professional and very coordinated. The food and service were excellent. Usually with 30+ people in a party and a fixed menu the food sometimes suffers, but one market really delivered. Our guests really enjoyed it. I highly recommend one market for events.
author: Alex N.

description:
Came here for a team dinner and it seemed the food did not agree with my palette or my palette did not agree with the food.  In any case, ordered the split pea soup with avacados and shrimp.  It was ok.  A little to salty. Thought that the soup was missing some depth because the salt just overpowered everything.

Tried the crab cake or lobster cake appetizers (forgot what exactly they were but) ... yum.  Perfectly cooked with a light thin crunch on the outside paired with the perfect sauce.  

Had the scallops and I felt a little nauseous once I finished most of the plate.  Not to say it wasn't good but it tasted heavily of butter and I guess I couldn't handle it. I needed so much water to wash it down.

It's a pricey restaurant.  So needless to say they had great service.  This I give 5 stars.  They also gave our table free fresh oysters each on an individual spoon.  Which had the juciest citrus, shallot topped, ...JUICE. I just cannot think of another more explanatory word.  

Oh yes, the bellini, without it I might have been sicker from the butter. 

Therefore, I have to give it 3 overall.
author: Hanna Y.

description:
I love:

Beef Tongue Salad
Bacon Wrapped Pork
Crunch Cake/Mint Ice Cream Sandwich
author: Sae W.

description:
I've been here twice now, once for DAT and another for a company luncheon.  I didn't particularly enjoy the food during DAT a couple years ago, but it was great at the luncheon.

I tend to like my food slightly on the bland side, and I was pleasantly surprised to see that the salad wasn't doused with dressing or that the steak wasn't heavily salted or over-seasoned, the chocolate dessert was simply amazing, literally melting in my mouth.  The service was impeccable, but you'd expect no less from an upscale restaurant.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner and the overall experience was great!! I can't think of a single complaint.
- Tasty food very attractively plated, food came fairly quickly for a large group. We had starters, entree, sides and dessert and none dissappointed. A couple of my favorites was the trout starter and coconut dessert.
- Our waiter was very nice and gave good recommendations. 
- Nice environment, suited for both trendy and more dressy attire. 

I came here for Dine About Town maybe three or four years ago, and their regular menu this time around really is so much tastier! The only reason for a 4 star instead of 5 is that the food, while very delicious, is not crazy out of this world good. I would definitely go back again sooner than another three years though. Great experience overall!
author: Jessica W.

description: Came here with Four people for my friends birthday. The food was subpar. When my friend asked for a steak knife for his chicken dish, the waiter didn't bat an eye that a steak knife should not be needed. Even with a steak knife it was too tough for him to eat. The tomato soup was the only dish any of the four of us enjoyed. The prosciutto tasted like it had been cut a week in advance and it was dry, chewy, and lost flavor. The tomatoes on the salad weren't close to ripe. The goat was dry, poorly cooked and flavorless. We were constantly trying to flag down our waiters, because the service was terrible. Several items we ordered never even showed up. Overall, each of our entrées and appetizers could be described as tiny portions, bad ingredients, dry and chewy. Very disappointing.
author: D M.

description: Wow, what a great meal. The scallops with vanilla are outstanding.  The service was great and the the owner, Mark, is a great guy. I'd put it at the top of the list in San Francisco.
author: David J.

description:
This is a review for Dine About Town.

One of the Michelin Star restaurants that I wanted to try. Unfortunately, I don't know how it received a star. 

I had high expectations I suppose.... 

Service was great. Our waiter was very attentive and polite. Explained the menu, the normal DAT menu and the Deluxe DAT. The price difference was about $10. The Deluxe had the shaved beef tongue salad, the duck confit and the chocolate souffle. Even though I wanted the chocolate souffle for dessert, I opted for the normal DAT menu because I wanted the flounder. I had the Caesar salad, Flounder, and the sorbet with the 2-course wine pairing. 
Caesar salad was nothing to rave about. You can't really go wrong with this salad. 
The Flounder was bland and the rice crispy texture did not do it for me. Fish was slightly overcooked and was not flaky. It was borderline 'rubbery'. I thought I was eating calamari. 
The mango and pineapple sorbet was probably the best part of the meal. It was light and refreshing. 

I tried my friend's chicken and it was dry! Not flavorful at all! The chocolate souffle was boring. Reminded me of something from the supermarket. Isn't a chocolate souffle suppose to have warm chocolate running out from the center? This one didn't. 

My friends weren't too crazy over the duck. They just said it was OK. 

The wine pairing with my meal was fine but I wished they would tell me the name of the wines I'm pairing them with. 

Overall, I found the meal just OK. Not sure if this is how the food is normally. It is DAT time and maybe the quality of food goes down? I expected more from a Michelin star restaurant. 

Would I come back? I might give it another try.
author: Molly T.

description: an interesting place...not quite interested in the food, but the venue is great.  I came with a large party and the food was average but good service, great ambiance, and perfect location will bring me back.
author: Christina K.

description:
Came here for Saturday happy hour and for a lunch meeting with professional colleagues. You should call ahead and make a reservation if you don't plan on eating at the bar. I found (and heard) it was particularly busy during lunch hours. The staff wait on you very well. Very professional and private atmosphere. Their happy hour on Saturday is a great spot to go to after visiting the Embarcadero or Wharf, or before heading to dinner in the area. For lunch I ordered a delicious soup of the day (butternut squash I want to say) that was particularly good thanks to the cheese they chose to sprinkle onto it. I also ordered the rice-covered flounder that was lightly fried, perfectly cooked, and not too crispy. 

Minus one star for advertising discounted well drinks on their happy hour and only offering vodka or gin tonics.
author: Anthony R.

description:
Don't get the prime rib, it was the worst i've ever had.

Waiter recommended it and asked me how i wanted it cooked. I said medium rare, it was brought to me medium well.
author: Javier D.

description:
It is so hard for me to rate all these San Francisco restaurants because they all have their specialties and also their less appealing aspects.

I came here for lunch, and I'm not sure if dinner prices are more expensive, but if so, I probably wouldn't eat here.  I had the flounder, which was one of the entrees recommended by the waiter---the fish was very high quality, but the flavor was nothing unique.  Bok choy, mushroom---you can get it at any Chinese restaurant and for a lot less.

The crab cakes were good, but were literally three bites.  Again, I know with these types of restaurants, the quantity tends to be small, but three bites was even less than I expected.  

My lunch came out to be about $45-$50, a little on the steep side.  The restaurant does have a Michelin Star, and maybe that's why they can charge more.  I think it is worth trying so you can form your own opinion.
author: Suzi F.

description: One of the greatest meals I've had in a VERY long time. It is a Michelin Star rated restaurant and you can absolutely taste the quality. The ambiance is well suited for a higher end restaurant, and the service was completely on the ball all night long.
author: E G.

description:
Yay for other people's birthdays! - the reason I got to come here.

They have unique dishes that I normally wouldn't eat elsewhere, but I came with 4 others and we all had different dishes, so I got to sample a bit of each. There was a lot of different food, so I'm just going to quickly blurb about each.

The shaved beef tongue is not as unappealing as it may sound. It was quite savory, with a similar taste to roast beef, and soft in texture. It was good, just think of it as food not cow tongue. Or call it lengua so it sounds less like a body part.

The golden beet soup was slightly thick and deliciously sweet. They give you an almost bare dish with the fixings, but then they calm your fears when they start to pour in the soup AFTER they bring it to you. Same with the chick pea soup.

The chick pea soup is served cold, and had the same thick texture to it. It was refreshing with the mint, but personally mint isn't my thing. It's good in its own right though!

I got the SMOKED TASMANIAN OCEAN TROUT with a chicken egg, potato sorti, and some kind of bacon garnishing. IT WAS DELICIOUSSSSSS. And it's pretty substantial for a starter, enough for 5 people to have a decently sized sample. I RECOMMENDDDDD IF YOU CAN'T TELL!

I also got the Bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin as my entree. DELICIOUS. I love the bacon theme running through my meal. The pork was sooo juicy and tender. Couldn't have been better. And the veggies that came with it were nicely done. Thumbs up! But what took the cake was the glaze. Oh the sauce was SOOOOOOO SAVORY. It just took the dish to another level. YUM!

The herb-roasted potatoes were balls with a crisp skin. The herb was more herbal than I was anticipating, versus savory house potatoes you get for breakfast. It was still good though. 

For the birthday boy, they gave him a complimentary butterscotch pudding adorned with "Happy Birthday" written in chocolate and the obligatory candle. 

The chocolate souffle was delish. The fresh strawberry gratin(?) with ice cream reminded me of the sweet strawberries that come on funnel cakes. Just a neutral observation.

Despite those fancy-pants restaurant that serve you bite-sized dishes for $50, I think One Market is worth its value. If I had the money, I'd come back soon. Until then, I will savor the memories.
author: michelle f.

description:
Mmm...yummy 1 star Michelin rated restaurant!! 
Now I'm on a active prowl to try all Michelin rated restaurants...

Make a reservation if you want to get seated promptly. I came here for lunch so not sure how dinner is like, but I can expect it to get pretty busy. Service here is attentive but we found ourselves having to reminder our server for things we had previously asked. We came here for Dine About Town and the choices on there were amazing! Here's what I got to try...

RASPBERRY LEMONADE
I did not get to try this but I have to write about it. When it came to our table, it was an awesome presented drink! It looked like a huge slushee, not just red colored juice which I was imagining but a mix of the yellow lemonade with the deep red raspberry.

CHICK PEA FRIES (not on DAT menu but A MUST GET!)
I've NEVER heard of a place that has chick pea fries! I imagined it to taste like hummus but it wasn't quite just hummus. For some reason, it wasn't oily at all and it was good with the aioli dipping sauce. Somewhat powerful so don't dip too much in it unless you want to just taste the aioli sauce. It's definitely worth the $7.50 they charge you for it. If you're scared of trying these chick pea fries b/c you don't like hummus, don't worry...it tastes SO much better.

LENTIL SOUP
This was a cream based soup so I didn't really taste much of the lentil. I wouldn't go out of my way to order this but since it came with the DAT menu, I thought I'd give it a go. This tasted pretty good with the complimentary bread they start you off with.

MUSHROOM POT PIE
OMG. This was heaven! They bring out the pot pie in a pot and then they disassemble it for you. They take off the flaky crust and put it on the side of your plate, then dump the mushroom cream filling into your big plated bowl. There were a variety of mushrooms in here and there were no button mushrooms -- thank goodness! Button mushrooms are good but I think they're low-class mushrooms. This was paired off well with cubes of root vegetables -- carrots, potatoes, and a few others I can't remember. Yum. 

PEAR TART DESSERT (forgot what i's called)
This was so filling! I loved every bite of it and it was paired off with vanilla bean ice cream so it definitely had that hot-cold dessert kick to it. 

I like One Market and this is definitely a place to take your clients to if you want to wow them a bit. Good work, One Market. 

(Pictures to be loaded)
author: Heidi C.

description:
I came here for a work event and it was set dinner.  

I would say this place is a decent restaurant but not as amazing as everyone else makes it to be.  I ordered the steak medium rare and it came out medium well.  The steak quality was so good that it didnt matter but i would still like my steak done the way i want it.  The chocolate cake i had was off the wall good.  The salad was decent.

The service was great with the waiters on top of it.

Bottom line is that its a pretty good restaurant in the SF area but the food doesnt warrant the awards they have won.  I havnt seen the prices but if its more tha 30 dollars for a steak, its not worth it.  If its less, i would definitly give it a try.
author: Curtis C.

description:
Dinner here was decent:

* Chickpea fries with aioli dip were a hit at our table!
* Oysters were excellent and fresh - we gobbled those up quick!
* Scallops were pretty good -- I've had better.  The flavor was lacking...
* Sorbet dessert was ok -- I like the crispy, almond bake that covered it
* Mt. Tamalpais pinot noir was tasty!

The service was pretty good although the server rambled the specials off pretty quickly -- a bit hard to understand -- but oh well, I already knew what I wanted to order.  Lots of room for big parties.
author: Maile N.

description:
I've eaten here a couple of times for client dinners. The wine selection is pretty good. The food is also very good, albeit somewhat standard American Cuisine. They do throw in some interesting dishes such as the Pork-Basil stuffed Rabbit. I have ordered the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin and the NY Strip. Both were good. I thought my steak was prepared pretty near perfect. There are some other comments on here about the steak not presenting well, and not having a sauce or anything special on it. 

As a steak lover, sauces on steak are frowned upon. This piece was perfectly cooked to my instructions and was delicious. 

Be sure to order sides as its more a la carte on that front. Don't miss out on the tater tots. So yummy. The deserts are also pretty good. I've had the Mint Chocolate Chip ice cream sandwich, and the blueberry cheesecake. Both were tasty.

As these dinners are expensed, I can't comment on the overall value for the quality you get.

Only negative is that while the service is good, I felt that the lags between attendance were too long. This may in part be due to the fact that both times I went they were really busy, and I was with parties of 7-10 people.

Overall, you will have a pretty much guaranteed solid experience here. Great location, good views of Ferry building and the Chef's area, great ambiance, and a busy feel like you are in a popular restaurant.
author: Neal F.

description:
All sorts of foo-foo-ness oozed out from this place.  For a pretty penny you shall have all your demands met.  To oblige and pamper is their motto... BUT it was too much for me and my girlfriend (2 girls who just simply want to have some time to catch up over brunch)... We felt suffocated as our waitress came every 5 minutes to check on us and chimed into our conversation. Wish I had a restraining order... With that being said, however, the food was the highlight of our brunch.  The dungeness crab cake in their petite size were delectable.  The house-made cavatelli is a must have.  It was just divine. If you have any room left (as we did since the portion size was nothing to boost) try the chocolate toffee almond crunch cake.  You won't regret it.

So all in all the food was great, ambience was elegant and posh but with a 3 digit bill for a party of 2 this grandiose restaurant shall be my first and last visit.  There are way too many other restaurants to try and explore.
author: Y L.

description: Just OK. Good ambiance and bar scene. Service was good, but food was just OK. We had the Ahi Tuna (tender, but overcooked slightly and ended up being pretty bland) and Pork loin (very good). Crab salad starter is highly recommended.
author: Heather H.

description:
This is my fourth dining experience with this restaurant.  I absolutely love it.  I went there last weekend with some friends and we all had a great time.

The place is big with tall ceilings so for those who don't like the feeling of being cramped this may be your place.  They have a nice sized bar for waiting and the kitchen is open so you can swing by and watch them cook your dinner.  They have a lot of great private rooms which my company had a party in about a year ago.  It is a great location for a business dinner.  The restaurant is right across the street from the ferry building so it also has a great location. 

So what about the food????  Here is what One Market blessed my stomach with this week.

Dungeness Crab Salad
Red Wine Braised Beef Short Ribs
Cheese Course
Creme Brulee

Every course was amazing!  I really haven't had a bad thing at this restaurant.  I would give it 5 stars but I like to save those ratings for the "OMG...can I marry this meal?" type of situations.
author: Brandon M.

description:
Food and Ambiance: Great!  
Service : Could be better

We had dinner here tonight and to our surprise was better than expected.  The weekly beast set meal is an awesome deal.  Four courses; carpaccio with foie gras shavings, beef cheeks, NY strip steak and brown butter tart with strawberry-vanilla ice cream.   Carpaccio was excellent, beef cheeks were on the heavier side, NY strip steak was well made and the tart was a good dish to finish with.  

Gf had foie gras and duck.  Foie was tasty but she thought duck was a bit dry however I liked it especially the earl grey jus it came with.  Mom had the crab salad and fish.  She liked both so no complaints there.

The restaurant was busy with couples, big groups and older people.  Comfortable booths, good lighting, wasn't too noisy, overall a great dining experience.

The only negative was the waiter.  He seemed friendly when he first came over to introduce himself but after we all ordered water, he barely said anything afterwards; he didn't even ask how we wanted our steaks cooked.  After I signed the check, he came, swooped it away and took a look to see how much I tipped him.  I tipped average but it was because the bus boys did well.  For whatever reason towards the end of the meal his attitude changed and finally asked how everything was on the third course.

Anyway I would definitely come back and enjoy the weekly beast.  It's a great deal and a great place for dinner.
author: Pierre L.

description:
Ahhh...... One Market is one of my favorite places to eat.  The food is always great while the chief and staff treat me well.  I agree this place is pricey, crowded, noise, dressy, etc, etc.  What do you expect most of the people in this restaurant are the yuppified consumers that hones the meat market of packs of wolves.  It's mostly a couples paradise or small gatherings to converse with the masses.

But if your don't care about the who's who and how to swim with the fishes at the bar you can bypass the bar and the main meat market room their is a bar section close to where they prepare the food this is the place to be, it is kinda warm you're about 10ft from the grill but other then that the noise is behind you and the awesome aroma of food is in front of you.  What's cool of this section is that you can dress up super casual which is way cool for me.  I'm not there to socialize but have a great meal while nobody bothers me.
author: Rom S.

description: The bacon wrapped pork and scallops were amazing.  All the food we tried was awesome.  I give it 4 stars and not 5 because the service was good but extremely slow.
author: Mike H.

description:
A hoity-toity business crowd hangs here for lunch.
(could totally do without, but a friend invited me)

I ordered:
Crabcakes- AWESOME! The server told me they use scallops
instead of breadcrumbs to fuse the crab together. Who knew it
could work? $14.50

Crab "Louie" topped with quail egg- again, delicious!!!
Very filling. I was almost too full to eat my entree after all the 
bread I consumed with my starters. $16.50

Grilled Mahi Mahi- Very good but such a small piece of fish!
wow! $22.50 for that? No Bueno. 

Something I found odd was how scratched up their china was.
I know nothing about china but it was pretty hammered looking
for such a classy place. They need to get that replaced asap!

Pricey $$$ bill for lunch but I enjoyed it (or maybe it was my 
company?)....So call it a splurge if you will.
author: S. M.

description:
Dine About Town at One Market was not good.  Value-wise, I would put it at one star, but apples to apples with other restaurants, I would put it two stars.

Chicken was terrible (Herbs tasted burnt), Butternut squash soup was ok, Butter Tart was greasy and stale.  The Deluxe DAT option was better, but then now your paying $45+tx+tip... beef tounge was good, sturgeon was great,  souffle was ok.  Not what you would want from a michellin restaurant.   Very inconsistent.  I don't think I will be back, there are too many better other options in the Bay Area.
author: Joe C.

description: Was here for an event and they have private rooms and a back area. The half roasted chicken was juicy and I recommend it
author: Amy T.

description:
This place is fantastic! I can easily see why they have been given a Michelin star. Their staff and service were friendly and prompt and their menu is a great combination of comfort classics, French standards, and more contemporary California cuisine that pushes the envelope just enough to get you out of your comfort zone with very familiar dishes. Best of all, they've got a great lunch special called the Businessman's Lunch which is a two-course lunch for only $22! 

After making a last minute OpenTable reservation for lunch, we got to One Market just in time to catch their last lunch seating. I ordered a glass of the 08 Testarossa Pinot Noir and soon after a perfectly warm epi baguette was bestowed upon us with room temperature butter (my favorite). I opted for the lamb carpaccio and OH MY GOODNESS. This is the best carpaccio I have ever had...and it was definitely on the list of best lamb dishes I have ever had. The carpaccio was incredibly rich and fresh tasting. I couldn't even tell it was lamb at first because it had such a clean taste. It was served with shaved asparagus, chives, a creme fraiche foam, and a nice, fatty piece of seared lamb belly; crisp and amazing-- a great contrast to the wonderfully melt-in-your-mouth raw lamb. Dad had the little gem salad which looked crisp and tasty-- served with cara cara navel segments and the boyfriend had the Ahi tuna burger which he gave two thumbs up. For my entree I went with the Roasted "True" Cod served atop a generous portion of chickpeas cooked in an onion-saffron broth with radiccio. The cod was roasted perfectly. Tender and moist but with crisp salty skin and just enough seasoning. The chickpeas were al dente but were very tasty. The broth was very well-balanced-- I wished it came with a couple pieces of bread to sop it all up. The picked onion garnish on top wasn't quite my thing as I hate picked things...but it was mild and went well with the cod. 

Overall, I think it's safe to say that I'll be back to try dinner. SUPER IMPRESSED by their very delicious, yet simple food.
author: Frances L.

description: Too little value for too steep a price. Unprofessional, arrogant staff with an uncanny ability to make you cringe. I wasn't planning on writing a review. But Yelp kept sending me emails, (indirectly) reminding me of my bad experience.
author: M A.

description:
Came here for DAT. Upgraded to the deluxe menu.
Crab soup was so salty! And for this salt fiend that's saying something!
Sturgeon fish was ok- nice arrangement of fresh vegetables but the sauce was way too rich and heavy for the fish. It  overwhelmed the palate. A lighter sauce would have complemented the fish better.Best dish by far was the strawberry panna cota. Disappointing overall.
author: Cynthia J.

description: I had dinner at One Market with my coworkers. I had the steak,it was very good. Expensive, but good food.
author: Wansu L.

description:
This is what Mother Goose really said...

One Market, One Market, to be a fat pig,
Home again, home again, dancing a jig;
One Market, One Market, to eat like a hog;
Home again, home again, jiggety-jog;
One Market, One Market, to end with a mini-platter,
Home again, home again, crap I got fatter.

What can I say about One Market? I've been a special-occasion diner and happy-hour tippler here since it opened in the mid-nineties. Its unbeatable location at the foot of Market in front of the refurbished Ferry Building assures its longevity as a culinary destination, and it also happens to offer a fine menu that never seems to disappoint me no matter what latest food fad I may be following.

After a long break, I took my good friend Maggie last week to thank her for a couple of free concert tickets she was giving me. Well, it wasn't a concert...it was Kathy Griffin at the Masonic, and she was a hoot. But that's another Yelp. Anyway, I had a splendid Cocoa-Rubbed Liberty Farms Duck Breast ($27.50) prepared "sous-vide" (which is French for "really slow cooking"...hey, I didn't know that either until I read it on the Food Network site, OK?). It was moist and tender, perfect really, and it came atop a sweet-potato puree in an orange reduction sauce.

Maggie had the $27.50 Pan-Seared Day-boat Scallops that came with leeks and shiitake mushrooms in a brown butter vinaigrette. Simple but elegant. We shared two fine side dishes at $6.95 each - Brussels sprouts speckled with Applewood-smoked bacon and a Swiss chard gratin. But I have to say we saved the best for last - a $13.50 Mini-Platter of "Singular Sensations" - three specialty desserts beautifully presented on a single plate - the Chocolate Toffee Almond Crunch Cake, Bradley's Butterscotch Pudding with Chantilly Cream and the Chocolate Almond Parfait with Coconut. Ridiculously good.

The food was superb, the service a bit less so as we found the hostess oddly snooty and the busboy a bit too anxious. The waiter was nice enough but not as informed as we would have preferred about the menu, especially after Maggie asked a less-than-challenging question about a Hawaiian fish. It was also, as usual, extremely crowded. Our table was unfortunately in a high-traffic zone where Nob Hill matrons in their PETA-averse furs would whip around the corner and swing their minks carelessly in my face.

But I think I'll try for the Chef's Table the next time I have a special event since I do think Bradley Ogden has consistently maintained such a high standard over the years. One Market, One Market, to be a fat but sated pig.

FOOD - 5 stars...still among the city's leaders of upscale American bistro cuisine
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...nice decor but so damn crowded that the fur does fly
SERVICE - 4 stars...I think they need a refresher
TOTAL - 5 stars...it's the food that matters here
author: Ed U.

description:
I chose to come here to celebrate my divorce and I am glad that I did. A classy restaurant with classy service.  I cannot remember what I ordered from a couple weeks ago, but I do remember that I had asked the waitress what plates had the larger portions, that's how I roll ;)  Their portions are considerably small.  

In any event, thanks 1 Market for showing a me an enjoyable time.
author: Patrick W.

description: Probably one of the worst bangs for your buck in SF.  Food is bland, some items taste microwaved, deserts tasted Safeway bought.  Mostly a place for corporate dinner meetings, like the one I was at.
author: Ryan S.

description:
I had to update my review for One Market after last night's meal. We went back there before a show at Punch Line. 
I had the same issue that I had last time. The hostess was RUDE as soon as I walked in the door. She definitely needs a job where she does not interact with people. She was rude to a caller, another diner and some of the help that was setting up the tables. We made sure to let the waiter what happened. 
So to the food... AMAZING. Our waiter was very attentive and had a great demeanor. 
We will go back there (with the hope that the hostess has the night off!). Definitely ask for a table by the window!
author: Dawn R.

description:
Disclaimer:  My dinner at One Market was at the Chef's Table.  Your mileage may vary.

What an experience this was!

For our friend Cindy's birthday, her boyfriend Nick arranged a surprise dinner @ One Market.  Not just any dinner, but a Chef's Table at One Market.  This having been my first "Chef's Table" experience, I had no idea what to expect - - I just knew it was going to be pricey.

Well, we gathered at the bar in the beginning, and by the time I got there, all of them were working on their first drink already.  I like this bar area at One Market, it was spacious, packed, and the drinks looked good.  Before I could get one, though, the hostess greeted us and we were led back.... all the way back.... through the first kitchen and then even further in - - until we got to the back kitchen.  Holy cow, we are sitting IN the kitchen.  

Everything was already set up to start serving us drinks and dinner.  
A manager came by to greet us, then the sommelier came by to help us pick our first wine, then someone else came by, then our wonderful server - and so forth.  Everyone just kept on coming by to say hello or check on us, it was wonderful.

I've uploaded some of the photos from that evening to this page - - you'll see a special menu prepared just for Cindy - 6 courses plus a dessert tasting menu, and there was also an amuse bouche for the evening, which was a fabulous oyster w/ caviar adorning it.  

I could write for pages on end about the food, but I will refrain.  Look at the photos and see for yourself - - every dish was prepared beautifully, and Chef Mark himself, or another person would come by to describe the plating, the ingredients, and answer any questions you might have about the food or how it was cooked.  Most of us liked the sea trout the most, which was amazing, but seriously - - all of the dishes were excellent.

The service was topnotch as well - which was great because we did have a lot of interaction with the staff here - and not only our server.  Our sommelier, Melanie, was at our table a lot since we drank 6 bottles of wine on this evening between the 6 of us, and once the restaurant tour began after the fifth course, we were guided by Francisco, who was outstanding.  Then, we were led into the cellar at One Market, and given a bottle of wine to share amongst all of us, and that was such a fun experience.  I'd like to live in that room for a month.  On our way back to our table for the last course, we got to joke around with Chef Mark, and the man is as great as his food.  He's just COOL.  

Just when you thought that this was an amazing experience, they hand you two chef's jackets - - and Cindy picked two of us to go back to the pastry kitchen to meet the pastry chef, and help prepare our own desserts.  I got lucky and got sent back - - photos of that are uploaded too.  

We had so much fun helping out w/ the desserts - -  the chef back there and the staff was just fabulous - - and we got a real kick out of eating fried dough which they just had us taste, as it wasn't even part of the menu.  For those of you who have not had plain fried dough - you're missing out.  I'd do the Chef's Table again simply to do that part again, it was so much fun.  (I think this was about the time that everyone started commenting that I was having way more fun than the birthday girl was on this evening!)  Henry, Marc and I were loud and rambunctious back there, but they didn't hesitate for an instant before handing me the blowtorch.  Wow.  Not just that, they were so welcoming and tolerant of our antics  - - thank you, you guys.

The evening was truly spectacular.  It broke down to perhaps a bit over $200 per person - - but the experience was worth so much more than that, in my opinion.  It was terrific food, great wines, amazing staff, and just an all around fun time for all.  

If ever you are looking to host a Chef's Table somewhere, I recommend One Market wholeheartedly.  What a fun time!

And this, folks, was SUPPOSED to be my 400th review, except I forgot I was at #399 and ended up reviewing something else that was totally not worthy of being #400.  Oh well!  402 is a GREAT number!
author: Grace K.

description:
Solid.  This place never disappoints with a solid showing on food and exceptional service.  We like the fact that while it is a Michelin star restaurant...it doesn't have the fussy pretense of many other restaurants of this genre.  

I've been pleased with the bacon wrapped pork, the scallops and I LOVE the beet salad.  They have a decent wine list and the prices are totally reasonable for a place of this caliber.  

To be clear, it is not quite Boulevard caliber (which is my favorite place in this genre) ...but we still really like this place as a solid farm to table theme.
author: David A.

description: Fail.  I've forgiven you for your always disappointing house-made ketchup.  But today you committed a cardinal sin that simply can't slide -- forcing me and my table to a 2 1/2 hour lunch IN THE MIDDLE OF THE WORK DAY.  Do you not understand that we need to get back to work?  Why does it take 45 minutes for a salad to be served?  And then have our main courses come, but the sides arrive well after we've all finished eating our main courses.  This was supposed to be a fun lunch with friends, but you managed to make it a painful experience.  By the end, all we could think about was WTF, why are we still here?!?!?!  I will never eat here again on my own time -- you have been relegated to generic, work-related events only, which I have no control over booking.
author: Emily W.

description:
Since I had MLK Jr Day off I made a day out of it in SF.  My friend & I decided on One Market for DAT 2008 and we're there.  She had made reservations using Opentable, she said the earliest they had was 12:15pm but we got there at 11:30am and the hostess said we could dine early..cool.

We didn't get a window table but we weren't too far away from one.  She took the comfy looking seat, I took the chair with my back toward the window.

Friend had to get a Diet Coke even though we already got tap water.  Diet Coke is $2.50!

So I got the Berry Lemonade after the push from the waiter..I hate paying for drinks so it pissed me off that it was $3.95! It was fine, but water is fine too.

Free warm Epi bread & cold butter given after we ordered.  All good.

Our DAT meal:

Starters: We both got the Portobello mushroom soup - just ok, soy flan was kinda weird for me, quail egg is runny-not my favorite.  Good presentation.

She picked for her entree: Grilled Idaho farmed Trout w/ warm herb vinaigrette.  She liked it fine, didn't like the sauce.
Comes w/ chard & mashed potatoes on the side - separate dish for that.

I got: Angus Tri Tip "Sous Vide" w/ green peppercorn sauce: 5 slices of tri tip, very tender, sauce just ok, didn't eat peppercorns.  Also comes w/ a side of chard & mashed potatoes.  Good.

Desserts:

She got: Bosc Pear Galette w/ Tahitian vanilla bean ice-cream-I got a taste & thought the pear was ok, don't like puff pastry so skipped that, vanilla bean ice-cream just average.

I got: Chocolate pot de creme verrine-whipped white chocolate, crunchy steusel, candied hazelnuts.  It looked great though very average.  Chocolate pudding served cold, cookie just ok, only good thing was the candied hazelnuts.

Bathrooms behind the hostess station on the Left.  Separate men/women.  Women has 4 stalls, was clean when I went in.

I don't like the automatic Gratuity of 18%. Yikes.  Our total w/ 2 drinks, 2 DAT, tax & Gratuity was $63.69!  Expensive lunch, but might be worth it for a splurge.

Close to the Ferry Bldg; Embarcadero Bart Station.
author: Ann L.

description:
Good all around! Came here from dinner on a friday night (reservations in advance!) Really enjoyed the full course from appetizer to dessert, which is not always the case at other Michelin star places. The staff were so courteous and seated us as we waited for one more member of my party to arrive.

Parking: got to SF around 4pm- plenty of street parking left for $3.50/hr until 6pm. Valet here is $10, but since I came early, went to Ferry Building.

I ordered a la carte, although others in my party went with the Market Menu + wine pairing.

Appetizers:
- House-cured Mangalitsa. I didn't know wild, hairy boars could be so tasty. This is an in-house cured meat served with arugula and pears. The pears were a little bit greasy which, compounded with pork, makes this dish good for sharing. I was a pig and ate most of it myself...I wanted to barf when I saw bacon the next day (especially since I also ordered the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin)
- Pan-seared Artisan Foie Gras wakame, wood-ear mushrooms, bonito consommé   --- according to my foie gras loving friend who ordered this, it was excellent, but still not as good as the one from the ritz.

** complimentary from chef: a saffron soup taster- delicious! 

Entree: 
- Bacon-wrapped Pork Tenderloin dandelion "persillade," salsify, natural jus --- oh so tender and juicy! it was probably medium rare, which usually scares me since i'm in the healthcare field and hear about parasites in pigs. It came with 3 pork medallions which were plenty for one person. really loved this dish!
- Roasted Liberty Farms Duck Breast  -- didn't stand out to me. a little bland even, not as moist as I had expected for a duck dish. 

Dessert: 
- N.Y. Cheesecake, lemon sugar cookie crumbs, huckleberry sauce -- really liked the tang in this one. really made it stand out from a boring old cheesecake. this dessert was firm but not overly dense. really enjoyed it!
- Chocolate Toffee Almond Crunch Cake-- this one was just a plain chocolate cake (almost a tad dry too)  +  a special toffee layer on top to "dress it up"

I would definitely come back here, take visitors from out of town here again for a well rounded meal with excellent service!
author: Lina C.

description:
Day: Thursday
Party size: 4
Service: good, attentive
Ambiance: Nice
Best dishes: Appetizer - Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout "Mi Cuit" 
Entree - pancetta wrapped Filet Mignon

My duck entree was alright. A bit undercooked even though i requested it medium well and it was a teeny bit gamy.
author: Terry C.

description: Great business lunch location, highly recommend - crab cakes were excellent!
author: Andrew S.

description:
My family and I spent Mother's Day here last year and they did a nice job managing the crowds. There were a lot of families with the same idea because the food is always good and the restaurant is a beautiful place to enjoy.

This week, I went here for lunch with my friend Tracy who moved here from Boston and needs to try some of our local favorite restaurants. We went to One Market because they were offering the Dine about Town menu and we thought it was a great value ... 3 courses for $22.

We each had a salad and Tracy had Trout and I had lamb sausage for our main course. We each got one of the dessert specials and shared them. Everything was good and very good but nothing was outstanding ... except our server who was perfect with us and each table around us. He did a fine job with a full house.

The valet parking for $10 around the corner from the entrance came in handy. You get three hours so I went to the Ferry building after lunch for a little shopping. Overall, it was a nice afternoon in the city.
author: Lee R.

description:
One Market, an average lunch with a high price check at the end! 

I thought it was weird how they have velvet curtains at the door that you need to walk through. You would think with that amazing space/ big windows that they wouldn't  want to cover the front door with heavy curtains....anyways, came to the hostess station and was ignored for a few minutes and then someone came to help me and bring me to a table. 

I was immediately greeted by my server and he brought me a black napkin without me even having to ask! I didn't know but Dine About Town had already started, so my gf and I opted for the DAT lunch. Two courses for $17.99! What a deal! We both started off with the gem lettuce salad (pretty good) and then I had the cod. Standard 4oz piece over chickpeas and a little spinach. It was okay, a little over cooked. 

Overall lunch was alright, its mainly business types for lunch where you can expense your food. I was SHOCKED that for my party of 2 they charged me 18% gratuity automatically on my bill. THAT IS INSANE. That's great for those business people with expense cards but hello I'm paying for my lunch here... I was not  pleased about the automatic gratuity charge and frankly I'd probably never come back for an average meal at such a high price.
author: Julie F.

description:
On a quest to try new places, my friend Trudy and I decided to try One Market.  Since it is a 2010 Michelin star recipient, it seemed like a solid choice for us.

Our dining experience got off to a bad start. It took a while to get seated,even though we were on time.  mostly due to the fact that the hostess mixed us up with another couple with a later reservation. Their reception area is small, so we were really in the way of all the people they seated ahead of us (and who came in after us to boot). It was a very awkward star to dinner. 

Once seated, things improved markedly. We got our drinks promptly and the bread arrived shortly after. We had two options, white and olive. I opted to try the olive bread. Served warm, it was terrific plain and amazing with a dab of butter  That was quickLy followed by a lovely amuse-bouche made with tuna and tangerines. For dinner, I chose the market menu (3 courses for $39). For a starter, I chose the house-cured mangalitsa (bacon) with  bosc pear, wild arugula, and niçoise olive powder. It was absolutely delicious. I asked about the olive powder. It turns out the olives are frozen with liquid nitrogen and ground up. The little bites were delicate in texture, with a lovely blend of salty, sweet, and peppery flavors. For a main course, I went for the roasted duck breast with duck leg confit, saffron, polenta, and a cocoa reduction. The duck was a perfect medium rare and the confit was served in a novel (to me) way. It was a brick of duck stuffing goodness. I ended things up with the butterscotch pudding with chantilly cream and a pecan wedding cookie. the pudding was rich and silky, the chantilly cream had a textbook consistency and the cookie was crisp and light. Dinner ended with another gift from the kitchen, a chocolate peanut butter truffle. it was really good, but it had a strong flavor that I didn't enjoy ending my meal on. 

One Market is super convenient to BART and Muni, which was nice. Parking in the Embarcadero can be downright nightmareish. The atmosphere was good and the table service was as well. If I just based my review on food, I think they would have been a solid 4.5. 

Taking service into account, they slid down the scale considerably. Even though everyone was really friendly,I think the hostess should have taken a moment to figure out why we were still standing around 15 minutes after we had checked in. It was a really uncomfortable 15 minutes that got the meal off to a so so start.
author: Nicole M.

description:
I don't remember the food as well as I should because I was here on a job interview (for my current job) and was focused on other things (i.e. getting a job). The caesar salad was good, although served as  long stalk/leaves of lettuce that fancy places like to serve and I just find annoying because they're difficult to eat. I don't like to have to cut lettuce leaves in order to eat them and I don't care if you call me unrefined and uncouth. My salmon was good but mediocre. 

You can eat in the indoor courtyard here but I don't know why you would want to. It's really loud because it's in the interior of the One Market complex right next to the food court.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
I've been to One Market Restaurant for both lunch and dinner and the food and service has always been consistent.  Although I love everything I've had there so far... my favorite is still the brussell sprouts and bacon side dish that you can order with your meal. 

We recently hosted our company holiday party in the atrium and it was an absolute pleasure working with Beth Brown because she did an excellent job with helping us coordinate our party from beginning to end.... from picking out the decorations to the linens to the layout.  Everything was perfect and almost seemed effortless because Beth is such a pro at what she does.  

Overall, everyone had a great time at the venue and the food was very tasty and of high quality.  Service was impeccable and the pace at which the courses were brought out were timed perfectly.  No one felt rushed to eat and overall, it was a pleasant experience for our annual corporate celebration.  I would highly recommend One Market Restaurant and Beth Brown if you're looking for a budget friendly venue to host your next large group event.
author: Vindy C.

description:
With schmancy appetizers like Artisan Foie Gras Terrine, Beet Carpacio, and Hand-picked Dungeness Crab, One Market is quickly making its way on my list of "Most Expensive Dinners, Ever". I went with a large party, got plenty cocktails, appetizers, food, and dessert. And though I feel rather dinky rating an already Michelin-rated restaurant, there are a few things that need to be said:

-The food is generally great, dishes were tasty, fitting the "fine-dining" experience of delectable but small portions in elegant plating. The crab was fresh, the foie gras complex and rich, the meat grilled and marinated deliciously.
-BUT. Some of our drinks took forever and a half to arrive. It really doesn't take 30 minutes to mix a cocktail...
-ALSO. Birthday girl received a dozen cupcakes as a gift. We opened the box and devoured them. One Market charged us a fee of $2.50 per cupcake eaten. As one guy in the party said, "Hey, I brought breathmints. How much will that cost to eat in here?"
-They mostly humored our fabulously rowdy group, even throwing in some chocolate covered nuts at the end.

All in all, a good experience; much damage done to the wallet, fits the fine-dining experience, but the downer was the whole cupcake charge and the cocktails-that-took-forever. I get that this is a swanky restaurant and they don't want you to eat your birthday cupcakes inside, but it just didn't feel so friendly. Plus, its not like we didn't order tons of food and drinks.
author: Angela C.

description:
One Market, I love you.

This is the first Michelin star restaurant I utterly loved in SF, and don't regret at all coming to after deciding to wait after Dine About Town as I wasn't feeling well enough in time for our first reservation. The ambiance is relaxed without losing a whit of elegance. There's a definite feel of rapport between the staff and Maria, our sommelier and hostess, was warm and attentive. What impressed me first off was that we were late for our reservation, and I called my parents up to order for us as the kitchen closed at 9. We were told they would wait for us as the food would get cold. :)

I came here to have our first dinner with my parents. I wanted to impress them with some SF-style New American cooking, which they haven't had much of despite my family's long history with the Bay Area. To my pleasure, One Market more than exceeded my hopes. The food was just absolutely delicious and everything felt just right. (The only thing was that the waiter was a little hasty in refilling our glasses and splashed a little, but nothing else was amiss about the food or service.)

I had the Shaved Beef Tongue with Napa cabbage for starters, which was unusual and tasty, though not really what I expected it to be (from my native cuisine I associate beef tongue with very tender meat, and I suppose I'm biased that way). Then my order of duck breast with farro, nettles and the homemade foie gras sausage arrived and I forgot everything else. One mouthful, and I knew I had to have it again someday. The duck breast was superb - a good cut of meat, roasted to melt-in-your-mouth perfection, resting on a bed of farro. The farro itself complemented the duck breast very well with its al dente texture, and the Earl Grey jus was excellent and tied everything together. I ate and lingered over every last bite; I think the last time I enjoyed a meal this much was on Christmas Eve, but that's another story for another time.

For dessert we chose the tiny dessert platter, and our selection was comprised of the creme brulee duo of espresso and vanilla bean, Valrhona chocolate pudding (topped with almond streusel and whipped cream) and the chocolate toffee almond crunch cake. Everything was as rich and sinful as it sounds, and I particularly enjoyed what I had of the espresso creme brulee (to my surprise) and the tiny dollop of vanilla bean ice cream accompanying the slice of cake. I'm only grateful that the servings weren't bigger, else some of us might have had more than what was good for us. I'm not a dessert person (and somewhat of a purist who likes the taste of the best part of the meal - in this case, the duck - to remain in my memory) so there would be no harm in skipping it if you feel so inclined, but I have to say, if heavy desserts are your thing, then definitely have them.

The meal ended on a warm note and we left in high spirits. My thanks goes to One Market for a wonderful evening.
author: Kit A.

description: I have read that this restaurant is michlin rated. It is very good and they do everything well from the service to desert.  Great cocktails and everybodies seafood dish was good
author: ben n.

description:
I have been here twice. I can't recall what I ate the first time here,  so let's talk the last time. First, the location of this place. Any business would trive here- I could picture a big sports bar doign well here. A crummy restaurant would do well here. But this place ain't crummy. 

All their ingredients taste ridiculously fresh and more importantly, healthy. The carrot soup isn't over the top salty, and everything is pretty damn seasoned well. They also have a great beer selection. Would love to come back here and try the burger. Looked really good. If you skipped lunch and are really, really hungry, I wouldn't recommend coming here.  It seems like this restaurant keeps getting better and better....
author: Jim B.

description:
Talk about super crisp white collar. Located in the prime location of Financial District and directly across from the Ferry Building, this is where your SF top executives and corporate raiders congregate. Definitely a more mature and high-profile crowd. Thanks to DAT, a kid like me was let into this elite dining club. 

My three course meal began with a mushroom soup. It was a creamy mushroom soup with a quail egg in the middle. The soup was rich and filled with aromas of assorted mushrooms. To this day, I still reminisce about it, that's how damn good it was. I don't think this item is on the menu all the time so you'll have to ask for it. For main course I had the Roasted Liberty Farms Duck Breast with duck leg confit, saffron, Anson Mills polenta, cocoa reduction. It was so amazing that I put it up on my Yelp profile picture to honor it (see Exhibit A: Yelp profile picture). Everything was right about it - from the flavor to its tenderness with slight pink in the middle. For dessert I ordered the duo cream brulee with vanilla bean & espresso flavors. 

This is one of the top restaurants in SF, up there with Spruce, Bix, etc. It is catered towards an older and more affluent crowd. But that changes when it's DAT weeks in SF, so take advantage of DAT to try this place!
author: Melody L.

description: I am still scarred from a bad experience I had two years ago in which our veggies were served in a froth akin to what oozes out during a epileptic seizure. The fish was undercooked and the wine glasses had the strangest smell whenever I swirled. Unfortunately it was a really bad food day at One Market back then and I haven't been back for any business lunches. Whenever someone recommends it I wince in pain and tell them in explicit detail what I just told you. I still gave it 3 stars for the atmosphere.
author: John B.

description: My martini lacked any spark (or cold enough gin) but they did have Deaths Door gin from Wisconsin, a bonus for a SF restaurant. But the craft cocktail was excellent and the dinner superb.
author: Howard B.

description:
If I could write this review without having to give the restaurant a star, It would be more appropriate for the restaurant. I believe that you should be extremely stuffed before considering to enter this restaurant as the meal requires a magnifying glass to locate. Slicing up 2 pieces of minuscule shrimp and drowning it in an ocean of salsa is hardly creative or delicious for that matter. Vegetable juice does not taste delicious with raw fish and the lamb tongue presented to us tasted like regular salami, not to mention that the presentation leads one to hold their head in perplexity and wonder whether they forgot to add the main piece to the dish. 

0 on presentation and taste and quantity. I hardly find overfilled plates appetising, however, I do expect SOME food to be on the plate. 

The best thing I can say, nice atmosphere, but bring your own food! And well done to the piano man. The server was nice.
author: Aisha A.

description:
I think my expectations were a little too high for this place. We took my parents out for dinner here and it was good, but not great. I had the daily roast which was the ham and my wife had the bacon wrapped pork (the tastiest dish we ordered). My parents got the duck and sturgeon. 

I guess I was expecting a little more from a Michelin starred restaurant
author: Steve K.

description:
Weekly Beast - Rabbit, Market Select tasting menu ( geoduck "chowder", duck breast, souffle cake) So yummy!

The BF and I came here for a romantic dinner one evening. he surprised me with the restaurant as it was lovely and romantic. 

Our waitress was excellent and gave us her thoughts on the menu and didn't push us towards a dish. She let us choose and boy, did we choose some delicious food. 

The BF did the Weekly Beast (which was featuring Rabbit) and I did the Market Select tasting menu (which had geoduck "chowder", duck breast, souffle cake). We also chose the accompanying wine tasting to go along with our meal. 

Everything was delicious. We tasted each other's plate and was just totally satisfied with our meal. I definitely want to come back and try another Weekly Beast.
author: Julia W.

description:
Went here as part of Dine About Town with my team at work. The Dine About Town menu usually isn't a very fair way to judge a restaurant so I'd be interested to go back and see how the rest of the menu seems.

I had a salad for my starter which included blood orange and fennel. It had a good flavor (and was served on an awesome plate!)  but was nothing spectacular.

For a main I had "garden greens" ravioli (stuffed with kale, collard greens, chard, etc.) in browned butter walnut sauce. This was also good. The pasta was delicate and stuffing ravioli with greens is something I've never seen before.

Service was a little slow, but no other complaints.

One Market deserves 3.5 stars in my opinion but nothing particularly "wow'ed" me, so 3 stars it is.
author: Sydney L.

description:
I've been to One Market three times. Twice for dinner (one planned for a group event), and a lunch. All three times the food was marvelous.

The dishes I've gotten in the past include a vegetarian pot pie for lunch and ravioli for dinner. The pot pie was fantastic - it was my first pot pie. And during dinner, the ravioli was alright (nothing too different than any other restaurant). However, their dessert and wine pairings were fantastic. I really did enjoy my meal and will go back again sometime soon.

The service was fairly quick and the waiters and waitresses were extremely knowledgeable. Overall it was a great experience - I give it four stars because I think it would be fantastic if they could add another vegetarian entree (for dinner) to their menu.
author: Vrinda S.

description: Chick pea fries are heavenly! Come early for happy hour. Gets packed very quickly.
author: Connoisseur D.

description: Came here for our anniversary. The place has a very romantic atmosphere; candle lit tables, piano player, the works. Food was delicious and the service was excellent. They even gave us free dessert for our anniversary. Yes, it is pricey but definitely worth it!
author: Suzanne L.

description:
Good place for a business lunch or company function.  Spacious with ample tables and booths. Booths are pretty plush...didn't quite have the b-day ambiance for our group, though they did make an effort on the dessert sampler by writing a birthday wish on the platters.

I'd go back for their veggie sampler which you can choose any four Farmers' Market side dishes (see photo).
author: Cathy K.

description:
My partner and I celebrated our anniversary here this past week and we had a great experience.  I had never been in the main dining room for dinner before, so had no idea what to expect.  I knew they had a Michelin star, but that's it.  We had a great meal.

Key to our experience was getting a great waiter.  He was knowledgeable, friendly, fun and willing to give his opinion.  He paired our wines perfectly.  My partner had the pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon and it was outstanding.  Delicious!  I had the NY strip steak and it was very good.  We started out with the tater tots, and I highly recommend them as a potato dish.  They were very tasty, especially with the house made ketchup.  Our waiter was attentive but certainly not annoyingly so.

The space is very nice, although it does feel like there are a lot of business deals happening or people dining on expenses accounts, but it wasn't that bad.

Overall, a great experience with great food and wine.
author: Scott L.

description:
Great service and lively atmosphere
Great scallops, great ny strip
Great foie Gras

Lives up to the hype without being overly stuffy
author: Sara B.

description:
I'm not a big foodie, I care more for the ambiance, service and overall feel of a place.  But I love this place for the delicious food.
  
I came here for a work lunch, I pretty much had the best lemonade ever, its like a lemonade slushie.
  
Other amazing lunch orders -
Appetizer - Dungeness Crab Cake, a little smaller than I had expected.  Not worth the money.

Entree - Potato Gnocchi, WINNER!  I was reading a book the night before my lunch here, and someone in the book made their on Gnocchis, I was really craving Gnocchis after I read that, this completely satisfied my craving.  I think their Gnocchi was a lot better than the ones you get at Little Italy.

Sides -
Chick Pea Fries - This is like fried hummus.  Sounds weird, but tastes good.
Potato Tots - Need I say anything more
Sautéed Spinach - whatevs, healthy I guess

A great work lunch spot!
author: Anoo L.

description: Excellent quality and fresh delicious menu items. Friendly staff, efficient and attentive. I highly recommend.
author: Maria R.

description:
Awesome place for a business lunch. One Market is huge and they had no problems accommodating a party of 10 when we made our reservation the day before.

Service is excellent.

Appetizers:
We ordered oysters (very fresh & yummy) and crab cakes (very tiny and good but not TDF).

For my main dish I ordered the flank steak rare.  Their version of rare is between a rare/medium rare.  I loved it.  Thought the sauce was a good compliment to the steak and i really like the peppercorn.  Good portion for lunch.

I must rave about the roasted brussels sprouts w/ apple-wood smoked bacon.  It was delicious!!!! The brussels sprouts had a nice crunch to it and wasn't over cooked.  Flavor is really good and combined with the bacon? very very yummy.

For dessert I had the mint chocolate chip ice cream sandwich.  Loved the super minty ice cream.  Didn't really care for the cookie.

Price: most entrees were under $20.  Reasonable FIDI pricing.

I would definitely recommend this place if you are up for fine dining with coworkers but don't really want to spend a whole lot.
author: Terry D.

description: I like coming here for lunch. The waiters are friendly, the food is good, they have a good lunch tasting menu. I have enjoyed every visit. Each time I have tried something new and it has been enjoyable. The tater tots are usually recommended by the staff, but I think they are too large for my preference.
author: Azizi A.

description:
I ate here the week before trying Frances for the first time. Good grief. If you are looking for Michelin Star food, save yourself some money and go get a vastly superior meal in the Castro. I'll try not to draw too many comparisons between the two restaurants (I could go on and on about Frances' applewood smoked bacon beignets with maple chive crème fraîche or the five-dot bavette steak with sauteed wild ramps, fingerling potatos and crème fraîche); just know that Frances is considerably better. 

One Market is okay, definitely not worth a $160 price tag for two people. I started with the beet carpaccio which was pretty good (especially considering that I don't particularly care for beets). The chèvre topping was actually really tasty. For my second course, I had the roast duck with andouille sausage. The duck was probably the best I've had. The portions were small too, which I liked. The andouille sausage, however, was awful. Unpalatable.  It had the consistency and taste of a heavily processed meat (think Spam), albeit spicier. The sausage may have been rendered particularly unappealing by virtue of the fact that the duck was so delicious, but that really isn't an acceptable excuse. Also, the sausage looked deceptively similar to the duck. Biting into it was a huge disappointment.


My girlfriend had the bacon wrapped pork loin. The pork was really good (tender, juicy, surrounded by crisp bacon), the potatoes, on the other hand, were considerably undercooked. Were I more of a diva, I would have sent the dish back.

I had whatever unimaginative little chocolate soufflé cake thing they had for desert; not particularly memorable. The cheesecake, was pretty good, but again, nothing ground breaking -- a small rectangle of cheesecake filling rolled in crumbled cinnamon graham cracker crust (I know, right? The crust was like... on the outside, man. Mind = blown).

Bottom line, some of the meal was good, most was just okay. 

Seriously, just go to Frances.
author: Tyson T.

description:
Top level cuisine- a gastronomic adventure!

I think the context of your dining experience shapes your outlook-- business dinners vs. romantic dinners vs. restaurant week sampling etc.  I'm learning more and more that if you want to truly have an extraordinary dining experience, you have to go to a place that uses only the finest, freshest ingredients and has a chef that is committed to quality of food, not just creating a chic restaurant.

One Market definitely satisfies all of this.  My husband and I were in town for a weekend getaway and were determined to sample some of the best cuisine that San Francisco has to offer.  We arrived after 9pm (the last seating) but the maitre'd restaurant kindly seated us.

I started with the field greens salad, followed by the scallops on creamed corn (normally it's on a farina cake, but I avoid gluten products).  My husband started with the trout-poached egg appetizer-- one of their specialties and followed with the seared ahi.  We finished with the bing cherries, butter cake and ice cream (all house made!). 

Everything was absolutely wonderfully well-balanced and complemented each other.  In each dish, it had a perfect combination of sweet/salty/bitter/tart and textures of creamy and crunchy.  The sauces were just right- not too heavy, but enough to give a hint of the fresh herbs and spices.

With appetizers, main courses, side dishes, wine, dessert, and coffee, it came to around $150 for two people--- well worth the adventure!
author: Christine S.
