description: Probably one of my favourite business lunch places. Very decent ambiance and service is great as well.
author: Shell J.

description:
Yum! Came here for a business lunch (I love it when I get to eat fancy food on the company's dime) and it was great. The pace was appropriate for lunch, the server was knowledgeable, and the food was delicious.

First course: shrimp bisque. Whole pieces of bay shrimp in a creamy tomato cream bisque. 

Main course: grilled Mahi-Mahi. Cooked perfectly. Flaky, tasty, awesomeness 

Will definately have to come back for dinner!
author: Tiffany K.

description: This review is for happy hour. Great location. The chickpea Harissa fries are so good. Had a nonalcoholic beverage as I was working which was excellent. Of course awesome location.
author: Tina L.

description:
I typically come to One Market for cocktails but the boss needed me to schedule a work lunch with a new partner. We were at the Hyatt at our user conference so One Market was perfect.. 

I had the BEST lunch yesterday! the pumpkin soup was sooo good! I can't stop thinking about it.. 

My main dish was a suggestion by the waiter. The shrimp louie salad 0- sounds unexciting, right.. Not this one.. the presentation was excellent.. Three barrels of  lettuce wrapped with 2 shrimp perched on top.. I cut into it and the flavors were amazing. 

I'm coming back next week!
author: Monica S.

description:
I recently had a noon-time luncheon with another friend at One Market Restaurant. I have had dinner their some time ago and recalled it was a positive experience.
This time, I ordered a grilled trout drizzled with a delicious chutney of sorts that included a tinge of raspberry flavor. I also ordered a Caesar's salad. (I don't remember what my friend ordered and that was only 3 weeks ago!) The service was impeccable and the ambience was enjoyable as was the energy level for that time of day: not too hurried or rushed like some places can get. And the best part, I mentioned to our waiter that I had a 65 minute window in which to enjoy lunch and then I had to leave for a meeting nearby. He assured me that would be no problem (and I had this concern due to some previous YELP reviews that said lunch could take an hour-and-a-half or more). The bottom line was that it was a completely pleasant experience that included good food and service. The only bumps were the meager size of the food portions. I am a sensible eater who does not like huge portions of food on any plate ever since I was a child, but friends that know me would be shocked to find me finally admitting that I found a restaurant that actually served ME too little food!  LOL! My trout entre' lying very lonely and stranded in the midst of a huge sea of white bone china. This trout was a stingy filet cut of no more than a scant 1/4 " cut piece thick and about 6 inches long down to the tail. The entire fish was gone in about 7 normal fork bites.  The Caesar's salad actually made me laugh when I looked down at the small saucer (7 " diameter). It was really just 6 tender young romaine leaves about 4-5 inches long, laid parallel in a 2 " high stack. There appeared to be only a whisper of dressing on them, along with 3 croutons and two 1" x 1" shaved thin slices (using a micrometer). I think it was a sharp, dry cheese - but my taste buds were short-changed without enough mass to determine flavor. 
But, this is the way restaurants are serving food during this current economic depression our news media and government keep downplaying on TV. 
for the $120 this lunch cost us (no dessert or wine, but including an $18 dollar tip), it would have been perfect if the trout and salad was another 30% larger in volume.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
I joined to friends for dinner at One Market to take advantage of the Dine About Town menu.    The plusses - the Maitre D' was gracious and yet very San Francisco - comfortably formal and just enough fun to make me feel at home.  The timing of our courses was excellent.  Also, they were not at all put off that one member of our party was late and the other a no show.  

The food - everything was good but nothing really stood out.  I had the lamb's tongue salad.  While the tongue was well cooked and very tender, there was no much else to the salad.  The sauce and mustard were pleasant additions, but it needed more crunch to offset the soft texture of the tongue.  The salad had almost no greens, basically three small pieces on the plate.   The pork loin was very tasty and tender, beautifully cooked to a medium rare.  The portion was generous.  The grilled radicchio was a nice addition.  The faro was blandly unremarkable.  For desert I had bread pudding.  It was good but nothing special.   We were also served a "PB&J" amuse bouche - all I could taste was salt - and house made caramels which tasted a little burnt.  

The service was both good and bad.  One of our party was a little pushy with the waiter, and he handled it well.  However, there was a sort of an off vibe all evening.  The service was okay, but did not feel high end.  The busboys were weirdly intrusive.  I almost fely like the waiter had made a comment about the pushiness at our table and we were getting a bit of a smirk from the busboy (really, busman). 

Overall I feel like the experience at One Market has slipped considerably.  I would go there for a business lunch or dinner, but I would not go for a special occasion.
author: Donna S.

description:
I HAD to yelp today's lunch experience.

Lunch was expensed today, so we four business professionals decided, why not go somewhere pricey? 

Our server was a bit of a train wreck. She greeted us, handed us menus, walked away about 15 feet, turned around, came back to the table and said hello as if she were not just there 5 seconds ago. 

English was not her first language, yet she insisted on speaking quickly in a staccato/machine gun kind of way. She started suggesting drinks for us to order, reverting to her rehearsed sales pitch, and she would have gone through her entire 3-4 minute routine if I didn't finally just stop her and ask for a diet coke. She took my drink order, then one by one took my co-lunchers' drink orders, then looked back at me and said, "and something for you too drink?" Puzzled, I said, "Still diet coke please."

When she returned later to take our food order, one of my co-lunchers asked if he could hear about a particular sandwich on the menu, to which she replied "No," and then proceeded to tell him about it anyway. She wasn't trying to be funny; I blame the language handicap. But still, the rest of us were trying to hold it together at this point.

I ordered the ahi tuna burger with the "on whole grain bread" option listed on the menu. When it came, the "whole grain bread" was - I kid you not - two pieces of toasted cheap Homepride bread. 

Michelin star my a**!!!
author: Brian T.

description:
I had lunch here recently not knowing it was a Michelin star restaurant. I just walked in on a whim and thought, why not? Then, when my roasted chicken breast with mashed potatoes came, my eyes widened and I was thoroughly impressed. The last bite was just as good as the first and I devoured every bit of the mashed potatoes.

Also: they really do have excellent service. I told the waitress I was in a rush and had to hurry back to the office, and my dish arrived in no time. And they still managed to cook my chicken just right. In short, I ordered, ate, and paid without a single complaint.
author: Jenny T.

description:
I've only been here once, with some out-of-town friends for the "Weekly Beast" menu.  It was $50 (+ $20 for wine pairings) for a five course meal based on rabbit.  We had a rabbit terrine, rabbit ravioli, bacon-wrapped rabbit loin, and for dessert, carrot cake.  It was absolutely delicious, and is up there as one of the best meals I've had.  I appreciated being able to get the ravioli without cheese.  Unfortunately I felt a bit over-stuffed at the end of the meal, and missed my friend's band that night because I thought I might hurl if I tried to dance.  

Very good service as well.  

If I could afford to I'd go here more often, but I think that's my fancy meal budget for the year.  Would love to check out another "Weekly Beast" meal someday, though.  I don't think I would go for just dinner or anything, though--it's just too expensive.
author: Monica K.

description:
The Intro:
  One Market is a 1 starred Michelin restaurant located across the Ferry Building serving contemporary American cuisine. This restaurant belongs to the Lark Creek Restaurant Group and is probably their best restaurant. 

The Food:
  We went there for Mother's Day brunch and it was amazing. We started off with cheese doughnuts with bacon aioli. It was crunchy and fluffy, just the right way to start off a meal. It was followed by beet puree soup and beef tongue salad. Both were inventive, delicious and artfully prepared. The salad had a frozen horseradish dressing that was fun to eat. Then came the entrees, wow... best omelette I've had. Very light and fluffy but seasoned very well. The halibut sous-vide in the onion broth was cooked prefectly and had so much flavor. One of my favorites in the entire meal.

The Decor:
  High Ceiling and very spacious. High window panes make for a very warm and comfortable atmosphere. Looking out I can clearly see the Ferry Building with people walking around. An open grill station invites guests to see the action with the meat.

The Service:
  Our server was pretty attentive considering they had a packed house. There was number of large parties due to it being Mother's Day but we were treated properly.

The Summary:
  Definitley one of my new places to eat in the city. This place is kid friendly so I will definitely eat here alot in the future. Next time I eat here it will be for dinner and I will order the tasting menu. I reccomend this place for people who like to eat great food without the upscale price.
author: Stanley C.

description:
Unless a pregnant sous chef just surprised everyone by giving birth in the kitchen, it shouldn't take 2 hours for a lunch of green salad and mussels.  

Perhaps my friend and I don't appear to have demanding jobs?  Or maybe it's my fault for not remembering to remove my invisibility cloak like a bad little wizard.  

Except for feeling our time wasn't respected, the food was pretty tasty.  The green salad was fresh and the leaves were the perfect size for humans (a pet peeve of mine is oversized greens, better suited for animals of the bovine variety).  The mussels in vadouvan spice (think French curry) had nice flavor, as did the diced fingerling potatoes, which were likely delicious when warm.

Idea FiDi spot for languid business lunches on the corporate card.

Slow Food movement?   Noted.
author: Janney B.

description:
WOW..WOW..WOW! 

What a stunning meal we had at One Market last Wednesday night. We were a large party of 12 and had an extra 2 join & the restaurant was outstanding in accomodating us with grace and charm. 
We had a fabulous table with amazing views of the clock tower and bay bridge.
Now on to the food ..this could be one of the best meals I have ever had in San Francisco!!
We had people from all over the country in our party say the same. The food was beyond outstanding both in presentation , freshness and over the top flavor.
I mean it was unbelievable !! The bacon wrapped pork tenderloin truly amazing , the hand picked Dungeoness crab salad beyond belief, the Vichysoisse crab soup incredible and the Alaskin Halibut moist and melt in your mouth bursting with flavor.
Stunning service- our waiter was flawless and we were a big table!
I will be back again and again to this San Francisco Gem.

Sandra F.
author: Sandra F.

description: Ok service. They spooned the paella out of the metal tray and onto my plate. However, the paella was bland. I expected a better tasting meal.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Great service person = 5 stars (The small framed ady with the French sounding accent with the short choppy style hair (brown/blond tones in her hair).
Food = 3 stars (over priced for what I got)
Noise on platform area = 1 star (they need some acoustical tiling)

We were there around 2ish on during the end of the week.  We initially sat in the double chairs that were butted up next to another diner. We could hear all of their conversation which make it difficult and impossible to talk with their voices overshadowing ours.  We got up and asked the host to re-seat us, so we were placed in a booth side by side.  That was better.  However, they really need to put more acoustical elements in that area, it is really hard to hear a conversation.  The place is an upscale (uniforms and all) place and has a nice vibe minus the noise  issues. 

Delight:  We were served four small warm sourdough epi rolls with soft butter.  That was a treat 

Ordered:
-Grilled Trout warm herb vinaigrette 19.50  (Well prepared, nothing exciting or creative.  Just the trout and nothing else included in that price). Kind of pricy for a thin piece of fish. Boring presentation.   
-Buttery Mashed Potatoes (v)   5.50  (Excellent portion, creamy texture served in a square white bake-ware)
-Hamburger & Potato Tots sweet onions, Pt. Reyes blue cheese, coleslaw, port dijon 14.75
-Potato Tots house-made ketchup (v) 5.50
-Lemonade slushy (This was a great treat and very tasty).

It is a nicely appointed restaurant if you like spending lots of money on lunch.  However, I think there are some nicer and cheaper places nearby where you don't have to spend $18.00 for a piece of thinly sliced  fish.
author: Vanilla C.

description:
I attended a Lymphoma & Leukemia luncheon here last week.  The restaurant was generous enough to sponsor this lunch, and I enjoyed my meal.

It was a two course meal with salad and a chicken entree.  The salad was delicious.  I don't know what it's called, but it had baby lettuce leaves tossed with a light vinaigrette and served with pear slices, blue cheese, and candied walnuts.  The chicken dish was okay.  It had a little dollop of polenta, a little dollop of spinach, and two gigantic pieces of chicken.  The polenta was a bit overcooked and the spinach was bland.  The chicken was yummy.  The meat was very, very tender and the skin was crispy.  I would have liked it served with a bit more carbs.

Our meal was served in a room located right outside the restaurant, and it was freezing!!!  I don't think they were used to the unusual SF heat so they cranked up the air conditioner.  The service itself was good.  The waiters timed the courses well, and we finished within the allotted hour timeframe.

I want to come back here to try out some of their other dishes!
author: Melisa C.

description:
One Market is my perpetual standby sitdown lunch spot.
It is never busy, the prices are very reasonable, the food is always good-to-great. This consistent quality is the primary requirement of earning a single Michellin star. I've had few things here wow me, but I've never left displeased.

My favorites on the menu are: Crab Cakes, Cavatelli, Gnocchi and the Ahi Burger. Their mint iced tea hits the right spot on days when it's actually warm too.

I don't see how anyone can complain about One Market being expensive when you can get an app and entree for $22 through their rotating "Business Lunch" menu. Maybe if you're from (way) out of town that seems like a lot, but even a simple sando in FiDi can run $10. Whenever I've had dinner here the bill was likewise as palatable as my food.

The one issue I could take with One Market is the consistency of service. Most waiters are cordial and quick but a few are dour and slow.
author: Max G.

description:
I came here for Dine About Town 2011 and had a fantastic dinner. My boyfriend and I split the regular dinner DAT menu, so we tried everything except the chicken.

The meal started off well with a tuna amuse bouche, which was delicious. Appetizers were good -- the butternut squash soup was fantastic (I highly recommend it, and I'm not a big soup eater), and the caesar salad was good but it was just a caesar salad.

For the entrees, I had the flounder, which was perfectly crispy on top and juicy everywhere else. My boyfriend had the tortellini, which was too rich/heavy for me, but most tortellini is. The portions were perfect, and both of us finished our dishes feeling full, but not stuffed.

For dessert, I had the pear brown butter tart, which was good but a bit dry. The mango and pineapple sorbet was AMAZING, though! I would definitely get that over the tart.

As for the atmosphere, the crowd seemed much older and it didn't seem like a great place to go with a group. Service was quick but didn't make us feel like we were in a rush.
author: Jackie C.

description:
I went here for lunch with two other coworkers .  After the entrees I was going to give the place three stars. The trout appetizer was good.  The house pork sausage was tasty. However, nothing really stood out other than the mint Arnold Palmer.


The desserts made it four stars - the butterscotch pudding was amazing!  The mint chocolate chip ice cream sandwich had such a fresh taste, it was like the mints were picked straight from the garden then made into ice cream. Everyone should order the dessert platter just to get an sample of all the desserts that the place has to offer.


After the dessert, we found out that it was strawberry week and we can get a free recipe book with our Visa Signature card. As we looked at the recipe by Patti Dellamonica-Bauler, Pastry Chef of One Market, we saw that she was standing in the pastry kitchen.  Since the desserts were the highlight of the meal, my coworkers and I went to the kitchen to pay Patti our compliments.  She was really nice and agreed to take a picture with us.  When I mentioned that I was going to Napa this weekend, she recommended restaurants for me and even went to www.OpenTable.com to check out available time of multiple restaurants for me.  

While Patti was checking out www.OpenTable.com site for me, she introduced us to the head chef Mark Dommen.  Mark was also really nice.  He looked up restaurants for me on his iPhone.  We chatted a little bit about him appearing on Hell's Kitchen when the contestants ate at the chef's table this last season as one of the awards.  The funny thing was, I didn't even make the connection that he was THE Mark Dommen that appeared on Hell's Kitchen until he mentioned it, even though I watched every episode.  I guess you just don't expect the people on TV to be so real and nice .  Anyhow, that made the experience 5 stars.  Thanks Patti and Mark for making the experience memorable!
author: Joyce J.

description:
Very average restaurant with unjustified prices.  Food was nothing special at all.  Waiters were kinda rude and clueless.  Nicest feature of the restaurant is its location.

Don't have much else to say since I doubt I'm ever going back unless I have to due to peer pressure...Gotta learn how to just say no...no means no.
author: Justin L.

description:
The hostess/reservationist was rude! It would have been 4 stars, but I'm taking away a star because she (the reservationist) had a really bad attitude. 

My manager treated me to lunch here for my birthday. We ordered crab cakes for appetizers (while we were waiting for my friend to join). The crab cakes were tasty, definitely not made with imitation crab. For my entree, I ordered Olive Oil Poached Alaskan Black Cod. It was delicious. I was a bit skeptical when it came out since there was this white foam around my plate (looked like soap/dish washing detergent). The fish was very light and didn't have a fishy taste to it (definitely fresh!). I also ordered the chocolate souffle for dessert. YUM-O!
author: Candice H.

description:
Reservations are definitely needed for lunch.  Dress is more than just casual - business casual to almost business formal.  Extremely crowded, difficult to get someone to seat me (I was meeting colleagues already seated).  

I had the tortellini, trying to find something that was quick.  It was pretty much floating in butter.  Tasted OK.  The others had fish (trout and whatever the day's special was) and thought they were good.

Service could be very good, probably at dinner when the pace is much slower.
author: Debbie E.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner that turned out to be quite a production. For the prices, the food was adequate but the service was severely lacking. The appetizers were fine, and out of the 3 main courses at our table I would probably only order 1 of them again. The desserts were pretty tasty, though.

The huge drawback was the (lack of) service. At first, it seemed like there were quite a few people on the floor, but our drink order got lost for about a half hour, despite inquiring with at least 3 different people about it. The waiter was hard to find, with long gaps between his check-ins, especially when we were ready to order our entrees.

About 2 hours after we were initially seated, we finally got around to the dessert course. After ordering my choice, the waiter returned a full 20 minutes later to inform me that my choice was unavailable. Cut to another 10 minutes before the plates arrived, and another 5 or so for the coffee that was ordered about 30 minutes previously.

Overall, a long, drawn out experience with average food and laughable service.
author: Geno B.

description: So i guess this place got a Michelin star, but sadly i was in no condition to give it my full attention, and neither was the wife as she actually had to leave when the first course arrived because she was plastered. I know i did end up eating the Pork Tasting Menu with wine pairing. The first course was crunchy, the second course was soft, and the dessert had peanuts (allergy) in the crust and i had to puke it all out at the end. sad face.
author: Johnny C.

description:
A very typical place to bring anyone work-related to.  It was the end of the quarter so my boss treated us out.

I ordered the Golden Beet & Saffron Soup, Ahi Tuna Burger, and Lemonade.  The soup was great!  It comes with a couple pieces of Ahi Tuna wrapped around apple slices, which complimented the flavor of the soup.  I'm not usually a fan of beets, but either I couldn't taste it or I might have to convert.  The burger was ok.  The tuna was cooked perfectly and I wish I put more of the Saffron Aioli that came with it, but it was still just average for me.  If it was a beef or chicken burger, I probably would never get it again.  Also comes with a side salad.  Lemonade was sweeter than most places I've had and a bit carbonated, but still pretty good.  It's more of a lemonade icee though.

I'd def go to One Market again...but only if someone was treating me or if I had extra money to spare.
author: Jane N.

description: Wonderful restaurant. The food is fresh and interesting and the location is excellent. The service is a little slow but still a great place for a leisurely lunch or dinner.
author: Erika B.

description:
Hi
First I need to tell you that I work in hospitality and have formally reviewed restaurants in the past so although this is not a formal review I believe you'll find my experience useful as someone who has been lucky enough to dine in some of the Bay Areas finest restaurants since 1998.

One Market is an incredible experience. It is not inexpensive but if you either have the expendable cash for a dinner that can approach $100+ or are looking for a place to celebrate a special occassion, this is the place.

The bar is lively even on a Tuesday night at 5 p.m. It's primarily business people but I also saw a young kid with a backpack grinning ear to ear as he hosted his young female friend at the bar. The picture window, the location, it just feels good to be inside the space.

The dining room is large and I definately suggest dining at or near the windows. It's filled with an enthusiastic business crowd. Our server Steven Anderson was very quick on the trigger to confirm, advise although we were pretty decisive and just  be there when needed.

We were both drawn toward the same entree so I can't give a complete review on entrees but the Pan Seared Scallops were to die for. I am guessing there were fewer than 6 of them but the lobster emulsion ( and I don't even like Lobster) stole the show... the bubbling red broth, the creaminess of the mashed potato or sweet potatoes at the base and the crispy artichoke made the dish outstanding.

We order something that just sounded fun-- chick pea fries and I gotta tell you that dipping those fries into the lobster emultion... sent me ... Divine!

As the entrees don't come with anything not stated like the beef, chicken or whatever we also got a side of spinach which was wonderful but not out of the ordinary.

What was however also out of the ordinary was the beet salad where instead of the typical chunks of beets they were sliced thin with radish, goat cheese and a vinagrette really beautifully plated.

This is all food to eat slowly while enjoying conversation as it's not hefty serving of food but a cause of celebration of food. Petite cuisine? You decide.

Great salad, great fries, great entrees.

What was unusual is that without asking the bread server continued to bring over  a crispy white and an olive roll. Again, just impeccible and the servers just seem to be around without the need to hail them or if there was the need, the wait was only momentary.

We opted for the mini trio for dessert and got two gorgeous mini flans-- a coffee and a vanilla, various little cookies, a butterscotch pudding and a chocolate nut torte. Splitting them made it seem as if we'd hardly ordered much but again because the food is very rich and flavorful it seems that less is more here.

We wanted to try a great deal, didn't want liquor or coffees so we ordered more plates of food than one might but not the liquids and our bill still came to about $100 with the tax.

It was so darn memorable that frankly I can't help but recommend these folks highly. Their food is as good as the day it opened 20 years or so ago, maybe better.

Did server Seven Anderson make the difference? I don't know but to be on the safe side you might request to be in his section.

They also have a new wine tasting room that can be rented for parties or larger parties that spread into the lobby of One Market so lots of creative ways to utilize this setting.

I love the nearby Boulevard as well but simply hadn't dined for years at ONE MARKET and it turned out to be a great place to celebrate my birthday-- won't tell you which one!
author: ALLEGRA A.

description: The lettuce cups are the best! Pork belly with a delicious glaze
author: Patrick F.

description:
I chose this restaurant for a special anniversary dinner because it was Michelin-starred. Having only been to one other Michelin starred restaurant (which completely blew me away), I expected a lot.  While One Market was good, solidly good, even wonderful at times, it was not the drop-dead, holy-cow good that I expected.

The service was excellent. We arrived a few minutes early for our reservation so we started with drinks at the bar. I rarely drink so I wouldn't know how to rate a drink, but the bartender and server get points here for listening to me. I told the server that I wanted something weak and fruity. Usually when I tell bartenders that, they still put in tons of alocohol. Here, the server listened to what I wanted, told the bartender, and brought out a drink that tasted like juice - exactly what I wanted.

We weren't even halfway done with our drinks by the time our table was ready. Unbeknownst to me, while I was in the bathroom my boyfriend had told the hostess that it was our anniversary and requested a special table. The hostess happily found us a great little corner table.

Our waitress was great. She took time to explain the tasting menus to us, gave recommendations, and seemed genuinely happy to serve us.

Because we were expecting "if eating this bite of food is the last thing I ever do, I will die happy" food, we thought we better order as much of it as possible. We shared two starters, had our own entrees, and shared two sides and a dessert.

The starters were an heirloom tomato consumme and what I would describe as a trout eggs benedict. The consumme was definitely the highlight of the meal for me. My absolute favorite thing is when I can taste my food - particularly fresh fruits and vegetables - without having to rely on seasonings, fats, or anything else. A carrot that tastes like a carrot, a tomato picked at its peak - there's nothing like it. That's what this soup did, and it was wonderful. The trout was also good, just not my style. I think it'd be perfect for brunch, and I can see why people fawn over it.

For entrees, my boyfriend had the bacon-wrapped tenderloin, and I had tortellini. Both were good; neither were exceptional. I appreciated that there was a vegetarian option, and that it featured seasonal tomatoes, but it wasn't that exciting. My boyfriend enjoyed his pork, but noted that it wasn't particularly creative. They were both above average, but not exceptional.

We could have done without the sides, friend green tomatoes and tater tots.  I love tater tots, and homemade ketchup was nice, but it certainly didn't blow me away. I could find the same if not better at plenty of other places in the bay. Just like the entrees, the sides were above average, but certainly not innovative.

By the time we got to dessert we were pretty stuffed, but we made room for a sampler of 3 desserts, which were all good, none spectacular. The standout of the dessert was the "happy anniversary" written in chocolate on the plate. It was a simple touch that made a big difference. The staff really need not care that we were celebrating a special event, but they chose to acknowledge it, and we appreciated that.

The service was, for me, what bumped this restaurant up to 4 stars. I almost knocked it down to three for its cheesy gimmicks though. Beast of the week, banners outside advertising a seaonsal menu (I just *assume* I get a seasonal menu at a high-end restaurant. Why the banner?), and, quite possibly the worst aspect of the whole evening for me: table flyers advertising the owners' other restaurants. The ads really cheapened the place.

I feel like this restaurant would stand better on its own, without the ads, and perhaps without the Michelin star. It was good. It was not Michelin star good. Had I expected less, I may have enjoyed it more.
author: Sarah F.

description: Recently reserved the chefs table and had a great time. Food was all top notch. Next time I will bring my own wine and pay the corkage. Their Chardonnay tasted and was too old and oxidized.  $100 for a rose was a bit much. Reds were not very impressive, same for their wine cellar. The kids had fun helping prep desert :). An enjoyable 4 hours.
author: Honest R.

description:
Not amazing, but a nice atmosphere and decent food.  The rock shrimp pizza tasted great, but it wasn't light years ahead of a CPK or something.  I guess gourmet pizza really isn't my thing...

I would like to note that the wine glasses were SPOTLESS.  I mean spotless.  I love that in a restaurant.
author: Steve A.

description:
Took some friends from out of town here, and between the excellent food + service, the scrumptious wine, and the lively conversation...they said it was the highlight of their visit!

The bacon wrapped pork loin is melt-in-your-mouth, the briny oysters, the imaginative soups...we had a great dinner.

The happy hour special with half price apps can't be beat - but get their early to create your territory - it gets really really crowded. Yelp needs to put "Happy Hour" on their "Good For..." list.
author: Susan M.

description:
Ordered the crab cakes as an appetizer and the scallops as a main course. Great location and fairly good service with reasonable prices, but - and I know this is a little strange and it makes me feel like an old, old man to write it - there was just way too much salt in everything. I've never felt so dehydrated after a meal in my life. 

Best part of my meal was the wine pairing, to be honest.
author: P. H.

description:
I do not typically post reviews online, but One Market was so good, I feel compelled to post here.

Last weekend, my wife and I got married.  We held a small reception for 35 people at One Market in the Atrium Room and Pavilion.  It was absolutely beautiful, and we were blown away by everything from the professionalism and assistance of the event staff to the wait staff's attention to detail to the quality of food and wine.  

First, I have to say that Beth, Kristen, and Pamela of the event staff were phenomenal in helping us set up the reception.  They created a wonderful space for us and our guests to have hors d'oeuvres in the pavilion, lunch in the atrium room, and cake and champagne back out in the atrium.  They arranged all of our favors, flowers, and seating requests perfectly.  And, they accommodated all of our special food requests (we had to work with a few food allergies and my wife requested a small change to one of the offered dishes).  

The wait staff did a great job making all our guests feel comfortable, and they paced our event perfectly.  I have to give them special credit for this, since the bride and I were late arriving to the restaurant, and a few toasts went on longer than expected.  Nevertheless, our servers paid very close attention to how we were doing and timed everything exactly right.  We were never rushed.  Our guests always had plenty of water, wine, or whatever else they required.   And the service between courses was seamless.

Finally, the food and wine were very, very good.  For the hors d'oeuvres we had rock shrimp tacos, seared tuna on house-made chips, and boneless chicken wings with chipotle glaze.  The seared tuna was definitely my favorite, but all our guests raved about all the hors d'oeuvres.  For lunch, we had a caesar salad and a choice of either mahi-mahi or a new york steak.  We served Merry Edwards sauvignon blanc and A. Raffanelli zinfandel for the wine (both highly recommended).  The steak was decent, but the mahi-mahi really stole the show.  Definitely one of the best fish courses we've ever had in San Francisco.  Even though my wife is a bit of a foodie, we were very pleased with the quality of the food, especially the mahi-mahi.  

I would highly recommend One Market for an event.  My wife and I will certainly be back for dinner soon.  Thanks to One Market for such an excellent job.
author: Josh M.

description:
I pass by this corner restaurant a few times a week. It's situated on a 90 degree turn, with an unobstructed view of the ferry building and has huge windows which draws in ample light on a sunny day. It looks chic, modern, and has a business lunch appeal.
I walked into this restaurant with medium to high expectations. I've worked in the city for a total of 5 years and have never heard anyone recommend this place.
I decided to go in anyway to give it a fair shake and because I wanted to take a colleague for a job well done and this place fit the bill. And when I say fit the bill, I mean the actual bill. 
When I first entered, the place it was fairly uninviting. This was the type of place where backdoor bank deals are made, food is second class, and the servers and hostess are robotic. 

Needless to say, It's a fairly pricey restaurant, with diminished proportions and flavor dispute a large menu.

It's a shame that a restaurant that's in a great location and decor has such poor conception of food.
author: Bob Y.

description:
Ambience very warm and inviting. The price- expensive, the  food, nothing to get excited about and I would recommend you stay away from!

I ordered the petrale sole that the waitress said included a side, it did not and for
$27.00 what a disappointment .  I think they forgot to cook this tiny rolled up piece
of fish. Really-it was disgusting and raw, and not sushi quality. The ceasar salad
was equally disappointing, a few leaves of lettuce with 4 croutons made into a corner....for 12.50.

Someone took my drink away when it still was 1/2 full.  The 4 of us wondered
how they did this without us noticing. 

We were leaving when my friend realized she forgot her gloves. When we returned to
the table, it was cleaned and set. The waitress was nearby and we asked her if she
had seen a pair of gloves to which she responded that she had not. Decided
to check myself, and they had fallen on the floor under the table.

Go to Slanted Door across the street., not so hedonistic and much tastier.
author: Anna G.

description:
Before I begin my rant, this place shouldn't have received their Michelin 1 star.

Also, if the length of this review is about to turn you away, WAIT! Just remember: If you go, ORDER THE HAND-PICKED DUNGENESS CRAB!!!

If you're going for lunch & ordering the $22.50 for starter/main course or $26.50 for starter/main course/dessert - then on value:taste alone, I'd give it 4 stars. However, our first trip there was for the Valentine's Day dinner and to give it anything higher than 3 stars would be a prevarication of epic proportions.

We both were limited to the Valentine's Day menu, $75 for 3 courses including dessert - Ref: http://www.onemarket.com/images/menus/VDay2010.pdf

*** We ordered:

* HOUSE MADE CAVATELLI - dungeness crab, artichoke, basil, meyer lemon - my first course
           - [2.5/5 - Chewy, tough, bland.. but edible.]
* HAND-PICKED DUNGENESS CRAB - green apple water, jalapeño, cilantro - his first course
           - [5/5 - THIS WAS THE HIGHLIGHT OF THE EVENING! It was light, refreshing, cool.. and a great mixture of sweet, sour and yum. This is one of the most delicious dishes I've ever had, and the only thing that makes up for the rest of One Market's fails. If I knew the dish would be that good, I might have ordered two in place of the icky steak.]
* GRILLED PAINTED HILLS N.Y. STEAK - dandelion, roasted garlic, béarnaise relish
           - [2/5 - One of the most repulsive things I've had to force myself to eat. It was bland, extremely tough to chew, and just... awful. No, we didn't finish even finish a third of it - and mind you, I was trying to be optimistic about it!]
* VALRHONA CHOCOLATE DESSERT TASTING - milk chocolate mousse,
white chocolate verrine, bittersweet chocolate soufllé cake
           - [3.5/5 - Good but not special. I mean, good God, it's chocolate! It should be worth the calories!]

Because 1.) I was hopeful & wanted to believe that I'd gone on an "off day", 2.) the lunch menu is so inexpensive and, most importantly, 3.) the Hand-picked Dungeness Crab with green apple water, jalapeño, cilantro was SO BEEPING INCREDIBLE, we decided to give it another shot.

For lunch the next day, we had 2 courses each and a glass of wine. We ordered:

* DUNGENESS CRAB CAKES
           - [3.5/5 - Average. Good, but we've both had better.]
* HAND-PICKED DUNGENESS CRAB - green apple water, jalapeño, cilantro
           - [5/5 - Still delicious.. hmm, tempted to go back soon just for this dish...]
* SWISS CHARD RAVIOLI - ricotta, hedgehog mushrooms
           - [4/5 - Yummy, but not the most amazing thing in the world..]


SERVICE: For the Valentine's Day dinner, the service was mediocre at best. For lunch, however, our server (a very charming French lady..) was delightful, informative, and attentive! :-)
author: Asha S.

description:
So, this place has over 600 reviews...what could I possibly add? Probably not much, but 2010 is almost over and I need to keep my elite status...thank you.

This place is amazing.  This isn't exactly in my price range, and honestly even if it was I don't think you could eat from here on a regular basis (though I am sure enough people will prove me wrong) because the food is soooo much, rich, intense, fattening, crazy...they have a beast of the week!

This is not the kind of place you go if you are vegan, or vegetarian or even watching your weight...This is the kind of place you go if you want your meat wrapped in other meat...as a friend did when he ordered the porkchop wrapped in bacon (at least its two meats from the same animal) which he did say was awesome...

The wine list is incredible, but mostly california wines...they even had the prisoner...I rarely see that on a wine list...The tuna was pretty good...the amuse buche...so amusing...the anchovies, probably yummy if I liked anchovies...so its not them-its me.  The bread super good...the wait staff sooooo attentive, but lets get to the good part.  The dessert.  You can pick three, a little dessert flight.  I order the mint chip dessert, someone else picked some pineapple thing maybe, and then in the middle was a toffee thing (that the waiter suggested) and it changed my life.  

Enough said, one market....you aren't good for me.  but i love you.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
One Market. One Michelin Star. One hell of a good lunch.

I haven't been this excited by American food in quite some time. Why? Because what you think you order is not exactly what you get. I was so excited by it, in fact, that I wrote my latest Examiner article on this restaurant so that I could delve into all the details of why my food was so impressive. 

You can read that full article by following the Examiner link in my profile.

In the meantime, here are the quick hits:

- Excellent prices for what you're getting. The $28 2-course lunch, and the $49 "Weekly Beast" dinner special are steals considering the quality of food you're receiving.

- They have a exhibition kitchen, meaning, you can sit at a bar that wraps around the kitchen and watch the chefs preparing your food. 

- While all of the dishes I ordered were more than solid, the Tazmanian Trout (mi-cuit) stood out in terms of flavor from the rest of the pack, while the "COBB" salad stood out in terms of creativity.

Don't let your preconceived notions of Embarcadero dining or grand exterior  -  the food being served inside deserves that star.
author: Kelsey E.

description: Have been to this restaurant for lunch many times and never disappointed.    Good service and nice meal.  Had the Flounder which was cooked perfectly.  Never felt rushed by server which is always a plus!
author: Steve F.

description:
My main compliant about this place is that you literally need to set aside anywhere from 1.5-2 hours to dine here during lunch, which just isn't practical for the FiDi.

However, during a recent recruiting lunch the asparagus soup and the hot pastrami sandwich were absolutely amazing.

This may be hard to believe and horrific all at the same time - but this is the first time I have ever had a hot pastrami sandwich and sauerkraut and by God, I'm a fan. Their sauerkraut is super yummy. I was a bit nervous, it being my first time an all. But that sauerkraut was a total gentleman through and through and he showed me what I have been missing all these years.

Thanks One Market - you really know how to treat a girl right!
author: Becky M.

description:
Pretty solid business lunch place. And  chickpea fries - YUM.

Been here a couple times for business lunches and dinners. The place is always humming with suits and biz mtgs on weekdays. 

I've never had a bad meal here. The menu's always changing and there's always some cool new enticing items on the menu. Some  memorable items I've had: farm raised salmon - cooked simply and so perfectly, scallops - so fresh and loved every bite, and of course, the famous chickpea fries with the aioli sauce... so different and love 'em!

And I never got to try, but the chef's table in the kitchen looks like a lot of fun and you get to cook some food/make pastries w/the chefs. 

Bottom line: Great place for a business meal on corporate card. Food is always solid. But would I come here for a non-business event or recommend to others to take a date? Probably not - just something about this place that's too corporate for me. I could be tempted by the chef's table though...
author: Jim C.

description:
I'm sorry but I was really not impressed with One Market considering its reputation and highly boasted Michelin star rating. I think that when you go to a restaurant, the food, atmosphere, service and experience should be able to meet expectations and my highly anticipated trip to One Market was definitely unable to do just that.

Our party of 6 had a late reservation at 8:30 pm and found ourselves being rushed to order because the kitchen closes at 9:00 pm. That's fine, but there is a tactful and professional way of getting your diners to hurry it up. A friend and I shared the smoked trout appetizer and although it was interesting, it was by no means amazing. Then I ordered the beef cheeks and it had been highly recommended by yelp and yes, it truly does melt in your mouth. A good dish to try although I i found the sauce to be a little heavy. 

Between the 6 of us we had ordered the steelhead on the DAT menu, bacon wrapped tenderloin and the black cod. Although all the dishes were beautiful and relatively good we did not get that "mmMmMMMmm" moment that is usually standard for fine dining. Trust me, we all are major foodies and truly enjoy those mmm moments.

I am definitely glad that I came to One Market to give it a try but I don't think I will be back. Too much hype, not enough follow through.
author: Christina L.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to One Market because his mom gave him at $100 gift card for his birthday. Good thing too because we spent almost $200 after tax and tip! Granted, we ordered 2 appetizers, two entrees, a bottle of wine, expensive scotch, and the 3 mini-desserts...so it wasn't actually all that ridiculous. 

Most of the food was REALLY good, but there were a couple meh items. 

For appetizers we had the lightly smoked trout and heirloom tomato consomee.  The trout was served on top of a potatoes that resembled a crispy potato latke and under a runny egg. It may sound odd but it was SOOOO good. I was in love. I didn't like the tomato consomee, but my boyfriend seemed to think it was ok. 

For entrees, we got the scallops and the Friday-night meat special which was lamb with a cocoa reduction. I don't eat lamb so I can't give my two cents, but he seemed to think it was pretty good but not amazing. I really liked my scallops, but I don't really know from scallops (I've only ordered them once before...that's the problem of growing up in a vegetarian family).

For dessert we got the three mini-desserts and chose the cheesecake, chocolate (pecan?) cake, and the mint ice cream sandwich. The chocolate nutty cake was DELICIOUS, the cheesecake was good, but the mint ice cream sandwich was suuuuper minty. Not at all what I was expecting. It was clearly made with fresh mint leaves and a whole lot of them. 

The weirdest part of the night was when the old white couple sitting next to us (giving us odd looks for the 5+ minutes they were sitting there) asked to be moved.  I don't know why, but judging from the fact that they were only moved a couple tables away, I assume it was either:
1. because we were being too loud (even though we weren't being loud AT ALL)
2. because we were too young (in our early-mid twenties)
or 3. because we're an inter-racial couple (my boyfriend is Filipino)

I'm not saying that that reflects badly upon the restaurant, but it does say something about the type of people the restaurant attracts. 

All in all, I enjoyed my meal but I probably won't go back anytime soon. Next time I feel like spending $100-$200 for a meal, I'll probably check out other restaurants in the city.
author: Talia G.

description:
Great restaurant!

Nice ambiance, we had a reservation for 7:45 pm on Fri and was brought to our seats at 7:43pm. The food was delicious! Pork tenderloin was awesome. Had  chocolate souffle and a peach cobbler with ice cream, also to die for. The service was very very good and we did  their market deal (3 course for $35 - $39) which made it very economical. Wife had the scallops and they were also very good although with scallops I never feel like they give you enough. At least the 4 scallops served on the plate were large and cooked to perfection.

One plus is that it has a good view; right across the ferry building clock tower.

Will definitely come back!
author: Kevin L.

description:
FOR THE BAR ONLY - I've never felt more compelled to sign up and write a review until I attended a work function during (not so) Happy Hour at the bar last Friday. I only gave 1 star because I couldn't give zero.

After we were ignored by the waitress for about 20 minutes, we decided to approach the bar. The bartender was rude and mixed our drinks sloppily while we watched.  it was as if he was somehow being inconvenienced.

Once we all got our drinks and sat down, the waitress decides to come to our table. Not knowing If we would get the opportunity again, we order another round. It was more than 10 minutes later when the rude bartender brought 2 of the 6 drinks we ordered to our table....was the waitress behind the bar mixing drinks?

We found her several minutes later and had to wave her over to our table. We asked where the other drinks were, at which time she put her hand on her hip and began her 5 minute response which included calling me "sweetie" in a condescending tone, then a cry me a river "I'm the only waitress here" excuse, and finished by throwing the bartender, who was doing her job just a minute ago, under the bus saying he hadn't even started making our drinks yet.

Needless to say, we closed our tab and went to Chaya where we enjoyed excellent service. I will NEVER go back and neither will my coworkers.
author: Ruby B.

description:
I am not one to write many reviews and consider myself quite tolerant and flexible when it comes to cuisine and dining experiences.  That being said, I feel compelled to write this review for One Market as it was probably one of the most disappointing experiences I have ever had at any dining establishment.  

I was part of a private group function celebrating a special event.  The evening started out fine, but then quickly deteriorated in terms of service.  I won't comment much on the cuisine which I'd say was good but not great (2.5 stars for the food).  

We ended up pouring our own wine, serving our own bread, and never being offered any coffee or tea with our dessert.  I actual don't mind having to do some of these things, but  it was really over the top.  I attempted to speak with the manager (unclear if he really was the manager) who instead of apologizing or even trying to appear somewhat apologetic, was confrontational.  

For those considering a group or private event, I would recommend highly against this place.  Perhaps it was an off night in terms of service, but the attitude I received when I tried to explain our dissatisfaction was something else.  

I would hate to have anyone's special event ruined or be at risk of being ruined by dining here.  

Sorry to write this review, but I feel people should know.
author: Ken S.

description:
Lunch here was exactly what I needed after the lackluster meal we had at Coi. Unfortunately for me they somehow managed to lose my OpenTable reservation, an occurrence which seemed common after overhearing several people who came in have the same issue. The hostess was rather indignant, and asked me to step aside and wait for a table. I obliged as it gave me a chance to unpack the Canon from my camera bag and get quickly adjusted to the warmth inside the restaurant, a nice reprieve from the cold, windy day. After watching her sit another party, whose reservation they had also lost, I approached her to find out how long I would be waiting for tables which I could clearly see were vacant. She informed me when the rest of my party arrived she would sit me, so I responded, for the second time, that it was just myself and I would like to sit down now.

By the time I finally get to my seat I'm a little bit irritated, especially after the piss poor service the night before, but once I get attuned to the hustle and bustle of the atmosphere in this place I quickly become distracted by plates of delicious looking food hovering all around me. It doesn't take me long to figure out what I want, the "Market Lunch" here is an outstanding deal at just $28 for any 2 courses on the menu (plus another $4 if you want to add a dessert), and considering the quality of the food here could very well be the best business lunch special in San Francisco. My waitress was a bit aloof, and I'm not entirely sure she spoke much English other than what was required to serve what's on the menu, but she was deftly efficient at refilling my water and constantly asking how everything was, even if she didn't stick around to hear my answer. Fortunately for her, it was all great.

My first course was the handpicked Dungeness crab salad with avocado, tomato water, and a basil and corn sorbet. Visually this was one of the most beautiful plates (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=LmT61_oRntUy0OKZmdOrFg) I've ever seen, and the flavors that follow are equally impressive. I can only imagine how refreshing this dish must be on a hot summer day, every aspect of it awes you and makes you want more. They certainly aren't stingy with the crabmeat either, as the lump and diced portions were both very generous. At first the tomato water may seem a bit odd, and you begin to wonder why exactly this is called a salad, but soon you get past the texture unfamiliarity and being to enjoy every bite.

After the light start to the meal, I really wanted something with some backbone, and they had the perfect match, house-made cavatelli pasta w/ lamb, nepitella, and house-made ricotta cheese. There were so many good aspects to this dish (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/u-pywNLq06dgqR48kbFR9w?select=3qIHIQ12Z4GXeq9H1DLVBg), you just simply have to try it. They even add some of the ricotta to the pasta as they're making it. The lamb is minced expertly, and so flavorful you just want to keep eating until the bowl is empty. I cannot praise this dish enough, if you come here and want the most filling, delicious lunch One Market has to offer you must order this.

I wasn't initially going to order a dessert, but after the first 2 courses went so well I figured it was worth the mere $4 to tack on a few more calories. I decided to get the Sonoma apple crumb top pie w/ a blackberry sauce and vanilla ice cream. It was a good throw back to mom's desserts, with a little more flair. As far as lunch desserts go I would say it was pretty fair, but not nearly up to the caliber as the crab salad and lamb pasta.
author: Justin C.

description:
Service was great and ambiance was very nice and clean...since it does have a Michelin Star rating.  We had a salad with was so simple I could have made a better one...it need it something to make it more memorable...like feta cheese.  

We also had the steam muscles which came out luke warm...which does not qualify for consistent good food and service for a place that has a Michelin Star.  I had the linguini which was more like an appetizer serving..so small I couldn't believe my eyes...for freakin pasta...like the palm of my hands size..not including the fingers extended..just the palm.  It tasted pretty healthy since it had very minimal flavor to it...like they just boiled the pasta and dressed it up with steamed veges and a very light butter sauce if any.  

My anchor steam beer did come out nice an cool in a beautiful tall slim glass.
author: Jeremy K.

description:
When we lived near the city, we used to come to One Market often, always enjoying the food...nothing has changed.  The food is still delish.  I did have to slow down the service a bit, they were bringing our second course before we finished our first, but once I did, our server was right on pace.  I started with the Grilled Apricot Salad, with Foie and Duck Proscuitto ($16.00) (I'm going to miss that Foie); my husband had the Smoked Trout with a Poached Egg that was served on a crisp potato chive "pancake"  ($15.00)- so good, and fun to just break that perfectly cooked egg and let it ooze over the dish.  Being in a ducky kind of mood, for my main I had  the grilled duck breast with Foie/Sausage on Farro with Nettles  ($29.50)(I did mention I was going to miss that Foie?) Wonderful.  The breast was cut perfectly and the farro was oh so good, with a wonderful Earl Grey Jus.  My husband had the Pan Roasted Sturgeon with Spring Vegetables (also $29.50) - perfectly cooked fish with a wonderful array of fresh vegetables...YUM!  As we were meeting friends later, we skipped dessert, but I'll bet it would have been great too!

LindySez:  I've missed you One Market.  Not overly fancy, but down to earth good!
author: Lindy B.

description:
This place is great for business lunches and dinners. Personally I wouldn't want to pay $20 for a half chicken but on expenses it's great. There is always something for everyone (steak, chicken, fish, vegetarian). 

I got the half chicken which was very flavorful. The skin was crispy and the meat was moist. I usually pick mashed potatoes as the side because I like to use the sauce from the chicken as a gravy. The mashed potatoes are very smooth and buttery. They kind of remind me of instant potatoes though they taste a lot better. They always seem a bit too thin to pick up with a fork but I keep ordering them so I guess it doesn't discourage me that much. 

The butterscotch pudding is very rich and the taste is almost caramelized, which I really enjoy. I recommend it as a dessert to share (because it's very sweet). 

They have an autumn menu right now so there are a couple of dishes with pumpkin in them. I may go back just to try the pumpkin profiteroles. 

The ambiance is classy and on a Friday at lunch you may even get lucky and be able to walk in without a reservation. They have a great wine list. The service is a bit slow so it's best for meals where you are not pressed for time.
author: Brittany M.

description:
Worst experience in a nice restaurant ever. I went out with 5 others for a nice dinner - we each averaged about $60/person and were not skimping. We expected good food, unobtrusive but prompt service, and friendliness. 

Waitress was abrupt and frequently interrupted our conversation by asking us to hand her our plates. Our 6th person arrived about 10 minutes after we placed our order (but well before we got our food). The waitress never stopped by to take his order. I finally flagged over the maitre d' to ask for assistance when the rest of us were almost *done with dinner. He took the order and put a rush on my friend's food..... but the waitress didn't bother to apologize and only came back to take dessert orders. 

Adding insult to injury, I stopped into the WC as I left and there was no toilet paper...I had to ask someone in the next stall to help. Not a remarkable experience for a Wednesday night. I won't be back.
author: Wendy M.

description:
Food: A+
Wine List: A- (No French)
Service: A+
Ambiance: A relaxed upscale

We live nearby and dine here about once per month.  We have never had a bad meal here or bad service.  I would all the ambiance upscale but relaxed.

We often dine at the kitchen counter and watch everything being cooked.

I frankly cannot believe the lowish ratings here.  This is a "Go To" place for special occasions.
author: GP R.

description: Growing to like this place. They have very fresh ingredients, nice seasonal stuff, well cooked meats and fish. Really enjoyed the last few soups and entrees I've had.  Quite nice and becoming a regular lunch spot.
author: Josh B.

description: Went there for lunch, excellent food, decent service.  With many up scale resturants not open for lunch, this is definitely the place to go if you need some sophistication in the middle of your day.
author: K L.

description:
It's so nice to go into the city and get terrific food served impeccably. One Market is that place for me. They are always so amazingly superb in their execution. 

I have to tell you about the Mushroom ravioli, it was so delcious and what a pleasant surprise to find they used thin slices of Portabello mushrooms to make the skins of the ravioli. So delicate!

I am breaking out my mandoline because I was inspired by the razor thin cauliflower and aspargus in my salad. Yum!

Yes, the place is full at lunch time of loud and self important windbags but just focus on your date and food.
author: Lhm M.

description:
It's our annual college roommate gift exchange dinner.  Of course we have to pick a swanky place, because that's just how we roll.

The warm bread to start the night was excellent.

We shared the sauteed wild gulf shrimp.  The presentation 
was amazing, and it was definitely delicious.

For the main course, we had the pancetta-wrapped day boat scallops, the ahi tuna, and their grill special of the day, the filet mignon.

Scallops were cooked to perfection, and all the sides were good.

The ahi tuna was really salty, and they give you five pieces for $25.  It looked really bare next to our other dishes.

The filet mignon was thick, juicy, and fabulous.

We ended the night with the chocolate souffle cake.  The banana ice cream was literally the icing on (or in this case, near) the cake!
author: Jenny L.

description:
A belated review of the Dine about Town menu. I can see why they have a Michelin star. The service is superb- very accomodating at the hostess' desk, and the servers are exceedingly professional.

First, we got a free amuse bouche. I think it was a bite of tuna. It was delicious and whet my appetite for more. Their bread is really good too. I had a piece of the olive bread. I don't know why I chose olive bread as I hate olives, but it was actually really yummy baked into the soft but crunchy bread. 

Next:

Rancho Gordo Chick Pea Soup
saffron, wild shrimp, niçoise olives
Delicious dish, beautiful tableside presentation. The soup is a very pretty green. It is really flavorful and the shrimp have a nice bite to them.

Bay Leaf Tri-Tip with chimichurri and fresh corn polenta 
This was unlike any polenta I've ever had. It was bursting with corn flavor and little fresh corn bits. AMAZING! The meat was nice too, but the accompaniments made the meal. 

Roasted Blenheim Apricots
brown butter cake, nayou sabayon, blueberries,
candied almonds, apricot ice cream
Really nice dessert. Warm, not overly sweet.

Strawberry shortcake
The ice cream was a funny, adventurous flavor. I forgot what it was though since it wasn't my dessert, and it's not on the menu. Other than that it was great (but not as good as the nectarine)
author: Cathy S.

description: Beginning with the lamb tongue to the scallops and the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin, I was in food heaven. Writing this review makes me want to go back for another round.
author: Courtney S.

description:
We grabbed an early dinner at One Market before the Swan Lake Ballet on 1/26/2010. I had not been there in many years. 

Excellent meal overall, I give it a 4.5 stars. Not a 5 because some of the dishes lacked flavor.

Dine About Town (DAT) is really a good deal. I cannot really afford to pay $80 for a prix fix dinner at a premium restaurant in SF, but $35 is a great deal a 3 course meal. And unlike some of the other restaurants offering DAT meals, the portions at One Market were big and we were stuffed when we left.

I did the DAT Deluxe for $45 since they offered the Grilled Sardines and the Valrhona soufflé cake options. DAT Deluxe gives one more access to the popular dishes like these and also the duck breast confit and the black cod.

Service was excellent. I suppose the only negative in this area was that the waitress told me about what is "popular". I hate to hear what is popular because most people do not have my taste buds. So telling me about what is popular is insulting. Other than that, she was phenomenal.

When we first arrived at exactly 5:30, the restaurant was almost empty. However by the time we left at 7:15, every table was full. The crowd was not too stuffy either. No need for a suit and tie. "Smart casual" works just fine. Even nice jeans would be OK. 

Other restaurants should take a lesson from the speed of the dish delivery at One Market. Within 5 minutes of placing our order, appetizers were on the table. 5 minutes after the appetizers were cleared, entrees were on the table. We were never rushed, but we never waited and since we were on a time table to get to the Ballet, this speedy service worked very well. This is in sharp contrast to the Salt House Restaurant where my wife and I waited about 30 minutes for appetizers and about the same for the entrees. Never going back there.

Additionally, everything was served at the correct temperature. This is one of my biggest pet peeves. Hot items served luke warm and cold items served warm. 

The cauliflower soup was all that everyone had said about it. Just perfect. Not an overwhelming cauliflower taste, but enough. Nice little bits of cut up scallops, pears, onions, etc. 

The Caesar salad was good. Nice and neat. Perhaps a bit buttery/oily, but my daughter loved it.

The olive oil poached black cod was very nice. Tender and flakey, super moist, not too fatty. Nice little almond pieces were nice.

My wife liked her rice flake crusted Petrale sole in carrot-ginger emulsion, but I thought that it was a bit plain. It had a nice crispy top on it, but it was still plain. My cod was way better.

The skirt steak was quite tasty. My Mom and daughter both loved it. Personally, I felt that it lacked a little in the flavor category but I did not pay that much attention to it. 

The bread pudding (Dulce de Leche) was not very good. I kept on hoping for some cut up chunks of apple in the  inch square chopped-up bread cubes, but that is not what bread pudding is about.

We brought in 2 bottles of our own wine but the wine adder to the DAT menu seemed like a great deal. $13 more for wine pairing. But since corkage was only $20 per bottle and since I only like French and Italian wines (and One Market only stocks Cali wines), I kinda had to bring my own. Note that this is a very good corkage price. Many restaurants of this caliber are quite a bit more.

The Valrohna chocolate cake was just a bit boring. I like mine a bit more runny and moist in the middle like a molten cake. Not chocolaty enough.

The apple dumplings with crème fraiche ice cream were quite nice.
Since we were a bit unhappy with bread pudding desserts, they manager gave us a complimentary Bradley's butterscotch pudding. It was amazing. 

Overall, a phenomenal experience at a restaurant that has been around since 1993 and one might have expected to slip a bit. Also DAT often puts stress on these places and One Market shone throughout the experience. They deserve their one Michelin star if not another.
author: TJ M.

description:
Went here for my Fiance's work dinner and  was left unsatisfied. The service was slow, and one of our attendees found a piece of plastic in his Foi Grois (spelling?!).  The ambiance is typical/fancy pretentious place; very stiff and unoriginal. 

I had the potato gnocchi, as it was the only vegetarian entree on the menu, very unsual for a San Francisco restaurant. Bella in the inner richmond has fresh gnocchi for less cost and a million times better.

The beet carpachio salad was decent, but small. 

Overall, another overpriced, overated restaurant that will bring in the tourists and pretentious folk. I'll stick to my favorite neighborhood  hot spots.
author: Kate V.

description: I came here with a few co-workers for lunch and I remember the food being disappointing. I wish it had ended there, but our waiter was soo rude, didn't pay any attention to us, and pretty sure forgot we were there. Didn't give any recommendation and didn't even ask how I liked my meat cooked. One of the other waiters kindly took notice and tried to accomidate the best he could.
author: Dara S.

description:
Excelent service

Very good food, great blend of flavors. Nice atmosphere!
author: Laura B.

description:
The food is wonderful.  Just had the dine about town menu for lunch which was amazing.  I never knew a simple salad could taste so fresh.  The main fish dish was equally fresh, tasty and well presented.  Every bite hit the spot. 

So the food definitely deserves a 4 or 5 star but the service is really lacking.  Our server showed up 2 minutes after we sat down and asked us if we were ready to order.  We said that we weren't.  He didn't reappear for about 15 minutes.  He couldn't hear what I was attempting to order so he raised his voice at me.  A bit embarrassing during a work lunch.   The food took an eternity to arrive.  We were in and seated at 12:15 and left at 1:45 after gobbling down our meal to get back to the office.
author: Billy B.

description:
Since moving to San Francisco and after a couple of "fine dining experiences" I was feeling rather disappointed at the mediocre fine dining scene.  I had decided that good wholesome food may be the way to go...  

Well One Market revived my interest in fine dining.

It was a very special occasion for us - and we had originally wanted to do the Chef's Table (where you get to sit at the table behind the kitchen and actually get an explanation about each course that comes out) but there was a minimum 4 required for that to happen.  So we decided to try Chef's counter instead (at Matire D's  suggestion).  We actually booked for Chef's counter.  Even though on the night we were there, there wasn't anyone on the Chef's counter, I've been told that it can fill up.

We had decided to try the Chef's Tasting Course (for which there was no menu - it was whatever the Chef was going to give you).  I also decided to have wine pairing - it actually ended up being enough wine for both of us. 

Starters: Bread.  To Die For.  The choices were french bread and olive bread. Both had crusty outer and chewy inner. I'm not a huge bread eater but I could probably have had 10 of those...

Course 1: Amuse Bouche - Prawn in tequila foam
Course 2: Hand picked dungeness crab with jalapeno sorbet & jalapeno jelly (Under the crab) with apple water
Course 3: Grilled Octopus with scallion & wasabi paste with black garlic puree topped with soy foam.
Course 4: Alaskan black cod with crispy pork skin & pork cheek bones with soy sauce. Decorated with Pea puree & English peas.
Course 5: Duck breast with duck leg meat (pulled and pressed) Polenta puree & braised cabbage with valrona chocolate
Duck jus reduction
Course 6: Skirt steak with dandelion collard garlic cream sauce with hanchi minchi mushrooms and beef peppercorn jus
Course Special (this was not part of the course but we requested this because we were staring at this being prepared in front of all night and were drooling all night - Chef was kind enough to give us this additional course) - Pork loin wrapped in bacon on top of mashed potato and pork jus (tender-est pork loin ever!)
Course 7 - we could choose any dessert from the menu. I chose chocolate fondant with irish cream ice cream and berries. (BEAUTIFUL)

I can't say enough great things about this restaurant.  Portions were generous.  Every plate was flavourful (not bland or over flavoured in anyway). It was interesting seeing the sous-chefs working at each of the stations as well as the Chef being in charge of everyone.

Definitely going back!

Chef's tasting menu is well worth the money (I think it was $60-70  which is super reasonable for a Chef's tasting course)
author: Sujan H.

description: Easily Best dinner I have ever had. The Michelin star is rightfully earned. I went to San Fran to visit my best friend. She had already set up reservations. Everything I had for was to die for. Of course it is pricey but that's why they have a Michelin star. If you have the chance to eat here and can afford it. I highly recommend it.
author: Jen G.

description:
One Market is a restaurant of contradictions.  It fancies itself as a figurehead of the Embarcadero and of the financial district.  I suppose that it achieves that with a little irony.

The kitchen is good; there's no disputing that.  But forget about ideas like customers being right and that sort of thing.  The dining room staff purport to know what's good for you and if you want otherwise, it's an argument.  Apparently, one thing that can be good for you is for your wine to arrive after your food, and it can be tough going to get some help to remediate the situation.

Consequently, I choose the bar for a lower-stress experience.  Last dinner I ordered there was the seared tuna on mushroom escabeche (a bit in the "fra diavolo" vein) with a side of green beans and shiitake mushrooms -- a double mushroom whammy.  It was all very nice, and my waitress went searching for some soy sauce for me when I inquired.
author: T D.

description:
My fiance and I were treated to dinner at One Market on Saturday night by a gf who was visiting from out of town. It's one of those places that you always see, sometimes hear of, never think about, and wouldn't necessarily go. BUT-- a Michelin rated restaurant always deserves a chance, and it blew it. One Market severely lacks in style, PIZZAZ! and outstanding service.

The restaurant itself is quite gorgeous, and boasts a pretty view of the Bay and the Ferry Building. Its location is perfect, particularly if you want to entertain guests from out of town. Its the kind of place you don a dress for a date, and enjoy and evening of what they like to call 'fine' wine and 'fine' food. The word 'fine' is disputable in this instance, so I'll let you be the judge.

For a restaurant bustling with waiters-- my poor gf got bumped in the head by wait staff more often than she was actually served. Our service was slow, our drinks were slow, and when our food finally came out, there were definitely no fireworks! We started off with pumpkin soup and a beet/ goat cheese salad which certainly looked fancier than it tasted. I mean, if the arty pumpkin soup pour over a 'yoghurt cloud' doesn't make it taste any more tastier then I would prefer you to skip the theatrics and just top up my water please. For my entree, we ordered the pork medallions, pumpkin ravioli and seared scallops, and, expected, all were good-- but definitely not great.

Overall, a very mediocre experience. There are hundreds of other gorgeous restaurants that will blow you away, unfortunately this is not one of them!
author: Shahirah I.

description:
Was delighted to find that Dine Around Town, SF's restaurant week, was ongoing when I arrived for the weekend.  At a friend's recommendation (based on a visit several years prior) booked One Market for lunch.  

1. Greeted and brought to table right next to server station.  Fine, not ideal, but fine.  

2. I asked if I could have entree and dessert instead of app and entree.  Only if I wanted to pay a la carte price.  I would have gotten the whole shebang, but my options for course one were either salad or cauliflower soup!

3. My friend's wine glass was very dirty with lipstick marks.  Our waiter's response, "well you aren't having wine anyways."  

4. 20 minutes in, waiter came back to remove our appetizer forks.  Wondered why that was more important than offering us bread.  

5. Then, the straw that broke the camel's back.  Discovered spider in water.  Gross!  Left immediately!  Experience ruined in no small part by extremely apathetic service - shame we didn't even get to try the food (not even the bread)
author: Ida C.

description:
My wife and I were really disappointed. My wife's Caesar salad had a large piece of rusty lettuce, the sole was soulless in taste, and the Dulce de Leche Bread Pudding was only par-baked. My Caesar salad was okay, a bit overdressed and the leaves not the quality I was expecting. The dessert of Apple Dumplings was uninspired and frankly reminded me of an Apple Pie from McDonalds (that's harsh, I know). On the other hand, my oysters and entree of Grilled Bay Leaf Marinated Skirt Steak were absolutely delicious. 
The service was top-notch, except for when our entrees arrived before we had finished the salads. However, the staff seemed to be out of sync as more than once the waitstaff almost collided with each other. 
To be fair, we were 15 minutes late for our 5:30 reservation. I hate to think our experience is due in part because we chose from the Dine About Town prix fixe menu.
author: Bryan B.

description:
I've been several times--and not once did I have bad service or for that matter, a bad meal. 

Sure, there are a lot of suits here. But it's in the heart of the financial district. What do you expect? Starving artist students who haven't bathed in 5 days? Take the uniform as a way to blend in with the decor. It doesn't detract from the food - that's for sure. 

This place knows how make meat. Hands down. Their chicken is amazingly moist and tender. Their duck is well seasoned and juicy. And their beef is just right. 

This is only assisted by the fact that they also know their soups and desserts. Some soups lean towards being seen as interesting concoctions - chestnut soup to a wild mushroom veloute--but all that I've ever tried have been delicious. And their desserts--wow.. Decadent, really. But the good kind of decadent. Like the kind that you'd be willing to go to the gym for the next week just to have a bite of one of their desserts. 

I don't understand the hate. Sure, it's a pricey meal, but worth it for what you get. And that's all that really matters in my book.
author: Vic C.

description:
One Market is not as good as it is said to be.  I went there for a birthday celebration, and I was a little disappointed with the quality of food.
I ordered the Mahi Mahi a la carte, and it was way too salty!  The desserts, however, were delicious (especially the chocolate toffee cake)
If you are looking for a nice, pricey restaurant, I'd say skip One Market, and use your money somewhere else in the city.
author: Alison L.

description:
Came here for DAT...$31.95 for the 3 course meal, $45 with the wine pairing. I got the wine pairing.

First, let us review what went right.

1. The white wine was excellent...it was refreshing and crisp. 

2. For my appetizer I got the black bean soup with salt and pepper calamari. It was a very dramatic dish because they poured the soup over the calamari, and the soup was totally black. It was EXCELLENT, though...cream of black bean, and I didn't taste the beans at all. (By the way, I hate beans because they're mushy.) Very well done.

3. Peach brown butter tart with homemade vanilla bean ice cream and blueberry compote. Very very good...not sure what the brown butter tart is made of but it was delicious.

Now let's move on to what can be improved...

1. $13 for a wine pairing with 2 half-glasses of wine? Maybe it would have been worth it if the red wine actually tasted good, but it didn't. I didn't get red off the wine, which tells you how little they gave us. For $13 I expect at least 1.5 glasses of wine. 

2. Already covered above, but must add another bullet point for the red wine not tasting good.

3. DAT menu was very limited. Two choices for appetizer, entree, and dessert...very disappointing. 

4. Pork short ribs were just okay. It didn't blow me out of my chair like the black bean soup did. For a one-star Michelin restaurant I was expecting more.

All in all a ho-hum dining experience. Next time I'll be giving the waiter my feedback on the red wine.
author: Ted W.

description:
