What is important is Food, Price, Location, service, and Ambiance. For the food I am mixed as I had a killer appetizer of trout which looked like salmon on a crispy potato cake and some sauces.  I then ordered for my main lunch entree the Cavelli which I was told should be excellent by the waitress.  Well it looked and tasted like chewy maggots and I should have sent it back but was with my parents and in a hurry to finish lunch.  It had cooked crab and some tiny pieces of sausage.

I feel like this restaurant is going on the rep of Brad Ogden who I can't say his food is so spectacular, so don't understand what the big deal is.

The ambiance and location deserve 4-5 stars and price is on the high side, but a 3-4 stars and the food is 3-5 stars depending on what you order.  I won't be rushing back to this place, but decent if your going to expense your lunch for business and not expecting much but want a nice place to go.
author: James H.

description:
We got the Dine About Town menu, so the food might have been completely different in quality from the normal menu. I got the seasonal salad, which consisted of peas, onions, radishes, carrots, and scallions ... it was quite bad. The potato and portabella terrine was very good (probably the best thing at the table that night). The strawberry and grand marnier cream was bad. Others got the pork and skatewing and also disliked them.

The atmosphere and location are very nice. Drinks from the bar are strong and there are lots of options.
author: Akash K.

description:
I'm not sure how this place got a Michelin star-- it definitely was not for its food.  Three of us dined here the other night and got an appetizer that was mediocre, and then two entrees-- the rib eye for two, and the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin.

The pork tenderloin was too dry, and the bacon was not thick enough.  Overall rating of that plate was weak.

The rib eye apparently takes 45 minutes to cook, which is pretty ridiculous when you think that most prime steakhouses can bring out the steak in 20 minutes, especially when you order it medium-rare.  The steak is sliced for you, and then sauce is put on, which makes it difficult to judge the quality of the meat.  It was also mediocre at best, and came with spinach and mashed potatoes.

I would not eat here for the food again, as it was overpriced based on the taste.  Service was fine, as was the overall ambiance, but definitely seems like a powerlunch spot versus a place you might go for a really fancy dinner.
author: Winston G.

description:
If only I was rich enough to enjoy a daily lunch at places like One Market...pimpin it with my white cuffs on the table, clicking away on my Blackberry while waiters left and right bring me San Pelligrino in a champagne glass!

But alas! Instead my work takes me here instead :) Would I come here on my own free will again? Meh. Probably not.

They did have decent sized servings, being that most restaurants this pricey serve you dinky cuts of meat drizzled in sauces. I think the lunch special was a super rip off, though. Appetizers of Beet Carpaccio with Rock Shrimp - nothing super special, but light and cool for the hot summer days - and Crab Cakes, which were surprisingly very good for someone who refuses to eat more than a bite or two of seafood! I went with their Vegetable Consomme - very tasty combination of herbs made it enjoyable, but damnit I wanted more of their so called "tortellini"!! and the caesar salad (psst! It's ten times more amazing at Colibri's!!!) 

The only worthwhile part of my luncheon, other than the company, was their delicious fresh mint lemonade that was like a slushy and their delicious seasonal sorbet dessert plate made with local fruits from the Embarcadero Farmer's Market our waitress recommended....heavenly flavors!
author: Alita M.

description:
I enjoyed 5 new restaurants this year as part of dine about town, and the food at one market was probably my favorite.

The cauliflower soup (as many others have mentioned) was phenomenal.  The scallops (usually bay scallops can be tough or fishy, but not these) were so flavorful and divine, and the bowl came out hot, which ensured warm soup from start to finish (good work, one market).  I even learned what a ramp is! (no, not an incline, but rather a member of the leek family).  The steak for the main course was surprisingly tender given its cut, the sauce was delicious, and those potatoes and bacon on the side were sooo good.  And the bread pudding dessert was impressive.  Not too strong of flavors, uniquely textured, sweetly satisfying.  

The portions were also pretty large (considering some restaurants might be inclined to skimp on portions when they're offering such a large discount).  The food here was perfectly cooked (mmm rare beef) and I was extremely pleased.  

However, the service.  First of all, they seemed way over staffed, but the bread server, water server, and food servers were all very nice and attentive.  It was just that darn waiter  who clearly was not pleased that we didn't want anything to drink, nothing off of the regular menu, and no coffee with dessert.  Dear sir, I'm sorry your tip with us was not as meaty as it would be with regularly paying customers, but had you not acted like we were wasting your time, perhaps we'd come back after the promotion and gladly order two of everything off the menu to stuff your pockets.  

So because the experience wasn't ideal, I probably will only come back for DAT, b/c if the food is just as delicious, I don't want to pay a premium for snarky service to be thrown on top.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
The only reason I'm giving this place 4 stars instead of 5 is because I've never been there during normal business hours. Food, service, and decor are great!!! I'm going to have to revisit One Market during normal business hours so that I can fairly evaluate them. 

I will say this, this is most definately the place to rent out to have your special event.
author: Luke B.

description:
Came here for Dine About Town, and my my my was it delicious. 4.5 stars.

Food: 
Cauliflower soup with scallops was AMAZING.  The actual soup was just a backdrop for the tender, flavorful scallops and the zing of the pickled ramps.  Still not sure where ramps came from or why I had never heard of them, but they were a great addition

Skirt Steak: delicious sauce, good steak, and amazing potatoes.  Came with bacon, no complaints there.  The steak didn't blow me away, though.

Apple dumpling: I have a very soft spot in my stomach for apple dumplings.  I come from Philly and the best Apple Dumplings in the wrold are made by ladies at Reading Terminal Market.  One Market apple dumplings are not too shabby!  A very interesting and delicious take on the traditional apple dumpling, made with puff pastry and with a side of ice cream...delish!

Service-wise, I don't know what our waiter had up his ass.  Fortunately, we didn't need much from him, other than for him to take our order and bring us the check.  There was a bread guy (kept our bread plates from sitting empty), water guy (same with water), and different servers who actually gave us our delicious food.  I'm sorry to the waiter that we didn't buy bottles of wine and only ordered the Dine About Town menu...but not really.  He really didn't need to act so openly pissed that we were not bringing him the big bucks.  Ah well, the food was delicious and I can only take off half a star for him.
author: Cathy Y.

description: I like this place, the food is very good and the waitresses were very nice and helpful. The only thing that bothered me was that the waitresses kept coming to the table every few minutes which I felt was unnecessary since i was trying to converse with my friends.
author: Ana A.

description:
For this price, i was underwhelmed. I've been here for both dinner and lunch, and I would say that it was completely not memorable. To be fair, it was good...but for a michelin rated restaurant, I expect a lot more than mediocre. 

I have to say, when I was here for lunch, I had the worst service I've ever had at a fine dining restaurant. I am sure that it was one particular server and not the whole restaurant, however, I have to note, this woman was rude/not responsive, and when she poured our wine, she did it so brusquely and unskillfully that when she brought it up, wine spilled into my water! And she was a wine ninja, she would pour the wine before people would finish (which i guess is nice) but not when you don't know how to pour wine! UGH in any case, it was a company paid lunch, so I wasn't as angry as I would have been if I were paying.
author: Angela H.

description:
unremarkable.

I had the porkbelly - they should have listed it under salads or appetizers instead. The 4 pieces of pork belly laid on top of a salad with very heavy  olive puree that made the whole dish look like something pooped on it.

I was starving after my appetizer, main course and dessert. There are so many other choices out there that are better.
author: Anna T.

description:
Had a great dinner at One Market Restaurant.

I looked for plenty of places to spend my "big" dinner in San Fran, and picked this restaurant due to the menu and prices.

The ambiance was great, menu was good, and service was very attentive. We even ordered the wrong appie and got the one we meant to order with no fuss.  The food was outstanding and extremely well laid out on the plate. Dessert was delicious too!

I would highly recommend this restaurant to anyone that enjoys good food and doesn't want to pay hundreds of dollars for two people.
author: nicole p.

description: VEGAN REVIEW - I went here for a work event.  There was nothing on the menu that we were offered (small group, private room, limited menu), but they brought a great vegetable medley.  No vegan protein options.  They did the best that they could for someone that I didn't feel that they were expecting.  Three stars because the staff was very friendly.  One overall vegan star.
author: Jeremy O.

description:
Went for a dinner. Absolutely delicious! Every  dish we tried was out of this world.Their beet carpaccio is something! Pefectly handled slices of beets, toasted spices and yummy goat cheese. 
The service is as it is supposed to be in a high end dining place: though you get everyting you need timely, you do not even notice how you are being served, no interruption whatsoever.
Just perfect!
I also did not think the place is pricey for San Francisco. I've dined in other places in SF that were way worse and charged the same $$ or more.
author: Skate K.

description:
Sat at the chef's table in the kitchen with a group of friends just for the hell of it. I wasn't expecting much. Maybe that was a good thing, because I really, thoroughly enjoyed everything and the entire night was incredible.

The menu:

Oyster amuse bouche - yummy, nothing special

Dungeness crab salad with apple, celery root, and a celery sorbet - Honestly, I'm a little tired of dungeness crab salad. I think if you're going to do it, you've got to do something really special. The salad was not anything special. The celery sorbet was very nice, and I may have been more blown away by it had I not just had some at Citizen Cake the week before. All in all, a solid dish, but I was bored with it.

Spring Vegetable Salad with banyuls vinaigrette - This was very good. Asparagus, fennel root, fava beans, and other yummy stuff. All green and gorgeous. Very nice dish.

Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Sea Trout "Mi Cuit" with potato rosti, quail egg, and warm pancetta vinaigrette - This dish was incredible. My boyfriend hates most fish because it's just too fishy, but even he loved the trout. It was so lightly smoked (but fully cooked) that it looked raw and tasted perfect. The egg was a nice addition, and the warm pancetta sauce was incredible. It also played up the light smoke taste quite nicely.

Seared Day Boat Scallops with gnocchi, fava beans, hon shemiji mushrooms, and a carrot-cardamom emulsion - The dish is great, the scallops, not so much. I love scallops, but I felt these were overcooked. The gnocchi with the carrot-cardamom emulsion were fabulous, though, and I would have loved the dish had it not even included the scallops.

Liberty Farms Duck Breast with duck leg confit, rhubarb, sweet potato-vanilla bean puree, and five spice jus - BEST DUCK I'VE EVER HAD. No kidding. Best. This was absolutely incredible. Everything about it. YUM-O.

Almondwood-Grilled New York Steak, parsley root puree, green peppercorn sauce - Very good classic dish. Nothing innovative, but that's not necessary. Not a WOW dish, just a very nice course.

The dessert sampler included banana pudding, butterscotch pudding, a mint chocolate ice cream sandwich, two kinds of creme brulee, a toffee-chocolate cake, a lemon pie-type dessert, and an assortment of cookies. The only things that stand out to me are the lemon thing and the butterscotch pudding, which were very very good, and the toffee cake, which just didn't play up to everything else and kinda got lost in the midst of other desserts.

I was a little surprised that we didn't get any kind of cheese course, and there were no take away goodies. Sitting at a chef's table, I really expected that. 

Beyond the food, the experience was incredibly special. First of all, the chef's table is totally affordable! The meal above, eaten in the kitchen, with a private tour of the restaurant, the kitchens, the wine cellar, and constant conversations with the chef and the sommelier, PLUS the wine pairing with each dish, PLUS two of us got to help make the desserts - $165 per person, including tip and tax. INSANELY affordable for the experience. I strongly recommend that if you're planning on eating here anyway, you go for it and do it right.

Bonus points for the following:
Chef Mark was extremely cool and we had fun talking with him.
We REALLY loved one bottle of wine, so they let us finish the bottle.
Melanie the sommelier entertained our crazy questions and seemed to really enjoy making the wine pairings as she went along.
Service was excellent, of course.
The happy hour in the bar before dinner was also very affordable, with GREAT drinks. Try the pomerita for $5!

I'll definitely go back.
author: Monika M.

description:
Very good food, always consistent and well season.  Good wine selection.  This is a fine dining establishment.  Best cesar salad i've ever had was at One Market. 

Tends to have business type folks for lunch & dinner. Large groups are well accommodated here.  There is a busy bar area which tends to get packed during Happy Hour time period.
author: Ka C.

description:
Went here for a birthday dinner with my girlfriend.  The restaurant had a nice atmosphere and our servers were very friendly.

We both decided to go with seafood with the Ahi Tuna and Mahi Mahi.  Both were delicious!  As were the sides.

It's easy to get to, right across the street from the Embarcadero BART station.  The only downside is that I found the menu to be somewhat limited.  I would expect more options at a fine dining restaurant.
author: Dylan H.

description:
This is a pretty and comfortable place to sit - we could hear ourselves talk, which is a plus - especially when you are at a large table for six.  There were hits and misses on the menu. My vegetable ravioli with brown butter emulsion was good.  The caesar salad was on the bland side. 

My husband had the carrot soup, which was overwhelmingly anise flavored - he did not enjoy it. Also, his pork tenderloin was on a bed of awful tasting dandelion greens. I've never had a green I didn't want to eat before.   

My butterscotch pudding was not cooked properly - it had the distinct grittiness of either flour or cornstarch, which was too bad, as it was very well flavored. Maybe it was just an off night.

For the food itself I would rate it more in the 2 to 2.5 star range, but the comfort and ambiance in the restaurant nudged it up to 3 stars.
author: Carrie D.

description:
This was my first time to One Market, I went with the bf and another couple for Dine About Town. My first impression was the customer service was lacking, no one greeted us or acknowledged we cam through the doors. We found our friends and then were seated right in front of the door which was a little unpleasant considering every time the door opened a crazy gush of cold wind came through. 

We brought two bottles and put the first on the table. The Sommelier came to our table, we asked if we bought our second bottle would they waive the cork age and he said "no do not worry about it, i will waive it for you, you do not need to buy a bottle". So we thought.. wow that is pretty cool. We drank our first wine and decided to open the second since apparently it did not matter if we bought one of their wines. The Sommelier came back around and asked if "everything was okay" and blatantly looking at the wine bottle as if we did something wrong by not buying a bottle??.. which was really uncomfortable for everyone at the table 

I ordered the Cauliflower Soup which I thought was delicious, I also liked the way it was served; the bowl comes with the smoked Nantucket Bay scallops, pickled ramps, asian pears and then they pour the soup over it. For my main I chose the Grilled Bay Leaf Marinated Skirt Steak which I enjoyed. And for dessert I had the Valrhona Chocolate Souffle Cake which was actually off the second dinner option. ( my boyfriend and I traded )  Which ended up being a mistake because the Dulce de Leche Bread Pudding was AMAZING! and I never like bread pudding. I also sampled the Apple Dumplings which I liked but did not love. 

Overall I enjoyed the meal it was worth doing for DAT, However no one said goodbye thank you for coming when we left .. which to me is offensive you have like 3 people behind that desk.. the customer service is lacking.. not to mention they charged us cork age for both of our bottles.. To me that was in poor taste and rather offensive.. I don't know that I would go back mainly because customer service is important to me when I am dining out .. its not always just about the food but the entire experience.
author: Alexa V.

description:
I had dinner here last Saturday, the "Dine About Town" deluxe menu was my choice.  

Before bringing the first course, we were served very warm, green olive wheat rolls, still hot from the oven. Very good, and I would love the recipe!

I chose the Sardine Salad (I know, it sounds so gross) but it was surprisingly very very good! 

My entree was a Black Cod with Marcona Almonds.  Again, very very good!

I chose the Chocolate Souffle Cake as my dessert; it was extremely rich, with a strong hint of dark chocolate, and had a scoop of chocolate/hazelnut gelato next to some chambord? flavored and candied mandarin orange pieces, and a bit of whipped cream on top.  It was too good to ever have another, as I am POSITIVE it contained more calories than any other item they offered!

The ambiance and service was excellent, as which you would expect from a Michelin Star resturant.  The Chordonnay I was served during my salad was so good, and I need to call and get the name! 

I will definelty come here again, very soon.
author: Nikki Z.

description:
Packed w/ the expense account business crowd....and tourists.   If you are one of those two groups, you'll probably like this place.  

For the money, you can do so much better in San Francisco.  But they do have a nice location....
author: Thomas C.

description: Great place for a business lunch - food has been consistent the last few times.  Their grilled trout has been cooked to perfection every time - I'm having a hard time getting away from it.  Their beet salad is excellent as are their crab cakes.  A colleague of mine always gets the crab "louie".  Buttery mash potatoes, great brussell sprouts (with bacon) and yummy tots.
author: Ketan D.

description: Well located and inviting interior, but the menu is meat. All meat all the time. Hubby ordered the pork loin and got a PLATTER with three very large pieces of pork loin (see photos posted on yelp). It was too much food for one person let alone two yet you pay through the nose. Probably would not order the bland broccoli-flower side again. But the side of Brussel sprouts were well done with bits of tasty applewood bacon and the portion size was very generous. Service was efficient until the end, when we were ignored a bit and had to flag down the waitstaff for the check. Drinks were very clever and good- hubby had a classic Manhattan which he thoroughly enjoyed and I had the one with basil. Unique flavor but too strong for me to finish! Gave this three stars because of the menu choices and meat portion sizes. Wish Menu was more diverse- too much meat and only a one dish I could see appropriate for a vegetarian. So if you like meat, you'll have a good time here.
author: K J.

description:
I can't believe this place has one Michelin star.  I've had lunch here twice and both times I've had terrible experiences.  It might be due to the fact that both times were large group meals and perhaps catering to such a large crowd diminished the quality.  Still, I was very disappointed by my meals.

I ordered a steak medium rare and it came out purple.  Some other people at my table ordered the exact same dish in the same manner but had a differently cooked steak.  I couldn't decide what to do with my steak and I almost never send dishes back to the kitchen but my friend thought my plate definitely warranted it.  So after debating a few minutes I sent it back and about 15 minutes later, he came back with the same exact steak well done.  

It's clear that One Market has problems with providing a consistent and good dining experience. Very disappointing.
author: Christine L.

description:
I hadn't been to this restaurant for some years and I invited a friend to dinner for her birthday. While the service and food were excellent (we both chose the Prix Fix Market Menu with wine parings), there were a couple of awkward moments which should not have occurred at a restaurant of this caliber: 

I arrived before my guest for a 7:00 PM reservation on a recent Saturday evening and I was assigned what I considered to be an undesirable table next to a serving station. Since there were other tables available, I promptly requested a different table and my request was accommodated efficiently but not necessarily graciously.

When I made the reservation I mentioned that I had a gift certificate I would like to use that I had been awarded at a benefit auction. I was informed that I should present it to the server, however, when I did so, she passed it over to a maitre d' and, instead of being discrete about it, in front of me they proceeded to have a discussion about how to handle it  and apply it to the check, the expiraton date (next year), etc.,  which I found rather embarrassing. Fortunately my guest hadn't yet arrived to witness this encounter.

Finally, we were not offered any extra bread after I had finished mine with the soup course.

Personally, I prefer smaller restaurants, especially for dinner, but I think this restaurant is ideal for lunch.
author: sf k.

description:
I don't know why it took us so long to go to One Market and now that we've had the experience we will be back. 

Complimentary amuse bouche was a potato soup...yummy.

We started with the smoked trout on a potato rosti with a poached egg and panchetta sauce...OMFG! Our server told us she could eat this every day for breakfast and we could not agree more. I have never eaten a poached egg and I was lapping this one up like a kitten. Simply amazing...all components working in unison perfectly and culminating in a taste bud explosion.

We had the bacon wrapped pork loin and a special which was a grilled wild Alaskan salmon with avocado mousse.  Both were delicious but the salmon was breath taking...cooked perfectly, well seasoned and that mousse was out of this world.  

As for sides we had the baby carrots and mashed potatoes. The mashed potatoes were okay (we wouldn't necessarily order them again) but the baby carrots were addicting! I am sure they were bathed in butter and sprinkled with crack because we could not stop eating them...carrots (really?) that good??? YES. 

Despite full bellies we could not NOT order a desert. We picked the chocolate toffee crunch cake from the "smaller items."  First of all it was much bigger than we expected, certainly plenty for two to share after our earlier binge. It was tasty...and we ate it all. 

Service was good. 

Michelin starred for a reason.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
Dined here in December 2010 and otherwise on a couple of other occasions in 2010 for business.  Overall I think they are trying too hard and dishes lack consistency.

Specifics from the December 2010 visit follow.

The good in rel the food:

Hand picked dungeness crab appetizer was tender, succulent, generous, and garnished beautifully (both visually and flavor-wise) with hearts of palm and citrus.

Shaved beef tongue salad appetizer was an amazing blend of fresh lettuce/cabbage/slaw with a light horseradish cream and nice, tender, briny tongue.

Side of brussels sprouts was excellent.  Good caramelization.

Other times I have been here I enjoyed grilled octopus (the most tender ever) and the raw oysters.

The not-so-good in rel the food:

Foie gras appetizer with mushrooms would have been good if it had not been doused with bonito broth.  The broth diluted the flavor of the foie gras and ruined any caramelizing that might have been achieved.

Entree of sole with sauteed kale, trumpet mushrooms, and butternut squash puree was gorgeous in its presentation but boring.  The kale was the best part of the dish (and it was very good).  The sole was bland, albeit tender and moist.  The mushrooms had nice flavor but were a little too salty, the butternut squash puree was bland.  Finally, the sauce tasted like almost burnt caramel and was unpleasantly sweet.

The good in rel location:
author: Rachel E.

description:
One Market is an excellent restaurant that I have been to many times.  It has good food and excellent desserts.  At its best, it truly deserves the one Michelin star that it has.  

However, it could use some better consistency in their main courses and their service.  A few times, my fish or meat have been a little overcooked.  This is somewhat acceptable since the flavors are usually nice.  Service can be iffy sometimes if they get busy with crowds or groups.  This is why I'm only giving 3 stars.  

I would suggest getting reservations beforehand which isn't typically hard to do a few days in advance.  If you are in the North Bay, I actually like their sister restaurant, the Tavern at Lark Creek better.  It has similar food, a simpler menu, and generally better consistency.
author: Channing W.

description:
The food was very good.  I really, really enjoyed mine, but a couple people around the table weren't blown away.  I think it was more from their experimenting with a new entree rather than the food actually not being good.  Sort of a personal preference situation.  
We were seated at a large table by the two open kitchens and it was great.  I love watching open kitchens, but sometimes they can be loud.  I didn't notice that here.  Wonderful ambiance, great waitstaff, beautiful presentation, perfectly prepared meats and seafood, and desserts to die for.  You won't be disappointed.  
I can't speak about the prices as it was a business dinner, but I do know I am glad I wasn't paying for it!!
author: Katy H.

description:
Bradley Odgen (Lark Creek family of restaurants) opened One Market back in 1993. Seventeen years later it's still going strong with a Michelin star under its toque. I'd been a few years ago and left unimpressed but with its bloodlines I felt a second look at the was in order...especially since I dine several times a year at Lark Creek Steak.

A Tuesday night gave us a little breathing room to get a good table. After a Belvedere martini at the bar we were shown our table. Not too crowded at 6:30 (almost unconscionably early for dinner for me), the service was almost as attentive as I might have expected. The waitstaff was fine and everything was well delivered though perhaps a bit impersonally. We ordered right away.

I started with Geoduck Clam "Chowder" with herbed crème fraîche, celery, and house-cured pancetta. As you often see at good restaurants, the ingredients are offered the broth of the soup at the table giving the diner a chance to see the ingredients before mixing while keeping them from being overcooked. It worked well. The clams were fresh and tasted like clams. They kept their texture and weren't rubbery as when they're overcooked. The dish was very good. Perhaps a bit less crème fraîche might have kept the dish a bit hotter but it was creamy and good. 

For the main course I ordered the Roasted Liberty Farms Duck Breast
and duck leg confit with saffron, anson mills polenta, and cocoa reduction.  The breast was particularly fatty which meant lots of flavor but the ratio of fat to meat meant a less than satisfying entree. The confit and accompanying polenta were very good. A 2007 Freeman Pinot was good.

Dessert was Bradley's Butterscotch Pudding with Chantilly cream, and a pecan wedding cookie. It was lovely though perhaps a bit small in portion size.

I should mention that I ordered the three-course Market Menu. At $39 it was really quite a good value.

Overall, I enjoyed the meal but it all felt a bit perfunctory.  The value was good. Somehow I was hoping for just a bit more spark...a more personalized experience perhaps?

3.75 stars.
author: Gary C.

description:
Came here for a quick appetizer and drink at the bar area. Their dungeness crab taco appetizers are simply amazing, and they had a good selection of beers on tap as well....including one of my favorites, Bear Republic IPA. Wasn't a huge fan of the potato tots though, but they weren't awful either. The view and location of One Market are fantastic, and we had very friendly service at the bar area with knowledgeable bartenders. 

I would definitely go back for dinner the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Al G.

description: The restaurant is nicely appointed and the wait staff was excellent. The food, however, was mediocre. I had a green salad that had no flavor, could have been dressed with water. My wife had a Caesar salad that was also uninspired. Our entrees, day-boat scallops and halibut, were decent but not great. We had a fine time, but it's an expensive place so we expected better.
author: Daniel B.

description:
My mouth was salivating in anticipation for lunch yesterday at One Market, however, I am finding it difficult to understand how in the world this restaurant received a Michelin star!  I have dined at Le Chanteclar, in Nice; Michel Rostang, Paris; and Lorenz Adlon, Berlin.  My experience at One Market was less than stellar.

For my first course  I had the Heirloom and Melon Gazpacho.  I believe the chef dumped the salt pig in the Gazpacho!  Needless to say I sent it back, but unfortunately the damage was already done.  I then asked for the field green salad with the mustard vinaigrette, ON THE SIDE, just in case, and it arrived drenched in mustard vinaigrette, again so salty I could hardly eat it, but did because I was famished by this time.  I have to say my fish was unremarkable, so much so I cannot even tell you what it was.

I am giving One Market two stars, for three reasons:  1) the blueberry cheese cake was FABULOUS (incredible pastry chef); 2) the waiter was very nice, apologetic and understanding; and 3) every restaurant has a bad day, so maybe this just wasn't their day.

I have to say I would try it again.
author: Maureen R.

description: Solid, but spendy.  Great for business meals, but not for casual grubbin' with homeys.
author: Kevin C.

description: Perfect for a business lunch.  Easy to have a conversation.  Very attentive but unobtrusive service.  Food well prepared, but pretty standard.  Don't be fooled by the "trout", its really salmon.
author: Howard B.

description:
We've been here twice now and we really enjoy it.  Definitely a treat for us, as really nice dinners are few and far between and need a good reason.  This last time was because my husband's brother and his wife were visiting.  The service and wines were very good, as was most of our meal.  Three of us opted for the tasting menu with the weekly beast.  Goat seemed like an interesting idea, though none of us had tried it before.  We enjoyed most of the courses, but the goat chop was chewy and didn't sit well with us.  Other than that, everyone had a fabulous time and the service was great.  My husband hates bothering management if not necessary, and didn't want to complain about the goat chop.

Definitely a place I would recommend for dinner for a really nice night out.  And reservations are a very good idea.
author: Libbi J.

description: Great place for a business lunch - especially with the business lunch menu. Had Rabbit Terrine & the Pork Chop - beautiful presentation, great food, & great service.
author: Johnson H.

description:
We went to One Market last weekend. My hubby wound up getting tempted by the "weekly beast" (it was rabbit) and decided to skip the DAT dinner, while I got the "deluxe" version of DAT for an extra 10 bucks.

I had the cauliflower soup as the appetizer. The portion wasn't huge (almost the same size as one of my hubby's 5 courses), but I thought it was enough for soup. The duck entree was much larger, it came with three large slices of duck breast plus some duck confit. I thought it was very tasty and definitely worth the extra $10. The chocolate cake was really good too, it was more like a flourless chocolate cake instead of a lava cake, which I prefer anyway.

Since the hubby had the 5-course while I got a 3-course , I also ordered a cheese course, since at first I wanted an extra course to even things out a bit. I think it wound up being a bit unecessary though since my entree about the same size as his 2 courses. We only ordered two cheeses, but they sure gave us a lot of bread, grapes, and marcona almonds to go with it. I was already stuffed before we even had dessert.

The wine pairings were $20 for the 5-course (4 wines) and $13 for the 3-course (2 wines), and the pours were extremely generous. My hubby had around half a glass for each pairing and I had almost a full glass for my first course and a full glass for my main. If more restaurants offered pairings these affordable I wouldn't ever bother bringing my own wines.

We were initially going to go because of the DAT deal, but I was pleasantly surprised that their menu and wine pairings are very affordable for a 1-Michelin star restaurant. I would probably go back even without the DAT deal. The weekly beast is definitely a bargain at $50, and I would like to try it especially they have duck or pig on the menu. 

While nothing blew me away, I thought this place was an excellent value for DAT and their other prix-fixe options.
author: Arlene M.

description:
We came here for the Weekly Beast last Saturday, and it was terrific!  A five course meal, featuring lamb this week, for $49.  The courses were all delicious, and we were surprised by how much we liked the "unusual" lamb parts -- very flavorful!  The $20 wine pairing nicely complimented the courses. 

The service and atmosphere were first class, as expected.  This really is an amazing deal for a dining experience of this level.  We'll be back soon...maybe for the duck "Weekly Beast"?
author: John R.

description:
I would not recommend this restaurant to any of my friends or family not because of the food but because of the abysmal service. 

I went with my husband, his mother, aunt , and grandmother. We were seated at a round table. We ordered wine and one of the glasses came with a huge lipstick stain on the rim. I pointed it out to the waitress and as she went to pick it up she dropped my full glass of red wine, which broke. The wine went all over my arm, leg, and chair and there was broken glass all over the floor. They handed me a towel to wipe things up and didn't completely wipe up the wine nor the glass on the floor. They pushed my husband and my chairs far apart around the spill/stain and then put a napkin over the large stain on the table instead of changing the table linen. I had to clean the chair myself, which was dripping. I had to sit through the rest of dinner about 3 feet away from my husband and totally uncomfortable with a wet arm and leg. 

The worst part is they offered no concession, no discount, nothing, even though we had nearly a 400 dollar bill. The manager gave me his card and said to send him the dry cleaning bill. Well, the sweater was ruined, as the stains didn't come out with the dry cleaner. 

I was at Pakwan , a divey Pakistani restaurant, a few days later. The guy sitting next to me accidentally exploded green chutney and it sprayed my white pants. He felt so bad he paid for half of our dinner, even though I insisted it was OK. He handled the situation better than One Market!!!
author: Tania T.

description: Perception is a funny thing.  It's weird how having a Michelin star almost works against them, because this place doesn't really warrant a star.  So if you come here expecting a Michelin restaurant, you will be sorely disappointed.  Without that expectation, though, this place is four stars.
author: Erika C.

description: Went to One Market Restaurant for Thanksgiving dinner.  Food was ok, Service was poor ,   One thing I really didn't like was they had a "MANDITORY  18% GRATUITY"  for a party of two ,added to the total bill.  Maybe, because the wait staff knows this, the service is so poor.  I will not go back.
author: Jerry H.

description:
I'm surprised this place has a Michelin star.  The food was very ordinary, and the prices are pretty steep if you are not here on the company dime.  

On the plus side, they did save our table for a while even though our party arrived late.
author: Chris L.

description:
This was yet another one of those business-related dinner where I was enticed to have it here via the slick advert on the tele in my hotel room. As usual, I arrived late and a bit flustered due to almost having ran the valet over when my too-high-heel slipped off the brake. Oops, lucky for him he's quick on his toes otherwise he would have lost it to my rental. 

Anyway, I needed a stiff drink or two and the cocktail and wine list easily sufficed here. Each of us had a starter and surprise, surprise, I ordered the seared Fois Gras - ah, such the predictable creature of habit am I. Two of our party ordered the Yukon Gold Potato soup to start and yes, I did experienced the rare Appetizer Envy. A bowl was set in front of them that contained a dollop of creme fresh with lovely bits of bacon sprinkled on top. Then server the slowly poured a steaming stream of potato goodness all around it. It was a decadent display that made me make a mental note of "Next time." 

One of my dining habits, aside from ordering what no one else would, is to always try the chef or house special. I am rarely, rarely disappointed and, unfortunately, that night I was. One Market boasts a daily roast and Wednesday's roast was a Mishima Ranch "Wagyu" Top Round with natural jus. You eat with your eyes first and the first thing I wanted to do was close my eyes. The muddy burgandy color, albeit, medium rare red, was not at all appetizing. The taste was less than par and this cut of meat would have been better served on toasted a toasted pretzel bread, with a horseradish spread and caramelized red onions.. just a suggestion. 

Having graduated to Entree Envy, I looked across the table at my colleague who was thoroughly enjoying his duck breast.  Damn him.  Forget about the special, trust your first gut instinct and order that.  

On to dessert, at this point, my dining experience was going down in flames and the final fireball came with the mint ice cream sandwich.  The chocolate cookie part of it was fine, it was the overpowering basil flavor of the home-made ice cream that sent me over.  The mint was near or non-existent.

Everyone else in the party enjoyed their meal - good for them.  Picky me, well, it wasn't my night, but I lucky us, there are hundreds of restaurants yet to be Yelped.
author: Jenny D.

description: The bar staff was more attentive than our waiter when we were seated in the dining room. I admit the food was good, and I have to give a three star, because the food came out so slow. It could've been a bad night, but our waiter never came to give us an explanation nor did he check up on us. Our appetizer came out about 25 minutes later accompanied by our main course at the same time... we weren't too thrilled. Even the table adjacent to us complained about slow service, and their food was cold. I would give it a second chance, but would not be returning anytime soon.
author: Minette C.

description:
I've eaten here twice in the past year.  The first time it was the chef's tasting menu and sandwiched between Manresa and Gary Danko.  Suffice to say it was inferior compared to the others and I was jaded.  

The second time, was a week ago and wow, it was amazing.  I had really forgotten how good it was.  There is a little more creativeness with the food and presentation that I had forgotten that really has pushed this place further up on my list of places to eat at.

I ordered the Hand-picked Dungeness Crab and it was excellent.  What makes it interesting is the green-apple water that the crab is presented in.  It is almost a water jelly and the textures are very unique.  My sister didn't like it at all; however, I loved it.  A very unique dish in the presentation.  Pretty impressed on an otherwise simple dish.

As for the main course, I had the Ono, which was cooked sous-vide, and it was delicious.  However, again, its presented in a unique way that suggests more of an artistic flare. 

My girlfriend had the Thursday night daily roast.  Which is the roasted filet that is wrapped in pancetta.  Amazingly good and a lot bigger than the waiter suggested.  I think he said 8oz and its more like 10oz.  Really big and incredibly good with the pancetta. 

Overall, I can't complain.  More realistically, I'd give this place a 4.5 stars but I can't.  Its worthy of that one star.  May not be the 5-star like Manresa and Gary Danko, but I'm splitting hairs here.
author: Mark K.

description:
Brilliant.  Really.  Just brilliant.

I have been to One Market many times over the years since the mid-1990s, and they were always quite good and reliable -- 3-3.5 stars easy.  However, I hadn't been back since they surprisingly were awarded one Michelin Star.  I couldn't believe it.  Was this the same old but reliable One Market?  A year passed since their first star and then out came the Michelin ratings.  One Market hadn't fallen off.  Really?  Time to go back, since I seem to have hit every One Star restaurant in the City but the one that is closest to work.

So I finally went there for lunch.  I did the Dine About Town menu, figuring it was a good bet:  Market Salad, Duck Confit in red wine risotto, Chocolate and Butterscotch pudding

Impressive.  The flavors popped.  The Duck confit was soft and the risotto practically melted in my mouth.  And the butterscotch pudding?  WOAH!   (Nuff said.)

One Market is certainly deserving of its One Star.  And deserving of 5 stars here.
author: Marc E.

description:
I went to the One Market whole beast dinner Friday night.

First let me start by saying WORST dinner I've eaten in the city in 10 years!
Let's start with the offerings! Mind you this is a Whole beast dinner! 

A country pate- It came looking pleasant, however, after the first bite I turned to my friend and quietly said it tasted like dog food. If you're going to say country pate, let's have some of that lovely coarse texture and some flavor of duck! The brioche served with it made the mushy paste seem worse due to its Wonder bread softness. 

Duck risotto- First impression of the plate - The dishwasher threw up in a bowl and they served it to me! 
If the look of it wasn't bad enough, it tasted like nothing, the rice, if it was rice in the thing, was so soft it was no longer definable as rice. All topped with a parmesan foam, FOAM, yeah well I could go on a rant about foam in risotto so I'll leave it at the fact that we both had 2 bits and informed the waitress it was inedible!  

Duck breast- Cooked perfect! Too bad the chef decided it was a good idea to put pure Tahini on the plate, ok so eat around it. The freekin waiter drops the plate and tells us that there is Kombucha squash on the plate and walks away. I say to myself well at least the duck and squash will be a good. Yeah, NO, the squash, get this, the squash is actually cantaloupe! Yes, it actually said it on the menu, too, not Kombucha Squash.

Thankfully, the dessert was fine, just fine
. 
For a whole beast meal it lacked the whole beast and any creativity on the chef's part. I don't know, maybe the chef was out smoozing the tables and not back in the kitchen making sure some quality came out.
 If you're going to offer such a tantalizing thing as a whole duck then don't feed me a shitty tourist meal you're trying to make a few extra bucks on the turn. 

This is still San Francisco and people come here to eat!
author: Jabir P.

description: Food was good after I sent back my rare pork. Service was only ok. But after my pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon came back it was amazing! Salmon was only ok. Rabbit stuffed with pork was great. Appetizers were also good. Over all good experience. Would maybe go back.
author: Jason S.

description:
I was underwhelmed by the food here on a recent visit, but the main reason i won't be back is that i read in the WSJ recently that One Market has been ripping off their employees.  They added a surcharge to bills called  "Healthy SF"  that they claimed was earmarked for employee health care.  Instead, they pocketed most of that add-on fee for themselves.

 That kind of dishonesty does not deserve my business.
author: Troy B.

description:
ahhh happy hour that goes until 9. i tried two drinks and they were both delicious - some drink with cucumber and kiwi and another with grapefruit and elderflower?  $5 each i think. so good.

when we came in, the bar area was mostly empty tables.  uncleaned at that.  there was only one waitress manning that area and it was tough for her to get everyone.  

i always make the mistake of ordering chickpea fries.  the last time i was at urban tavern i discovered that in my mind i had on idea of what chickpea fries were and then there was that disgusting, yucky version that everyone else has, inclu one market and urban tavern.  mochica has these lightly breaded garbonzo beans that i think are chickpea fries.  but they are not.  booo.  we also had crab tacos.  pretty good.
author: claudia y.

description: This place is nice on a really nice day.  You can sit here with a cocktail and watch all the people running along the wharf and tourists checking out the ferry building.  Food here is mediocre.  We had padron peppers (which is the best thing), sliders, tuna bruschetta (tuna fish on toasted bread...boring).  Nothing else on the snack menu looked unique or appetizing.  I think the dinner men is much better.  But if you wanna sit and enjoy nice weather and have a cocktail this is a nice place.  Plus I think they need more servers because it was always hard to find ours.
author: Gina S.

description:
I was kind of disappointed.  I expected more out of a one star restaurant.  The appetizers were good, but the main course were disappointing.  
1. Cauliflower soup:  nice and light, but lack of cauliflower flavor
2. Grill Octopus:  The octopus were cooked and then grilled.  The texture was a bit weird.  
3. Ravioli:  way too salty; I cannot taste anything else 
4. Duck Breast:  it was ok
Overall the food was too salty.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I went here for Dine About Town lunch with my co-worker. First of all, they have amazing warm bread! Some of the best table bread I have ever had. LOVED it! I ordered off the DAT menu: farmers market salad and dock confit. The salad was light and refreshing, a good start but nothing special. The duck confit was delicious! Not too heavy (even with a bowl of risotto), lots of great flavors, interesting texture. My co-worker ordered the Cobb salad. When it arrived we were both a little confused. It appeared to be a couple pieces of lettuce, some avocado slices, bacon and poached quail eggs on top of something that resembled a pita or flat bread. Turns out it was thinly pounded boneless, skinless chicken breast under the salad! Very well seasoned, the chicken alone encompassed all flavors that go into a Cobb salad. It was a very unique presentation on a classic favorite.

The only bad thing about the meal was that our server was kind of all over the place, and she took a very long time to bring our entrees. Other than that, she was very nice and polite - probably just a little busy during the lunch hour.

If you can afford it without the Dine About Town menu, I definitely recommend it for a date, small group, or business lunch.
author: Kelsey M.

description: $50 (no booze, just food) for a lunch that was so over salted it literally made me gag, and a waiter who was so rude it would've been funny... If I wasn't paying $50 for a meal I couldn't take more than a few bites of. The owners of One Market should be embarrassed at how bad their food and service is.
author: Susan V.

description:
mm, i don't see what the fuss is about with why people are hating on this restaurant.  it's so close to home and work, that it became one of those restaurants you kind of take for granted because of the convenience.  in fact, the location is so good, that it's hard to expect a restaurant like this to have great food, considering how much i've heard people bash it, saying it doesn't deserve its michelin star.  i'd easily pick one market over boulevard (1 block away) if i had to choose between restaurants any day of the week.

now that that's out of the way, my awesome girlfriend, knowing i've been curious about one market for quite some time, surprised me with reservations here for dinner one night.  i honestly didn't have high expectations, given everything i said earlier, but part of me also hoped that it'd be really really good....Alexander's good.  unfortunately, not a lot of places can get close to Alexander's, but that's not to say that one market isn't clearly above a lot of the rest.

i'm a tad late on this review, so i can't remember everything i had, but i can tell you that the duck breast is simply awesome.  a perfectly cooked medium rare duck breast with foie gras sausage, sitting on top of an earl grey jus just blew me away with how everything came together so well.  

my suggestion would be to come here open minded and hungry....and order things around one of the best ducks that you'll ever eat.
author: Jeff N.

description: I've never had a bad meal here, not even a so-so one.  Everything on the menu hits the spot and whether you're looking for a good happy hour spot, a place to take a friend or client for lunch or dinner, or a nice place for dessert, One Market will likely be a suitable choice.  Everything from the decor, ambiance, service, speed are where they should be.  The food, moreover, is exquisite and they change the menu constantly.
author: Angel S.

description:
My friend L was in town. It also happened to be Dine About Town week so we headed to One Market and had ourselves a lovely little dinner. We each had a yummy three course meal and a few glasses of wine each to boot. 
I really enjoyed my braised short ribs. I think I'm simply a sucker for braised short ribs done right. But I mean, who isn't right?
Dessert wasn't exceptional but service and the atmosphere both were.
author: rachel b.

description: You cant' missed this restaurant if u come to SFO . It was the best steak , and it is still the one . Perhaps I come on busy night and without reservation so it's not a surprised to be 45 mins for table. But its worth every bite.
author: Vivi R.

description: I love this restaurant! The food was beautifully prepared and delicious. The hand picked dungeness crab-green papaya salad and the beef cheeks were fantastic! Our service from Jessie was extremely attentive and gracious. He made us feel extra special for our anniversary as well. Definitely coming back!
author: Eric P.

description:
Went for a business dinner on Friday night with my wife, my boss and his wife. The atmosphere and location are excellent. The service was reasonably attentive, and the drinks were tasty. The Amuse Bouche of tuna with wasabe was pretty good...a bit fishy, but again, pretty good. 

We went there because my boss' wife wanted "american" food, and i could not get a reservation at Town Hall for a reasonable time. I should have dropped a $20 on the reservationist at TH...the two restaurants are in seperate leagues. For the money, One Market is no where near the quality it should be. For that matter, the Lark Creek Group, is no where near the quality it once was. 

The appetizers around the table were OK...but just ok. My fennel soup was salty, not much crab, and generally uninspired. The crab salad my boss had was much more of science project with gelatin cubes and jalapeno sorbet than crab. The foie gras my wife ordered was delicious....and my boss' wife's salad was, well, a salad!

As for the main courses, the two men had lamb shank. Dry, rubbery, salty, on a bed of very salty lentils. My wife's pasta was thicker than Pasta Pamadoro. Once again, my boss' wife chose well...she had the black cod, which looked delish. We shared a few sides, brussel sprouts, spinach, and chick pea fries. All were better than the main courses....

As for dessert, this course was the highlight. We had to order a second butterscotch pudding it was so good. The choc souffle was also incredible.

I feel slightly guilty giving such a low star rating, HOWEVER, SF is a foodie town, and if we are being honest, One Market did not live up to its reputation nor the cost of the meal.  Two stars means "Meh, I've experienced better". That is definitely the case. It should also take into account the $75-100 per person cost. One Market is categorized as a top quality SF restaurant. It is not. If you have 1) a discerning palette, 2) experienced top quality restaurants here or elsewhere, and are 3) honest with yourself about your culinary experiences, this is not a place deserving of its accolades. As I booked it for my boss, I wish I could have been writing a different review right now....but sadly, no. I will not be returning....at least on my own dime.

PS - The waitress was cute, though!
author: Brian B.

description: Great for business lunch. Had homemade squash risotto and Brussel sprouts.  Very good and our waiter was very helpful with recommendations. Nice atmosphere in booth seating.
author: Robin F.

description:
I had a lunch in the bar area with a friend of mine. I had a "business lunch" with lobster bisque and a breaded catfish dish.

The bisque was good, but perhaps a bit too salty. The catfish was Southwest-style, with guacamole and surrounded by salsa. Not bad at all. The complimentary bread was warm and delicious. There is a good wine selection, with a few wines on tap. Service was good, as expected from a Michelin-star restaurant, but on the slow side (as far as bringing out food). Prices are very reasonable, given the Michelin star and location.

What surprised me was my friend's steak. He claimed it was well-prepared, but it seemed very "plain" to me. The presentation wasn't very interesting, and it didn't come in an interesting sauce or anything like that. In my opinion, that's not very Michelin-star-restaurant-like.

While I wasn't disappointed with anything, I think that there are a couple of better options for a pricy, Michelin-star lunch downtown: Michael Mina and Campton Place Restaurant.
author: Paul K.

description:
Good for some dishes, just ok for others.

Appetizer- 

Smoked Tasmanian Trout with Organic egg, Pancetta Vinaigrette, and a crispy potato cake- This was SO SO good, the best part of the meal in my opinion--crispy potato cake (kind of like a gourmet hash brown) topped with a delicious smoked trout (tasted like a smoked samon or sashimi almost) and a yummy egg yolk which you break open and mix into the rest of the dish. It was so good..we were licking our spoons and mopped up any egg yolk-sauce on the plate with the nice crunchy rolls they give you when you arrive. The Pancetta Vinaigrette was amazing alone- pancetta bits, olive oil, chives..maybe some bits of caramelized onion..heaven!

Entrees:

Berkshire pork- a few big slices of brined pork served on top of mash and sauteed spinach--nothing special about this dish and the pork was kind of tough and dry. It almost tasted like a ham, which is fine but not as an entree for me! The mash and spinach were also very mediocre.

Wild Mushroom Pot Pie- Super flaky crust, almost like a croissant..buttery and delicious! The creamy mushroom filling (porcinis mostly) was good, and had nice cruncy pistachios in it..but was lacking something. Pretty good dish though I wouldn't recommend ordering it as an entree unless you really love rich, heavy food. 

The Service was pretty good but a little slow at times and it wasn't particularly nice, just standard good service.

Altogether, it's a pretty good restaurant, but only one dish really stood out to me (the trout appetizer) and the rest were good but not fantastic. Service is the same.
author: amy k.

description: Amazing food! Phil was a lot of fun and made our dining experience extra special;)
author: Natalie K.

description:
This review is for happy hour only. 

HH starts at 4:30, yet when I arrived at 4:30, many of the tables at the bar were already filled with people. This is not a place to come for happy hour deals. The atmosphere and the crowd are very similar to Americano's. They had a couple of cocktail specials and wine specials at $5. We ordered sliders, duck spring rolls, and calamari. I think each cost 9 or 10 bucks. I do have to admit that the food tasted fantastic. I am actually still dreaming about those duck spring rolls . . . Yum . . .

There was only one server for the entire bar area which was increasingly getting crowded between 4:30 and 5:30. She tried her best to be nice, but she seemed very overworked, stressed, and tired. Poor lady . . .

I can see how this place can be nice for expense account lunches. The location is convenient and the place seems swanky. However, this is not my cup of tea. The place lacked a certain fun factor that I want at my Friday happy hour joints.
author: Su K.

description:
This is one of the most beatuiful restauarants in SF.  When we walked in, we got a great table by the window where we could watch all the action on the street.

When we sat down, we had to quickly order our food as we were headed to a meeting after our meal. 

We ordered the rib-eye steak, duck breast and the Burger w/fries.  The duck breat was crispy and tasted amazing.  The rib eye steak was prepared perfectly and the Burger was super tasty and very rich.  

We wanted to order desert.....but our time had run out.....next time we will take out time end enjoy this wonderful restaurant.

Great ambience and service and view of Market Street and the Embarcadero.

A well deserved Michelin Star Restaurant!
author: Raider J.

description:
We came here twice in one week. I would give the food 5 star, it's really delicious. Second time, I took a family friend that was visiting from China. The food I had at Ritz Carlton in Shanghai was terrible, so I had to show him a really good place. Everything we ordered was wonderful, fresh ingredient paired with perfect cooking is everything you need in a good dish.

The staff was great, too.The general manager checked in with us, which I really didn't expect. The only thing is, even though they are really nice, we waited a while to be seated both times and the waitress forgot to answer our questions when she had to check in with the kitchen. it seems that they are just really busy.
author: Cicie W.

description:
I've been here a few times (lunch, dinner and Dine About Town dinner) and just haven't been wowed any time.  The food has been good but service wasn't that attentive any time and I expect more when the prices are high.  

I was very disappointed with the Dine About Town meal.  I just felt that we weren't getting the full display of talent from the chef.

I'm cautious on giving 3 stars but the experiences just haven't been 4 star.
author: Jason N.

description:
I think a good deal of the low rating is due to people hating trendy or superpopular places.

I went here about dine about town, therefore my evaluation of the value might be different from others.

I will say that considering how labor intensive the meals were (especially the pea emulsion homemade ravioli), I would expect them to taste amazing, but if I were just to evaluate taste regardless of labor, it is still very good.

The pea soup (plated tableside) was also very delicious, especially the egg (although I don't think it's unreasonable in San Francisco for waiters to know where the food is sourced from). Dessert was a little on the doughy side.

With so much competition, I don't imagine going back here again, but I don't regret going there, and had a good meal.

Not deserving of a Michelin star, however.
author: Mark A.

description:
Overall: A
One of the best dining experiences I've ever had... period. Ranks right up there with other Michelin starred restaurants. 

Food: A
Great textures, aromas and flavors. Chef's tasting menu w/wine pairing covers the gamut of gastronomy. 

Service: A
Mikki our server answered every nerdy ass wine question I threw at her. As I got more drunk throughout the night, she never got annoyed having to repeat the food presentation.

Decor: A
They sat us at the same table that we sat at last year. Elegant place. Great for a power lunch or a late romantic evening.

Value: A
With our bill coming out at over 3 bills it's hard to say this place is a great deal but I rarely say I've just eaten one of the best meals I've ever had.
author: Roger H.

description:
Cost/person to do it right: $40

I recently went here for the first time and was pleasantly surprised.  Based on the excessive in-hotel advertising and the location, I expected sub-par food for West Bay prices.  What I actually got was pretty good food for reasonable prices.  I ducked in with two people and no reservation on a Thursday night ~8p and was seated within five minutes.  The service was very good, and generally knowledgeable about the menu and food pairings.  I ended up ordering a Grilled Ahi Steak, and getting forkfuls of scallops/cuttlefish and bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin from my guests.  In retrospect, I should have ordered the scallops, which are hard to get just right, but One Market had done it quite well.  

While the Ahi was good, but I can easily say I've had better for less more than once.  Also, I'll have to go back and confirm, but I think that the prices here are a bit high for the food.  However, given the location, they're about spot on.  On the location note, it is quite ferry/BART accessible, which is always a plus.

Verdict: Beats most of what I've eaten on Embarcadero, but not worth the trip if you're not willing to lay down a bit of money.
author: Troy M.

description:
Ambiance: delightful and fancy filled with a lot of business- men and woman
Service: friendly and helpful with deciding what to get
Decor: Dim lighting, fancy, tall ceilings, comfortable cushioned seats

A group of us came here for dinner for their Dine About Town Menu back in the beginning of the year.  I walked in to find the place was filled with a lot of business-men in their suits, who have probably just gotten off of work in the financial district.  It seemed to be the spot for business parties and older folks.  I thought the waiter would discriminate my party because we a bit younger than everyone else who seemed to be there. (Our group consisted of grad school students and newly college graduates) Despite the fact of our age, the waiter was very friendly and helpful while serving us.

Everything that was served at our table was very well presented and from what I can recall, the food was quite tasty. What I remembered most about this place were their desserts.  The five of us chose 5 different desserts, all of which were recommended by our waiter.  The desserts were so beautifully presented and it definitely tasted just as good as it looked.  I was very skeptical about their Orange Creamsicle Soda dessert which consisted of tahitian vanilla ice cream and scottish shortbread.  To my surprise, it was my favorite dessert out of the 5.  We also had the butterscotch pudding, chocolate toffee almond crunch cake, blueberry crumb pie and mint chocolate ice cream sandwich.  IT WAS ALL SO TASTY!!!!
author: Sarah F.

description:
Kind of mediocre for the setting and the prices. The happy hour isn't too bad for the wine and Margarita but the food is so-so.

The location of course is wonderful and right around many businesses so the happy hour is a great pull.
author: Brian R.

description: This is my go to restaurant for business lunches.  The food is outstanding, literally I have enjoyed every dish I have ordered (and I dine there at least once a week).  The menu changes seasonally, the food is as fresh and perfectly prepared.  Service is knowledgeable and wonderfuilly attentive.
author: Sara A.

description:
Last meal was so-so. Knocking them down a star.

--------------------------------Love it! Been here four times over the past six years and was never disappointed. Last visit in May for lunch the char-grilled trout was unbelievable!
author: Wing C.

description:
As I write this, I realize that I've never actually had a proper entree at this place - I always end up with an app and salad or like this past time, soup and salad.  Their caesar is good, but be warned that if you're the type who likes their salad chopped, you'll have to man up and use your knife on this one.  A little extra work but totally worth it.  They'll also add chicken or shrimp if you request it.  

Back to the soup.  As I mentioned, on my most recent visit, I had soup with my caesar.  I went with the cauliflower soup with smoked scallops and it was wonderful!  The presentation is lovely, if not a little over the top (they bring the bowl with the scallops, ramps, etc and then pour the soup in at the table for a big ta-da).  Flavorful and creamy goodness.

I wasn't really going to go for dessert but those I was dining with spotted the butterscotch pudding on the menu and decided to order it to share.  This was sublime!!!!  Even if you're full, just do it.  You won't be sorry.

Service is good and the food is tasty.  Good for a power lunch but a little pricey for an everyday spot.
author: Carrie L.

description: Chickpea fried and savory donuts with bacon dipping butter are amazing.  Tuna burger was fine but lacked a little flavor in my opinion.  Service was friendly and professional.
author: Kevin M.

description:
The bread is delicious--had olive bread, it was warm and so soft. 

Drink: had the lemon drop. Not that great, especially for it being $10. A little too strong for me. More alcohol than I expected. 

Entree: Bacon-wrapped Pork Tenderloin
dandelion "persillade", salsify, natural jus. It was reasonably priced and oh so good! Cooked perfectly--nice, tender, juicy, and the right amount of salt.
*My mom had the ravioli and it was delicious as well. You can tell that it was made from scratch and it just had that "home/love/TLC" feeling to it. 

Sides: Mashed potatoes and spinach. Great. No complaints here!

Dessert: Carmelized Banana Chocolate Tart
Best banana chocolate combo dessert I ever had. 

Great food!
author: Victoria B.

description:
I went to One Market for a birthday dinner, but it also happened to be Dine About Town.  Of all the Dine About Town places that I have tried in the past (Tommy Toy's, Big 4, Cassis, etc) I have to say that One Market might be one of the best ones for your buck.

The problem with other places is that (as Vicky L. pointed out) they "dumb down" the menu.  Instead of the other delicious sounding choices, you get choices that are ... well... what you pay for.  With One Market, I was really impressed with their asparagus soup (perfectly seasoned with a poached egg and bacon).  Although the Halibut Cheeks weren't anything to make me squeal with foodie delight, it was a well prepared meal.  They paired the firm fish with hearty vegetables and clams.  

The creme brulee was nice, crispy and caramelized (I've had some that weren't -- booo) and the spark plug is a really delicious concoction of coffee and coffee liqueur.  

If you're looking for a good DAT choice, I'd suggest One Market.  Though for the fancy pants people out there, the six course chef's tasting menu is $79 ... which is surprisingly "cheap" (HA) compared to other places like Michael Minna.
author: Shay F.

description:
In spite of living in San Francisco for many years, I really didn't know anything about One Market.  I picked it, quite frankly, for its proximity to the BART station as girlfriends from the East Bay were joining me for dinner.  However, when I told my husband where we were headed for dinner, he made some offhand comment about the fact that we never go anywhere that fancy.  My friends were also a bit surprised I had picked such a place for a simple Ladies Night Out.  Only then did I look at the website and begin to understand what the fussing was about.  A Michelin Star right under my nose all this time?  

I had the "Weekly Beast" 5 course tasting menu. This week's feature creature was Muscovy Duck.  I was a little worried that I'd be ducked out the second course, but for a mere $49, I figured  "what the heck?"  It did not disappoint... a very interesting mix of flavors, my favorite of which was the Liver Mousse Terrine.  So delicious.  So bad for you.  So morally reprehensible.  I'm still flogging myself for even considering ordering it let alone putting it in my mouth.  But it was a package deal?  What could I do?  I didn't eat it all, really, I swear!  

Anyhoo... the ravioli was great as was the Valrhona Chocolate Duck Egg Budino.  I really don't know what that is, but the gooey chocolate stuff that was delivered to me to top off the meal may as well have been crack.  Was it the duck egg that did it?  Perhaps.  But whatever "it" is, it should be put on the regular menu.  And sold on the street corner.
author: LeSLiE W.

description:
This is a tough one.  I like to give stars for a combination of the food - service - bevvies - ambiance - company.  Yet all of those have such different reviews. . . . What to do . . .

5 Stars - My group of friends. I'd say that One Market hadn't heard the likes of conversations similar to that bellowing from our booth. Shock therapy.

5 Stars - Our waiter.  He was a hottie.  

4 Stars - Cocktails.  I can't remember the exact name, but it was something with "Lawn" in it.  It was a gin martini that included basil and some other adult goodies.  All I know.  I could have had a tray of 'em. 

4 Stars - Caesar Salad & Dessert.  Honestly, could have had a larger Caesar Salad for my entree.  That's it.  Well ... On second thought, I'd add the deep dish apple dessert thingee to it.  

3 Stars - Entrees.  None of us were impressed with our entrees.  The tastes just weren't right.  Too much sweet with my Pancetta-wrapped Day Boat Scallops.  Not enough punch with the Mushroom Pot Pie. 

2 Stars - The Value.  I expected more for all the hype.

1 Star - Tip already added to a table of 4.  Really?  Who does this?

If you find yourself needing to go to this Michelin rated restaurant, I suggest grabbing a few cocktails and appies in the bar.  You'll enjoy yourself much more.
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description: I made a reservation with a special request for a window table facing the water. The staff was incredibly helpful and made the night fantastic.  Our food was delicious.  I really enjoy the crowd at One Market as it is fairly diverse.  There is definitely more of a business feel to the place but it also has a fairly wide variety of folks.  Couldn't ask for a better dinner - thanks!
author: Adam S.

description: We had a reservation but were seated at a table in front of a servers station which was noisy. We asked if we could be seated at another table.  it would only be a few minutes we were told. We went to the bar to wait. But no one came to seat us. When 25 minutes went by my husband went to check and was told "oh no one told us you were here.". The meal was just ok. My soup too salty. My salmon lacked flavor. My husband's salad and scallops were ok.  I must say our server was excellent. It was definitely not a Michelin 1 star experienceand we will not go back
author: Nan W.

description: I attented a private lunch with about 20 persons. That said - it was a very boring meal at what I assume was a very expensive price tag. Tasteless salad. Uninspired service. Below avg presentation.  Went several years ago by myself and was underimpressed also.
author: Josh F.

description: I came in for a Dine About Town lunch and it was absolutely wonderful. Excellent light, nice views of Embarcadero and the street. Service was impeccable and included a crumb brush of the tablecloth after the entree. My sole was perfectly flakey and still moist; my companion's sunchoke tortellini was bursting with flavor. (I barely got a bite before it was gone!) The squash soup was well-balanced with enjoyable creme fraische and balsamic drizzles. We desperately wanted to stay for dessert but were already late to get back from an overly long lunch. It would have been wonderful to stay another hour over coffee and creme brûlée...
author: Bill B.

description:
I've been here before for DAT lunch and a beef weekly beast dinner but this was the best dinner I've had from One Market.  

I went to the weekly beast (offal) on friday and was delighted with how delectable each course was.  I knew I would love the bone marrow, but the surprise dish that I loved even more than the bone marrow was the braised tripe.  It was rich, and the corn puree offset the richness of the braised tripe beautifully.  The other courses were crispy sweetbreads (wonderful, but I thought the portion would be bigger) and marscapone cheesecake with strawberries.  The dessert was a great finish to a wonderful meal.  

Tip: They have happy hour until 7 p.m. where you can get $5 house red/white wine.  You have to order and pay for it in the bar/lounge area.
author: Binh S.

description:
Dine About Town Dinner! Three course meal with wine pairings: 1) Rancho Gordo Chick Pea Soup (poured at the table over complex flavored olive-saffron shrimp) and a Spanish varietal, 2) Bay Leaf Tri-Tip with cilantro chimichurri over fresh corn polenta (extremely fresh ingredients - amazing combination of cilantro and fresh corn with the juicy tri-tip) and a full-bodied Zinfindel, 3) Nectarine Brown Tart with ice cream and blueberries (the nectarine was hidden only in the direct center of the tart but it was a nice combination of flavors) and a side of espresso (a bit more bitter than I normally enjoy)

Giant booths for comfortable seating. Walking distance from the Embarcadero BART. Fully enjoyed my food AND wine pairings. All my friends also did the Dine About Town and their food was delicious too. Free appetizer compliments of the chef (fried potato with fresh seared tuna... the friedness overpowered the tuna a bit, though). One Michelin Star.
author: Anna R.

description:
Solid restaurant: fantastic food and ambiance 

Cost to worth it ratio: 3

Eve award: mighty succulent melt in your mouth beef cheeks

Highlights:
- Atmosphere: corner location overlooking the embarcadero and bay across the street, pleasant lighting and fixtures, mix of tables with large booths along the window.
- Menu: good amount of choices and props for listing dine about town right on the regular menu as well as creatively offering a slightly upgraded 3 course menu for a bit more. Also Eve smile points for offering wine pairings
- Beef cheeks: a big hunk of braised meat that was oh so fork tender and soaking in tasty saucy delicious flavor. Black spaetzle wasn't very peppery and more similar to linguine form, but in the sauce was buttery goodness. Superb dish all around that I'm sure I'll be wanting again--possibly soon.
- Brussel sprouts: I'm a sucker for brussel sprouts and was delighted to discover my visiting friends are too. They were perfectly charred with thick pieces of bacon to add some saltiness and enhance the side dish.
- Wine list: substantial options by the glass (including one of my faves the prisoner) and popular local wines as well as a few others by the bottle.
- Bread: Siamese twin pieces of football shaped French bread. Interesting having them stuck together, but had the basics down: warm and soft on the inside and just the right amount of hard crispness on the outside.  
- Chick pea fries: quite interesting middle eastern flavors. Quite a hearty item, held it's form, and not greasy at all.     
- Small dessert sizes: coined "singular sensations," these are mini versions of desserts. As a savory food lover, I don't need much to end my meal so this fits the bill. Butterscotch pudding as well as banana cheesecake were excellent.  

Lowlights:
- Wine awkwardness: when my friend asked about a wine selection to go with both her starter and entrée, our waitress fumbled through notes of paper and informed her of one that pairs well with just her starter. I have no issue with servers not knowing wine pairings off the bat, but if it's not part of your expertise, just hand it off to the sommolier--either by saying you'll consult them or sending them by the table. I ask for pairing suggestions often and it's usually a seamless process. Also I found it odd for the dine about town menus, we were told there were the same 2 wines no matter the menu choice. Sure, some wines are that versatile, but I like the idea of a pairing being matched to a specific dish.

Besides the blip in the service, I quite enjoyed my meal here even more than I was expecting. I'd put it on my list to go back to and recommend--especially for the dine about town time
author: Eve K.

description:
3 out of 5 means that I enjoyed the overall experience, the food was just fine, nothing outstanding, not really worth a repeat visit, but wasnt a complete waste of time.  My wife and I came here for a light lunch.  we did ther lunch special and split it up so that we had the entire menu.  here is what we had and my thoughts on the dishes. 
Asparagus Soup house-made guanciale, parmesan flan, croutons.  this is what i started with, and ended up switching with my wife for the Frisee salad, because she didnt care for the lamb belly.  I was glad, as I was not fancying the soup all that much.  the parmesan flan bites were great with the soup, but on the bites were the flan ran out, the flavors were a bit too much for my likings.  It, to me, was like eating a bad baby food, that you would expect a kid to spit back up.
