Frisée Salad bellwether farms lamb belly, king trumpet mushrooms.  this is a interesting salad, which i had never had the likes of before.  as i stated this plate started with my wife, who could not get over the lamb belly "fatness", so i was willing to switch, as i didnt fancy the soup.  this was an interesting flavor.  the frisee was bitter on its own, but when you added the fat flavor to it, it worked and tasted pretty darn okay.  that being said it was still hard for me to take down the chunks of fat.  
Grilled Black Drum kohlrabi-daikon slaw, ramp vinaigrette.  this is the plate that i started with and then passed on to my wife.  I enjoyed this dish, i thought that the fish was very flavorful and tender, well cooked and spiced.   Potato Gnocchi parmesan puree, hon shimeji mushrooms,fava beans, English peas, carrot emulsion.  i thought that this was a nice dish, the gnocchi was tasty and smooth, nothing mind blowing. 

the staff and service was great, very accommidating to our needs and very kind with their service.
author: Nick S.

description:
Been here for lunch twice in one month. Both times the service was really bad that is why the three stars.  Food is four stars.

The first time was for a vendor lunch.  A few of us ordered the lobster risotto, our waiter and the kitchen were somehow not on the same page and we were delivered the shrimp Louie salad instead. We told the waiter it was a mistake, but he insisted that was what was ordered. Since i had a glass of wine to start,  I was starting to doubt myself that maybe I slurred during ordering? Only one of us who ordered the risotto got the risotto. We stared at the salad wondering at this point if we should just eat it since most us of had to be back to work. The vendor who took us was embarrassed because he chose the restaurant. Anyway, since we breathed on the salad it was considered ours. Finally the waiter found our order lost in the kitchen, and runs out to ask if we still want the risotto - it will be 20 min. Otherwise, there is the salad. We all agreed to just eat the damn shrimp louie salad since we all had to be back at work!   Salad was excellent but my mouth watered for the risotto! My coworker let us have a taste and that's it! 

The second time was for my sister's bday celebration during Dine About Town.  I chose One Market because of convenience and location to my office. Plus we couldn't get in anywhere else during lunch! 

Again, service very slow. We waited 15 minutes for a server to acknowledge and another 5 for water! WTF! This time I ordered the lobster risotto and I got it! My mom got the market salad and said it was the best salad she's ever had. Something about the dressing! My sister had the sea bass and said it was very tasty. 

All in all service very spotty and slow! Food and presentation when you finally  get it, is yummy!
author: Lauren W.

description:
I expected more from a Michelin-rated restaurant.

Service:  3 stars.  Aside from the server pouring the wine on the table instead in my glass, the service was quite good.

Food:  2 stars.  As suggested by previous reviewers, I asked for recommendations from the server.  He was adamant about the fresh-caught octopus starter and the halibut main dish.  
 - The fresh-caught octopus was very tough:  it was hard to cut and even harder to chew.  I felt awkward as I laboriously sawed off bite-size pieces while trying to conduct a business conversation.  
 - The halibut was over-cooked and flavorless.  Although it was disintegrating into the broth in which it was served, the halibut's texture still managed to be dry and spongy.  Very strange.

Value for money:  1 star.  I'm glad my first experience here was for a business dinner.  I don't plan on wasting my own money on sub-par gastronomy such as this.
author: Ashley S.

description:
This review is rather late considering I went to this restaurant back in March 09 but better late than never I suppose. I went there during the afternoon for lunch with my 2 co-workers and had a lovely time basking outside in the sun. The only issue with the sun is, it's so freaking bright! Practically blinded me as I struggled to locate my food. 

I decided to go for the prix fixe menu for $22? I forget the exact price. Anyways, I had an appetizer, entree, and dessert. 

Appetizer: Plantain and Shrimp Soup. Really smooth, creamy and rich. It was almost a meal in itself. Definitely needed more shrimp though, it was like a treasure hunt searching for those little morsels of delight. 

Entree: Grilled swordfish over asparagus and sundried tomatos. The fish was alright, nothing Red Lobster couldn't concoct on short notice. The asparagus was cooked wonderfully, just the right amount of crispness with a hint of spice. 

Dessert: Ohh it was the best part. Vanilla creme brulee with a biscotti cookie. Now I love creme brulee. I mean, anything that requires a blow torch to complete is fantastic in my book, but this was incredible. The creme brulee didn't even have a hint of egg-flavor and they use real vanilla. There was actually the black seeded look of vanilla beans throughout the dish. The biscotti was alright, a bit bland in comparison to the creme brulee, but perhaps that was there intention.

All in all, a fairly decent meal for the financial district. Definitely worth the price though. I may go back one day if they offer something other than swordfish for us non-meat eaters.
author: Scooby D.

description:
In a nutshell:

Food - 4 stars
P/C - 4.5 stars
Service - 5 stars

I had my reservations about going to this restaurant - after hearing from a couple of veteran foodie friends of mine that they had lukewarm experiences with the food and the service.  And reading previous yelp reviews didn't really tempt me either.  But, I decided to give my benefit of the doubt and try out.  All in all - it was a thoroughly pleasant experience, the food was better than decent, the service was seamless and courteous and the decor of the restaurant was very pleasant and calm.

So - four of my friends and I sat down to a table....it could have been nice to sit at the window table with a view of the Embarcadero but whatever.  We were immediately greeted by the server and were offered drinks - got my usual and they were brought out immediately.  The server came by to answer any questions that we had on the menu and explained chef's specials, dine about town menu.  I could tell that she studied the menu well and she knew what she was doing.

My first course was a simple caesar salad...i never get this because i normally think it's boring, but for some weird reason, i was craving it, got it, and enjoyed it.  The romaine lettuce was well coated with the caesar dressing with a very nice fragrance of the parmesan cheese and was complemented by the home-made crunch croutons.  My friends had various other appetizers - the cauliflower soup looked great, the sardines and the octopus dishes all looked great.  Oh, and I requested for the wine pairing a little too late but they brought the wine just in the nick of time.  My caesar was paired with a crisp glass of pinot grigio...nice.

My second course was the riceflake crusted petrale sole - very well cooked...soft, steamy and juicy....and the crunchiness from the crust was a good call.  the sauce was also a great touch - the carrot and ginger emulsion really brought out the buttery and soft texture of the fish.  My friends once again opted for something different - the skirt steak was good - juicy and tender, the duck looked great (I just wouldn't eat it because i don't eat birds)...My sole was surprisingly paired with a rieseling and i almost thought it was a glass of nice sparkly gewurztraminer...was a pleasant surprise.

Ok - the dessert, I had the dulche de leche bread pudding with the rum sace and pecans...out of this world.  It wasn't soggy and chunky as other bread puddings i've had.  it was crusty, soft and gooey.  Yum.  I almost had a bite of my friend's grand-marnier chocolate souffle cake but oh well.  Ha.

Just on a side note, my dinner which was part of the dine about town...was $35...and the wine pairing...$11...!!!  Yes $11 - how can you beat that in SF?

Conclusion:  This was a great experience - I'd definitely return here for more.  This restaurant had the three crucial elements right - the service (which in my opinion is more important than good), the food, and the ambiance.
author: Mike P.

description:
My company tends to have a lot of dinners here, and I have always found it to teeter between consistently good, moderately good, and good but unspectacular.  The key take away is that you're always guaranteed a good meal here.  

The last time I was here was probably three weeks ago, and I must say that the foie gras first course was the most inventive dish I've had in quite sometime.  It was prepared in the torchon style, but with some type of coffee reduction running through the center.  I have never paired the two before, and the flavor sensation truly heightened the experience on this trip.  It was almost as good as blue cheese and honey...almost.
author: Allen K.

description:
Beautiful uptown gorgeous restaurant.  The interior exudes class and sophistication.  

My pal and I ventured to this stop after our indecision over sushi.  Good thing because I greatly enjoyed the experience.  The customer service was first class and very attentive.  They checked every 5-10 minutes to fill our glasses and stock us with great sourdough bread.  

We had the oysters to start (very fresh and iced), however their dipping sauce lacked that usual lime vinegar taste I'm accustomed to.  I ordered the Braised Sonoma Lamb Shank: it was delicious!!! fall off the bone goodness!!! the sauce was rich and flavorful.  YUMMM
He had the Bacon-Wrapped Pork Tenderloin: honestly I thought it was alright... nothing special, but no complaints.  

We topped the meal off with cheesecake and creme brulee.  I especially loved the creme brulee because they came with three mini cups with three distinct flavors.

The price was fair and the experience was complementary.  
Good job One Market!
author: tammy c.

description: The food here is pricey, good presentation, excellent taste, excellent atmosphere for either a high - powered lunch or a date at dinner.  I did not go on a date here and it was a little depressing and / or a real downer, but service was still courteous, albeit a little slow. "One Market" should be an industrial - strength destination restaurant for San Francisco some day if it is not already.  Really good.
author: Thomas H S.

description: Please narrow the specials to a few. And 3 tasting menus is obscene. Especially lacking any a-la-cart options. Wow, that app sounds great, but I don't want to have a gut bomb for the whole meal.
author: Carl P.

description:
It was a nice sit down Friday night dinner. The food very nicely prepared, though not very unique and especially for the that price.

We had the foie gras, it had a strong cholocate taste as the chief added a strip of choclate on the top. The presentation was nice, but the food so so. Friday's daily roast was lamb leg meat, the roast was actually delicious though had a ring of fat around the meat.

The dessert was actually to die for. Very rich, splendid sweets. I think that was the best part of the meal!
author: Charlie Y.

description:
Don't believe the hype. This restaurant just isn't that great considering the pedigree that it's supposed to have.  My husband likes his steak well-done. I know that's not gastronimically saavy, however, it's his steak, he should get what he wants. He had to send it back three times before they got it right and that was with some effort. One of the chefs came out to ask what he thought was well done. My husband said, well done is the same anywhere...NO PINK. The guy rolled his eyes and went back to the kitchen. 

 And then hubby made the mistake of asking for ketchup....I thought the server's eyes were going to pop out of her head. She didn't come back to check again on us after dropping off the ketchup.

My food was mediocre at best. I've had better in dives here in PHX than a place that is so revered online and in magazines. 

Very disappointing for a place that is so hyped.
author: Beth S.

description:
I take out of town business folks here due to the location (right across from Ferry Market and water), accomodations which are spacious and lively bar, and nice level of service.  The menu  could be limiting for non-foody types and probably 2/3'rd of the entrees are seafood based.  Depending on your group dynamics, there are not traditional appetizers to order/share for the table.

We had a nice dinner for 4 Thursday night with a full restaurant and bar.  End of Orcl World.  We chose sides (entrees do not come with sides) to share as appetizers, fried green tomatoes, chickpea fries and terrine pate.  All very good.  

One of the guys spilled his drink on the table, and the service staff was very prompt in cleaning it up, without making a big deal of it, at all.  Thank you!

All four plates were cleaned when dinner was over.  Two of us had desserts - the options are interesting and offer two sizes, which makes one feel not too guilty ordering a 'mini-dessert'.  (Mini desserts are plenty big).

Overall : Attentive service, very good quality food and nice ambience.
author: Nancy N.

description: Interesting juxtaposition between the privilege of those who can afford to eat here, and the OWS protesters outside who had signs up saying that those eating in there were the 1% (which I don't agree with btw, it's expensive, but it's not expensive-expensive).  Anyway, don't let that put you off. The food & the wino were top notch. Highly recommend.
author: Anna J.

description: My wife is a researcher, so when we visited SF she wanted to eat here. The hostess was very accommodating, we didn't have a reservation. She didn't believe me when I said we walked all the way from Seattle to eat there, imagine that! Anyway, we were seated quickly, and our server came right away. The service was great, the food was amazing and the price equal to the experience. Highly recommend for special occasions or to anyone wanting to be treated well!
author: Mike B.

description:
Came here tonight with a friend for the Dine About Town.  After reading all the reviews, I was a little skeptical about how good this place will actually be... but I think overall, this place is really good.  The restaurant itself is classy and upscale.  The restaurant was packed with the working crowd (...meaning they have $$$)... but as a young 25yr old... I was still welcomed by the hostess and waiter.  The restaurant had a nice feel to it--not too upscale where I had to worry about my etiquette, but also not too casual where I could burp loudly and it go unnoticed.

The food, in my opinion, was really good.  First of all, DAT is $34.95, and wine pairing with it is $48.  That's $13 for wine pairing... quite a deal.  They are pretty generous in their pourings.  The wine came with the starter and the main entree, but no dessert wine.  It was still a deal though.  

My friend got: caesar salad, halibut cheeks, and chocolate toffee almond crunch cake.

I got the asparagus soup, skirt steak, and nectarine tart.

First, the assistant waiter come to our table and hands us a dish with 2 mini spoons with a wasabi tuna complimentary of the chef.  It was a nice surprise, and tasted really good.  The tuna was cooked perfectly on the outside and inside, it was fresh, and tasted really good with the wasabi fish eggs.  According to my friend, the caesar salad was "damn good".  He mentioned that the dressing was different than any other caesar salad he's ever tasted and came with lots of cheese.  Now I wish I had tried a piece...=P  The asparagus soup was...the greenest soup I have every had.... but also really good!!  First, the waiter brings out a dish with just the slightly cooked egg with the yolk intact with bacon, and then pours the asparagus soup into the bowl. Impressive.  The waiter said that the "chef recommends for you to break the yolk and then mix it in with the soup for better taste"... good advice!  It was delicious, and went VERY well with the wine! (A Pinot grigio).

Our entrees came out rather quickly after we were done with our appetizers.  The steak was cooked medium rare, but more on the rare side.  It was nice and tender, however was a little too rare for me... my jaw started getting really tired after a while!  The red wine reduction that came with the steak was a very nice added touch!  It went really well with the steak!!  The halibut was cooked to a perfect tenderness.  I only had a small piece, but it was delicious.  I didn't have much sauce, so I can't comment on it... but it was good from what I tasted!  We had Pinot Noir to pair with our meal... which also went very well with the steak and fish!

For dessert, we got the nectarine tart and the chocolate toffee almond crunch cake.  The CTACC (for short) WAS FREAKIN DELICIOUS!!  I'm not a big fan of chocolate, but this was DAMN GOOD.  It is a 2 layered chocolate cake with chocolate mousse in the middle, all rolled in almonds and toffee bits.  The toffee bits were huge chunks, so you definitely tasted it.  The mousse was so creamy and rich.... YUMM.  The nectarine tart was also very tasty.  It came with blackberries on top.  The tart itself was flaky, and didn't have a strong fruit sour flavor... which was good.  I think i prefer the CTACC.  I liked how you got to choose b etween 5 different desserts.  They all sounded very good.  

Overall, service was great, ambience was great, and food was great.  I think this place is definitely worth going to for DAT... otherwise I'll come here when I'm rich... which is like 30yrs from now =P
author: Diane L.

description:
I've been to One Market three times and each time I walk out slightly unimpressed by the food. I don't think the quality and taste justifies the prices but each time I read the menu, I can't help thinking the next time will be better than the last. 

In the spirit of trying to become a pescetarian (seafood + veggies), I ordered the Mahi Mahi. The waiter, who was very knowledgeable and pleasant to look at, made sure to emphasize how great it was! For an appetizer, I ordered the pear salad. 

The pear salad was excellent. Be prepared for a frou-frou salad - a very small salad with a few greens, a couple slivers of pear and some candied walnuts. Overall, the taste was very complimentary. The goat cheese was a very nice touch with the sweet pears. I recommend the dish if you feel like spending over $10 for a small salad. 

The Mahi Mahi main course was good. My biggest problem with the dish was that it was swimming in a sea of oil.. no joke! The fish was overcooked for my liking but I should have asked if it came raw or cooked before I ordered the dish. It was a heavier meal than I would have liked but once I got past the fact that I was coating my stomach in oil, I began to enjoy the dish. 

The meal was capped off with a pleasant cup of cappuccino to waken me from my food coma. Overall, good meal but not great.
author: Lan H.

description: Good happy hours and happy hour prices. Dinner was expensive and a la carte but the rabbit (first time I ever had rabbit and was a little apprehensive) was absolutely delicious with incredible seasoning.
author: Anna K.

description: I've eaten here for lunch & for dinner and what I can say about One Market is that its a bit too "commercial"/"businessy" for me but the food is solid. Service is on and off. Sometimes the service is really attentive while during my most recent trip, it took forever to get our entrees but our appetizers came quick. Weird. Most recently, went to lunch with my friend and had the business lunch special where I got a sunchoke veloute (soup) and the pan fried flouder. Solid dishes, but not something I would pay a premium for.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I went as a party of one for lunch the other day and ordered the 2 course option from the DAT menu. The food wasn't bad, actually the butternut squash soup was good and the lamb sausage would also have been good if it hadn't been a bit over-salted. 

But what ruined my lunch were two things: a pushy waiter who kept wanting to upsell me first with the bottled water (management get a clue, bottled water is so over in SF), then with an extra appetizer that I didn't want, then pushing more courses  after I was clearly done and just wanted my check. 

And to top it off, he includes an 18% tip even though I was a party of one. He probably knew that I was irritated with him so wasn't going to give him 18% so he just went and included it anyway. i wasn't going to argue over a couple of bucks so I quietly paid and left vowing never to return. 

It's too bad the front of the house ruins it for the kitchen.
author: Jay K.

description: Yup!!  i love One Market, been there many times...  the food was great, so was the ambiance...  however, their prix fix menu doesn't change much, and i ended up eating the same thing every time i go back there...  i wish they would offer more choices on the prix fix...
author: IceSnow N.

description:
As one of the yelpers put it..."Why it took me so long to rediscover this 3 star rated Michelin restaurant", Yes it could be pricey and yes it is worth every penny. My dinning companions and I had a marvelous time on this particular evening. The food is amazing and the service is superb. One very important thing to remember, the menu at One Market is seasonal. Let me start sharing my outstanding review. 

Our amuse Bouche was a Cherry Gazpacho (v) yogurt sorbet, shiso, radish and it was so yummy! Then the Hand-picked Dungeness Crab -green apple water, jalapeno, cilantro- this was my appetizer was outstanding. My dinning companions were so pleased with their appetizers as well. For our main course I wanted to try their signature steaks, and let me tell you ... The New York Steak was very tender and flavorful actually one of the best New York steaks I ever. To accompany the streak we did choose the Sautéed Spinach (v vg) minus the garlic chips ...2 of us had the same delicious item. My other dinning companion opted for the Ahi Tuna 
escabeche of beech mushrooms ...mmmm very, very good. 

One final advise "do" leave room for dessert since One Market also have a very talented Pastry Chef.
author: Ernesto C.

description: My family and I ate at the chefs table at One Market this week.  It was fabulous.  They treat you like a princess.  The wait staff Jessie, Johnny, and justin were so attentive and fun.  They gave a tour of the restaurant including the wine cellar.  You donned aprons and plated dessert.   The chef  was attentive.  He explained the the artful process he used with each course.  He ran a well functioning kitchen.  The food was superb.   There were seven courses, each was cooked, plated and presented with perfection.  They burst with flavor!   My whole family oohed and aahed.  It was a sensory experience of sight taste  and smell.    Thank you to  chef Dommen for the best meal and evening.
author: Melissa G.

description: Extremely disappointing. Went into the city for a nice dinner with friends. Main course portion size to small and overpriced!
author: Mark N.

description:
I've completely changed my mind about one market.  My first experience was fantastic, but subsequent experiences have led me to the opinion that this is a very inconsistent restaurant.  Unfortunately, it is more often consistently bad.

The service is decent, but not terribly welcoming.  The food is all over the place.  The menu has some excellent choices, but how they turn out really depends on how the stars are aligned.

I'm reasonably sure that I won't return.
author: David G.

description: Drinking Anchor Steam San Francisco Beer.   City is going bananas. I love it!!! SF GIANTS!!!!!!  WORLD SERIOUS
author: Sonny S.

description:
I used to work very near here and would come here all the time when lunch meetings were called for.  I was never a huge fan of the food.  I think it might have been the overemphasis on red meats, combined with kind of small portions.  Not really sure - it just wasn't a place I was all that thrilled about going to.  But -  the service was always friendly, efficient and professional.  I remember that much.  

The last couple of times I have been to One Market, the menu has been very different.  I am not sure when that happened, but I really do like the new menu, and always have trouble deciding what I want because everything looks so damn good.  But as the menu has improved, and Michelin showed up with its little star, the service has gotten worse.  

Today, a few of us went for an early lunch without a reservation.  
"Feel free to take any available table in the bar."
"Nothing available in the main dining room?" I asked.
[Smile-less eye-lock for at least 3 seconds]
"Of course not," she replied

Of course not?  What?
May I suggest, "I am so sorry, we've been very busy lately.  Perhaps next time."  

You know who you are, long dark-haired hostess.  Perhaps you'd prefer a job taking tolls on the bay bridge?  You certainly aren't cut out to be dealing with the public in a supposedly high-end restaurant. 

So we sat in the bar in plain view of Bitchy McBitcherson, and I periodically looked up to see if I could catch her in a smiley, friendly moment. No way.  That stick was firmly implanted up her ass.  

The server in the bar was friendly enough, but couldn't describe any of the entrees without actually looking over at one of our menus, and then she would just read the menu to us.  It was kind of humorous.   The food was pretty good, as usual, although today my otherwise excellent crab chowder was served luke warm.  

One Market is just not doing it for me.  It glimpses greatness, but I have had far far better dining experiences over here in the Biggedy O.
author: Jay Z.

description:
Came here in lieu of Dine About Town. I was very excited about it because I have heard wonderful things about this place from friends and coworkers.

We showed up to the restaurant and were seated immediately. Our server greeted us and started off with drinks. When he came back he began to go through some of the popular items on the menu. That server talked FOREVER! We all thought he was going to go through the entire menu. Five minutes later.... we had an idea of what we were going to do.

The nice thing about this place was that in addition to their "Dine About Town Menu" they had a deluxe "Dine About Town Menu" for a few buck more (like 5-10 bucks). It definitely gave us more options to look at with their features.  In our party of four, 1 choose the standard menu (me), 2 choose the deluxe, and one went for the special of the evening, Prime Rib. I went with the standard because they had skirt steak on it and well, it sounded really good. 

For the first course, I had the asparagus soup. It was excellent! A lot of flavor and the poached egg was interesting featured and added another element to the soup. Another perk was they prepare it table side for you, which was really cool. Following the soup, I had the skirt steak. The meat was perfectly cooked to my liking as well as it being full of flavor.  For desert, I had the Strawberry "Panzanella," which again was really delicious. In addition to my food being excellent, the other members in my group were happy with their meals as well. 

One option that we had with the food was for the first two courses to be paired with a wine. I choose to go with this route and I am glad I did. For the food I had, the wine accented the food perfectly. I say this because the two people in my group that got the deluxe meal had the same wine paired with different food and one of them mentioned that it didn't compliment the food as well as it could. By the end, I was very full and satisfied. This was definitely one of the better meals I have had in my life.
author: Diana R.

description:
I easily spent more money and more time at this place in 2006 than anyone should or seemingly could. 

"Hey Drue, so and so just got a promotion. Lets go down to One Market for lunch. We'll order lots of celebratory alcohol, but don't get too drunk because when we get back to the office you have a ton of work to do. Its going to be a late one for you....but lets go for lunch and make it half liquid. Um, what is that you say? You can't go, too much work? Well....I am not really asking, I was just trying to be polite."

"Hey Drue, Its Dine about Town, and, well, since you have so much work to do and have to stay late anyhow, why don't we grab dinner down at One Market before you head back upstairs to finish up your work? What, no time for dinner? Well, you have to eat, come on."

"Hey Drue, lets get a seat for happy hour in the bar before all of the douchebags trying to pretend they are more financially stable than they are arrive to cram themselves in like sardines so they can save a buck or two on the fantastic happy hour. Oh, you have to work late? Well, just meet us down there, I'll order you some happy hour cocktails so you don't have to pay full price when you get done."

"Hey Drue, why do we always go here? I mean the food is just okay at best. The service is  good but the decor is pretty generic, certainly not the fine dining experience they are pricing for. The bar gets super crowded at happy hour and super expensive after its over, and it only lasts until 6, which isn't very happy at all. Oh, because you are always working and it is right downstairs? Riiiiggghhhttt."

So, I did the only logical thing I could in 2007 to rectify the situation. I quit my job. I haven't been to One Market since, and I haven't looked back. 

One star for the service which is generally quite good, one for the happy hour prices and one for providing me alcohol to ease the pain of one of the most horrific, most corporate,  jobs I have ever had in my life.
author: Drue C.

description:
Where could we find dessert on the Embarcadero when it was pushing 10pm?  

One Market had a nice dessert menu, and let us order from the bar.  My Lady settled on a peach tart and hot tea.  I shared the tart, and had a Keoki coffee.  The bill was $25.44 + tip.  

That's not cheap, by any means, but the tart was delicious!
author: David D.

description:
Had a great lunch today.

Fantastic golden lentil soup that was light and refreshing.  Well spiced too.

Excellent crab salad with grapefruit topped with sorbet.  A little too oily for my taste, although olive oil is certainly needed in the dish.  If they had backed off a bit it would have been perfect, but I don't think that most people would complain.

Service was very attentive, almost too attentive and salesey.  However I'd rather err on the side of too helpful and involved than the opposite.
author: Nate H.

description:
-one star for the sliders (balsamic onions on top?!? YUM) and fresh oysters
-one star for the nice wine menu (i had a couple of really decent glasses of norcal chard that really did it for me)
-one star for the two tables seated next to us (they were individually, really really nice folks)

minus two stars for the weird service from the server/busser in the bar/lounge area. she never knew what was going on, and only came to our tables if we waived her down for something. not something i expected from an establishment like one market, and it wasn't really even that busy!

the table next to us was celebrating a late birthday/cinco de mayo. the other were tourists, i believe. 

our table was comprised of just a couple of friends, making silly faces and having a grand ol' time talking to each other about our weekends. 

to me, happy hour is always about the company, never about the place although if service had been better, i would have given the establishment a five-star rating, much like the night i had. 

:-)
author: May T.

description:
Wow, One Market was actually one of my very very first reviews.  And it's still pretty much dead-on-balls-accurate.  Which is a technical term.

Anyway, sometimes, I need a drink.  And wonderful service.  And decent decor.  And an excellent menu.  In FiDi.  And when these needs collide, I head to One Market.  Like today, for example.  And if I can arrange to meet a certain blond internal controls division manager here, why so much the better!  Particularly if she promises not to wear her t-shirt that says "I'm in Control" on the front.  I see enough of that in the bedroom.

Good Manhattan in the bar.  Not too sweet, not overdone, classic, simple, and sophisticated.  Like the people who drink it.  Also: when they say roasted nuts, they are NOT kidding.  Some were too hot to eat.  Also, while $6 may seem steep, it's damn near a pound of nuts.  I was thinking about getting a doggy bag.  But between the martini, the Manhattan, and the Crown & Coke (in that order---notice the subtly decreasing quality [and cost] of the drinks), I wasn't really all that concerned with...much by the time I left the bar, wandered over to the hostess stand, and said "we're your problem now."  Hey, at least I'm honest.

Gloria Ferrer champagne before dinner?  Sure.  Roasted gulf shrimp?  Why not.  Fried green tomatoes for wifey?  Absolutely, just don't ask me to have any.  Duck for B2P?  Pretty predictable, but the duck WAS delicious, and came with both white meat and dark meat cuts.  Veal chop for wifey?  Also predictable, but no less delectable.  Like the girl herself.  Glass of barbera went well with dinner and made sure I didn't sober up.  Dessert was some berry and cookie and whipped fluff thing, which was amazing, and plenty big enough to share.

So, departing One Market, and looking back on my first year of Yelp, I am reminded of the words of Big Audio Dynamite: "If I had my time again, I would do it all the same, and not change a single thing, even when I was to blame."  Bring on year 2!
author: Ben P.

description:
Came here for a business lunch and it's a great place to grab lunch with your co-workers. It got a little packed with people waiting for a table and there isn't much room to stand around and wait inside when it's raining like mad. 

I ordered the trout with the brussel sprouts which was amazing and the side dish sizes are big enough to share. The chickpea fries were the real knock out here though! They were SO delicious! I wasn't sure what to expect, but it was like chickpeas mushed into a mashed potato texture and then shaped into rectangles and then fried! MMMM! 

Also ordered the arnold palmer which was really fancy with slushy lemonade an iced tea which was really tasty. We split a sampler of three desserts which included the pot de creme, toffee cake, and something else which I can't remember. All of the desserts were delicious and perfect to share.
author: Austin K.

description:
After Gary Danko, I thought that restaurants with Michelin stars would be of a certain caliber.  Unfortunately, One Market proves this to be incorrect.  

I went here with my girlfriend as part of the Dine About Town event.  The experience was marred the moment we stepped in the door, when the receptionist thought we entered too slowly and hissed for us to come in faster because cold air was blowing into the restaurant.  As we stepped in, they let down some heavy drapes parked behind the door, and a drape slammed in my girlfriend's face.  Next, we were given a table that was squeezed into a window so that a chair couldn't be pulled out all the way...um, not good.  The hostess disappeared for a while so I had to wait a bit before getting a table change.

The actual food was pretty decent.  The cauliflower soup with mini scallops was very savory without being too heavy, and the skirt steak was done very well.
author: C L.

description:
More like a 2.5...

So, we went here for a birthday celebration in a small party, and I was definitely less than impressed by several things, some of them very major in my opinion: 

1) Snooty Patrons - well, I guess I'd be a bit biased, but my other friends I was with said the same thing; there was an older couple (apparently having the taster menu and wine pairing which is like $150 a pop) that seriously stared at all the asian people in this restaurant like they didn't belong there.  What the hell, so who cares if you're dropping $300 on dinner and im dropping $30?  Seriously, the woman KEPT staring at me even AFTER I made eye contact with her. ... UMMMM. 

2) Snooty ass waiter - Okay dude, so what if I want to leave my empty wine bottle on the table for decoration after you decant it!? Shut up and don't make smart ass comments and snicker, or look at me like im a poor retard for having the DAT menu.  If you don't want me to order it, then don't shove the special menu in my face!

3)Misleading me about the dress "code" - Okay Mr. Reservation dude  that told me most people will be in FORMAL wear that evening - WHAT THE HELL WERE YOU THINKING!? I saw fools in baseball caps and ratty jeans.  

4) Forgetting about my SPECIAL REQUEST - I wrote clearly on the OpenTable reservation comments box that it was for a friend's birthday.  I understand that they don't have to do anything special but what I request was NOT done, and that pissed me off.  Sure my friend didn't mind, but I sure did. And, no apologies either! 

THE FOOD: 

Mushroom Soup with Soy Flan and a poached Quail Egg - This tasted like I was biting into a big juicy portabella mushroom and had a good thick and creamy texture.  The Soy Flan was kinda weird, but the poached quail egg was tres cute! :) 

Seared Bay Scallops atop Mashed Potatoes  - Three big scallops on top of mashed potatoes; meaty and tasty, but the potatoes were thin and non impressive.

Duck Two Ways - This was pretty ok from the SMALL piece I tried; braised duck breast atop a duck-loaf :) 

Chocolate Beignets with White CHocolate hot cocoa - looked good enough but kinda small compared to the other dessert 

Vanilla Bean Ice Cream atop Flaky Pastry - Yeah you stupid waiter, I call it the ice cream thing, so sue me!  Jeesh, what a bitchy waiter.  Anyways, I felt like this was the little dessert that tried to overcompensate for EVERYTHING.  The dessert huge - even bigger than my entree, not enough ice cream, but a REALLY TOO sweet sauce and non-ripe blueberries, and a huge square of flaky pastry.  It was too sour and too sweet at the same time.... ew. 

It was just.... LACKING.  I wasn't impressed to say the least!

So, you pretty much know what I think about this restaurant. Skip it - too expensive for what it is, and a little pretentious.
author: Linda C.

description: Went here with friends and was very disappointed.  The food was mediocre and bland, very traditional and boring.  Will not be back.  There are better offerings in the neighborhood.
author: lisa z.

description:
I came here with a friend back during Dine About Town, and that was definitely a worthwhile experience. One Market offers standard and upgraded versions of their prix fixe plates (one with more expensive dishes than the other) and wine pairings for an additional $12. My friend and went with the standard option and the wine pairings, which was totally the way to go.

To start, we both had a golden lentil soup plated tableside. Who plates a soup tableside? That won me over right there. Plus, the soup itself was delicious, creamy and rich and pureed, which is odd for a lentil soup. I followed this with a mushroom pot pie, which was also plated tableside for me and was delicious--richer and more flavorful than any pot pie I've ever had. The desserts weren't as interesting as the soup and the pot pie, so much so that I barely remember mine. It had mint in it, I know that much.

But the most impressive thing was the wine pairing that went with this. The soup course was paired with a Chardonnay from Trione that was so astounding that my friend likes to describe it as "creme brulee in a glass."

It's rustic French cuisine with local, Organic ingredients. The crowd there is a little different than my usual restaurant crowd (i.e. financial district denizens), but I can't fault anyone for wanting to have a business lunch at such a good restaurant.
author: Stevi C.

description: Honestly I don't know why the overall score for this restaurant isn't a tad higher. When you pay a certain price for a meal, and in my case that meal was lunch, you expect a few things: good service, good atmosphere, quality ingredients and intriguing flavor combinations. I experienced all of those things, starting with a nice huckleberry smoothy, followed by a pumpkin soup, an ahi tuna burger, and a nice cheesecake for desert. Straight up, good stuff, over and out.
author: Joe F.

description: Good but not worth the price. Service of course was top notch. Seafood was...the menu was like...whatever.  At least they had oysters on the half shell. Try it for a business meeting but spend your own dough somewhere else.
author: V L.

description: Don't eat here!! We spent thousands on a Xmas party and valet service. The valet service got me a parking ticket, threw it away and I didn't know until I got a 2nd notice in the mail. I imm called the restaurant and spoke with Kris. I faxed the ticket notice and now she won't take or return my calls to let me know if she even got my fax!! She insisted I send it via fax, is that so she can later say she didn't get meanwhile causing my ticket cost to go up! Don't ever ever ever go here they don't treat their well paying customers well at all!
author: Julia B.

description:
One Market certainly knows its Veggies.  Currently showcased in their Farmers Market Sides are:  Roasted Baby Carrots w/ sherry vinegar, Chickpea Fries w/ Harissa Aioli, Sauted Spinach w/ garlic chips, Big Fries, Swiss Chard Gratin w/ Herbed Panko, Roasted Brussels Sprouts w / applewood-smoked bacon, Buttery Mashed Potatoes and Roasted Sunchokes.  Comforting and amazingly flavorful and fresh.  I loved the smokey bacon flavor of the Brussels Sprouts and the flawlessly rendered Chickpea Fries, good paired with or without Harissa Aioli.  The Sauteed Spinach was amazingly fresh, and the Sunchokes screamed of simple, unembellished mushy goodness.

I also really enjoyed the seasonal Fuyu Persimmon Salad, with Candied Pistachios and wilted Savoy Spinach topped with a huge fluffy heap of Ricotta Salata tendrils.  Taken altogether in one bite, a delightful and savory medley of flavors.

For dessert, we chose the Platter of 3 of their Mini Desserts, picking Pumpkin Cheesecake, Chocolate Toffee Almond Crunch Cake and Butterscotch Pudding with Chantilly Cream.  My favorite was the Pumpkin Cheesecake.  (Nice side note, One Market also offers a decorate-your-own frosted Gingerbread Man cookie with sprinkle and gumdrop toppings, proceeds of the dessert from all Bay Area Lark Creek restaurants to go to Bay Area Make A Wish foundations.)

What I liked, strike that, LOVED, about One Market was their varied and plentiful use of seasonal Fruits & Veggies with touches of Middle Eastern / Mediterranean flavorings like Harissa and Saffron.  I was less impressed by the Saffron Soup with Mussels,  Pistou and Yukon Gold Potatoes. OK taste but the texture and visuals were offputting, read: floating pockets of oil.  

Peg S., per usual, appropriately captured the decor as "nonconfrontational."   And if you feel your soul suffocate every time you step foot in the FiDi, may I suggest a proverbial inhaler of Kick-Ass Soul-Replenishing Friends to accompany you?  Cuz hipster, this ain't the Mission.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Can someone please explain the hype about this place? I just went for Dine About Town lunch and I am really underwhelmed. Glad I didn't pay for an a la carte meal here.

Starter: Farmer's salad. Supposedly comes with seasonal vegetables. Mine had a few paper thin slices of radish and fennel and some crumbles of something that may have resembled romnaesque broccoli if the pieces had been large enough to identify the vegetable.

Entree: Farro "risotto" with roasted winter squash. Way, way too salty. Also, if you're going to have the cohones to create a risotto out of anything other than arborio rice, you better have the skill to make it creamy and starchy like risotto. Dumping melted butter onto it does not make it seem more risotto-like. I did think the farro had good texture as farro. And the raisins and currants were a nice touch.

Dessert: Pear galette. The pastry had the consistency and flavor of toaster strudel. You shouldn't need a knife to cut your pastry. I would rather have just had the poached pear and vanilla ice cream.  

And the kicker: they tacked on an 18% gratuity for a party of two! WTF? I mean, I know I am taking advantage of a lower cost deal, and I am not wearing an Armani suit, but I am not exactly crawling out my trailer and dusting off my overalls and hoping they have squirrel on the menu. A lot of people use DAT to explore new places- places they will probably return to (and pay full price) if they have a good experience.

Guess whether I will go back to One Market?
author: Angie R.

description:
This is not a happy hour meet your friends and be loud, see and be seen type of place.  More of a one on one or date type place.

They had $5 drink specials and served these long crackers/bread in a cup that's complimentary.  They were addicting.  Came here on a Wednesday for Happy Hour.  The crowd was older (late 30's-older) and the atmosphere was calmer than Americano's or Palomino's.

p.s.  Saw Posh and Becks here before he unveiled his package in his Armani underwear.   Damn Becks, I'll be your SF tour guide.  I have a soccer field in my bed you can score goals in, snicker snicker.
author: Nezza F.

description:
After working in the financial district for 8 years, one gets to know One Market.  I have had too numerable good lunches and dinners here to begin to recount them in any detail.

5 Years ago, we moved the offices to Berkeley - to the Gourmet Ghetto (so I don't hurt for good food), but I still miss One Market and Aqua and, strangely enough, the Royal Exchange among others.

So, when someone said, "let's meet at One Market," I jumped at the chance.  We were supposed to meet at 11:00 and I showed up a bit early (as is my normal procedure) and was on the phone when 11:00 came around.    One of the staff poked there head out and said they did not open until 11:30, but would I like to come inside to wait (+1 star for paying attention and showing a kindness to strangers - I could have said weary travelers there but that really would have been over the top).  

The person I was meeting showed up at about 11:05 and he to was invited into the establishment and we were sitting in the bar area chatting before they were set up for lunch.  Unfortunately, I had to leave at about 12:10 to get to another meeting, so I ended up not getting anything to eat, but my friend ordered lunch and we both had some iced tea, so we were able to leave a generous tip for their kindness in accommodating us and now I want to go back and spend money because I really enjoy great service and the experience, sans food, was excellent.

One Market has always been and is now staffed by good people.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
We dined here over the weekend.  We did not order the tasting menu, but chose instead to order two course meals.  The food was quite good but the overall feel of the restaurant was not great.  The hostess did not speak to us except to mumble "follow me" as she walked away.

The waiter was nice but the restaurant is very loud and crowded feeling.  I don't expect that sort of feel from a restaurant with these prices.  I could hardly hear my dining partner, the waiter had trouble hearing our orders and I felt like we were entirely too close to the table beside us.
author: Tamara A.

description: Great atmosphere for dinner.  I came here for Dine About Town about a year ago.  I had the roasted chicken which was pretty solid.  The dessert was really cute, it had a flat cookie with the shape of a dog.
author: Sue N.

description:
Its January! And you know what that means!  Dine About Town! (AKA put off your New Year's Resolution for one more month)...

One Market doesnt skimp on their DAT menu.  Rather than offer a "special" menu featuring "cheaper" items not on their regular menu, they offer a few of their favorites straight off their regular dinner menu.  And as a couple, you can try all six offerings on the menu, which is spectacular!  The sunchoke soup is divine (I love sunchoke!) And both entrees were delicious, with surprisingly generous portions.  The desserts were sinful, the flourless chocolate cake paired with the most ridiculously caramel-icious caramel ice cream.  Service was spectacular, and the view of the ferry building is fun.  The bar looks crazily crowded on friday night, but they do offer some tasty looking goodies at the bar for happy hour at great prices.

Regular prices are expensive, but they dont skimp on portions.  A good place to bring parents.
author: Cathleya G.

description:
I had very high expectations dining at a house with a michelin star.  
It was disappointing.  It literally took us 15 minutes to get water.  The wait staff was just horrible.  The manager was actually rude to us.  The food was good, but not breathtaking.  I had the terrine.  I really liked it and it would recommend it.  I also had the trout.  It was a bit overdone and a bit bland.
author: david w.

description:
Perhaps some of the best service I've experienced in San Francisco.  The food was actually probably only worth 4 stars (tomato bisque appetizer and halibut main course) but the combination of great service and pleasant atmosphere makes me want to give this place 5.

Oh, the delicious warm gooey chocolate souffle didn't hurt putting it over the edge.
author: Derek B.

description: Highly overrated. The food is so very average. If you must go do a drink at the bar and cut your losses
author: Neil B.

description:
This exquisite restaurant has been at the top of my favorites list for a long time standing now. It is one that seems to always meet my expectations. It is a great place to take the out of towner or for a family meal, or even if you just wanted to have a cocktail with a friend. The bar is sometimes a little too crowded after work, but when you get it on a perfect night it is serene.

You know the chef is top notch when they allow an open exhibition of the kitchen from the dinning hall. Last time I made a visit to One Market I enjoyed one of my favorite meals. I started out by sharing a Dungeness Crab Salad with heirloom apples and celery root with celery sorbet with my boyfriend. My main course was the Alaskan Halibut in applewood-smoked bacon, yukon gold potatoes, fennel, and sweet corn. My meal went perfectly with my favorite glass of Pinot Grigio from Napa Valley. Oooh and to top it off we had dessert... I'll admit I only had a couple nibbles. But my BF cant end a meal without a little chocolate... fine! and neither can I. We had the Chocolate Toffee
Almond Crunch Cake.

All of which I'd highly recommend when visiting the tastiest place on earth.

P.S. After reading back my review, I anticipate becoming fat someday with an appetite like that.
author: Dee C.

description:
My husband and I decided to go out for a date night on a busy holiday weekend. After years of overlooking One Market, we decided to give it a try when we quickly discovered they had a table at the time we wanted. This should have been our first indication that the formerly-great restaurant may have lost some of its luster.

The host was friendly, but not overly welcoming. Despite the reservation, our table was not ready and we waited in the bar area until the host retrieved us. I had asked for a quiet table in the corner, yet we were seated in the middle of the room (not really a big deal). Also, no one offered to take my coat, so I draped it over my chair on my own. The menus were placed in front of us without much fanfare and it did take several minutes before anyone else visited our table.

Our server may have had too many tables, but there were several service missteps throughout the evening. Despite being reminded that I am a vegetarian (this was also indicated in the reservation and I casually mentioned it to her when she brought the menus and I was seeking guidance), the amuse bouche was not vegetarian. When I asked for recommendations, she mentioned non-vegetarian items and was less than helpful when I had questions. She did not go out of her way to share ideas or make us feel special. In fact, she completely forgot my husband's wine pairing and my glass of wine until we finally were able to get her attention in the middle of our main courses. Instead of apologizing or going out of her way, she brought us both the same exact glass of wine and charged us the full price, despite the discount my husband's wine three-course pairing should have had (she completely missed the pairing with the first course and did not offer anything to pair with dessert). By now, we were beyond frustrated and feeling like we had to work extra hard to get what we had originally ordered.

Our dishes were good, but not memorable. My gnocchi was drowned in a heavy foam (very 1980s) and the pasta was lukewarm - not hot. My husband's halibut was slightly overcooked, but that may have been because he waited too long to start when he did not have his wine to drink with the meal. I finally implored him to start eating. He claimed that the flavor combination with the fish was a bit off and the vegetables that came with his fish were also overcooked. We did enjoy the side of roasted artichokes with lemon - that may have been the best part of the main course.

For dessert, my husband ordered the blueberry cheesecake and I ordered the chocolate pudding with caramel and sea salt. Both of us truly enjoyed the desserts, but the almond crumble that topped mine was a bit heavy-handed and dense. We resisted pairing any beverages with this course, as we were still smarting from getting our wine so late in the main course and had plenty left to go with our desserts. The spoon that was presented to me for the dessert course was much too large for the small glass vessel that contained my pudding, but I didn't want to wait another 20 minutes to play hide and seek with our server. I managed to make it work and was able to get to most of the pudding out of the glass.

The location and views of this San Francisco mainstay make it desirable, but I would hesitate to return anytime soon. I might return for the piano and bar scene, but not for a meal in the dining room.
author: Rachel P.

description:
evening reservations...six.thirty pm....early arrival...friday evening...wait at bar drinking $three stella....happy hour pricing!...take one more while wait....

party arrival and awaiting chef's table experience....following and follow....back and back....deep into actual kitchen?....marvelous@!....cozy booth (for seven max) inside kitchen center stage....introduction from staffing...host, waiter, sommelier to chef....treatment of importance from start.....sommelier!...order of wine start...leaving to experts....self not knowing....just wanting endless flow....

tasting to begin....explanation of each from the chef himself....starting with shucked oysters seasoned with caviar resting on salt bed....deliteful slurp and fresh ocean seafood flavors....amusing buds for five course to come.....order of bottle per each tasting....additional bottle complimentary enjoyed in inners of one market wine cellar....ah..the tastings explanation....trout marvelous...details of ultra low heat cooking of trout....almost sashimi, almost smoked...great texture and flavoring....and favorite.....seared scallop resting over sweet creamed corn....completely covered in thick whole spring truffle slicing....sweet corn bit overpowering rest of tastes....avoid of corn and just picking scallop & truffle for excellent bite & second bite....

sip, drink and guzzle of wine...many bottles deep....sommelier must be knowing...or wise to my drinking....always finishing each bottle with a second pour to my own glass....(or just only glass always empty after each bottle?)...

tasting of duck and steak..memory bit fairytale land this point....all cooked perfection....bravo to outside front griller....who overheard how marvelous the grilling...proudly boasting, "i cooked that!".....yes..wonderful job, sir...

into the back to make dessert....one market having few cooking stations and seperate preparation rooms....back to dessert....supposed to make, but too much glee from endless wine....more interested in flat donut frying....umm....i think i'll have one....just cooling on board...wait?...was that for another customer?...self just wearing bigger than life smile....over happy and skip back to table....wait?....did i forget about the dessert making?....eating of donut and running about in kitchen?.....too happy to care....dinner coming to end.....

too hard to read bill....looking at receipt, customer copy....appears to be $two hundred per person....toss of additional $twenty bill for jacket taken...wearing white cook's jacket out and about in san francisco....sorry....will return if needed....return to repeat one of best enjoyable dinners had....food, care, presentation to staff....also perfect five stars....
author: Hen A.

description:
When a placed is advertised on the television set of every hotel in Union Square, you know you're going to have a pretty crappy meal. I'm pleased to say, however, that One Market is an exception to that annoying rule. 

First, this restaurant is so conveniently located. You can check out amazing views across the street and do some shopping in the Ferry Building, and you can easily access the Embarcadero BART station, which is a huge plus. 

We walked in on a weeknight during the dinner rush, and our wait was less than five minutes. This, as well as our ultra aloof hostess, also scared me, but things got better. 

I ate with two other people, and we shared three entrees: the bacon wrapped pork, scallops, and grilled ahi. The scallops were my favorite by a long shot, but the other two dishes were better than just "good." 

The service (after the hostess) was pretty solid, and the cost seemed about right for the area and for the quality/amount of food. If you're in the area, I'd recommend it.
author: Sacha M.

description:
We came to One Market to celebrate our girlfriend's 30th birthday.  We arrived Saturday at 8pm and the restaurant was full of diners.   We were waiting for one of our friends, so we decided to grab a drink at the bar first.  The drinks were pretty standard in terms of cost and taste.  

I would say that most of the diners were probably around their 40s and up.  The atmosphere wasn't overly stuffy which was nice, we could still talk/laugh without feeling like we were creating too much commotion.  When we were seated our waitress asked if we were celebrating something.  We told her it was our friend's 30th bday, so I was sure there would be a nice dessert given to her after our meal.   The waitress was very nice and patient considering we had multiple questions regarding the menu.

We ordered the following:

Bradley's Caesar Salad ($9.75)- The caesar was pretty standard with an average-sized portion.  I didn't feel like it was worth $10 though.

Hen special (not sure price)- It looked delicious and tender.  Some of my friends liked it.  When I tasted it, it was TOO moist.  Is that possible you ask?  Yes.  There was no texture and it was basically...wet meat.  Gross.   

Potato-crusted Petrale Sole ($26.50)- The fish was just okay to me.  The artichoke barigoule and basil broth were very unappealing to me.  It didn't complement the fish at all.

Roasted Liberty Farms Duck Breast ($29.50)- I didn't try this dish but my friend said it was good.

Bacon-wrapped Pork Tenderloin ($26.75)- Pork wrapped in bacon.  Do I even need to say more?   Haha.  Well, in my opinion, it was the best dish that was ordered.

Sides ($7.75 each):
Overview- the portions are TINY and not worth the price.  For $7.75, I expect the portion to be big and darn tasty.  I could get a delicious bacon cheeseburger w fries at Slider's in SJ for that price!!!  

Grilled Asparagus-  wow, totally....overcooked.  Limp with no flavor. Disappointing.  
Sauteed Spinach- Spinach w garlic.  Nothing outstanding.
Buttery Mashed Potatoes-  My friend described this perfectly, saying they tasted exactly like those instant boxed Potato Buds.  Yep.  Potato buds with a cup of butter.

After our meal we were given dessert menus.  Everyone was stuffed so I just whispered to the waitress, "Does she get a birthday dessert?"  She replied with, "I don't understand."  Hmm...  So my friend repeats my question and then the waitress finally says no, they don't offer that.

Uhh...what?  That's lame in my opinion.  Lame enough for me to subtract a star.

On their website, they show that they have a 1 star rating according to the Michelin guide.  I had no idea this guide existed, so I decided to check it out online.  Their rating system: 1 star- very good restaurant, 2 star- excellent cooking, 3 star- exceptional cooking.  Apparently this guide is well-known in Europe.  I thought Michelin made tires?  I'm confused.  They even have the same marshmallow looking dude on the guide.  Here's some info if you are interested:  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michelin_Guide

I took a look at what else is in their SF 1 star category.  Wow.  Gary Danko?!  Chez Panisse?!   One Market is NOT is the same category of these great restaurants at ALL.  They list Aqua and Michael Mina in the 2 stars.  They have only one restaurant with 3 stars...French Laundry.  I just cannot comprehend how One Market got onto this list?!

Vivian's rating based on the Yelp system:

3 stars for the food  - 1 star for no complimentary birthday dessert and the prices.

2 stars.  Luckily, I had great company, so I still had a fantastic time.
author: Vivian W.

description:
There are certain demarkers that one can look for in a fine dining establishment.  These markers virtually LIFT the restaurant up to a higher strata, thereby validating their very expensive prices and related wine mark up.  One Market did not succeed at this task. 

Had a family dinner here last Friday night.  They were especially accomodating last minute which was nice, however, the evening started off with things, well, a bit off.  We ordered a bottle of Rombauer Chardonnay, which at the marked up prices is a bit of a crazy decision.  The wine arrived at the table luke warm, which was terribly dissapointing.  This wine, which is overly robust, really needs to be served pretty cold.  We sent it away for a wine bath, which the waiter confused for a wine bucket....one Michelin star eh? 

My Dad and I both ordered the Dungenous Crab salad, which at $15 a pop was sure to be good.  First bite, the crab claw on top.  Disgusting.  Seriously, did you guys leave the meat out on the counter since lunch?  Was the crab green when you cracked it?  It tasted like BAD CRAB, which is simply disgusting if you've ever had it.  The smell alone should have keyed in the chef that the crab was bad...then, at least 3 or 4 crab shells were in my crab mixture under the polenta (which was quite good). Soooo, bad bad start.  My Dad's top piece of crab was also very gross.  This is just no acceptable at a restaurant with as high of accolades as this place. 

We moved onto our mains, I had the New York Strip and a side of summer squash.  Both were quite good.  The highlight for the table was the pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon, both parties that ate this were very happy.  My Mom had the nightly special, lamb.  It was to be thinly sliced and plated.  It was a pile of meat that was stringy, tough and the opposite of what lamb should be. Another failure. 

All in all this dining experience was fine.  It wasn't BAD but it wasn't great either.  Our waiter seemed a little incompentent and we did have to resort to flagging him down a couple of times...again, not the type of service you expect at a restaurant with a Michelin star and one that continues to be on Michael Bauer's Top 100.  I was dissapointed, perhaps my expectations were too high? 

All in all, you are better off spending this type of money at Range, Absinthe, or Jardinaire, all of which have spectacular service, great food and less than mortifying wine mark up.
author: Claire C.

description:
**My rating is based strictly on their Happy Hour***

One of my co-workers loves this place because they pour a good glass of Maker's Mark, but the overall scene just really gets me down...the crowd is older, the bartender can be rude, the servers don't seem to care at all, and the food prices are obscene (e.g. the $11 for 3 small potato skins).  Yes, I do realize it's One Market, so the prices are hard to complain about, and the drinks and food are pretty tasty/strong, but I certainly expect better service from a restaurant that charges this much.
author: Krystle S.

description:
It's a Tuesday night and my Hottie Blade is downtown for a meeting.  Hey!  Let's be spontaneous and go out to dinner!  No reservations, no plans - just go out.  We ended up at One Market.  Two words:  Loved It.  We totally splurged and got the 6 course tasting menu.  Wow-oh-wowie that was a smart decision.

One Market gets 40 of 50 Fussy Fusspot Points... and 4 stars

---

Clean table and dishes?  5 of 5 points.  Very clean.  Super clean.  And new silverware with every dish.

Clean server?  5 of 5 points.  Clean.  And also quite handsome in a unique way.

Clean bathroom?  4 of 5 points.  Kind of a surprise but it needed a quick cleanup.

Subtotal = 14 of 15 Fussy Points on the Clean Scale.

Service?  5 of 5 points.  Excellent service - prompt and accommodating.

Ambiance?  4 of 5 points.  Nice, comfortable, great view, good spot to watch tourists and businessmen.

Friends from Finland Practical Scale?  3 of 5 points.  Like all SF restaurants it's -1 point for the lack of parking.

Food?  9 of 10 points.   The 6-course tasting menu was actually 7 courses with the complementary amuse bouche.  The black bean soup with calamari - what a surprise!  It was amazing.  The seafood courses were great, the pasta course was delicious and beautiful.  Every course was a taste-treat.

Price/Food ratio?  3 of 5 points.  Great food but a little on the expensive side.  Definitely worth it.

Bonus?  2 of 5 points.  1 bonus point for the terrific variety on the Tasting Menu, 1 bonus point for presentation of the food, 1 bonus point for having my favorite local Vodka at the bar.  But they lose one bonus point for the funny sound in the bathroom... it was adjacent to some kind of machine that made a screek-screek noise that sounded like the shower scene in the Psycho movie.  Even my Hottie Blade came back from bathroom wondering if someone with a knife was after him.

Total:  40 Fussy Fusspot Points.
author: Fussy F.

description:
This is a place to go on a business lunch, ideally you'll expense this meal or whoever is treating you will expense it. Reasons to go here and pay out of your own pocket include: 

1) treating a coworker to a first or last day lunch 
2) that's all I can think of.. 

Being a business lunch spot, the service is lets say.. leisurely. You will never feel rushed, you will also never feel like there is any urgency to get good food in your tummy quickly.  (Obviously business lunches are paid for by business people do whatever they want, and therefore can afford to take hour and a half lunch.) 

On to the nitty gritty, I had a House-made Duck Ravioli with a foie gras emulsion and maittake mushrooms. As expected it was fantastic, the foie gras emulsion which I expected to be a sauce was was actually foamy yum. Brilliant.

I also had the pleasure of pilfering the House-made Chicken, Pork & Pistachio Sausage with caramelized apples from another plate. Not exactly my thing, but the taste was very delicate, not too salty, and the apples were a great compliment to the sausage. 

4 stars if someone is paying, 3 if not. Either way, if you haven't been here before you should try it at least once.  A 10-12 minute walk from 33 New Montgomery.
author: Eric L.

description:
The restaurant's 3.5 overall rating is spot on. That's what I would've given it if Yelp offered half stars (HINT HINT).

Went with some coworkers for DAT dinner. I thought the restaurant was beautiful: perfectly lit with romantic decor, the street view of the embarcadero at night was nice... it just all worked for me.

Service was attentive although I thought our waiter seemed a tad snooty. Yea we're obviously there for the fixed-prix menu but it's not like we're begging for leftovers. Stop with the judging. I wasn't hating on him for his greased back hair and handle-bar mustache (well I am now, but at the time I wasn't).

We started with the caesar salad and lentil soup. Both good. Entrees of braised pork ribs and wild steelhead. The pork was definitely better than the fish. And dessert saved the entire meal. They were orgasms in the mouth. No joke. Creme brulee, toffee cake and banana cheese cake were AMAZING. Particularly the banana cheese cake - which I wouldn't expect to like, but HOT DAMN it was good. Lick the plate good. I would return just to have dessert here!
author: Felicia H.

description:
Honey and I met up with my chi-town best friend and her hubby last night for dinner.  We were seated promptly.  Initially I wasn't too keen on our round table in the middle of the restaurant.  It didn't seem very intimate, but  once we started talking, laughing, and reminiscing, the background scenery just melted away.  Childhood friends are da best.

The ambiance was nice, great view, impeccable service.  Our server was so sweet, I wanted to hug her. 

Foodwise, I was expecting more creativity, better presentation (even on a la carte dishes like the filet), and better execution of staple sides (e.g. mashed potatoes) from a restaurant of this caliber.

NOW ONTO TO THE FOOD:

     Duck mousse (complimentary) - smooth, very flavorful

     Farmer's Market Salad - bitter greens didn't mesh with dressing

     Roasted Peach Salad - AMAZING TEXTURE, taste, and creativity

     Pan-seared Dayboat Scallops - enjoyable, but eh on the fava beans

     Alaskan Halibut Sous Vide - very, very tasty, but NOT CREATIVE.  could have ordered something similar at a typical asian restaurant.    

     Grilled Sonoma Lamb Chops - BEST MEAL OF THE NIGHT.

     Filet Mignon Special - TENDER, presentation so so, portion and grilled onions good

     Buttery mashed potatoes - tasted like sitting in a warming oven all day.  not buttery or creamy, more like CRUSTY outside.  

     Big fries - good

     Fried Green Tomatoes (b/c they ran out of spinach) - small tomatoe, thick batter.  tasted DINER PREPARED instead of a michelin star restaurant

     Mini platter dessert included - blueberry upside down cornmeal cake, two creme brulees, and chocolate toffee almost crunch cake.  SUPERSTAR OF THE NIGHT!!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Very much a 'business-lunch' type of place, my friend and I decided to crash this restaurant with our hoodies and plaid shirts. It's a great location with lots of windows to let the sun shine though and a good view of the Port of San Fran. 

The service was great and the food was fantastic! I took the 'business lunch' that included a salad and trout served with a delicious shallot sauce. The fish was incredibly flakey and perfect. My friend had the ahi tuna burger which was yummy as well. The tuna was cooked perfectly as well, sealing my opinion that they know how to cook their seafood. My dish came with a side of whipped potatoes and spinach; my friend's dish came with nice potatoes that had a good crunchy crust. 

Basically everything was delicious, right down to the post-lunch coffee. The price is moderate to high, but worth the trip.
author: Jenn S.

description:
This is not the kind of place that I would return to if I didn't have co-workers that made me return all the time.  

Let's see.  Extra star for Dora, the cocktail waitress, who always remembers me by name.  It's not her fault that during busy Friday happy hours the drinks take 20 minutes to make it to our table; the restaurant is no-place-to-sit-packed on they under-staff for the occasion.

The place gets zero extra stars for the food.  I don't even eat in their dining room because it's so not worth it (I do have SOME say when it comes to my co-workers!)  The bar menu once upon a time had one thing on it worth ordering - the popcorn shrimp.  They pulled that from the menu and despite my formal request to management for its return, they have stuck with the sliders instead.  I order the oysters just to have something to eat, but usually run through three dozen before the after-work hunger pangs start to subside.

The place stays popular year after year, so what am I missing when it comes to the food?  Well, the the crowd is lots of yuppie types who come in for power lunches and/or after work so I can only speculate that maybe this place is popular for people who have relocated to SF for work.  Like someone from the North Carolina asks their Mid-Western colleague where to go after work for good food and drinks and One Market is all they know.  But, the crowd is always friendly and sociable during happy hour.
  
Be careful of the bill.  Between bar menu and drinks for four to five people, I am always surprised how the bill can get over $200 in only a couple of hours.

http://www.dph.sf.ca.us/eh/Violations/Loc_CurrentViol.asp?LocationID=3082
author: Ann W.

description:
We went to One Market for lunch on the Dine About Town menu.  It was really yummie.  We had everything on the menu except the Mushroom Pot Pie.  The wine paring option is a deal - considering that the glass of wine ranged from $8.50-12.  The wine paring was an extra $13 to the Dine About Town menu.  I wish I knew this before I ordered a glass of wine at the bar while waiting for our table!  

I would give this place a 4 star rating, but part of this review was on Dine About Town experience there.
author: Theary K.

description:
Michelin, right? Wrong! Here goes:

1. They sat us in a very strange location - my husband's back was to a window and he was right next to a large plant. They put a chair in front of a banquette,  turned the table, and I was perpendicular to him. Why couldn't they just seat us at a two top where we could face each other?

2. Appetizers included octopus, and then the caesar salad. Salad was fine, but not memorable. Octopus had a very strange flavor-- tasted smoked, which was interesting, and then it was served with a soy reduction, which helped the flavor but definitely didn't dazzle me. My husband spent time in Japan and said it reminded him of a street food dish that he loved, so I'm glad he liked it.

3. Scallops and sweetbreads entree was good, but again, not memorable. I had heard that sweetbreads were delicious when done perfectly. These were battered and deep fried-- a preparation I rarely turn away-- but that didn't seem to do them justice. The texture was a little spongey and tough inside the crispy exterior. Scallops were perfectly caramelized and soft in the middle. Hubbie had lamb shank and he loved it. I helped him eat the bone marrow and that made up for the mediocre apps. 

4. Chocolate Souffle- very very good. The ice cream that was paired with it was good, but not outstanding (my favorite is the salt caramel ice cream at Perbacco, so that is always tough to beat)... but the souffle itself was very good. 

Service was good- we had a nice server. 

For $180 including a glass of champagne and wine each, I would have expected better food. Sorry.
author: Sonal B.

description: The bacon wrapped pork tenderloin was pretty good and it was also the highlight of my meal.  As for the starter, I enjoyed the hand-picked Dungeness crab, which was...unique.  The dish had a lot of gelatinous material, which I wasn't expecting, but it was fun to try.  My dessert was a creme brulee duo...very forgetable.  While I enjoyed my meal, as well as the wine that was selected, I didn't experience anything that would make me want to come back.
author: Agent X.

description:
First of all, I have to be totally honest. I have received a number of love letter "compliments" from a variety of you. Yes, quite similar to the love letters I received from prior lovers. You know the type... you have such a lovely face and such a great personality. Basically, you know, they meant, "but damn you have a rear end big enough to rest a tea cup on!"

Ooooops, I forgot that I have lost 140 pounds since then. Also, I have been totally disabled for the past year which means I am laying here in bed reliving all my favorite meals so I apologize in advance if any of information is outdate.

I saw that a recent review was written for One Market and there is only one thing I go to there for and it is absolutely my favorite thing. If you are broke and can't afford anything other than a completely self-indulgent dessert, please please, please, try out their chocolate brioche bread pudding. I swear it is an orgasm in a bowl. It is not puddingish (sorry, acid flash back to my mother's instant jello days) but rather is the most tongue tantalizing dessert with absolutely the perfect balance of firm and moist you will ever indulge in. It is definitely a chocolate lovers "wet dream".

Best,
Theresa

P.S. For what it is worth, I have eaten meals there and I found them over priced and rather ordinary fare to my uneducated palate. I also have no problems driving across town just for dessert! And the 5 stars are for that course only!
author: TiMarie S.

description:
A good place for a business lunch (ie: the kind that go on the company card.) The food is quite nice. I had the Wild Nettle Ravioli with hen-of-the-woods mushrooms, and parmesan-green garlic emulsion. The apple turnover and the Valrhona Manjari Souffle Cake twarnt bad either. Yum. The atmosphere is upscale, relatively quiet, and modern. The service was good and operated at an efficient but sedate pace. 
3 stars because it's spendy and I probably wouldn't eat there of my own accord, but again, it's pretty ideal for a business lunch, when time, conversation, and good impressions are key.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
i came here a couple years ago for happy hour and lemme tell you, happy hour is SO worth it. the prices are wallet-friendly and the food is stomach and tastebuds friendly.

tonight my friends and i checked out one market for sf dine about town. $31.25 for mmmness. I had the portobello mushroom soup with soy flan and a quail egg. at first it had a really strong balsamic vinegar flavor, but after you mix everything up, it tasted good.
for entree i had the autumn squash pumpkin seed farra "risotto". it was DELICIOUS! I LOVED the buttery texture of the grains, with the sweetness of the squash and hints of toasted pumpkin seed goodness. YUM. My friends had the duck breast and another had the scallops. Both are worth four Ms for Mmmm. for dessert, it was chocolate fritters with hot chocolate and pear gallet. again, mmmm! I was so stuffed I couldn't finish it all.

thumbs up: friendly wait staff, flavor, the warm 2 pieces of BREAD /person AND BUTTER, atmosphere - loud enough to chat but not too load where i could hear and didn't have to tell

thumbs down: its rather $$$$ if you order off the dine about or happy hour menu, but still tasty. the waiter forgot a fork and a water for my friends, but it was a busy night i guess...
