author: Lauren Y.

description:
Another great find thanks to DAT.   The theme of our meal for the evening  was "all things shrinkwrapped with bacon."   I knew I was going to like this place!

For starters my dining companion and I both opted for sunchoke veloute over the casaer salad.  The veloute was unusual, but I like the combination of the mild creamy (which wasn't cream at all but a broth thickened by flour) soup and the walnuts and bacon crisps.  I've never had sunchoke before (the waiter described it as being leek-y) and leek-y it was!    

My friend ordered the pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon on a bed of blanched  spinach, and I opted the scallops again wrapped in bacon on bed of thinly sliced fingerling potatoes.  I was surprised (as well as bit disappointed) how large his portions were and how small mine.  He got 3 huge rounds of porktenderloins  and I got 3 scallops.  Me thinks I got the short end of the stick, Shmee.  They were both absolutely delicious -- sweet, moist and succulent.     

For desert we decided to split the two offerings of pear tart with a blueberry sauce and ice cream and the chocolate souffle also served with ice cream and a lovely dollop of freshly whipped cream.  I wasn't too impressed with the tart but my friend absolutely loved it.  Me, it was all about the souffle, warm gooey chocolatey-ness.  HEAVEN!

Again, atmosphere was a bit off since the whole place seemed to be filled with an older crowd - think white men in their 50s with dark suits and ties and the ladies dining club with pearl necklaces and such.  Nice but not really my scene.  I could imagine taking older clients here if I was a banker or something.   But alas, I am not.  

Perhaps I'll take my dad here the next time he visits.
author: Melissa S.

description:
THROW YO HANDS IN THE AY-ER, AND WAVE 'EM LIKE YOU JUST DON'T CARE... ABOUT MONEY

this place isn't cheap. admittedly, i'm not cheap either, but one look at the menu made it abundantly clear: bring money if you want to eat here. or put it on the company tab. or draw it from your trust fund. however the hell you get your money, you're gonna need it.

that said, my economics background held that "inelastic demand" theory firmly in my front view the entire time, raising my expectations to nearly artificial levels. the waiter came by, me and my brothers made our demands for the dinner he organized to announce that he is a new father, and we got to it. 

we started with a round of incredibly strong drinks. apparently, that's the way you celebrate the conception of a new child. and it's definitely the way your bar should prepare a drink at all times. ten points.

i do have to say that they have a gigantic menu. places that charge this much don't usually tend to spread themselves this thin, but i guess it's a risk worth taking in a city of such picky eaters. we all ended up taking the server's 'recommendations,' with better than average results. exemplary, even. let me continue.

we had a strange tobiko-thingy as compliments from the kitchen upon getting wind of our occasion. i've never been one to have anything even remotely caviar-like, so i'll withhold comment on it.

our regular appetizers had a wide range of quality, from "oh my god you have to try this" to "why the hell do i have a salmon chunk on top of a cheesy croissant thingy with a soft-boiled egg on top" apparently, the kitchen thinks that america considers croque monsieurs "exotic" and tried to merge it with eggs benedict. i had to pass. subtract two points.

our main courses actually came at a decent time. the pork was good and soft [though salty], my steak was tender and aromatic, and apparently the new dad had the best duck EVAR, but i'll save that honor for the confit salad at viognier until a duck dish comes along that knocks me flat on my ass. this didn't, though some more seasoning would've provided at least a jostle. seventeen points.

and the dessert? we'd be sitting around in a movie theater for two hours afterward so i wish i changed my coffee order to an irish coffee, but the non-alcoholic kind did well enough on its own. the creme brulee was appropriately cremic. and bruleic. it's worth a return trip even just for a last course. nineteen points.

my brothers shared a warm chocolate tart, but i never find those appetizing. lukewarm or fleshtone food has, historically, never done much for me, save for contribute to nausea.

but that's beside the point. this place is worth coming to. i'll give it a few more months, even until mid-2008, before this restaurant shifts from something just barely on the cusp of greatness to one of san francisco's more elite restaurants [so they won't need to rely so much on the view of the embarcadero that they provide]. 

maybe then i won't feel even remotely guilty about dropping a hundred damned dollars on a thursday night.
author: Charles C.

description:
One Market is a restaurant that everyone who works in the FiDi has probably tried. I finally checked it out for dinner and I must admit, it did not meet my expectations. 

My starter salad had way too much dressing and blue cheese. I was scraping it off midway. My duck entree was a little salty but felt incomplete somehow. The berry tart thing I had for dessert was overwhelming and I left the entire dish. :(

A few good things: great service, amazing space and layout, and fantastic people watching (if you like lookin at old business men and their much younger dates).
author: Han C.

description:
We went there for Dine about Town.

The food was alright but not great.

Even though they have a full bar, don't bother ordering a cocktail or mix drink; it will be very watered down (but the price of it won't be). Just stick with either wine or spirits.

Service was not really good or completely horrible, but I didn't appreciate being forced to pay an 18% tip for a party of three; nor did I really like being constantly asked if I was under 21 - even after showing ID (it was flattering at first but it got annoying especially after I got a really watered down jack and coke).

In my opinion the only thing that One Market has that's above average is atmosphere... I'd eat somewhere else for the price (Michelin rated... whatever).
author: Brian L.

description: Enjoyed a birthday celebration at the Chef's Table in the Kitchen area. I haven't been at One Market for a number of years and I wasn't disappointed. The Chef's table is a nice experience gift for someone. First enjoy a generous tasting menu orchestrated by the Executive Chef and his team. You'll also enjoy some special treats which are sent over by the Executive Chef. During the dinner your group takes a tour of the restaurant and learn a bit of history.  You can't appreciate the size of this operation unless you get behind the counter.  After you complete your last tasting entree, 2 guests join the Dessert Chef to finish off several desserts for the table. Our service was attentive and professional. My guests had a wonderful night!
author: Gerry C.

description: What an amazing lunch! We came here for dine about town lunch and the food was awesome! we ordered the chickpea fries as extra side and with the chili dipping sauce they were outstanding. The potato gnocchi was so smooth and fluffy. The entire set menu was delicious. And omg i love love love the creme brulee. I'll be back for dinner for sure!
author: Kameelah R.

description:
Definitely on the buisness-y side for dining. I enjoyed my food, and we had good service.

To start I had the heirloom tomato salad with pork belly. Divine.

For my main course I had the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin...hmm I see a theme... That was good but my friend had a great suggestion--he said they could have improved the dish by making the bacon crispier, and I agree. It was still tasty though.

For our sides we had
chickpea fries: yummy
Green beans w/chorizo: so good
Fried green tomatoes: good but didn't mesh as well with our meal.

Great red wine blend, and decent desserts. Can't really go wrong!

Would definitely return even if I was paying myself! :)
author: Lu E.

description:
Been there several times for dinner and all have been positive to excellent across my four main criteria: taste, service, ambiance and value. 
Taste: love the appetizers, the lamb tongue, charcuterie and ocean trout stick out as our favorites. For entrees the lamb shank, duck breast as well as the seasonal specials have been quite good, the duo of creme brûlée have been a staple as our finisher.
Service: consistently excellent, a waiter to be flagged down within a few minutes but not one that is always there to make you feel uncomfortable, knowledgeable staff and courteous servers and hosts at the front desk
Ambiance: spacious with a lot of conversations going on, clean and well organized, good feel for what I am thinking is a restaurant downtown. Some might disagree and expect a theme or elaborate decorations, to each there own!
Value: a little tricky but I find this to be quite a good value, not excellent but given it's location and looking at the price tags for the surrounding sitdown/good atmosphere places, I think you will be happy.
Overall: 16/20 sounds about right, excellent across multiple factors, but not "top notch" in any. (My scoring system is really set up to discourage 20s anyways)
author: Aldo K.

description:
I usually don't like to write reviews, but after eating at this place and seeing how people actually like this food puzzles me.  Now keep in mind this was a FREE dinner paid for by our manager for our holiday dinner.  This is how bad this place was that I had to complain about it.

The restaurant ambiance is nice, but it pretty much ends there. I'll try to keep this short.

Bread: Hard and chewy...totally didn't expect this.

Complimentary app: Tuna with ginger foam

Made me want to spit it out...not a great start.  Over salted and you couldn't even taste the tuna.  It was like eating a tablespoon of salt and ginger.

Apps: Trout, Crab, foie gras
Out of these 3 the foie gras was actually the only think I liked from this place.  The trout had a distinct fishy after taste which made me wonder how fresh it was, the crab was frozen which you can taste.  You're in SF during crab season and your serving frozen crab? I've had better crab at local restaurants that are hole in the walls.

Entree: Lobster

Now for a place that is suppose to be this highly rated with 5 star reviews from other yelpers confuses me. The lobster was over cooked and chewy.  It was so bad that I had trouble cutting through it with a knife. I've been to some crappy restaurants before that served lobster better than this place. 

Sides: Mashed potatoes, and garlic spinach

Both horrible. The mash tasted like it was instant and was bland.  There was maybe a hint of butter, but everyone agreed this was the worst mash they ever had.  The spinach was bland as well and the slices of roasted garlic wasn't cooked long enough so they were chewy instead of being crunchy.  I definitely do not recommend any of these sides.  

Dessert: Duo of creme brulee

At least this was a pleasant surprise, although a bit on the thick side it tasted ok. 

Service: The wait staff seemed a bit incompetent. They were attentive, but didn't remember who ordered what and kept placing the food in front of the wrong person.  The waitress also had to keep referring to who ordered what when placing silverware down for our entrees. I mean its ok to glance to remind yourself, but she literally stood there starring at the orders then placed the silver ware down then did the same thing with the next person.

Overall, I definitely would not recommend this place.  When you spend close to what we did, you'll definitely walk away feeling like you got ripped off.  If someone offered to pay for my meal again at this place, I would definitely say NO THANKS!
author: Erick N.

description:
I always like to take a look at other reviews to make sure i'm not off the mark...and i don't think i am....but my caveat is that i only hung out at the bar (yes, that's where you will typically find me - a girl likes her cocktail!)...nevertheless i am giving it 4 stars because i love the ambiance.  and shawn, our mixologist, ROCKS.  he was so nice and sometimes when you are in a nice bar like that - sometimes you don't always get the help you need...  we had a few bites - the cheese, the wings and the calamari (wow - that's a list of your typical bar food - but it was a little dressed up).  i would order the cheese again - and the hubby liked the wings.  the calamari - meh.
we were there on a saturday night and i loved the fact that there were not a million people there.   

btw - shawn makes a mean drink called the ISIS - pretty sure he came up with it.  it's yummy!!!  

"meet me for a cocktail at one market!"
author: Square P.

description:
The food is nice. 

Of course the food is nice. It's a well-established, venerable San Francisco restaurant in the heart of the Financial District, and you pay a lot for the meal.  If the food wasn't nice, something would be seriously wrong, and I could write a scathing review that would have people sending me "funny" and "cool" comments by the dozen.

But instead, I have to settle for nitpicking. This place feels stuffy to me, and this was during two business meals with my overly stuffy corporate office. We should have fit right in. Instead, the service was unimpressive and the staff made little effort to treat our corporate posse like something special (of course, we weren't anything special, but that's not the point).  On one occasion, they struggled to accommodate our large party, despite the fact we'd made a reservation well in advance, and on another, our waiter seemed so hyper I thought I might choke him.

This is a great place if you are going out to lunch with your ultra conservative parents or want to show a really pretentious and boring date a really pretentious and boring time.  The menu is conservative and fairly well-executed, and the space feels, well, rich and slightly bland.  You're certainly not going to strike out, but with so many great and inventive options for dining in downtown SF,  you might go out on a limb and spend your business-lunch bucks somewhere else.
author: Chelsea R.

description: I was really torn on whether to give this place a three or four star rating. I dined here for two separate occasions. One for a friends birthday and another for the hubbys birthday. The first time we dined here me and the hubby loved it. We thought the food was great and loved the decor and ambience. The second time we returned alot of the dishes were disappointing. The first time we dined here we also ordered from the bar menu and everything was delicious. They have a great wine selection. I ordered the Apple crab salad and i swear this is the best salad ever even though there isnt any veggies lol. It is a FOODGASM worthy dish and so unique because i havent seen anything like this anywhere else. To be honest i cant really recall what i had for my entree but i do remember not liking it very much. The second time me & the hubby return i again had to order the crab salad mmmmmm it was so amazing. we also order the oysters which were good, we also had the trout but it wasnt all that. I liked the foie gras but the hubby didnt but thats because he doesnt like it torchon style. I loved the mini brioche it was super cute. I had the steak but it came with a butter sauce and i asked if maybe they could sub it with a red wine reduction instead, simple request right? the server tells me that they pre make everything and dont have the ingredients to make a red wine reduction. WHAT? i could make that at home. WOW that costed this place from a four star to a three star. Dinner for two: $239 including tip $300.
author: Gina H.

description:
One Market is an oldie but goodie restaurant that truly reminds you what fresh food, sensible creations and clean presentation is all about.  It's not about the latest trends here.  Just a great restaurant and what one should expect to eat in America's culinary capital.

One Market is the bright line between posers and real restaurants.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Happy month of July, I am a sucker for over-priced grape juice, everything is 50% off. Gulp gulp gulp. I spent some crazy money in there. Yet so tasty. 
Food was good to fair, not many appetizers for the big reds. Server doesn't seem to serve wine too often. Kind of disappointing, maybe I was at the bar. 
Sexy view when you leave there kind of buzzed.
author: Jonathan C.

description: The service wasn't too amazing here, but the food was very good. I had a great scallop dish, halibut (i think) and a yellow tomato soup with an excellent sauv blanc. pretty atmosphere too
author: Sheeva G.

description:
I have no idea what all the other reviews are complaining about. I just got back from the city and definitely feel that this restaurant deserved the "One Star Michelin" Rating. If you're not familiar with the rating system, just google or wikipedia it, you'll see.... All the complaints are a bit ridiculous... 40 year olds? Some bar bill? 

The service was nothing but amazing. Right when we got to the restaurant, they uncorked the bottle of Dutch Henry wine we brought and poured it in a decanter.

The food was absolutely delicious and the flavors were so complex. I ordered the duck ravioli to start and my boyf had the crab salad. The salad pieces were cut very thinly and so were the crab pieces where you couldn't tell which was what when you ate it. The crab salad also had this scoop of lime-green colored sorbet. Instead of it being sweet, it was a savory sorbet. Now how trippy is that?!

I had the halibut, which was amazingly well-presented, and my boyf had the lamb chops, also very amazing.

I believe some people complained about the portion size. This is a great and awesome restaurant, not Dave and Busters. That's why this country is overweight! Get used to the REGULAR sized portions. And if you're still hungry, order the sides. (The spinach was very good.) Or just order two desserts. We had the mint-ice-cream-sandwhich and a make-your-own Gingerbread cookies where the cost of the dessert went to the Make-A-Wish Foundation. How awesome is that?

You go here for the food. The decor is pleasant, the restaurant is very open with high ceilings and it's a very nice place to go.

Not sure how the bar is but they have a pretty nice bar with some beer on tap if you get there early.
author: Ivy C.

description: I usually give this place 4 stars, but on my last visit I was very impressed. One Market is one of my favorite restaurants to hangout with family and friends. It is also a fine restaurant to bring your clients as well to discuss business and enjoy the views of San Francisco. The food and wine list is top-notch as well. The service is very attentive, and I would request David or Mickey to wait on your table for incredible service. I would recommend starting with the smoked trout which is one of their signature dishes. For the main entree go with the bacon wrapped pork tenderloins which will make you come back for more. The NY steak with a side order of sauted spinach is very good as well. I would recommend ordering 4 or 5 desserts and sharing amongst others at the table. All the desserts were fabulous. You can always tell if a restaurant is good by their coffee, and yes the coffee was very good. Overall, I will keep coming back here on a quarterly basis, and you should as well.
author: Mark L.

description:
Service: C
Food: C
Decor: B
Dessert: N/A  

The one thing I would remember vividly from this place was the ugly waitress yelling at my face. I didn't understand why the waitress had to yell at me for being early for my reservation.

The food was,in a nutshell, terrible. 

Chicken noodle soup looked pretty and the presentation was interesting (i.e. the consomme was poured into the vegetable ravioli by your waitress on the table). However, the taste was negatively correlated to the presentation. Smoked trout looked delicious but tasted like the 2 dollar smoked salmon from Safeway. Dungeness crab risotto is probably the biggest disappointment of the day since it tasted like wild rice drenched in tomato sauce and lemon.
author: Fred F.

description:
Went here for dine about town.

Now while this restaraunt was great and tasty. The atmosphere was a bit weird ... it seemed to be mainly post work people coming there. Considering the location this shouldn't have surprised me, however it just felt a bit off. The atmosphere wasn't too relaxed (and the bar was really crowded)

Food was excelllent though. I had the Caesar Salad, Pork Tenerloin, and flourless chocolate cake. No fresh pepper for the caesar salad? That was a bit of a disappointment. That's certainly a minus. The pork was juicy and tasty and yet didn't leave me feeling bloated and like a glutton.

Oh yes, the orange flavored tea was amazing. If you're a tea fan check it out.
author: Alex C.

description:
Got invited to a business dinner last night that I couldn't turn down last night.  I've tried to come here for lunch last year but reservations were needed.  Reservations were made by a colleague, but not really needed on a Thursday night. 3 stars is really more like 3.5 stars, I'm not a fan, but its a nice place to take a date or meet friends at. I wouldn't say I'll be a regular to this place.

Happy Hour - 4 stars
Its seems like a great place to grab a drink before you head home from working in the city.  The Ferry Building and Bart are close by, like a block.  The prices are cheap. There's a lot of young hip crowd. 

Dinner - 3.5 stars
Not sure if its a normal thing, but the chef made an amuse bush of duck pate, it was a wonderful and delicate bite of food.  Then again I'm a big fan of anything duck based. I got the duck breast cooked duck confit. It was cooked perfectly, but the fig paste thing that was to compliment the duck was over powering and wasn't appetizing.  

Service - 5 stars
The service staff are very accommodating and attentive.  My water was filled promptly and very courteous. Something I'd expect, if I was paying that much for dinner. 

Ambiance - 4
There's a rustic feel and a great place to have dinner. Very warm and intimate place.
author: Sid E.

description:
See profile site for full review with formatted pics.

It is a holiday Monday in San Francisco; you had Tartine for breakfast and were blown away, you had Boulevard for lunch and were very impressed - you want to keep with the great yet classic concept but your companions don't want "prix fixe" or a tasting menu.  You've wandered the wharf, Ghirardelli square, and even Coit tower and no find yourself in the financial district around 8:30pm.  Browsing the Michelin Guide you spot One Market and realize they're one of the few starred restaurants participating in Crab-Week - You love crab and rarely get anything fresh in Ohio - Sold.

Entering One Market around 8:30pm after securing free parking one immediately notes the large Michelin Star perched on the hostess station and next notices the boisterous bar on the right, beautiful restaurant on the left, open kitchen in the back, and large windows peering out onto the Embarcadero.  No reservations are no problem, jeans and a leather blazer not too upscale or too casual, a table by the window?  Sure.

Seating was prompt, wine offered and declined, water filled and menus delivered - our waiter Nelsen was much older than the other servers we met on our trip and while somewhat fuddling in his dish descriptions also had a level of respect and attentiveness to detail that was a nice change from the aloof approach at Boulevard that was later also experienced at Aqua, Bazaar, Osteria Mozza, and Chez Panisse Café.  After approximately 10 minutes Nelsen returned with a plate of sourdough rolls and took our orders.  The rolls were fair, but the icy cold butter was unimpressive at best.  Shortly after the bread arrived, a group of well dressed businessmen were seated close to our table and another server, similar in age to Nelsen, appeared to take care of their table.  Upon looking around, it appeared all the staff was more experienced and that each table had its own server - I'm unsure whether this speaks to the economy or just a style choice for the restaurant, but it was interesting to have such individualized service.

Five minutes after the orders were taken, a young lady emerged from the kitchen with an amuse bouche of seared toro and tomato compote with microbasil that more than made up for the butter, however.  Having never tasted toro before, my aunt was particularly impressed by this dish and I will note that the texture of the fish was every bit as good as any toro I've tried while the tomatoes were quite fresh and zesty.  Shortly after the amuse, our appetizers began to arrive.  Like many other meals, I personally opted for multiple appetizers in order to maximize taste experience without any masticatory boredom.

For myself, course one consisted of the Grilled Octopus with kabocha squash, asian pear, tamarind, pumpkin seeds.  A fan of Grilled Octopus, this version was remarkable in that it did not use a heavy handed citrus component like Babbo or Spiaggia, but instead focused on contrasting textures and highlighting the brininess of the Octopi.  Perfectly seared and succulent, the crunch of the seeds alongside the delicate squash was a great experience and certainly something I'll try to recreate in the future.  One of the best octopus dishes yet to grace my palate.

Dish one for my mother was the Dungeness Crab & Coconut Milk Soup with leeks, carrots, fennel, kaffir lime.  Beautifully plated tableside I can honestly say this dish was a huge miss for me.  While my mother liked it and was glad she ordered it, there was an undefined spice to the dish similar to a curry that refluxed on me throughout the night and left me with significant heart burn on my morning run the next day that actually required the purchase of TUMS.  My mom did not experience this, thankfully, but for me this dish left sour memories of the meal as a whole.

My next dish, another appetizer, was the Pan-seared Artisan Foie Gras with golden raisin puree and hazelnut crackle.  Having had multiple presentations of Foie in the past, at the time I consumed this dish it was the single best Foie Gras I had ever tasted and is still my favorite all time seared preparation (the cold terrines at TFL and Aqua were more "my style.")  Perfectly seared and large in portion, no veins and plenty of texture, the sweet raisin and candied hazelnut/apricot compote for texture - amazing and a must have dish.
author: Michael U.

description:
Good atmosphere for a business meeting.  Great service.  Their crab risotto was really amazing.  

However, the chicken consummate was a little bitter (North Beach Restaurant was much better) and the sand dab special was a little sour.  Overall, except the risotto, everything else was not too impressive.
author: Gin H.

description: I was sure I had written a review of One Market when we had a deal closing dinner there a couple years ago.  Apparently, I didn't.  Probably for the best since there's absolutely nothing in particular I can remember about that meal - not a good sign for a restuarant like One Market.  Anyway, this review is mostly about the bar where I went recently for a drink.  Not a terrible experience, but not great either.  The bar was comfortably full, but the bartender didn't seem in much of a rush to make sure everyone was served.  I still with beer since none of their wines by the glass interested me.  The heffeweisen I ordered didn't come with a lemon wedge and was a little on the warm side.  Still, it was a beer and I was fine with that.  But really, it was the effort it too to get the bartender to do his job that earns One Market just three stars this go 'round.
author: Ryan W.

description:
This is a review of the cocktail lounge at One Market. (I'd give it four stars for a business lunch place and 3 for a swanky dinner).  The One Market Bar belongs to the great triumvirate of Embarcadero drinking disappointments:  the bars at Hotel Vitale, One Market and Market Bar. All have the same ailments:  too many marketing clones, too crowded, bad service, expensive drinks.  

I like to enjoy my cocktails seated, with friends, food and some good people watching.  Balancing a martini on your laptop with your face smushed into the backside of some obese VP does not quite feel the same.
author: James E.

description:
I've been to One Market now twice for Dine About Town and both times it was a great experience.  Some places for a stigma with those diners who come in to try the restaurant for the DAT even though it's supposed to expose people to how great they are.  One Market does not make you feel like a leper.  The service is attentive and they don't make you wait for your whole party to get there before seating you.

The presentation both times for their soup was spectacular and the flavor was amazing.

This January I had the duck confit which was a bit of heaven.  I ordered the banana foster tart and it was delicious.

This place is a must if you are making a Dine about town list for next time.
author: Debora B.

description:
Came here last week to take advantage of their "Appetite Stimulas Plan" special.  Prix Fix for $35 including an appetizer, entree and dessert.

Appetizer consists of a warm grilled pear salad with cheese and candied walnuts.  

My dining companion ordered the olive oil poached fish dish (can't remember whether it was sea bass or cod).  It was very very good.  Cooked perfectly.  Fish came out tender and flaky.  Even the beans were nicely done (not mushy at all).  Even though the menu said it was olive oil poached, we didn't get the feeling that anything was greasy at all.  I ordered the pancetta wrapped pork tenderloin.  That was so flavorful with a roasted apple disk on the bottom and sauteed kale in the middle with the pork tenderloin on top.  Pork was done just right.  Still very juicy, very warm ... 

Dessert was a warm ginger cake with a dallop of somthing that's a little tangy.  Not sure what it was, and honestly, at first taste, I didn't even think it was all that great and wouldn't go with the ginger cake ... but as we dive further into it, I found myself fighting over it with my friend.

Very enjoyable meal.  I was pleasantly surprised.
author: Winnie C.

description:
still a fan of their butterscotch pudding... so freaking creamy! and the chantilly cream... oh... so perfect!  did i mention that to start off, i'm not a butterscotch or a pudding fanatic? but chef Bradley's butterscotch pudding... it's awesome!!

the entrees have been quite good the last couple of times i've been here... both lunches and dinners.  i always lean towards their fish because it's cooked well! their halibuts are good, poached any fish is good, hand picked dungeness crab is great! 

and i love that they use seasonal ingredients.  if they have a heirloom tomato anything... get it! The last time i had dinner there, their clam chowder was nom nom nom!! i'm still savoring that geoduck clam chowder!!
author: Kelly H.

description:
My business used to be located in the 1 Market office complex so this was a nice go to spot for celebrations, business lunches, or afterwork bar time. While never overtly dissappointed, it's safe to feel generally underwhelmed by this place. 

All the components of a great SF resto are here. 
great views-check
fresh semi-sustainable food-check
attentive staff-check
warm decorum-check

However, there is no pulse or livelihood to the place. Great for business lunches, sure , but I am in no rush to return there when my company is not picking up the tab.

Additionally, we had the private room on several occassions and in each instance definetly felt like we had been forgotten and utterly ignored. It's one thing to give the private room some privacy (duh) but its another to forget an entree and ignore our repeated shivering requests to turn down the damn AC.

Not to miss while there: crab cakes (sooo moist and fresh), sausage with lentils (nice balance of being satisfying without being heavy) and and the pot pie (creamy masterpiece with flaky crust perfection).

However, if you're walking down Market, these three dishes aren't enough to draw you in, considering youre in such a great food city....
author: Ali R.

description:
One Market's Michelin rating is well deserved.

We celebrated my brother's birthday by having dinner at One Market and it was one of the best culinary experiences I have ever had.

We had the tasting menu, a six course meal, plus foie gras to complement our meal.  Lucky for us, bottles of wine were served at half the cost.  We were able to enjoy our meal along with "Opus One."

The food was superb from the first course all the way through the sixth course.  Delectable flavors, perfect textures, delightful aromas, and beautiful presentation.  Food that appealed to almost all of your senses (I didn't hear any of it).

Service (by Bob) was great, despite the snafu with the wine bottle that broke in his hand.

We loved every minute of our dining experience and I look forward to my next experience.  Bon Appetit!
author: Annalynn C.

description: A really nice recent visit makes me revisit past experiences which were not so stellar. I took 8 teenagers there for a celebratory dinner and was impressed with seating (a round table for 9 of us was lovely) and the service.  A patient and gracious server treated us like royalty and did not seem chagrined by the inexperience of the diners or our lack of ordering alcohol.  The food was very good though I am not sure it rates a Michelin star, hence my 4-star rating. I would go back in the right circumstances, but I don't consider it particularly innovative and exciting for the price. A great business or celebration destination for the right group, but not a place to show off for true foodie friends. There is a lot of good here and some outstanding elements, but overall what I would expect from a top SF restaurant, in general. Solid but not awe-inspiring.
author: Andrea E.

description: delectable appetizers, stiff drinks, and had a great experience with the banquet person. Party of 12 is usually difficult to reserve in sf but they did it very easily.  Reception was great with a bar to the right of the entrance..the curtains were a bit old fashioned for an entrance but got a few giggles from our party. Dinner started promptly at 730 and we were finished by 945pm. Service was a bit spotty, our server didnt seemed overwhelmed but was albeit mishmash...food was overall great and as the drinks...for a one star michelin restaurant i expected a bit more on service...to put the icing on the cake was, one of our friends brought a dozen cupcakes which not all were eaten...we were charged $2.50 per cupcake for bringing it in..but not all of us ate it but still charged for 12 people..how rude and a bit sneaky. Should i come back? perhaps not right away, i have to forget about the bad cupcake experience first.
author: Dustin G.

description:
Took my husband here for his birthday after seeing Gordon Ramsey bring a group of his Hell's Kitchen contestants here as a prize for winning a challenge on the show.  It was the only restaurant he took them to in San Francisco and with all the various restaurants we have here, I figured that said something.

I loved the ambiance and the Vegan and Vegetarian options.  Plus, I really love that they use local foods.  My husband ordered a meat option for the a starter and a fish for the entree and was less impressed with those and liked my vegetarian and vegan dishes better.  Hence the 4 stars.  Overall though, a good experience :)
author: D S.

description: Went here for the Dine About Town, in which we got a good deal (3-course-dinner for $34.95). The food was good, and service was OK. The pork chops were outstanding, and portions were pretty good for a Michelin Star recipient.
author: Anne N.

description:
I came here for my office Christmas lunch, big spenders, high rollers and loads of wine glasses....

You know, chick pea french fries sounds like a good idea at first, but the feeling of sandpaper and cotton in my mouth is one I generally try to avoid.

The crabcakes were inventive, thick and flavorful. The duck risotto wasn't as powerful or creative as I thought it would be. I sampled someone's ravioli appetizer though and almost melted into my chair. That, and the wonderful pinot could've aided in my culinary orgasmic state.

It's a "suits" type of place. Too loud, too close to work and a bit pricey for less than extraordinary food. Don't get me wrong, the meal was fine and the service grand, but I don't need to come here again.

Unless I'm wooing a client or drinking with the devil-er,  I mean a lawyer.
author: Jessica P.

description: Didn't they read my Yelp review??? "Spotted: David Beckham, Vicky and the kids having lunch at One Market in San Francisco (around 3:00 P.M. Pacific) on Wednesday [June 18]."
author: Cheralyn H.

description:
2009 Dine About Town

Appetizer: 
* Caesar Salad - whole leaf, parmesan, croutons = too much dressing, but the croutons were delicious
* Golden Lentil Soup - poured fresh over the yogurt & cauliflower at your table = good balanced flavor, nice warm appetizer to get your taste buds going

Entree: 
* Braised Pork Short Ribs - over faro risotto & lacinto kale = a bit disappointing because half of the ribs were unedible due to excessive fat content and the top of the ribs were burnt and hard to chew while underneath it was so tender, the meat fell off the bones. the sauce was a little too heavy and sweet, tasted almost like teriyaki sauce. the risotto & kale were good though.
* Pan Seared Wild Steelhead - butter beans, fennel, baby carrots, pistou = i only had a bite of the fish, but it was deliciously cooked and much better than my ribs

Dessert: 
* Chocolate Toffee Almond Crunch Cake = delicious! not too crunchy, not too sweet, nice presentation, and comes with a spoonful of ice cream
* Mint Chocolate Chip Ice Cream Sandwich = not bad, but you have to like mint because the ice cream is very minty, but the chocolate cookie balances it out

Drink: 
* Blended Cranberry Lemonade - very light & fruity. more for a nice sunny lunch rather than a cold, drizzly night in january

Service was good although I think the bussers were better than the actual servers, the decor is comfortable and sophisticated, noise level is okay. Dress code was mixed with some people wearing suits and others in jeans. Great place for a business dinner.
author: Linda C.

description:
So my fiance proposed to me.  Then we went to One Market after picking up my new diamond ring.  NOTHING COULD GET ME DOWN, RIGHT?

Wrong.  We went in for dinner - the menu was uninspiring, the service was mediocre (I had to explain why we were ordering champagne and they didn't even congratulate us on our pending nuptuals).  Worst part was, there were start-up companies getting funded on either side of us - or so it seemed.  Nervous, fidgetty, well-dressed young entrepreneurs barely eating but grabbing the tab while speaking seriously about plans for profitability with older white-haired men.  Our fault for choosing a Financial District spot, but puh-lease - do you hafta be so boring?  :)

Could've been a low-night, but it should've been one of the most memorable of my life and it was rather disappointing.  2 stars for an average evening and for not celebrating our engagement properly - any restaurant worth it's salt should at least congratulate good news.
author: Tanya S.

description: My husband and I ate at One Market last night.  We weren't expecting much from the service because of some of the negative reviews, but our waiter was great.  The food was delicious.  I had the three course menu with wine pairings and my husband had the 4 course "Beast of the Week" menu with wine pairings.   My favorite dish from the evening was the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin.
author: Kristina R.

description:
You know, I genuinely like this place but I wouldn't go out of my way on a non-workday to eat here. It is great for what it is - a nice place for a business lunch if you work in the FiDi and need a central location that anyone can find. 

I see raves about the desserts but have never tried them (I guess I will next time). They make a mean Arnold Palmer and I like the Vegetarian's Choice for lunch (any four of the veggie side dishes). I like variety and they use local farmer's market stuff so that kind of rocks.
author: Julie C.

description: Had our holiday party a couple years back here.  They put us in the back and outside of the main restaurant. The service was alright and so was the food.  Probably won't be back for a holiday party, but still not too shabby.
author: Brian G.

description: Good DAT menu for lunch, but regarding the service, if the staff is not excited about Dine about Town, don't offer it!
author: D T.

description:
Wow, what a disappointment. Food was decent... ya, maybe Michelin quality, but the service/ambiance was very... Outback Steak House. 

Ambiance - crowded, LOUD, huge... which probably plays in to the: 
Service - hole in napkin (which wasn't folded when I left for the bathroom), clueless waitress, wait staff kept reaching across me to pour water, slow, served a drink with wine dripping off the bottom of the glass... ya, I know, I'm very nit-picky... but these are the thing that I expect to be perfected at a restaurant w/ these prices.

Food - started with the amuse-bouche little seared tuna w/ wasabi caviar, good start, not unique... next we shared a mussels w/ a saffron soup, highlight of the meal... couple entrees: bacon wrapped pork tenderloin and sea bream w/ dungeness crab; both were okay, sea bream was a fairly undercooked, pork tenderloin was very mediocre... then for dessert we had the 3 "mini" platter and the creamsicle; the 3 mini weren't mini at all (some advance notice of this would have been nice by the wait staff... good for you fat asses out there) and the creamsicle has been done many-a-times at various restaurants I have been to, and this example was unworthy of the creamsicle name. 

... So, would I ever go back... no... ranks at the bottom of the list at my attempt to eat at every Michelin restaurant (granted I am only 6 restaurants in... but besides the point)
author: Ryan A.

description:
Came here for a special night out a few weeks ago. Had the ahi, my husband had the scallops. The waiter & chef were very accommodating of some special allergy-related requests. 

Overall, a great time but I have to say I think this is better for business lunches. It's nice and bright during the day, but the space is a little voluminious for a romantic night out.
author: Erin H.

description:
Rip Off. 

But, I probably ordered the wrong thing.
author: Misha F.

description:
The Best Happy Hour in the Financial District!  
This place rocks!  The happy hour prices can't be beat and it has a great atmosphere.  Check out Brian and Marcelino behind the bar on Thursday's and Friday's, they will take good care of you........and if you are looking for wine recommendations be sure to ask for Steve, the Sommelier, he is the BEST!  :)
author: Star S.

description:
One Market happy hour is far and beyond the best downtown, and  Brian's Bourbon Refresher is the best drink on their menu....
I highly recommend Thursday night when Brian (best looking bartender in the city) and Marcelino (best bar back in the city) are behind the bar!
author: MO L.

description:
This is probably the least pretentious Michelin star restaurant I've ever been to, which definitely boosts my impression of it.  We were running a little late, but the reservationist was very understanding.  We actually found street parking on Stuart, too (Friday night), though there's a garage available for the building.

I love the large open windows with the view of the bridge, ferry building, and bay.  The bread is warm and crusty and one of the best I've had in a while.  The amuse bouche of duck liver was way too organ-tasting for me, unfortunately.

My boyfriend got the deluxe dine about town menu with wine pairings (additional $15), which was a good deal.  The interesting white blend is usually $13 per glass, and the pinot noir is in the $10-12 range, too.  The pinot noir was very smooth, and the pours were very generous.  

He started with the asparagus soup with an organic poached egg.  The soup itself, poured tableside, was very green and tasted very pure and clean, but the egg, parmesan, and pancetta added much more dimension to it, enhancing the flavors a lot.  He then had the duck breast with duck confit, which is the least gamey tasting duck I've ever had.  The duck itself was cooked perfectly tender and not too fatty.  For once, it was not combined with a cherry sauce like most places do - instead, it was paired with a coffee flavored puree and huckleberries, which I enjoyed a lot. It was refreshing to have a novel preparation of the duck. 

I started with the beet carpaccio, which was a gorgeous deep red color, looking almost like a beef carpaccio.  It came with a tangy vinaigrette but wasn't overdressed, and there was mild goat cheese scattered with some micro greens, corn flakes, and thinly sliced radish.  This is one of the most innovative beet dishes I've had, and it's up there among my favorites, along with the beet layer cake from Spago.

I went with another appetizer for my main - the crab salad.  The crab meat was very generous, with claw meet scattered with grapefruit segments around the plate and also a mound of shredded meat in the center underneath a cooling olive oil sorbet.  The sorbet was a nice, smooth, temperature contrast, but it didn't taste much like olive oil.  The crab was fresh and sweet and not masked by the gelatin like dressing that it sat in.  It was a pretty cool preparation, once again.. not the typical crab salad in a martini glass.

For dessert, we had the valrhona chocolate souffle cake, which was light, very chocolatey, and not overly sweet.  The whipped mascarpone on top was light, and the milk chocolate ice cream was smooth.  I'm not a big fan of raspberries with chocolate, but the raspberry wasn't overdone.  It was perfect paired with strong coffee.

Service wasn't bad, except when they forget to tell us which wine we received with the 1st course.  It was a busy night, but dishes came out and were cleared at a good pace.  One thing that I really appreciated about the service was that the waiter made sure I knew the 18% gratuity had already been included, which I've never had anyone else do.  

I love the younger crowd, the more casual yet classy ambiance, the unpretentiousness, and the innovative takes on more traditional dishes.  The setting is so nice by the waterfront, and prices are very reasonable. It's definitely one of my new favorites!
author: Marilyn H.

description:
Thank goodness for dine about town because otherwise, One Market would not be part of my reviews!  The ambiance is lovely, though I did feel like my salary was 100,000 bucks less than everyone else there.  Our waiter was, just average, not really knowledgeable or personable, (which sort of surprised me for a Micheline star restaurant), but the food was excellent.  I had the mushroom pot pie (and they assembled it table side) and the Cesar salad (not quite as good as Zuni's but still tasty) and the chocolate crunch cake.  All were great.  My friends had the short ribs and the fish and both noted they were solid.  

One thing I really liked was the fact that they had regular 10 buck desserts and 5 buck desserts.  I thought that since it was a fancy restaurant, I was going to get like an amuse bouche of a dessert when I ordered the 5 bucker, and I was pleasantly surprised!

All in all, a good place for a super fancy business dinner or birthday celebration.  Not my favorite restaurant but certainly worth the good reviews.  Next time, if I ever strike at rich, or go again next year, I will splurge and get some sides!
author: Annie F.

description:
The place has fine food, good atmosphere, and fantastic location. I have been going there for years, but lately the service has been quite pushy to move people in and out. It is a business and turnover is key to restaurants. The busboy last time grabbed our plates before we were finished with our meal. It has happened twice during our last five visits. So there was only two bites left on one of the plates. Once busboys fingers touched the plate it was a no u-turn situation. The waiter commented 'it was not like he took away the whole meal' and offered nothing to our guest. 

In a time of a changing economy, they can do better, much better. Maybe there was a management change.
author: Martha G.

description: Went for a biz lunch. Great food. Amazing waiter. My buddy was unsure of what wine to have with lunch and the waiter did an impromptu 'blind taste test' rather than just recommend the more expensive wine. Impressive. He got a big tip and the 1M picked up a customer for life (as long as someone else flashes plastic, that is~)
author: Brian B.

description:
Went here for Happy Hour and I have to say the cocktails were very good. They have all there martini's for $5.00 and they use premium vodka. Very nice! They don't really have any specials on bar bites but we went ahead and tried the Chicken Pots for $12. Not really my thing. 
You get 6 chicken drumsticks with the meat pulled off the bone. They where swimming in sour cream and a red hot sauce. 
Drinks are one of the best deals I have found. Service was not the best, but I will be back. Place did fill up by 5:30.
author: Lisa A.

description:
When your typical splurge for lunch out includes Chipotle or the occasional burger, a Dine About Town prix fixe lunch like this is pretty sweet.  Our group of eight got out for $260, including gratuity, two glasses of wine, a few lemonades, and two french fry appetizer plates.

I had no idea about the lemonade.  I'm not one to get excited about lemonade.  But this was some tasty lemonade, even on a gloomy, rainy Friday.  I got the mint lemonade, which appears to have a mint infused simple syrup on the bottom.  Served over crushed ice (is there any better ice?), this was a very nice surprise.

You MUST try the chickpea fries.  And I'm not one to brag about chickpeas.

I went with the portobello mushroom soup, the tri-tip, and the chocolate pot de creme.  I experienced my first soy flan and quail egg with my soup.  I thought the flan added a nice texture.  The tri-tip was a tiny bit on the dry side, but tender nonetheless.  The side of mashed potatoes and chard was a pleasant surprise.  And the dessert . . . I'm still high on the dessert.  I thought it hit the right balance of sweet, but not overly rich.

All in all this was a five-star experience in my book.  The service was fast and attentive.  The food was several cuts above my typical lunch treats and worth every dime.
author: Daryl E.

description:
I took a colleague here for a last minute business lunch. It was handy because I work in the building and it gives all the appearance of a nice restaurant with a foodie menu. The best part was that I was able to make a reservation for 2 at OpenTable.com about 20 minutes ahead of time. Some other nearby places like Boulevard won't let you make same day reservations online at the last minute. I was in a bit of a Denny's mood so I kicked it with the Petaluma Three Egg Open-Faced Omelet with Sonoma goat cheese. 

It was one of the most disgusting meals I've ever had. 

If it weren't for the bread at the table, I would have been SOL. The service was decent, but this place is really about the convenience and location. The lunchtime volume is just a little bit louder than I'd like, but workable. If you have the option, go to any of the other restaurants on the block... FAZ, Chaya, Ozumo, Boulevard... hell, even Quizno's is better.
author: Bernadette D.

description: One Market has the best business lunch in the City.  The food is good at dinner but extraordinary at lunch.  Try the trout, spiced perfectly, or the little gem salad which has a vinaigrette dressing with a hint of curry or turmeric.  Crab cakes are tiny but pure crab, a delicious mouth full.  Mini desserts are just the right size to share if you are watching calories.  Soups are elegant.  Prices are good considering the quality.  The food is innovative so if you are looking for typical seasonings you may be unhappy.  This is a restaurant for foodies.  Service is adequate and cheerful. The setting is lovely along the Embarcadero.
author: Jeanne D.

description:
for some reason, i never had any desire to come here before, but we had a big family dinner last night, and i was impressed.  service was great, and the food was delicious. 

we started off sharing the caesar salad, roasted aspargus salad, dungeness crab, and another app w/ a smoky salmon topped w/ a poached egg, all on top of a potato latke.  i have no idea if that was what it was exactly (i didn't look at the menu), but it sure tasted good.  the other salads were simple and not particularly memorable, but the salmon was definitely my fave.

after all that, we then all got the 3 course prix fixe.  i started w/ a cherry gazpacho, which sounded interesting, but it was a tad sweet and could have been a dessert.  for my entree, i got the halibut sous vide, which was delicate and delicious.  

the desserts were the highlight of the meal.  i ordered the mint chocolate chip ice cream sandwich, and you can tell the ice cream was made w/ really fresh mint leaves.  my cousin thought it tasted like toothpaste, but i liked it.  also good were the toffee crunch chocolate cake and the nectarine pie verrine, which was like a peach pie, reconstructed.  

their wine list consists of only american wines, and we tried 3 bottles, which were all good (including a cakebread sauvignon blanc).
author: Helen T.

description:
After reading the recent SF Chronicle review of this place, I was pretty excited and looking forward to the dining experience. Then, I checked Yelp and there were a lot of people who were dissatisfied with the place, so that got me a little wary.

In any case, our party had a pretty nice dinner here. I can understand the comments made by both sides.

Everyone at the table had the 6 course tasting menu, including one vegetarian. That must earn kudos, how many places can boast a great 6 course vegetarian tasting menu? In fact, I was a little envious of all the creative vegetarian dishes landing across the table from me as I think the veggies really stand out here.

The six course tasting menu ($75/person) consisted of  the dungeness crab salad (creative use of the celery root and celery sorbet- never had that before with an appetizer), the sauteed wild gulf shrimp (cleaning the green chile vinaigrette of the plate), duck ravioli with foie gras emulsion (i think i prefer my foie gras in solid form), day scallop, and lavender rubbed lamb (really tender succulent lamb, wish I had more), and a choice of dessert.  I picked the chocolate toffee almond crunch cake (i.e., essentially a chocolate toffee bar). I tasted other people's desserts, including the vanilla and espresso creme brulee and the butterscotch pudding topped with a LOT of whipped cream (yummy!). 

Everyone liked the food. The atmosphere was a little more business-like and louder than I would have wanted for an intimate dinner with friends, but what do you expect from such a big restaurant? Service at the front desk was attentive but our serving staff could have been a little more professional. Overall, I was glad I visited and if I happen to be in the area, I might drop by again.
author: Prista C.

description: I love me some One Market... Best thing on the menu is the smoked trout app...  YUMMO!  Had my wedding reception here, so maybe I'm a little biased also... BUT I've never been disappointed with the food.
author: Robyn B.

description:
Food: 4+
Decor: 4
Service: 3
Atmosphere: 3+

I went with a group of friends to One Market during the Dine-About-Town special earlier this year.  We all had a great time and really enjoyed the meal.  The oysters we started with were fantastic and the sea bass entree was delectable.  OK, we ended up straying far from the Dine-About-Town selection and paying a lot more than $30/person or whatever, but it was worth it.  The foie gras was particularly delightful.

Our service that night was admittedly so-so, and I was most disappointed with the wine recommendations, which didn't match what I asked for nor did they match our food.  On previous visits, service has never been an issue.  I once went in with a friend and sat at the counter where you can overlook the kitchen, and the (former) executive chef was super friendly and styled us with a few extras.

Although I have not been in a few months, I felt compelled to write this review in protest to the low ratings from others.  I have simply always had a pleasurable dining experience here with the food being the star attraction.
author: Nate B.

description:
I couldn't decide how I felt about this place. So for starters I LOVED the mint arnold palmer and the lump crab meat salad. Seriously I would not normally pay $15 for a salad, but  it was AMAZING. Even comes with a little celery sorbet. 

For entree I had the crab & chorizo pasta.. which I didn't realize until I got it. I love chorizo and I LOVE crab meat.. but put them together and you have a really strange tasting dish. My mouth was a bit confused... 

Our waitress was a very friendly french? (i think) lady who was really helpful and humorous. 

I will go back.. if only for that amazingness they call a salad..
author: Sarah W.

description:
Note: I am reviewing only the SF Dine About Town menu.

So I had initially reserved a table for five for a late Friday night dinner, SF Dine About Town menu.  On Friday night, two more friends tell me they'd like to tag along and, on top of that, we all might be slightly late.  I call One Market, expecting the hostess to hang up on me but, instead, she politely accommodated my requests and accepted our new party of seven and delayed arrival.

THEN, then - silly me, I get lost in SF (I know, I know - lame).  I call my friend in a panic and she hands the phone over to the hostess.  I thought the hostess was going to hang up on me but, again, she pleasantly surprised me - and freakin' STAYED ON THE PHONE with me until I arrived at the restaurant. WTF.  Who does that?!?  She gave me directions, made sure I got to the restaurant successfully - and even waited outside for me!!  WTF.  Bless her!!  I bet she's the kind of friend who takes care of her drunkard friends, buys food for homeless people and dedicates her life to serving and helping people.  That's one extra star on top of a wonderful evening and a wonderful meal.

Speaking of food, if any of y'all go to One Market for Dine About Town this time around, you MUST order the black bean soup, the skatewing and the butter tart.  Holy mother of God.  I've never had skatewing before but, it was AMAZING.  AMAZING.  And who knew black bean soup could be so dang delicious?!?  Dayamn.  My friends who ordered the other choices on the Dine About Town menu were not as pleased.  Muahahaha.  But I was a good friend and let them pick off my plate.  :)  

Agreed that the crowd is very "Financial District' and it's not a very trendy, upscale or dressy restaurant.  But, it still has a lovely ambiance and there are huge windows, great for people watching and natural lighting.  

Overall, I was incredibly impressed with the level of service and food and would absolutely recommend One Market.  Waitress, whoever you are, seriously - bless you.  

Good choice, Nancy (pat on the back).
author: Nancy L.

description:
I thought One Market was wonderful and would happily return and recommend it. While many places around these parts are into farm-to-table cuisine, I get annoyed when I spend $15 for the best pear ever as my dessert course. When I go out to eat, I want the experience to be more than competent trawling of the farmer's market. To paraphrase Mystikal, show me what you're workin' with! One Market did so. The food highlighted the ingredients in all their seasonal glory, but had enough technique and presentation to be exciting.

The other thing I really liked about it was that the menu was designed for a lot of different price-levels. You could go there and be perfectly satisfied with a relatively affordable dinner (3 course prix fixe menu with limited options, easy on the alcohol for $39/person), or you could splash out with a $79 tasting menu. Same with drinks, dessert menu, the whole bit.

My meal:
Grilled octopus that had been sous vide first, over pureed kabocha squash with pear and tamarind sauce. The octopus was tender and tasty and the flavor and texture contrasts through the dish were great.
Then Pan Roasted Domestic Lamb Loin w/chick peas, wild ramps, cocoa reduction. I don't know what ramps are, but the lamb was perfect.
Also added the farmer's market side ($6.75) of sauteed baby artichokes, which were simple and great.
You can do seasonal desserts for $10, which is a decent portion, or mini desserts for $5.75 each or $15 for 3 if you want tastes of awesome but conserve cost.
We shared the chocolate souffle cake with raspberry pinot noir compote (huzzah!) and strawberry business thing with almond brioche and ricotta cream (sha-zam!).
author: Nato G.

description: Great place for a not-too-expensive sophisticated lunch. Fast, friendly service. Bright, airy, but not-too-loud ambiance. Really good food, presented really well.
author: Michael C.

description: The atmosphere for Christmas was wonderful.  The waiter was an experienced man.  But, the food was disappointing and could have been top notch had it not been over salted.  Three of us had the prime rib and it was cooked to perfection.  But, the salt overpowered and burned out palettes.   Wine list is lovely and the wine steward very gracious.  Too bad for the entrees.  We passed on dessert.
author: Kathleen F.

description:
Just go for Happy Hopur when its not busy.  Typical hapy hour crowd in the financial district area. The food way overpriced for what you get. Don't mind paying for really good food. I do mind paying a lot for food that doesn't wow me at all. This is the happy hour spot we love and we hate. It's in our building so the coworkers go there almost every week yet complain that it sucks but end up going there every week. Its in our building so its convienent. Nice  tall draft beers for 2.50 and they usually have some drinks specials for happy hour. 

The fries are good. 

Gets a littel crowded for happy hour on fridays but during the week its not so bad.
author: Hyung L.

description:
Well, the unexpected!  This restaurant is yet unrated?  Amazing!  Just for now, anyway, I will post this and then await correction.  

First time last night I had an excuse to walk to the Absolute End of Market Street for something other than the ferry building!  Something is actually open evenings along there besides BART?  Dine About Town and a MeetUp dining group instigated a try, and this turned out well.  

A good sized pile of good food for a fair price, and the special Dine About Town selections were a real attraction.  

More later when I find out if this really is the name of the restaurant.  
;-)
author: Joe J.

description:
Okay, this place is VERY pricey.  Expect to spend a lot of $$$.  I was here on a date. Thankfully, I did not chose this place but then again I wouldn't of even considered it in the first place so I guess I am glad I went. 

The wine selection was pretty good, our waitress was really nice and knowledgeable. We ordered the prime rib dish for 2 with a side of spinach and garlic mashed potatoes. It was really good, I just didn't think it was worth the money.
author: Inga B.

description:
Delish! 

I went here for a business lunch and bottles of wine were half off. It was exactly what I love about great San Francisco dining- farmers market fresh ingredients and rich flavors while still perfectly simple.

The seafood was excellent and I enjoyed the ambiance. 

I would definitely try it for dinner next time I'm in town!
author: Brooke R.

description: Lunch this afternoon with a friend. The place was absolutely packed with holiday celebrations, yet we were promptly seated and service was excellent. The dining room is lovely and many tables have views of the Ferry Building and the water (as ours did). I ordered the crab salad. It was a "composed" affair with bits of fennel and pomegranate, but was a ridiculously small portion (even though I did order the entree size, not the appetizer size). My friend ordered a "goat ham" sandwich, which was, on the other hand, a hearty portion. The food was good, fresh and artistically plated. However, alas, my salad, although tasty, was just not a lunch portion. Consdering the price, that was unacceptable.
author: Joanna S.

description: One of the best meals and service I've had in a long time with a great atmosphere.  Oysters, asparagus salad, duck with "tots" on the side were all exceptional.
author: Emily S.

description: My experience at One Market can be summed up in one word: Eh. I came here for lunch, and I just wasn't all that impressed. I had the flat iron steak, which was juicy and tender.. but nothing spectacular. My sister wanted to order the cavatelli and dungeness crab, but the waitress failed to tell us they didn't have it on the menu for the day until after we ordered.. off to a bad start. She settled on hamburger with fries, but she didn't seem to enjoy it very much. The fries were dry. The service was also lacking. Our glasses were never refilled, and the waitress barely came around. Not worth the bucks.
author: Sophia B.

description: The menu has changed and the sides of vegetables are no longer offered. The dish I ordered was pretty good but it won't be the same without sides.
author: Susan C.

description:
July was 1/2 off a bottle of wine.  Will look for it again next year.  : )
Had a burger which was cooked superbly but I not a fan of the big fries (bigger than wedges).
author: David L.

description: 1 word, BLAND! i would expect more creativity and flavor from a $150 bill. the highlight of the night, the $30 glass of port.
author: Edward R.

description: One Market is one of my favorite San Francisco restaurants.  My lunch yesterday did not disappoint.  The food was good and the service was excellent.  My trout was not the best dish that I have had there hence the four stars, but it still ranks on my SF top ten list.
author: Hugh L.

description:
Came here with my two friends for the appetite stimulus plan. I had the pear salad, black cod, and gingerbread ice cream for $35. The food is what you expect, delicious but teeny tiny portions. The black cod basically melted in my mouth. Too bad I don't like olives, or I'm sure the side would have been great too. My friend's pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon was AMAZING. SO delicious. Melts in your  mouth.

Service was unexpectedly slow. We got there at 7 and left at 9:30pm. The service between entree and dessert and getting the bill was really slow. It was like our waiter disappeared! Maybe it's because we looked like we were 18. 

I don't think I'd come here if it weren't for the special prix fixe menu since it would still leave me hungry after the meal was over.
author: Angela L.

description: Worst steak ever...couldn't believe how bad it was.  Maybe the rest of the menu is okay but considering the prices, I'm not willing to take that chance.  Sorry dudes, I'm sure you'll get along just fine without my cash :-)
author: Gabriel F.

description:
I expected more from a Michelin rated restaurant - Yelper 

I agree. 

Starters:
- Hand-picked Dungeness Crab Salad
pink grapefruit, cilantro olive oil sorbet 
- Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout "Mi Cuit" 
potato rösti, organic chicken egg, pancetta vinaigrette

Main:
- Alaskan Halibut "Sous Vide"
mustard green ravioli, shiitake mushrooms, bean sprouts, mushroom-dashi broth
- Bacon-wrapped Pork Tenderloin
dandelion "persillade", salsify, natural jus

** marbled potatoes

Dessert:
- Market Fruit Sorbet
- Tahitian Creme Brulee

I think this is a great place for people who are interested in experimenting fine dining. Great price too. Once you have tried other places like Mina or Danko, you can differentiate each chef's own creativity and style.
author: Ken C.

description: Portions were larger than I expected. Service was very good. Location of large table by kitchen was fantastic! But halibut was just okay. Loved the variety on the menu i.e.Sturgeon, beets, cows tongue (was very good). My wife and I enjoyed our steaks, and I especially liked the mashed potatoes (very buttery). She liked the caesar salad, but for me the anchovy was a little too strong. I would get dressing on the side next time. Soufle and creme brûlée was wonderful. A quality place for a special event like a birthday.
author: Steve R.

description:
Perfect location, great farm-fresh ingredients, perfectly executed.  Mm, mmm.  They have a great big table right by their open kitchen for large parties, where you can watch the cooks in action and still feel part of the main floor bustle.  

Got the pureed white bean soup with garlic flan and lean bacon.  One of those deals where you get the flan, bacon and chives in the dry bowl, and then they come and pour the rich bean puree around it.  Great presentation, super delicious. Not too garlicky.

Pouched halibut (in grapeseed oil apparently) with the most fragrant, rich, cracked dungeness crab emulsion and shaved asparagus.  Mm.

And a little strawberry rhubarb crumble so perfectly sweet-tart with crumbly buttery crust.  Great meal...... And only $30 as part of the commemorative Earthquake Dinners all week.   Only 4 stars because there are just way too many suits and ties in one room at one time.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Here for DAT on Friday night and it was great!  You really can't beat the location.  Be sure to ask for a booth by the window for optimum people-watching-clock-tower-looking views.  

We stopped at the bar for a drink before while we waited for the others in our group to arrive.  The drinks were strong (just what the doctor ordered after a long ass week) and the bar staff was very friendly.  We were promptly seated when the whole party arrived at a great seat that had a view of all the action. We brought two bottles of wine to be corked and the waiter was very gracious about opening them.  I've had experiences where they give you dirty looks or act exasperated because you're not drinking their wine.  

They then brought us complimentary duck livers on little toasts.  I don't do bird organs (or any organs really...) so I passed, but the others said they were ok.  Had the black bean soup which was served with crunchy little calamari strips on top.  Delishhhh!  Followed shortly thereafter by the DELICIOUS pork ribs.  The meat was incredibly tender and the beans and greens it was served over were divine.  Someone got the skate wing, however, I wasn't blown away by it.  For dessert we all got the brown butter pear tart, but since we had such a hard time deciding, they also brought us the strawberry creme dessert, free of charge.  They were both delicious!  If I didn't care about looking like the heffer at the table, I would have eaten everyone's leftovers.  Oh wait, I did.  

The bill came and the waiter had waived the corkage fee for both bottles.  The service at One Market was by far the best service I have received in SF.  They are incredibly attentive without being overly so and just so very nice and accomadating!  

This wasn't my favorite meal ever, so I can't give it 5 stars, but this place did NOT disappoint!
author: Kathleen B.

description:
I'll be succinct as possible seeing as almost everything was stellar: exceptional service (the Asian gal that served us was amazing), an amazing wine list, and entrees that were acceptable.

There wasn't anything out of the ordinary in the way of entrees that made the hairs on the back of my neck stand up, but the duck dish I has was exceptional. 

Without a doubt a phenomenal place for a special occasion.
author: Rodney P.

description: Mediocre food, bad service. The hostess was giving us major attitude. I would not go back.
author: Maggie L.

description:
After a many-year hiatus, I decided to give One Market a try again after a friend (very generously) offered to treat me to a belated birthday dinner.  

Sadly, I was disappointed in some key areas, most of which where I expected One Market to really shine. First off, we arrived a few minutes before 7 pm on a Tuesday for a 7:15 pm reservation. We ducked into the bar to grab a happy hour drink before happy hour ended at 7. The bartender snapped that we were too late and when I said it wasn't yet seven, she got really uppity about it. "Well it is according to my computer, so don't look at me." Her tone was completely out of line and off-putting as I hadn't even raised my voice to her.

They gave us a really nice table to sit at, and the server was had was very attentive and nice. I perused the wine list, tho, and my eyes nearly fell out of my head. Almost 70 bones for a bottle of Honig red? Come ON! This place is seriously lacking in the reasonable wine department, or they just cater to tourists who think good wine's gotta cost a Benjamin... so not true. So, we ordered a $110 bottle of Silver Oak (if you're gonna splurge a little, go for it, right), but were told they were out of it. So, we found a nice bottle of T-Vine at a more modest markup. 

The food is where this place really excelled. Even the bread we got was amazing. Wonderfully warmed French and olive rolls. Too bad when I wanted a second olive roll, they were out of those, too. My portabello soup was delicious, and the steak I had was fantastic. Totally flavorful and cooked to perfection. My dinner companion wanted the Tuesday special, but they were out of that, too. At 7:30 pm? Did they serve them for lunch?

The trio of desserts we opted for were indeed delicious, and the server was very thoughtful in his presentation and odd (but kinda charming) insistence that I take a birthday shot. 

So, the food made One Market surely did delivery on Bradley Ogden's expertise in the area of New American dining. Still, the service and--what do you call them--inventory? blemishes on my evening there were noticeable and recurring. Considering the many other choices at this dining level, it may be some time before I go back.
author: Aaron L.

description: Excellent food and great service! The Alaskan Halibut was to die for! Will definitely visit this place again when I visit San Fran!
author: Christina H.

description: I came to One Market last week for the first time in a really long time with my boyfriend and a friend of ours visiting from New York. My boyfriend and I arrived early and had a glass of wine in the bar and ordered the calamari. Wine was good, calamari was just ok. It was very fresh which was great, but the coating on the outside kept falling off so all the flavoring went with it. When our friend arrived we went over to the dining room - the service was great. That was really my only real positive experience about the place. The food - just ok. Nothing really impressed me or stood out. I had the gnocchi - not very good, and a very small portion. The desserts were just ok too. I would have given this review 3 stars because everything was just "ok" but the price made me push it to a 2-star review. It was far too expensive for the food. Ambiance was good, service was good, but everything else wasn't.
author: Courtney E.

description:
I go to One Market for business lunches, where I did not get to pick the restaurant.  The food is just extremely mediocre and not worth the price.

I have tried a variety of appetizers, most of the fish dishes, and some of the pasta dishes -- everything virtually forgettable.  Their main dishes tend to be overseasoned, which is a shame considering that they do actually use fresh, high quality ingredients.  The 2 course "business lunch" (salad and usually a choice between a fish or chicken dish) for $23 is a popular option.

I have had one outstanding dish here - it was a lentil and cauliflower soup seasoned with indian spices.  It was extremely interesting and flavorful yet subtle - basically, nothing like their other food.  Definitely get it If it is on the menu and you like soup.

The location and ambiance are admittedly great, and the service is consistently good.  So I guess I would recommend this place if you are ok with mediocre food made from high quality ingredients, and want to impress someone with the locale.
author: Leslie L.

description:
What a pretty place! I took my BF and two others to celebrate my Bf's birthday. The ambiance was impeccable as my small group of 4 excitedly awaited our order. 2 halibut, one red snapper and for me the vegetarian squash skewers. The shock was deafening as the halibut was brought to the table and it appeared to be the portion size fit for a 9 year old. The small size was bad enough but The taste of snapper was "mediocre" and so was the squash. To add salt to the wound, the price for such small portions of mediocre food was outrageous. We dine out relatively often and do not mind paying extraordinary prices for extraordinary food. We were bamboozled..lol.. The food here was simply not great. not worth the price at all.

We will NOT return to One Market again. 

The good:
ambiance, location, Service was ok. and they did bring out a nice plate of dessert for the birthday man. (I left a memo on the open table reservation that we were celebrating a bday--- that was a nice touch)

The bad:
mediocre food, way overpriced, only serve sparkling wine and mostly from California, no champagne ;-(

The ugly: 
mediocre food, way overpriced
author: Zetha N.

description:
I came here for a meeting having always contemplated coming for Dine About Town. I'm kind of glad I didn't waste my money previously.

Don't get me wrong. The food wasn't bad. It just wasn't anything special and certainly not what people had built it up to be. I had a salad, flatiron steak and a chocolate souffle thingy for dessert. And it was just so...plain!

I mean I felt like I could be eating food at TGI Friday's. Service was generally good. And the bread was yummy. So how come the rest of the meal couldn't match up?

Disappointed. :-(
author: Aaron F.

description:
Absolutely THE worst Irish Coffee ever. I don't even think it was the way the bartender made the drink. It was the coffee. ACK! HORRIOUS! And they have an espresso machine, so what gives?

On the flip side, I really enjoyed my lunch. A lot. I had the Farmer's Salad and the Mushroom Risotto. I am usually loath to order any risotto at a restaurant because its usually crap. But this really stood out. It was really good. Fresh herbs on top. I took a bite and this explosion of freshness happened. It was joyful.

The wine made up for the bad coffee. But bad coffee where you have a gigantor espresso machine is just not acceptable.
author: Marz W.

description:
Avoid going during DAT.  Avoid taking the 9pm seating.  Avoid the mushroom soup.  Avoid the overcooked scallops.  

In all fairness, I should probably try going when it's not DAT.
author: K W.

description:
