I really liked this restaurant, and would give it a five except for a few shortcomings. First the positives-happy hour is cheap and the well liqour is decent. After a couple of greyhounds we moved into the dining room. I ordered a garden salad, mahi mahi, and spinach. The salad was delicious-the dressing was just the right amount and ithe veggies were really crisp and delicious.  The mahi mahi was flavored just right, flaky and buttery, and a good side portion. The spinach was amazing, cooked with big garlic chips.

For desert we got the mini platter with the lemon cheesecake, mint choclate chip ice cream cookie, and a choclate toffee thing that tasted like a heath bar. The cheescake was delicious as was the toffee thing, however the mint choclate chip thing was overly minty and inedible.I also had a latte for desert, but they didnt have skim milk, so I had to have 2% which I don't love.

The service was great. Our server really balanced out giving my sister and I who hadn't seen each other in six months room to talk, but also offered seamless service andgood suggesstions of food and wine pairing. She didn't rush us at all.

The downside. The bathroom was quite dirty. Two of the stalls were filthy and I was pretty amazed such a swanky place had a bathroom in such array. The other downside was that the room was too dark-they went a little over board on the mood lighting.

Our tab was $130. I won't pay that much for a meal, but we were on my sister's treat. Great place, but I can't afford to go back.
author: Kim C.

description: Great Ambiance , Good Appetizers and just decent main course , over all experience is just OK , would probably give it a try again....
author: Yulenka M.

description: If you stop by Friday or Saturday nights, as we did, you can opt for the Weekly Beast, in which the adventurous yet skillful chef Mark Dommen creates a 4-course feast using the theme "beast" of the week (in our case, Albacore Tuna from Oregon). The optional 4-course wine pairing makes the meal a delight for all senses.
author: Dave G.

description:
Food is OK, overpriced, main dish is too salty. Service is good. Nothing specials.
Will not return.
author: George F.

description:
I stumbled upon One Market after a meeting I had in the building. I had sometime to kill before my red eye flight back to Toronto so I decided to have dinner and some wine. 
My first impression I must admit wasn't the greatest and that just really boiled down to the bitchy hostess. She was totally annoyed that I was on my own and didn't have a reservation. 
Eventually she sat me at the back - which she made a big deal about it. I sat at the Chef's table which is just wonderful for me as I enjoy watching the food get created. 
I started with nice Freeman Pinot '07 which was delic and smooth. They came out with some mouth watering warm olive bread and I probably could of just downed that all night it was so good. Since I was on the West coast I had to have the Oysters and I seriously devoured them in record time. 
I didn't want to have a huge meal so I ordered the appetizer Smoked Trout. I soo was not disappointed it was served on a potato pancake with an egg on top on my it was soooo good. 
I definitely would go back the food was excellent....I was just fire the bitch host.
author: Sharon S.

description:
I called many restaurants in the Financial District trying to get a table for 5 in the last minute.  I finally was able to secure a table at One Market Restaurant 1 hour before the lunch time.  I reserved a Chef's Table that is located in the center of the kitchen.  It is really cool to sit there as we could see how the food is prepared and plated!!!  I guess it is kind of like sitting at the bar when you eat sushi.  There are pictures hanging on the walls.  All famous people I suppose.  :)

I had the Dine About Town 2007 lunch (the year is incorrect on the menu though) --- sunchoke soup with mushrooms and bacon, skatewing with mashed potato and spinach and pear brown butter tart!  Delicious!!!  I always love the crme brulee there.  Since I know how to make crme brulee, I don't order one when I go out anymore.

It is a very special experience for me to dine at the Chef's table.  The food is great!  I'd love to go back for the Happy Hours.  Will report back when that happens.
author: Michelle H.

description: I've been  to this place several times and I was always delighted by the food quality, wine selection and service. Everything from cocktails, to starters, to main courses to dessert is always extremely good. Ambiance is nice and if you get a table near the windows it gets even better. I would recommend to always ask for the specialty of the day, it may really be worthwhile (like my thin sliced roasted beef I just had last night...to die for). I would also recommend to ask for help in wine selection, unless you are an expert you might be overwhelmed by the long list and on top of that you can be fairly sure to get a wine that matches the food you ordered. It's expensive, yes, but it's worth every cent.
author: Steve E.

description:
We were precariously seated next to, and too close to, the warm grill. Patrons kept bumping into us as they walked in between our and another table, so we moved the table when the staff wasn't looking. Two of us ordered the deluxe Dine About Town menus, one the regular DAT, and two ordered straight off the menu. I tried a few other things, but here's what I can remember.

The Amouse bouche was smoked paprika spiced tuna on a fried potato, and topped with micro basil: The potatoes were like a delicious gourmet "tater tot," and the tuna was unbelievably good, probably the best thing I ate all evening. Despite the pretty presentation, it was a waste of good tuna-- the potatoes dominated the dish. This was best eaten unassembled. 

Rancho Gordo Chick Pea Soup saffron, wild shrimp, niçoise olives: The shrimp were crisp, and soup was very good overall.
Geoduck Clam "Chowder" herbed crème fraîche, celery, house-cured pancetta: The soup might have been better had we been provided with an instruction manual. The base was too subtly flavored, and when I mixed in the creme fraiche, it became overly sour and the flavor of the underlying soup disappeared. Even still, the richness and acidity of the soup could not cut the extreme fishiness of the geoduck. Overall, the celery, geoduck, and creme fraiche were all overpowering, and poorly interacted. 

Roasted Liberty Farms Duck Breast, duck leg confit, saffron, anson mills polenta, red cabbage, cocoa reduction: There were too many "buts." The duck breast was good, but not as ducky as the Liberty Farms Duck Breast I've had before. There were two rectangular slices of confit. They tasted right, but the texture was too dry. The polenta grains had just the right amount of resistance, but were too salty. The cocoa reduction had a complex flavor, but there wasn't enough of it for me to go into more detail. The tart and crisp red cabbage was the one solid item, and was a good pairing to the rest of the dish. I could imagine this dish shining on a different night.

Roasted Brussels Sprouts applewood smoked bacon. The sprouts were perfectly cooked, and the scattered leaves were so good they could have been used as a dish by themselves. The bacon was top quality.

Valrhona Chocolate Soufflé Cake blood orange gelée, jivara chocolate mandarin ice cream. The souffle was light, evenly cooked, and a good place between sweet and bitter. Their accompaniments were well matched, and plentiful enough to allow for you to experiment with a few cool combinations. The blood orange and raspberry sauce was especially good.

White Peach sorbet, strawberry consommé, fresh berries, almond shortbread.  Divorced from their actual fruits, it was fun trying to figure out what the sorbets contained-- scoops of apricot and raspberry sorbet were added, but not listed on the menu. Regardless, they each were delicious, smooth, and didn't have any ice crystals. 

I'm somewhat surprised to be giving a Michelin 1 Star a 3/5 rating, but the unevenness of the savory dishes, despite some exception components, was really a downer.
author: Jason B.

description:
One Market is a great dining experience IF you choose to go during lunch Monday thru Friday or for dinner on the weekends (reasoning for 4 stars). They have great lunch specials for a fine dining restaurant in the Financial District (the roasted chicken lunch is divine) and great, mouth-watering desserts (mini-desserts). For cocktails, try their Tickler. 

As many foodies have claimed on yelp.com, DO NOT try to go for Happy Hour during the week. They do have a great Happy Hour, do not misunderstand, but it is severely overcrowded with salesforce marketing people who literally take over the entire bar area of the restaurant. If you do go for happy hour you need to arrive super early (around 3 for Fridays) and be prepared for a crowded bar. A happy hour tip is to start at One Market early (say around 3 PM) and then venture either to the Hyatt bar across the street or further down Market before the marketing crowd arrives.
author: City M.

description:
I've eaten here many times over the years and I've always enjoyed the food and the surroundings.  Conveniently located near BART.  I've dined twice at the Chef's Table, which is a table in the kitchen where you can see food being prepared.  

The last time I went there with three others, we ordered a lot of drinks and wine.  The bill out the door was a memorable $777.  Expensive?  Yes.
author: Doctor G.

description:
Came here for a lunch meeting yesterday.

Ordered the Wild Salmon, which was a bit on the well done side.
Service was sort of a disappointment in the beginning because we had to wait about 20 minutes before our server came by - maybe because we went during peak hour?  

Ambience is definitely great - very comfy and right by the bay.    Plus, I would recommend the Chocolate Toffee Crunch Cake. MmmMm
author: susie b.

description:
It's been awhile since I was last at One Market - it's usually one of my stand-bys for a wine trade lunch but so many other new places have been on my radar lately. So I met a supplier here yesterday (who had never been) and introduced him to this classy joint. A delightfully crisp Grenache Blanc started off our lunch, along with an order of piping-hot chickpea fries. My obsession with these fries knows no bounds. I could wolf down an order every day - they are just so light & fluffy, and the harissa aioli on the side is so divine I always ask for extra.
We then received a soup amuse of the coconut-lettuce soup in a little cup & saucer. Coconut & lettuce sounds like a strange combination, but it was actually very good. The coconut milk added a creamy smoothness, while pureed avocado and Little Gem lettuces provided a delicate celadon color - very visually appealing. There was some roasted peanut for crunch and little shreds of shrimp as well. For the next course, we shared the seasonal salad composed of roasted peaches, fennel, and arugula. The peaches were insanely good! The arugula seemed weirdly bitter alongside, but it was probably because the peaches were so freaking sweet. I found lush little ribbons of my favorite (domestic!) prosciutto, La Quercia, amid the tangles of shaved fennel which was also a great salty-sweet combination.
I asked our server, the magnificent Wade, if it was possible to order the pasta course from the business lunch menu and he obliged. Out came a shallow bowl of chitarra pasta (clearly housemade, and perfectly toothsome) drenched in a white-wine & garlic sauce. The sauce was so simple, yet so delicious. Six littleneck clams rounded out the plate. We stuck with pasta for our next course and chose to share the cavatelli entree. A pile of cavatelli pasta (again, housemade) shared the plate with artfully shredded duck leg, hen-of-the-woods mushrooms, and broccoli di ciccio (akin to broccoli rabe). This was a great, earthy dish with lots of layers of flavor. My favorite layer was the thinly-sliced duck bresaola on top :-) I had to pack up half the dish because I absolutely had to order my favorite for dessert, the butterscotch pudding. I just can't leave this place without it. It's just so smooth and butterscotchy, and the "singular sensation" portion is the perfect size! The pecan wedding cookie on the side is deliciously crumbly as well.

I was really glad the experience went so well today because I had such a bummer experience the last time (a few months ago): service was rushed & inattentive, the egg on the trout app was not properly cooked, and I found bits of shell in my crab dish. Clearly, it was a departure from the norm... All is forgiven, One Market! Wade was a particularly knowledgeable, yet not pedantic, server, while the wine director also made a personal appearance at the table. Great service from all members of the team.

[PS: I swear I will make to the Weekly Beast at least *once* this summer!]
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Went for a business dinner - small group. 

This is a restaurant for meat eaters! Everyone at the table that had a protein was raving about it; my duck with berry sauce was excellent, if small in portion size. Another member of our table had the pork loin and it was cooked perfectly. 

The appetizers were ok, but nothing incredibly special - a good salad, a couple of soups, etc. Desserts were outstanding - I had the banana cheesecake and it was the perfect way to end the meal.

Service was solid, especially the Sommalier. We had an excellent bottle and would go back just to have that again!

Overall a good choice and the location is great.
author: Andy B.

description:
This seems to be our go-to place for special occasions. We love the location; hop off the ferry, dinner, then back home on the ferry. The floor to ceiling windows looking out on the ferry building and the F cars rolling by enhance an already great dining experience.

The atmosphere is relaxed and friendly, the staff extremely accommodating. Very kid-friendly. You couldn't tell this is a Michelin starred restaurant, but by the food.  In fact, my 5-year old loves this place.  Once we were going to another restaurant in the area, and we told him we're going to eat near the ferry building.  His response: "One Market"?
author: Marc T.

description: The best Nice Restaurant I've been to so far in SF.  The food blew me away. Truly gourmet, well balanced, complex flavors.  Would love to take clients here (or my parents).
author: Whitney B.

description: I have dined here a couple times and I think I have enough to write a fair review. The service is excellent and the ambiance is comfortable. Of more importance, the food is also pretty good. The lamb shank is delicious but next time I would skip the Artisan Foie Gras Terrine, which was not to my taste. Why would they take something as smooth and buttery as foie gras and then mash it into pate and top it off with date spread? Beats me. Despite that, our main courses were spot on (lamb shank, duck breast, ahi tuna, NY steak). Desserts  were also wonderful. We got each of the singular sensations and they were all delicious in their own right.... you can't go wrong with your selection here. We are satisfied with our overall dining experience and would recommend One Market.
author: Vitamin C.

description: Excellent food, poor service. We were informed that our  bottle of chardonnay was not chilled, and to wait 5-10min. OK - but it was  45 min until it was properly chilled. In the meantime, our appetizers were served, and we chose to order glasses of sparkling wine to accompany our food - these should have been offered free for our inconvenience (I didn't think to speak to the manager; and  our waitress was virtually unavailable, essentially the entire meal.) I'll try another place next.
author: Eileen M.

description:
Enjoyable.  Had been meaning to go here for some time.  Overall, we had a very nice time.  

Pros:
- excellent crab starter with jalapeno and apple. Inventive, fresh and light.
- great coffee in personal French press!
- good duck dish
- skilled server
- gave us black napkins even though the table was set with white - I can't tell you how frustrating it is to walk out with white lint all over black pants

Cons:
- tables too close
- duck confit was a bit dry
- yes, it's summer, but I would have liked a beef option
- amuse bouche was so-so

I'll definitely be back when I'm in the area to see how the menu changes with the seasons.
author: Erin C.

description: Came here twice. Once for dinner and enjoyed the bacon wrapped tenderloin, cooked to perfection. The almond toffee crunch cake was good. The second time I had lunch and tried the filet which was good but I still prefer the bacon wrapped tenderloin. The chocolate souffle for dessert is a must try! It was so moist and not too sweet. The best I have ever had and I've had a lot to compare with.
author: Peachie Y.

description:
I popped my Michelin cherry with One Market on v-day and now I can see what all the fuss is about. We got there early to have a drink before our reservation, but we didn't really need to do that because we didn't get seated until 45 mins after our reservation time. I guess most people would have been pissed and walked out, there were a some couples that did that, but hey I was with great company so it didn't really matter and the drinks on the house while we waited was nice too. Their reasoning was because of the pillow fight that was outside. 

Food highlights, the amuse bouche was a foie gras egg puree that was served in an egg shell, I still get chills just thinking about that first bite. One of the first courses we had was a smoked trout on a potato pancake topped with a bacon relish, awesome. 

The small disappointment was when they told us they ran out of the scallops and pear tart, but I'm not going to really hold that against them too much. 

Overall, a great dinner.
author: edrick w.

description:
I tried this place during dine about town. I had a blast of an experience. The staff was very courteous and attentive. I had lentil soup and Mahi mahi fish. Food was great and presentation was excellent. 
Will definitely go there again
author: Hasham Y.

description:
Almost forgot about One Market Restaurant... 

I've been here a few times for lunch, service has always been very good/friendly/efficient. One Market is a large space with huge windows so that plenty of light comes in, very nice.

For lunch today we had the halibut cheeks- those suckers were tasty! Even the sauce they used was delicious and I wiped up the remaining sauce with my bread. 

So yes, recommended... but not sure if it's really my thing in the evening...
author: Nenette Y.

description:
On my first visit to One Market a few years ago, I thought, "WOW!!!  What a treat!!!"  My taste buds jumped over every bite.  

Now, the exuberance is simply... gone.  My last visit confirmed it. 

On a week night, the place was packed with the typical FiDi crowd.   Service was still great as usual - the staff, from the hostess to the busboy, was pleasant.  The wine list was fabulous.  The food, on the other hand, was just... hmmmmmm... for lack of a better word, "Blahhhh...."   Frankly, you can get the same kind of plate at Myth, or Frisson, or Jack Falstaff, or any other American place around the town.  Completely uninspiring.  Nothing special, other than getting a fuzzy feeling for being a sucker that just paid $28 for 3 scallops.   

It's time for a NEW menu.  Or bring the old chef back.  Otherwise, I am boycotting.
author: Shirley F.

description:
Went there for a business lunch yesterday.  Not sure why this place is so infamous, and I guess it was also the "it" place for awhile. 

My lunch was okay, nothing special, and definitely not worth the $25.  Crab cake appetizer was equally not special.  Palomino's has better cakes.

The service was great, but again, nothing too special.

Overall, another WAY too expensive restaurant that's getting by with just passing food, and a reputation that's been played out.
author: Rod '.

description: Homeade cheese-its with a hint of habenero.... And July wine specials!
author: James W.

description:
I went to Market One recently while on business up in SF; we made reservations but got to the restaurant a little early to enjoy a pint at their bar.  Apparently, a friend and local to the area, said that Market One's Bar won best happy hour in SF recently (not sure of the source) and said she had a great time there weeks before; it was great especially if you're looking for a good, vibrant, professional atmosphere; it also has the look and feel of upscale London pub; they pour a nice pint in a proper matching glass; only downside was it was packed but there was still enough wiggle room for our party of four; we were called into the dining room twenty minutes later.

I checked out the menu before going in and thought I knew what I was going to order until our waiter went through the chef specials; he strongly sugggested the halibut and convinced me not to even consider my other options; I started with the oysters and then went with the dungeness crab & coconut milk soup w/ leeks, carrots, fennel, kaffir lime.  The Halibut special was fantastic.  Also, I don't usually go for much bread, but there bread was the best...so fresh and melted in your mouth.  Overall, Chef Mark Dommen is very deserving of his restaurant's recent Michelin Star.

The location is great and right near a BART station so was very convenient for all of us.  I will definitely go back next time I'm in SF...
author: Samuel C.

description:
This is a review for their bar only.
$5 cocktails during Happy Hr (until 7), and they use good liquor.  All very tasty.  Best deal around my work place for quality cocktails.  Friendly bartenders.  Not so friendly waitresses, so try to sit at the bar.  Extremely hard to find a seat anywhere on most weekdays, especially toward the end of the week.  The scene... what can you expect when it's so centrally located in the FiDi/SoMA area?  So you'll get the uptight suits and champion yuppies.  But do go for the cocktails, for sure!  4 of 'em will make all the fat lawyers in the room look tolerable.
author: Chris T.

description: We were excited to go here based on it's location and the fact that it has a Michelin star. We had 11:30 a.m. reservations because we had theater tickets for a 2:00 show.  Considering the fact that our reservation was for when the restaurant just opened for the day and there were very few other diners seated, the service was quite slow.  It took a good 15 minutes for our drink orders to arrive (and we ordered martinis - nothing fancy or time-consuming to make).  We ordered the Shrimp Louis, sweet potato soup, flatiron steak, Pho, and a pasta dish.  All the dishes were just average - nothing special that would make any of us want to return.  It's a nice restaurant, but nothing to rave about and I doubt any of us will return.
author: Stacey L.

description:
#9 on the quest to conquer the 2008 Top 100...

Another DAT hit, a fine, bourgeoisie restaurant for mature people, age and behavior wise, unlike myself. I almost felt like they had senior discount like Denny's since most people were at least pushing 60 years old. But back to the food which was very good.

Started with the chef's complimentary duck liver mousse with cocoa nibs. I don't do organs but I pretended I was on Fear Factor and downed it. Surprisingly not bad, but organs psych me out. The black bean soup looked like a bowl of crude oil, was about to take it to go and pour it down my car since that shit is so bank these days. That also was very tasty surprisingly and left my lips looking Gothic. Braised pork ribs melted in your moth like butter, skate-wing with poppy seed was very delicate. The ala mode tart for dessert was fabulous and rich.

Service is great, the waitress seriously asked how the food was every other minute and my glass of water was also refilled at that rate. One Market is like the stock markets with the ups and downs throughout the years. Right now, it's booming.
author: Ed L.

description:
In a city with an array of options to choose from when it comes to dining, you really have to make yourself stand out from the crowd if you want to survive.  

I don't know how One Market has managed to stay around as long as it has because for me nothing about the place was memorable.  

Service was great, my champagne glass never reached empty.  When I didn't like the mojito, it was promptly replaced.  The waiters were always around when I needed them and did everything with a smile.  

The atmosphere is SF.  Lots of wood, lots of suits, and lots of business and pleasure going on.  

But the food, which usually is why we come to such an establishment, leaves no marking in my memory.  I don't even remember what I ordered to be honest.  It wasn't bad though, it just didn't even warrant any brain space in my memory.  

Hmmmmmmmmmmmm..
author: Denise B.

description:
The bf brought me here this year for Valentine's Day! We got a gift card from my brother and his gf as well, so we figured to use this on a special occasion. Thanks!!

When we got there, it was about 15 mins before our reservation, but we got seated right on time! 

The ambiance is very mellow and not super fancy. I like the dim lighting and how they had a grand piano near the doorway. No one was on the piano that night, but I can imagine, when there is, it can be very romantic and relaxing.

Our waiter was very helpful and attentive. The chef gave us a complimentary dish, which from the looks on yelp, everyone gets this dish. It was a decorative sashimi (tuna) on a silver spoon. It wasn't the freshest, but, hey, you can't complain when it's on the house!

Since we did go on Valentine's, they had a prefix menu. I got a crab salad dish for appetizer and he got the half dozen oyster in a half shell. I'm not too big on oysters, but they were fresh and pretty delicious. The crab, I really have to say, they were not shady at all! I was impressed on how big they were and I loved that they combined that with pieces of mandarin oranges. For our main entree, I ordered the sole topped with more crab! Yummy!! He had the duck breast dish. I don't like duck too much because I'm used to the fatty roast ducks from Chinatown. But, they made their duck dish really unique. It consisted of 3 different pieces. One looked like a minced duck piece, another was a fattier piece and the last was a leaner but juicy part of the duck breast. They were all very yummy! As for our desserts....the bf ordered the sampler that had 3 diff types of sweets. One I remember was the chocolate souflee, that he said was a little disappointing because there wasn't hot chocolate flowing in the middle. I'm don't have a sweet tooth, so I can't comment on that. I ordered the cheese/fruit plate. OMG....Yummmmm-O! I heart cheese and I heart fruit! So, that's all I can say!

At the end of the day, I can say my overall experience was excellent! I was with my loved one and we had a great meal on a special day. The service was great and the food was great! I recommend you to come here for a romantic dinner for 2 any day. You don't have to spend as much as a restaurant like Gary Danko or French Laundry, but can still enjoy fine dining and superb service! Cheers!
author: Christina T.

description: I went there for a business dinner. The food is expensive and the portion is small, but both food and services are good.  We notified the waiter that we have to be back in the office by a certain time, and they managed to bring food/check out so we can make it on time. Overall this is a good experience.
author: Linda S.

description:
"It's not butter lettuce! It's not romaine! It's...little gem!" - Waiter, explaining why we should order the Little Gem salad

I never knew a waiter could be so excited about a particular variety of lettuce until I came to One Market. The overall experience was very pleasant, particularly because I was here for a work-related lunch (read: free). 

The mahi mahi came on a generous bed of basmati rice, and the only thing I wasn't a fan of was the orange foam that surrounded it (why is foam so trendy in food these days?)

I highly recommend the blended raspberry lemonade and just about any of the desserts. What's great is that they serve "mini" versions so you can try many different ones!
author: lindsay w.

description:
This review is for One Market's Happy Hour.  From 4:30-7PM M-F hit up One Market for $3 beers on tap (including the elusive Boont Amber Ale), multiple $5 cocktail specials and a reasonable and yummy bar menu. We tried the chickpea fries.The "fries" are mealy and substantial, but not at all greasy, and the portion is really generous. The other apps looked and smelled great. Food is between 6-15 dollars per plate. The bartender was awesome. Really funny, took our order when we couldn't get a waitress and brought our fries to our table. Overall, I will be back. 

Two downers: 1. Gets really crowed really quickly. If you can't get there by about 5:15, you won't get a seat. 2. The waitstaff really, blatantly ignored us. We sat in a sea of tables in the "lounge" and everyone around us got stellar service. No one even acknowledged us. My friend even said "excuse me" several times to no avail. Glad that the bartender made up for it!
author: Jenni D.

description:
Pretty disappointing for a one Michelin Star joint. Dessert and amuse bouche were the highlights. 

Unfortunately our server knew very little about the wine list except for the few wines he thought would go well with anything. When asked for an unoaked Chardonnay he didn't seem to have a clue and didn't get any help! He then proceeded to pour a warm wine several times before it was chilled well.

That aside the food was not very impressive - apps and entrees were good but not great. Grilled octopus app had a good char, but texture wasn't exactly right and tamarind sauce needed to be tamed a bit in terms of zing. 

Scallop entree was kinda blah too - crispy chix wings weren't so crispy, sauce overpowered the scallops. The duck breast sounded great but was oh-so boring and just didn't seem to come together on the plate!

Despite the 1/2 price bottles of wine the quality of food at the price could not be justified!
author: Manj G.

description: Excellent location and I actually like the ambiance.  The bar is great -- nice place to chill out over a drink and wait to be seated.  I love the crab salad -- the flavors are deliciously complex.  I had the steak -- nicely done and excellent.  The wait staff was pretty attentive.  I've gone there for business lunches and dinners plus dinners with friends.  I'm usually too fully for dessert; thus, I cannot comment on their desserts
author: Peace L.

description:
Ate here once each for dinner and Sunday brunch.  Dinner was great.  We got a good booth seat and had some tasty food.  I ordered just an entree since I wasn't too hungry.  The guys ordered appetizers and salad and I couldn't resist trying some.  The risotto with rabbit meatballs was so good.  Corn soup, good.  And my duck breast, also good.  I was happy.  The sides were good too.  Potatoes and asparagus.

Came back for Mother's Day brunch.  Excellent booth table at the window, so we could watch our valeted car.  Pretty good service.  Good food.  No complaints.
author: spiff e.

description:
DINE ABOUT TOWN 2007 (3/3)

A little out of my element here, with the Fi-di after work crowd, but it was fun anyway.  The excellent food outweighed any weirdness with that scene.  The veloute soup was excellent - quite unique.  I had the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin for my entree, and it was very good, but perhaps a bit on the heavy side.  The chickpea fries were interesting and tasty as well.  I'd recommend this place for the food and wine list.
author: Josh L.

description:
I was skeptical about One Market's Dine About Town menu.  I haven't had too many good experiences with Dine About Town (Campton's Place, Sutro, etc.)  One Market proved me wrong!  The $45 three course menu with the two glass wine pairing was a superb deal.  We even got an extra bite of pate mousse from the chef!  I ordered the very unique salad, pork entree and peach tart dessert; and everything was good.  My boyfriend chose three different items and liked it as well.  

The waiter was so nice.  I felt bad for him due to the many many people he was serving, but he did his best to make us feel welcome.    

I will definitely come back to One Market on a normal day.  So far, I totally recommend!
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
I did the Dine About Town menu with a friend awhile back and wasn't impressed. His food was wayyy better than mine though. He got the black bean soup that was basically tar in a bowl because it was soo thick, the pork ribs (soo tender and delicious), and the pear brown butter tart (best thing we ate, in my opinion). I got the salad, which was decent. I like the baby vegetables, especially the baby onions. The skatewing was superrr salty though and I could barely finish it. Except I had to finish it because I'm me and I don't like food left on my plate. The trifle was okay but I thought you could taste too much alcohol and being the one-shot wonder I am, I wouldn't be surprised if I got Asian glow just from the dessert. 

On the other hand, I can tell that the food is pretty good and the atmosphere seems like a nice place to go eat after work with your friends.
author: Esther K.

description: The location is good a bad.  Good - a block away from the Ferry Building; Bad - pretty far from everything else in the city.  The service was solid.  The tables were nicely spaced to provide  just enough intimacy.  And the food was solid.  Why no four stars?  New American, quasi-French simply isn't my favorite.
author: Mike F.

description:
DAT 2010

Menu:

Cauliflower Soup with Nantucket Bay Scallops, Asian pears, pickled ramps - very smooth, a bit watery, but the crunchiness and sweetness of the pears juxtaposed beautifully with the soup.  Scallops were seared nicely, if a bit cold, but the soup helped warm them.

Mussels with lemongrass, Thai basil, coconut - delicious! Fresh mussels that had just been delivered (make sure to check with your waiter if they are available).  Great portion, delicious broth, but I wanted some crunch, especially since the squash and broth brought a sogginess to the dish.

Maui Pineapple "Upside Down Cake" with pineapple gastrique, vanilla bean ice cream - I like any other person loves a good quenelle (especially hard to make correctly with a spoon), but the cake was super dry, the vanilla bean ice cream tasted store bought.  Flavorless, nothing to "WOW" me.

Atmosphere is packed with the regular Financial District Crowd.  

Server seemed super distracted, as he had many tables to juggle, but I think One Market could have stretched their budget and scheduled one more person.


DEFINITELY NOT WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Dessert with the ladies (CMM voice) of the SoT, past and present, courtesy of Dine about Town (http://www.onlyinsanfrancisco.com/dineabouttown/), helping this arts administrator eat out in San Fran since 2003.  

JMS obstinately declared that she wasn't sharing her flourless chocolate souffle cake, leaving RLF and me to go halves on that, and the pear brown butter tart -- both served with ice cream, and the chocolate with like a cinnamon chiffon sauce (and I thought chiffon was just for evening wear).  MBC showed restraint and took her flourless dessert to go for Reebee; the rest of us showed restraint and didn't lick our plates.

I was so full, I had to save my housemade caramel that came w/ the check for later.  Next time, I'll have to lay off the warm olive bread... but it tasted so good!

As my Cousin Suzy would say, "If you serve them a good dessert, they'll forget a bad dinner."  Or in our case, and bitchy hostess.(Complimentary champagne helps to blur that unfortunate memory as well.  Thanks to MBC, for wearing the daddy pants, and to our new BFF, Jeff).  I'll never understand how it's okay to be bitchy to patrons who are abt to drop $50 a head for dinner.  That doesn't fly at the Theatre where they're dropping $50/ticket.

The bottom line: I don't usually pay for attitude, no matter how delicious the dessert.  HOWEVER, the manager went a long way in making things right, and that's got to count for something.

ERF
author: Emily F.

description:
I give this restaurant five stars because it really exceeded my already high expectations of what the food and service would be like here. For example, I ordered a mojito from the bar (off the menu) as soon as our waiter came to our table. When he returned he brought my mojito and a plate of extra limes just in case I wanted them. That level of proactivity was so darling to me and that action alone sealed the deal to win my heart (translation: heart = frequent returns). 

I often order mojitos and if the mixture isn't exactly what I wanted such as if it's too strong, or not enough sugar and/or mint (or none) the whole drink just tastes OFF. At One Market ,not only was the mojito perfect, but it came with a plate of limes, so I could alter the drink to my own liking - that was just terrific! :)

The food was so beautifully presented as well.....top notch. I had the ahi tuna with a side of big fries and sunchokes - it hit the spot. What I loved the most was the bold earthy flavor of the sunchokes, which blended very well with my ahi. Sunchokes are the root of a sunflower. They appear bulb-ish but have a very subdued and earthy flavor too them when sauteed with olive oil and seasoning.

I would definitely eat here again.
author: Laura G.

description:
I recently went to One Market for a business dinner and it certainly didn't disappoint.

The cuisine was excellent but not outstanding. As for the price, I didn't see the check so I cannot say whether I would return on my own dime. Although the establishment fits into the nouveau American sort of genre, I felt that the menu seemed to be titled slightly towards seafood. The scallops were great and my wife's cod dish was also quite good.  Although there were a couple of vegetarian sides, I noticed that there were very few vegetarian entrees so you may want to take that into consideration depending upon the restrictions of your party. The wine menu is quite diverse and not everything on it is going to bust the bank. There is a reasonable size bar in the lobby but I found the service in there to be extraordinarily slow. The service in the restaurant was very good and I found our server to be very attentive. However, I could clearly see that this would probably not be a good place for a quick lunch meeting. Whoever thought of offering mini sized versions of their various desserts was a genius.
author: Neil A.

description:
I go for the view and the half priced drinks at happy hour (M-F, 4:30-7:00.)

So gouda!
author: Jessica S.

description:
Right off the bat I know I'm going to judge this place a little harsher and here's why. I don't like to walk more than a 2 block radius from my office for lunch, which severely limits my lunch options, but damn it, if I wanted exercise I'd go to the gym and if I wanted to enjoy the weather I'd go to Tahoe. Walking around in an urban jungle is not my idea of fun. My Dine About Town junkie friend wanted to try this so I went along for the ride, and I'm glad I did.

The restaurant is located on the corner of Market and Steuart and is relatively large with a full bar and high ceilings. It has wall to wall windows on all the sides facing the street so it was really well lit. Having reservations (thanks Open Table!) we were seated right away. My companion was there for DAT, so of course she ordered off that menu. I however, do not like to judge a restaurant based solely on what it can sell for $21.95 at lunch so I ordered off the regular menu. Her starter was the Farmer's Market Salad, a rather pedestrian blend of greens and not a lot of flavor with it. I got the Gulf Shrimp over Cucumber, Daikon, with Green Chile Vinaigrette and just wow. Every bite a perfect blend of sweet shrimp, crunchy cucumber/daikon, and a nice bit of spicyness with the green chile. This dish displayed some seriously complex flavors. Next up, she had the Grilled Idaho Trout with Almond Vinaigrette. The fish was pretty good, it was served butterflied with the skin still on, The almonds worked well with the dish, but my only complaint was that some parts of the fish were overgrilled and tasted charred and bitter. The parts that were cooked correctly however, was amazing. I had the House Made Duck Ravioli in the Foie Gras emulsion and Maittake mushrooms. Again, another complex dish displaying some very advanced cooking techniques. I was hesitant to order the Duck Ravioli only because I was expecting one large ravioli over a bed of mushrooms. Fortunately, my gamble paid off and I was rewarded with 6(!) decent sized ravioli. It came in a foie gras emulsion (which is just a fancy way of saying foam). I enjoyed the flavors here as well, duck, foie gras, mushrooms, the chef certainly knew what he was doing. Small complaint was that the emulsion was on the salty side, but only slightly. You want to know why foie gras tastes so good to me? Because every time I take a bite of it a little piece of PETA dies. If we weren't meant to eat fattened goose livers, evolution would have provided a better defense mechanism against humans. You don't see us eating fattened lion livers.

We also got some sides. My companion ordered the Chick Pea Fries with Harissa Aioli and I think they also brought out some Sauteed Spinach and Buttered Mash Potatoes. The Chick Pea Fries were somewhat of a novelty, I've never seen chick peas served this way before and the aioli was perfect to dip in. There was a skin on the Mashed Potatoes, probably a function of sitting under a heat lamp for too long. The Spinach was a little soggy and again only bleh.

Finally for dessert, my companion got the Peach Brown Butter Tart with Blueberry Compote and Tahitian Vanilla Ice Cream. Individually, each element was really good, but they didn't mix well together as a dish. The blueberries kind of overpowered everything and the Tart wasn't as peachy as I would have liked it to be. I ordered the Grand Marnier Strawberry Trifle with Citrus Scented Chiffon, Ricotta, Marscapone, and Candied Almonds, and WOW. Granted the first bite I dug into was full of Grand Marnier and was a little heady, but each successive bite was like a dessert explosion in my mouth with strawberries, chiffon, and marscapone all battling to make the biggest bang. It was so good, I licked the bowl, if you don't believe me, check out my profile pics.

Service was impeccable. The waitress kept our bread basket bountiful and our water topped off. I think my companion was annoyed at her coming over so often, but I'm needy and crave attention so that was fine by me. The biggest downer was that she failed to mention that for Dine About Town, they charged an 18% gratuity. What the?!! I've never been mugged inside a restaurant before but this was a first. I didn't even order off the DAT menu and I still got charged the 18%. I mean really? Just...wow.

Minus 1 Star for Taking 18%.
author: Tony V.

description:
Food: 5 stars
Service: 5
Ambiance: 4
Overall: 4.5 stars

Came here with friends for Dine About Town dinner.  Was a little dubious, since i've been disappointed by other Embarcadero restaurants (i.e. Slanted Door, Momo's, etc).  But this place is on par w/ some top-notch places, in terms of taste, creativity, and service.  Compared w/ Campton Place's similar DAT menu, each of One Market's courses were implemented slightly better.  The bread service is non-stop and great.  And the Chocolate Toffee Almond Crunch Cake is amazing. The orange financier dessert pales in comparison.
author: Tina J.

description:
My memories of this place are intimately mixed with the very bizarre conversation I had with respect to Tantric Sex.  
I admit it was my fault, I started the conversation because one male member at the table didn't know what Kegel muscles were good for......Respect man - get a grip!
The steak I had was perfect - somedays only red meat will do.  The pudding was chocolate heaven.
author: Berty B.

description: This place was great for a business lunch. We were in and out in about 45 mins and the food and service were really good. The chick pea French fries were awesome but a little curry and they would  have been perfect! I had fish stuffed with spinach, mushroom and in chicken stock. It was healthy, light but yummy. Portions aren't huge, but in a good way.
author: Lisa K.

description:
This is a good place for happy hour if you and your coworkers just want to get away from it all and spend some alone time gossiping/complaining about work. Not a good place if you want to be rowdy. I've never bumped into anyone I know here, hence eliminates the possibility of eavesdroppers and drama. I think the crowd consists of more executives and upper management. (so these people can care less about office gossips) 

The cocktail drinks are good here for happy hour. Order the tickler (i think that's what it's called) It's fruity with a splash of champaign at the top. Most of their signature cocktails are definitely well worth the $5. 

The service is a little snobby. Sorry if I like to pay $3 for my beer at a upscale restaurant! =X They should people to order happy hour specials during happy hour and not their regular priced stuff.

Lunch is so so. The crab is pretty good. But unless it's a business lunch that I can expense I wouldn't feel right paying $20+ dungeness crab salad.
author: Keara C.

description:
Another expensive restaurant you say, yup but the food & service are great here.  

A great place to dine for a special occasion.
author: Cali G.

description:
Love One Market and its quintessential Californian food. Their Caesar Salad is wonderful, great wine selection, and overall wonderful use of local, fresh ingredients. 

We celebrated my parents' anniversary/birthdays by dining at One Market's Chef's Table. Totally worth it. Each course was beautifully presented and incredibly tasty. As part of the Chef's Table experience, you even get to go into the kitchen to help prepare your dessert! The Chef's Table is a must-do for a truly special celebration.
author: Lily Y.

description:
Food B
Service B
Location A
Hostess D
GPA  2.75 = A-OK
author: Kathy T.

description:
Bottom line: good food, good location, good staff... just shy of excellent, but worth a visit.

I recently had a mid-week dinner here with a friend. We were running late due to rush hour traffic issues and called ahead to warn them we'd be about 15 minutes late. They were accommodating and pleasant, and our table was ready and waiting as soon as we arrived. Knowing we'd only have one glass of wine each, we asked to sample all three of their Pinot Noirs before deciding and our request was met with a smile. We settled on the Testarossa Lark Creek Cuvée Pinot Noir, which was delicious.

Pluses: 
* The location is excellent -- right across the street from the Ferry Building, with easy access by car and inexpensive valet parking. An abundance of windows make for great people and scenery watching.
* The Spring Vegetable Salad was delicious and refreshing, with crispy vegetables and a basil oil that was so good that it stood out as a favorite part of the entire meal.
* The Almond Wood-Smoked Wild Salmon, a limited-time special, was delicious. It had a distinct flavor that was unlike any other salmon I'd tried before, and it was cooked to perfection. According to our server, it's only available about three weeks per year -- the only disappointing part of the dish.
* The portions are huge for a fine dining restaurant -- way bigger than any I've seen at a Michelin-starred restaurant. My friend and I shared a single salad appetizer, split two entrees and two sides, and we might have finished 1/2 of what we ordered. 
* Service was prompt, organized and efficient. Glasses were kept full, the table was kept clean and organized, and plates were cleared quickly and unobtrusively. And, when a near-empty glass of wine was accidentally knocked over, it was cleaned up and the stain covered in what felt like seconds. Altogether, a great service experience.

Minuses:
* While the food was good, and had some definite bright spots, it fell short of spectacular. I can't put my finger on it, but it just wasn't quite at the level I've come to expect from similarly lauded San Francisco restaurants.
* The Bacon-Wrapped Pork Tenderloin, recommended as one of their "signature dishes", was a little too salty for my taste. Granted, this may be because I'm a flexitarian and hadn't had pork in quite a while, but my instinct tells me it just wasn't quite right. Also, my fellow diner and I agreed that the pork was a little overdone, and the dish overall looked and felt like it had been kept under a heat lamp for a while. 
* The sides -- Wild Nettle Polenta and Buttery Mashed Potatoes -- also had that "heat lamp" appearance and, while tasty enough, were rather ordinary. 

On balance, I had an exceedingly neutral experience at One Market. I'll go back again to relive the magic of my salad and to see if I can find satisfaction in another entree, but my first visit was just plain vanilla.
author: Stephanie R.

description:
This was recommended to us by the concierge at the hotel. Well, we think the chef must have forgot that he had already salted both dishes, because he must have added more. The dishes , my lamb and my husband's steak were way too salty. My vegetables were overcooked and soggy. The food was overpriced. We would have paid happily if there is quality, but the taste of salt was so strong, we could not taste anything else.
You pay for the main food separately, and then pay for each side separately. Needless to say, this is an overpriced restaurant whose quality of food did not measure up.
And it took "forever" for us to get the food. The place was packed with business people in suits, the waiters look like he was running because there were so many wine glasses that needed to be filled. The atmosphere was pretentious. 
We would not go back again. If you want a nice friendly place to eat, don't go here.
author: Connie S.

description:
Three of us came in for DAT (Dine About Town) last night. A former coworker of mine was in town from India, so I made a resrevation here to show him one of the finest restaurants in town. Wondered about whether he would enjoy it (imagining my parents trying pasta for the first time came into mind - they are old fashion chinese, so will probably complain about it), but hey, it's my bf and my dinner too!  We were seated upon arrival. Staff was friendly and attentive. Probably due to the economy, we didn't have the noise or crowd problem some yelper had. Now the food -

Starters
- half dozen of oysters on the half shell: very fresh and tasty
- all had the golden lentil soup, which was great - tasted kind of like curry, but that's not a bad thing

Main Course
- I ordered braised short ribs with risotto: tender and flavorful
- bf ordered bacon-wrapped tenderloin: meat was cooked just right, a bit on the sweet side to his taste
- friend ordered the steelhead: looked a little dry from my side of the table. even thought he said it was good, the dish was left half-finished..

Dessert
- cocunut chocolate parfait for me: very refreshing, loved the combination
- chocolate soufflé cake: chocolaty-moltten goodness
- banana cheesecake: only one slice of banana on top, tasted like regular cheescake according to my friend

Overall, I was very satisfied with the experience. Will definitely be back for another ocassion.
author: Lois W.

description: Unimpressive food, excellent service. They do aim to please. Bartenders are cool and it didn't feel like a scene.
author: Helen K.

description: The creamy, rich, shaved foie gras salad complements their fresh, warm, baked breads and baguettes.  Their scallops are succulent, but their roasted  veal chop fails to absorb the flavors of the salty, mushroom sauce.  If you like garbanzo beans, order their light, fluffy chickpea fries!  Above average decor with good service by the Embarcadero.
author: Jenny L.

description: My review may be a bit dated because the last time I ate here was three years ago.  Nevertheless, I do have a good memory so read on fellow yelpers.  I went here for my "Welcome to the Firm" lunch with my previous employer.  It was nice. I ordered the salmon.  It was OK but not stellar.  Nice to try once but I wouldn't really give it a second look.  Good for a business lunch.
author: Christine P.

description: My friend Lisa took me here for lunch.  Service was outstanding and the food was darn near that way.
author: Eric B.

description: Awesome venue for private company party.  We were seated in a private room for about 30 people, with dedicated server.  The cauliflower soup over scallops, flat iron steak, grits that accompanied the chicken dish and the foam on the mushroom ravioli dish were amazing.  I will return to eat it again, and that's always the test of a delicious restaurant.  Will I return?
author: Wakako U.

description:
My wife & I went for my 40th birthday along with our 16 month old daughter and we could not have had a better expericence. 
They were very accomidating from the start. 
The food was excellent, my wife had the duck, I had the lamb loin & our Olivia had mac & cheese.

We live in the Los Angeles area, but will be back to eat here once we come back to SF.
author: Terry D.

description:
Save your bacon.

Dining out on an expense account, I ordinarily try and draw attention away from charges that are likely to raise an eyebrow, or worse, the hairs on the back of my CFO's neck. (Expensive dinners don't get flagged nearly as often as Thai massages or 900 numbers, for instance.) Once in a while, however, one slips by that I can almost predict will get bounced back to me along with a tell-tale yellow post-it, 'wtf?!' scrawled hastily across it, and the extent of my CFO's incredulity measured by the number of exclamation points tacked on for emphasis.

This would be the likely outcome of my latest act of gregarious gluttony, a meal at One Market with one of my best friends and his troupe of visiting ophthalmologists. The venue had been chosen carefully for its glitzy sex appeal to out-of-towners and for its rising star, Chef Mark Dommen, whose chutzpah in the kitchen repeatedly fetches the one-star satisfaction of the Michelin guide.

I plotted, connived, and calculated how I might justify the excursion as a business expense, but I held out slim hope. It was important that I mentally prepare myself for the inevitable reaming that would accompany the price tag. This dinner would be on the Bank of Nils, and not my poor, struggling company, hence I vowed to keep it light, keep it cheap and to keep away from the wine list.

The moment I was handed a menu, caution was thrown out the window along with my prospects of retiring before the age of 90. I soothed my conscience by laying some of the blame on Yelp and attempted to come to grips with my complete lack of self control around haute cuisine. I would go down for this one, but at least I could claim that the menu, Dommen's cooking and the limits of the General Manager's patience would be tested to the fullest in the process.

Our crew was mathematically challenged from the start - the curse of dining with doctors and not bankers, evidently. We started the evening as a table of five, ballooned to nine within the first half hour, and shrank back to five immediately after being accommodated at a larger table. Eight amuse-bouche were consumed by seven of us, six drink orders were placed and imbibed by five of us, four had no food allergies, three only liked red wine, two swapped plates, and one had the featured Weekly Beast, a 5-course tasting menu "dining from head to hoof" on lamb.

And outside our window on Market Street, a partridge cooed softly in a pear tree.

Dommen's execution on the lamb was an impressive feat in its orchestration, interspersed and timed to coincide with the other orders of appetizers and main courses. Both the LAMB TONGUE SALAD and the ricotta CAVATELLI with braised shoulder were inhaled, each one an exciting combination of textures and flavors. The other two lamb courses - leg and loin - were respectable, but they paled in comparison to the stable of dishes on the regular menu.

A "mi cuit" smoked TROUT served on a potato rosti with a farm-fresh egg and pancetta vinaigrette had me stealing bite after bite from my friend's plate. The grilled OCTOPUS was as exotic as a Moroccan spice market, its combination of eggplant, mint, and an harissa vinaigrette making our taste buds express their enjoyment by temporarily assuming control of the moan button on our vocal chords. The sous vide halibut, by contrast, was simple elegance, with the mushrooms and green apple flavors performing a soft ballad with the fish. Last but certainly not least, we ate the bacon-wrapped PORK TENDERLOIN with a dandelion persillade, the garlic and parsley giving character and depth to a pork overload. We had the distinct impression that Dommen was showing off with this dish, but he earned the right as it was every bit as delicious as it was billed to be by our waiter (and on the menu as the dish served to Gordon Ramsay on Hell's Kitchen).

We closed the meal with the fifth and final lamb dish: ricotta FRITTERS with pumpkin pot de crème, caramelized quince and pecan ice cream...100% pure, unadulterated decadence.

This is your friendly neighborhood corporate restaurant experience, but it is not remotely one-dimensional. In these turbulent economic times, elegance, like chivalry, is not dead, not even dying from the looks of this place. However, corporate expense accounts are a must, or better yet? Drunk, disorderly doctors who are overly generous in showing their appreciation for a great night out, thus sparing my fragile bank account...for now.
author: Nils E.

description: I've been here many times during my time working in financial district and strangely have never wrote a review.  I happened to go there for lunch for the first time in a while which inspired me to finally write one.  This is easily the best business lunch restaurant in the area in my opinion.  Everyone is always polite and service is solid and precise.  It has one of my favorite starters around in their Chickpea fries.  This was the first place I've had them and I've tried them at a couple other spots and no one comes close.  The menu isn't complex which is nice.  Sometimes great food doesn't need to be too showy One Market is very good at this concept.  The happy hour is priced well for the area if you end up there.  Views and ambiance are very nice but as I said it's a very business like atmosphere for lunch and dinner (except maybe at the bar during happy hour). It will always be on the top of my list for nice lunch spots in financial district.
author: Joco F.

description:
One Market offers a very elegant dining experience.  It definitely has white-tablecloth service.  I was taken there for my birthday (lunchtime) and the waiter recommended the smoked trout appetizer.  It was fantastic !!  It was topped by a cooked egg (poached, I think) and the trout was atop a potato pancake.  The trout tasted just like very dense, smoked salmon (lox).  For the main entree, of all the fancy things they offer, the plain ole Hamburger and Big Fries were GOURMET !!  

The view is amazing -- you can't get any better than that in San Francisco. Give One Market a try !
author: Max G.

description: This is the perfect place for lunch. I've been here twice before with no reservation on a Friday around 1 PM and we were seated immediately. The service, decor and food is top notch with the grilled trout, adouille sausage and a dungeness crab salad ranking amongst my favorites. I'm baffled at the number of bad reviews although I wonder if it has anything to do for the dine around town promo that people were taking advantage of (perhaps that menu was different from their normal one). The total cost for two including a shared appetizer, two entrees, two drinks, a shared dessert and coffee for lunch was around $85.
author: Procter F.

description: I was really excited about this restaurant but all in all my meal was only okay. I'm vegetarian and although they had a few appetizers and sides that I could eat, they only had one entree option (the gnocchi) and it was such a small portion I was still hungry afterwards. It was pretty tasty but I found the carrot emulsion sauce a little strange.  My appetizer, the beet carpachio, was only okay. Nothing was particularly bad about it, but it was nothing to write home about either. My boyfriend however, ordered the trout appetizer and the pork and became very sick afterward. We're not sure if it was because of the trout being bad or the egg on top being undercooked, but whatever it was made him spend the night throwing up our rather expensive dinner. Service was fine as was our dessert, the duo creme brulee, although they both tasted exactly the same.  Not going back...
author: Swaicha C.

description:
When I use to work in advertising, I had a lot of magazine/newspaper vendors who would take me out to lunch -- best part of the job. Yes, I miss it. One Market was one those such places. 

Since the bill was not on me, I felt free to order a complete 5-course meal--and that for lunch. I had their steak...a little over done, but still tasty. Everything else was pretty good.
author: Sue L.

description:
I've eaten here a few times for lunch and had drinks after work once or twice. I'm not as enamored of the Happy Hour as some of the other reviewers (and as some of my friends), but maybe that's because I'm not drooling over the bartender.

Last week, I had a lovely, large free range chicken for lunch. It was a half chicken, but it was huge. I couldn't finish it. I ordered green beans a la carte, and they complimented the chicken nicely. My friend ordered the Dine About Town menu, and I was jealous when the profiteroles came. (And the reviewer who complained that the dessert was too sweet and rich... that's the point of profiteroles.)

The service was slow, which seems par for the course. It didn't seem like they were overwhelmed. We ate after the lunch rush. They just seemed slow.
author: Timothy O.

description:
I have been wanting to see what all the fuss about this place was for a while. I was very pleased with the dining experience that I had there last night. The service was pretty outstanding. The hostess was friendly, the manager was thoughtful and our waiter bent over backwards to be accomodating.

Started off the meal with a glass of champagne. They had three choices so I went with Mike, our waiter's suggestion. It was delicious. In terms of the menu there were several options, a la carte, six course and three course choices. Went with the three course option which was a shrimp appetizer with the lamb loin and a dessert choice as well as the mushroom soup and duck plate for my companion. All were good although I thought my lamb loin was better. It's so nice to not have to deal with fatty lamb on a chop. For dessert we got the mint chip chocalate sandwich as well as the cheese plate which was expensive but had very generous amounts of cheese, fruit and nuts. No need to get more than one cheese. It will be too much to eat. Pair that all with a nice dessert wine and/or port and you have a pricey but totally worth it meal. Will definitely go again.
author: Heather L.

description: Disappointing to the max!  Only giving 3 stars because my creme brûlée was so damn good.
author: Rosie M.

description:
Incredibly fresh ingredients, most likely straight from the Ferry Building Farmer's Market, hosted by CUESA. 

Beware how the menu font casts some doubt whether one is ordering the Bee"t" Carpaccio or Bee"f" Carpaccio. My meat-loving co-worker was so disappointed to see beets, but my other co-worker snatched the fresh slices of beet to add to her recommended daily intake of iron...or rather there was enough beet to fulfill an entire week's recommended iron.

I probably had the most uneventful sounding dish, Petaluma three egg open-faced omelette. DANG! It was the freshest omelette I ever had! I swear the chef probably took the egg soon after the mother hen laid it! The omlette was topped with this stringy potato hash, which gave flair to this otherwise simple dish.

Plus, this location is situated on a perfect financial district corner, on Market and Steuart, and it makes for the best covert people-watching from the inside out.
author: Cathy H.

description:
We came to One Market for my birthday. I really wanted to celebrate somewhere else but unfortunately the restaurant I wanted went out of business. After endless hours searching (thanks to my BFF)on Yelp, we found this place. I looked at their website and it looked interesting and at the time the menu looked impressive. 

When we got there we started in the bar while we waited for our friend before being seated. The bar was standard and the drinks were ...ehh. When my friend got there, half our party went to the table while I waited with her to get a drink. We ended up waiting so long we got frustrated and just went to our table and ordered there.

Our server overall was great. She was very patient and she answered ALL our questions. At one point though while we were ordering dinner we were wavering on a decision, and she told us to hold on and she left. Which was a little bit random. She was doing something for the table next to us. I was a little thrown off by it. 

I had the duck and I know that you can't compare to other restaurants but I really wanted this to be something it wasn't and I was disappointed it didn't excite me to change my mind and love it. I was really expecting something exceptional and instead I was a little bored and wishing we'd of just eaten at a hot dog cart on the pier! 

The one great thing I have to say about this place was the location, the space and the view. It is a beautiful restaurant, but other than that everything else was just blah. Happy Birthday to me...
author: Stacy S.

description:
hostess: good, nothing special
waiter: great
speed of service: excellent
bread: very good
butternut squash soup: bland
cod: bland (seriously tasteless)
creme brulee: good
pecan tart: very good
price: okay

overall it's a "nice" restaurant with great service...but when it comes to the actual food i think this place is a huge fail. it doesn't taste bad, but just doesnt taste like anything. anyone can get dessert and bread right....but the main course and appetizers? come on. thats the clincher. i'm open to trying this place again but won't order off the dine about town menu the next time.
author: Tushar K.

description: Food was mediocre.   Had oysters and beet soup for appetizer.  Oysters were decent.  Beet soup was unimpressive.  Next, tasted the seared halibut and a scallop dish both were also good but nothing special.  Was pretty disappointed with dessert.  Had the chocolate souffle which did not taste like a souffle at all, tasted more like a chocolate cake.  Service was good.  Probably would not come back...
author: Linh H.

description: We didnt have a reservation and just showed up for good food and wine. Alex was very accomadating for us on a Friday night. We love the chefs counter at this restaurant. Every single dish was amazing as usual.
author: Three D.

description: Healthy choices no matter what you order. Everything was delicious. Ordered the turkey burger with sweet potato hash. Very tasty. Drinks are different, but good. Service was quick and the place was PACKED. Hope this one sticks around.
author: Mark H.

description:
I have heard alot about Bradley Ogden as a chef and had always wanted to try his restaurant. When the Dine About Town promotion featured One Market, I jumped on the opportunity. 

I choose the following from the limited DAT menu: Carrot and Ginger Soup with sweet Maine Shrimp, Duck Pappardelle and Profiterole.

The carrot and ginger soup was presented to me in an empty shallow bowl to showcase the shrimps, fried shallots and cream. The server then pour the soup into the bowl in a small jar. This help keep the soup hot and was a nice touch. The soup itself is pale yelllow in color, which makes me wonder where is the carrot? It was also very thick, which leads me to assume the soup was thicken with potatoes. The soup itself was sweet, the ginger flavor and a hint of curry highlighted the soup and the shrimp well. I enjoy this dish very much and would like it more if the soup is thinner.

The Duck Pappardelle was recommended by the waiter. However, I found it to be a little too salty. The pappardelle noodles seems a little stiff when I poked my fork at it, but was perfectly al dente when I chewed into them, so it must be because I am not used to the texture of ribbon pasta. I also felt the ratio of the duck sauce to pasta leaned too much towards the sauce, and I found myself eating the sauce alone after the pasta is done. Finally, being a duck sauce, it was a little too greasy for my palate. I personally would not order this dish again.

The profiterole was described as a cream puffed filled with ice cream to me and again was recommend by the server. It came with 4 cream puffed, drizzled with chocolate sauce and candied nuts. My usual complaint about desserts in restaurants is they are too sweet and this dessert is the same way. Also after the duck pasta, the dessert felt too heavy. Luckily, I did order a coffee to go with the dessert and that reduces the sweetness by a little.

I was hoping to be turely wowed by this restaurant, but came away with a nice meal, but without the intention of going back. This may be due to the fact that I order the DAT menu and therefore not taken as seriously, but I have enjoyed several DAT  meals more than this one. Given it regular price, the food, while good seems not worth the cost. Hence the lower score.
author: hsiao c.

description:
This was my first of several Dine About Town meals and it was a great way to begin! The food was really good and the portions seemed small but we were sufficiently full. 

We ordered the sunchoke (aka Jerusalem artichoke) soup which was really delicious. We also tried both main entrees offered on the DAT menu. (Scallops for one dish and pork tenderloin for the other - both were good.)

My friend told me that One Market is of the same family as Parcel 104 and Creek something or rather... the food at Parcel was tasty but pricey and One Market was just the same: tasty but pricey. 

DAT made it a less guitly pleasure but on a regular night,  it might just be a nice splurge to have on infrequent occassions.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
There's only a few things to say about One Market, especially when there are one hundred other reviewers.

I spent a few times here during the dot com boom, so this place always reminds me of big sales closing parties. No doubt about it, when you are ready to break out the Caymus Select amongst your business crew, this is the perfect place to get the long table and make a lot of self-important huffy noises. You'll have waiters running around and the whole nine yards. That's what One Market is all about.

The second thing you need to know is the pate. The pate at One Market is to die for, and I use that phrase just like I was some ditz on Entertainment Tonight. It really is so good that it makes you stupid. 

Other than that, you can't smoke cigars so why bother?
author: Michael B.

description:
I restaurant was pretty good.  I'd give it a 4 and half stars actually if i can but its not quite a five so I'll stick with 4.  We arrived and planned on having their buy one bottle half off the second bottle deal.  I think with six ppl there we had three bottles of wine... the selection was all great.  Let's start with the appetizers.  We had the risotto, the foie gras, and the Trout.  The server recommended the trout to us.  The crab risotto was great.. not OUTSTANDINg... but still yummy.  The Foie Gras was UNBELIEVABLE... that one is a MUST... and the Trout.. doesn't SOUND good.. BUT IT TASTE SOOOO GOOd. seems like its raw but its a lil smoked I believe.. and they put it on top of these potato hash brown looking circles and with some poached egg on top... THAT ONE is definately a must....

let's move on the main dishes.  I didn't get to try everyone's . Their menus change but I had the 12 oz NY steak that I was not close to being done with.... Their sauce is slightly sweet so its realllyy delicious...Their striped bass was a bit on the dry side.. so i did not really fancy it.. but the sauce was really nice. Tha Halibut was to DIE for as well...

Too full for desert unfortunately... Service was wonderful as expected... the server pointed us out to a local spot for a wine bar for us to continue our night... unfortunately the bar was packed with a party going on... so we went to The Hidden Vine.. which welcomed us with open arms :)

I think it was about  $90 per person... but the food and drinks makes life so great... that's why we work hard right?
author: Stephanie C.

description:
It's a big, imposing place.
It screams "power lunch", dark suits, and juicy cabernets with bloody cuts of meat.

You'll get good service and a stuffy atmosphere.  You'll even get food that mama can't cook at home.

What you won't get is memorable food that speaks to your culinary soul.
That's okay, I guess.  The stuffed suits have to eat somewhere.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
For a Michelin rated restaurant I was not impressed.  Service was OK, didn't get a water refill once and I was handed my plate every time it was never placed in front of me (I'm sure being the inside the booth  made it harder) although for the prices you would expect superb service.  

I ate the pear salad for starters...absolutely delicious.
The cream of wheat crusted sole which was OK, nice texture didn't impress me too much and I felt a little uneasy after eating.  The apple salad that accompanied it was a nice addition.  Because of the prices and selection I doubt I will ever go back.

Atmosphere was nice, lots of uppity business folks....nice views and ambiance.
author: N S.

description: Went here for lunch and had the best experience. Everything that I ordered was nothing short of Amazing! I love the ambiance and the service was Amazing. I plan to go back really soon :)
author: jen b.

description:
So as I point out in all of my food reviews, I am allergic to peppers. This believe it or not makes it very challenging to eat at most places. We enjoy going to SF because in most occasions the chefs have high standards for their food and are very accommodation to allergies. However, One Market must not have many people with food allergies enter their restaurant. 

After must disruption as to really you are allergic to peppers and so on and them forgetting us in general, we finally got around to ordering. My date and I wanted their Market Menu. Which is an excellent deal at $39. I ordered the Octopus, Duck and Souffle Cake. After a short while the waitress came back and said that unfortunately I could order the octopus or the duck and that I had to order something else because some accompaniment to the items had peppers in them. I said that because they couldn't accommodate my food allergy I was now having to order more expensive items that I didn't want and she said, well yes. She they pointed to this fish dish and said it was very light and good, but the description said it included salsa, so I am not really sure what she was thinking. She left us to look at the menu and of course I was pretty annoyed that I really wanted the octopus and the duck, but because apparently they could leave out the peppers or make a different sauce I was going to have to order something else or go to another restaurant. When the waitress came back I complained (yes, I complained) that it was ridiculous that I would have to pay more for something I didn't want because they didn't want to accommodate my food allergy and couldn't they just leave out the sauce or items that contained peppers? I mean, this is a Michelin Star restaurant! Of course she went and asked and they were able to do that for me. I have no idea why this was such a big deal. This wasted a ton of time and of course the waitress forgot our amuse bouche because of this whole mess. The food was very good, but this is absolutely ridiculous for a Michelin Star restaurant. 

UPDATED 4/3/2010: Today I spoke with Larry Bouchard after we played a little bit of phone tag to discuss my negative experience (based off my comment card) at his restaurant. The phone call was much appreciated. I have a ton of respect for those who own up to mistakes like he did. He said he understood how I was disappointed with the service I received. We also discussed a return visit to his restaurant. So we shall see how that goes. I have high hopes. :)
author: Michelle B.

description: I went for a business lunch (not DAT). My Arnold Palmer tasted like Crystal Light(tm) Lemonade. The "fresh greens" in the "fresh greens" salad were wilted. The flat iron steak was tough and overcooked. The adult tater tots unsalted. The french press coffee was wonderful - added a star. Skip this one.
author: Ben S.

description: Enjoyed a New Years Eve here and enjoyed it very much. I had a meat dish that was amazing. Service was very good and I would return to try their regular menu.
author: Shaun A.

description:
I'm a sucker for restaurants that serve soft butter - whether it is whipped or warmed - whatever makes it easier for me to slather a thick layer onto my bread.  So, I must commend One Market for warming up their butter so that I can O.D. on it and pay for it later in the evening...

Their food wasn't especially memorable.  Well, I take that back.  What was memorable about the food was that there was one thing per dish that tasted out of place.  For instance, their mushroom soup.  The gelatinous pudding in the middle of the soup reminded me of the pre-watered version of a can of Campbell's soup.  It tasted like it as well.  

So you see, the creamy butter at the beginning of the meal was such a tease.  I expected great things from a place that warmed their butter for their patrons.  But alas, a slight let-down.
author: Liz C.

description:
Been here twice - once with the visiting family and more recently last week with a large group - 17 friends.

Given that I generally prefer a plant-based diet, the options here are very good. Last week I had the roasted squash and farro "risotto". Great veggie sides can be ordered as a whole, which I wouldn't hesitate to do. It was one of the best vegetarian meals I've ever had in a restaurant.

Note that they usually have a great prix fix lunch at a very reasonable price (usually under $25). 

Kudos and thanks to the team at One Market for these two great experiences.
author: Christian B.

description:
I don't care if this place has one michelin star...I don't think it lives up to the hype and here's why...

1. The food didn't WOW me.  The best part of the meal was the desserts...we got the platter where you can choose 3 and they were all delicious.  The entrees were just mediocre.
