They were cooked well, but the flavors weren't spectacular.  I got the scallops and my friend got the pork.  I did like the appetizer which was gulf shrimp with dicon..I thought it was refreshing.

2. When we ordered dessert, the waiter asked if we wanted coffee and my friend ordered a latte.  We got the dessert and no sign of the latte.  Fifteen minutes went by and we couldn't get a hold of our waiter.  He finally came around and then asked us if we wanted any coffee...HELLO you already asked us and we ordered one and you didn't bring it!!!  He apologized and we told him we just wanted the check since we had an event to go to.  Um....usually places will comp you your dessert or something if they screw up like that...I mean especially when we are dropping $150 for two people.  Uhhh...nope....NOTHING.  I think that is poor customer service.

The ambiance here is nice.  You definitely feel like you are eating at a top restaurant.  But like mentioned earlier, the food is just okay for the price.  I will for sure not be going back.....I would go back only if I was able to just order desserts!!!
author: Neety P.

description:
Great service and the food is decent, if not not a little overpriced.  I had a pasta dish - not mind-blowing but better than average.

It's a destination lunch spot for business lunch meeting with clients.  Gets pretty crowded.

Also, if you're making a reservation, you have to give them your credit card number.  They ask for advanced notice if your party members cannot make it and will take $10 for each no-show head.  Supposedly it's for all the prep work that goes into setting up the table, but seriously?  $10 bucks a head?  That's just ridiculous.
author: L Y.

description:
Went for lunch...and it was pretty much what I expected. We ordered the crab salad and trout for apps. Both were good though I was expecting some greens in the crab salad. It was pretty much just crab and grapefruit but it was very refreshing. The trout was huge. I think we were both pretty full from the appetizers alone.
I ordered the black cod for my main course which was light and nicely prepared. I think I would have been perfectly content and not stuffed had I avoided the bread. But alas, I can only avoid the bread basket for soo long. The restaurant itself is spacious and and it was a gorgeous sunny day which always helps. The service was fine. Overall, if you're downtown, its a great place to get lunch with a colleague.
author: shadi m.

description:
Bacon wrapped pork tenderloin - the one highlight!  sizable,  delicious, tender, loved the bed of spinach and the cider jus.  I'm not sure what was on the very bottom but it added a lot to the dish.  4 stars.  Best dish all night!  Not quite like anything I've ever tasted.

Duck - Blarghh it was okay.  The duck was well done but not terribly flavorful.  I wasn't feeling the vanilla and huckleberry sauce.  It sounds interesting, but it tastes kinda forgettable.  I was hoping the huckleberry would be sweeter.  2 stars

Dessert sampler of 3 were okay to kinda good

Atmosphere is too stuffy to be romantic.  Not a good date spot.  
Overall, it was... underwhelming, not worth it.  

For a little more money, Boulevard will knock your socks off!!
(Boulevard's really close)
author: Tammy L.

description:
I am re-claiming the classic business lunch! And One Market is the perfect place to do it.

It's almost silly to comment on the location -- gorgeous no matter what time of day or weather. This is postcard version of San Francisco and a perfect backdrop.

The room is spacious and the waiters are polite, quiet, and quick. The menu is well balanced out for lunch with some wonderful choices. Both my party and I had the lentil soup (creamy and awesome!) and then I had the pear salad and she had the sole. Both dishes were great and presented beautifully. The dessert items didn't disappoint either -- we slip a C Pavlova and loved every spoonful of citrus-y heaven.

Now for the other side of the story...  (you knew this is too good to be true, right?) With high-end experience comes high-end bill. All lunch entrees are at least $20, combining two appetizers would also result in $20-ish charge before any beverages, desserts, tips, or tax. (and don't get me started with the martini temptation.)

So, grab your corporate credit card, block off 2 hours off your calendar and enjoy!
author: Gina M.

description: Ah yes..it's always good to try a Michelin Star restaurant. My understanding of how restaurants receive their star or stars, is to serve food of high quality..not necessarily complex dishes...combine that with mind-blowing flavor and do it consistently. One Market has been on my list of restaurants to try for quite a while...so I was psyched. I went for lunch with the wife and some friends and let me say...take Bart if at all possible or definitely use the valet for $12 bucks..at least during lunch anyway. The interior definitely suits the environment it's in...I can almost imagine the business deals made and lost in this place...a perfect place for that business luncheon to wooo clients...My entree was a Risotto with duck confit and the wife had their version of shrimp Louie..we skipped the appetizers for now. The risotto was great..creamy, flavorful with just the right bite and the duck had some nice crispy texture which went well with the risotto..I didn't sample enough of the shrimp Louie to give an honest opinion about it though. We moved on to desserts in which I had the Creme Brulee..pretty good as well. So, what's suppose to be flavorful, creamy, crisp...is..so why only 3 stars...as good as everything was, the flavors were not mind-blowing...I guess I've come to expect more at this level. Now to be fair..this was lunch and it was not the chef's tasting menu..I'll have to update this review once I've tried the dinner and or the tasting menu.
author: Orlando J.

description:
Dine About Town. Friday Lunch. 8 people. 1 n00b server. 

Faux Pas by the Server:
- Did not bring water. Had to ask a hostess for it. 
- Insisted on collecting menus later, but had to ask hostess to remove them. 
- Did not decide to card for drinks until he brought them all to the table. At which point he takes a very long time examining my cousin's (age 30) ID and proclaims that my other cousin (age 28) is "almost there". He wasn't joking. He apologized and said "sorry I'm number dyslexic" - but that would make her birth year 1918 instead of 1981...
- Hastily removed items from the table and dropped a butter knife on me. Apologized, but did not pick it up himself. 
- Was not available to serve us beyond ordering the food; had to ask for bread from another waiter. 
- We ordered dessert as part of the DAT menu, but he still came around to ask us if we wanted any after our entrees were cleared. Tried to recover by saying "oh, you wanted the ____ right?" Nope. Had a 50/50 chance of getting it right. 

Food (DAT menu)

Appetizers:
- Cauliflower soup: Delicious. Creamy but light and a great texture experience with the fresh veggies, pickles, scallops, and creamy broth. 
- Farmers Salad: Fresh w/ great variety, but how great can a plate of greens be. Esp when compared with the soup. 

Entrees: 
- Duck Confit: Worst looking dish ever. Completely unappealing in texture and color. Tastewise, not my cup of tea but others seemed to enjoy it. 
- Mussels: Delectable. Fresh, light, and savory. The lemongrass flavor really shined. Sauce was excellent for dipping bread into. 

Dessert:
- Only tried the pudding. It was fantastically creamy/custardy and tasted exactly like vanilla bean ice cream - but with a different texture. Very decadent. 

Drinks:
- The lemonade is TASTELESS. I got the huckleberry and even the syrup lacked flavor. Tasted like water with a hint of lemon versus lemonade. 

I have to throw in that I LOVED the bread they give you! Remember that scene in Ratatouille where Colette is teaching Linguini that good bread should sing? This bread does exactly that. 

Overall: Very disappointed with service. Food was very good but did not live up to expectations.
author: Juliana C.

description:
FOOD: We had a great meal, though a few dishes were unexciting. The pancetta wrapped scallops were delicious, as was the lentil soup, and the desserts were all fantastic. A couple of people were pretty unexcited with their apps and entrees, and felt they were way overpriced.

SERVICE: Service was mixed good and bad. The waiter was a bit gruff and seemed to forget about us a few times, leaving us waiting a long time before we ordered a bottle of wine, then again leaving us a long time when asked to bring a wine list so we could order another. 

ATMOSPHERE: biggest complaint was noise. The attached bar has a big after work scene, and when we got there at 6:30 it was PACKED and the overall noise level really took away from the experience in the restaurant, even though our table couldn't have been further away. Even hours later there were still frat-boy-esque yells and chants resonating across the restaurant every once in a while, which was pretty obnoxious.

PRICE: Food-wise, the better dishes were well worth the price, but a few people felt they didnt get their money's worth. But overall experience, particularly because of mediocre service and noise, made it a little frustrating to drop that kind of money for the meal.
author: Gregory P.

description:
Every single piece of food was incredible!  And our waiter was a hoot - telling us all about how the wine glass made such a big difference in how the wine tasted...  He also had definite opinions on the food, which is always great.

I suggest the foie gras - it was awesome, on a pecan bed with an onion (I think) foam over it.   The best I have had in the last five years.  Everything else was great, too.

We went next door to the ferry building and bought a zin and a pinot noir to drink with dinner.  They were happy to open them.  The wine list by the glass was fairly extensive and expensive ($14 prisoner, when the whole bottle is $35 - but it's an awesome zin mix.)  And their mixed drinks were intriguing; I had a coffee martini at the end of the night and one of us had a margarita that was tasty.

The trout appetizer was good (especially the raw egg!), the Caesar salad was excellent...  for main meals we had the mushroom pot pie, savory!  And the parma ham, the duck (excellent) and finally the pork - all done to perfection.  The sides were also excellent.

Finally, the coup de grace was the desserts!  $5 bucks apiece (they encourage you to buy three, but not necessary.)  I had an almond chocolate cake that was incredible.  One of us had the donuts (superb) along with other stuff (I was too busy salivating over my cake to pay much attention.)

Another attention to detail was the warm rolls offered periodically.  Excellent olive bread or sour dough.  

Finally, we plan to come back and sit at the chef's table in the kitchen (and the kitchen is incredible - huge, always busy, and state of the art.)  For $95 you get a six course meal prix fixe.  Sounds like a great deal to me. 

I think this is now one of my favorite restaurants - and it's right across from the ferry building where they have great cheeses, wines and organic food.

This restaurant definitely deserves its one star Michelin rating.  I highly recommend it.
author: mike r.

description:
I ate here for the first time recently and the overall experience was excellent. I will definitely be going back for seconds. 

They have this thing called the "Weekly Beast" menu, which is a 5 course prix fixe for $49. The "Weekly Beast" menus showcase relationships with local farmers, ranchers, meat purveyors, and so far, looks like they've had lamb, duck, goat, rabbit, suckling pig, and muscovy duck. Such a great concept and a wonderful way to support local businesses. It also keeps the menus interesting.=)
http://www.onemarket.com/calendar_weeklybeast.html

Here's my dining experience at a glance:

-  Parking - not as bad as I expected - look near embarcadero center or the surrounding office buildings
-  Wait - we had reservations and were seated immediately upon arrival
-  Service - servers were very knowledgeable and all the staff were very professional and attentive overall
-  Food - excellent in taste, presentation, menu selections, quality
author: Grace Y.

description:
We had one of the best lunches ever here - one note before I detail the food, there is a waiter named Joshua who also works at Bacar who is the nicest, funniest and best waiter of anyone in SF. He actually remembered which wine we ordered at Bacar months ago and asked us if we wanted the same thing, what a memory. Management needs to know that its people like him that MAKE their restaurants.
Okay so I had a work lunch here. We had a few glasses of wine and UNLIKE the joke called Bacar pours they were nice generous pours, thank you One market. Then we sat down and had appetizers, a fresh dungeness crabl cake DELICIOUS, farmers market salad and califlower soup - they knocked it out of the park on all 3. For lunch I had the Rice Flake Crusted Petrale Sole and it was just brilliant.  My colleagues had the ahi burger which I have never had and it was also just fantastic. Our service was very good, a blonde german gal who I had before. She is an 8.5 a little slow but since its lunch and it all happens at once we fully understand. Also the desserts were great, I cant remember but one was chocoalte. Anyway thanks to Joshua and the food this is FIVE STARS ALL THE WAY - BACAR is a rip off with an arrogant floor manager that was a total and complete asshole and but not for it the fact that I threatened to report him to the owners was completely rude. However, One Market was brilliant in every regard thank you.
author: John j.

description:
I feel it is my duty to warn you that this place, often lauded, sucks the big one.  I have had some of the worst food here.  I gave it 2 stars because the staff has always been nice and the ambiance is decent.  GO ELSEWHERE.  
Bummer, too, because it would be so convenient for me for fancy expense account lunches.
author: Pamela D.

description:
"eh" pretty much sums up my dining expereince. I was here for a business lunch and had the Tombo Tuna Salad. Bland... I've had their seared tuna burger as well and thought the same. I managed to scrounge off a co-workers plate and try some chickpea fries  (like fried hummus! & not at all greasy tasting) which at least left me feeling a little more satisfied... but I'd only dine here again if work's paying. 

I've heard good things about this place, so maybe it's just the seafood... 

The happy hour scene here is worth it--  so far I've noticed that everyone seems really friendly, wait staff as well as patrons. Its a small bar space, so expect to be squished in a little...
author: Ikeb I.

description:
All I can say is $5 happy hour drinks! They have the best happy hour menu, hands down. I really do not know of another establishment that has the same extensive happy hour drink menu, and the crowd that congregates around the bar area between the hours of 4:30-7 only affirms my observation. 

Working in the One Market building, and thus having that added convenience, also helps to bolster my ratings as well. 

As for lunch, it's a decent place to have a meal when it's not on your own dime. I wouldn't come here if I had to foot the bill myself.
author: Sandy Y.

description:
Lunch time - 2 words: Skip it.  The raspberry lemonade is the only thing worth trying.  The farmer's market salad, butternut squash risotto and crab pasta dish was highly forgettable.  

The crab salad was good but not worth planning ahead to go to "One Market".

Restaurant is loud and crowded.  Full of suits.

Spend your two hours walking along the Embarcadero and eating lunch outside with friends.
author: Mo P.

description:
I generally really like this restaurant.  It has a nice bar where you can spend excessive amounts of money waiting for your table (believe me... the drinks are expensive).  Great location and it's not ridiculously busy.  I've been able to get reservations the same day even on a Saturday.

I would give the food about a 7 and the service about a 7.  The portions are pretty generous and I love the comfortable laid back atmosphere.  You get a really nice view of the Ferry building.
author: Michael C.

description:
Wowow I could not miss reviewing this place. I came here on a double date the other night for Dine About Town goodness, and for me it was more than good, it was somehow...amazing.

Pretty much, I loved everything I ordered. I loved the vegetable salad - the presentation was smart, everything was tasty. I'll say that I was impressed because I honestly don't eat vegetables too often. But I figured I should be good to my body and stop stuffing it with protein and fill it with some healthy green goodness. But after that, I did go right to the protein, with the pork tenderloin ribs..which got me really excited. No dryness.. repeat, no dryness.. succulent, juicy, well cooked meat, extremely well marinated, and a good portion. I lean more on the salty side of the palate, and I loved the flavor of this so I dunno, perhaps it may be more salty for others. Very well cooked. Last but not least, I had the Strawberry trifle, which was just good. Strawberries -good. Other layers of trifle - good. Can't go wrong with that. All of this for $32? Awesome. 

The location? I'm not too picky; I'm more about food. But it's overlooking the Embarcadero area and right across is the Ferry Building. Generally a great area overall; I work in the financial district so I am familiar with it. The atmosphere is definitely more that of a business lunch, but at night I admit it's quite romantic. Our table was right next to the window so we had a great view. 

Also, our waiter was VERY informative when it came to the dishes; he also recommended wines that were perfect for the dine about town menu, one white, one red (a Tudor pinot noir I believe). I cleaned everything off my plate and in my wine glasses (and so did the other dinner companions) so from the looks of it, I'm pretty sure he did a solid job. Everything was great; come here, give it a try, I trust that you will like it.
author: Nebula H.

description:
I'd give this place an OK.  I came here for food for the first time and had a pretty good lunch.  The waitress barely spoke ingles and so ordering was a chore.  Her recommendations were, shocker, the most expensive menu items and her descriptions of them were unintelligible. 

Even so the food was decent and served quickly enough.  They have a "half glass of wine" here, the only time i've ever heard of such a thing.  What a crock.
author: Matt S.

description:
I have only been to the bar at this restaurant, and I have to say that their cocktails ($$$) plus their sliders ($$$) are a great after-work snack! Not the cheapest place around, but the atmosphere is great and the bar food is awesome. It can get crowded, but I have usually been able to find a spot.

A word about the sliders: not little thin discs of meat, rather they are a healthy chunk of medium-rare ground beef with carmelized onions and a toasted bun. Served as 3 sliders on a plate.
author: Amy L.

description:
This is a popular place for business lunches. I find it good depending on what you have. 

The burgers LOOKED delicious...but being a good girl, I had to get the more healthy options :)

The rolls were fresh, crunchy, and delicious.

The Mango ice tea was interesting since it's ice tea with a small shot glass of mango concentrate to flavor your tea with as you wish.

The lentil soup was very well strained so don't expect to bite into an actual lentil! But it was good and creamy.

The Bass was pretty good but it was a bit under cooked in the middle. 

Overall, I'd go again.
author: Kitty N.

description:
Came here for the dine-about-town pre-fixe lunch.  Our table got:

- white bean soup w/ meatballs
- garden salad
- mussels
- beef pot roast
- vanilla bean and chocolate cream pie

White bean soup w/ meatballs:  Yummy.  Delicious, thick soup with cabbage and other vegetable bits, complemented with three small, slightly salty and flavorful meatballs.

Green salad:  Good salad--very fresh leaves, light dressing that wasn't overpowering..  Not as yum as the soup, although probably healthier.

Mussels:  I thought this was the weakest dish we had.  While there was a generous helping, the mussels didn't taste that fresh.  There was a spicy broth at the bottom of the bowl, that seemed to clash with the taste of the mussels.

Beef pot roast:  The star of the night, for me.  Delicious, flavorful beef, cooked until it's soft and tender.  On a bed of mashed potatoes and some vegetable--I want to say kale.  Incredibly yummy.

Vanilla bean chocolate cream pie:  A bit too sweet for my taste.  My first impression is that it was like the dressed-up, adult version of a child's snack.  The vanilla bean portion had a wonderful, strong, real vanilla bean flavor, and the pie crust was perfectly crumbly.  A bit sweet for my taste (but most desserts are), but I didn't feel icky after a few bites.

Overall, I was impressed with the food.  I went in with high expectations, and I think these were answered.  Servings were larger than I'd expected, but this can be a good thing.

My only quibbles are the mussels, which really disappointed both with their flavor and quality/lack of freshness, and the service, which was occasionally lackluster.  (I don't usually care about service, but when I'm going to a nice place like One Market, I expect something a bit nicer than the Chinese hole-in-the-wall down the street.)
author: s h.

description: In 4-5 trips here, I've found the food to be very good, and the service as well.  However, the management was just busted for misleading their customers about the 4% surcharge on the menu.  When I ate there, I thought the charge was to provide health care for the workers.  According to the WSJ and Bauer, it's not.  I wonder what other descriptions on the menu are equally inaccurate?
author: John-Marc C.

description:
Went here with a friend after we failed to find a sushi place close by. Before we entered, she warned me that she heard it's a fancy restaurant so I told her I don't care I want to try it. Despite being busy, we were sat quite fast and the server started handing us the wine menu. She asked me the second time if it's really okay because the menu seems to be quite pricey. So I was like, WTF, but I politely responded, "really it's okay and it's my treat." So we ordered a bottle of Cain Cuvee Merlot/Cabernet Blend and proceeded with an order of the roasted duck for each and roasted baby carrots on the side.

The duck was still pink but it's good that I've seen an episode of Emeril before explaining why duck breasts should be cook to pink (otherwise it would be chewy) because my friend almost complained to the server about her duck being undercooked. Anyhow, the duck was perfectly cooked and tasty, and despite being served in such a small portion, the meal was surprisingly filling. It blended well with the wine thanks to the recommendation of the server since at first I felt that he just sales-talked us (okay, so I'm not used with a Hispanic-looking server giving recommendations about wine but I was proven wrong).

I'm happy with the service overall. The servers were polite and prompt when I asked for something. So stay tuned but based on my experience, highly recommendable....
author: Jerry S.

description:
Fabulous!  Fabulous!  Overall, a memorable dining experience!  I've been here before for happy hour and thought it was standard in terms of apps, drinks, and venue, however after dining this past Saturday it went from ZERO to HERO, in my book.  :) 

LOCATION: Amazing.  Across from the Ferry Building...  you can stroll along the Embarcadero... you're backdrop is the Bay Bridge.  How can you go wrong?

RESERVATION: I used OpenTable to make reservations for 5.  I included under Note: "Birthday celebration".  Not only did I get a reservation confirmation via email that night, I also received a call from One Market a few days after booking to confirm my reservation and also to ask for the name of the celebrant.  Additionally, the night before- they called to let me know of the location and the cost for valet parking.  Wonderful follow up!  They made logistics of the evening easy and smooth.

PARKING:  $10 for dinner valet.  Cheapest in the area.  Its found on Stuart Street.  The valet staff was fabulous!  Friendly, polite!  We were one of the last tables in the restaurant.  The valet attendant even brought my car from the garage, parked it right in front of the restaurant, and brought my keys in to me before leaving.  What a sweetheart!  They made everything so easy and convenient!

CUSTOMER SERVICE:  Upon entering the restaurant, we were greeted by the hostess and a gentlemen who seemed to be the manager that evening.  We were seated promptly near the window (which I highly recommend, esp if SF blesses us with a clear night).  

Our waiter was knowledgeable about all the wines, pairings, ingredients, and made wonderful suggestions.  He was a balance between being there when we needed him and also letting us enjoy the night.  

FOOD:  3 of us ordered the "Market Menu" which is a 3 course menu.  
Califlower Soup- AMAZING!  I read reviews on yelp, and thank you to those who yelped about it because what a well-balanced experience that was--- creamy from the califlower, crunch from the pear & ramps, soft from the scallops.  My second course was the Pan Seared Scallops with mushrooms which was wonderful!  It was a hearty portion, as there were 6-7 scallops on my dish.   I tried the sweet breads which looked just like hushpuppies.  Personally, sweetbreads are not my cup of tea so I can't speak too much about that.  Our table shared an array of sides: White Corn grits (which I am now a believer in), Sauteed Baby Beets (fresh, crunchy, flavorful), Chickpea Fries with Aioli sauce (FABULOUS!), and Sauteed Spinach with Garlic Chips (to die for! esp, if you are a garlic lover like I am).  Out of all of these, I recommend the fries and the spinach!

My third and final dish was dessert!  Ahhhh (siighh) dessert!  Dessert is the equivalent of the last glance that you give to your love before you leave them after the best weekend getaway.  Its the final hurrah... you're lasting impression.... the cherry on top.  On the "Market Menu", it states that you have a choice of the "Seasonal Desserts".  They actually allow you to pick from their entire dessert menu.  Be still my heart!  My favorite dessert is Creme Brulee.  Lo & behold--- there it was "Creme Brulee Duo with petite cookies".  One mini creme brulee... accompanied by one mini expresso creme brulee.  I'm in heaven.  Rich, creamy, and a substantial crunchy top brulee.  Loved the mini cookie.  There was a mini biscotti as well which had anise in it which I'm not too big of a fan of, but still enjoyed.  Overall, fabulous!!! fabulous!!!

I'm one of those friends that likes share food.  I like to make perfect little amuse bouche's (if you will) of my plate and taste other's dishes too.  So here's what else I tasted: On the Weekly Beast, I had the lamb tongue with fingerlings.  I was COMPLETELY APPREHENSIVE at first, but was surprised at how darn tasty it was.  Eating such a delicacy is definitely a mind over matter battle.  The bacon wrapped pork sat on a bed of apples.  Moist and succulent!  Butterscotch pudding- heavenly.  I don't even like butterscotch, and I loved it.  It was thick, rich, and bursting with flavor although not bum-rushing your taste buds leaving you over-whelmed.  I also tasted a seasonal dessert of carmelized bananas accompanied by a chocolate tart and house-made vanilla bean ice cream.  Oh my tasty!  

I'm coming back!  Everything was delicious.  Beautifully presented.  Staff and service - well orchestrated.  We dined for over 3 hours and I enjoyed the entire experience.  

I also thought it was interesting to see a diversity in patronage.  Date nights, families, couple with a behaved child, business dinners, and we were a table of 5 (ages ranging from 28-60's).  All of us truly enjoyed the evening.
author: Deanna A.

description:
Full review and photos in blog

One Market (San Francisco) - Thanksgiving Dinner 2010

There are many different holidays in the Western world which are celebrated in all countries like Christmas or Easter but there are certain holidays which are very specific for each country. Often these holidays are related to the founding of a country like Independence Day in the US, Bastille Day in France or the Day of German Unity. The day which represents for us from a foodie perspective the most specific American celebration of gathering and food was always Thanksgiving. There are remotely related holidays in Europe like Erntedankfest in Germany but those celebrations are much more based on a religious background and are often only celebrated in scattered areas. 
When we moved to the US Thanksgiving was for the first few years always an international potluck we celebrated with many coworkers from all over the world at the research institute we worked at that time. In the last few years we often used the Thanksgiving break for a short foodie trip to Las Vegas but this year Thanksgiving was for us the starting day of a longer trip to the Bay Area and the wine country. We never really had problems to find a good restaurant in Las Vegas on Thanksgiving but it turned out to be surprisingly challenging to find something suitable in San Francisco. Either many restaurants we were interested in weren't open for Thanksgiving or they were open but had very boring and vastly overpriced special menus. After many phone calls and emails with different restaurants we finally settled on One Market for our Thanksgiving Dinner. 

One Market is the best known restaurant of the Lark Creek Restaurant Group. The Lark Creek Restaurant Group was founded by Chef Bradley Ogden and business partner Michael Dellar in 1989. Bradley Ogden has over the years established himself as a well respected chef in the culinary world and was critical in setting up all twelve restaurant of the Lark Creek Restaurant Group throughout California and Las Vegas with several more planned in the near future. Even though Bradley Ogden was the founding chef of One Market in 1993 since then a number of executive chefs have followed him with Mark Dommen at the helm for the last six years. Chef Dommen started his culinary education at the California Culinary Academy before honing his skills and moving up the ranks by working for many exceptional chefs like Hubert Keller (Fleur de Lys), Gary Kunz (Lespinasse) and Jean-Louis Palladin (Palladin). He was also opening chef of Julia's Kitchen in Napa before joining One Market. 

One Market restaurant is located across the Ferry Building in one of the large buildings which house banks and investment firms. The restaurant is on the first floor and has windows all-around which gives the place an open feeling. 

When we arrived at One Market the place was extremely crowded in the entrance and it soon became clear that they were about 20-30 minutes behind their schedule. They have a small bar area to the right where most people waited for their table.

The dining area has two levels. We were seated on the lower level and even though the tables are relatively close to each other the restaurant didn't feel too overcrowded. 

We started the night with two cocktails. No Partridge - Hangar One spiced pear vodka, Orchard pear liqueur, Domaine de canton ginger liqueur. Pleasantly fruity cocktail with nice pear flavor which got a nice kick from the ginger liqueur. The drink had a nice balance between alcohol and fruitiness. Hot Apple Pie - Tuaca, mulled apple cider, cinnamon whipped cream. The warm cocktail was perfect for this cold night and was indeed reminiscent of an apple pie. The vanilla liqueur paired nicely with the apple cider.

The bread was an epi-style bread which reminded us on the bread you get at the different Bouchon restaurants. A simple but very fresh bread.

Amuse Bouche: Duck liver mousse, quinoa tabbouleh, pickled cauliflowers and carrots.
The menu just mentioned an amuse bouche to start the dinner but our waiter brought a rather large plate of a few different appetizers - a light version of tabbouleh with quinoa instead of the normal bulgur which gave it a more nutty flavor, pickled cauliflowers and carrots which weren't overly sour like many pickled vegetables often tend to be and, as the highlight of the plate, a very creamy and smooth duck liver mousse. One often sees chicken liver mousse on restaurant menus but duck liver mousse seems to be much less popular which is surprising as this example shows a wonderfully rich and creamy version which has a nuanced livery taste and is perfectly accompanied by toasted bread.

Course 1a: Golden lentil soup, vadouvan, yogurt cloud.
This soup was made of pureed lentils so that it had a smooth and creamy consistency without the use of cream which made the soup very....
author: Twofoodiesonejourney T.

description: It's easy to see why this restaurant is a mainstay of classic San Francisco fine dining. Everything we ordered was perfect. The cocktails were clearly made by a seasoned professional. I had the bacon wrapped pork loin which was perfectly cooked, medium-rare thank you very much. And the desserts were top notch. To top it all off, the service was great. I can't remember the servers name, but he was clearly from the East Coast and a total charmer. I will definitely be going back and recommending it to all my friends. Ask for a booth by the window so you can watch the Bay Bridge lights!
author: Jeremiah P.

description:
An observation I have noticed about people that go to fancy restaurants a lot, they end up not liking fancy food anymore and prefer fast food or home cooked meals. I don't go to fancy restaurants that often, but after going to a number of them, I do get less and less impressed with the food. One starts to wonder if it's worth paying so much for the quality that you can make or get somewhere else for much less.

As for One Market, I can say the octopus appetizer was surprising interesting and tasty. I expected octopus to be bland and chewy, but this was the exact opposite. The waitress was friendly and knowledgeable. She even gave me the recipe for one of the dishes. The rest of the meal was just ok. I usually dislike the wine choices made for wine pairings, but this pairing was probably the one of best pairing I ever had. Cheers to the Sommelier. Ambiance is nice especially with the live and non-obtrusive pianist.
author: Korn D.

description:
I've been here twice now; my most recent visit on V-day.  Both times I've been very impressed with this place.  I'm sure this restaurant is about to get a slew of negitive reviews due to their mismanaged reservation timeline (many pissed off patrons in the bar waiting for over 45 minutes for their tables) but, I've worked at restaurants before and know these things may happen beyond anyones control.  Luckily, my boyfriend and I wouldn't let a late seating ruin our night out...

Between the two of us we had...

Amuse bouche: Egg flan with foie gras (wonderful flavor but odd texture...nothing wrong with the dish, I just never like flan/pudding/mush textures while I'm eating)

Appetizers: 
Him- Oysters (he thought they were amazing, oysters just aren't my thing either so I can't comment)
Me: Lightly Smoked Tasmanian Ocean Trout 
"Mi Cuit" potato rösti, organic chicken egg, pancetta vinaigrette (Quite simply, the best "breakfast" I have ever put in my mouth.  I know it was a dinner app but I could eat this dish for breakfast every day, YUM!)

Entrees:
Him:  Mushroom Pot Pie (Absolutely amazing...loved the mushroom flavors and very well-balanced.  The boyfriend is a meat-eater but he LOVED this dish...I did too, slightly better than my choice!)
Me: Thai snapper and crab dish with fennel:  (I can't remember the exact details but this was very good as well...Although, I have to say the Pot Pie was better)

Dessert:
Him:  Trio of Chocolate (very rich, very good...the cream soda drink thing was delicious!)
Me:  Pear tarte with pear ice-cream (not really ice-cream but can't think of the name) and creme fraiche (I liked this dessert more than the chocolate...but, I also love fruity desserts.  The "ice-cream" was to die for, you could really taste the fresh pear).

Overall, One Market was a wonderful dinner.  The service was timely as we never waiter too long for a dish or were rushed through the courses.  It's too bad so many people were disappointed by the late seating because otherwise I'm sure they would have had a lot of happy patrons.  Highly recommended!
author: a e.

description: One market served beautiful culinary art. It was very tasty and well put together. I had the chef's 6 course meal, it was very balanced and delicious. The wines were paired extremely well with the food. The service was very friendly and knowledgable. I would definitely recommend one market to visitors of San francisco.
author: Summer E.

description: This is a great place for lunch, but my dinner there last Friday with at friend from DC was atrocious.  The crab starter served on a bed of "mango" that looked liked leftover sour kraut was tasteless.  Moreover, the duck breast was two minuscule pieces of duck breast accompanied by two inedible mounds of duck confit - simply terrible.  I would caution dinner here although I know they have the ability to do better based on my lunch experiences.
author: David B.

description: we had a dinner tonight for a party of six. the service is ok but the food is mediocre. They definitely need a good executive chef for a michelin starred restaurant. We were supposed to have a dinner at campton place but that restaurant was closed today so we have to take market one as a second choice. The entrees were not worth michelin starred.
author: Hippo T.

description: Top notch. The atmosphere is perfect for the business lunch. I had the ahi burger with fennel salad and it was perfect.
author: Matt L.

description:
I've been to One Market three times, twice for Dine-About-Town and once for dinner to celebrate several friends' birthdays. It is definitely a high-powered, corporate write-off, treat-your-client locations. That being said, the price and the overly-high expectation kept this from being five-stars as it is actually a great place to dine otherwise. 

They have wonderful service and are very accommodating to whatever request, birthday or seating. Our most recent table had crab cakes and calamari to share. Both were very well done, especially the crab cakes. I have heard and agree with the suggestion that these are must haves. I split the daily roasted chicken with a friend; they suggest we order well-ahead, so we put in our request before the rest of the table ordered. The chicken was cooked very well and I disagree with other reviewers that it is too raw. Though slightly pink, it was exceptionally juicy and very well and appropriately seasoned. I have no complaints here. The sides we chose were the greens and the chickpea fries. Both were wonderful sides and would be enough to order by themselves. (The chicken comes with two side choices.) For dessert we split the three-plate mini-sampler. We ordered two and tried each of the six options. This was fantastic. Although nothing was particularly good, I attribute that to the well-rounded quality; nothing lacked. The others at our table had scallops and duck and they all commented on the good quality of their food. 

The current chef often sends out complimentary mini-appetizers which went over well. (The day we went most recently, they offered salmon roe.)

I really enjoyed the experience here. The only drawback is, very understandably, the price and the somewhat stuck-up atmosphere which is through no fault of the waiters. The people who are there, are bored, and are only there cause they want to show off their wallets. It makes us little people feel slightly intimidated.
author: Larry Y.

description: I am so disappointed right now I should probably wait to write the review. I just experienced treatment at this restaurant I have never received elsewhere let alone one with a Michelin Star. The star should be revoke immediately. Let's just say that if you are not a "regular" don't bother. We actually were flat out told by our waiter that our treatment would be different since we were not "regulars". Our amuse bouche was a joke compared to what the "regulars" received. What an insult!  Comments and treatment only went down hill from there topping it off with them returning the bill without our credit and leaving our card out on a counter. I do agree that the olive bread is fabulous but the rest of the meal was so so and not worth the price or inconsistent service.
author: P K.

description:
This place struck me more as a business lunch/dinner dining option than a fine night out. The environment was not incredibly elegant, romantic, or sophisticated, but more along the lines of being nice and professional. That wasn't what bothered me though. The menu seemed great; there were plenty of options, though the focus seemed to be on seafood (scallops, shrimp, and a few different fish). I love seafood and was going to go for the mahi mahi, but the waiter really talked up the lambchops. Apparently, the Grilled Sonoma Lambchops was one of their specialties. 

It was disappointing. While the texture of the lamb was good, the flavoring was quite off. The meat was over marinated and was quite salty. The side of brocoli was also extremely salty. A couple of my friends also said the same about their dishes, which leads me to believe that it's just their style. I had to keep drinking water after, so it didn't seem worth it to me to spend 50 bucks (without wine) here. Plus, if this was their so called "specialty," I wouldn't want to try their other dishes. 

Also, points taken off for slow service.
author: Kevin T.

description:
One Market, a swank venue on the Embarcadero,  is neither so beloved as Boulevard nor so popular as the Slanted Door, its neighbors.  It's beautiful but without soul, a bit cold at heart.  

Roasted Pear Salad with blue cheese, frisée, and candied walnuts is a good way to begin.  The sweet pear and slightly bitter cheese are perfect foils.  The walnuts are crisp and the frisee perfectly fresh.

Three sautéed medium sized shrimp are interlocked over cucumber and daikon.  A green chile vinaigrette to the side is a fiery contrast to the cool shrimp and cucumber.  Very good. For what you get, very costly. 

Haddock cooked Sous Vide comes with clams, and a saffron risotto cake.  The haddock has a fishy taste that comes from being topped by the clams.  Strange.  You go out of your way to get fish that is pristine and add an off taste.  Well, chefs will be chefs.  The risotto cake is nice and the haddock nice enough, if you ignore the clams.  

I pass on dessert.   My waistline is enlarging,  my wallet depleting.
author: David D.

description:
Though I was thinking "pretty much like every other nice/expensive restaurant in the city," the desserts prompted me to write. Go for the desserts. I had a brownie with butterscotch ice-cream that came with little pitchers of chocolate AND caramel syrup. The other two chocolate-themed desserts at my table were also fantastic. 
Dinner was also very good. We all got fish and it was all prepared in creative ways that weren't too far out there. The vegetable side dishes were a highlight, especially the roasted carrots. 
One star off for an extremely snooty waitstaff.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
Chef's Table: amazing. I have been to One Market three times now, but only for the Chef's Table. I just brought my dad here for his 65th birthday along with the rest of my family. Our meal lasted for 4 hours - which included my parents cooking one of our courses with the Chef, Mark. 

We also had a great tour of the facility and had a tasting in the Wine Cellar (which is really upstairs). The sommelier was very nice and knowledgeable. Our courses started with an oyster and caviar, then came an amazing crab salad (prob my fav), then some shrimp (with a hint of cilantro), then halibut, then duck, then steak, then plethora of dessert. In July, the wine list is 50% off and if you bring in your own and buy some off the list, they WAVE corkage!! Service was excellent and overall, we had a fabulous time. The food was 7 out of 10.

 This is no Gary Danko or Michael Mina, but overall, the experience exceptional.
author: Hilary H.

description:
Tried One Market yesterday for lunch - it was a Tuesday at 11:30AM, thought there'd be no problem getting a table given that it's Tuesday and relatively early for lunch.  Strangely enough, the hostess said they were fully booked - but somehow managed to squeeze us in - and I was pleased they did.  

As to be expected with any nice restaurant near the ferry building the prices are pretty extreme, but on the bright side they don't skimp on the portions - even for lunch.  

They brought out the bread as soon as we ordered and YAY...warm bread & soft whipped butter, for me always a strong indicator of the calibur of a restaurant.  Just delicious.

I ordered their portobello mushroom soup, and skatewing.  The portobello mushroom soup had a poached egg in the center and they poured the soup around it, and it also had something akin to rice crispies in the bowl - and while it may sound odd - it was quite good.  Though the manager, I think in an attempt to turn over the table quickly basically ripped the soup out from under me before I had finished.  

The skatewing was good - not the best I've had (thank foreign cinema for that), but definitely solid, if a little heavy on the capers and lemon juice.  Collegue ordered a ceasar salad that just looked like 3 large pieces of lettuce with shaved parmesan on it. 

The waitstaff was friendly without being overbearing - but brought the check faster than the food.  Probably just a by-product of being busy, but their timing seemed a bit off.  Not a meal I would consider $70 worth, but might be willing to give it a try for dinner.  If you're looking for a business lunch near the embarcadero, go here - but make a reservation!
author: Alison L.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in town, I guess it's about time I write a review (because you know, there aren't enough out there).  The food is great, excellent choice of wines  (wine is food right??).  As for the actual food itself, they have a great seasonal menu which I like--a non-static menu.  There are many reasons why this is a consistently TOP 100 restaurant, so I'll try to highlight a few.

Atmosphere
  The restaurant has excellent decor (as always), from the nicely done curtains to the table set-up.  Upon entering, the bar is to the right and the dining section is to your left.  The restaurant is right on the corner of 1 Market (err duh??) so expect a lot of light and window views (exhibitionist views?).
The only thing you have to drown out are the corporate sheep at the bar.  Of course, I use to be a corporate whore so I can't exactly complain about the people.  

Food
  One reason why I like this restaurant is the use of natural, seasonal foods.  The products are excellent in quality and fresh (e.g. Peking duck instead of the drier Mandrake Duck), but--once again--expected for a top 100 restaurant.  Their fusion appetizers are great--a good hint of Asian flavors with American sauces and spices.

Service
  The service is always excellent--top notch.  Our waiter was knowledgeable with the wine (esp. since I'm partial to reds) and quite a bit of the food on the menu.  He served us adeptly, any better and we'd be spoon fed.  LoL.

Someone already mentioned it, but yes--the chocolate toffee cake is that good.
author: Billy C.

description:
This is the kind of place you should only dine at if it's for some company-sponsored work event. It's filled with business shmoozers and hobnobbers and although the ambiance is very pretty, it's also very loud. It's your typical Financial District power lunch location. Our service was slow and we ran out of time and didn't get to try dessert (drat!). 

I don't normally eat at places that are this expensive, so maybe I'm not the best person to review it. One Market is admittedly NOT my scene.  I got the one vegetarian entree (The Terrine) and enjoyed it enough but it didn't astound me (especially for the price). I tried the chickpea fries and they were tasty too. I'd like to pop in here for happy hour someday to see what that's all about.
author: Stumbalina b.

description:
I had high hopes for this restaurant given its Michelin-star pedigree, but I was somewhat disappointed.

I had the crab salad which was light and flavorful with just enough brine from the sprinkling of sea beans on the top. However, my main course, the potato-crusted sole left something to be desired. The basil broth was underseasoned, and as was the fish itself, though it was plenty salty. The fish was nicely cooked, but the entire dish overall was pretty bland.

As for dessert, this was one of the highlights of the meal. I had a mini platter including the chocolate toffee almond crunch cake, strawberry cheesecake and creme brulee duo. All were lovely, though the cake got a bit sweet towards the end.

Service was mediocre. The hostess was quite snooty and when I asked politely if we could have a booth, she rolled her eyes, and snarked that I should have mentioned it in our reservation and not now. Did I get a booth? No. Attitude? Yes.  Our server was also a bit unattentive, and communication seemed to be an issue at this restaurant. One server put our wine on ice, and didn't let our main server know. He thought it was on our table, so we had to wait, several times to have more wine poured.

Lastly, we called in advance and asked them to charge the total to the card we booked the reservation on since we have a guest who has a habit of insisting on paying. They confirmed they would do this, but didn't, so we ended up in another tussle over the bill. *sigh*

Would I come here again? Probably not on my own accord.
author: Andrea T.

description:
So my wife disagrees with this review.  But I'm going to stay on my high horse and write it anyway - and stick with my two stars.

First the food.  Clearly four star.  Not five, but the beet appetizer was very good, my wife's halibut was excellent and my bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin was very tasty too - not perfect, but really good.

So why the two stars?  Because of the wine list - and in particular the mark-ups.  I like a nice wine with my dinner, and I'm willing to pay a bit more for the experience.  But the extent to which "OK" wines were marked up to silly prices made the entire experience sour.  Why should a $46 retail wine cost $115?  I understand that restaurants need to make money - but the wine shop is making money at $46 - I would guess wholesale is $40 or less.  So why a $75 mark-up for a $40 bottle of wine?  

Plus, what's that mark-up relative to the rest of the food on our table?  I would assume at $32 for an entree you've got a profit, so why ruin my experience by kicking me with a big mark-up on my wine, for which I then feel obligated to tip even more for?

The bottom line, two people, one pre-dinner drink, a single appitizer (split), two entrees, two sides, one bottle of OK wine, no dessert and two expressos - all for just shy of $260.  Meh.  Two stars.
author: Bert R.

description: For all the hype I just didn't see what was the big deal.  I got the ahi tuna burger for lunch with big fries.  The ahi Tuna was cooked perfectly and not overdone.    The big fries needed to be fried harder, just a tad-bit to soft for me.  Really didn't care for the salad it came with.  It had arugula (a very strong aromatic taste) and a couple other leafs I couldn't i.d. but it seemed to over power the rest of the salad and it had red onions, which is a formula for heart burn.  Overall, it was okay....glad the company paid for this one.
author: Krissy A.

description: I was looking for an upscale place close to Embarcadero Bart and was rewarded with this restaurant. While the food portions are small, they make up for it in quality. I had the gnocchi and it was delicious, so I highly recommend it.
author: Robert F.

description: Love the roast duck tenderloins... Top notch dining!
author: Marissa C.

description: Sort of meh. Food  and service just ok, certainly nothing special enough to justify the prices. Not impressed.
author: Beth D.

description: Don't pay attention to the two-star reviews.  This is a very, very good restaurant, just a little below Gary Danko.   We went there tonight with four people.  Appetizers: smoked trout,  house-made speck on pickled artichokes, citrus/crab/avocado, celery root soup with rock shrimp.  Main courses: bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin, mushroom ravioli, duck breast--all great.  The grilled mahi-mahi was a little salty or else this would be a five star review.  Service was very warm and knowledgeable.  We tried six of the mini desserts: creme brulee, cheesecake, pecan tart, crunchy cake, butterscotch, and chocolate creme pie--all excellent.  The place has valet parking for only 10 bucks, which on a rainy night like tonight was a bargain.  I will be going back.
author: Joseph M.

description:
this was my 2nd visit -- my 1st visit happened many moons ago when my former employer booked our christmas party at this restaurant. 

back then, service was great but the food was far from memorable. we were sorely disappointed, especially since we had heard so many good things. the food did not even measure up to the decor nor the staff.

fast forward 4 years later and we're back -- this time for my husband's company christmas dinner. 

when he first told me that his office had chosen one market, i was disappointed and we went in last saturday evening with no expectations except that the food would be "meh."  we were in for a surprise.

during happy hour we feasted on bite-sized starter appetizers that were wonderful. they included crab cakes wrapped in a phyllo pouch and risotto balls. i can't find them on their online menu but trust me, they were good. 

for our sit down meal, i was surprised to see the wide selection of appetizers, entrees and desserts. at other restaurants, private parties are usually restricted to 1 or 2 options for each course but this time, we were able to select from 4-5. 

hubby and i had:
Appetizer: Beet Carpaccio and Bradley's Caesar Salad
Entree: Ono Sous Vide and Seared Scallops
Dessert: Duo of Creme Brulee and Valrhona Manjari Souffle Cake

we really enjoyed our dishes and felt it was a big improvement from last time. overall the staff was very attentive and the decor was still very nice.
author: yvonne g.

description:
i was hesitant to come here because i had heard mixed reviews about this place. but being that this was the only michelin rated restaurant that was offering dinner on a friday night, i made reservations. i dont regret it at all. 

i ordered the dine about town menu with the wine pairing, while my date ordered off the menu. the dine about town was $35 and i believe the wine pairing was $13 more, which was cheaper than ordering two wines. so my date and i just shared the wine as we got it. we ordered: 

- Cauliflower Soup with nantucket bay scallops, asian pears, pickled ramps - very tasty. the asian pears added an interesting flavor, however i really did not like the pickled ramps. most of it was left over in my soup (came with a chardonnay) 
- Grilled Bay Leaf Marinated Skirt Steak with"boulangere" potatoes, red wine shallot reduction - your normal steak; wasn't too impressed.
- Roasted Liberty Farms DUCK BREAST with duck leg confit, saffron, anson mills polenta, cocoa reduction - BEST duck. so delicious!! maybe b/c the duck was their 'weekly beast' special but it was sooo good. definitely order this. waiter warned us that the meat might be game-y if youre not used to it. but it was great. not too game-y for me
- Dulce de Leche Bread Pudding with caramel rum sauce, pecans, Tahitian vanilla bean ice cream - we were stuff by the time we got this but still indulged. the ice cream tasted delicious on top of the bread pudding. 

ive had better food at other one star michelin restaurants. but this place was good and i would definitely recommend it.
author: Jen S.

description:
Like LaShanda's , my office is close to here so we often take recruits to lunch here.  It is pretty much my favorite expense account restaurant in the neighborhood for the following reasons:
The menu is really diverse, everything from sandwiches and onion rings to a nice tuna steak.  
I have been happy with the food every time I have eaten here.
The waitstaff  is great and mindful of the business lunch reality so service is fast and attentive.
author: Tim G.

description:
Nearly every time I've been here, I've found the food to be not remarkable enough for the price tag it carries.  The service has always been superb, however.  Then I went with a large group from work and the food I got was actually creative and exotic (except for the capers...who the hell puts capers in a caesar salad?!)  The service was atrocious.  We didn't get the main course until an hour and a half after we sat down - one of our party actually didn't get served because he had to leave for a meeting!

And yes, the manager apologized profusely, but what good is an apology when there's the mandatory group gratuitiy no matter what they do or don't do?

There are much better restaurants in the same price range, even in the same area.
author: Frankie D.

description:
Atmosphere: big
What was nice: tuna salad for lunch, which seemed mis-titled, however, for seared tuna on the tiniest bed of lettuce
What wasn't nice: the very pushy waitperson, who kept pressuring us to order add-ons...fizzy water, drinks, side dishes, soups, etc. - was he trying to hit some quota, or what? It was third class all the way...
author: Leah B.

description:
I'd like One Market much more if our waiter hadn't kept trying to pressure us into purchasing bottles of wine for $300.  For that, I'm getting the cheapest bottle I can find on your menu.  And I'm getting four of them!

The food is pretty great though.  I loved my bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin (Though, to be honest, few things are bad when wrapped in bacon.) and some of my dining companions raved about their duck.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Keep in mind ... I had their Dine About Town prix fixe for $31.95.  There were only two choices with appetizer (soup or salad) and dessert (chocolate or not chocolate), and three choices with entrees.  We were a group of five, seated in front of the waiter's station.  It was a bit hard to concentrate on the table's conversation with them zipping back and forth so much.  

1st :: portobello mushroom soup with soy flan, quail egg and toasted rice.  The presentation was nice, as the waiter poured the soup into your bowl at the table.  It had a strong umami flavor, nice texture.  I was happy to have soup because it was so stormy outside.

2nd :: dayboat scallops with mashed potatoes in truffle oil.  The scallops were a bit overcooked, but still very tasty.  What threw me off was my plate being hotter than the food in it.    The mashed potatoes were warm, texture was just right.  

3rd :: pear galette with vanilla ice cream.  They totally saved the meal with this dessert.   The candied pecans were the perfect compliment too.   

Since it was a DAT meal, they automatically add 18% gratuity.  So, it came to $250 with some bottles of sparkling water, and a cocktail for 5 people.   Service was attentive.  I know, I had a great view of the waiters zipping around.   Overall, my $50 was well spent.  

I probably will make another visit so I can order from the ALL of the menu.
author: Lily C.

description:
Another good place for a business lunch.  We got a booth by the window, which had a fantastic view and was quite roomy.

We started with the beet carpaccio, highly recommended by our server.  It was quite nice and tasty with the sliced beets, rock shrimp, and crispy ginger.  I had the house made duck ravioli, and that was really fantastic!  The ravioli was perfectly firm, with the right amount of chewiness, and the duck filling was yummy.  The foamy broth they sat in was also quite fabulous.  The only downside was the large plate with just five of these raviolis sitting in it, looking so lonely.  

We also had the chickpea fries, broccoli rabe, and sauteed spinach.  The broccoli and spinach were great, but I don't think I'm a fan of chickpeas!  Others at the table had the skatewing and the housemade sausage.  The portions were a great size of these other entrees.  Mine must have been California cuisine.

The service was great, and our server was very friendly, telling us about the different menu items and their specialties.  Again, these places are rather pricey for some of the food portions, so I would probably take my own wallet elsewhere.
author: Angela O.

description:
It deserves 3.5 stars, but Yelp can't manage that.

Before my first visit to One Market, I had an expectation of going to an expensive restaurant that was one of the finest in San Francisco. I can confirm that the restaurant is expensive, but the jury is out on whether it is one of the finest.

First, for the good parts. One Market has amazing servers who provide the perfect level of attention without interrupting. They facilitate dinner at One Market being a social occasion. This further amplifies and ideal atmosphere. My wife and I really enjoyed their cocktails too. Their bartender mixed a pretty near perfect mojito. For the food, I was less impressed but it may have been what we ordered. My wife and I both had their "Market Menu". I believe this changes by the night. For this night, I had their halibut while my wife had pork tenderloin. We also had a dessert and appetizer with the market menu. I had the Gazpacho while my wife had the salad. 

First comment about all of the food at One Market is that presentation is superb. I was not as thrilled with the taste. The Gazpacho was good but didn't shake me to my boots and the halibut was near tasteless. My wife fared better with the pork tenderloin which had a beautiful smoked flavor as well as a nice texture. Her starter was underwhelming however. Dessert was equally mixed. The Chocolate Toffee Almond Crunch Cake was incredible. But they were out of the Chocolate Souffle and the other dish my wife had (forgot the name, I'm afraid) was less impressive. 

All this for a $70/person meal strikes me as underwhelming. Certainly, One Market is above average. But for the price, the value is not quite there in my opinion.
author: Jamie E.

description: I usually pop in through the week and grab a seat at the bar. Always a great experience!  The wine selection is wonderful, and the tasty dishes never disappoint. It's the perfect setting for unwinding after a busy day at work.
author: Jennifer V.

description:
The service was excellent. 

The food was uniformly four star with a few five star exceptions, notably the pork tenderloin and the ahi tuna, which was the highlight of the meal for me. The wine list was okay. 

The desserts? Heavenly. The tangerine pavlova was a dream, and the dessert wine we chose (Odissea) - was obscenely good and just obscene. 

All in all, a pricey but wonderful meal.
author: SC M.

description:
I can't believe that I forgot to check Yelp before making a Dine About Town reservation here for Thursday night.  I invited a friend who helped me secure my new job, thinking this would be an excellent place to have a "thank you" dinner.

I will take the blame for being late (to be fair, it was raining) and a total fumbling idiot when it came to finding a parking space.  It didn't even strike me that they would have valet until about 20 minutes after my reservation.  I drove up to the restaurant, didn't see an attendant, so called to where the person was.  The restaurant put me on hold...?

I finally just pulled over and wandered around (in the rain) until I found the valet guy.  So I was wet and feeling flustered when I walked in.  My friend had been seated and just after I had slipped into the table, the server came over to tell him that we might have to move tables because there was another reservation after us.  (Of course, no one was waiting for our table when we left...)

I was really miffed about the fact that we were being hurried along.  I was late, so I didn't take too long to study the wine list (which as a side note, is a really great wine list - mostly Northern CA/WA/OR) and went with the Ridge Lytton Spring Zinfandel.  A great zin for people who like their zin.  My pour was reasonably large and after a few sips, I was feeling less stressed out about how things had started.

In order, I chose the caesar salad, the skirt steak, and the bread pudding.  I was impressed with the presentation of the other appetizer option (cauliflower soup served over scallops) but my salad was just a boring caesar salad.  I kept thinking, shouldn't I be more impressed?

When the steaks came (portion sizes decent, with a few roasted potatoes and some steamed greens) I happily dug in.  The meat was tender and very good.  I was ambivalent about their sauce, which seemed to have a subtle burnt taste.  

Dessert was again, "good" but not great.  It was served warm (kudos on that) and I did find the caramels that came afterwards to be a sweet treat.  Oh!  And I almost forgot the seared tuna slices that came out as a starter, compliments of the kitchen.  That was a fun surprise.

The bread and water service was great, but our server forgot a glass of wine.  Since it was part of the pre-fixe Dine About Town wine pairing, I would have expected him to be able to at least tell us about the wine, but instead he was guessing and interrupting other servers to provide the details for us.  Strange...

For $125 after tip, I was completely underwhelmed.  I'd like to try this place again - when hopefully someone else will be picking up the check, dare I risk being disappointed by another dinner here.
author: Lindsay M.

description: By far the best restaurant and dinner experience in SF. We have been coming here for special occasions for years and have never been disappointed. The service, food and atmosphere are just what one would expect from a Michelin winning establishment. Make sure to make a reservation.
author: Don B.

description:
My family of six recently dined here for a special birthday dinner before heading off to a show. We arrived late (horrendous holiday traffic!) and had a deadline by when we needed to leave, but other than a vacant valet station (we left the car at the curb and raced inside, leaving keys with maitre d') they could not have been more gracious or accommodating. 
Our server, Marie, was calm, warm, and professional, and service was excellently timed. Every dish was delicious (from tongue salad to a "basic" steak; my dinner, roast sturgeon, was perfectly cooked, perfectly hot, and served on a bed of green lentils cooked with bacon - an amazing, balanced, and extremely satisfying combination of earth and sea). 
With no time for dessert, they nonetheless celebrated my 12-year-old's birthday with a special, personalized after-dinner treat, served up with the check to ensure our timely departure. 
Can't recommend One Market highly enough - top marks all around!
author: Andie T.

description: thought I'd give One Market a shot for Happy Hour which was a bad choice.  Maybe they were short handed, maybe the waitress was new... but regardless, the service was bad.  We attempted to order drinks and subsequently a second round and some apps; however, after being there for over an hour and only actually getting one round of drinks, we opted to cancel the drink order and head elsewhere.  Now I"m definitely not going back to this place for dinner or happy hour.  There are just too many good bars and restaurants in downtown SF to waste time with one that's mediocre on a good day.
author: Nedra D.

description:
Ok, seriously.  How did this place earn a Michelin star?  Either I ended up at One Market on a "bad day", or the Michelin reviewers aren't nearly as discriminating as I give them credit for.
My dining companions and I had reservations, so we were seated very quickly by the hostess.  The ambiance of the restaurant is very nice and the volume in the room isn't too loud.  However, their wait service was lacking.  Our waitress was nice enough, but didn't leave us with that warm fuzzy feeling.  While delivering our drinks, she kept reaching over people to hand out glasses.  When telling us about the specials for the day, she mumbled and we couldn't understand her.  And when we told her we were ready to order, she said okay... then walked away for 10 minutes.  Once our meal was ordered, it was an hour before we received our food.   "While waiting, I must have counted 3-4 instances where various waiters/bus boys dropped silverware, plates, or trays on the floor.  Luckily, I didn't get hit by any of the food on it -- the same could not be said about the guy sitting across from me.
The food itself was not that impressive.  I had the crab cakes, which were about the size of quarters.  For $15, I expected a little bit more.  My fellow diners had the cauliflower soup with scallops, I had a bit of food envy over that.  For the main course, I had the trout.  It was really salty and tasted just a bit burnt around the edges.  On the plus side, the bread and mashed potatoes were quite good.
author: Alex O.

description: I can't believe this place has a Michelin star.  Totally proves the adage that Michelin gives American cities a break compared to London or Paris.  At any rate, the food is, as Colin H. says below, "standard high end business lunch fare."  Totally tasty, but nothing special.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I came here with my mom awhile back and although I enjoyed the experience, I somehow expected more and was kind of disappointed.  The location is great, and I like the big open dining room with all the natural light flooding in, but I wanted more of an "oomph" in the dish for what it cost.

And service seems a tiny bit snotty there.  Not such a fan of that.
author: Karen L.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by my meal.  They had wild sockeye salmon which is hard to find on menus in the city.  I'm a big fan of sockeye but restaurants prefer to serve King Salmon.  

The creamed corn I had with the salmon was excellent.  Another highlight was the ice cream sandwhich for dessert.  Yum.
author: jeff k.

description:
Meh.  Food was good, but here are my gripes:

- Price:  Come on - $32.00 for 4 slices of tuna for the "Simply Grilled" tuna entree?  Your average high-end sushi bar gets $12.00 for this prepared sashimi-style - and there wasn't anything more to this entree than that.  The lamb loin entree for $32.00 was no more than 4oz of meat (4 slices)

- Service: Slow but attentive.  One of the people in our party is finnicky about eating underdone meat and requested that the sliders appetizer be cooked well-done.  The chef refused, and instead sent the manager over to offer something else.  I understand that he doesnj't want them to turn into Slider Hockeypucks, but then don't bother cooking them and tell the waitstaff to take the alternate order immediately

And now for the good stuff

- Food was delicious.  The aformentioned tuna and lamb entrees were both excellent - delicious and well prepared.  The burger that replaced the sliders was also an excellent burger.
author: David T.

description:
One Market is not as good as Bradley Ogden's other Restaurants.  The food was decent, but a little over priced - but that could be expected with it's location on the Embarcadero and view of the Bay & Bay Bridge.  

Service was excellent and the ambiance is great.  It's a very clean and contemporary looking restaurant.  Some tables seem to be a little too close together, which takes away from the intimacy of being there for a special occasion.  

There were a lot of large groups there the night I went there, which made it hard to talk at a normal level across the table to my fiancee.  It felt like we were almost yelling across our table for two.

Very nice wine list.  Drinks are moderately priced for SF.  Parking can be difficult; best to Cab there if you are already in the City.

Would recommend if it's available on the 'Dine About Town" Program.
author: Gurdeep J.

description: I stopped in without having much time, so i thought I'd sit at the bar and order a burger.  Jeezuz that was the best burger I've ever eaten....and I've eaten a lot of burgers in my day. It was big, juicy, and at the same time elegant.  I didn't think a burger could ever be called elegant, but it was.  Awesome quality beef, perfectly caramelized onions, a high quality blue cheese, a bun that was soft, but perfectly toated around the edges, and homemade ketchup.  I swear to god I'm salivating as I write this.
author: Mr P.

description:
My iPhone was stolen from One Market after work last week.  I literally left the restaurant, realized that I left my phone on the table, and returned.  The time between leaving the restaurant and returning = approx. 10-15 minutes.  During this time my iPhone was taken.  While I would expect to have my iPhone stolen under a similar situation in other restaurants of lower quality, I was fairly surprised that this happened at One Market.  It's possible that a patron took it, although I would imagine that the clientele who frequent One Market wouldn't feel the need to take an iPhone.

I haven't received much help from One Market in retrieving the phone (I've contacted them 3 times now).   And, while I don't think they should be responsible given the circumstances, I also think they could be more helpful.  I don't think it's unreasonable for a manager to offer to speak with the staff about the situation.  I'm planning to speak with a manager this week - hopefully I'll get more help. 

I haven't been to One Market for lunch or dinner yet.  This is simply a review on the service in an unfortunate situation.
author: Bethany S.

description: I do not yelp restaurant very often but I just wanted to express myself that the food was good but service was not, trying to find the seat numbers for every course, I was not even asked if I wanted a drink but the server asked the rest of my party, wine: I never said I did not drink any, and coffees, server takes 5 trips for 5 guests, easier to ask everyone and do one trip no? Anyway not for me, will not be back, and I am sure one less guests is no big deal, but I wanted to say what I had to say. I was very disapointed for such a so called great restaurant, the whole service for my party and all my friends was a very bad experience to all of us, I have worked in the restaurant industry for now 24years and never seen such a bad service in my whole entire career. Need training or just need professional ? not quite sure but I will not be the one trying it again that is for sure !
author: Wilson D.

description:
So, i think I am going to go in tomorrow to compliment our waitress.  She was that good. I am in a law school course where we go out and teach constitutional law to public school students.  The school I ended up teaching at was in west Oakland and for the "prize" for the best students we took them here for dinner tonight.  The waitress was amazing.  When she saw the students were confused by the menu she instantly chipped in to help them out.  When someone used the wrong fork she swooped by to pour water and whispered in their ear.  The food was good...I would say a four.  But, our waitress stole my heart.  She was incredible.  Anywhere/anyone who is willing to put in the kind of effort she put in is great by me. 
 Oh, and the chef came to our table to speak to the students too.  SWOOON!  I was worried about how tonight would go and had I been anywhere else it may have been sketchy, but Onemarket made it the best evening I have had in a very long time.  If i could give them six stars I would.  Thank you, thank you, thank you
author: Caleb R.

description:
I LOOOVE duck. They do it right. 

It was a duck night for me last night. I ordered seared foie gras and nearly fell out of my chair, it was so good. The duck breast was served medium rare, and the confit had the consistency of pulled pork. The little slices of seared ahi (on the house) were great. Also, they had a very nice wine selection, by the glass and by the bottle or half bottle. I will be thinking about the foie gras for days to come...  I thought I would return for my birthday but I don't think I can wait that long. Worth every penny.
author: Jin I.

description: Meh. I don't quite understand the Michelin star for this place. Our server was very, very inattentive. She forgot to bring TWO different things that I ordered. Some of the food was good, some was just OK. The dessert was a stand-out. But poor service and unremarkable food means that I would not recommend, nor will I go back. I'd rather do Boulevard...
author: Jason Y.

description: Every time I've been there the food has been good.  The "business lunch" menu is exceptionally well priced.
author: David H.

description:
Went here with my boyfriend for a lunch date - I was left unimpressed. My expectations were especially high after reading some good reviews and keeping in mind that this is definitely one of the pricier restaurants that I have dined at.
After arriving, we were promptly seated at a small table by the door. I noticed that the restaurant was filled with people on business lunches, etc, and there did not seem to be enough waiters to give every table prompt service. After a long wait, we placed our order. At the beginning of the meal, they do serve delicious bread, and because our food came out so slowly, we asked for 1 or 2 more baskets of bread to munch on. My first course was the Farmer's Market Salad. It was extremely bland - just a jumble of leaves tossed in balsamic vinegar. I could have made this in my sleep! My boyfriend's soup was slightly better, but the flavors were bland and reminded me a bit of Campbell's canned chicken noodle soup..
Next came our main courses. While the presentation was nice - my mushroom ravioli was surrounded by foam, the taste was once again, bland and boring. After eating several bites of it, I was already tired of the taste, and my boyfriend offered to trade dishes with me. His pot roast was quite tender and flavorful, but once again, nothing in particular stood out to me. And finally, after another very very long wait, our dessert arrived - strawberry shortcake. The strawberries were fresh, the cream was good, the cake portion of it was okay, another mediocre course. Sadly, the bread was the best part of the meal.
If we hadn't been eating this lunch at Dine About Town prices, I would have been outraged at how much we would have to pay for this meal. And if you think that perhaps the menu items on the DAT menu did not accurately portray courses from One Market, note that many of the items we ordered were on the actual menu itself. I do not think I will be returning to One Market. It is definitely not worth it to pay this much for a slow and very forgettable meal.
author: Shawna C.
