description: The food and service here generally are good, but I think there are other more deserving restaurants out there.  The last time I went for dinner, the service was not great - slow, not helpful and seemed to ignore our table.
author: B. Y.

description: One of the best dining experiences I've ever had. Great date spot. Amazing food. Decent proportions.
author: Jared G.

description:
The food was amazing. I have never in my life had such an emotional experience with the food that I have been served. My boyfriend and I ordered the meal that comes with a wine pairing and chose of dessert. It was amazing, The wine choices clearly fit each individual dish. 

It was a little on the more expensive side. But so so worth it!
author: Jolene P.

description: Very delicious.... Definitely warrants a return visit. I tried the 5 course sampler dinner with wine pairing. Excellent food.
author: Joey D.

description:
Two great dining experiences two days in a row   Bully for me!!
This is a nice place right on market street and the water.  I knew we were in for a interesting dining experience when the waiter came over.  He was a little bit on the sarcastic, obnoxious side, but funny and attentive nonetheless.  I had a Vodka Cranberry before dinner, made with a local vodka called "Hanger One"....Actually not bad, similar to Grey Goose, but not quite as tasty, but with far less "bite."  If you like Vodka, try this.  We ordered a tray of olives and such, and a Tomato/Peppers Pizza.  Both were very good.  I was actually suprised how tasty the olives were.  I am a huge olive fan, and these were great.  The pizza was good, just a little plain for me.  Worth checking this place out again, as they have a nice menu and much more to choose from.
author: Josh S.

description:
The food isn't as amazing as you'd hope.  There's a few things on the menu that sound good but turn out being pretty bizarre.  I was pretty disappointed when my dungeness crab salad came out with a jello-like corn substance on top.

I might come back for dessert and drinks but will try to avoid having another meal here since it's a little overpriced.
author: Andrea S.

description: My husband and I had a DAT lunch here on Friday. So disappointing. The service was slow, and my husband had finished his dessert before they brought my coffee. My pollock was dry and looked as if it had been waiting under the warming lamp for too long. I was surprised when I received the check. Our waiter had charged me an 18% gratuity.When I asked him he said "We charge this gratuity for all Dine about Town customers". The restaurant had posted no information on this practice,also I have not been charged this in the past by other restaurants participating in the Dine about Town .I will not return to this restaurant.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: It was one of those business dinners and you're like okay why not it's free food. As soon as you enter the restaurant the Michelen Award is in your face telling you that there is good food to be had. The food was not good enough for me to escape to another place, and ignore the girl across from me constantly talking about her personnel issues. I guess she was keeping it real. Anyways back to the food, the hamachi tomatillo would have been better w/o the tomatillo sauce. The sauce to me was bland. The NY steak, it was my fault for choosing it, as how good could a NY steak be cooked. The chocolate souffle was like a dense chocolate cake w/ creme fresh on top.
author: Andrenaline R.

description: Great location for lunch meetings. Foods are always decent.
author: Jon D.

description: Been disappointed three times in a row.  Why is it so highly rated by the M Guide again?  Great location, but very average food...
author: Joseph F.

description: Food is good but not one Michelin star good.
author: Platform Universe S.

description: Refreshing to have non-alcoholic special drinks, in this case lemonade slushies flavored with additional strawberries or mint -- so refreshing! The risotto was phenomenal, service exceptional and ambiance airy and full of light. Great experience all around. Spendy and worth it.
author: Kay R.

description: Couldn't be happier. Tonight was our first time there and I'm happy to say it was awesome. The food and service was the best I've had in a while. But when I go back I plan to sit near the kitchen so I can watch them work. Everything is so fresh.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Not very good.

Highlight of the evening was a bottle of great Nickel and Nicel cab. For those of you who haven't tried it, try it. Great wine from the makers of Far Niente. 

Alas, they even managed to screw this up. Towards the end of dinner the waitress poured sparkling water into the wine glass. Ruined a perfectly good glass of wine. At 135.00 a bottle, it's not a extremely pricey wine, but not cheap either.

Appetizer was decent, a nice Foie Gras salad. Can't really go worng with seared foie gras. Entrees were mediocre at best. Place was just boring and tired. Won't return.
author: Jason K.

description:
My husband and I ate here for Dine About Town this past week on our anniversary.  I first came here for DAT in January 2002 with a girlfriend and loved the food.  I've gone to other restaurants for DAT over the years (Moose's, Le Colonial, Cliff House), but none of them were as good as One Market, so I decided to come back this year.  And I wasn't disappointed.

What I like best about One Market's DAT is that they put items from their menu on the DAT menu, unlike some other restaurants.  There were two starter choices, three entree choices, and two dessert choices.

I had Bradley's Caesar Salad for my appetizer (I'm a Bradley's Caesar groupie--have had it at the Lark Creek Inn, Yankee Pier, and his restaurant in Vegas, so I was glad when I saw it on the menu, although I was kinda hoping to try something new) and my husband had the mushroom soup.  The presentation of the soup was great and it was really good.  For our entree, I had the winter squash with risotto appetizer (soooooo yummy!) and my husband had the scallops.  We each ordered one of the desserts and shared them.  The restaurant knew it was our anniversary, so the pastry chef wrote "Happy Anniversary" in chocolate on our dessert plates.  Very nice.  The service was excellent and food was amazing.  We ordered lovely cocktails from the bar when we first sat down and a nice bottle of wine to go with our food.

If you're looking for a restaurant to try during DAT, go to One Market.  You will not be disappointed!
author: Jen N.

description:
Rev 2/22/08: Came here again for lunch with 6 coworkers and lunch took almost 2 hours.  I would again state that service was slow but did venture into their lemonade, which I would recommend if you were to go there.  It's slushy-like and very yummy.

Went there last Friday for dine about town and I have to give it two stars for the following: 1. for a table of 2, lunch took 1.5 hrs not cuz we were chatty but it took a really long time for each course to be served. 2. bill came with 18% gratuity included, hello-there were only 2 of us.

I had the soup, tri-tip and  mousse.  Only the tri-tip is worth mentioning cuz it tasted much better than it looked.  Nothing special about this place.  Even for a work lunch/dinner, I would not choose to come back here again as there are much better places in the area.
author: bunnymouse k.

description:
like it's not bad enough dining solo without reservation... then the hostess treats you like a nobody.  ehh fine.  hostess should be nicer.

Had Dine About Town dinner here tonight:

APPETIZER:
Lentil Soup - it was okay. didnt finish it

ENTREE:
Short Ribs - i dont know if it's cooked wrong or it's not fresh but  the short ribs had a scent to it. you know that old unpleasant scent?  the first bite was delicious and everything else later was so dry. I do like their risotto. that was very yummy

DESSERT:
Crunch Cake - not bad. best thing i had here.  cake itself was flavorless but VERY moist.  glad it was flavorless because everything else around it (the toffee and chocolate) were very sweet.  

i dont get it.  i dined alone and they charged me 18% gratuity. it rang up to about $6 in gratuity but i was going to give her $10 anyway.  since they pre-charged me i decided not to give the extra. Too bad, she woudl've gotten more.  I know on the menu it said gratuity on group of 7+, so for them to do that to me, it felt like they were judging me and i felt like they were thinking i wasn't going to tip them or something. 

Overall...food is okay and they need new staff and i felt very unwelcomed.
-Hostess needs to be nicer and welcoming. i dont care how busy they are, it's a restaurant business.
-Busser or runners need to have some kind of a smile or something... they have a look like i was an inconvenience to them
-server was really nice, but the gratuity threw me off
author: Joanne H.

description:
nice bar area with some every day cocktails.  seems like a solid happy hour venue...

i wish that the cocktails were more inventive but the diners are the older and financial folks and by 9:30pm...the place was dead. .

the 2009 dine about town menu was uninspiring, so we ordered from the main menu.

there were 5 diff varietals for oysters.  they didn't say that one was no longer available so i was quite peeved to see a double order of one kind that i did not request...

they normally carry:

1. malpeque (out that night)
2. fanny bay
3. saccostrea? (unsure due to waiter's delivery)
4. buckley bay
5. hood canal

a third of the oysters had shell pieces.  not the best shucking i have seen...

the amuse bouche with crostini, duck liver and cocoa nibs was quite tasty.  a definite thumbs up!

1. the beef cheeks  were a must - the pieces of meat were melt in your mouth soft and tender.
2. the duck was breast and confit mix - flavorful as well
3. the pancetta wrapped scallops were well cooked but not extraordinary.  the balance of the sweetness of the scallops were a nice contrast with the salty pancetta and garlic spinach.  but i found the foam to be too old school. 

4. the deep dish dutch apple pie was delicious. - browned crumble with lovely tart apple, thin apple crisp in the icecream and sweet raisins.

the wine and liquor selection was passable.  i sipped the prisoner orin swift - a usual berry bet.

overall good, but not a great scene unless you are conducting business there.
author: Anh V.

description:
I experienced One Market for the first time a few months ago when I came here for a casual dinner with coworkers. The overall atmosphere was very pleasant; the decor was quite neutral, but tasteful nonetheless. We were greeted by a host who all but refused to seat us without reservations. No worries - we grabbed drinks and waited until a table became available.
Once seated, I found our waiter to be very friendly; he struck my preferred balance of being informative without becoming overbearing. Luckily, this visit was before the State of California took our foie gras away, so my choice of appetizer was easily made. That was followed by a Caesar salad - I personally do not agree with serving Romain leaves whole, but it certainly did not detract from their flavor or ability to hold fresh parmesan. I ordered steak as a main course (I'm not exactly sure of the cut, but it may have been a NY strip). It was prepared well, not much room for creativity here. To be completely honest, I may have had slightly heightened expectations brought upon by seeing their Michelin Star proudly displayed, but I was thankfully not disappointed by the quality of the food.
Dessert followed suit. The cheese platter was markedly underwhelming, but the berry sorbet I tried was quite impressive. Overall, I was rather pleased with the menu and service. One Market is definitely one of my preferred places to eat in San Francisco.
author: Paul S.

description: Great food, service and atmophere. A perfect spot for a business dinner.
author: Jim R.

description: I was so excited to try One Market after hearing such great reviews. Unfortunately I was extremely disappointed with both the service and my meal last night! Firstly, they tout their association with the Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Watch and use of sustainable meats and produce. But our waitress had a tough time explaining why day boat scallops from PEI were on the menu. It gets better. I ordered the Golden Beet & Saffron Soup with geoduck clam, ahi tuna, and green apple. (Sounds delicious, right?) Well, halfway through it I realized there was shrimp in it. I'm mildly allergic to shrimp so I mentioned it to the waitress and she insisted it was listed as an ingredient on the menu. To her credit, she had the soup removed from our bill, but when I returned home I double checked the menu online, and, as suspected, no shrimp. That's a pretty serious mixup, and I'm lucky I'm not severely allergic. Aside from that, the meal was lackluster, bland, overpriced, and run-of-the-mill. To top it all off, my guests and I could not get a cab afterwards and ended up walking a mile or more up Market Street to find a bus. The restaurant tried calling a cab, but after waiting for more than 30 minutes, we decided it was best to track down some public transit. Needless to say, I will not be returning to One Market for a meal anytime soon. There are far better places in this city!
author: Jessica M.

description: Cant believe I havent reviewed this place before.  The dine about town lunch menu (asparagus soup, open-face fresh pea ravioli and nectarine tart dessert) and wine pairings were fantastic.  It was the best lunch I've had in a good while.
author: brewgirl b.

description: Don't really have anything to complain about.  Service was great.  They replaced our silverware promptly after each course although the water came a little slow.  The inside is set up nicely with large windows and a good location.  I had the lamb which was done a few different ways - all of which were very good.  My girlfriend had the weekly beast (pigeon), and we both agreed this was one of our best meals in SF.  It was a very complete experience, and I would definitely go back again just to try their different prix fixe options.
author: Nate W.

description: I know there are a ton of reviews on this restaurant, but I had to write about our experience at the Chef's Table.  In terms of the service, it was great, our server was very friendly and knowledgeable about the details of the restaurant as well as wine selections.  One of the managers also gave us a tour of the restaurant which was pretty interesting.  On to the food, for me it was more about the presentation and interesting combinations, not necessarily amazingly delicious.  Having said that, for some of the others, they really did think each of the courses were very tasty.  Overall I think the Chef's Table for $85 was really a great deal.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
Overpriced for what it is.

We came here for a Saturday night special occasion dinner while visiting SF. After doing much Yelp-based research from Boston, we picked this spot based on the Weekly Beast lamb menu. The first course, ravioli with lamb ragu, was out of this world and would have been a sufficient dinner in itself. The next two courses failed to impress, with undercooked meat and odd flavorings. At $195 for 2 prix fixe dinners with wine, we felt we could have done better both food and price-wise somewhere else.
author: Kate G.

description: "generic" and "impersonal" business dining "ambiance" is the main draw to this "embarcadero weekend ghost town" staple. the "amex corporate card" and "crusty old white guys in suits" pair well with the "excessive use of french" on the menu.  soup was "unintentionally cool," fish was "ok," but the standout was the "pushy but ultimately incompetent" service that explained "why our two course lunch took almost 2.5 hours."  you might have better luck in the "evening," with the "above 40 happy hour crowd," but one market is likely "not worth a second visit."
author: Stephanie L.

description: One of my favourite restaurants in SF and definitely the best choice in financial district. Good choice of wines.
author: Sergey K.

description: I was really torn on 3 or 4 stars here. I had to bump this place up a star because of it's huge windows and view of the ferry building. The food gets a 3 star for just being okay. The menu was kind of vague in the sense that in a party of eight people had no idea what to expect and some were NOT pleasantly surprised. I had a lack luster ceasar salad, "paella" with quotations (the quotations are for an impression of paella), and ended with creme brulee. The creme brulee was the highlight of the meal. Again, this was my first visit and it is possible that I would enjoy another entree more. Some of my counterparts really enjoyed their dishes. The shrimp and crab cakes looked good from a distance. Service is above standard, as expected at a 3 $$$ sign restaurant. I will try this place again, especially for a business lunch.
author: Stafford J.

description: they do deserve the michelin star. excellent service and great food. On a Wednesday night they ran out of foir gras, so that was the disappointment. the salmon appertizer was super fresh and delicious. I ordered the cod and it did not have a strong taste. the broil it for awhile. The fish was still moist with a light sauce. My friend got the porkchop and that was tender, the steak wrapped with bacon was cooked perfectly and yummy. the sides are my fav. the chick pea fries are to die for. mash potatos and garlic spinish was good too. for dessert we tried a few, but don't reall remember what, so I don't think they were that good.
author: Karen H.

description:
I came here with a group of girlfriends for Dine About Town in January and we enjoyed ourselves so much that we ended up eating a three-hour meal and were the last customers to leave the restaurant. 

Pancetta-wrapped scallops were good, and my friend's bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin was really juicy and tender. I'm not a big red meat eater but I'd order the tenderloin if I come here again. (edit: reading this 4 years later.. this must've been one of the catalysts of reversing my pescetarianism)

Overall a classy but vibrant atmosphere, perfect for both dates and business meals.
author: S L.

description: Have been here a few times now, and it never fails to impress. Great food, smaller portions, but really rich and well prepared! LOVED the rabbit!
author: Chris H.

description: I came here with a skinny cow that actually eats more than me and probably weighs as much as my left thigh.  The restaurant is the perfect location for people looking to grab dinner after work.  The person that gave this place a michelin star for two years in a row isn't a fatty.  I felt this place didn't deserve a star.  It was good but it didn't blow me away.  I think they should give their star to Absinthe.  The food here is served a la cart.  Interesting set up.  I am glad I tried it once.
author: Fatty A.

description:
The hostess has major attitude and seems to enjoy being condescending despite her position. Quite condescending. Not just on one occasion, but several. But since I find the food quite enjoyable, as well as the location and decor of the restaurant, I decided to pop in on a recent sat evening for a quick meal. I called for reservations and whoever answered seemed pissy. Going against my better judgement, I went ahead and made a reservation anyways. Upon arrival, she was worse in person than on the phone.

Asides from that, the menu emphasizes fresh, locally sourced ingredients, with options such as duck, fish, and lots of vegetables. I think the Bradley Ceasar Salad is probably one of the better ceasars Ive had, ice cold romaine, not overpowered by a dressing thats just tart and creamy enough, topped with delicious parm and of course the croutons....the duck was perfectly seasoned, but on the one occasion my friend ordered the skate...it was a bit unnerving. So it was served with poppy seeds and at first glance, we couldn't figure out if it was the skin, or what all the spreckles were. Even after being reassured by our server that this was not skin, its probably safer to stick with some other type of fish if you're not into wierd looking spots on your food. If you're not into a full meal, they do have a bar bites menu at the bar. You really can't go wrong with potato skins layered with bacon and cheese, sliders with oodles of carmelized onions, and of plate of fries.

So yes, the food is good, and the location is great, and its a beautiful restaurant, but really, there are so many other restaurants in the city to choose from, why would I subject myself to such rude off-putting treatment by a hostess? Maybe I'll return for HH in the bar area...or if the hostess learns how to behave...btw it's four stars but minus one star for the hostess.
author: helen l.

description:
amazingly busy during weekday lunch. very very fancy (I haven't grown up yet; I'm not good at spending that much for lunch!).... went for dine about town. 

huge round table for 8 of us - really hard to hear across! 

huge portions, considering it's a fancy place.

purple risotto was amazing.

scallop dry soup was good - served dry, then they pour the soup base on in front of you!....

pineapple upside down cake was a mini cake with chopped pineapple etc on top after the fact...very modern interpretation i guess...
author: S V.

description: I just had the best coconut cream pie that I have ever tasted.  Delicious.  Also - they are having the half off wine month.
author: Sarah M.

description: Great location.  Decent decor.  The food is simply wonderful.  Not overly creative, but expertly executed.  Best salmon I've ever had.  Came here for business lunch.  Would return for business, but not for pleasure.  There are other restaurants in the area with great food, that have lower prices and a nicer atmosphere.
author: J W.

description: We were there for Dine Around Town. Elegant and efficient.  Loved the bread stuffed with olives.  Menu was limited and the food quality/taste was not memorable.  Nothing healthy on children's menu (even though price was very reasonable).  I give the restaurant a 4 start for their service.  I will go there to be pampered, but if and when I crave for good food, I'll go to Gary Danko instead.
author: El C.

description:
Went here for dine about town.  Entree options were decent and you had plenty of dessert options. They started out with olive & sour dough bread. (The sour dough was superb...yum). I had the Bradley's Caesar Salad as my app, Open Face Pea Ravioli as my entree and for dessert, I had the Nectarine Tart with Blackberry compote (which just means fresh berries on top). Caesar Salad was nothing special, but I did notice more lemon juice in their dressing. And if you are a cheese fan, you'll love it b/c they put LOTS of cheese on top of  the salad. The Open Face Pea Ravioli was just okay. The ingredients seemed very fresh, but a bit lack of character in taste for this dish. It was a bit too plain and the peas were not cooked too well. If you're a pea fan, then this is your dish b/c there's a lot of peas. You're basically eating a plate of cooked peas. The dessert was AMAZING! Very buttery with a fresh fruity taste! Perfect with your latte. 

We also ordered the cheesy pasta and Beet Carpaccio with
radishes, fresh chevre, sherry vinaigrette. The cheesy pasta was SUPER CHEESY and rich (Not worth it). The Beet Carpaccio however was fabulous. The app was super fresh and the taste of the sherry vinaigrette, radish and beet was very unique and tasty. 


Other Dine about Town options: 
Appz: Asparagus Soup with pasture egg "sous vide", parmesan, prosciutto (My sis had this app and it was rich and tasty)
Entree: Halibut with mustard green ravioli, shiitake mushrooms, bean sprouts, mushroom-dashi broth (Sis got this entree and the Halibut was cooked to close to perfection. Delicious! or Beef (Did not try)
Dessert: You pick any on their mini dessert. 

Service was great and it better had been for the money we spent. Location was good and parking is fairly easy to find. Just park a block down or two after 6pm.  Overall, Dine About Town here is a good experience, but don't think it's worth to pay the regular price to eat here even with the large glass windows with view.  So if Dine About Town is here again, take advantage of it while you can!
author: Yvonne T.

description: Really not that impressed. Definitely not deserving of a Michelin Star. I could easily name other restaurants in the city that are far better. I didn't feel like any of the flavors stood out to me. Everything was just fairly bland. The only thing I would go back for is the salted carmel candy they give you with your check. Now that was amazing! Now I won't pretend like I didn't have high standards for a Michelin-rated restaurant, so I'm not saying the food was bad, it was just unimpressive.
author: Alexandra B.

description: This has got to be one of the worst restaurants I've ever been to. I know it's sppose to be a Michelin 1 star restaurant. But I have got to say that McDonald food taste so much better. I went there the other day for a business lunch. Ordered a roasted chicken. Looked super plain on the outside. After cutting the chicken open for a first bite, I noticed it was raw inside. I know we're not suppose to be eating raw chicken so I called the waitress explained the situation. She told me that it's suppose to be raw. Wow, I told myself, are you crazy?!! You can get sick from eating raw chicken!! Anyway, she took the chicken back and had it baked a little more. The chicken came back in a few minutes and I finally was able to enjoy the chicken. However, upon the first bite, the chicken just tasted blend. The $5 roasted chicken at Costco taste 10 times better. I didn't even finish it because it was so tasteless. Michelin 1 star?!!! I don't know...I rather eat at McDonald.
author: Ting R.

description: Simply put, the very best restaurant in all San Francisco.  Incredibly delicious, creative, and magical food.  Weekly Beast and the cheese plate are must haves.  Also, reserve the Chef's Table for the ultimate experience. Very good wine selection ($20 corkage fee), excellent desserts, and the service is superb.
author: Lynn S.

description: 6 of of went last Friday night and I and 2 friends had the "weekly beast". It was lamb that night and all the dishes were excellent. Lamb belly salad, shoulder that melted in your mouth, rack of lamb... The best value for $49 (5 full courses) you could imaging and the $20 wine pairing add on was nearly 4 glasses of good, well paired wine. Our food was so good one friend and her husband went back the next week for the "weekly beast" which was beef. I'm so jealous!
author: Christopher B.

description:
Came here last week and ordered the following appetizers:

trout (delicious)
grilled octopus (too chewy and sort of bland) 
dungeness crab cakes (watery and salty, fell apart easily) 

and ordered the ravioli as main course
WAYYY too salty

The service was really good though, and yes the location amazing.  I'd definitely give this place a try again, I'll just order something different next time because I wasn't too pleased with what I ordered.
author: Emily L.

description: completely disappointed... price wasn't bad... $400 for 3 people but the quality of the food was subpar... I expected more from a Michelin starred restaurant... I haven't given up on trying all Michelin starred restaurants in the bay though... :)
author: Maureen A.

description:
For private dining only.

There are some foo-foo, chichi restaurants who have private dining rooms  but don't want to deal with having private dining service.  They want you to choose 1 entree for your group (Tru in Chicago).  Or refuse to open early (Boulevard in SF) or don't want do do anything outside of how they usually do things (LOTS of them).

One Market isn't like that.  From my first call everything was easy-peasy.  Okay, well easy, cause I had a hard time reaching private dining at first, but otherwise, cool.  They have a great menu for private events and the events team is VERY flexible and helpful.  As I said, a lot of the foofoo chichi restaurants won't start an event at 10am or provide morning treats for my guests. Even though One Market isn't open for breakfast, they provided a great spread of goodies that everyone seemed to enjoy.  They were flexible with the room set up and a changing number of tables.  The service was great - everyone was very courteous.  Shawn, my event captain, was on her toes but cool and even verified details I hadn't thought about.  Eric - the co-captain (?) even helped me carry things in from my car.  The rest of the servers were great.  The room I had was smallish, and has it's back to the kitchen - so there is a bit of a noise issue, but not real bad.  

The food was delish.  The spring veggie salad is sooooo good, asparagus, fennel, carrots - so light and fresh.  I had the mahi mahi, which was similar to a dish I had at Food Studio in Atlanta.  Had Food Studio not been a-may-zing, I would have loved this dish.  The chicken looked great as well.  The dessert, however, stole the show.  The Valrhona chocolate cake was deeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeevine.  I wanted to take one home and have my way with it, but instead I had to sit the primly while enjoying this amazing thing.  I wasn't the only one, I saw a couple other guests sighing contently.

All in all, this is a great location for business events.  The staff knows how to help you make it happen and the food will make your guests happy.
author: Gracie B.

description: Maybe I'm biased because I was invited to sit at the chef's table, located inside the kitchen, but holy f-ing shit! The food was so spectacular. This is what top chef is all about baby. Fancy shmancy food, prepared like art that tastes like little drops of heaven on your tongue. I went here for a friend's birthday with her richy rich parents. We were led past all the "normal" diners and into the kitchen, where the staff were calmly, yet efficiently preparing the patron's meals. At the chefs table, you are welcomed by the chef, then led to the wine storage room by the sommelier, who talks about the restaurant's selection of wine and allows you to taste some. Then you go back to the table and partake in gastronomic fantasy. I think we ate a 7 course meal, but after the first three courses I hit a food coma and blanked out. I just remember that I kept shoveling food into my mouth, despite my buttons popping, because damn that was some good eats. risottos and and scallops and chocolate tortes, oh my. There was some foamy stuff, some squash blossoms, pretty squiggles painted on the plate. I know, I sound like a five year old describing a painting, but the food made me feel like I grew up in a cardboard box (a small one), instead of San Anselmo. If you have the will and the means, go to One Market and reserve the chef's table for a really special occasion. It is sooo worth it. I only wish my friend's wealthy parents would adopt me as a surrogate child so I could eat this well every freaking day of my life. If I was to actually come back here with my own wallet, I would probably be eating the appetizers and a pretty drink at the bar. So sad...
author: Sammy S.

description:
Just missed the 5 star-mark - by a soup!  We went for the first time (yes, I know, unbelievable) on a Dine About Town night.  Not sure yet if i think the meal you get on a DAT night is a good measure of a restaurant or not.  But it's a false economy, no matter what.  I always want to order off the "real menu!"  We stuck to our guns, mostly, and the bill ended up being $100.  Which isn't cheap (well, maybe for One Market it is), but most of the meal and experience were well worth it.

First course, the aforementioned soup:  Touted as a portabella mushroom soup with a soy flan thing in the middle, and a beautiful tiny fried quail egg on top.  presentation was great - they poured the soup from a little tureen into the bowl, making the soy disc a little island.  however, it tasted so incredibly weird that we couldn't finish it.  It smelled very strongly of beef broth, but a very sweet beef broth, almost like a french onion soup.  not mushroomy at all.  it tasted sweet too, but also a bit sour, like when you overcook garlic. and the soy thing in the middle was just bitter.  and there were crunchy floating things that tasted like bits of matzo crackers but supposedly was crispy rice.  just a bad, bad dish.  the waitress said "most people like it", implying that we were rubes, and that the dish had "very strong asian and fish flavors" that i guess our untrained pedestrian palates wouldn't appreciate.  um, no.  (she redeemed herself later tho - actually very excellent attentive service.)  and no mushroom taste discernable at all.  a total failure, which was truly shocking compared to the rest of our meal.  we actually sent the soup back and asked to see the menu for another app, this time off the regular menu.  waitress offered to give us the cesar salad that was on the DAT menu, but we decided to go for the real deal.  she recommended a "bistro" starter - a delicious potato rosti,  perfectly crispy on the outside, warm and pillowy on the inside.  Atop that, a kind of loose puree of watercress, and then a peachy-pink mound of smoked trout.  The waitress warned us that it wasn't "too smoky", as if we we would be afraid, being the obvious avant-garde-asian-mushroom-soup-hating-hicks that we were, and it wasn't.  It was perfectly smoky.  On top of that, a quivering pure white organic poached egg with a creamy yellow center to ooze down over the mound.  The plate was swirled with a vinaigrette blended with little bits of savory pancetta.  great flavor combo.  Very rich.  Very Lyonnaise!  Fabulous.

My duck:  two ways - tender perfectly pearly-red breast meat, served atop duck confit - in this incarnation, a kind of ground duck patty, spiced, almost sausage-y.  Served alongside were roasted chestnuts - nice nutty sweet accompaniment to the maple-y duck breast.  My sister's scallops: 3 plump - and she says - perfectly cooked diver scallops, on a creamy cloud of mashed taters, with sauteed fennel, and a delicious tarragon butter.  The tarragon and fennel went exceedingly well together, despite or maybe because of being both licorice  flavors.

Desserts were incredible.  A pear galette with vanilla ice cream was topped by a perfect paper-thin cross-sectional slice of baked pear.  The pastry itself was warm, chewy yet flaky, with a delicate pear flavor.  Sister's dessert was a take on churros dipped in thick Mexican chocolate - here they were called chocolate fritters with molten chocolate inside, served with a cup of thick melted white chocolate, with a great bite of cinnamon.  And our waitress comped us a 3rd dessert -  for our hatred of the soup - a mint chocolate chip ice cream sandwich.  I'm the only person on earth who hates mint and chocolate together, but my sister said the ice cream - a ball of chocolate-flecked jade - had obviously been made with fresh spearmint.

Despite the terrible (and I mean really terrible) start, I will go back and try the "real" menu. They can't get rid of us that easily.
author: maria a.

description: This is a great place for an impressive dinner - whether you are taking your client or a date.  The bar area gets very crowded fast, so arrive in time for your reservations.  The booths are very impressive when seating a party of four.  The wine list is reasonably priced with a wide range of options.  The appetizers are not really for sharing, although we did end up splitting foie gras and smoked trout.  I had Ono for the main entree which was solid, but the presentation more memorable than the taste.  Pork looks fabulous, ordered by my colleague.  We also got a couple side dishes - the mashed potatoes were not impressive, but the brussell sprouts were mere perfection.  The creme brulee dessert out shined the pecan pie.
author: Yevgenia F.

description: Location, location, location.  And besides that is an expensive place with OK food and sup-par staff.
author: A B.

description: Look.  I have been here a zillion times, mostly for interview lunches.  The seafood is always fresh and good, and reservations are a cinch (perhaps that tells you something).  But it had been a while since I had been for dinner.  I don't think I will be back for dinner anytime soon.  My biggest issue was with the sommelier.  The wine list is on the pricey side, and I asked for help navigating it -- the focus was a well-balanced pinot noir (which I thought would be a versatile choice for our group of 4).  I was immediately steered to some of the more expensive options ($120-150 range), even though about 1/3 of the list is under $100.  When I explained that I would like a wine under $100 (this was a business meal and I did not want red flags going up for the reimbursement), I was given a suggestion at $105.  I again asked for something under $100, and sommelier said there was nothing she could recommend at that price point.  Talk about the hard sell.  In short, dinner definitely started off on a low point.  From there, we recovered.  The appetizers were good, especially the foie.  But the pork tenderloin I was recommended was too salty -- should have stuck with the fish.  Come here if you want old school SF, a nice view of the Embarcadero, and an undeserved Michelin star.  Don't come for the service.
author: Matthew C.

description:
Fancy looking space, so I was prepared for a "serious," i.e., serious foodie, dinner.  Unfortunately, it was...meh.  I still wasn't over the shock of a ridiculously ginormous rib eye the night before (see my review of Bacar), and definitely wanted something light.  So I ordered the halibut, though I wasn't hugely optimistic about it, given that the restaurant was almost empty, and that's never a good sign for the turnover of seafood in a place.  The halibut itself turned out fine -- fresh, tender and perfectly cooked.  It didn't have a lot of flavor though, and wasn't particularly well-complimented by what looked like shreds of celery and fried green beans.  I was all ready to be impressed by the accompanying foie gras "emulsion," but that turned out actually to be foie gras "foam," and as I've never liked the idea of foamy food, that didn't do anything for me either.  
The dessert was the best part, and out of blackberry cobbler with vanilla ice cream (the smallest portion), a mint ice cream sandwich (supposedly very good; I don't like mint ice cream) and a brownie with coconut ice cream (disproportionately huge scoops), the last was the best.  The sides of chocolate sauce were also delicious.  Didn't make up for a overall mediocre dinner though.

What DID almost help was the view of a guy dressed in a Santa suit at the bus stop across the way.  He hung out for quite a while fiddling with some chained-up bike, starting out fully dressed, but at some point stripping, apparently naked from the waist down.  As he continued fiddling with the bike, we were struck by his particularly pink bum.  Was he really naked? we asked each other.  And if so, why couldn't we see his little man parts?  The debate continued throughout dinner and only ended when we were finally ready to leave.  As we stood up, we got a better view of what was going on -- of Santa waiting at the bus stop, having apparently given up on the bike, wearing -- and we were almost disappointed -- pale-pink jammies.   
Alas, we'll never know Santa's story, or what he was doing.  Was he late for a Halloween party?  Was he trying to steal the bike, because he was late for the Halloween party?  Of course, a Santa costume for Halloween was a fabulous idea, for which he deserved kudos.  Then again, maybe he was just your average SF street resident, feeling the holiday spirit well before the season officially began.  Either way, we agreed that this scenario could happen only in San Francisco.  
And as such, it was a great way to end to our meal.
author: Sue Z.

description: Really great dine about town menu. Super happy with my skirt steak and bread pudding dessert.
author: Marissa A.

description: I went here last night for the first time and had dinner.  The food and service were pretty good.  I didn't order an appetizer, but I tried the Caesar salad.  I'm not a huge fan of Caesar salad, but this one was very tasty.  I also ordered the Halibut.  It was good, but it didn't come with anything else, so I suggest getting either an appetizer or side dish.  I also tasted the lamb which was tender and flavorful.  For dessert I tried the souffle and creme brulee.  The souffle was so rich I could only have one bite.  It tasted like cocoa straight off the plant.  The creme brulees came in three mini dishes in different flavors.  Those were delicious.  Great for sharing.  Service was very good and formal.  Friendly staff.  Overall, a good experience, however, the entrees weren't all that memorable.
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
yummy yummy yummy 

everything was perrrrfict.. had a grat experince and no complaints. 
I will go back soon. 
I want you to experinc this restaruant. amazing menu.
author: Steve M.

description:
We came here also for the Dine About Town menu. The ambiance is nice and the waitstaff were excellent. One thing that really made them shine was when they mixed up an order for one of our friends. They managed to take care of it right away, which really showed how important they value customer service. We were definitely not disappointed here. Now for the food:

Golden Lentil Soup: Good soup, nice presentation because they pour the soup on the yogurt and cauliflower at our table. Both the yogurt and cauliflower complemented the soup quite nicely.

Braised Pork Short Ribs - The meat was very tender and juicy, and the risotto was a little too sweet, which was good because the ribs tasted slightly bland on their own. 
Pan Seared Wild Steelhead - The fish was good along with the veggies, but nothing really stood out for this dish.
Mushroom Pot Pie - A variety of mushrooms under a tasty puff pastry. Great on a cold day, but I'm not sure I would order this again.

Chocolate Toffee Almond Crunch Cake: One of the best desserts I've ever had! I like chocolate, and I like toffee so it was perfect. The pastry chef did a great job with the beautiful presentation, and also with keeping the crunch theme going with the crispy almonds and toffee bits. Even the little chocolate piece over the ice cream had a little crisp to it.

Overall, I would say the dessert stood out the most. The meal was decent, atmosphere is nice, and the waiters make sure you're completely satisfied by the end. But definitely try their desserts! I know I'd come back just for that alone!
author: Adrian K.

description: An amazing experience from start to finish. We do not get to experience a treat like this often so we took advantage and ordered half the items on the menu. Absolutely nothing dissapointed us! The service was well timed, polite, and knowledgeable, the food exceptional, and the restaurant itself was beautiful and in a fantastic location.
author: Patrick N.

description: Wed night we got here  before dinner...sat at the bar and had the tater tots...really nice. Dinner...bread is fantastic...Sous vide Halibut was ok...the pork tender was not great but my wife ordered it medium. The apple, balsamic and vegetable just did not go well together and are a bit unbalanced. The salad has too much of the bitter leaf.
author: Bob H.

description: This was a very tasty lunch experience. The salad was prepared well with just the right amount of dressing. My burger was cooked to perfection!!! The rest of the table also enjoyed their meals. What a fun place to bring your colleagues and business associates...
author: Miguel V.

description:
One Market, named after its location, is the brain child of the infamous Bradley Ogden (it's part of the Lark Creek Restaurant Group).  It's oft-frequented for business lunches and views of the Ferry Building.  I was actually one of the many people who decided to come here for the Dine About Town lunch special on MLK Jr Day.

Food:  4 stars.   I'm always a sucker when it comes to Dine About Town because I'm usually one of those people that strays to the regular menu (isn't that the whole point?), but I resisted temptation this time.  I had the portabello mushroom soup, which was creamy and perfectly seasoned and textured.  The quail egg really didn't do much except make it look prettier.  My friend had the farmer's market salad, which was not very memorable.  For main courses, I went with the Angus tri-tip "sous vide" in a green peppercorn sauce.  It was nice and tender and the green peppercorns were not overpowering.  My friend had the grilled mahi mahi with warm herb vinaigrette (they ran out of the grilled Idaho trout), which was decent.  Both entrees came with swiss chard gratin (with herbed panko) and the most excellent buttery mashed potatoes, served separately.  I've always looked forward to desserts here because the presentations have always been intricate.  I was not disappointed by the bosc pear galette with Tahitian vanilla bean ice cream, which also tasted heavenly.  My friend had the chocolate pot de creme verrine withwhipped white chocolate, crunchy steusel, and candied hazelnuts.  It was more boring with the exception of the hazelnuts.  All in all, I ended up making better decisions than my lunch companion on all three courses.  That always makes me happy.

Service:  3 stars.   Service seemed subtly snooty, which is a bit tiring (although nowhere near as bad as dealing with people in retail).  

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  Although in a prime location, the restaurant interior looks a little outdated and a bit old-school corporate.  The crowd is an even mix of young and old, but mostly corporate.

Hits:  Portabello mushroom soup, Angus tri-tip "sous vide," buttery mashed potatoes, bosc pear galette.

Misses:  Farmer's market salad, chocolate pot de creme.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Arterra, Boulevard, Manresa
author: Keith C.

description: I'm too broke to eat at One Market. That is why when I got a gift certificate for $50 to One Market I got pretty psyched. I used that gift certificate to eat lunch and seriously enjoyed it. I had the pink lentil soup, which had a nice flavor and was presented nicely, but was not all that memorable. Then I moved onto my main, which was the pan seared flounder. This was fantastic. The sear on the fish was executed perfectly, the romesco was outstanding, and pairing it with little mandarin oranges worked beautifully. I had really high expectations for One Market and they were met. Service was outstanding without being pretentious, atmosphere was spot on, and most importantly, the food was great. The outrageous prices are almost (almost) warranted (7.50 for Pellegrino water, 11 for soup, 25+ for mains). All in all; great food, great service, great atmosphere. By the way, my lunch came to 49.50, good thing I had that gift certificate.
author: Alex E.

description: Wonderful. Simply wonderful. Everything we ordered at the table was fantastic. The service was stellar. Our waiter was charming and made great recomendations. Our food was fantastic. The lamb shank and duck breast was above and beyond. Definately enjoyable. Great service, great meal, great night.
author: Justin N.

description:
Ah yes, One Market.  It's a nicer place for business luncheons, sure.  At this point it's not a place I would choose to go for anything more than drinks and chickpea fries.  Sad, but true.  I've had lunch here several times, for business mostly, a couple times just because, and once for SF's Dine About Town.

One Market sadly disappoints me.  I want to love it, but I simply do not.  I suppose that is why I've given them chance after chance after chance, with no luck.  I still feel disappointed when I leave, and that isn't what I should be feeling when I leave such an establishment.  The space is beautiful, and full of grandeur, but that is about it.  For instance, my experience a while back for Dine About Town was a three course lunch midweek.  We had an 11:30 reservation.  Got there a couple minutes early, and was seated promptly at 11:30.  We were one of the first tables seated for their lunch service, and placed our order quickly.  We received bread, and a delicious iced tea infused with peach and served alongside a peach puree for extra sweetening.  The first course came out quickly, the spring mixed green salad.  It was fresh and perfectly dressed, we enjoyed this quite a bit... then we waited for our second course... we waited... we waited... we waited... by this time 45 minutes had passed since we placed our order.  Our second course arrived finally at 12:20, and I mentioned to our waiter, please add two orders of chick pea fries to go to have ready at the end of the meal, please place the order now as we're on a time crunch.  He made a snarky remark, "Well this IS a three course meal you know, it takes time.  You should really mention these things when you place your order."  I realize a three course meal takes a little time, but we had waited over 25 minutes after we finished our first course, with no second course in sight.  This, for lunch in the Financial District is a bit excessive, three course meal or otherwise.  I admit, I should have mentioned our time limitations in the beginning since we had meetings to get to.  I just didn't appreciate the snarkiness of our waiter, and I typically don't mind brash sarcasm, and a little attitude since I tend to be a snarky sarcastic being myself, but this was ridiculous.  All in all, the food was fine.  Nothing was outstanding, nor memorable.  

This was me giving them another chance because I had thought my prior experiences were just flukes.  I must say, this isn't a fluke, and I wont be returning unless it is for business and someone else is paying, or drinks and apps in the bar area.  I should mention my prior lunch experience here about 10 months ago.  They tried to serve me a raw grilled chicken sandwich... twice.  And explained it away by telling me the sandwich was made of dark meat.  Um, I love dark meat, but I do not love raw dark meat chicken.  I don't know any restaurant that serves up raw chicken... and twice... they seared my meat again from the original sandwich and placed it on the same bread I sent it back on.  (I had cut my sandwich in half and that is when I noticed it was raw)  That said, I sent it back, it came back raw still and on the bread I had cut in half with all the raw chicken juices still on it.  CAN WE SAY SALMONELLA???  The floor manager came by and gave me the dark meat excuse then offered me a different sandwich.  Then she explained to me the tuna sandwich is seared, so it will arrive raw.  HELLO!!!  Tuna can be served seared and raw in the middle, I love raw tuna, sashimi, etc.  I DO NOT like raw chicken, and don't know anyone who does.  Food poisoning people, food poisoning... hasn't any of the staff heard of what happens when you eat raw chicken???  Anyway.  As I said before, I will likely return for business as so many people like to go there for meetings, etc.  This will never be my first choice with so many other great options around.  Although, there's a good possibility I will be back for their delicious martinis and chick pea fries... but that's it.  2 stars for the consistently disappointing dining experience and food, 4 stars for the bar area and chick pea fries.  Come on One Market, you can do better than this.
author: Kelly K.

description: seems to be the spot where are all the business lunches take place for my office. BORING. the lunch menu is very thin and most of the time i don't feel like eating a damned thing on the menu. good standbys for this place include the ahi tuna burger (if the fish is fresh that day.. ask) and the regular hamburger. that way you'll at least get enough food to fill you up. beware of the alacarte menu items as they are small and come with sides that are well... lackluster. do try their variety of iced teas though. they are fun and will keep you busy as someone in upper management drones on and on about recruiting and other unnecessary crap.
author: Aly L.

description: I had dinner there a couple of weeks ago, and I really can't remember anything about it. That should tell you something, because I wasn't drinking.
author: Jason R.

description:
i've only eaten here on the corporate god's tab, with that said, the place is fabulous.  

We sat outside on a fabulous day, such as today, i indulged myself with a fizzy lizzy and some sea bass.  Both were enjoyed by my stomach, and i love to people watch, since we all know everyone in san fran is crazy.  This is a good place to watch all the crazies in action.

like those silly people who exercise, please comon, just sit down and eat, you know you want to.
author: Chrammy D.

description:
Thankfully dine about town only comes periodically because I eat out way too much when this promo is offered.   Alrighty.. so I ended up eating at One Market twice in one day - once for a client lunch then again that night for dinner with friends - i think I got my fill of this place for a good few months!   I had a good experience for lunch and dinner:

lunch:  ordered this interesting mango ice tea drink - nice presentation and very light with a hint of fresh mango juice.    I ordered the beet salad - nicely presented with very thin slices of beets and a citrus/lemon dressing.  The rock shrimp in the salad had a nice citrus flavor as well.   A few beets were not as fresh as others, but overall it was a strong dish.  For my lunch entree I ordered the lobster and crab cavatelli (pasta dish that looks a little like mini larvae -- not the most appetizing comparison - but visually that's basically what this pasta looks like).   This dish was good - had enough lobster/crab and had a light cream sauce although could have been a bit saltier for my taste buds.    

Onto dinner... I had the dine-about-town set meal with the lentil soup, mushroom pot pie and mint ice cream sandwich.   5 stars for all of these dishes.   Lentil soup had a nice presentation where the waiters pour in the broth with the cauliflower and vadouvan sitting in the empty bowl beforehand.   This wasn't the lentil soup I was expecting - but it was a good surprise - creamy but not too rich and the yogurt/cauliflower gave the soup a nice twist.   My mushroom pot pie was absolutely delicious.   I love mushrooms so this entree hit the spot..  the mushroom filling tasted unhealthy - which = great.   the baked crust was light and fluffy and they have a nice presentation of showing you the pot pie prior to scooping it out from the baking dish into a white bowl/plate.   To top off the meal, I ordered the mint chocolate chip ice cream cookie.... personally i think diddy reese in brentwood tops the cake as far as ice cream sandwiches.. but for a fancy venue i think this is a close second.   

I wouldn't go to One Market regularly as it would burn a whole in my wallet but for nice occasions and for the deal of dine-about-town, this is is a good spot.
author: T M.

description: I was looking forward to this Michelin Star dinner and it did not disappoint!  Service was good, but the food was great!
author: Jeff W.

description: Like dining in a Las Vegas casino restaurant. Food was good but a bit oversauced, reminscent of 1998. Service was attentive. Manhattan was tasty. But it needs to be taken down a few pegs.
author: Brandon R.

description: My boss, who is a total foodie, recommended this restaurant to me for lunch (she frequents the place about once a month) a few weeks ago. I went with my parents for the first time to celebrate my new job in the area, and all three of us were thoroughly disappointed for multiple reasons. Our server had one large party and our small table of three which resided right next to the larger party. After the first of our plates arrived (for 2 of the 3 of us, at any rate) she proceeded to completely ignore us for about 20 minutes while I was left fork-less and my mom never received her plate at all. The waitress understood English so poorly that I had to ask for a "fork" four times, but the atrocious service and overcooked food was definitely not something lost in translation- she and the food prep/runners simply did a horrible job. Every time I walk by that corner I am reminded about how disappointing my experience there was.
author: Trevor R.

description:
I wish they had negative stars, or a bit*h slap option on Yelp for times like this.

I ate off the Dine About Town lunch menu with several of my friends, and we all thought the food was mediocre.  Like Michelle H (in an earlier review), I too ordered the sunchoke veloute, the skate wing, and the butter pear tart.  First, the soup was a few tablespoons of creamy liquid with these horrifying bites of coagulated bacon fat, the skate wing was dry, overcooked, and coated with an allegedly high-end sauce that tasted like Wendy's honey mustard dipping sauce.  Worst of all, is that the skate (which my friend and I ordered) came naked on the plate, without the spinach and mashed potatoes that came with Michelle H's meal.  C'mon now, you guys think you could get away with giving some patrons less?  Funny too, because my friend and I thought it was weird that the main dish was literally just a piece of fish with nothing else.  We all walked away hungry and dissatisfied.  Also, I should note that we were probably the only ones that ordered off of the DAT menu, and it showed--they served us last, and we were probably the last stragglers out during the lunch hour.  All of the other high-profile financial district power people were served first.

Way too expensive for crappy and discriminatory service.

Reading the other Yelp reviews (for "One Market" in addition to those for "One Market Restaurant"), I realize that I am not alone.  As Ben Folds Five sang in the Song for the Dumped, "Give me my money back, you bit*h."
author: Passionate E.

description:
this is delicious and expensive. it is the kind of restaurant that you ask your southern california parents to take you out to when they are in town. 

it seems the food is mostly local and free-range and all that shnizz, and tastes good too. they give you a free little caviar thingy too right before your appetizer. 

there's no reason not to go to this place...unless your parents aren't in town yet.
author: Adam S.

description: I've come here twice now...once, a business lunch a few years ago that did not impress, and the second time was last week for DAT lunch. Our server tried to upsell pretty much every item on the menu. Water was not refilled quickly enough. Food was really not worth finishing, even though i was still hungry afterwards.
author: j d.

description: I took my parents here because I liked the ambiance of the place- not too pretentious nor mediocre. We had the oysters, Foi Grais, halibut, and the scallops. The Foi Grais here is absolutely delicious! My parents never had it before, and I didn't tell my mom what it was either (she is very, very picky)..and they LOVED it! That put a smile to my face, I hope they enjoyed their visit & One Market as well.
author: Em A.

description: I don't eat out at classy places too often, so I don't know what is and is not worth the price, but I thoroughly enjoyed my meal here which was for an early mother's day present to my mom.  Nice natural lighting at 6pm.  Very good individual mini sour dough rolls which seemed hard at first, but I enjoyed them after opening them up.  They only give you one at a time, I suspect so you don't fill up and will order dessert.  I had the Indonesian pepper-spiced ahi tuna with grapefruit vinaigrette @23.50.  It was 4 seared pieces and excellent in taste and quantity.  Shared some Big Fries at the table which are essentially gigantic french fries and were good.  My parents enjoyed their meal as well.  Service was very nice.  They were very good at not rushing you between courses (my parents had salads) and filled up water promptly.  $11 and $8 for martinis and gin and tonics respectively were ok.  Very good caramel treat given with bill was the best  "parting candy" I've ever had.  In all, I thought it was a fine dining experience, though understand my lack in comparing top notch restaurants may make me not the best judge.  I just know I enjoyed the place and that it was within reason of my ideas of classy dining costs.
author: Marc S.

description: I think the lunch hour is the best hour and preferably with any seafood dish on the menu.  I tried the sorbet's once and was very pleased, and they seem to also have a varied menu based on seasonal farmer's market favorites, something I really like to have a lot of fun with.
author: Yelper A.

description: We settled at this place simply because we were COLD & wanted a drink & some app's before getting on BART. Their bar ambiance is great but the service and food leave little to be desired! They do have a happy hour until 7pm in the bar area with some discounted cocktails, wine & beer. The service was extremely lacking. I think our waitress either hated her job or hated her customers (or at least that's how we felt!) We literally waited 35 minutes for an order of mini crab tacos which come in orders of 3. I asked for an additional one & they charged $3.75 for the 4th mini taco (less than 2 bites). The calamari was sparse to say the least...we felt that there was way more fried batter than actual calamari and for $9.25 I would have like to have some real bites of food & not just fried batter left-overs:( The $11 shrimp skewers were tiny (all 3 of them) and covered in a weird tasting foam...basically I felt totally ripped off! The only saving grace about this bar is it's location. I do not plan on ever going back & would not recommend this place to anyone. In such a great city there are SO MANY better restaurants than One Market so don't waste your time here!
author: Mel A.

description:
I ordered crab salad for a starter and the plate came out to be very artistic. Flat iron steak was GREAT. Creme Bulee for desert was average.

This place is very businessy and dressy and is a common to go place for a lot of businessmen for lunch in the financial district.
author: Linda Y.

description:
great service.
delicious food.
nice atmosphere.

adorable and really great waiter.  he was a redhead, i have a thing for redheads apparently.  he was very attentive and made excellent recommendations.

food was presented nicely and was fresh and perfectly cooked.
everything had just a perfect amount of bite to be tantalizing throughout the whole dish.

good espresso too.

very much enjoyed.

(though i CANNOT afford those prices)
author: Ge O.

description: Eh, it was okay. I had a duck entree which was not bad. The chestnut soup was impeccable, though, and I've never had another like it. Dessert was unimpressive. I went during Dine About Town earlier this year which was nice. I don't think I'd want to pay more for this food.
author: Jane C.

description: Thanksgiving Dinner here was amazing.  I had never heard of OneMarket, even after working in the city for two years and frequenting chic Soma restaurants with clients.  Anyway the prixe fixe Thanksgiving dinner was amazing.  I'm not a fan of pate so the liver pate was not very good, neither was the bread pudding, but the salmon, the turkey, the potatos, spinach and stuffing were top notch.  Best thanksgiving dinner, hands down. Don't tell my grandmother!
author: Christine S.

description: I thought this place was pretty good.  A girlfriend and I wandered in here when the wait at the Slanted Door was too long.  The food was good, the service was good, and I like that they use all local ingredients.  I would go back.
author: Selah M.

description: I went with a large group of co-workers for a company dinner and came away slightly drunk but thoroughly unimpressed.  The service was good- helpful and knowledgeable, but not obsequious or pushy.  As for the food...well, I'm hardly a trained chef, but I've made better myself.  Sometimes less is more...
author: Dean C.

description:
Guess what One Market Chef??? You ain't escaping Coach K. 

I went to One Market this past Friday with my GF and another couple. Our entire experience here was actually quite nice. Great service, attractive ambiance, and even better company. The four diners in attendance all ended up getting fairly intoxicated by the end of the meal (two cocktails each, two bottles of wine, and Irish coffee's to finish have a tendency of making this happen). In the midst of our debauchery a meal was also served. The black bean soup to start might as well of been called black bean paste - the texture was disgusting, and room temperature I might add. For my entree I ordered the short ribs - sure they were good but not great, and great is what I expect for the price. My GF ordered the Skate Wing and it tasted worse than it sounds. Far too fishy with an ever so disgusting touch of stale vinegar and overall grossness. Truly an inappropriate dish to serve at a nice restaurant. The desert was desert; I mean how badly can you screw that up?

 All in all I loved everything except the food. I will not be returning to this establishment for that reason.

More to come from Coach K soon...
author: Coach K.

description: We went here last summer with friends for the prix fixe menu promotion.  I was expecting an amazing meal based on reading other reviews and the fact that this restaurant received a Michelin star, but we were dissappointed.  The meal was good, but not spectacular.  We thought the food could have been more special and creative.
author: John L.

description: Went for a business dinner and had a great experience. The wine selection was superb, they even have a resident Somalia. Dinner was on the better side, but I've had much better for the price. Great scene, especially for out of towners who want a great San Francisco vibe.
author: Carl M.

description: Rudest service I've ever experienced in 30 years of dining in San Francisco...wish I could tell you something about the food, but we were so disgusted by the disdain we were given as customers that we left the restaurant before being served.  In this day and age, I could not believe that customers could be treated so poorly.
author: Meyer C.

description: I had lunch at One Market on Friday and loved my whole experience at this restaurant!!! The food and service was fabulous. I will go back to this restaurant again.
author: Ricardo A.

description: Today I had lunch with some business associates.  Two of us ordered scallops for the main course.  The others ordered the grilled flounder and the duck sausage.  All dishes came out cold.  We did not bother to send them back, since we were on a lunchtime schedule and could not afford the wait for the dishes to be sent back.  This happened on a previous visit as well.  With so many excellent restaurants from which to choose, this will not be on the list again.
author: Mark L.

description: Okay, so a group of us went here after work one day for happy hour, and took advantage of the $3 Guinness drafts. After working up a bit of a beer hunger, we decided to grab a few appetizers. The apps weren't very good, in my opinion, though they did managed to get finished up by the group.  We had to leave and grab more food elsewhere. Nothing special here, and would only go back during happy hour, when the drinks are reasonable.
author: Lucas M.

description: I went there for a lunch meeting today, and while the location is fantastic-the food was ok. I tried to order a salad and the waiter told me that it wasn't "really a salad" as there wasn't any lettuce. A non-lettuce $14 salad hmm...next I asked for the crab cakes at $14 for 3 or $22.50 for five, the waiter said that  the crab cakes were small, and I might want something else, so I ordered a bowl of chowder at $10. The presentation of my meal was excellent, but the food was way too expensive. The crab cakes were more like crab puff/dollups the size of a 50 cent piece. Good thing I got the soup.
author: Leesa P.

description:
Ready for a full review?  Here we go...

My friend and I eat out a lot and we go to a new restaurant every time.  Our bills usually come to the upper 100s, but we're OK with that, just as long as it's worth it.  One Market is DEFINITELY worth it.  The only "bad" thing I can say about this place is that the directions they give you force you to make a U at the corner of Market and Steuart to valet.  Not a tough job, unless you have a trolley coming at you.

Now on to the restaurant.  They're part of OpenTable (bonus points), so getting a reservation isn't hard.  We arrived 15 min. early and were quite content with having a drink at the bar (happy hour goes until 7pm), but the hostess was very pleasant and infomed us that our table would be ready in just a minute.  We had a lovely corner table, on the raised portion of the floor, that faced the open kitchen and the chef's table.  We were seated at 6:20pm and the sunlight was not in my eyes.  We had a great view of the restaurant (which filled up in a matter of minutes), the Ferry Building, and the kitchen.  Then our server approached.

Upon request he promptly brought us a cocktail menu and gave us the right amount of time to decide.  He was attentive, without being overbearing.  He recommended a couple of things on their standard menu, but we were more focused on their daily grill option - the prime rib.  We started with cocktails and an amuse bouch, compliments of the chef.  The appy was a calamari ceviche and it was fantabulous.  Give me a bowl of that and some tortilla chips, and I'm in heaven.  We had ordered the dungeness crab risotto to share and they split it for us.  There was a nice lump of crab in the middle of the risotto, with bits of crab throughout.  The risotto was a nice tomato based one, quite a nice change from your standard.  This was followed with 2 oysters, again, compliments of the chef.  The oysters were raw, topped with a warm buttery, creamy sauce which warmed it through just a tad.  It was then topped with caviar and chives.  The raw hama hama's I had were better.  Then the prime rib arrived.

I've had my fair share of prime rib, and I have to give this one a standing ovation.  It was a perfect medium rare with a lovely sprinkling of sea salt right on top.  Normally I don't eat the crusty outside because it's usually burnt, but I ate every last piece of this one.  My friend is notorious for salt and peppering everything, but this is the one and only time that I didn't see her adjust the taste.  That's a clear sign of perfection if ever there was one.  The meat is ala carte, so we had the buttered mashed potatos and swiss chard gratin.  Both very well done.  And to end the meal, we each had the mini butterscotch pudding.  It was the perfect ending to a perfect meal.  

Next time we're coming for happy hour and eating in the bar/lounge.  When we were sitting, we saw a tasty burger go by us.  It was destined for the bar, so that makes the bar our next destination.
author: Alison N.

description: I did a brief stint as garde manger for a Bradley Ogden outpost in San Diego called Arterra, so I really wanted to like this place.  Halfway through the meal I decided this was a something better not mentioning to my 5 friends.  Shouldn't mushroom soup taste like mushrooms?  Theirs tastes like roasted veal bones.  Maybe they ran out of vegetable stock.  Still confused  about why there was a quail egg sitting on top of a soy flan in the middle of my bowl.  And this is coming from a Filipino who enjoys eating eggs over almost anything.  My trout was very moist and flavorful but had 2 fish bones in it.  Good thing I am a careful chewer.  Greens were good.  Potatoes may have been reconstituted from flakes.  The highlight would have to be the pear tart with vanilla ice cream and huckleberry.  I am not a dessert person.  Don't be surprised if you get the bill before dessert, however.  We did.
author: Kevin G.

description:
a nice restaurant but kinda for the older/stuffier crowd.
it feels like a place that business guys go to do deals.  

i went for a birthday dinner during dine about town.  the food was ok but it didn't really make a huge impression on me.  if i was paying full price for dinner, i would not come here.

the service was great though.  very attentive.
author: Patrick L.

description: Great Food, great service, great atmosphere.  My husband and I got a referral from a friend to come here and it did not disappoint!  The rolls were fresh and toasty, right out of the oven. The bacon wrapped pork tenderloin was to die for as was the pumpkin soup and chocolate toffee cake!  And our server, Steve, was soo nice, attentive and helpful... even for a couple having a late night dinner at the end of his very long shift.  Rather than upsell us on ordering too much food, he told us how large the portions were and that we could easily split and start with one entree and order more later if we wanted.  I always like that being most nice restaurants try to get you to order more for a bigger bill when really the portions are huge... and they were pretty big!  We were stuffed off the one main dish we split along with the soup and desert.  We will definitely be coming back and highly recommend it.
author: Niki R.

description: I've only been here once and only got drinks so can't say much for the food and/or dining experience but for the bar this place is great. The lighting is dark, soothing, and very much like a lounge. The bar service was very friendly and fast. All I ordered was a Heineken and they brought it out with a beautiful tall beer glass, it was pretty cool. The beer was on the pricier side for a bar ($5), I could've easily had the same at my local bar for half the price, but we were in the area and it was a place that was open so we went in.  I don't regret.  For a Saturday night, it wasn't super busy or crowded and you could have a nice, no rushed, relaxed conversation without raising your voice. I give this venue a thumbs up!
author: Swetha G.

description: * I am only reviewing the bar at happy hour.* It's a small area, and gets crowded quickly, even if you get there at 5pm or shortly after.  There aren't a lot of tables or seats at the bar, so get there early and stake your claim.  IMHO, it has the same feel as Americano (crowd-wise).  They do have a $3 beer and $5 signature cocktails during happy hour, which is nice when you are trying to be frugal in a weary economy.
author: San D.

description: Thought I'd give this restaurant another shot and came here for the dine about town menu. The selection was not that exciting so I went with the regular menu. the steak....not very memorable! The server seemed like she would rather be somewhere else. The best part....A great martini!
author: Jeremiah A.

description:
hmmm ... not crazy about this place.  rather "high school cafeteria" feel inside.  did appreciate the abundance of natural light pouring through the large windows.

this month (july, 06) all bottles of wine are 1/2 off ... which makes for a pretty good deal.  (the only wine offered is CA wine ... )

as for the food it's decent ... have to admit i'm a bit jaded after last night's dinner at Piperade.  it would have taken a lot to have uncurled my toes ...

server was competent, and she seemed to have a good sense of the restaurant's wine offerings.
author: Gavin M.

description: Okay, if you ever want to experience the feeling of a tourist, come to this restaurant. Although, the overall food rating is average, the staff is very friendly and willing to provide excellent service to all. The best time to go is around 1:30PM, it's not crowded and you can easily get a window table (people watching). By the way, don't sit by the front door; the outside air will make the event horrible and it's very noisy.
author: Kerr M.

description: I can't believe this but the reservationist was rude and hung up on me!  I was trying to reserve a table of 7 and they don't open on Sunday and she insisted that I check out one of her sister restaurants!  Lark Creek Steak House, I tried to explain that I had a vegetarian, and she cut me off!  They just lost my business!
author: I Y.

description: Solid, corporate feeling restaurant that's a mainstay for business lunches.  I've only been once and found it to be a-ok, but nothing exceptional.  There are other places with a bit more character in the area (Boulevard, Slanted Door) for business lunches though the location is nice (right at the end of Market within the Financial District so it's close to most offices though also close to Embarcadero/the Ferry Building) and the food and service are good.  It's an old restored building bridging the old and new of San Francisco.
author: John W.

description: To sum it up quickly, One Market has decent food at pretty steep prices.  Definitely has high quality food but never really stuck me as a place I had to go back to.  However, they do have some great fresh seafood entrees and their lamb is done very well.
author: Charles C.

description:
Went with two co-workers and a guest from out of town, since we wanted to impress him with a one-star Michelin dining experience. The food was excellent (golden lentil soup, pumpkin ravioli and a dessert trio). The dessert trio was especially amazing since they advertise it as a trio of mini desserts for $15 (as opposed to a regular dessert in the $10 range). When it arrived, it was actually a trio of not-so-mini desserts (creme brulee, chocolate cake and something else I've forgotten because of a sugar overdose) but wow! 

The service, wow from a different perspective. They were obviously pretty rushed when we got there but we were seated right away and our order taken. One of my co-workers had to get back fast, so ordered only one dish while the rest of us ordered the Dine-About Town (or equivalents). Bread was great, nice and hot, and went like a flash. Then since the appetizers seemed to be taking some time, tried to catch the eye of the waiter to replenish the bread. No luck. After 5 minutes of signaling, a waiter went off to get the bread and never came back. Instead, my soup arrived. And sat and sat in front of me getting cold while to be polite, I heroically refrained from eating because no one else had been served. After 5 minutes, the waitress rushes back (still no bread) and says that I had accidentally been served someone else's soup and would I like her to take it away and bring it back? I kind of shrugged and she said the remaining items would be arriving soon. And so I finished my soup while my companions looked on. Then the others' menu items arrived and they ate while I looked on. Then my main course arrived and I ate while they looked on, then ...

And they were out of two desserts which is why I ordered the trio and then we all went back on a sugar high and fell asleep during a crucial meeting, forcing our company to go bankrupt - but fortunately the government gave us a bailout.
author: Rags R.

description:
What a disappointment! I booked a reservation for five at the last minute on a Friday evening a couple of weeks before Christmas. To be honest, I choose this restaurant because it was one of the only reservations I could get on short notice and because it has a Michelin star.
