Granted I've only eaten here once, but after my experience at One Market I'd have to say that this Michelin rating is undeserved. 

I don't have much to say about the food. I had the cauliflower soup, a selection of oysters and the black cod. All were fine but unremarkable.

The real downfall of the restaurant on the evening we were there was the service. When we arrived the hostess seemed harried and indifferent. No one offered to check our coats and we were told that our table wasn't ready yet without apology and without being directed to the bar or anything like that. We got the feeling that the hostess would have been happier if we had waited outside on the sidewalk.  Once we were seated (15 minutes after our reservation time) our waiter seemed overwhelmed and unfamiliar with the menu and wine list. We ordered wine only to be informed 10 minutes later that they were out of it. These things happen, but our waiter was completely without suggestions for what might make a good substitute. Also, an order of 20 oysters for the table was completely forgotten despite the fact that our waiter appeared to have written everything down. When we reminded the waiter about the oysters he seemed more frustrated than anything. He also seemed to want to just forget about the order rather than delay the arrival of the entrees so that we could have the oysters.  Another thing that surprised me about the service was the way that that the food was sort of thrown at us. The restaurant was very busy, so maybe everyone was frazzled, but when wine was poured it was sloshed, each of our entrees and starters came at different times and the service was just in general totally uncoordinated and sloppy.
author: Lily T.

description:
We went to dinner Friday evening with six people, good to great food;
Bar service slow and had to send one drink back for do over, not impressed with bar at all.
Service at table a little stiff at first, but waiter finally loosened up a even smiled a little. The waiter was very knowledgeable, and helpful describing the preparation of food items. 
Good portions. 
Enjoyed, but might think twice before returning, especially with the horrible bar service.
author: Brian K.

description: Very tasty and creative dishes. I had poached peaches salad and halibut with crab meat sauce.  Finger-licking good~~ The ambiance is great because there is outdoor seating directly under the Bay Bridge.
author: Lisa L.

description: Came here during Dine about town in 2008 and I really like place. Checked in with the hostess and was seated pretty quickly. Our $48.00 (including tips) person dinner included appetizer, entree and dessert. For appetizer I ordered the mixed green salad with raspberry vinigrette dressing and it was very tasty-- light and flavorful. Ordered the special fish that they had that day and it was perfectly cooked (70% cooked and 30% raw.) For dessert had the chocolate souffle and it is pretty good.
author: Allison H.

description:
After picking up my Zipcard near the Montgomery St. BART, I moseyed over to the Ferry Building to salivate over the dry-aging chamber at the Golden Gate Meat Market, before finally arriving at One Market. 

One Market always participates in opentable promotions, and it is the only restaurant with a Michelin star on the Dine About Town list. 

The canapé - a crostini topped with fava bean purée with house-cured lardo - arrived in what felt like seconds after I sat down. Fava beans require multiple steps to prepare - shelling, blanching, removing each bean's individual membrane - adding up to a labor intensive process that I often chose to forgo. If someone else does the aforementioned prerequisites, blitzes the beans in a food processor, and smears the paste on toasted bread with pork fat, I am all for it. Not long after the server removed my canapé plate, another server came by with two kinds of bread - olive and baguette - accompanied by what can only be described as an impenetrable ingot once known as butter. Seriously, I did know whether I would need welding tools to get the butter on the bread. I consoled myself, attempting to deludedly justify the peccadillo with the thought that a meal without butter could possibly be salubrious. Ah, who am I kidding?

First course: Asparagus soup, pastured egg sous vide, parmesan, prosciutto. Not only was the soup's seasoning spot on, but it was also visually pleasing as the runny yolk elided with the puréed asparagus.

Second course: Braised halibut cheeks, micro greens, corn, clams, celery, applewood smoked bacon. After watching Mario Batali serve opah cheeks on Iron Chef America, I, too, thought fish cheeks would make for a tasty entrée. Do not let the halibut's eerily unattractive features fool you, for its cheeks are delicate enough to render a knife obsolete. I thought the progression from unsmoked pork belly in the soup to smoked belly meat for the main course was a clever - albeit probably overlooked by most - touch.

Third course: Nectarine tart, blackberry compote, vanilla bean ice cream. This dessert had a great harmony between its tart and sweet notes.  

Tonight was my third meal at One Market, and each time I have come away satisfied.
author: Andrew F.

description: "Great for biz lunch when someone else is paying. Crab there is always good...but other selections a tad salty and not all that great...sorry Damon...
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Meh...I've definitely had better.  This review is pretty late, since I dined here a few months ago.  Service was good, with a good pace for the food being brought out and the server was pretty attentive.  I did expect more from all the hype, but was totally let down.  The food seemed really fresh though, but not as tasty as I expected it to be.
author: Cee L.

description: This place definitely is as good as it gets! I would recommend valet parking for starters. We made reservations for 6 people and arrived alittle early. They promptly seated us and the service began from that moment. From the water, to the fresh bread served we were constantly being attended to. They allow you to bring your own wine($20 corkage per bottle) or you can certainly order their vast wine selection. We all ordered different things, but in the end we all loved what we ordered. Definitely order the chickpea fries, beef tongue salad, mushroom soup w/creme fraiche, the steak(what I ordered delish!) oh yea..they have tater tots as a a side! (wow so good with your steak but beware they are huge and you will only be able to eat a few), the porkloin dish was a hit at our table, scallops the size of your hand, and the duck was just as good. You will be stuffed, but squeeze in some dessert. You just have to. They are all good and they make their own house ice cream! Our bill with tip was under six bills! Really not bad considering they have high reviews from the Michelin!! Must go!
author: Jennifer A.

description: 3.  I would give it 4, except that the duck leg conft was too salty.  Disappointing, since this is one of my all time favorite disshes and I can't help ordering it whenever I see it.  The space was lovely and the service was good - friendly, not stuffy, quick.  My friends and I all ordered off the dine about town prix fixe menu, which came with three courses.  I didn't order any wine, since I had already thrown back a few by the time our 9:00 reservation rolled around, so I can't really speak to their wine offerings.  They had the best butternut sqash soup I've ever had.  It came with a pumpkin yogurt that gave the soup a nice creamy feel.  Plus there were roasted squash or pumpkin seeds mixed in.  The crunch was definitely nice.  I got the chocolate souffle cake for dessert, which was great in and of itself, though I wish they didnt put this banana sauce and ice cream on the side.  Would I go back?  For another prix fixe, sure.  I dn't think I'd pay the full price for this place though.
author: Ash T.

description: I have to give this "fancy and upscale" restaurant points for serving me with the same candor and delight as they would with any designer-toting elitist despite the fact that I was wearing converse and the same smokey clothes from the night before (the ultimate test). The only weird part about the restaurant was the ghost-face server who stalked my table.  I swear, she probably asked me "is there anything else you would like?" every single time I made any unusual movement.  I guess this is what you call service?  Quite frankly, I'd rather be left alone sometimes.  The calamari was good, but I'm not one to praise their "house-made" calamari sauce.
author: Margaux S.

description:
minus one star for it's food being way too salty
minus another star because seriously as another yelper mentioned... this place kinda makes a regular ol' joe feel uncomfortable

the food was decent though, although like i just mentioned, everything was way too salty. we did dine about town lunch (the most economical way to eat at most these places). 

i had the garden salad. eh. nothing impressive. and for the 2nd course i had the skatewing... kinda like a stringray fish with the texture of overcooked scallop. it flaked like scallop but it was meatier. it was quite delicious except for the fact that it was way to salty. 

finally the deserts... one was butter tart thingy... really it was like apple pie with ice cream and raspberry sauce. it was good. but the tropical fruit ice thingy... yummy... mango ice... soo good...

now if they only treated their customers better... too bad i'm not a 50something man in a business suit. we are 20somethings working in the fidi and wanted to enjoy a nice lunch
author: Mei N.

description: I dropped by One Market for drinks during Happy Hour with a couple friends, and I'd give the restaurant 3.5 stars.  The by the glass wine selections were mainly from California, and I liked my Dry creek valley Zinfandel.  I thought the wine prices were a bit high, though.  Happy hour beers were very reasonably priced.  We split an order of calimari, which was very tasty and fresh and well done.  The service was fine, and we sat at a table near the bar area.
author: Sarah W.

description: The service was flawless and well-executed. The server recommended the Robert Young 2002 Alexendria Valley wine (white) and he brought me a sample without me even asking for it. and it was superb. we immediately were set to buy a bottle. we did the dine about town menu. i had the Butter Lettuce Salad, Pears, Pt. Reyes Blue Cheese, Candied Walnuts as 1st course, Liberty Farms Duck Breast, Braised Red Cabbage, Fuji Apples, Black Trumpet Mushrooms for 2nd, and Trio of Petite Desserts - Chocolate Mousse Dome, Raspberry Sorbet Vacherin, Crme Brle & Biscotti for dessert. everything was well done, flavourful and fabulous. we also had oysters for starters. they were plump and yummy. it was a fabulous meal! money well spent.
author: Cindy L.

description: I ordered something from the Prix fixe menu. It was so yummy. Service was spectacular. Food was great. There was a lot of tiny flies flying around though. I don't recommend bringing any kids as there are a lot of breakable things. But if they're well behaved (as in 7+), I don't see the harm.

I just dined there last night for Dine About Town.  My bread knife had a piece of dried green onion on it.  Last my entree (I ordered the duck) had a WORM on it!  YES, A WORM!  I didn't get any apologies or a comped meal, only a mere excuse of "everything is organic here so once in a GREAT while a worm will appear".  WTF?  Yah, there's much better restaurants in SF that offer organic ingredients without the worm.  That was my first time dining there and will be my last time.
author: Jules M.

description: The Michelin Guide stickers in the entry windows indicated this place would be more memorable than our experience here. Oh well. Although we only had drinks and bar food (sliders, chick pea fries, and chicken wings--all portions ideally divided for three patrons), everything was good but underwhelming. And very expensive.
author: Maximillian M.

description: The food here is good, but I didn't think it was worth the expensive price.  Presentation of the food was very nice, and it was definitely fresh, but otherwise....meh.  Good thing work paid for this lunch.
author: Michelle N.

description: One Market is a Treat. All the food we ordered was outstanding in experience and presentation. Fresh and unique.  Varied tastes, textures, interesting pairings.  The one Michelin Star is well deserved.  The dessert menu is fantastic and very hard to choose from.  The sommellier came to our table and spent alot of time talking to us.  She was so pleasant and informative.  We loved our booth which had a picture window view of the iconic Ferry Building.  We have been dining in San Francisco for 20 years and One Market is now our new favorite.  The service was excellent. We could not have had a better experience at this wonderful restaurant.  Do not miss the fried green tomatoes with a light blue cheese dip and the corn polenta side dishes. The bacon wrapped pork was the most succulent pork we have ever had. Inventive cocktails were delicious.  Try the B2 and you will be pleasantly surprise at how light and delicious Bourbon can truly be.   Put this restaurant at the top of your list for fine dining in San Francisco.
author: Jennifer H.

description: The restaurant had a nice feel and a good crowd.... I was there for Happy Hour and the bar section was comfortable even though it was bustling.  The Aged Jack was quite good, it had a firm texture and rich, sharp flavor.  The Popcorn Shrimp and Calamari are the typical finger food and they don't usually go wrong... there was an appetizer that was not very tasty but I have no idea what it was... all I can say is it looked like a mozzarella stick but it didn't taste anything close to it.... stay away from whatever it might be!!!  Service was good...as busy as it was... we got our drinks quite quickly and the server checked on us regularly.
author: Susie L.

description: I set up a private group dinner (35 people) and it was a great event. The food was yummy (short-ribs are fantastic). I looked around at the end of dinner and there was hardly a crumb left on a plate. They gave us excellent service. The best thing about the event was that Beth, the lead for group events, was EXTREMELY flexible. She worked hard to give us options that stayed within our budget and made sure that all of the little details were taken care of in advance. At the end of the night, several people said that they would like to use them for future private events for work. Well done One Market!
author: Nessa F.

description: After a short evening at Taylor's with some old colleagues/friends at the Ferry Building, we wanted to grab a quick drink and desert. I had no idea about the neighborhood, so I was taken here. It was quiet since it was Wednesday Night. We sat down at the bar, had our drinks and some desert and talked for hours. The bartender is pretty chill, the location is relaxed. We obviously just missed happy hour. The prices were reasonable.
author: Michael C.

description: I've had the scallops here twice and they're absolutely delicious.  Had the mushroom soup for dine-about-town last year and it was kind of bleh.  A bit too pricey for me, but a good place to go when you've got someone else paying (i.e. someone who's trying to impress your boss and decides to take the interns out to dinner, too).
author: ML N.

description:
I had looked forward to trying this place for a while due to it's Michelin rating.  I was very disappointed with both the service and the food. 

The waitress was pretentious.  She was more focused on rattling off the ingredients than listening to my client request (three times) that they don't put avocado in her salad because she was allergic to it.  

I ordered a caesar salad and grilled trout with a red onion sauce.  Mashed potatoes and swiss chard came as sides.  I found a long piece of plastic in my chard with the second bite.  They replaced my sides and I found the chard tough and bitter.  For $40 per person for lunch, you'd think they would use the more tender inner leaves?  The mashed potatoes were bland.   The salad was oily and one of the worst I've ever had.
author: D C.

description:
I went to One Market during the Dine About Town weeks last year. 

I organized a group of 8 people, and they accommodated us very well. 

I had a four course meal, with wine parings, and I was quite impressed by both the individual items on the menu, and the flavorful themes throughout the meal. 

The atmosphere is upscale, and enjoyable. They have a pianist playing near the bar.

A very enjoyable dining experience. Thank you!
author: Nathan V.

description: This was our second time eating at One Market. This time we came with friends. We took advantage of the special Dine About Town menu. Overall, we loved the evening. The choices for Dine About Town were good. I had the mushroom pot pie and so did my friend. It was very good but a bit cold. My husband had the scallops wrapped in bacon and my other friend had the steelhead. The only complaint we have is that each time they brought a course to the table, they didn't seem to know who was supposed to get what. The ambience of One Market is very nice. I particularly like that we didn't feel right on top of the tables next to us. There's a lot of light and windows. Not very noisy either! Good place for a nice dinner in SF.
author: Rachel M.

description: Happy hour was great- fabulous $5 cocktails (the entire cocktail menu except for 2 were $5)- my favorite was the Tickler- excellent name for an excellent drink.
author: Noelle Q.

description: So not worth the $$$. The scallop entree came with literally 3 scallops for about $26. Ridiculous. Tourist trap or posh-hunter trap.  Not worthy of a foodie.
author: Sarah R.

description: Food and atmosphere were good, but the service was a lot slower than it should have been. I mean, I don't want to be rushed out of a place by any means, but we felt like we were doing a lot of waiting. The waiter was very pleasant, but he could have stopped back more quickly after our appetizers, entrees, etc. were delivered. Took a long time for our (simple) desserts to arrive, too.
author: Phil K.

description: If my memory served me right, I wouldn't have wasted my money twice over here.  I ate here 5 years ago and I couldn't remember the food, so in the spirit of crab fest I decided to give it another shot.  Man was I disappointed.  The appetizers were dull and boring.  (seared hamachi, beet slices, crab salad)  One of the main dishes were just as disappointing. (half chicken)  It tasted like Adobo made totally wrong.  The only saving grace was the new item on the crab menu, which included pasta, foamy sauce and prosciutto.  I just would rather have spent this much money elsewhere for lunch.
author: Jason A.

description: I was taken here on a business lunch.  I wasn't extremely impressed.  The gazpacho served was blended, not served with nice chunks of raw veggies.  I can't even recall what else I ate....guess it wasn't that memorable.  I do remember liking the bread served.  Hmmmm......doesn't say much for a supposedly upperscale restaurant.
author: Christina S.

description: I like to have business lunches here when I am in the City. Great service, nice atmosphere and decor and I always feel very welcome and have fun. There'something for everyone on the menu, admittedly I've had some humdrum dishes but I've also had some great steaks and pork chops.
author: martin c.

description: LOVE One Market! It's great for business lunches where you want to impress, a sophisticated dinner with a date or among friends, and of course they have a nice upscale Friday night happy hour! The food is always delectible yet innovative and with enough variety/change to keep things interesting...for American fare. The waitstaff is attentive and respectful/classy. There is a teeny enough bit of a view of the Ferry Building and streetcars to make the big windows fun, and the atmosphere is really beautiful in a big sweeping room that is not too pretentious. Overall, a wonderful place that can't miss!
author: Risa F.

description: Fancy mint lemonade granita - amazing!  Everything I've tried is great here - crab salad, crab cakes, mahi mahi, halibut, rabbit ravioli - and everything is sooo fresh!  Great lunch spot.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
i went hear last year for thanksgiving with some friends and it was a great experience.  i had never experienced a carved turkey before.  in my family the person who cooked just digs in and breaks apart.  we go rustic style or is it korean style?
the turkey was so moist and tender.  the side dishes were my fav. i don't remember them all now since it was so long ago but i do rememver they had the quinoa with veggies...fantastic.  
portion size was huge and i definitely was stuffed.  it was a first restaurant thangsgiving experience for me and it was great.  if i get lazy one year and decide not to cook a turkey i would go hear again.
author: junie k.

description: Went there for a work event. The best thing I ate all night was the mini burgers. The chocolate dessert was delicicous as well. We had the spring salad which the person next to me said it tasted all of vinegar, I had the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin which was pretty good though i was not a fan of some of the root veges (personal dislike) Definitely need help with their service. It was pretty bad when we were there. Lots more good restaurants in the city.
author: Kai T.

description: Finally dined at One Market after walking by it a hundred times.  The New York steak was one of the best steaks I have ever had.  Can't wait to go back and order it again.
author: Lilikoikitchen M.

description:
Very unfortunate experience. We arrived got to the restaurant about 8PM. The hostess was pleasant which helped offset the immediate lack of life in our waiter. Unfortunately, the older gentleman waiter did not seem very excited to be serving us that day. We started off with a couple of cocktails and ordered a couple of appetizers. The clam chowder was luke warm at best and clearly unacceptable considering the form in which it is served. We sent it back and replaced it with an acceptable salad. After we signaled for the waiter to order a bottle of wine he returned shortly to tell us that bottle was not in stock. So we chose another bottle and was immediately told it was also not in stock. The sommelier/ wine peddler was signaled by the waiter got quite pushy in our decision process, so we thanked her and sent her on her way. During the third try, the waiter was "Oh, I thought I told you we were out of that wine as well." The attitude was clearly unacceptable and is evident of some serious problems at the restaurant. The only one saving grace to our evening was that the lamb shank was possibly the best I have ever had. Trust me, I have had a lot of lamb shank. Unfortunately, the great entree could not salvage the very poor service other food. 

Pass on this restaurant.
author: Dalbert G.

description: Everytime I have eaten at One Market I have had a truely wonderful experience.  I love their sparkling lemonade and best creme brulee I've ever had.  Every meal I have ever had has been interesting and memorable.
author: Diane R.

description: I, like most of their lunchtime customers, dined at One Market with people from work.  Overall, the food was good but not great.  It took a very long time for the food to come and was hard to flag down our waiter anytime we needed something.  You end up eating a lot of bread and losing your appetite as a result.  Its pretty pricey for the quality of food/service that you get in return.  The food is probably a 4, the service and prices are a 2, so three stars overall.
author: M P.

description: The restaurant is really great, however the small portions make you not so excited.. I went here for an interview, and the feeling of the restaurant is that you have to elite or handle your fork in the most pleasant form in order to fit in. It made you uncomfortable... The food is quite fantastic, however the waiter made us feel unwelcome due to us not ordering wine pairing with every meal. Also, very expensive for what you get.
author: Marisa C.

description: Think "dining room of a nice hotel"...At least that's what it reminded me of.  No need to write too much here.  Formal and a little stuffy.  Great place to take the parents when they're in town for dinner.  Wear a jacket.  Service was professional and attentive, food was well prepared and tasty.  I've never been in during the day so I can't comment on that but for a tasty, formal, conservative dinner it works.
author: Spidermonkey J.

description: Friends and I went there for happy hour one night. The bartender was super friendly and patient (and made great drinks). Unfortunately, the waitress in the bar was not. She was extremely rude from the start. Then she asked if we would like to order food. We answer that we are not sure about what we want, but before we can even ask her opinion she says ok and walks off. Service goes down from there.
author: Cat S.

description:
I used to work in this restaurant as a busboy / food runner (Yes, they actually have a position doing specifically this..only bring dishes to patrons) over 12 years ago just as I came out of highschool and starting college.  
Eventhough this restaurant started by the California reknown chef, Bradley Ogden, I barely see him there.  But his signature dishes were left in good hands with his sou Chefs.

All the dishes was tasty and exceptionally well prepared.  They took pride in their dishes (If the finish dishes doesn't get to the customer within X # of minutes, they throw it away and make a new one)  They are extremely sanitary, washing their hands constantly after making every individual salads. (No worries there).  I LOVED their desserts, especially the Baked Alaskan when the nice pastry chef made one for me at the end of the shift to thank me for help them out.  It was light and fluffy, one of the best desserts I've had.  

Unfortunately, the service needs a little work.  Eventhough I work with service, I'm only a busboy and did the best I can.  (Probably why a lot of the waiters asked to work with me instead)  Each waiters are assigned certain area (about 7-8 tables) with a busboy assigned to them.   A lot of them are nice and friendly, but a few of them a rude and snotty.  They were not suppose to help tables which are not assigned to them to prevent mistakes from happening such as placing wrong orders or drinks (Happeneed a few times that I've seen for those friendly, helpful waiters! ...got the crap yelled out of em by the assigned waiter)    I do understand some of them of what they're going through.  Pressure from cooks / bartenders / customers / management / hostess.  Some of them were about to crack and needed psychiatric help!
author: Gary Y.

description:
i am new to san francisco, so i have not been able to compare One Market with other restaurants in town.
five stars for service. i'm a big stickler for good service, so one market definately gets two thumbs up.
i didn't even notice our table was wobbly until the Manager ran over and made it steady.  waiter was friendly.

i agree with some of the other yelp members, food was not too memorable. I only had it one night ago and had to think awhile before remembering what i had as an appetizer, but i do remember the entree (lavender enfused lamb), because of the way the waiter had described this dish, but not because it was particulary tasty. i really was hoping for more from the great way he desribed, but was a bit disappointed. 

price was also pretty good - wide range of options. if you dont want to spend as much, they have a prixe fix for $29, and one for $45 as well as a chef's tasting menu for $75. the first two includes appetizer, main, and dessert. rest of the entree menu ranged started from 20+
author: Diana T.

description: This was NOT the restaurant that I was expecting.  I ended up doing a business dinner here, hoping for good food, service, etc. etc.  the things you expect from a top notch SF restaurant.  Here's the pros: food was very good, not excellent mind you but very very good (I'll give it 2 very's).  Service was terrible.  Are you kidding me?  We had like 5 waiters serving our 8 person table and none could ever remember who ordered what from our drinks, salads, entrees, dessert.  I actually took a bite out of my supplier's meal before realizing it wasn't mine.  It felt like training day for their newest staff. For the type of restaurant this is and the prices they were charging I really expected better.  This just wasn't the caliber of restaurant I was expecting after all the hype.  Would I go there again?  Maybe, but not for a business dinner, the service was just too disruptive.
author: Ann F.

description: One Market is one of those classic, iconic American restaurants in the Financial District. Food and service was awesome. We both started off with the caesar salad which was perfectly dressed and had this crispy little bite size croutons.  My dad got the roasted chicken while I got the duck ravioli. Normally I don't get ravioli b'c they usually give you about 4 and you're still hungry afterwards. This one intrigued me though as it was stuffed with roasted duck and topped with a foie gras reduction. The sauce was very tasty but after a few spoonfuls, I realized that I probably was just spooning butter and foie gras juice into my mouth. Probably not so good for the waistline. The chicken was very juicy with a thin, crispy skin. It also came with a side order of spinach and the creamiest mashed potatoes.
author: Josephine H.

description:
Ron, having tasted chef Mark Dommen's food at a private event a few months back and really enjoying the meal, well we wanted to give One Market another visit.  
Our meal and service experience were both solid winners.  Here's what we had:
Liz: Tiger Shimp, Colorado Lamb Loin, Mint Chocolate Chip Ice Cream Sandwich
John: Portobello Mushroom Soup, Pork Tenderloin, Chocolate Bread Pudding
Ron: Smoked Trout Mi Cuit, Roasted Monkfish, Dessert Trio (Butterscotch Pudding, Lemon Meringue Cheesecake, Sundae Parfait)
We also pigged out and ordered other desserts: The Gingerbread and a Pavlova that was very good.
There wasn't a clunker in the bunch.  A few of the dishes had some flourishes that seemed a bit unnecessary, but it's a minor complaint.  Service was attentive, complete and we were never left wanting for anything or wondering "where had our waiter gone?".  
One Market has been around for quite a while (15 years?) and they do  a solid job.
Go check it out.
author: Ron T.

description: Brad Ogden knows seafood, and does it well. I always try to order stuff that's really in season, since they do have a tendency to put out of season stuff on the menu, but their fresh stuff is excellent. I don't like it at lunch, too many suits and cell phones, but dinner is very charming.
author: Alessandra J.

description: Surprising that noone's written a review about this place beside Joe? Thank goodness for SF's Dine About Town series...I don't think I wouldve tried this place if it wasn't for that. I had the Duck breast over duck confit and it was good, until I got to the end of the breast and it was kind of rubbery. The tart tatin was ok... I know that these prices are cheap $31.95 p/p but that doesn't mean you should give us your over-stock of food items and whip something up to put on the dine-about-town menu...i hate to say but I was not impressed...would not come back...maybe if they they get 3 more Michelins stars...maybe...but don't take my word for it...if you want to check it out, by all means do...
author: Jaimee T.

description: I was slightly confused when I first heard about the place. I guess still being a FinDis newbie, I didn't know this place actually existed. We also didn't know where the entrance was and walked into the office building. It's a great office building. finally we arrived. had a few beers and chatted.
author: Anita C.

description: We came here for the dine about town.  It was awesome how they were able to accomodate a large group with a short notice.  That was definitely a plus.  The service and the overall ambiance was great.  Our server recommended an awesome bottle of wine.  The food however, was a little disappointing. Although creative, the food was just so-so.
author: Jen L.

description: We were 5 women having the DAT dinner.  The food was good, and I really liked the mushroom soup with soy flan, a quail egg and rice crispies.  The duck main course and the pear galette were delicious as well.  But minus minus for charging the 18% tip for 5 people when the menu said they would charge the 18% for parties of 8.  I hate having a good meal and then going home feeling a bit screwed.  Kinda ruins the experience.
author: Mia G.

description: I'm rating this based on a near-decade-old memory so bear with me. Why would it be relevant today? A glass of syrah I ordered here way back in the 90s made me perk up and think, these are just fermented grapes, you say?? I stuck my nose in the glass and commenced sniffing. I haven't stopped since, and I owe it all to a glass of Qupe syrah. Was I ever that young? wonders the Niles Crane knee jerk reaction in me. Yes I was. And when I behold a fruit bomb from California, I still think of that happy hour, many moons ago, in One Market.
author: Audrey L.

description: Great dinner here.  I normally eat meat, meat, and more meat but went the veggie route this time and loved it.  The dish was a Portobello and potato "lasagna".  Out of this world.  Great Sunchokes for a side.  Waiter was wonderful and service was seemless.  I like it.
author: Doreen D.

description: Average is all I can say. It's a nice reastaurant, great views, great locale, good serivce, but lacking in food quality. I had high expectations for this restaurant as it has 1 Michelin star but it failed to appease. I don't think I will be returning or craving their menu anytime soon. It was good to try their dine about town menu to get a taste of their food but I am not sure it was an accurate depiction of what they can really create.
author: Josephine L.

description: Hmm, pretty restaurant and delicious food. I would definitely return for the food. One minus, though--rude hostess! She interrupted me while I was talking to another host at the counter and commanded that host go complete another task. Then, she proceeded to ignore me while she spoke to a staff member. When she finished her conversation, she went on to help two other guests before I had to, literally, interrupt her for her to realize that she had forgotten to finish helping me. Maybe it was busy but still I don't appreciate being ignored.
author: Royce L.

description:
I've eaten in many starred Michelin restaurants around the world, and I must say I am shocked this restaurant got one.  It is more closely a one or two 'knife and fork' rating.  Let me describe.

The Bar - The waitress in the bar was nice.  The drinks were good and not overly expensive.  The pianist, "Billy Philadelphia", dutifully banged away at various trite bar tunes to make conversation impossible.  I thought of tipping him $20 for a piece of silence.  Later during dinner, I actually heard him playing the theme from Charlie Brown.  ACK!

The Dining room - We were seated an oddly deep booth type table.  This is odd because one expects very nice service in a Michelin one-star.  However, the deep table required us to (a) assist in the busing of our dishs; (b) have arms thrust in front of our faces; (c) move items around the table so that plates could be served.  Sigh.  It was loud.  Not a reserved Michelin Star here.

The Food - The food was okay.  I have never said 'okay' in reference to a starred restaurant before.  The amuse bouche, which wasn't referred to as such, was a small dollop of duck liver mousse on top of a small round of toast.  The four servings were unceremoniously sitting on a small plate that was plopped toward the end of the table (remember the deep booth?).  It was okay.  
The "hand-picked dungeness crab salad" was good, though the crab was almost frozen and the "polenta flan" didn't taste like very much at all.  It was $15.  And what is hand-picked?  What else would one use?  A foot?
The Gulf Shrimp salad as about $14.  It had three smallish shrimp propped on a bed of shredded cucumber with some tasty sauce dribbled around.  It was pretty good, but there is no way those small shrimp were worth $5 each.
The guinea hen was very good, though the corn served with it was a bit salty.  The lamb chops were very good but were plated with all the imagination of a truck-stop diner:  White plate, two chops, some dark sauce underneath.  The fish cooked sous vide (such a trend) was served more or less room temperature.  Not impressive.

The Service - The server was nice, but I had to wonder if she just started working there when we arrived.  When we asked what type of oysters they had, she had to flip through a notepad to find out and then came back and said they were out of one.  The food came out at a slightly rapid pace and as one bottle of wine emptied, we were not asked if we wished to order another.  After asking twice for the wine list, I got it.  I asked about a wine and the server did not know so said that she would go ask the sommelier.  UM.  Since when does a sommelier not come to the table?  The server returned and said the sommelier thought we might like a particular wine (about $80).  I said ok.  The main courses came.  We ate.  Then the wine arrived 25 minutes later, carried by some man in a suit we had never seen.  We said we no longer wanted it as we were finished eating.  He said ok and walked off.  We were going to order a glass of wine instead, but it took another 15 minutes to even get the list of wines by the glass.  
They comped us dessert, but oh well.  The mini ice cream sandwich was good, but lacked all presentation.  The 'ice cream sundae' was about as boring as one could make it.  The ice cream was supposed to be cocoa nib, but was clearly coffee.  the brownie on the bottom wasn't the nice cake-like fudgy sort you'd love under ice cream, but a dense, compact, sugary brick.  The caramel sauce (served separately) had nothing in common with caramel except it was sort of the same color.  the whole almonds just sat in a small bowl (almonds? on a sundae???).  The fudge sauce was ok.

OVERALL -  There is no way this restaurant meets the standards of a Michelin star.  The food is passable and at times good, but nothing worth remembering.  The prices are not bad, but then again, the food and service aren't that good.  The atmosphere is sort of like "bistro-plunked-in-a-touristy-business-district".  Oh. And in the ultimate provincial statement, they "close" at 9pm (yes even on friday and saturday).  (Unlike some SF restaurants, they do not throw you out then, they just stop seating then.)  I'd recommend going somewhere else.
author: John B.

description: Was here for dinner 2 weeks ago, I ate so many things that I can't remember what I had. Had a duck of some kind and a salmon dish for a start then some desert. Anyways, I was food high cause I was stuff. Maybe I'll come back again actually enjoy the food and not munching on everything.
author: Danny V.

description: The drinks are good, nice and strong. Started with the amuse bouche of tuna which was nice. Followed with the roasted pear salad which had perfect combination of goat cheese, walnuts and the pears. We also got the fried green tomatoes which were sweet and very large. For the main I had the Duck which was amazing. Perfectly cooked and tender, one of the better duck dishes I've had in a long long time. Definitely pricey, but worth it...
author: Nicolas H.

description: I hadn't been to One Market in about 6 or 7 years, but glad to report that its still phenomenal. The menu has incredible choices and the presentation is awesome. Its an oldie but a goodie in my book. Oh, and you can't miss the butterscotch pudding-WOW! So good. We'll be back!
author: Kristin L.

description:
Went here for work lunch before Christmas, although I had never been here, I thought this place had a good holiday feel...tree in Rockefeller Center type feel.

Anyhow, not sure if I was right about that, but the food is tasty (I got a soup appetizer and salmon dish) and well presented. The place is pricey, but let me tell you that the dessert menu is pretty damn worth it.

I'm not a big sweets guy, but pretty much everyone saw something that had to have, and thoroughly enjoyed it.
author: Kaveh A.

description: Food is okay, but way over priced and way over rated.  BIG downside is service.  It can be slow at its best.  After disappointing lunch AND dinner with same results will not be coming back.  So many better places near by and without the snobby attitude.
author: jim T.

description: Dissapointing.  Large portions, with some odd moments of creativity, but largely mediocre.  A mystery why Michelin gave this restaurant a star...really?  Good location, blah decor, tends to be noisy.  Maybe we just hit a bad day for the kitchen.  Meh says it all.
author: Margaret T.

description: "I was really excited to try out this restaurant and I wasn't as pleased as I thought I would be. I went on a Wednesday night and they were out of their special, and it was only 7pm...? The service was good, and the desert platter made up for my not so great dinner. I'd give it a second shot, but have many other places I would like to try first."
author: Lisa K.

description: Went for lunch a few weeks ago and had a wonderful experience.  Excellent risotto, excellent crab salad.  Service was a bit awkward, but we were a big party.
author: Sheila W.

description:
one market is a surprise. a crazy surprise.

the first time i went, it was out of sheer desperation on a lazy sunday afternoon. one of those days where you take forever to roll out of bed, put some clothes on, and slowly figure out what you're going to do. by the time you are ready to head out for a meal, most decent brunch places are closed, and you're stuck in that twilight zone dining purgatory - after lunch and before dinner...when most restaurants are closed.

so we ended up at one market, and by golly, it was shockingly pleasant! nothing mindblowing, but nonetheless satisfying. 

i didn't want to admit it, but i guess it's possible: a huge restaurant, smack dab in the fi-di epicenter for business meals (consumed by those who usually don't have great taste), that's part of a chain, and with a chef at the helm who already has his hand in way too many other establishments (thus diluting quality),...CAN BE GOOD! 

went there last night with some chaps for dine about town, and it was enjoyable all the way through, from our hot olive bread to the flourless souffle chocolate cake (with some sort of complementary peanut brittle ice cream). 

we, a large party, were all very content with our meals.
author: jennifer y.

description:
The food wasn't bad, and neither was the service. I've had better though. The server was very serious. If he smiled a few more times, the experience would've been nicer. He did comp a few dishes after we asked a few times when we would get it. Thank goodness we weren't in a rush to go anywhere.
The food was a bit overpriced, but somewhat typical of SF restaurants like this one. Most of the proportions of the dishes were small..except for the main dish. For 5 gals, we shared 4 appetizers, 3 main dishes, 2 sides, and 3 desserts. We were pretty stuffed by the end of the evening though. The appetizers were all really delicious, except for the foie gras. The way they made the foie gras just made it taste like pate, so why spend so much on something that doesn't taste like what i really is? The crab risotto and the crab and pear salad were good. The glazed wild shrimp was tasty but it only came with 3 shrimps. The Colorado lamb was real tasty, but not if you don't like the "gamey" taste of lamb. The seabass was absolutely succulent, with all the flavors that were added to it!! That's a definite "RECOMMEND." As for dessert..how can you go wrong? There's no wrong choice there!
Parking wasn't easy, but they do have valet.
author: Dana S.

description: This place is a joke...I first walk in to see a bunch of suits in their 40's trying to act like they are still in college...ugh. I go with a group of friends and order a cocktail...yuck! I order a seafood dish and received the smallest portion of food I have ever seen. I went out for more food after dinner BTW! I'm sorry, did I go to French Laundry ..This place is fronting like it's hot s**t.
author: Tricia M.

description: I have dined here a couple of times and to be honest, it is just OK...nothing special. This "institution", produces the same ole' dishes that everyone else does. Ahi tuna, Dungeness crab, Duck Comfit etc. Truly tired. The major difference is that they charge a little more. I guess you have to charge more when your clientele are a bunch of suits and power bob's. Who else is going to pay for it?
author: Gabe T.

description: I really liked this place. Expensive but super yummy. The wine list was incredible and the little "amouse bouche" dishes(which were free, bonus!)were great. Kind of an old school place, definitely a power lunch with older business men vibe, but very traditionally fabulous. The waitress was very attentive and nice and I love the silky napkins...
author: Kaytee M.

description:
Took hubby here for his birthday and reserved the kitchen table.  Although it is very expensive and usually they only make reservations for a party of four or more, since it was a weeknight they let us reserve the table for two... and let me just say it was well worth the money.  
In the kitchen the table faces the banquet prep area and since this was December banquets were on and we got to experience the hustle and bustle of the kitchen.  
The menu is prefixed and if I remember correctly it was 7 courses we chose the wine pairing with it and should have only gotten one wine pairing because by the time it came to dessert... which you have to go to assemble yourself with the assistance of a chef of course... I was pretty toasty. 
The food was delicious and the wines complemented everything just perfect, can't say I remember dessert much but I'm sure it was good.
The server was very nice and friendly and with each course the chef comes over and explains what you are about to eat which is really cool.
Don't really know how the rest of the restaurant is because we were led back to the kitchen and didn't get much of a chance to look but it was low lighting and looked comfortable.
author: Agnes K.

description:
Had dinner here w/ a friend from out of town.  Last time I was here was about a year ago and tonite the decor and ambience seem to be different somehow.  Not sure if they changed anything but the place seemed more warm and inviting...maybe due to the "amber" lighting.  Well, after enjoying my "$12 martini!" at the bar we were seated about 15 mins delayed of our reservation time.  We were seated at a booth near the open kitchen which is always nice cause I like watching the chefs at work.  

I started with the beet carpaccio with marinated rock shrimp, radish sprouts, and crispy ginger pieces.  The appetizer was refreshing and light...good as a summer starter.  My entree was the liberty duck breast with trumpet mushroom.  The duck breast was juicy and tender.  The au jus reduction was sweet and tangy and the wilted swiss chard was not overcooked w/ a bit of crunchiness in them.  A decent duck breast entree.  For dessert I had the d'anjou pear galette.  I was a little disappointed with the puff pastry.  I LOVE puff pastry dessert.  Allow me to be tangential here...I love bread pudding and the best bread pudding ever that I've had was from the XYZ restauant from the W hotel in SF.  Unlike typical bread pudding, this one was made from croissant rather than "bread."  It was light, fluffy, buttery, and oh so good!  Anyways, getting back to my pear galette, I was disappointed at the rather "flat" and "unpuffed" pastry of the galette.  The pear was also so-so.  

This restaurant as one would expect, has a pretty extensive wine list, but unfortunately my dinner companion doesn't drink (a true sin!) so I ordered from the dreaded "by the glass" list.  The syrah I chose to go with my duck breast was an '05 Kinton Syrah which had a nice earthy tone w/ blackberry notes and a hint of pepperiness which went nicely with the duck breast.  A bit young but mellow with good fruit.

Food-wise I'd say a 3.5 but I'm easily swayed by ambience and there was something different this time that was warm and inviting so I rounded it to a 4.
author: Rick P.

description:
i think, after a place gets about 200 reviews or so, my stars won't make a huge difference.  but then again, i'm writing partly to increase my own review count, so i guess it doesn't matter that my stars won't matter.  

let's see...  the food was pretty good.  i had the filet mignon, and it wasn't too bad.  the desserts were good too.  though, overall, i do think it's a bit overpriced for what you get.  

one other thing - it was a bit too loud when i went (around 6-7 pm), with all the people there, but i guess that's to be expected on a weeknight right after work.  just something you should keep in mind if you want a cozy, intimate dinner.
author: Matt P.

description: We went there on my buddies expense account and it was ok.  I could not have imagined paying $40 for a steak that would have been better used to make shoes.  Tough and cold.  The lamb was very good, according to my wife who didn't even offer me a bite!  The Caesar salad had too much dressing.  The desserts, however, were good.  I would go back on another expense account but would not spend my own money on this place...
author: Erick Z.

description: I absolutely love this place for dinner.  We generally do the tasting menu, 7 courses for $70 and love each and every course.  Service has always been great and watching the open kitchen perform when they get busy is quite an experience.
author: Happy L.

description: Great work lunch place..great location, good service and great food :) Terrine of mushroom and fingerling potato was really good. Great wine list and dessert..  Enjoy!
author: Natasha R.

description:
(this review was on the company dime)
no problems with this place if someone else (ie company) is paying for it.  if i had to pay for it, there are other places in sf i'd rather drop some coin at.  

the food is good, i won't venture to say it's great.  the atmosphere is full of business folk, as expected for a restaurant of this caliber in financial.  and of course, i was in a tshirt / jeans, but needless to say the service is quite good.  again, to be expected.  overall, not mind-blowing nor deservedly like "you should come here", but if it's a business lunch, you might as well.  the regular burger here is quite good.  and so is the ahi burger.  the crab cakes are tasty, but small.

and the happy hour is phenomenal.  it's very reasonable (cheap by financial dist standards), and lasts until 7.  a far better deal than americano.
author: Jason J.

description:
Definitely expected more from an one Michelin star restaurant.  We had the weekly beast fixed menu for $49 and $20 wine pairing.  This week was duck:

1.  Started with the Muscovy Duck Liver Mousse Terrine & brioche.   It was way too sweet.  Not a good start.
2. The Muscovy Duck Salad.  A step up from the first course but our waitress gave us a white "pinot noir".  I think the waitress was new or a "trainee" and didn't realize she was describing a red wine while giving us a white one.  I think she was confused but we didn't say anything as she already felt bad about our telling her our disappointment with the sweet terrine.
3. Muscovy Duck Leg Ravioli.  A little better than the first 2 dishes.  The duck leg was a bit overcooked but overall tasty.  The problem came from the fact we got our food before our wine pairing which was a bit annoying as they are meant to be eaten together.
4. Roasted Muscovy Duck Breast.  Duck was cooked perfectly.  Very good.
5. Duck Egg Creme Brulee.  Very good.  The best part of the meal.  Too bad at this point I was full from the average dishes proceeding it.

I really wanted to like my meal but I don't think I should of had to try that hard to like it.  Overall just ok.  Wouldn't make an effort to come back here but wouldn't say no if someone wanted to come here.  Just wouldn't do the weekly beast again.  

We have been to Michelin star restaurants that just blew this place out of the water.  Not sure if this place really deserves a Michelin star.
author: Tammy S.

description: This is the restaurant I go to when I can't get a table at Boulevard.  The food is pretty good and so is the wine list.  You can usually get a table without a reservation and it's literally next door to where I work so it's very convenient for work dinners.  You can also get in and out in under an hour so it's a great place to have a dinner meeting that you want over as soon as possible.  They have a separate bar area but its pretty small and usually crammed with after work happy hour foiks.  But the restaurant is very large and usually has seating available.  The only downside is that on the rare occasion that the restaurant is very busy, the hostess is visibly stressed out and they seem unable to handle dealing with the flow.  However, this has only happened a couple of times.
author: V C.

description:
Yumm.  This place was phenomenal.  We are from denver, and we just do not have this caliber of food in denver.  Lovely
 atmosphere, perfect service, and the food was fantastic.  I did the 3 course tasting menu for $39.  I  started with the golden beet soup and it was delicious and creative with apples and ahi tuna in the soup.   Next I had the sole with crab and it was the best sole I have ever had.  Moist and delicious and the crab on top was just perfect too.  The sauce around the fish was lovely and flavorful but not overpowering.    For dessert I had the chocolate toffee cake which was good ..... but not as good as the Vahlrona Chocolate Souffle my husband had which was so amazing.  Each bite melted in your mouth and was light and fluffy.  Super yummy.  I also had the wine flight pairing and both the rose and the pinot (neither of which are wine varietals I usually drink) were very, very good and complimented my food perfectly.
I highly recommend One Market!
author: Aimee Z.

description: Don't know much about the food, but the happy hour drinks should not be missed.
author: Brad Z.

description: When I went, it was with a group of 8 people, so we had a pre-fixed menu.  WIth that said, I choose the Ceasar Salad, the Black Cod and then Sorbet for dessert.  All of the food was tasty.  THe only downsides were the service was a bit slow, but that might be because of our party size.  The place was packed at 6pm on a Thursday night though, so I would love to go back for a happy hour drink.
author: Pele N.

description: For the business traveler, you cannot go wrong here.  Great service and you can get full meals at the bar.  One Market has an excellent wine by the glass list and  superb scotch and bourbon selections.  I recommend the oysters and the strip steak.  The oysters are accompanied by an amazing champagne/vinaigrette /shallot sauce.  The NY Strip is topped a great shallot sauce
author: Paul L.

description: Went there for happy hours. Good selection of wine, makes for a good environment for conversations. I'm taking away one star for the pushy waitress who wanted us to order too much too soon since her shift was getting over and she had to head home (this was at 7pm)... blah.
author: Divya R.

description: The food is OK.  I had the scallops which were fine, but the juice it was surrounded by tasted like chinese medicine and was too tangy and salty.  The tomato bisque was pretty good though.  A colleague had the duck "sous vide" - which was done quite nicely (i got a taste), but I don't think I could just have that by itself - you would need to order a side.  Overall, the service was good but it took too long for the food to come out.
author: Cami P.

description:
One Market was a total let-down.  I had lunch there the other day.  Our waitress would not shut up.  She not only described the food in long, painful detail, but described everything as if she was working on commission.  It was as if she had to make it sound out-of-this-world or no one would eat there.  

I looked at the appetizers.  I noticed the smoked trout with an organic egg.  I thought that sounded pretty weird and unimaginative.  But sometimes those end up being the best dishes.  The waitress of course would not shut up about how everyone is talking about this smoked trout appetizer and how it is such a hit.  I considered the fresh crab with celery sorbet as well, but went with the trout.  I was less than thrilled when my plate arrived.  The appetizer was basically a giant hash brown with a thick piece of smoked trout on top, and a poached egg on top of the trout.  Small pieces of bacon or pancetta were scattered around the edge of the plate.  The smoked trout was fishy-tasting.  The whole thing made me feel like I was at IHOP.  It was awful.  My client ordered the crab appetizer.  After looking at it, I realized it looked pretty disgusting as well.  It looked like a lump of crab meat on one side of the plate and a small scoop of celery sorbet on the other side.  Pretty gross if you ask me.

My main course was pretty bad too.  I got the duck ravioli.  It was very salty.  You would never know that the ravioli was stuffed with duck meat.  Duck has a distinctive flavor, and I did not taste a trace of it in the ravioli.  To make things worse, the ravioli seemed to be drowning in butter.  The whole meal made me want to vomit afterwards.  All that grease and heaviness...yuck.  I hope I never have to go back there.
author: Kandi K.

description: I like the feel here. Service was acceptable.  Now to the food.  The mushroom soup was great, could've been perfect if it wasn't a tad over-salted.  The tri-tip was good.  Overall, good times and wouldn't mind coming back in a couple years.
author: Derek C.

description: Went here a couple weeks ago for Dine About Town. This is one of the restaurants that makes Dine About Town such a great thing. Everything was amazing. The pre fix choices were taken off the actual menu and not just thrown together. We couldn't believe what we got for what we actually paid. Of course it won't be as cheap the next time we go, but we will definitely be going back.
author: m t.

description: I've never eaten at the place but I have to say it gets super crowded during happy hour.  Standard drinks - nothing special. Always seems to be a starting point for me and end up somewhere else where the vibe is more upbeat.
author: Yve T.

description:
Every time I've walked by this place around happy hour it is jam packed w/ a lively crowd.  Apparently they have an absurdly affordable happy hour.  

We opted to avoid the mayhem and were able to enjoy a more relaxed setting.  Since it was some time ago I can't actually recall my exact choice but definiltey scallops to start which were perfectly done.  For my entree I ordered halibut - I can't recall the last time I ordered white fish because I'm usually so disappointed w/ the lack of flavor.  However...... this was probably one of the best pieces I've ever had.  A light, yet robust sauce w/ a strong Thai influence.  Absolutely to die for...and I don't say that lightly.
author: Lauren W.

description:
Three of us went for dinner and were happy to see the Dine About Town Dinner menu. One Market had the "Standard" and a "Deluxe", we all ordered off the "Deluxe". Many of the same items on both menus, so I was unclear on the difference... perhaps portion size?

Between the three of us, we tried the Ceaser salad, golden lentil soup, pork tenderloin and seared scallops. All the dishes were very good. The soup was creamy and the salads had a strong garlic flavor, but not overpowering. The entrees were very good 3 large rounds of pork wrapped in bacon, flavorful with apples and potatoes. Scallops looked and tasted great, well prepared and seasoned.

Dessert was an apple "pie" or chocolate cake. Both were good but the pie was more like a cobbler and was cold. I am sure it would have been better a bit warm.

After a brief delay in being seated, service was attentive and fast, repeatedly coming by with bread and refilling the water glasses. Plates were cleared quickly and the manager stopped by briefly.

The only negatives was the noise in the room and they didn't have our first wine selection, but recommended a serviceable replacement. For a Thursday night, the place was packed and it was a bit hard to have a conversation.

One Market deserves their Michelin star and we will be back.
author: Mark E.

description: Always a great experience. The atmosphere, the hostesses and the cooks are all reason to come here again and again. I have to applaud all of the chefs for doing such an amazing job every time I come here, especially the meats. The steak was cooked to perfection when I came to this restaurant on New Years. Thanks to everyone here for such a pleasant and delectable experience!
author: Your F.

description: came in after i saw a review in the paper.. the food was great the roast chicken was moist and tasty.. i'll come back again because i didn't have dessert =( to full lolz, if your in the area check it out
author: jonathan h.

description: I have had a good dining experience the both times I have eaten at One Market Restaurant, where they serve up American / Californian cuisine.  The restaurant doesn't look like all that, one hardly hears about the place, and there is a slight feel that there is something missing in terms of the ambiance but the food has been exceptional.  One of my favorites dishes anywhere is duck and One Market Restaurant prepared one of the best duck plates I have had, and my girlfriend agrees.  This place is under-rated and deserves more buzz.
author: Long Duk D.

description: Excellent Happy Hour Spot. Tall $2.50 Hefenweizens do make you forget about the past week on Friday evenings and get you warmed up nicely for the few precious hours you have ahead of you over the next couple of days. Crowd is older professional and I wouldn't say this is a young scene, but with $2.50 Tall Hef's, by 7pm everyone is ready to find magic into the night.
author: Nipur D.

description: I have had one really good meal and experience here about a year ago but other visits since then have been disappointing.  The service seems to be more bad than good, with a sommelier that's overpowering and a wait staff that's somewhat put out by your presence.  The food is also hit and miss and in general, I am not very impressed with their menu.  This place is suitable for a corporate expensed lunch or dinner but I wouldn't recommend it for any other occasion.
author: MJ E.

description: Great view and very good service. Food was very good but not great. I'm sure for the price you could find something great some where around the area. We had the crab salad to start, I had the king salmon, and we finished with a dessert trio of creme brulee, toffee almond something, and pinapple upside down cake.
author: Mike C.

description: I went here once and I had a ball.  Now, the food probably really deserves a four and the value is about a four as well, but the service was impeccable at our table.  It probably helped that we were in the kitchen table in the back where everyone sees us and serves us, and they gave a tour of their wine room with a complimentary bottle of crap wine, but it was fun.  I left here drunk on wine, but dinner was about 4.5 hours long.  Location is dope, right on the edge of the financial district by all the BART, buses, trolleys, cabs.  I'd go back here for the experience.  But I prolly wouldn't go here for a date.
author: David C.

description: Took one of my co-workers here the other day and was not impressed. Nice decor but not a cozy feeling, very business work kind of crowd with high ceilings and bright light filled windows. The food was really not that impressive considering the price. I had the house special which was the halibut and came with absolutely no sides and for $26 an entree at lunch, I was just expecting more. Not sure how this place got a Michelin star this year to be honest with you, I really did not see any kind of clever culinary attempt here, but then again, I didn't get a chance to try that much on the menu. All in all, I wouldn't recommend coming here unless you were dining on an expense account and just wanted a last minute place to bring a client or colleagues.
author: Susan K.

description:
Getting lazy

I come here a lot on the company's dime and every time I find the food to be mediocre for the price.  Specials aren't surprising and unique.  Dishes and flavors are safe.  For the price, there's better restaurants in the city.
author: Josh S.

description: Fantastic food and amazing service.  The menu was fun and interesting, and most importantly, the food was delicious.  I can honestly say I've never had a tastier rutabaga soup.  Most importantly, the in-house sommelier was friendly, knowledgeable, and eager and enthusiastic to share her knowledge and opinions with us.  Can't recommend her enough!
author: Jason L.

description: I came here tonight with 7 of my cousins after watching Wicked. We called after to the show around 5pm to make a reservation for 8 people @ 7 o'clock and it was very easy to do. Great customer service! When we got to the restaurant and i browsed the menu, so many different things popped out at me. I wanted it all! I was deciding between the halibut, the lamb shanks, scallops, and the ravioli. In the end i went with the scallops. I LOVED them! They were so delicious! It came with a lemongrass sauce, along with veggies (different types of squash). Very good dish! For appetizers we had raw oysters, which were also very good because they were fresh. The waiter said they get them fresh daily, good to know when eating raw oysters =) We also got complementary tasting of ahi tuna, which was great! Every dish the others in my party had were great! (Lamb shanks, new york steak, blacked cod, halibut, pork tenderloin, and the duck) The perks of going in such a large group was that I got to taste a little bit of everything! I would have to say everything on the menu is good, you can't go wrong. For dessert we had chocolate souffle, and a mini platter with cheesecake, chocolate cream pie, and 2 different creme brulees. All of which were amazing! We were all very pleased with the outcome of this last minute dinner spot. Our total for 8 people was 450, this included a bottle of wine (all wine bottles 1/2 off in july!) dozen oysters, 8 entrees, and dessert.  I will be back again! Loved it!
author: Jennifer W.

description: The best way to describe this restaurant is... Interesting, but good. I've eaten all over the place and phenomenal and dismal restaurants and my feeling is that this restaurant is trying to be something that it's incapable of. Unique combinations that never really reach fruition. I'm always drawn to the menu with the question, "That's interesting, I wonder what that will taste like?" and end up saying, "That's not at all what I was hoping for." Certainly not bad and I would never turn down a free meal here, but not worth my own money (in my opinion). The best part about this place is the happy hour, fantastic deals for top shelf drinks that are well made.
author: jess c.

description: great food, really expensive, it's for special occasions in my opinion.  Good location, be prepared to spend a long time there service is purposely slow so you can spend a long time there since it is a 'higher end restaurant.'
author: Tala L.

description: I had a good experience in this restaurant. Me and my co-workers went here last December 2006 and I had great food and great service. Would definitely come back here if I had the chance. It had a sophisticated ambiance fit for it's address One Market, and located in the heart of the financial district. I had fish (I think it was mahi-mahi) over basmati rice with a cream sauce (I think it's not on their menu anymore). And I absolutely loved it! The service was excellent as well.
author: Cindy S.

description:
My husband and I happened into One Market last Saturday night and had one of the best meals we've ever had.  (And we've dined at some amazing places.)  We walked in with no reservation and were seated without any attitude or issue.  We didn't plan to have a big meal, we were really craving oysters.  But when we looked at the menu and spoke with our friendly and knowledgeable waiter, we decided to try the tasting menu.  Each course was a beautiful little symphony of flavors.  The halibut melted in my mouth, the duck breast was tender and juicy (vanilla potatoes on the plate!!), our desserts were divine.  And for the month of July ALL wines on the wine list are 50% off, so we tried a bottle of wine we probably wouldn't have had otherwise.  

Our server was terrific.  We had a tight shedule (babysitter), so we gave him the time we needed to walk out the door.  He made sure the courses came quickly enough to fit our schedule and attended to our every need.  

Last night my husband and I dined at Gordon Ramsay at the London Hotel in West Hollywood.  The food was good, but we left talking about our amazing meal at One Market.
author: Bonita H.

description: I ate at One Market with my husband and 18 month old son last night.  We love the atmosphere and they were very accommodating with a toddler.  They have highchairs and a kid's menu, which was great.  But the food was very mediocre.  I had the pot roast and it was fatty and the chard served with it was drenched in vinegar.  My husband had the octopus and red pepper soup and he felt it was pretty bland as well.  We both agreed that the best thing was our kid's pasta!  So while we are fans of the atmosphere, we are not fans of the food,
author: kay g.

description: Hadn't visited this restaurant in about 10 years but just did so last week and it was FABULOUS.  My aunt and uncle were in town, and are pretty snoby about food and service, but they were blown away by the food and FANTASTIC service.  The waiter was sooooo helpful and had a complete understanding of all the dishes we asked about.  Other establishments really need to take a lesson from One Market regarding professonal and timely service, and in no way do I mean rushed.  We enjoyed a very leisurely meal while never once feeling we were forgoten.  The food was spectacular, all 3 or our main dishes were tasty without being overwhelming, and the sides were equally delicious.  This is certainly a pricey restaurant, but well worth it.
author: Sean M.

description:
I went there for lunch with my husband on a weekday.  The waiters are quite professional and gave me a black napkin coordinating with my clothes.  The food was really delicious.  The only thing was we had to wait for the main course to come for a while.
However, we are satisfied.
author: Miinno N.

description:
We ordered the six course tasting menu and were pleased with the food.  A couple of flaws didn't mar a very enjoyable evening.

Due to incredibly fortuitous transportation alignments and the easy to get to location, we arrived at the restaurant almost a half hour early.  The hostess was courteous and was able to seat us with only a minute delay.

Warm bread appeared almost immediately and the waiter started explaining the menu right away.  We ordered the six course tasting menu after some discussion with my dining companion, a beloved aunt, and the first person from my family to visit me here in San Francisco.

I am not a wine connoisseur, but the wine recommended to accompany the first courses of our meal was a bit sweet for my taste.  Sadly, I cannot remember what was I ordered.  (Bad reviewer, bad!)

We started out with an oyster which made my aunt say, "oh this is good.  I think this is the best oyster I've ever had." She went on to explain how that might not mean much, but I had to agree that I enjoyed it.

Up next was the crab salad, and it was my favorite of the evening.  Oh, try to imagine the apples and celery root that are going to die a horrible death as I try to replicate something half as good in my own kitchen.  I work near here and I can see myself darting in here at lunch to sit at the bar and savor my crab salad before heading back to the office.  My aunt exclaimed, "Oh, this is REALLY good."

Following that was the lightly smoked trout.  This was an interesting dish.  The light smokey taste was subtle and delicious.  But when paired with the pancetta vinaigrette became bolder and tasty in a different way.

The rabbit meatballs and ravioli were good, and I really liked the broth that accompanied them.  

After tasting the scallops, "bland, " described my culinarily un-adventuresome aunt, "the chef should have done something better with these."  Tough, I thought.  In another setting they would have been unremarkable, but next to the other dishes in the menu, they stood out and not in a good way.

I eyed the small green nub at the top of my roasted carrot.  Should I cut that off, I thought?  But, the carrot was so small.  I popped the whole thing in my mouth and was punished with grit.  Why put something on my plate, something so bite sized and inviting, if I cannot eat it?  Why does this keep happening to me?

By the time the lamb arrived, we were both near sated.  Still, I ate the lamb from my aunt's plate with permission.  The loin atop this dish catches the eye, but underneath is the visually less appealing but more interesting tasting braised shoulder with cocoa.

The best part of the pear galette were the same tangy huckleberries from the lamb course and the pears.  The puff pastry was not as good as other parts of the meal.

Tallying up the courses here, I now realize that we were promised a sea bream course in the description of the tasting menu that never arrived.  Hmmm.

The waiter explained the dishes fully, although he seemed to struggle to remember everything and had to resort to a crib sheet at times.  I was rooting for him.  It was a bit difficult to understand him due to his accent and the noise in the restaurant.  A couple courses arrived a bit closer together than I would like, and another just a bit too long.  Otherwise, the service was good throughout the meal. 

The price was $120 per person.  Too much?  Maybe.  I didn't go there looking for a bargain.  Would I go back?  Yeah.  I am very curious to try the vegetarian tasting menu.  But, I would order that with a crab salad starter.
author: Jeff M.

description: I called and asked if I could make a reservation for Noon today and she said ok.  When my bosses got back they told me the reservationist said the reservation was for 12:45pm - NOT TRUE.  I know it was for Noon because she told me she had to double-check on that time.  I am so mad because normally I get a name of the person who I spoke with, although I did not. this time.  In my gut, I really feel that person knows she was in the wrong.  I am the one who suggests the restaurants for my bosses, and I tell you, never again for One Market.  But if I really have to make a reservation there (NOT) I will go through OpenTable and get a written confirmation.
author: Nexia L.

description:
i enjoyed an excellent DAT (Dine about Town) meal here
5 stars for DAT Lunch specifically since it's a good deal
this year, the $22 DAT lunch menu reads:
farmer's market salad (boring, don't order)
golden lentil soup with vadouvan, yogurt, cilantro and cauliflower (indian inspired), was good, interesting
then tried the grilled trout -- very tasty, executed perfectly, highly recommended
the beef short ribs were also done right, with bold sauce, bed of grits, and some rhubarb
the other entree choice was the mushroom pot pie
for dessert, the best was the blood orange financier over the apple butter tart, both done properly but the edge given to the blood orange zest
for the price, this is an excellent deal since the lunch entrees themselves run around $18-26
while they do not garner as much buzz as it did during the days of Ogden (even while maintaining its one michelin star), the restaurant still manages to please the palate, but i'd only come for DAT
fyi, the atmosphere here during lunch is very corporate
and the food takes a little while
back again for a dinner talk, the salad was nothing to write home about
but the trout was pretty good.
author: Rob C.

description: I went here with a group from work for a weeknight dinner.  I have to admit that I am not a very adventurous diner.  As a result, I had a hard time finding things on the menu that interested me.  I ended up with the pork loin.  It was good.  The service was good.  Of course, you would expect that for an upscale restaurant, such as this.  With that in mind, I am pretty neutral on this place.  Nothing bad to say, nothing especially good.  There are better places not too far away.  If a group went here I would be OK with that.  If I was picking a place, I would not pick this one.  If I could give half stars I'd probably go to three and a half.
author: Roy C.

description:
I went last night during DAT and had an amazing experience.  

High points:
-  Service.  On point, courteous, only there at the perfect time
-  Food: mushroom soup was delectable, the scallops and tuna were perfect
-  Wine: great wine list, although the mark-up was a little steep (over 2 times).

I would definitely go back here again.
author: Brian M.

description: Dined here on Saturday Nov. 20.  Dined at Chef's table given no reservations.  It was okay, not great price/value for food quality.  Appetizers have more creativity that main courses lacked.  It's pricey given somewhat average food quality - nothing special.   Waiter was knowledgeable, attentive and pleasant.  Agree with Chris L. review of 11/14.
author: Robert P.

description: Seriously if I could give this place 0 stars I would. I know that sounds harsh, and it appears that some other Yelpers disagree...but I went to this place once and will never, ever go back. Forget the Michelin rating!! I was eating with 2 other people here and we all agreed our food was disgusting.The appetizers we ate really should have been our cue to just drink our way through dinner rather than eat more. Our entrees were equally as bad, and were not even prepared as asked (fish was seriously overcooked, meat seriously undercooked). Alas, our optimistic natures led us to believe the dessert would have to be the savior of the meal....but no. The mint ice cream sandwich was possibly the most horrible thing I've ever put into my mouth. The other 2 mini desserts we ordered to share were not so good either, but not inedible at least. To top it off our server had no clue what she was talking about when we asked questions and was pretty inattentive. Don't waste your money here!
author: Amber P.

description: they really do have excellent service. I told the waitress I was in a rush and had to hurry back to the office, and my dish arrived in no time. And they still managed to cook my chicken just right. In short, I ordered, ate, and paid without a single complaint.
