author: serah G.

description: Great food, great service, great ambience.   Food was very tasty without having a heavy overpowering aftertaste.  Our dinner was perfect. The dayboat scallops were yummy and pefectly cooked.  Ravioli was very good.  Desserts was the bomb.  I had Bragdens butterscotch pudding with the wedding cookie and it was sooo good.  Service was great as well.  No complaints.  We had a very pleasant dining experince.  Will definitely come back.
author: Cj P.

description: personally, i dont believe this is the worst food downtown, but certainly not the best. if i had an option to choose - whether on a company tab or my own - it wouldnt be this place. presentation of the food is decent, however taste is a bit overrated. and my goodness it is sure noisy during lunch. And isn't it always packed with lawyers?
author: Liz R.

description: ohMIgod our meal there tonight was soooo good!!! we had the dine-about-town menu. the veloute was alright, but the bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin was incredible. the service was impeccable and our merry edwards pinot complimented it perfectly as suggested. the flourless chocolate cake was divine - moist and not too rich but just rich enough. i'd go back in a heartbeat!
author: lisa w.

description: We just dined at One Market before heading off to hear Chris Botti play with the San Francisco Symphony. Dinner was very good - I had the prix fix  three course "dining around" and all courses were excellent. The oysters on the half shell were wonderful and the dessert that came with "dining around" was really special. We will return for another special occasion. Service was superb!!
author: Jack M.

description: Two of us had a $250 dinner there last week.  It was interesting.  First, the hostess couldn't give directions about how to get to the restaurant.  When I arrived and asked her why she couldn't help me, she said that she doesn't drive... !!!  When seated, we waited a long time for one of the cocktails we ordered, and we had to ask for it more than three times!  The drinks were good.  The appetizers, foi gras and crab salad, were so-so.  The dinner was ok.  Overall, the service was somewhat aloof. I don't like eating in a restaurant where the servers don't have time to come by and ask how your meal is.  After we were served our food, we never saw the waiter again until a lot of time had passed and we were obviously done.  I think that the waiter barely thanked us. We thanked him back by leaving only 10% as a tip, and that was really too much.  Would I go back? No.
author: Mark B.

description: I was so disappointed with my meal, and the service at One Market. I went here for dinner with three friends, and we'd been looking forward to the meal for awhile. I'll admit, the set up was great, but our server was just awful, and the food...oh lord. I had the portabello mushroom soup as am appetizer and it had absolutely no flavor at all. The bread was really good - but it was hard to get any. The real kicker was my entree - I ordered the mahi mahi and it was literally still frozen in the middle - yuck. I ended up sending it back and was ready to get out of there as quickly as possible, but the manager came up to apologize, which I appreciated. They also brought us four desserts - on the house - which were all really yummy. The mint chocolate chip sandwich was incredibly good and the lemon cheesecake was delicious. After hearing so many rave reviews about One Market, I hate to give it only two stars, but that was my experience. Maybe someday I'll go back for drinks and dessert!
author: meagan m.

description: The food was very good. I would go back for the food. Our server..not so much. He didn't have good attention to detail during our meal. Then, we ordered two different desserts and they brought out two of the same because they ran out of the other one. It probably would have been a good idea to ask us rather than leave it on the table with a here you go... Customer service definitely brought them down a notch.
author: Master C.

description: Yes, sorry I can only give three stars.  Service was pretty flaky and food was so-so.  We got the "Big Fries" as a starter and the name is pretty self-explanatory.  They are huge steak-cut fries, but no dipping sauce?!?  Give me some aioli or even ketchup, nawmeng?  We had to ask for bread, even though the bread man was running around giving bread to everyone else but us.  For my appetizer, I got the roasted quince salad, which was really good.  My three dining companions all got the portobella mushroom soup which sounded great on paper but did not present in person.  I tried it, and there was minimal flavor and had an odd consistency.  Kind of like a post-nasal drip consistency (sorry for being so graphic, but I had to paint the picture!)  For my entree, I got the scallops which were fine, but I didn't really like the sauce or vegetables that were paired with it.  It just didn't mesh.  And Meagan M.'s mahi-mahi was still frozen in the middle.  Our waiter never came by to check up on us, so we had to wait to tell him until we were done eating and he came by to clear away the plates.  I have to give a nod to their customer service though as the manager did come by and comp her entree along with four desserts.  We ordered the chocolate souffle and the chocolate mint chip ice cream sandwich.  They also added the butterscotch pudding and the lemon merangue cheesecake.  I have to admit, the desserts were pretty darn good.  Maybe I'll come back for happy hour sometime cuz the bar area seems pretty cool.
author: Michelle L.

description: after all the business lunches and dinners i've set up here, i finally was treated to a lunch (business of course) at one market.  i can see why the fidi suits flock here - it's a place to see and be seen, but while your soaking in the views and power, there is also some pretty tasty food to enjoy.  LOVED the farro risotto, speckled with pumpkin seeds and currants and topped with roasted squash - such a playful dance of salty, sweet and savory; creamy, chewy and crunchy.  it's pretty rich and can become a bit tiresome halfway thru the dish (too much of a good thing?) but oh so satisfying.  and the chickpea fries that everyone raves about - YUM. like fried rectangles of hummus.  deceptive in appearance, as they're dipped in some powder (chickpea flour?) that makes them look like cinnamon sugar donuts, but they're definitely not sweet.  but the service was the icing on the cake.  on top of the luxurious atmosphere and delicious food, our gracious, humorous and knowledgable server completed the experience.  i wish i had goten his name - our server was the pale-haired bespectacled man with an accent (?) or perhaps just an affected way of speaking, but nonetheless, he was so incredibly well-versed in the menu offerings and eloquent in his descriptions that it was hard do resist anything he recommended (which of course, was always delightful).  thank goodness he\'s not a car salesman, he'd be making bank commission!  i'd come back again only to sit at his table =)
author: Jen P.

description: There is a scene from a certain HBO series where the girl says to her date that the restaurant they are in makes her feel like she has stumbled upon a Republican nest...This is that place. I looked around me and saw a lot of 'well preserved' old, rich ladies and their husbands who were choking down their foie gras and nodding their heads to the witless banter. That would have been fine...always entertaining to watch the dining dead and realize that someday THIS COULD BE YOU! The thing that pissed me and my husband off was the waiter. (Usually the thing, along with food quality of course, that makes it or breaks it for me and a restaurant.)  He wouldn't even LOOK at me when it came time to order, didn't let us know the evening specials (heard it recited to other tables), hurried off without MY drink order, was very inattentive throughout the entire meal, AND had ZERO personality and never cracked a smile. It was really weird actually. We spent close to two hundred without dessert and vowed never to return. Here is the part that I have noticed in far too many upscale restaurants as of late and it is the part that gets the stars...Our busser was awesome. He checked on us and smiled and spoke to BOTH of us and made sure we had our drinks and bread and happiness and love. Why was this poor guy busing and not the one receiving our far too generous tip? He rocked. The waiter sucked. Won't be back and won't recommend. Oh...very important: the food. COLD. I wasn't brave enough to ask the android to take it back and see that is was served ... uh...warm? It was lamb and it was shivering.
author: Kris K.

description: The atmosphere was very loud and full of business suits who are mainly wine drinkers.  It was very hard to have an intimate conversation due to the loudness.  It seemed very busy for a Monday night.  We waited a long time for bread and the oysters were not shucked properly nor did they taste that great.  We both had the cauliflower soup that had scallops, parsley, and Asian pears.  This was delicious, the best soup we have ever eaten.  I had the pan seared scallops which were cooked perfectly, but there was a chocolate sauce that I could do without  My plate had fritters on it that were good, but I do not know what kind of meat was in it.  My husband had the bacon wrapped pork tenderloin which was cooked perfectly and seasoned very well.  The spinach on the plate was too dark of a taste, the apples were very sweet, and the unknown vegetable was delicious.  The sides we had were corn grits with jalapeno cheese which was delightful, with a small kick, and roasted brussel sprouts with applewood bacon, which was perfectly cooked and bold.  I normally do not like brussel sprouts, but this was delicious and I would go back to this place just ot have them.  This is not recommended for a romantic atmosphere or a first date or if you have children.  The price for the two of us was about $140 with tip.
author: CHERRYL H.

description: I suppose at one time this restaraunt was in the rotation of the hottest places to dine in the city.  I would venture to say that torch has been passed to better restaraunts.  Bar service was great.  Friendly bartender with gorgeous smile kept all of the customers consumed with libations.  When we moved into the dining room for dinner, the experience diminished a bit.  First of all, the hostess was just plain rude.  There were a group of older people, probably tourists or maybe just Bridge/Tunnel folk that were carried away with being there and not moving to the table quick enough for her.  I couldn't count how many times she rolled her eyes and scowled at them.  I ordered the Thursday special, which was the Filet.  Dawned on me after the fact that the server never asked me how I wanted the steak to be cooked.  So when he brought out the raw bloody piece of meat, I immediately requested that the steak be sent back.  The hostess, or maybe she was the manager gave me one of her infamous scowls and made a smart ass comment.  Like it was my fault.  My friend's dish was also forgettable.  We ordered the dessert trio, which was perfect, but we agreed that the rest of the dining experience left a bitter taste in our mouth.  Maybe she was having a bad night, but that doesn't excuse rude behavior.  And it makes me less likely to shell out $60 for a dinner there anytime soon!
author: Amy Z.

description:
one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  the majority of the time, the food is excellent.  however, my favorite dish--the foie gras--was less than spectacular the last time i went.  i'm not going to dock them a star though because I order this dish every time i go there and it's almost always superb.  of all the various restaurants i've been to around the world, one market has the best foie gras.

another great dish is their pea soup (which i normally hate).  the tasting menu is a great way to start if it's your first time there.  that's what i did and it allowed to taste so many important dishes on their regular menu.

i also like the fact that it's a "fancy" restaurant with a michelin star, but it isn't pretentious or stuff (like places like michael mina, aqua, etc.).  the view is great because you are sitting across from the ferry building and you have the line of beautiful palm trees right across the street.

i've taken a few people to one market for their bdays and every time i've used open table to make a reservation and noted it was someone's bday, they would bring out a free dessert with a candle at the end of the meal.
author: Jay M.

description: Horrible. We went there for thanksgiving dinner- Terrible service, boring food more suited to Shoney's than a michelin star restaurant. And the decor is 80's hotel bar. The manager is rude- I definitely I won't go back- there are too many good restaurants to try. And did I mention the food was lame? really disappointing.
author: s b.

description: I think this place is nice, but doesn't really deserve the 1 michelin star as the food is above average but doesn't compare to other restaurants with 1 star.
author: Adie B.

description: Had dinner last night for my friend and I's 5 year anniversary from work with my boss and our significant others. Food excellent! Service? - ummm....wow! How can I say this politely? - can't. If you go, please be aware...this was my first time and I'm hoping that if I do go back I do not get Jo'phine...really bad...c'mon 3 hour dinner for 3 courses. I would understand a 3 hour dinner with 8 courses, but 3?! 30 minutes just to get drinks, 30 minutes for appetizers, 30 minutes for dinners (figure - we consumed our dinner in about 30 minutes), 20 minutes for the dishes to be cleared (our plates were empty just in case you were wondering), 20 minutes to bring out dessert. To her credit, she did pick up the bill pretty quick. Service is a big part of the experience when your dinning at a restaurant that charges the way they do! 3 Stars for the food...Zero for the service...btw...it's not like we could have complained, we didn't want our food to come back with a little extra if you get my drift. Sorry one more thing Jo'phine - we could not understand you all night when you did remember to check on us!!!!
author: Benjamin L.

description: this place seems to fly low under the radar and yet is a solid rock of good american food! although I have had rocky moments over the last year a recent dine out there proved that you can pull it all back together. great wine list casual but elegant good waitstaff! and of course consistent great food. the halibut was amazing.
author: Ricote F.

description:
We wanted to host a small vegetarian wedding reception so at first we booked Millennium. But when our party grew over 30, we had to search elsewhere for a place that would be willing to fit 40 people and serve a vegetarian only private menu. We ate out for 2 weeks straight to find the right place. Absinthe had a great private room but was unwilling to do an all vegetarian menu, Fifth Floor was one of our favorites but couldn't fit 40 people, Campton Place had an excellent Chef who was willing to custom made dishes for us but was out of our price range. 

One Market turned out to be just perfect in every way. I did not consider it at first because I used to work in that building and thought of it as a corporate restaurant and the photos of the private rooms did not impress me too much. But when I stopped by to check out the rooms, we met Michael, the General Manager who could not be friendlier. The rooms also have a very soft lighting with a nice glow which did not come through the photos. We decided to schedule a tasting and Chef Mark went out of his way to let us sample all kinds of custom vegetarian dishes. We ended up going with the Yukon Gold Potato Soup, Heirloom Tomato Salad, Wild Mushroom Risotto, and Valrhona Manjari Souffle Cake. Everyone loved the food here including all of our non-vegetarian guests. My aunt didn't even realize we had an all vegetarian menu until I told her the next day.  They also took extra care of my sister in-law who is deathly allergic to nuts. But what impressed us the most about this place is its unparalleled service. Beth and Rita were both extremely accommodating and went above and beyond to help us out. We booked this place only 5 days before the event and with such short notice, they were able to help us tie all the loose ends. My aunt brought a bunch of random stuff that she wanted to be displayed (pebbles, lights, frames, etc) and they set it up beautifully. They also gave us extra candles and setup small reception area that turned out perfect for the event. 

My only suggestion is to ask for larger portions. For four courses it was just enough for me but for my husband and brother, they got hungry a few hours later. I guess vegetarian food might not be as filling as some of their other dishes.
author: Ester C.

description: i have eaten here at least a dozen times.  no i never paid to eat here --it was always a business lunch or dinner and thank goodness for that.  the food will not have you come back for more.  the wine list pedestrian.  we are in the heartland of America's viticulture.  i struggle... struggle to find a glass of wine!  this is a restaurant for business and the sport jacket set--the suburban set.  the interior could not be more uptight and dull.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: This place is close to my office building so we end up taking campus recruits here quite a bit to mix and mingle.  The menu items change periodically, but everything I tried has been really good.  It's good that I'm dining on the company's tab because being the cheap person I am, I would never go there for lunch otherwise.  I really liked the fresh vegetable garden salad, which had blanched carrots (red, organge, and yellow) and asparagus, topped with a tangy vinagrette dressing.  I've also tried the mahi mahi and another grilled fish dish, as well as the crab cakes -- all great flavors.  The crab cakes were really good, except for the cilantro.  I hate cilantro!  Why must people use it like it's going out of style?  Others enjoyed their gigantic burger and skin-on fries.   The rolls and butter were tasty...maybe too tasty because I couldn't stop eating them.  The best part was the dessert and since we go in large groups, we shared.  I tried the rhubarb pie (which was a first for me) and that was very good and I also had the lemon vanilla bean cheesecake which was probably the best lemon dessert I've ever had.  Others enjoyed the creme brulee, but I didn't get to it.  The white wine was excellent and the servers were friendly and very knowledgeable.  They also have this thing called the Chef's Table where for $85/person, you and 3-4 of your friends can go to a bar next to the kitchen and watch the chefs prepare a tasting menu, and where everyone also puts on cooking attire and assists in preparing the dish.  The price is a bit expensive for me, but I do want to try it one day.  Any takers?
author: LaSha G.

description: I guess because of its location very close to my office, I pretty much overlook One Market as a dinner destination.  However, I have had lunch here a few times and been to several happy hours as well.  As far as the food goes... pretty much everything I've had is decent, without being memorable.  I typically get the burger, which is always prepared right.  The big fries are a great accompaniment.  The Caesar salad is pretty good too.  I also like the fact that they have a good selection of non-alcoholic drinks, including a variety of lemonades... which are a nice option during work hours.   The service is usually pretty decent, but sometimes a little on the slow side.  I sat at the Chef's Table once for lunch and was not impressed.  The table was very pretty uncomfortable and not especially nice.  I definitely wouldn't intentionally try to eat there.  The happy hour is a pretty good deal and worth checking out if you're in the area.  However, it's frequently super-packed and waitress service takes forever so I'd recommend going to the bar to get drinks.  Certain apps like the crab cakes and satays are decent, but I avoid the sweetish buffalo wings like the plague.  They're pretty much inedible.
author: Saw T.

description: this place is easy to get to for the people in the financial district.  the food is just so-so and the service is really slow.  you don't get what you paid for.
author: Gina T.

description: bear with me as i try and remember what i ate here.  i will have to visit again to see if it is still 5 stars to me.  i remember i got skatewing.  it was the first time i tried it and it came with whole mustard and some kind of sauce.  the texture was just perfect.  i also got risotto, maybe with duck?  again, perfect and so savory, but not overly salty.  for dessert i remember profiteroles, which were made into little ice cream sandwiches.  i put one market in my top 3 of sf restaurants with town hall and quince.
author: Robert S.

description:
Hm. Wish I could give 3 1/2 stars. Here's the super-condensed version of my review: Fabulous food, almost perfect atmosphere but service needs improvement.

I went to One Market with my boyfriend two Fridays ago on the last night of the Open Table Appetite Stimulus Plan. Yes, it was crowded, but the service simply wasn't up to fine dining standards. First, we could hardly get the attention of anyone at the host station when we arrived. Then the hostess herself seemed irritated that we'd had the nerve to show up at her restaurant wanting service and food. She was unfriendly and unhelpful to the point of being unprofessional. Then the got our reservation wrong. I made a 7:15 reservation on Open Table but they'd had us down for 7 pm and, as we had arrived at approximately 7:18, they had evidently JUST given our table away when we arrived. I refrained from showing her the email confirmation I had in my BlackBerry saying 7:15, as I didn't see it getting our table any sooner. Once seated at our table, thankfully, our waiter was pretty attentive and friendly enough. But the little details that make it a fine dining experience weren't there: wiping up the crumbs between dishes, knowing exactly when to take away your dishes (we'd had our dessert about 5 minutes and it was mostly still on the plate when some overzealous busboy came around to take it away). Plus there was a little plastic tent on the table about buying gingerbread cookies for some charity -- not something I want to see while I'm having a nice dinner out.

However, the food was really excellent and the restaurant is beautiful, so I'm giving it 4 stars. I might go there again, but I'm more likely to take my dollars to Foreign Cinema or Boulevard, where I can count on service to match the prices.
author: Allison B.

description: I like there $72 dollar of steak for two. I and my female friend often go there for that course. It is three course diner for two. I dont know if they still have that available today. But I also like their chef's six small portion dinner for $75. Depending on the season, they sometimes have some free sample dish for tasting. I went there for at least 5 times. I give a four stars because I think the restaurant can still do better job.
author: CC C.

description: I took my father-in-law to One Market fore dinner on Friday, knowing that he's a hard man to please service-wise.  They were delightful!  The manager, Michael, gave us such special attention that we felt like royalty for the night, including a full tour of their amazing kitchen.  I have no problem with spending this kind of money (and it did add up... to around $150/ person... but only with much wine and a above average tip) if it feels like a true experience.  Too many restaurants in this town leave you with the "well, for $500, frankly, it SHOULD be amazing" feeling.  One Market truly felt like an "event" more than a dinner, and for that I gave them all five of the little red stars.  Food wise... good.  Above average.  I'm a little tired of the French/ California thing, but I've been eating out too much, so that's not their fault.  If I never see another huckleberry sauce, sunchoke, or pork belly that will be just fine, let's put it that way!  But it was good.  And the wines were great.  Really, it was the service that set them apart for me- there's so much good food in SF that service is often the deciding factor.  So, thanks Michael!  Good job, FOH staff!
author: Jennifer P.

description: I had the misfortune of going to dinner here recently on the recommendation that One Market was given a Michelin Star. I thought that was rather shocking for a chain restaurant, but decided to see for myself. Having tried many Michelin rated restaurants and foodie, I consider myself to have a palate that is up to par. This restaurant was a disgrace, i might as well have gone to Olive Garden or some other chain. Heck, Olive Garden is even better than this shameful establishment. I have been to their other restaurants that belong to this group and they are 10x better than this. I would love to know who is in charge of the Michelin rating group this year, as I imagine it must be a baboon or someone that was bribed easily. Don't ever spend your money here, unless you want uncooked beans and tasteless fish. If you enjoy this place, I have to admit........I feel sorry for you!
author: ana m.

description: went here earlier this year for the dine about town deal.  i thought the food was good.  it's conveniently located in downtown.  would i go back?  maybe for the chef's table.  i hear that's supposed to be good.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
i love the location of one market - right by the bay, off the embarcadero. the romantic feel of it all won me over. it was great timing that i had bumped into a friend who was working at the restaurant and she was able to suggest a variety of things to try. i had a special - which were scallops, and they were delicious. I looked at the tiny helping on my plate and didnt think i was going to get full. and i was right. but that usually comes with places like this. however my boyfriend had lamb and he fully enjoyed it. didn't get to have dessert because we ran out of time, maybe next time. 

crowd is not for the young. just the wanna be yuppy group. but i can see how ideal it is for business meals or older couples who want to enjoy a nice dinner with conversation.
author: L B.

description: Their Dine-About-Town menu definitely was subpar. As if they asked their chefs to see what they could do with food that costs less than $2 per plate. And the kicker: a two hour stomache after the meal.
author: Maura G.

description: i like the small 3 course american menu, i really like how much foie gras torchon they put on the foie gras salad.  i had some delicious ox tails here once.  the wine menu is relatively extensive for an american bistro kinda spot.  its pretty an informal restaurant, with a seperated bar that is clearly for afterwork idiots. if you never been, you should, but definately be seated and avoid the lame-asses in the bar.
author: christopher a.

description: came here for dine about town and it was great!  the staff was very nice for such a busy time of night and the food was fresh and tasty.  you get alot for what you paid for, especially that alot of the participating restaurants don't include dessert.  so this was great!
author: Food Is L.

description: did the dine about town thing here was very impressed (ended up not ordering off the dine about town menu but oh well). great location at the end of market and the food was fabuloso!
author: Patrick D.

description: I tried their cocoa rubbed liberty farms duck breasts, and it was so good. The crab salad is refreshing and a good starter. The desserts are also good but i was too full to have dessert.
author: sofie W.

description: I came here for DAT and was thrilled with the experience.  I had been to One Market once several years ago and had a memorably unpleasant encounter with a soft-shelled crab, but it was certainly worth a re-visit.  The menu for DAT was great--they had many tempting choices available.  I had the ceasar salad, which was rich and pungent, but in a decadent way.  Then I had the scallops with pureed potatoes and mushrooms which I thought was heavenly, but another diner complained was too rich.  Assess your tolerance for rich food, if you're a light eater you may be overwhelmed.  If you, like me, think the flavor's in the fat, you will be a happy camper here.  For dessert we had the beignets with white hot chocolate.  The beignets were awesome, but the white hot chocolate had cooled off and was only good for a few spoonfuls.  That was fine with me, though, because after all the preceeding food I needed to take it easy with dessert. It was a great meal and a great vlaue, and I know we'll be back for more after DAT.
author: Eleanor E.

description:
Bar for happy hour: 4 stars
Crowd: after-work professionals (late 20's-early 40's) looking for $5 cocktails and yummy bar food. I like this place b/c they have great cocktails and big glasses of wine. The only downside is if you have to stand... not a lot of room at the bar, so it can be awkward. Also, come with a friend or group... people don't seem to mingle here.

Restaurant: 4.5 stars (Dine About Town)
I went here last Wed. with two friends... We first ordered the House-Made Duck Ravioli (not on the Dine About Town menu). This was amazing! There was just the right amount of duck in the ravioli, and the foie gras emulsion was a perfect match. We then got the Caesar Salad for our first dish. Great dressing, just too bad they drenched the lettuce in it. Also, the salad was too big, so by the time we got to our main course of the amazingly tasting Seared Day Boat Scallops, we each left one on our plates. For dessert I got the Pear Brown Butter Tart (although, more like a puff pastry than a tart) with vanilla bean ice cream and my friends got these chocolate fritters with a cup of what seemed like hot chocolate w/ Jager. Both were amazing. So overall, great food. Just need work on the salad. Our server said it was his second night, but we never would have guessed. Great service. The ambiance was great and noise level good, although we got to sit in a booth on the upper level. Not sure if I'd like a table in the middle of the main floor.
author: Sarah K.

description: Fabulous fabulous fabulous. I have always wanted to try One Market and what perfect way than Dine about town. My wifeand friend joined me for dinner last Friday night at 8pm....We came a little early due to the rain and they sat us right away. The service was extremely impeccable. Really, a great job with making us feel at home. We went for the dine about town and were treated remarkably. We have had some *lemons* lately with the dine about town- some disgruntle waiters who fear their tip may be cut- but this server and his team were just great. The options were exceptional as well....I am going to take my assistant there for lunch tomorrow to try their lunch dine about town- I hope its as fabulous as dinners!
author: David B.

description: Had lunch here.  service was good, but not great.  the food was not bad, but not memorable.  a nice fancy restaurant if you want to impress someone, but not as good as I had expected.
author: Chris F.

description: I'm giving a 4 star rating thinking about places like French Laundry as 5 star.  I had dinner at One Market on June 13.  I am VEGETARIAN and greatly appreciative when a chef puts real culinary skill into creating a vegetarian dish.   The Chef at One Market did that.  He created a terrine of mushroom and fingerling potato that was incredibly flavorful, varied in texture, elegant to see, and in every way enjoyable.   Service was attentive and good with one error when a bus person started to clear dishes while one of us was still taking the last few bites.  Good wine list with affordable whites not restricted to Chardonnay and S. Blanc.     Enjoy!
author: Pepperminsky R.

description: One star is a bit harsh, cause it is better than that, but not when you consider this spot got one Michelin, which means it should be great. We got an expensive tasting menu which I would rather of not tasted. Tiny portions, burnt consumme, uninspired combinations, and uber-sweet desserts and I left hungry, broke, and disillusioned.
author: Jesse K.

description: Had a great meal there last night -- beet carpacio, halibut and the desserts were all excellent.  A classic place that continues to shine.
author: laurel t.

description: upscale. heavy on the meat side. impeccable service.  lots of suits in the place.  has a bar and a big dining room.  can't go wrong if you're looking for this kind of restaurant. i think i prefer boulevard though.
author: Yelper S.
